site_title: India can boost investments, hit borrowing targets: report
summary: India's finance ministry report suggests the country can increase public investments while meeting its borrowing targets. The report also indicates the government will stick to its debt targets, aiming to lower the fiscal deficit to 3% of GDP. This suggests Finance Minister Arun Jaitley will maintain the debt targets in his maiden full-year budget on Saturday.

site_title: SGX names Tan Boon Gin as new chief regulatory officer, effective June 15
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has appointed Tan Boon Gin as its new Chief Regulatory Officer, effective June 15. He replaces Richard Teng and will oversee regulatory affairs. Tan previously worked as a Deputy Public Prosecutor and a Justice's Law Clerk at the Singapore Supreme Court. Yeo Lian Sim will serve as interim Chief Regulatory Officer until June 14.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks remained flat in early trading on Friday, with the benchmark Hang Seng Index slipping 14.91 points to 24,887.15. The decline came after the dollar firmed against major currencies on US inflation data.

site_title: CIMB reports 81% drop in profit on provisions for bad loans
summary: CIMB Group Holdings, Malaysia's second-largest bank, reported an 81% drop in profit for the first quarter of 2015 due to provisions for bad loans, with net income declining to 200.3 million ringgit (US$56 million). The bank signaled a focus on controlling costs, citing softer growth prospects for emerging markets. CIMB plans to cut 50 equities-related jobs and close its Australian offices to reduce costs by 30% this year. Shares have fallen 16% over the past year, amid tougher regulations and higher capital requirements affecting financial companies globally.

site_title: Dymon Asia's US$3b macro hedge fund lost 10.45% in Jan: data
summary: Dymon Asia's US$3.1 billion macro hedge fund lost 10.45% in January, according to performance data seen by Reuters. The decline was attributed to a surprise rise in the Swiss franc, which negatively impacted several macro hedge funds. The fund's 2014 return of 18.75% was wiped out, as macro hedge funds gained just 4% on average last year. Dymon Asia President Jay Luo declined to comment on the exact reason for the loss.

site_title: Singapore: Stocks end lower to close the week; Noble's figures, SGX CEO in focus
summary: Singapore stocks ended the week lower, closing 1% down, as investors digested the surprise announcement of SGX CEO Magnus Bocker's non-renewal of his contract. Noble Group's ongoing dispute with short-seller Iceberg Research also weighed on the market. The Straits Times Index fell 23.32 points to 3,402.86, with a net 165 rises versus 270 falls. The week's trading was characterized by prices being trapped within narrow bands, with no fresh leads to drive the market.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks hit fresh 15-year high
summary: Tokyo stocks reached a 15-year high, closing at 18,797.94, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.06% and the Topix index advancing 0.14%. Despite profit-taking and a decline in Japan's inflation, the market surged due to a weak yen making Japanese exporters more competitive. Yamaha and Sony rose 1.96% and 2.03%, respectively, while the US dollar firmed against the yen ahead of potential interest rate hikes.

site_title: Hong Kong's ageing master tailors need a stitch in time
summary: Hong Kong's bespoke tailoring industry is in danger of dying out due to underinvestment and competition from low-cost centers like mainland China. The industry's reputation for quality and speedy delivery has been eroded, and the profession doesn't pay well, deterring young people from entering. The government has pledged HK$500 million to promote local designers and brands, but master tailors are left to fend for themselves. Despite a shortage of skilled tailors, demand remains robust, and some tailors have thrived through canny marketing and high-end clients, leading to a possible revival of the industry through increased prices and supply and demand adjustments.

images.alt_text: Bill Clinton did it. So did Boris Johnson, the mayor of London. For many tourists, even if they are not former US presidents, a trip to Hong Kong isn't over till they pick up a made-to-measure outfit from one of its family-run tailor shops.

site_title: Seoul: Shares snap 7-day winning run, but up for 2nd month
summary: Seoul shares ended a seven-session winning streak, snapping a 0.37% decline to 1,985.80 points, after heavyweights such as Hyundai Motor fell. Despite the decline, the KOSPI still posted a 1.9% gain for the month. The won ended slightly lower at 1,098.4 per dollar after a light trading session.

site_title: US consumer sentiment slides from 11-year peak in February
summary: US consumer sentiment fell from an 11-year high in February, according to a survey, with the final index reading 95.4. This marks a decline from January's reading of 98.1 and surpasses the market forecast of 94.0. The decline may signal a shift in consumer confidence, potentially impacting economic growth.

site_title: Free access to more data on SingStat website from March 1
summary: The Department of Statistics Singapore announced that 12,000 statistical data series will be made available for free on its website starting March 1, 2015. This move aims to encourage research, informed decision-making, and the creation of new solutions. The data series cover topics such as population and economy, and can be customized, viewed in chart form, and downloaded in various formats. The free access is part of the government's plan to make more data available to the public as part of its goal to build Singapore into a smart nation.

site_title: Asian cross-border funds on the way
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore and six other Asian countries have released a joint consultation paper on the proposed Asia Region Funds Passport (ARFP) rules. The rules, set to be finalized in 2016, will allow fund managers to offer products to investors in other member economies, streamlining regulatory processes and deepening regional financial markets. Key requirements include at least 5 years of experience and $500 million in assets under management. The ARFP aims to increase liquidity and access to finance, providing an additional route for investors to invest in the region's debt and equity markets.

site_title: Tax plight: The 5 per cent call an emergency meeting
summary: A group of high-income earners, known as the Society of Embattled High Income-Earners, held an emergency meeting to discuss the impending tax hike. Despite initial confusion over membership status, the group decided to lobby instead to perform "Charitable Acts in Lieu of Higher Taxes." These acts include flying economy class, eating at hawker centers, and using ATMs in specific situations to qualify for tax rebates. The group ultimately decided to pay the tax, citing the "Principle of the Thing."

site_title: Train delays along MRT North-South line after track intrusions
summary: A person intruded onto the MRT tracks between Bukit Gombak and Yew Tee stations in Singapore, causing delays and halting services on the North-South line around 9pm on Friday. The incident led to disruptions between the two stations. An SMRT spokesman attributed the delay to a "track intrusion". The incident is currently under investigation.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: US President Donald Trump's proposed 50% copper import tariff is expected to cover refined metal, impacting global markets. Oil prices rose over 2% amid concerns about market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. European stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector losses, with the US-EU trade tensions in focus. The US stock market edged down from record levels amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Kannan Ramesh appointed Judicial Commissioner of High Court
summary: Kannan Ramesh has been appointed as a Judicial Commissioner of the High Court for a two-year term, starting May 22, 2015. He was appointed by President Tony Tan Keng Yam in concurrence with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. Ramesh specializes in dispute resolution and international arbitration, and is the managing partner of Tan Kok Quan Partnership. This appointment brings the total number of judges in the Supreme Court to 13, including the Chief Justice.

site_title: China PMI shows factory activity shrank again in February
summary: China's factory sector activity contracted for a second consecutive month in February, with the official Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 49.9, below the 50-point growth threshold. The services sector showed growth, however, with a PMI of 53.9. The contraction was attributed to the Lunar New Year holiday, which affected factory data. China's central bank cut interest rates in response to slowing growth and rising deflationary risk, marking the second easing move in four weeks.

site_title: Otto Marine sinks to net loss of US$41.7m for 2014
summary: Otto Marine reported a net loss of US$41.66 million for the 2014 fiscal year, down from a net profit of US$14.08 million in the previous year. Revenue declined 30.5% to US$355.9 million, primarily due to decreased external revenue from the shipyard, offshore chartering, leasing, and geophysical segments.

site_title: China to raise retail price of gasoline and diesel
summary: China will raise retail prices for gasoline by 390 yuan (US$62) per tonne and diesel by 375 yuan (US$60) per tonne starting Saturday, following a second consecutive price increase by the National Development and Reform Commission. The pricing system, which links fuel prices to global crude oil, aims to ensure a closer connection to the market. The price hikes come as oil prices move off lows from last month, and the decision is the second consecutive increase by the commission.

images.alt_text: China will raise retail prices for gasoline by 390 yuan (US$62) per tonne and for diesel by 375 yuan (US$60) per tonne from Saturday as oil prices moved off lows plumbed last month, the country's powerful economic planning agency said on Friday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close lower on Friday, flat for week
summary: Hong Kong shares closed lower on Friday, ending a week on a flat note, as investors awaited clearer signals on China's monetary policy and industrial growth. The Hang Seng index fell 0.3% to 24,823.29, while the China Enterprises Index lost 0.3% to 12,185.85 points. For the month, the index gained 1.5%, underperforming the Shanghai Composite Index, which rose over 4%. The decline followed a boost in financials after 23 Zhejiang banks were allowed to cut their reserve ratios requirement by 50 basis points.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas swings to US$2.02b loss in Q4
summary: Malaysia's state-owned energy firm Petronas reported a net loss of 7.3 billion ringgit (S$2.75 billion) in Q4 2014 due to declining global oil prices and asset impairment losses. Revenue dropped 6.4% to 79.4 billion ringgit, and the company plans capital spending cuts of 20-30 billion ringgit for the next two years. Petronas expects average oil prices to hover around $55 a barrel for 2015, hurting profitability. The company's net profit for the 12-month period fell 27% to 47.6 billion ringgit.

site_title: Australian PM Abbott bats away leadership speculation
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott dismissed speculation about his leadership, saying he expects to lead his party to the next election. After a leadership challenge earlier this month, Abbott survived with 61 votes in favor of a leadership contest, and no challenger emerged. Speculation is mounting that colleagues will turn against Abbott before the next election, which must be held by mid-January 2017, with some ministers believing Communications Minister Malcolm Turnbull has the numbers to win a challenge. Abbott remains focused on the job of government, stating he won't be distracted by speculation.

site_title: US: Stocks little changed after Q4 growth downgrade
summary: US stocks fell slightly in opening trade on Friday after a downward revision to fourth-quarter US economic growth, which was revised to 2.2% from the initial estimate of 2.6%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.09% to 18,198.65, while the S&P 500 lost 0.01% to 2,110.44. The Nasdaq Composite Index declined 0.03% to 4,986.50. The revision was less severe than expected, with economists suggesting the trend may be around 3% growth.

site_title: India growth to top 8% in 2015/16: government
summary: India's economy is forecast to grow by 8.1-8.5% in the 2015/16 financial year, surpassing the 7.4% growth for the current year. The upbeat forecast comes after the government revised its GDP calculation method, making India one of the world's fastest-growing economies. Consumer inflation is expected to moderate to 5-5.5% in 2015/16, raising hopes for monetary policy easing. The forecast aligns with Prime Minister Narendra Modi's promise to reform and revive the economy, with investors eagerly awaiting specifics in the upcoming budget.

site_title: Straits Trading profit nearly trebles for Q4 2014
summary: Straits Trading's net profit nearly tripled to S$36.98 million in Q4 2014, driven by a 53.9% increase in revenue to S$209.11 million. However, the full-year net profit fell 84.4% to S$18.59 million, compared to FY2013's S$119.50 million.

site_title: Taiwan: Markets closed
summary: Taiwan's financial markets are closed on Friday for a public holiday. In the US, stocks edged down from record highs amid tariff threats, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records. In Europe, mining and healthcare stocks boosted shares, with US-EU trade talks in focus. Asia's stocks rally extended despite new Trump threats, with Singapore stocks posting a 5-day gain ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Indonesian rupiah hits 17-year low after central bank inflation forecasts
summary: Indonesia's rupiah hit a 17-year low against the US dollar, falling 0.8% to 12,935 per dollar, after Bank Indonesia Governor Agus Martowardojo forecast a decrease in inflation to below 6.5% in February. This eased chances for further interest rate cuts. The rupiah has lost 4.3% against the dollar so far this year, making it the worst performing emerging Asian currency. The news followed a surprise reduction in interest rates earlier this month.

site_title: Indonesia central bank comfortable with weakening rupiah, says helps exports
summary: Indonesia's central bank is comfortable with the weakening of the rupiah, which has fallen almost 4% in the year, making exports more competitive in Southeast Asia. The bank's deputy governor, Mirza Adityaswara, stated that a competitive exchange rate is needed to support exports and reduce non-productive imports. The government and central bank have focused on improving domestic economic conditions, with Chief Economics Minister Sofyan Djalil saying there's no need to defend the weak currency with foreign exchange reserves. This move is seen as a positive step for the country's exports.

site_title: Malaysia willing to work with Singapore on regional oil pricing
summary: Malaysia is willing to collaborate with Singapore to establish a regional oil pricing area, including offering land for storage facilities. Malaysia lacks sufficient storage and refineries to act as a pricing hub like Singapore, and is building the Pengerang Integrated Petroleum Complex to remedy this. The first phase of the project is expected to be completed by 2019. A commodity price reporting agency, Platts, is actively studying the potential for a regional pricing area, including a FOB Straits price that would involve Johor, Malaysia.

site_title: Japan inflation at new low since war on falling prices began
summary: Japan's inflation rate has dropped to its lowest level since 2013, challenging Bank of Japan chief Haruhiko Kuroda's claims of rising inflation. The data may worsen doubts about the government's efforts to boost the economy, which has been stagnant for two decades. The low inflation rate may also impact company expansion plans and the economy's growth prospects.

site_title: Malaysia fund's debts make defending ringgit tougher
summary: Malaysia's currency, the ringgit, faces significant challenges as the country struggles with a high debt burden and sliding oil prices. The cost of options protecting against ringgit declines reached a 1 1/2-year high, and the currency is at its weakest level since 2009. A bailout for 1Malaysia Development, the state investment fund, is needed to service debt, but the government has rejected the proposal. The ringgit's value is vulnerable to oil price fluctuations and has fallen 7.4% in the past three months, making it difficult for the country to repay foreign borrowings and achieve its economic targets.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open lower, Noble tumbles on resumption
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index down 4.10 points to 3,422.08. This follows a decline in oil prices, affecting oil-linked equities on the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500. Noble Group was the most active stock, with 127.2 million shares changing hands worth S$219.9 million.

site_title: Japan environment minister latest to deny illegal funding
summary: Japan's Environment Minister Yoshio Mochizuki denied wrongdoing after a newspaper reported his office received improper funds, the latest scandal to hit Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government. Mochizuki collected 1.4 million yen from a logistics company that had received government subsidies, violating a law banning political donations within a year of receiving subsidies. He returned the funds, citing morality, and top government spokesman Yoshihide Suga defended the minister's actions, saying he returned the funds immediately after discovering the possible conflict. This is the third minister to quit over funding and election scandals since Abe took office in 2012.

site_title: Malaysia fund's debts make defending ringgit tougher
summary: Malaysia's currency, the ringgit, faces significant challenges as the country struggles to defend its value amid high debt levels and a decline in oil prices. The cost of options protecting against ringgit declines reached a 1 1/2-year high, and the currency has tumbled 7% in the past three months, reaching a six-year low. The government's efforts to rein in its budget deficit are being hindered by investor exodus and a weaker currency, which makes it more expensive for the country to repay foreign borrowings. Experts predict a further decline in the ringgit, with some forecasting a 5% tumble to 3.76 by year-end.

site_title: Vard's Q4 profit, revenue rise on high activity at its yards and with subcontractors
summary: Vard Holdings reported a 36.3% increase in Q4 net profit to 154 million Norwegian kroner, driven by high activity at its yards and subcontractors. Revenue rose 45.5% to 4.5 billion kroner. Full-year net profit dipped 2.2% to 349 million kroner due to higher operational expenses. The company expects weak new order intake for 2015 due to the oil price decline, but its existing order book ensures revenue coverage. A cost improvement programme aims to boost flexibility and reduce costs to strengthen Vard's position in the competitive market.

site_title: Greek economy contracts more than first thought: official data
summary: Greek economy contracted by 0.4% in the fourth quarter of 2014, contrary to the initial estimate of 0.2%. The revised figure, released by the state statistics agency, suggests a more significant decline than initially thought. This revised data may have implications for the country's economic recovery and fiscal management.

site_title: BoE turns up the heat on accountants for banks
summary: The Bank of England's Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) has issued a consultation requiring "Big Four" accounting firms to provide written reports to the central bank on audits of Britain's main lenders starting from November 2016. The move aims to improve the accuracy of external audits and address concerns over the accuracy of audits during the 2007-09 financial crisis. The PRA will use these reports to monitor the quality of auditor-supervisor dialogue and take disciplinary action if necessary, increasing accountability for banks' accounting practices.

site_title: Average development charges cut 3% for non-landed residential use, but raised 2% for commercial use
summary: Singapore's development charge (DC) rates have been adjusted for the period March 1 to August 31. Non-landed residential use DC rates were reduced by 3% on average, while commercial use rates were increased by 2% on average. Landed residential, industrial, and certain other use groups' DC rates remained unchanged. The Ministry of National Development revises DC rates twice a year in consultation with the Chief Valuer.

images.alt_text: DEVELOPMENT charge (DC) rates - payable for enhancing the use of some sites or to build bigger projects on them - have been reduced by 3 per cent on average for non-landed residential use for the period March 1 to Aug 31.

site_title: China takes hard line on taxing foreigners on share gains: sources
summary: China's tax authorities have proposed a 10% capital-gains tax on foreign investors' share trading profits, applicable to investors in the Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor (QFII) and renminbi-denominated QFII programs between 2009 and 2014. This plan would result in investors potentially facing a tax bill of up to $4 billion, as they had set aside profits without accounting for losses. The tax applies retrospectively, and investors are likely to experience a wave of net asset value clawbacks and redemptions from QFII funds.

images.alt_text: China's tax authorities have alarmed foreign investors with a proposed capital-gains tax which would take 10 per cent of their share trading profits without taking into account any of their trading losses, according to sources briefed by tax officials.

site_title: Sunningdale Tech's Q4 profit up, outlook stable
summary: Sunningdale Tech reported a net profit of S$11.16 million for Q4 2014, up from S$4.02 million a year ago. Excluding provisional negative goodwill, the net profit would be S$8.3 million. Revenue rose 10.9% to S$134.99 million. Full-year net profit was S$27.68 million. The company expects business segments to remain stable in 2015. A final dividend of 0.8 cent per share was declared.

site_title: Hong Kong unveils fresh steps to cool property market
summary: Hong Kong has introduced new measures to cool its property market, reducing the amount of money home buyers can borrow to 60% of the property's value from 70%. The debt servicing ratio for second-home buyers will also be lowered to 40% from 50%. These measures come as home prices reached a record high last year, driven by strong local demand and tight supply. The move aims to curb the market's growth and stabilize prices.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong imposed new measures on Friday in its latest bid to cool one of the world's most expensive real estate markets, cutting the amount of money home buyers can borrow to 60 per cent of the property's value, from 70 per cent.

site_title: Google backflips on Blogger sexual content ban
summary: Google has reversed its decision to ban sexually explicit content on its Blogger platform, citing public feedback that expressed concerns about the negative impact on individuals who post sexually explicit content to express their identities. Instead, Google will step up enforcement of its existing policy prohibiting commercial porn, and operators can continue to mark blogs with explicit content as "adult" to receive a warning. The company will not require bloggers to make any changes to their blogs.

site_title: China plans yuan-denominated gold fix this year: sources
summary: China plans to launch a yuan-denominated gold fix this year, allowing the country to set its own pricing for the precious metal. The benchmark will be derived from a new 1 kg contract on the Shanghai Gold Exchange and will be traded and settled through the exchange. The move aims to increase China's market weight and counter the influence of the London gold fix, which is under scrutiny due to allegations of price manipulation. The Chinese fix could add pressure to the London benchmark and provide a more transparent and electronic price-setting process.

site_title: KrisEnergy widens losses in FY14 on higher costs
summary: KrisEnergy, an oil and gas company, reported a net loss of US$50.7 million for FY14, compared to US$12.7 million in the previous year, due to higher operating costs, depreciation, and administrative expenses. Revenue rose 8.5% to US$74.9 million, driven by increased oil and gas production, but lower average selling prices for the group's oil and liquids were affected by the fall in global oil prices in the second half of 2014.

site_title: US economic growth slows to 2.2% rate in fourth quarter
summary: The US economy expanded at a 2.2% rate in the fourth quarter of 2014, slower than the initially estimated 2.6% growth. The slowdown was driven by a smaller increase in inventory investment and higher imports, which subtracted from GDP. Consumer spending, accounting for 70% of economic activity, rose 4.2% and contributed 2.8 percentage points to growth, the largest share in nearly 10 years. Despite falling energy prices and a strong dollar, global economic weakness and trade imbalances also impacted US economic growth.

site_title: US SEC approves limits for arbitrators with industry ties
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has approved limits on financial industry veterans serving as arbitrators in cases against brokerage firms. The rule change excludes those with industry ties from serving on three-member panels unless investors opt for a panel with an industry background. The move aims to maintain the integrity of the arbitration system and addresses concerns of bias, pleasing investors who claimed industry professionals injected pro-industry bias into the process. The change is part of FINRA's efforts to strengthen rules protecting investors.

site_title: Australia: Shares pare losses, Woolworths results disappoint
summary: Australian shares were flat on Friday, offsetting gains in financials due to weakness in the consumer staples sector. Woolworths shares plummeted nearly 10% and energy-related shares fell on lower oil prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index remained at 5,908.3 points. Investors await local data and a Reserve Bank of Australia rate cut meeting next week. Global equities dipped due to a pullback in oil prices, while US consumer prices fell for the first time since 2009.

site_title: Venture's Q4 net profit up 3.5% to S$39.3m - highest for past 8 quarters
summary: VENTURE Corporation reported a 3.5% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$39.3m for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2014, marking the highest quarterly net profit in the past 8 quarters. Revenue rose 8.3% to S$674.68m, driven by strength in the Test & Measurement/Medical & Life Science/Others segment, despite a decline in the Computer Peripherals & Data Storage segment.

site_title: Seoul: Shares set to snap 7-session rally; won slips
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.2% to 1,988.27 points, snapping a seven-day rally, amid weak investor sentiment sparked by a decline in oil prices and a fall in the won against the dollar. The decline was attributed to poor risk appetite and foreign investors' pullback from risky assets. Despite this, some stocks, such as Unidus Corp, rose due to recent court rulings, including the striking down of a law banning adultery.

site_title: Asia: Markets largely flat in morning trade
summary: Asian markets were largely flat in morning trade on Friday, following the US dollar's firming after inflation data. Japanese inflation slowed for a sixth straight month, while the dollar weakened to 119.27 yen from 119.42 yen in New York. The euro rose to US$1.1206, but the euro slipped to 133.65 yen. Despite disappointing Japanese figures, the US Federal Reserve is expected to hike interest rates in June, with inflation data suggesting rising price pressures.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia's 2014 profit falls 40.9%
summary: Hong Leong Asia reported a 40.9% decline in net profit to S$26.9 million for its 2014 full year, mainly due to higher losses at its Xinfei unit. Revenue rose 1% to S$4.56 billion, with higher profits from Yuchai and building materials units offsetting losses from other units. The company proposed a final dividend of two cents per share, down from three cents last year. Earnings per share fell from 12.19 cents to 7.20 cents, and shares closed at S$1.435, down 2.5 cents.

site_title: UBS sees record euro debt as state team funds M&A: China Credit
summary: UBS predicts a record €5.35 billion euro-denominated bond sales from China in 2015, driven by state-backed companies seeking acquisitions in Europe. China's "going out" policy aims to expand overseas markets, and the government has announced a $1.25 trillion investment plan over the next 10 years. European investors are attracted to Chinese euro bonds due to higher yields, and UBS forecasts a 15% increase in offshore dollar and euro-denominated bond sales this year.

site_title: United Engineers 2014 net profit down 49% to S$46m
summary: United Engineers reported a net profit of S$46 million for its 2014 full year, down 49% from S$89.5 million in 2013. Revenue rose 93% to S$3.2 billion, primarily driven by WBL Group's 12 months of results. The company has sold parts of WBL, including its luxury car distribution business.

site_title: Mazda bets on diesel-only car for Japan launch of key 2015 model
summary: Mazda Motor Corp plans to launch its 2015 model, the CX-3, in Japan as a diesel-only car, betting on the growing demand for diesel engines in the country. The company's CEO, Masamichi Kogai, cited the greater power offered by diesel engines as a selling point for the compact SUV. Mazda aims to capitalize on the growing compact SUV segment, which is expected to double in size by 2020. The CX-3 will be sold in 120 countries, starting with Japan, and will feature advanced technology to reduce emissions and sound.

site_title: Singapore services sector's sales revenue up 5.7% quarter on quarter in Q4
summary: Singapore's services sector saw a 5.7% quarter-over-quarter increase in sales revenue in Q4 2014, excluding wholesale and retail trade, as well as accommodation and food services. On a year-over-year basis, overall business receipts rose 6%. The only exception was education services, which saw a 1.7% decline. Recreation and personal services reported the highest growth of 11%, followed by financial and insurance services, and business services. Other sectors, such as transport and storage, health and social services, and information and communication services, also saw notable growth.

site_title: Australia: Shares reverse losses; up 0.8% for the week
summary: Australian shares reversed early losses to rise 0.3% on Friday, led by a late rally in banks and telecommunications shares. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 20.3 points to 5,928.8, up 0.8% for the week. Woolworths shares fell 9.5%, the most since Oct 2008, after warning of full-year earnings below consensus estimates.

site_title: Union, Shell discuss meeting in US refinery strike: sources
summary: The United Steelworkers union and Shell Oil Co discussed a possible resumption of face-to-face negotiations to settle the US refinery strike, now in its 26th day. No date was set for direct meetings as of Thursday evening. The USW ordered walkouts at three Shell refineries after the last meeting, when refinery owners balked at a possible settlement.

site_title: Update: Hong Kong steps up efforts to cool red-hot property market
summary: Hong Kong's central bank cut the amount of money home buyers can borrow to 60% of a property's value and lowered the debt-servicing ratio for second-home buyers to 40% to curb speculative demand in the city's red-hot property market. The measures come ahead of an expected US interest rate rise and aim to prevent a domestic rate hike that could increase mortgage payments. The city's household debt to GDP ratio has reached 64%, fueled by record high property prices and ultra low interest rates.

site_title: Intraco goes into the red with S$949,000 loss for 2014
summary: Intraco Limited reported a net loss of S$949,000 for its 2014 fiscal year, a significant decline from a net profit of S$1.1 million in 2013. Revenue increased 18.2% to S$151.2 million. The company attributed its recent acquisition of KA Group as a sound investment, expecting better performance in 2015. Managing director Foo Der Rong stated that the acquisition has shown encouraging results. No dividend was declared, and the company traded unchanged at 32 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Yangzijiang's Q4 profit falls 15% on lower shipbuilding margins
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 15% drop in Q4 net profit to 636.56 million yuan due to lower shipbuilding margins. Revenue rose 12% to 3.78 billion yuan, while gross profit fell 41% to 848.51 million yuan. The company delivered nine vessels in Q4, compared to six a year ago. For the full year, net profit rose 13% to 3.48 billion yuan, while revenue rose 7% to 15.35 billion yuan.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: China money rates slip after holiday, benchmark IRS forecast rate cut
summary: China's money rates slipped this week after a week-long holiday, with benchmark interest rate swaps forecasting another official interest rate cut to bolster the economy. The People's Bank of China drained excessive liquidity, and the weighted average of the seven-day repo rate fell to 4.75% from 4.82%. The central bank's easing bias remains intact, with traders expecting further monetary easing this year.

site_title: Alibaba's online payment firm Ant Financial eyes 2017 IPO
summary: Ant Financial, Alibaba's online payment firm, is seeking to raise up to $4 billion in a private placement and plans a domestic IPO in 2017. Alipay, its platform, is valued between $35 billion and $40 billion and is seen as crucial to Alibaba's business. The company, controlled by Jack Ma, has seen revenue jump 92% to 10.2 billion yuan in 2014, with net profit expected to grow at a 64% compound annual rate from 2015 to 2017. Strategic investors, including Chinese government-backed firms, will purchase 10% of the company.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open
summary: European stock markets opened steady on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index dipping 0.01% to 6,949.25 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 edged up 0.09% to 11,337.11 points, while Paris's CAC 40 index inched down 0.10% to 4,905.77 points. The steady trading follows recent market fluctuations, with US-EU trade tensions and tariff threats remaining a focus for investors.

site_title: Asia: Japanese stocks at 15-year peak, dollar firm after data boost
summary: Japanese stocks reached a 15-year peak on Friday, driven by a stronger dollar and upbeat US data. The dollar surged 0.5% against the yen, boosting competitiveness and earnings for Japanese exporters. Asian equity markets outside Japan fell 0.3%, while the dollar index hovered near a one-month high. US core inflation rose more than expected, supporting the dollar, and Treasury yields increased. Economists expect a revised US GDP growth rate, which may influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike timeline.

site_title: Airbus posts higher 2014 profit and increases A320 build rates
summary: Airbus reported a 15% gain in annual profit to 4.07 billion euros in 2014, beating estimates. The company increased commercial plane deliveries and plans to boost A320 production to 50 per month by 2017. Sales rose 5% to 60.7 billion euros, driven by demand for fuel-efficient aircraft. Airbus aims to build 46 single-aisle planes per month by 2016, surpassing Boeing's target of 52 by 2018. The company also took a 551 million euro charge for A400M military transport delays.

site_title: KS Energy's 2014 profit leaps to S$30 million
summary: KS Energy reported a net profit of S$30.13 million for 2014, exceeding the previous year's S$23,000. Revenue increased 40.5% to S$227.33 million, driven by a 45.5% jump in drilling business revenue. The drilling business contributed 92.2% of the group's consolidated revenue, mainly due to charter contracts in Indonesia and Vietnam. The company's earnings per share and net asset value per share were 5.87 cents and 72.3 cents, respectively.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Friday
summary: Singapore's key stories include Citigroup setting a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index. Vietnam surprised by Trump's tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate. The Asian garment industry braces for higher US tariffs. In Malaysia, a government agency plans to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. The UK economy shrank for the second month, dealing a fresh blow to Labour leader Starmer.

images.alt_text: Total bank lending in Singapore fell in January from the previous month, as a drop in loans to general commerce and financial institutions offset increases in lending to manufacturers, central bank data showed on Friday.

site_title: Italy's government under pressure to soften reform of cooperative banks
summary: Italy's government is under pressure to soften a landmark reform of large cooperative banks, which would turn them into joint-stock companies, allowing for easier fundraising and potentially leading to consolidation. The banks, including UBI Banca and Banca Popolare, are demanding changes to the decree, citing concerns over foreign takeovers and speculative investors. The government is reluctant to water down the reform, but lawmakers are considering modifications, such as capping voting rights at 3-5% of capital. The Bank of Italy has expressed support for the reform, but warns that watering it down could hinder the transition.

site_title: Passenger traffic at Changi slips 3.8% in January
summary: Changi Airport reported a 3.8% decline in passenger traffic to 4.42 million in January, in line with a 5.2% drop in aircraft movements. However, air-freight movements increased by 1% to 151,800 tonnes. Traffic to South Asia grew 5% year-over-year, driven by increased travel to India. Traffic between Singapore and Thailand rebounded, with Bangkok seeing a 34% year-over-year increase.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed flat on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.34 points to 1,821.21. The market saw 2.21 billion lots traded worth RM2.73 billion, with 484 losers beating 367 gainers.

images.alt_text: MALAYSIA share prices closed flat on Friday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index up just 0.34 points to 1,821.21.

site_title: UK consumer confidence holds at high level in February: GfK
summary: UK consumer confidence remained high in February, holding steady at a +1 level, according to a GfK poll. Low inflation and rising wages boosted confidence, which is seen as a positive sign for Prime Minister David Cameron ahead of the May 7 election. However, economists expect little change in confidence before the election, citing the need for "dramatic change" in indicators. The survey also found the highest level of confidence in personal finances since May 2014, but the UK economy's slow growth rate in the last quarter may impact the outcome of the election.

site_title: German negotiated wages rise at 3.2% in 2014
summary: German negotiated wages rose 3.2% in 2014, the largest increase since 2010, driven by a strong labor market and lower oil prices. This boost in household spending is expected to drive growth in the country this year. The wage increase far surpassed inflation, with workers under collective wage agreements seeing a 3.4% hike, including a one-off payment of 150 euros. This news is positive for private consumption and the overall economy, particularly with consumer morale at its highest in over 13 years.

images.alt_text: German negotiated wages including special payments climbed by 3.2 per cent on average last year - the biggest increase since the statistics were first compiled in 2010 - boding well for private consumption to drive growth this year.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks rise before annual congress meeting
summary: Chinese stocks rose 0.4% to 3,310.30 before the National People's Congress meeting, capping a 3.3% monthly gain. The Shanghai Composite Index jumped 2.2% on Thursday after Premier Li Keqiang called for active fiscal policy. The yuan weakened, adding to the market's volatility ahead of the meeting, which is expected to set the country's economic direction.

site_title: IndoAgri's Q4 profit dips; revenue up 11.8%
summary: Indofood Agri Resources (IndoAgri) reported a 0.9% dip in net profit to 225.5 billion Indonesian rupiah for its Q4 2014, despite an 11.8% increase in revenue to 4.19 trillion rupiah. The decline in profit was mainly due to higher finance expenses and an effective income tax rate. The company attributed the revenue increase to higher sales volume of crude palm oil. Despite this, the global economic slowdown and higher supply of competing vegetable oils negatively impacted the palm oil industry.

site_title: Golden Agri in the red in Q4, to pay lower dividend
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported a net loss of US$21.93 million for Q4 2014, down from a net profit of US$123 million a year ago. Revenue slipped 4.2% to US$1.82 billion, and full-year net profit fell 63.5% to US$113.6 million. The company attributed losses to lower refining margins and start-up costs. It expects operating performance to be affected by fluctuating commodity prices and global economic conditions, and plans to focus on improving yield and cost efficiency. A lower final dividend of 0.177 Singapore cent per share was proposed.

site_title: 5.4-magnitude earthquake hits northwest Pakistan
summary: A 5.4-magnitude earthquake struck northwest Pakistan, injuring at least five people and causing minor damage, 37km north-northeast of Mansehra, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province. Two aftershocks with magnitudes of 3.2 and 4 followed the quake, reported at a depth of 28.9km.

site_title: Update: Union, Shell discuss meeting in US refinery strike: sources
summary: The United Steelworkers (USW) union and Shell Oil Co. discussed a possible resumption of face-to-face negotiations to settle a 26-day strike at US refineries. No date has been set for direct meetings, but the USW remains ready to negotiate. The union seeks to retain safety provisions and tighten fatigue standards, while Shell wants to maintain management flexibility in staffing. The strike affects 6,550 USW members at 15 plants, including 12 refineries that account for one-fifth of national capacity.

site_title: US signs trade pledge with East Africa, eyes rest of continent
summary: The US has signed a trade pledge with five East African countries (Tanzania, Kenya, Uganda, Rwanda, and Burundi) to ease trade flows and set the stage for US investment. The agreement commits the countries to cooperate on customs issues, reduce red tape, and harmonize trade standards. The US will provide training on food safety and international regulations. The deal aims to boost US trade with the region, which has grown 52% to $2.8 billion in 2014. The agreement is seen as a stepping stone for future US investment in the rest of Africa.

site_title: Ho Bee Land posts 43.6% drop in Q4 net profit
summary: Ho Bee Land Limited, a MAINBOARD-LISTED property group, reported a 43.6% drop in Q4 net profit to S$285.2 million due to smaller fair value changes in investment properties and a 49% decline in group turnover. Despite this, rental income from commercial, industrial, and residential properties rose 110%. Full-year profit was 46.8% lower at S$315 million. A first and final dividend of five Singapore cents a share has been proposed, with the group expecting to face stronger headwinds in the property market this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up 0.31%
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.31% on Friday, driven by a weak yen that makes Japanese exporters more competitive abroad. The Nikkei 225 index reached a fresh 15-year high, adding 58.49 points to 18,844.28. US inflation data pointed to rising pressures, easing concerns about the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike. The dollar firmed against other major currencies, including the euro and yen. A mixed picture of Japanese data, including slowing inflation and rising factory production, also contributed to the market's positive trend.

site_title: Singapore January bank lending dips as commerce, financial loans decline
summary: Singapore's total bank lending in January decreased to S$607.47 billion, a 0.3% drop from December, despite a 4.3% year-over-year increase. Loans to general commerce and financial institutions declined, while housing and bridging loans increased. Non-Singapore Asian currencies loans rose 2.5% from December. The decline may signal economic slowdown concerns.

site_title: Struggling S i2i widens Q4 losses; CEO to take S$1 annual salary
summary: Struggling S i2i, a regional distributor and service provider, widened its fourth-quarter net losses to $37.3 million, compared to $23.2 million a year ago. Revenue dropped 5% to $94.5 million due to increased competition and reduced capital expenditure. The company plans to scale down staff and streamline its retail business, incurring a one-time restructuring cost. CEO Maneesh Tripathi has voluntarily reduced his annual salary to $1 and linked his variable pay to the company's profitability. The restructuring aims to allow the company to operate at a leaner cost structure.

site_title: British media unmask killer "Jihadi John" with first schoolboy photograph
summary: British media identified Mohammed Emwazi, known as "Jihadi John," a killer who fronted Islamic State beheading videos, as a smiling schoolboy in a 2012 photograph. Emwazi, a British-Kuwaiti man, appeared to have little interest in Islam as a boy, and his true identity was first reported by the Washington Post. US government sources confirmed that Emwazi was the man behind the menacing videos, which featured beheadings of Americans, Britons, and Syrians. The revelation marks the first public unmasking of the elusive militant.

site_title: Rio Tinto cuts energy chief's job in austerity drive
summary: Rio Tinto has cut the job of its energy chief, Harry Kenyon-Slaney, as part of its cost-cutting measures in response to weak commodity prices. The company will roll its coal and uranium businesses into two other units, resulting in four product groups, including iron ore and aluminium. This move supports Rio Tinto's commitment to delivering US$750 million in savings this year. The changes aim to simplify and strengthen the company, delivering sustainable value for shareholders.

site_title: Japan's January retail sales fall 2.0% year on year
summary: Japan's January retail sales declined 2.0% year-over-year, exceeding economists' expectations of a 1.3% drop. The decline indicates weak underlying demand.

images.alt_text: Japanese retail sales fell 2.0 per cent in January from a year earlier, more than economists'median estimate of a 1.3 per cent decline, government data showed on Friday, in a sign underlying demand remains weak.

site_title: XinRen Aluminum's FY14 profit gets boost from China government subsidies
summary: XinRen Aluminum Holdings reported a 374% increase in net profit to 284.01 million yuan (S$61.5 million) for FY14, driven by 76.4% revenue growth and local government subsidies of 228.97 million yuan. The company aims to increase output at its Xinjiang plant to 1.1 million tonnes by the end of 2015 and plans to operationalize two more power-generating units. A first and final dividend of S$0.01 per share was declared, marking the first dividend payment in two years.

site_title: US House Republicans discuss plan to extend security funding for three weeks
summary: US House Republicans are meeting to discuss a three-week extension of funding for the Department of Homeland Security, averted from a partial shutdown. Lawmakers face a Friday midnight deadline to pass a funding bill. Republicans aim to attach measures to block President Obama's immigration actions, while the Senate moves towards a "clean" bill. The temporary extension would give lawmakers more time to resolve their differences.

site_title: Japan's January core CPI rises 2.2% year on year
summary: Japan's core consumer prices rose 2.2% in January from the previous year, slightly below economists' median estimate of 2.3%. The core-core inflation index, excluding food and energy prices, rose 2.1% in the same period. This is the first time the core CPI has surpassed 2% since 2014, indicating inflation is on the rise in Japan.

images.alt_text: Japan's core consumer prices rose 2.2 per cent in January from a year earlier, government data showed on Friday.

site_title: ST Engineering posts 16.2% fall in Q4 profit, declares 15 cent per share FY14 dividend
summary: ST Engineering reported a 16.2% drop in Q4 profit to S$140.3 million and a 4.6% drop in revenue to S$1.85 billion. For FY14, net profit fell 8.4% to S$531.95 million, and earnings per share fell 9% to 17.06 Singapore cents. The company declared a 15-cent per share dividend for FY14, matching the previous year's payout. Revenue from all sectors except marine was comparable to the previous year, while "others" revenue fell 18%.

images.alt_text: ST Engineering on Friday reported a 16.2 per cent drop in net profit for its fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2014, to S$140.3 million, while revenue fell 4.6 per cent to S$1.85 billion.

site_title: US spymaster warns over low-level cyber attacks
summary: US intelligence director James Clapper warned that low-level cyber attacks pose the greatest danger to the US, rather than a catastrophic "cyber Armageddon." Persistent, low-to-moderate level cyber attacks from various sources could harm US economic competitiveness and national security. Clapper cited recent "destructive cyber attacks" by countries like North Korea and Iran, which used cyber capabilities to target US infrastructure systems. The US has offensive capabilities in cyberspace, but lacks clear policy on cyber deterrence.

site_title: Japan's January household spending falls 5.1% vs year ago
summary: Japan's household spending declined 5.1% in January compared to the same period last year, exceeding economists' median estimate of a 4.1% drop. This marks a worrying sign that consumer spending remains weak. In contrast, spending fell 0.3% from the previous month, contrary to the median estimate of a 0.4% increase. The decline in spending suggests ongoing economic challenges for Japan.

site_title: China investors top US list of 2013 national security reviews
summary: China investors faced the most scrutiny from a US national security watchdog in 2013, with 21 of 97 transactions reviewed due to potential national security concerns. This marked the second consecutive year China topped the list, with Japan and Canada following. The increased reviews reflect higher investment flows from China, which some Chinese companies claim is singled out by the US, despite the administration's assertion that it does not discriminate against any country.

site_title: NZ business confidence picks up in February
summary: New Zealand business confidence improved in February with a net 34.4% of respondents expecting the economy to improve over the year ahead, the highest since July last year. Expectations for business growth and hiring also increased, while inflation pressures eased to 1.72%. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has halted interest rate tightening, with economists predicting rates will remain on hold through 2016.

images.alt_text: New Zealand business confidence improved in February with respondents expecting to hire staff and invest more, while inflation pressures softened, an ANZ Bank survey showed on Friday.

site_title: Investors tell hedge funds they want lower fees: survey
summary: Institutional investors polled by Preqin Ltd. have expressed dissatisfaction with hedge funds, citing high fees as a major concern. 68% of respondents said fees should be reduced, up from 45% in 2013. Despite this, 84% of investors plan to maintain or increase their allocations to hedge funds this year, with half willing to invest up to $50 million in new capital. The data comes after the California Public Employees' Retirement System, the largest US pension fund, exited hedge funds in 2014 due to high costs and poor performance.

site_title: Fiat gives boost to Italy PM's job reform with stable contracts
summary: Fiat Chrysler has agreed to give permanent contracts to hundreds of new hires at its Melfi plant in southern Italy, a union said. This move is seen as a boost to Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's labor reforms, specifically the Jobs Act, which aims to ease hiring and firing restrictions. The switch is expected to take place in six months, marking the first clear sign that the law can persuade big employers to take on more permanent staff. This move is considered a positive step for Renzi's labor reforms.

site_title: US: Nasdaq nears 5,000 as oil weakness weighs on S&P 500
summary: US stocks experienced mixed results, with the Nasdaq Composite Index nearing 5,000 points, driven by tech giants Apple, Google, and Tesla. However, the Dow and S&P 500 fell due to oil weakness, with Chevron and Schlumberger declining. Morgan Stanley trimmed its 2014 earnings due to a settlement with the Justice Department. Other notable movers included Avago Technologies, L Brands, and Salesforce.com. Bond prices fell as yields rose, with the 10-year Treasury yield reaching 2.03% and the 30-year Treasury yield at 2.63%.

site_title: EU unveils plans for historic single energy market
summary: The European Union has unveiled plans for a single energy market to reduce its reliance on Russian gas supplies and cut a massive annual import bill of 400 billion euros. The proposal aims to increase energy security, boost efficiency, and reduce fossil fuel use, with a goal of completing the single market by 2020. The EU faces a pressing need for action as Russia threatens to cut gas deliveries to Ukraine, putting Europe's energy supply at risk. The plan requires an investment of over one trillion euros by 2020 and has been welcomed by business groups but criticized by environmentalists.

images.alt_text: French Prime Minister Manuel Valls (centre) and Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy (second from right) watching as technicians connect a power line from Baixas in France to Santa Llogaia in Spain, in Montesquieu des Alberes this month. The link is one step towards the single market.

site_title: ExxonMobil says Russia sanctions could cost it US$1b
summary: ExxonMobil has estimated that US sanctions against Russia could cost it up to $1 billion, primarily due to the winding down of joint venture activities with Rosneft in the Black Sea and Arctic regions. The US and EU imposed sanctions on Rosneft and its president Igor Sechin over the conflict in Ukraine. Exxon was forced to abandon its joint venture for exploration drilling in the Kara Sea, an area estimated to hold 87 billion barrels of oil.

site_title: Events at a glance
summary: Masterchef Jean-Yves Leuranguer and Chef Ronan Kervarrec will host French cuisine dinner events in Singapore, featuring wine pairings. Leuranguer's event, "The Cuisine of Masterchef Jean-Yves Leuranguer," will take place March 17-21, while Kervarrec's event, "The Cuisine of Masterchef Ronan Kervarrec," will occur March 24-28. Additionally, Chef Pepe Moncayo will present modern Spanish cuisine with Emilio Moro wines, and Buyan Russian Restaurant will feature rustic Russian flavors with vodka-based cocktails.

site_title: Oil market slide on oversupply woes
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday, with European benchmark Brent North Sea crude dipping 63 cents to $61.00 per barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) diving $1.72 to $49.27 a barrel. The US Department of Energy reported record crude inventories of 434.1 million barrels, despite modest signs of global demand recovery. Analysts attributed the price drop to swelling US inventories and supply glut, while positive comments from Saudi Arabia's oil minister and solid demand in Europe and China also contributed to the decline.

site_title: Citi backs move to make it easier for shareholders to nominate directors
summary: Citigroup will support a shareholder resolution allowing groups of up to 20 shareholders to nominate directors for up to 20% of its board seats, similar to General Electric's new bylaws. The proposal, backed by private shareholder James McRitchie, aims to make boards less insular and more responsive to investor concerns. Citigroup's support is seen as the latest large company to embrace the "proxy access" reform, which advocates say helps improve corporate governance. The proposal is set to be voted on at Citigroup's annual meeting in April.

site_title: S'pore arts fest: Local stories come to fore
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts will feature a local-centric lineup, including a musical about Nanyang artists and a dance piece drawing from traditional Chinese, Malay, and Indian dance forms. The festival will also bring stand-up comedy shows to heartlands and transform ordinary living rooms into mini-theatres. Meanwhile, international acts, such as baritone Matthias Goerne, will perform alongside a dance marathon and a Hungarian play addressing post-empire themes. The festival, part of Singapore's 50th anniversary celebrations, aims to bring the arts out of the city centre and into homes, promoting multiple perspectives and decentralization.

site_title: Europe: Stocks higher, FTSE and DAX hit record closes
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed at record highs on Thursday, with the FTSE 100 and DAX 30 indices rising 0.21% and 1.04% respectively. The CAC 40 index also reached a record high, climbing 0.58%. These gains came despite the looming threat of US-EU tariffs, which are expected to impact the region's economy. The record closes mark a positive end to the week for European markets, which had experienced a decline earlier in the week.

site_title: McFerrin happy to be in a class of his own
summary: Bobby McFerrin, a 10-time Grammy winner, will perform at the Singapore International Jazz Festival from March 5-8. McFerrin, known for his signature a cappella song "Don't Worry, Be Happy," has a unique pre-show routine that involves meditation and prayer. He has "disowned" the song due to its association with a presidential campaign and instead focuses on his original compositions. McFerrin's music has delighted fans and inspired a new generation of a cappella singers, and he continues to push the boundaries of his art.

site_title: Twitter boosts effort to stop spoofing, data leaks
summary: Twitter has updated its efforts to combat impersonation, data leaks, and harassment on its platform. The company is streamlining its reporting process and adding new enforcement actions for accounts violating its rules. With increased resources, Twitter now reviews five times more user reports and has tripled its support team. The changes aim to discourage behavior that goes against Twitter's policies and provide new options for addressing rule-breaking accounts. The updates will roll out to all users in the coming weeks.

site_title: China drops some global tech brands from list of suppliers
summary: China has dropped some global tech brands, including Cisco Systems, Apple Inc, Intel Corp's McAfee, and Citrix Systems, from its approved state purchase lists, citing concerns over Western surveillance. The move, which approved thousands more local products, is seen as a response to the Snowden leaks and a shift towards promoting China's domestic technology industry. The number of foreign tech brands fell by a third, while local makers increased by over 2,000, with experts warning that China risks leaving itself dependent on inferior domestic technology.

site_title: Pity Smith still hasn't recovered his focus
summary: Will Smith stars in the film "Focus" as a third-generation con artist, but his performance is underwhelming. The movie follows Nicky Spurgeon and his protégée Jess (Margot Robbie) as they execute a series of cons, but the plot is unrealistic and lacks quality entertainment. Despite its fun moments, the film falls short, with Smith not fully recovering from his previous box office misfire "After Earth." The movie's rating is a C-.

site_title: Writing history's wrongs
summary: A play called "Three Inches of Alive" imagines the life of 19th-century Malayan philanthropist Leila "Anjung" Keats, who was written out of history due to her mixed parentage and lack of recognition. The play, written by Clarilyn Khoo, aims to address the issue of inaccurate historical representation and the lack of awareness about female pioneers in Singapore's history. The play will be staged at various venues from February 26 to March 21, and tickets are free.

site_title: A third of global food production goes to waste, says report
summary: A report estimates that a third of global food production, worth around US$400 billion annually, goes to waste. In the US, 60 million tonnes of food are wasted each year, valued at US$162 billion, with 32 million tonnes ending up in landfills. Globally, food waste contributes to 7% of greenhouse gas emissions, with the potential to save US$120-300 billion annually if reduced from 20-50%. The issue is expected to worsen as the global population increases, with US$600 billion in annual waste costs by 2030 unless action is taken.

site_title: Hackers attack Lenovo website, redirect traffic
summary: Hackers compromised Lenovo's website, redirecting traffic to CloudFlare's network, just days after the company apologized for pre-installing ad software on consumer laptops that exposed users to hacking. The attack involved altering the domain name registrar's records, and Lenovo has restored some functionality to the site while reviewing network security. The incident follows a similar attack by the Lizard Squad group on Sony's PlayStation network.

images.alt_text: The hackers, a group called the Lizard Squad, took over the Lenovo site by altering records with the domain name registrar used by the company.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation's stock is expected to benefit from a deferred foreign workers' levy increase, potentially leading to higher profits in 2015. The company is also expected to receive contributions from its property development segment, including the expected completion of the Park Hotel at Alexandra in 2015. Analysts from UOB Kay Hian and StarHub maintain a "Hold" rating, with target prices at S$0.975 and S$4.50 respectively.

site_title: Turkish Airlines plans fleet expansion after tripling profit
summary: Turkish Airlines reported a near-tripling in 2014 net profit to $1.82 billion, with planned $3.74 billion investments in aircraft this year, aiming for a 300-plane fleet by the end of 2015. The airline's shares fell due to a weak euro impacting passenger yield, which fell to 9.36 cents per mile per passenger from 9.64 cents in 2013. Turkish Airlines is also arranging a $500 million-$2.5 billion bond issue and in talks with Malaysia Airlines for leasing aircraft.

site_title: IS jihadists destroy ancient artefacts in Iraq: video
summary: Islamic State militants in Iraq have destroyed ancient artefacts in Mosul, a video shows. The destruction, using sledgehammers and jackhammers, sparked alarm among archaeologists and heritage experts, drawing comparisons to the Taliban's 2001 demolition of the Bamiyan Buddhas. The UN's cultural agency demanded an emergency meeting of the Security Council, citing heritage protection as integral to Iraq's security.

images.alt_text: Islamic State militants armed with sledgehammers and jackhammers have destroyed priceless ancient artefacts in Iraq's city of Mosul, a video released by the jihadists Thursday shows.

site_title: City Buzz
summary: A Singaporean online community, The Platform Collective, promotes bartering among its members. Thevar 2.0 showcases Indian cuisine, while The Social Kitchen sets up a food stall at the Bank of Singapore. The NCSS rallies partners to engage volunteers better. CMC Markets partners with Sophia Women to drive financial literacy for women. The concept of corporate purpose is discussed, and a project documents Singapore's retail history. Additionally, design solutions are offered for unusual home layouts, highlighting various initiatives in Singapore's startup and social sectors.

images.alt_text: The Platform Collective is an online community initiated by four university students - (from left) Olivia Ng, Wong Yan Ting, Isaac Tan and Caster Teoh. It aims to congregate local small businesses and provide a platform for them to barter their skills.

The Platform Collective is an online community initiated by four university students - Olivia Ng, Wong Yan Ting, Isaac Tan and Caster Teoh. It aims to congregate local small businesses and provide a platform for them to barter their skills.
In between writing and recording her second album, Perri played Singapore in 2012 at the Kallang Theatre
Exhibitions closing on March 1 include the terrific show at the Centre for Contemporary Art by Chinese superstar Yang Fudong (above)
Owner Cherie Chua
Stephane Soret, Raffles Singapore's wine director

site_title: Trinidad offers Venezuela oil-for-tissue paper swap
summary: Venezuela, facing severe shortages of basic goods, has been offered an oil-for-tissue paper swap by Trinidad & Tobago's Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar. The deal, proposed after a meeting with President Nicolas Maduro, would see Trinidad purchasing goods from Venezuela, such as tissue paper and gasoline, in exchange for oil. The proposal aims to benefit both countries amid Venezuela's economic crisis, including a 7% economic contraction and 69% inflation. Maduro's government blames hoarders for the shortages, and the proposal must be approved by the end of the year, according to Venezuela's constitution.

site_title: HSBC bosses reject calls to quit over tax scandal
summary: HSBC bosses, chairman Douglas Flint and CEO Stuart Gulliver, rejected calls to quit over the bank's Swiss tax scandal, acknowledging collective responsibility for failings. The bank admitted control and compliance failures, leading to millions of dollars in tax evasion. HSBC has made substantial changes to address the issue, but the scandal has damaged its reputation. The bank has faced previous fines and investigations, including $1.9 billion and $611 million penalties, and is undergoing a transformation to simplify and centralize control.

site_title: More Asians investing in European hotels
summary: Asian investors are expected to increase their investment in European hotels by 58% to $22.7 billion this year, driven by the relaxation of domestic controls on outbound funds. This follows a 90% rise in hotel acquisitions in Europe last year, with Singapore companies investing $331 million. The liberalization of insurance regulations in China, Taiwan, and South Korea has led to increased allocations to real estate, with hotel properties seen as an attractive asset for diversifying portfolios.

site_title: Thai Beverage net profit for FY14 up 13.4%
summary: Thai Beverage's net profit for FY14 rose 13.4% to 21.69 billion baht, driven by improved performance from its spirits, beer, and food businesses. Revenue increased 4.0% to 162.04 billion baht. The company will pay an annual dividend of 0.61 baht per share. Political events in Thailand continued to impact the beverage business, but the economy began to pick up in Q4, led by export, industrial, and tourism sectors.

site_title: Low petrol prices drag CPI down in January
summary: US consumer prices fell 0.7% in January, the largest decline since 2008, driven by low petrol prices. This drop in the Consumer Price Index (CPI) could give the Federal Reserve ammunition to keep interest rates low. Meanwhile, a gauge of business investment plans rebounded in January, with non-defence capital goods orders increasing 0.6%. The unemployment rate remained at 5.7% in January, with initial jobless claims totaling 313,000, pushing the number above 300,000 for the first time in two years.

site_title: Never underestimate low-priced wines
summary: A low-priced Bordeaux wine, the Antoine Moueix 2010, was found to possess potential despite its lower status, developing complex flavors and aromas over time. In contrast, a high-end Bordeaux wine, the Chateau l'Eglise Clinet 2004, demonstrated exceptional quality and calibre, with a rich, dense, and balanced taste. These findings challenge the notion that expensive wines are always superior, highlighting the importance of approaching wine with an open mind and considering factors such as price and context. The article concludes that the key to enjoying wine is finding a good match with the food being served.

site_title: Pure Iskandar developer on its way to list on SGX
summary: Astaka Padu, a pure Iskandar developer, is set to complete its first mixed-use project in 2020. The project's estimated gross development value is RM3.54 billion (S$1.34 billion), with 60% of residential units already sold. The group plans to rope in joint-venture partners for the remaining components, including a five-star hotel, offices, and retail shops. Astaka Padu aims to attract companies in Singapore to relocate their back-offices and hopes to bring in luxury hotel brands like Ritz-Carlton, Grand Hyatt, or Marriott. The group expects to complete its reverse takeover of E2 Capital in Q2 and may list on the Singapore Exchange (SGX).

site_title: Moving from moderate to top quartile zone on the staff engage-o-meter
summary: ROCHE Diagnostics Asia Pacific has achieved a top quartile ranking on Aon Hewitt's engage-o-meter, indicating high employee engagement. This recognition validates the company's efforts to create a best place to work. The move comes after the company shifted from the moderate zone to the top quartile zone, with Asia-Pacific head Lance Little stating that the recognition legitimizes their engagement initiatives.

site_title: UOL sees challenging Singapore outlook, diversifies overseas
summary: UOL Group, a Singaporean property developer, expects a challenging outlook for the residential and retail sectors in Singapore this year, citing lower fair value gains and waning development sales. To diversify its portfolio, the company plans to selectively increase investments overseas, particularly in gateway cities. Group revenue rose 29% to S$1.36 billion in 2014, with property development revenue increasing 65% to S$675.9 million. UOL will launch two new residential projects in Singapore this year and a mixed development in Shanghai.

site_title: Ex-executives say they were fired by Microsoft for hostess charge doubts
summary: Two former Microsoft executives, George Engstrom and John Stockwell, have filed a lawsuit against the company, alleging they were fired after raising concerns about a high-expense claims made by an employee in South Korea. The employee reportedly took business partners to "hostess bars" that may have provided sex services. Microsoft denied the claims and says it will fight the matter in court. Engstrom and Stockwell claim they were retaliated against after the company unilaterally raised the employee's performance rating and transferred them off a project. The trial is set for March 7, 2016.

site_title: Iron Lady's case for preserving Taiwan's independence
summary: Former Taiwanese Vice-President Lu Hsiu-lichen emphasizes the importance of preserving Taiwan's independence in the face of rising China. She notes that Taiwan has earned the right to live as it wishes and should not be forced into a one-China framework. Lu, a strong advocate for women's rights and democracy, urges Pacific powers to defend Taiwan's freedom, citing its unique developments in human rights and democracy. If the Democratic Progressive Party wins next year's election, the new government will increase defense spending to 3% of GDP and consider a national plebiscite on establishing Taiwan's neutrality.

site_title: Goodrich wins 1st special recognition prize for SMEs
summary: GOODRICH Global, a Singapore-based interior wall-covering dealer, has won Aon Hewitt's Best Employers Special Recognition - SME prize. Chairman and CEO Chan Chong Beng praised the award, saying it aligns with the company's vision to be an employer of choice for SMEs. Workers at Goodrich benefit from career growth, wellness programs, and societal contributions, fostering a collaborative and innovative work environment.

site_title: Putting people first at McDonald's
summary: McDonald's Singapore has won the Aon Hewitt Best Employers award for prioritizing its employees, with a near-perfect score of 98-100% for worker engagement, employer brand, leadership, and high performance culture. The company has fostered a "dynamic and flexible family environment" that supports staff growth, resulting in an "inspired and passionate" workforce. With over 8,000 staff, McDonald's Singapore has also developed at least nine local employees who have taken on global leadership roles. The company's focus on employee development and training has helped retain staff, despite facing a labor crunch in Singapore.

site_title: Many US policymakers tilt towards trade protectionism
summary: US policymakers are leaning towards trade protectionism, citing the negative effects of the 2008 financial crisis and the Great Depression of 1929. The country is facing pressure to block two major free trade agreements, the Trans-Pacific Partnership and the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, which could raise global income by $295 billion annually. Many US Congressmen view free trade pacts as a threat to US jobs and sovereignty, with some arguing that the vast American continent is self-sustaining and that foreign trade accounts for only 23% of GDP.

site_title: Banks, Jardine push STI down 14.65 points
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 14.65 points to 3,426.18, with turnover below the S$1-1.1 billion average of the past week. Banks and Jardine were under pressure, while Noble Group suspended trading after a short selling report alleged accounting irregularities. In contrast, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 0.5%. Water treatment firm Moya Asia surged 70.3% after an Indonesian hydroelectric firm acquired a 29% stake.

site_title: Hertz raises impact of accounting errors
summary: Hertz Global Holdings has estimated an additional $125 million of accounting errors in its ongoing review of financial statements, doubling its cost-saving target to $200 million. The cumulative effect of the errors on pretax income was $28 million in 2013, $74 million in 2012, and $51 million in 2011. CEO John Tague aims to deliver improved performance and value creation, and the company is reviewing its leadership, data integrity, and decision-support systems.

site_title: Time to think design
summary: Singapore Design Week (SDW) 2015 will take place in March, featuring over 60 design events across various disciplines. The week-long festival aims to raise public awareness and appreciation of design, coinciding with the mid-term school holidays. Key events include the International Furniture Fair Singapore and the Singapore Design Business Summit. The festival also showcases the work of local and international designers, including the Paris-based Maison & Objet Asia, and features interactive exhibitions, such as the "Many Ways of Seeing" exhibition for children. SDW 2015 is expected to attract more than 90,000 visitors, building on the success of last year's event.

site_title: New World of Work increases productivity of Microsoft staff
summary: Microsoft's New World of Work Initiative, launched three years ago, has improved the productivity of 54% of its employees in its Singapore office, according to an internal survey. The flexible work style has led to increased collaboration, better working environments, and improved employee satisfaction. Nearly half of staff reported working more with colleagues, and 77% found the environment better. This success has contributed to Microsoft winning the Aon Hewitt Best Employer award for the second time, affirming the company's culture and talent.

site_title: Tax deal may help Swiss banks keep Italian clients
summary: Switzerland has secured a tax deal with Italy, allowing the country to remove Switzerland from a black list and enabling Italian clients to voluntarily disclose undeclared funds on more favorable terms. The agreement is expected to help Swiss banks retain clients, as Italian clients will pay between 7-12% in taxes and penalties, compared to 40% if Switzerland hadn't reached the agreement. The deal is seen as a relief for Swiss asset managers, who were facing costly investigations from the US to France, and is expected to prevent a significant exodus of Italian funds.

site_title: More Chinese developers to be downgraded: S&P
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) expects more Chinese property developers to have their credit ratings downgraded this year, with a growing chance of default on debt, due to weaker sales and limited financing options. China's real estate market slowdown and Kaisa Group's late bond coupon payment have already affected Asian corporate debt markets. S&P expects China property sales to fall by up to 5% in 2015, with prices stabilizing in the second half of the year.

site_title: RHT Holdings prepares to list on Catalist
summary: RHT Holdings Limited, a professional services group in Asia, has initiated the process for its proposed listing on the Catalist board of Singapore Exchange. The move aims to raise funds for the group's international ambitions and is scheduled for the first quarter of 2016 or earlier. The holding company for four subsidiaries, including RHT Compliance Solutions and RHT Capital, plans to tap into capital markets to accelerate growth in Singapore and internationally. The proposed listing will provide funds for acquisitions and is expected to fuel the company's growth in the financial hub of Singapore.

site_title: Group show by artists from Silpakorn Uni
summary: A group of 10 young artists from Silpakorn University's Masters of Fine Arts program will hold their first collective show, featuring drawings, paintings, photographs, and sculptural installations. The Fingerprint group consists of recent and current graduate students from the university's fine arts and archaeology program. The show is a representation of the university's leading status in Thai fine arts and archaeology, and it will be displayed at an unspecified location.

images.alt_text: The show includes this work by Kanjana Chonsiri

site_title: In brief
summary: Singapore companies reported varying financial performances for the full year 2014.
