Amara Holdings posted a 32% increase in net profit to S$35.3 million, while Hotel Royal's net profit rose 15.9% to S$11.2 million. BAKER Technology's net profit fell 40%, but INNOVALUES Ltd saw a 82.2% increase. Interra Resource, however, posted a net loss of US$11.7 million due to impairment of oil and gas properties. Dividend recommendations ranged from 0.2 cent to five cents per share across the companies.

site_title: A different ballgame for United Envirotech?
summary: Chinese conglomerate Citic is set to acquire over 50% of Singapore-listed wastewater treatment company United Envirotech, potentially giving the company access to China's burgeoning wastewater treatment sector. Analysts predict water tariff hikes in China will drive growth in the sector, with United Envirotech's net profit forecast to grow 7% despite its limited capacity compared to competitors. However, investors may be disappointed as the company's acquisition is at a different time, and its valuations are rich, trading at a 31.6 price-earnings ratio. Citic's backing may take time to yield significant returns.

site_title: Maersk CEO ends four-year hiatus with plan to order new ships
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container line, is ending a four-year hiatus in ordering new ships, aiming to focus on smaller vessels due to the low oil price. CEO Nils Smedegaard Andersen plans to order new ships by 2017 to keep up with market growth, with a combined capacity of 425,000 standard-size containers. The decision marks a shift from the industry's strategy of building larger ships to save fuel. Maersk expects to invest $3 billion annually through 2019 on new vessels and retro-fitting current ships.

images.alt_text: Mr Andersen: "We're not making long-term plans based on what the oil price is exactly today, but nevertheless we're currently looking into what effect the low oil price should have on our vessel size."

site_title: MMA Offshore eyes global market out of Singapore
summary: MMA Offshore, an Australia-listed marine-services provider, is expanding into the global market from its Singapore office. The firm has converted its Tuas shipyard into an oil and gas mobilisation area and is focusing on newbuilds at its Batam facility. MMA's five-year strategic plan identifies East and West Africa, the Middle East, South-east Asia, and Australasia as key growth regions. The company posted a 55.7% rise in net profit to US$37.7 million for the half year ended Dec 31, driven by the addition of earnings from its Jaya Holdings acquisition.

site_title: DBS's old-style touch to usher in the Year of the Goat
summary: DBS launched a Chinese New Year celebration, honoring the Year of the Goat, by thanking its customers for their support. Chairman Peter Seah expressed confidence in the year ahead, citing the bank's successful Year of the Horse in 2014. DBS launched several initiatives to support SMEs and startups in 2014, including venture debt and online business account opening services. The bank remains committed to helping customers grow their businesses and improve banking services.

site_title: German unemployment falls to post-unification low
summary: German unemployment fell to 2.812 million in February, the lowest level since reunification in 1990, with a 6.5% unemployment rate. The decline was stronger than expected, with a seasonally-adjusted 20,000 decrease. The economy is expected to continue improving, with growth driven by private consumption and construction investment, according to the Federal Labour Office. Economists welcomed the data, citing the national minimum wage as having had no negative effect. The unemployment rate remains steady at 6.5%.

site_title: Property developer Hongkong Land focuses on staff development
summary: Hongkong Land, a property developer, has been recognized as one of the Best Employers in the industry, attributing its success to fostering a culture of teamwork, dedication, and professionalism. The company provides staff with learning and development opportunities, challenging work, and recognition for achievements. Hongkong Land also offers job rotations and overseas assignments to broaden employees' professional experiences. The company's "people mission" aims to create a healthy and challenging work environment that promotes job satisfaction and personal growth.

images.alt_text: Hongkong Land's office properties in Singapore include One Raffles Quay (above).

site_title: Qantas back in the black with A$203m H1 net
summary: Qantas reported a net profit of A$203 million for the first half of 2015, reversing a loss of A$235 million in the same period last year. The airline's transformation program delivered A$374 million in cost savings, with revenue and underlying profit before tax increasing 2.1% and 45% respectively. Qantas expects all operating units to be profitable for the full year, driven by steady demand, easing capacity growth, and lower fuel prices. The airline's shares rose 4 cents to A$2.85.

site_title: Evidence shows offer for Keppel Land is reasonable: KPMG
summary: KPMG Corporate Finance says the offer by Keppel Corp to take its real estate subsidiary Keppel Land private is reasonable despite being at a significant discount to the sum-of-the-parts estimated valuation range of S$6.58 to S$6.79 per share. The offer's base price and higher offer price represent significant premiums to the median share price and compare favourably to Keppel Land's listed peers and precedent transactions. The independent directors concur with KPMG's assessment, recommending that shareholders consider taking one of three routes, while Keppel Corp and Keppel Land's shares trade at S$8.77 and S$4.53 respectively.

site_title: Centurion Corp's Q4 net profit swells to S$72.9m on fair value gains
summary: Centurion Corp's Q4 net profit surged to S$72.9 million, driven by a S$40.3 million fair value gain on investment properties. Revenue jumped 74% to S$26.1 million, with the accommodation business growing 90%. The company reported a record full-year net profit of S$111.2 million, up 21% from last year. Centurion expects its accommodation business to remain "encouraging" and plans to unveil more details on its plans to set up a workers accommodation Reit, aiming to unlock value in certain assets and recycle capital.

site_title: US developers banking on buyers of million-dollar homes
summary: US developers are banking on buyers of million-dollar homes, with prices ranging from $1 million to upwards in new developments. Homebuyers like Lisa Gray are looking for properties that cater to multiple generations, with features such as game rooms and guest bedrooms. The high-end market is expected to continue, with no current indication of a decline.

site_title: Bloomberg to launch Canada TV channel by mid-2015
summary: Bloomberg LLP plans to launch a Canadian TV channel by mid-2015, highlighting domestic news makers and detailing global news' impact on Canadian business. The channel, in partnership with Channel Zero, will feature content from Toronto, Ottawa, Calgary, Montreal, Vancouver, and Winnipeg. Canada is one of Bloomberg's fastest-growing markets, according to founder Michael Bloomberg.

site_title: CIMB to cut about 50 jobs across Asia to reduce costs: sources
summary: CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, Malaysia's second-largest lender, plans to cut about 50 jobs in Asia to trim costs. The reductions involve mostly equities-related positions in Hong Kong, Taiwan, India, and South Korea. The move is part of the bank's efforts to reduce costs after expanding by purchasing Royal Bank of Scotland Group operations in 2012. CIMB also confirmed Acting Chief Zafrul Aziz as its group CEO and executive director, with a plan to cut investment-banking costs by 30% this year.

site_title: January household spending, retail sales in Japan seen falling
summary: Japan's households cut spending further and retail sales fell for the first time in seven months in January, data is likely to show. Household spending is recovering but only moderately due to stagnant wages. Factory output is expected to rise 2.7% in January, while core consumer price index is forecast to hit 0.3% in the year to January. The Bank of Japan's stimulus may not be convincing consumers of inflation, raising doubts on the strength of the recovery and meeting its inflation target.

site_title: Household mortgage loans grow record 10.2% in Korea
summary: South Korean households saw a record 10.2% growth in mortgage loans by the end of December, with total outstanding loans reaching 460.60 trillion won. This marks the fastest growth since records began in 2008. Household credit, including mortgage loans and credit purchases, also grew 6.6% to 1,088.98 trillion won, with annual growth matching September's rate, the highest since 2012. The robust growth in mortgage loans underscores a recovering property market but raises concerns about household debt risks for Asia's fourth-largest economy.

site_title: CAI consortium wins tender for Vladivostok airport shares
summary: A consortium led by Changi Airports International (CAI), the Russian Direct Investment Fund (RDIF), and Basic Element has won a tender to acquire 52.16% shares in Vladivostok International Airport in Russia. The consortium will also fully acquire the airport's terminal. Strategically located at the crossroads of two major air routes, Vladivostok International Airport has the potential to become a key Russian hub in the Asia-Pacific region, promoting economic development in the region. The deal is expected to close after regulatory approvals are obtained.

site_title: Greece and Europe: a family drama with major consequences
summary: Greece's newly elected Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is trying to clean up the country's economy after years of austerity policies. The country's dysfunctional family dynamic, where Greece is the rebellious child, is at an impasse with the Eurogroup over the existing bailout program. Tsipras must navigate between pleasing his left-wing supporters and adhering to European mores, promoting further integration and economic reforms to prevent Greece from becoming absorbed by the European establishment. A deal must be struck to balance fiscal austerity with growth-enhancing reforms to enable Greece's positive developments.

site_title: S'pore and Hong Kong must both prepare for the next lap
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong, both rapidly growing cities, share similarities as financial hubs and free economies. Hong Kong's strength lies in its role as a connector between China and the world, while Singapore is a key destination for foreign investment in the Asean region and India. Despite Hong Kong's decline in port rankings, experts believe both cities have unique niches and space for growth, with potential to become technology hubs. Singapore and Hong Kong must prepare for the next lap of growth, focusing on internal development to gain a leading edge.

site_title: Still in the game
summary: Rufus Wainwright, a folk-pop icon, continues to tour and perform despite his last album, Out of the Game, being almost three years old. The singer-songwriter, known for his family feuds in his songs, has been busy with side projects, including writing operas and classical pieces. He is set to perform in Singapore on March 17, playing a selection from his discography, including new songs about his daughter. Wainwright is also working on a second opera, set to premiere in Toronto in 2018, and has been writing songs in between.

site_title: The latest investment theme in Toronto is rental apartments
summary: Toronto's rental apartment market is experiencing a boom, driven by rising demand for leased space due to surging house prices and cooling condo market. At least 21 high-rise rental projects are slated for construction, with companies like Timbercreek Asset Management Inc. and Canadian Apartment Properties Reit benefiting from the trend. Rental companies are seeing high returns, with Timbercreek's internal rate of return reaching 20% and shares of Canadian Apartment Properties Reit up 13% this year. The demand for rental apartments is expected to continue, with developers citing affordability and faster, more profitable investment opportunities as key drivers.

site_title: Strata office units at GSH Towers slated for sale soon
summary: The GSH Corporation-led consortium plans to launch strata office units at GSH Plaza in Singapore, with sizes ranging from 440 to 1,600 sq ft and indicative pricing at S$2,900-3,600 psf. The building, formerly known as Equity Plaza, will undergo a massive refurbishment and will have 259 strata office units available for sale. The owners will retain the first two levels, which will have 21 retail units. The building has a balance lease of about 73 years and is expected to be completed in 18-24 months.

site_title: A people company for all seasons
summary: Hilti has won Aon Hewitt's Best Employers award for a fourth consecutive time, demonstrating its commitment to employee development. The company's focus on staff growth through job rotation and overseas postings has contributed to its success. Hilti Asia Pacific president Robbert Van Der Feltz emphasizes the importance of maintaining a people-focused approach, even during challenging times, as it tests the company's dedication to its values. This achievement highlights Hilti's dedication to its employees and its dedication to being a positive workplace.

images.alt_text: Bad times are the moments of truth for an employer to prove its word to employees, says Mr Van Der Feltz

site_title: Design as an intrinsic part of life
summary: Three designers, including Rodney Loh Jun Kern, will participate in Singapore Design Week. Loh, design director of NextOfKin Creatives, emphasizes the importance of design awareness in everyday life. He believes it is a valuable skillset that can be applied in various aspects of life. This highlights the growing recognition of design as a fundamental part of daily living, rather than just a professional field.

site_title: Flooding, commodity rout slash Sime Darby Q2 earnings by 47%
summary: Sime Darby, the world's largest listed palm oil producer, reported a 47% decline in Q2 net profit due to a commodities rout, flooding, and oversupply of competing oilseeds. Malaysian palm oil prices fell 9% in the October-December period, while global prices fell 15% over the year. The company's revenue inched up 0.3% to RM10.74 billion, while palm production fell 22% in December due to flooding. The company also announced a proposed takeover of New Britain Palm Oil for US$1.74 billion.

site_title: Swee Hong gets order against proceedings
summary: Swee Hong, a Singaporean contractor, has obtained a six-month restraining order from the High Court to prevent further proceedings against the company. This follows its application to propose a debt restructuring plan with three creditors. The order aims to bring stability to the company's operations and allow time to finalize the plan. Swee Hong will continue to operate normally and deliver ongoing construction projects, reassuring stakeholders that the filing of the application will not affect its commitment to these projects.

site_title: StanChart picks ex-JPMorgan man to take the helm in June
summary: Standard Chartered has appointed Bill Winters, a former JPMorgan executive, as its new group CEO, replacing Peter Sands in June. Winters, 53, lacks Asian experience and retail banking expertise, but Temasek Holdings, the bank's largest shareholder, welcomed his appointment. The bank also announced changes to its senior management and board, including the departure of Bindra and the retirement of three independent non-executive directors. The changes aim to reduce the board size to 14 directors and are part of the bank's multi-year succession plan.

site_title: Maybank's full-year profit rises 2.2% to RM6.72 billion in 2014
summary: Malayan Banking Bhd (Maybank) reported a 2.2% increase in full-year profit to RM6.72 billion in 2014, driven by a 11.5% profit surge in the last quarter. The bank proposed a single-tier final dividend of 33 sen per share, totaling 78.5% of net earnings. Maybank expects 2015 to be economically softer, with targets for return on equity (ROE) of 13-14% and group loans and deposit growth of 9-10%. The bank's international operations achieved the highest year-on-year income growth of 6.5%.

site_title: Deutsche Bank lands JPMorgan's Jeff Urwin for key role
summary: Deutsche Bank has hired Jeff Urwin, a former JPMorgan executive, to lead its investment-banking and trading unit, replacing Robert Rankin. Urwin will oversee debt and equity underwriting and be based in New York, while Colin Fan oversees trading from London. The move aims to boost revenue from advising clients on deals and selling securities, as low interest rates and tougher regulation crimp trading revenue. Deutsche Bank is seeking to expand in the US, where fees are more lucrative.

site_title: GM, Toyota take top spots in US study
summary: General Motors (GM) and Toyota took the top spots in J D Power's latest US vehicle dependability study, with both automakers tied for the most top ratings in 19 categories. Toyota's Lexus brand was rated best overall for the fourth straight year, followed by Buick at 110 problems per 100 vehicles. Connected-car technology issues, such as Bluetooth and voice recognition systems, were the top problems reported by owners, with vehicle owners expressing growing expectations for advanced technology capabilities.

site_title: Parkour caper is purely a star vehicle for Lautner
summary: Taylor Lautner stars in Tracers, a fast-paced but forgettable crime caper that prioritizes parkour and his on-screen chemistry with co-star Marie Avgeropoulos. The film checks off fan expectations, including Lautner performing his own stunts and shirtless scenes. However, the plot feels secondary and relies on cliches from straight-to-video action thrillers. Director Daniel Benmayor's parkour sequences are visually impressive, but later stunt scenes suffer from poor production values and shaky camerawork. The film receives a rating of C due to its lackluster storytelling and reliance on Lautner's star power.

site_title: Thai artist to hold solo show
summary: Thai artist Knakorn Kachacheewa is set to hold his first solo exhibition in Singapore, "The Jungle of Form, Colour and Tempo," from March 5-26. The exhibition features paintings that blend East and Western styles, focusing on human and animal characters inspired by personal experiences. Kachacheewa's technique emphasizes light and shadows, a Western concept, and his compositions have a surreal quality while remaining relatable. The exhibition is a showcase of his daily experiences and thoughts, drawing parallels with French painter Henri Rousseau's works.

images.alt_text: Knakorn Kachacheewa's composition has been described as a blend of East and West. His characters have a surreal quality but they remain real enough to relate to.

site_title: Noble says Iceberg author a former staff; group posts US$240m Q4 loss
summary: Noble Group, a commodities trader, reported its first quarterly loss in three years due to a heavy impairment charge on an associate. The company identified a former employee as the author of critical research reports, Iceberg Research, but will not take legal action. Noble's net quarterly loss was $240 million, and its full-year net profit was almost halved to $132 million. The company disputed Iceberg's claims of overstated contract values and said its accounting practices are in line with industry standards.

site_title: Rickmers Maritime posts DPU of 0.6 US cents in Q4
summary: Rickmers Maritime posted a Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.6 US cents, matching the previous year's quarter. Charter revenue declined 12% to US$31.9 million, mainly due to reduced charter rates. Net profit was US$11.2 million, reversing a Q4 loss of US$8.04 million in the previous year. Full-year charter revenue fell 9% to US$130.3 million, and DPU was 2.4 US cents. The company's CEO noted that the coming year may be more volatile due to expiring charter agreements.

site_title: Extending the value chain beyond science education
summary: A critical need exists for a supportive ecosystem to make STEM careers rewarding, enabling innovation. The UK and US are grappling with a perceived STEM labor shortage, prompting concerted efforts to promote STEM education. Record highs in STEM students have been achieved in the UK, while the US has launched initiatives like "Educate to Innovate" and invested $2.9 billion in STEM education. However, graduates often face career support challenges, and restrictive immigration laws force many STEM graduates to leave the country. To sustain STEM growth, countries need to develop an interrelated landscape of education, culture, career pathways, and funding, and create pull factors rather than benefiting from others' failures.

site_title: Aussie, NZ dollars move in opposite directions
summary: The Australian dollar fell 0.5% against the US dollar, euro, and yen, recovering after weak business investment numbers, while the New Zealand dollar gained 0.4% against the US dollar and yen following a surprise trade surplus. Expectations of US interest rate hikes have been pushed back to the second half of the year, and investors are now focusing on US consumer price data for further market direction.

site_title: Zendesk opens Asia-Pac headquarters in Singapore
summary: Zendesk has opened its Asia-Pacific headquarters in Singapore, expanding its existing office in the city-state. The move, which doubles the company's headcount to 80, is seen as a boost to jobs and intellectual property in the country. The company's founder, Mikkel Svane, cited Singapore's talent pool and supportive government as reasons for the decision. The expansion comes after Zendesk acquired Singapore-based live-chat startup Zopim last year, integrating its software into Zendesk's platform.

site_title: Petrol companies must come clean on latest increase in prices
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam announced a surprise 20- and 15-cent-per-litre increase in petrol duty to discourage car usage and reduce carbon emissions. However, three out of four petrol companies raised pump prices by up to 25 cents for 98-octane petrol, prompting the Competition Commission of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry to investigate. The petrol companies cited various factors for the price hike, but consumer watchdogs accused them of "profiteering". The authorities have vowed to take firm action against anti-competitive behavior, calling for greater transparency from the companies.

site_title: Creating a great place to work, grow
summary: The Aon Hewitt Best Employers awards in Singapore 2015 recognize companies that prioritize employee development and create a great place to work and grow. Winners, including McDonald's Singapore and Hilti Asia Pacific, offer formal learning schemes, internal promotions, and a positive work environment, leading to higher employee engagement, reduced job-hopping, and increased profits. The awards also highlight the importance of investing in people, with nearly four in five Best Employers' staff believing their senior management values their contributions.

site_title: Low taxes may be luxury for Hong Kong, Singapore
summary: Hong Kong and Singapore, known for their low taxes, are shifting towards addressing rising inequality. Singapore raised its top income tax rate, while Hong Kong resisted, focusing on growth instead. The Group of 20 and economists argue that inequality is a pressing issue, with the richest 1% expected to control most of the world's wealth by 2016. Development economists recommend increasing productivity, investing in education, and establishing secure safety nets to reduce inequality. Both cities' governments must adopt pragmatic measures to address the issue, or risk hollowing out the middle class and social unrest.

site_title: A taste of Europe in S'pore
summary: Salon Gourmet 2015, a year-long event, showcases top European restaurants and chefs in Singapore. The event features over 12 culinary events, including wine and spirits pairing dinners and cooking workshops, until March 31. Headliners include Michelin-starred guest masterchefs Ronan Kervarrec and Jean-Yves Leuranguer, and participating local chefs like Stephane Istel and Nicolas Reynard. The event aims to give Singaporeans a deeper appreciation of European cuisine and offer a "gastronomic experience" through cooking workshops and wine-pairing dinners.

site_title: QAF full-year profit up 49% to S$45.1m
summary: QAF Limited reported a net profit of S$45.1 million for the full year ended Dec 31, 2014, up 49% from S$30.2 million in 2013. Revenue remained flat at S$1.02 billion. The company attributed the increase to lower feed costs and staff costs for its pork business. QAF guided for a "comparable or better" level of profitability in the first quarter and expects sales increases in its main bakery and pork businesses for 2015.

site_title: RBS says Swiss private bank probed in Germany over tax evasion
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland's Coutts private bank is being investigated by German authorities over alleged tax evasion by clients. Current and former employees in Switzerland are being probed, with the bank cooperating with the authority. The probe risks dragging RBS into a political storm similar to HSBC's tax evasion scandal. RBS is seeking to sell its Zurich-based international unit, which could fetch $600-900 million, and is providing an indemnity to protect itself from potential buyers. The sale is nearing completion, with an announcement expected within the next couple of months.

site_title: Lee Kuan Yew still sedated in ICU
summary: Former Singapore Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, 91, remains sedated and on a ventilator in intensive care at the Singapore General Hospital, where he has been treated for severe pneumonia. He missed the Tanjong Pagar Chinese New Year dinner for the third consecutive year, as his doctors continue to monitor him closely. Lee's condition was previously stable, but his doctors have restarted him on antibiotics.

site_title: YHS net falls 22% to S$13.3m in Q4
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng's net profit for Q4 2014 fell 22% to S$13.3m, mainly due to absent net profit from its property division and lower fair value gains. Revenue dropped 3.3% to S$99.7m. The company's F&B division saw a 0.3% increase in revenue, but a lower segment profit of S$16.27m. A dividend of S$0.02 per share was proposed. The company's counter ended trading at S$1.70, one cent down.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance warns SMEs of headwinds
summary: Hong Leong Finance reported a 10.4% fall in full-year net profit to S$62.8 million, due to restructuring toll and increased doubtful debts. Despite low non-performing loans, the company warned SMEs of headwinds, citing a subdued property market and motor vehicle downturn. Net interest income rose 0.5%, while fee and commission income fell 20.9%. Hong Leong proposed a final dividend of six Singapore cents per share, with shares closing at S$2.67.

images.alt_text: Hong Leong Finance on Thursday warned of uncertainties and challenges among small and medium-enterprises amid the restructuring toll.

site_title: AIA Singapore posts 22% rise in new premiums in 2014
summary: AIA Singapore reported a 22% rise in new premiums in 2014, reaching US$489 million, driven by increased sales of protection, long-term savings, and legacy plans. Operating profit after tax rose 8% to US$429 million, while new business margin decreased 6.1 percentage points to 61.2%. The company attributes its growth to a strong agency force and expansion into bancassurance channels.

site_title: Billionaire's Moscow office block is two-thirds empty
summary: Roman Abramovich's Moscow office complex, White Gardens, is approximately two-thirds empty due to a supply glut and the Russian economy's slump. Despite securing new leases for less than 10% of the property's space, the complex remains largely vacant, with about a third occupied. The vacancy rate for high-quality office space in Moscow has risen to 29% at the end of 2014, driven by a decrease in oil prices and economic sanctions. Abramovich's other premium office blocks remain fully occupied, but the White Gardens complex is struggling to find new tenants amidst a surplus of office space in the city.

images.alt_text: Mr Abramovich has secured new leases accounting for less than 10% of White Gardens' 63,000 square metres of space.

site_title: More pay for hourly-wage workers in US
summary: US retail giant Wal-Mart is raising wages for hundreds of thousands of hourly workers, with employees set to make at least $10 an hour next year. The move aims to help workers make ends meet, particularly those with large families. Despite the wage increase, workers like Anthony Rodriguez, who already earns above-minimum wages, will still face financial challenges due to rising living costs.

images.alt_text: Mr Rodriguez, who works at Wal-Mart assembling bikes and barbecue sets, supports his fiancée and son on an income that can be as little as US$900 a month. He is assigned as little as 18 hours of work weekly.

site_title: US durable goods orders rise in January
summary: US durable goods orders rose 2.8% in January, the first increase in three months, driven by a 128.5% surge in commercial aircraft orders. Excluding transportation, orders rose 0.3%. Year-over-year, durable goods orders increased 1.6%. The increase was largely due to a rebound in the transportation sector, which had declined in the previous two months.

site_title: Revaluation gains lift Banyan's Q4 profit
summary: Banyan Tree, a resort operator, reported a 13% year-on-year rise in net profit to S$4.13 million in Q4 2014, driven by revaluation gains from properties in Seychelles. Revenue fell 6% to S$91.83 million, mainly due to lower sales in fee-based and hotel investment segments. The company's property sales division saw higher revenue.

images.alt_text: "The outlook for our planned property sales in Wenjiang, Chengdu, is positive," says Mr Ho

site_title: Japan's FSA explores opening market to Islamic finance
summary: Japan's Financial Services Agency (FSA) is exploring rules to allow banks to provide Islamic financial products in its domestic market for the first time. The move would make Japan's largest bond market more accessible to Islamic finance. Japanese lenders have already offered Islamic financial products through their overseas subsidiaries, and Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ (BTMU) recently issued the country's first Islamic bond. Relaxing rules could boost the Islamic finance sector, but would require addressing taxation challenges.

site_title: Dismal start to 2015 for manufacturing
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector started 2015 on a weak note, with factory output rising just 0.9% in January, below the market's consensus forecast of 3.3%. The sector's performance was broad-based, with only biomedical manufacturing and precision engineering showing growth. Economists now predict Q1 GDP growth will come in under the government's 2-4% forecast range, with some predicting a decline in Q1 GDP. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) may ease monetary policy further in April due to subdued inflation outlook and lower oil prices.

site_title: US: Stocks dip on mixed data
summary: US stocks dipped in opening trade on Thursday, with the Dow Jones falling 26.22 points to 18,198.35, and the S&P 500 shedding 3.20 points to 2,110.66. Mixed economic data, including a 2.8% rise in durable goods orders and a 0.7% decline in consumer prices, contributed to the market's indecisiveness. Initial jobless claims also rose to 313,000. Analysts characterized the data as "mixed," which may impact market action.

site_title: Malaysia to dish out more incentives for foreign investment
summary: Malaysia plans to increase incentives for foreign investment, aiming to bolster growth and propel the economy into a developed status by the end of this decade. The country approved a record 235.9 billion ringgit in direct investments in 2014, with domestic investments accounting for 73% and foreign investments for 27%. The government aims to create over 178,000 new jobs through these investments, and has already approved projects worth over 65 billion ringgit in manufacturing and services. The move is part of Prime Minister Najib Razak's efforts to reduce the country's dependence on oil and increase private sector-led investment.

site_title: US consumer prices fall 0.7% in January
summary: US consumer prices fell 0.7% in January, marking the first 12-month decline since 2009. The drop was driven by a 18.7% decrease in gasoline prices and a 9.7% decrease in energy prices. This was the third consecutive month of falling prices, primarily due to a global drop in crude prices. Food prices also remained soft, contributing to the overall decline.

site_title: UK business investment slips as oil prices fall, trade boosts GDP
summary: British business investment fell at its sharpest rate in nearly six years due to tumbling global oil prices affecting the North Sea petroleum industry. However, stronger exports contributed to a balanced economic growth of 0.5% in the fourth quarter of 2014. Economists raised concerns about the recovery, citing the second consecutive quarterly fall in business investment.

site_title: Q4 UK business investment slips as oil prices fall; GDP growth steady at 0.5%
summary: UK business investment declined 1.4% in Q4 2014, the largest drop in nearly six years, due to lower investment in the petroleum sector as oil prices fell. GDP growth remained steady at 0.5% in Q4, slowing from 0.7% in Q3. Household spending and the services industry continued to drive growth, while industrial output and construction declined. The slowdown has not deterred the UK's economic growth, which is forecast to reach 2.9% this year, its fastest growth in nearly a decade.

site_title: A tale told through sounds, lights and objects
summary: A Singaporean performance-installation, "OneTwoSix," at the Drama Centre Black Box, uses everyday objects to narrate a story through sounds and lights. Created by well-regarded theatre designers, the work explores the language of inanimate objects in space, aiming to share an expression rather than convey a message. The performance features a man surrounded by mundane objects, with a narrative emerging through the objects' sounds and lights. The show runs from March 5 to 7, with tickets allocated by pre-registration and donation basis.

site_title: Noble Group's FY14 profit tumbles 46%; writes off US$200m for Yancoal
summary: Noble Group's FY14 net profit plummeted 46% to $132 million due to rising losses on supply chain assets, despite a 4% increase in revenue to $85.8 billion. The group wrote off $438 million, including $200 million for Yancoal, a valuation criticized by Iceberg Research. The firm is set to provide further details on its rebuttal against the research firm in a conference call.

site_title: A great place for working and healing (Amended)
summary: Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) has won Aon Hewitt's Best Employers award for the second time, indicating progress in its "value-based" journey to become a "great place for working, healing, learning and becoming the best". The hospital engaged staff and patients to identify key values, resulting in initiatives such as nursing-shared governance and "creatively inclusive" health and well-being schemes. TTSH anchors its people strategy on three key initiatives, focusing on staff engagement, collaborative decision-making, and work-life balance. The hospital has over 7,000 staff members.

site_title: Li Ka-shing's companies post biggest profits in 15 yrs
summary: Li Ka-shing's companies, Cheung Kong Holdings Ltd and Hutchison Whampoa Ltd, reported record profits, with Cheung Kong's net income rising 53% to HK$53.9 billion (US$7 billion) and Hutchison's doubling to HK$67.2 billion. This comes ahead of Li's planned merger of the two companies, part of a US$29 billion reorganization. The reorganization, dubbed "Project Diamond," aims to streamline Li's vast business empire and prepare for his son Victor's takeover. Li's companies are also exploring new deals, including a potential purchase of British wireless carrier O2 for up to $16 billion.

site_title: Update: StanChart appoints ex-JPMorgan exec Winters as CEO to replace Sands
summary: Standard Chartered has appointed former JPMorgan executive Bill Winters as its new CEO, replacing Peter Sands, who will step down in June 2015. Sands, who became CEO in 2006, oversaw a period of significant change and challenge for the industry. Chairman John Peace praised Sands' leadership, while Winters brings experience as JPMorgan's investment bank head. The appointment is aimed at stabilizing the bank amid industry challenges.

site_title: KPMG finds offer to take Keppel Land private 'not fair but reasonable'
summary: Independent financial adviser KPMG has found Keppel Corp's offer to take its real estate subsidiary, Keppel Land, private to be "not fair but reasonable". The base offer price of $4.38 per share and higher offer price of $4.60 per share are at a significant discount to the sum-of-the-parts estimated valuation range of $6.58 to $6.79 per share. The offer is deemed reasonable due to significant premiums to the median share price, Keppel Corp's ownership stake, and favorable key valuation metrics.

site_title: UOL Group's FY2014 net profit falls 13% to S$686 million on lower fair value gains
summary: UOL Group's FY2014 net profit declined 13% to S$686 million, primarily due to lower fair value gains. Excluding fair value and other gains, pre-tax profit rose 21% to S$515.2 million. Revenue increased 29% to S$1.36 billion. The group proposed a 15 cents per share dividend for FY2014. Net asset value per share rose to S$9.71, and the counter closed 8 cents lower at S$7.73.

site_title: Elite Swiss private bankers still earning millions
summary: Elite Swiss private bankers continue to earn significant annual salaries, with top relationship managers earning up to $211,000. Despite industry pressures, including low interest rates and tax evasion crackdowns, successful bankers can still command millions in pay. Senior managers at Swiss private banks like EFG International AG can earn between $200,000 to $320,000 per year, driven by profitability and compliance. The industry's profitability varies, with over a third found unprofitable by KPMG, leading to evaluations of cost-cutting measures.

images.alt_text: The top Swiss private bankers overseeing funds for clients living outside the country can still command millions of dollars in annual pay, even as pressures on the industry mount, the head of EFG International AG said.

site_title: Europe: Shares steady after mixed earnings
summary: European shares remained steady in early trading on Thursday, taking a breather from a sharp two-month rally. Allianz fell 3.8% after its dividend rise disappointed, while the FTSEurofirst 300 index rose 0.1% to 1,543.44 points. The decline in Allianz was attributed to earnings lagging in its core insurance businesses and stalled results in its asset management unit. The mixed earnings results took a breather from the market's sharp rally, with the focus shifting to US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Thursday
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

Vietnam expressed surprise over the US announcement of tariffs on its garment industry, while the Asian garment industry braced for higher costs. In Malaysia, an agency plans to seize RM3 billion of assets from Daim Zainuddin. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Citigroup predicted a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index. In Thailand, Thaksin Shinawatra expressed confidence that his daughter's suspension as PM in an ethics case would be cleared. The UK economy shrank for the second month, dealing a fresh blow to Prime Minister Starmer.

images.alt_text: NOBLE Group, which halted the trading of its shares on Thursday after Iceberg Research launched its second litany of allegations against the commodities trading firm, said its auditors Ernst & Young have completed their review of their internal procedures and will sign off on the year-end accounts.

site_title: Goldman employees reaped US$2b from 2008 options
summary: Goldman Sachs employees exercised options worth US$2.03 billion in 2014, with over 96% of the contracts granted in 2008 as part of compensation for the financial crisis. Current partners accounted for a large portion of the payouts, with pretax gains of almost US$800 million from the 2008 options. The bank's senior leaders did not receive the options, and Goldman Sachs has cut employee compensation costs since the crisis, with US$12.7 billion in costs last year, down from a peak of US$20.2 billion in 2007.

images.alt_text: While Goldman Sachs Group Inc employees may get less compensation than in the past, many cashed in last year for a payday they've been awaiting since the depths of the financial crisis.

site_title: Sime Darby to defer motor business IPO
summary: Malaysian conglomerate Sime Darby Bhd will delay the initial public offering (IPO) of its auto business to the second half of 2015 due to unfavorable market conditions. The IPO was initially planned for the middle of the year and could raise approximately US$500 million. The auto division, which distributes high-end brands like Jaguar and Ferrari, accounts for nearly 37% of Sime Darby's group revenue. The delay is attributed to the current market environment.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 5.01 points to 1820.87. A total of 1.89 billion lots were traded, worth RM2.03 billion, with 503 gainers outnumbering 347 losers.

site_title: Malaysia's AirAsia posts first net loss in two years
summary: Malaysia's AirAsia reported its first net loss in two years, with a quarterly loss of 428.5 million ringgit (S$161.4 million) in the fourth quarter. The airline cited higher financing and operating costs, as well as foreign-exchange losses, contributing to the loss. Revenue rose 15% to 1.5 billion ringgit. This marks the first net loss for AirAsia since 2012.

site_title: Chinese stocks advance to 4-week high
summary: Chinese stocks reached a 4-week high, with the Shanghai Composite Index rising 2.2% to 3,298.36, as industrial and financial companies rallied amid speculation of government stimulus to cushion the economic slowdown. Premier Li Keqiang called for more active fiscal policy, while a central bank publication suggested additional monetary easing is needed. The National People's Congress convenes in March, when the government sets its growth target for the year.

site_title: Update: Noble says auditor EY seeks more time, refutes Iceberg's fresh allegations
summary: NOBLE Group halted trading of its shares after Iceberg Research launched its second set of allegations against the commodity trading firm, claiming its profits are overstated due to unrealized commodities contracts. The auditors, Ernst & Young, requested more time to review their internal processes before signing off on the group's annual accounts. Noble denies the allegations, stating they are without substance and will proceed with publishing the 2014 year-end results as scheduled. Iceberg believes Noble is engaging in accounting manipulation and that the company's performance indicators will be impacted by the overstated fair values.

site_title: RHT Holdings eyes Catalist listing in 2016
summary: RHT Holdings, a professional services group, is planning to list on Singapore's Catalist board by the first quarter of 2016. The company, which includes RHT Capital, Compliance Solutions, Corporate Advisory, and Management Services, is preparing for the listing.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance full-year profit falls 10% on allowances for bad debt
summary: Hong Leong Finance reported a 10.4% fall in full-year net profit to S$62.8 million, due to an allowance for doubtful debts of S$2.02 million. This compared to a writeback of S$2.34 million the previous year. Net interest income increased 0.5% and fee income fell 20.9%. The decline in profit was attributed to standard industry practice of immediately topping up general prudential provision when the loan book grew in 2014.

site_title: Singapore: Stocks dragged down by Jardine and banks
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 14.65 points to 3,426.18, weighed down by Jardine and banks. Turnover was below average, with 188 rises and 225 falls. The decline contrasts with Hong Kong's 0.5% gain. No clear reason for the selling was found, with speculation pointing to program selling ahead of anticipated US market weakness.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close up slightly, underperform mainland rally
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.5% to 24,902.06, following a strong rally on Chinese markets, but underperformed due to selling of heavyweights like Sands China, affected by China's anti-corruption campaign. The China Enterprises Index gained 1.4% to 12,227.75 points, with 1.9 billion shares traded.

site_title: QAF 2014 net profit up 49% to S$45.1m
summary: QAF Limited reported a 49% increase in net profit to S$45.1 million for the 2014 year-end, driven by higher selling prices and productivity gains at its Australian pork production business, Rivalea. Revenue remained flat at S$1.02 billion. The company declared a final dividend of 4 Singapore cents per share, unchanged from last year.

site_title: German consumer morale hits highest level in more than 13 years
summary: German consumer morale reached its highest level in over 13 years, increasing to 9.7 points in February, surpassing the Reuters forecast of 9.5 points. The boost in consumer sentiment is attributed to low oil prices, freeing up cash for households to spend on other items. Private consumption has become the main driver of Germany's economic growth, with a 3.4% wage increase for 3.7 million workers. Consumers remain optimistic about the economy, expecting continued growth due to low inflation, a weak euro, and low energy costs.

site_title: Music industry moves to Friday global album release
summary: The music industry has agreed to release albums globally on Fridays, ending regional variations that have fueled piracy. The decision, after nine months of consultation, is expected to take effect by summer in the Northern Hemisphere. A global release date aims to bring more excitement to the industry and direct consumers to the legitimate market, reducing the need to seek out albums on pirate sites. Key groups representing music retailers, record companies, and artists have coordinated the plan, with broad support but no legal ramifications for those who prefer alternative release dates.

images.alt_text: The music industry has announced an agreement to release albums globally on Fridays, ending divergences among regions that have fuelled piracy in an age of instant music.

site_title: Indian state-owned banks may need more capital for Basel III
summary: India's state-owned banks may need more capital than the estimated 2.4 trillion rupees (US$38.73 billion) to fulfill Basel III requirements, according to Reserve Bank of India Deputy Governor SS Mundra. Mundra also stated that restricting capital infusion to just a few state-owned banks based on performance is not the right time, citing the need for broader support.

site_title: CIMB to cut some 50 jobs across Asia
summary: CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, Malaysia's second-largest lender, plans to cut approximately 50 jobs in Asia to trim costs. The reductions primarily involve equities-related positions in Hong Kong, Taiwan, India, and South Korea. This move is part of the company's efforts to reduce costs after expanding operations in 2012. CIMB aims to cut investment-banking costs by 30% this year due to slower growth, following other financial firms such as Standard Chartered and CLSA Ltd, which have also cut staff in Asia amid tougher regulations and higher capital requirements.

site_title: Australia: Shares retreat from 7-year high, NZ shares storm to new record
summary: Australian shares retreated 0.6% from a seven-year high on Thursday, closing at 5908.5, due to weak economic data and mixed corporate earnings reports. New Zealand's NZX 50 index reached a fresh all-time closing high of 5861.7, adding 0.3%. The US stock market also edged down from records amid tariff threats, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh highs despite uncertainty.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks up 1.08% to fresh 15-year high
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.08% to a 15-year high, driven by dip buying after the previous day's fall and gains in energy shares due to higher oil prices. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 18,785.79, while the Topix index rose 0.93%. The gains follow a 15-year high set on February 26, 2015.

site_title: Swiss Space keen to build Spaceport in Croatia
summary: Swiss Space Systems plans to build a 60 million-euro spaceport in Udbina, southern Croatia, by 2017, offering zero-gravity flights to tourists. The spaceport will be the second in Europe for the company, which also operates in Switzerland. Croatia aims to boost tourism revenue, which accounts for about one-fifth of the country's economy. Zero-gravity flights will initially be offered from 15km above ground, with luxury options priced from 2,000 to 50,000 euros per passenger, and later suborbital flights to space and intercontinental destinations.

site_title: Bill to restrict protests sails through Thai parliament
summary: Thailand's parliament voted overwhelmingly in favor of a bill restricting political demonstrations, imposing restrictions on the "time, place, and manner" of protests. The law aims to give order to public gatherings, but critics fear it will stifle dissent and maintain the junta's largely unchallenged rule. The bill must pass two more readings to become law, and would ban protests outside courts, parliament, and government offices, as well as restrict nighttime gatherings. Critics argue the law is inconsistent with Thailand's human rights obligations.

site_title: Hot stocks: StarHub shares down 2.5% on broadband competition worries
summary: StarHub shares fell 2.5% to S$4.30 on Thursday due to concerns over intense competition in the broadband space. Despite a 10% increase in Q4 net profit to S$94.2 million, the telco's broadband revenue declined 15.3% and monthly average revenue per user (ARPU) hit a historic low of S$34. Analysts expect FY15 service revenue to grow in the low single-digit range, driven by enterprise fixed network and mobile services. StarHub maintained its Ebitda margin guidance at 32% despite the price competition worries.

site_title: Maersk to buy new ships
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container line, plans to order new ships for the first time in four years amid the industry's recovery from a four-decade crisis. CEO Nils Smedegaard Andersen stated that the company may focus on smaller vessels due to the low oil price, which reduces the benefits of larger ships. This shift marks a departure from the industry's strategy of building larger vessels to save fuel since containerization in the 1970s. Maersk's recent mega-ship project was in 2011, and the company is currently exploring the impact of low oil prices on vessel size.

site_title: Seoul: Shares retreat from 5-mth high; builders rally on robust housing market
summary: South Korean shares retreated 0.2% to 1,986.57 points, ending a six-day winning streak. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) was influenced by investors consolidating gains, with concerns over Greece's debt easing. Builders outperformed the market, driven by an improving housing market. Shares in Daewoo Engineering & Construction and Samsung C&T surged, while Asiana Airlines soared 7.5% on reports of private equity interest in its parent firm. The South Korean won drifted lower against the dollar, and March futures on three-year treasury bonds shed 1 basis points.

site_title: Swee Hong obtains court order to restrain proceedings against it for six months
summary: Swee Hong, a Singapore-listed construction firm, has obtained a six-month court order to restrain further proceedings against it. The order aims to bring stability to the company's operations and allow it to finalize a debt restructuring plan. The company will continue to operate as usual, providing customer services, while implementing the plan. This follows its application to propose a debt restructuring plan for three creditors. The court's decision strengthens Swee Hong's ability to perform its obligations under ongoing public sector construction contracts.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble halts trading as Iceberg lashes out with fresh allegations; 3rd report coming
summary: NOBLE Group halted trading after Iceberg Research released its second report, alleging that Noble's profits are overstated due to booking fair value gains on long-term offtake agreements upfront. Iceberg claims Noble's operating cash flows are weak, and its debt reporting is misleading. The anonymous group will release a third report focusing on Noble's debt and governance issues.

site_title: South Korea legalises adultery
summary: South Korea's Constitutional Court has struck down a 60-year-old statute outlawing adultery, ruling it unconstitutional. The decision, made by a 7-2 bench, means violators will no longer face up to two years in prison. The law, which made South Korea one of the few non-Muslim countries to consider marital infidelity a crime, was challenged by arguments that state power should not intervene in individuals' private lives. The ruling comes as societal trends in South Korea continue to shift, reflecting a changing public perception of individuals' rights in their sexual lives.

site_title: Seoul: Shares push winning streak to 7 days; won edges higher
summary: South Korean shares rose for a seventh consecutive session, driven by Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's hints on interest rate hikes. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) gained 0.13% to 1,993.08 points, a five-month high. The won edged higher against the dollar, supported by exporter demand for month-end settlements.

images.alt_text: South Korean shares reversed early losses to close higher for a seventh consecutive session on Thursday, with risk appetites underpinned by Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's hints that the central bank was in no hurry to raise interest rates.

site_title: India to invest US$137b on railways in next 5 years
summary: India plans to invest US$137 billion in its railway network over the next five years, with a focus on modernizing existing tracks. The investment, 8.5 trillion rupees, will be funded through a combination of market borrowing and multi-lateral lenders. Railway Minister Suresh Prabhu promised to raise funds from infrastructure and pension funds, but not to privatize the railways. The goal is to transform the railways over the next five years, but no specific details were provided.

site_title: Gold holds above US$1,200 on view US rate rise will be delayed
summary: Gold prices rose for the second consecutive session, holding above $1,200 an ounce, as Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen indicated the US interest rate hike would be delayed this year. Investors believed the delay would support gold prices, and firm Chinese physical demand also contributed to the increase. The spot price rose 0.3% to $1,208.50 an ounce, with premiums on the Shanghai Gold Exchange remaining firm. Yellen's comments suggested the Fed would be flexible in raising rates, supporting market thinking that a rate hike would occur later this year.

site_title: BOJ Ishida: Shouldn't ease further just to hit price goal at a set timing
summary: Bank of Japan board member Koji Ishida expressed concerns that easing monetary policy further to hit a 2% inflation target may not be necessary. Ishida suggested that the BOJ should adjust policy only if there's a significant risk of Japan's economy failing to achieve stable price growth. The BOJ has maintained steady monetary policy since October last year, aiming to prevent deflation from delaying a sustained economic expansion.

site_title: BOJ Kuroda says no ceiling set on its balance sheet expansion
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated there's no ceiling on the central bank's balance sheet expansion relative to Japan's GDP. The BOJ's balance sheet has grown to 277 trillion yen, nearly two-thirds of Japan's GDP, due to aggressive asset purchases. Kuroda also said core consumer inflation is expected to reach 2% by March 2017, meeting the central bank's target. He disputed claims that the stimulus program is ineffective, citing ongoing discussions and the need for a more thorough assessment of the exit strategy.

site_title: Australia to introduce country-of-origin labelling
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Tony Abbott has backed plans to introduce country-of-origin labelling for food products, following a hepatitis A outbreak linked to berries sold by Patties Foods Ltd. The move, aimed at increasing transparency for consumers, may risk WTO rules. Cabinet members are tasked with drafting legislation by the end of March, reversing a previous stance that the law would increase food costs.

site_title: Singapore January factory output rises 0.9%, comes under expectations
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector expanded 0.9% in January, missing market expectations of a 3.3% increase. The biomedical manufacturing cluster drove growth, rising 5.3%, while other sectors like transport engineering, chemicals, and general manufacturing contracted. Excluding biomedical, total manufacturing output would have been unchanged. Industrial production contracted 4.7% month-over-month, worse than anticipated.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE'S manufacturing sector expanded less than expected in January, with factory output rising just 0.9 per cent on a year-on-year basis - far lower than the market's consensus forecast of a 3.3 per cent increase.

site_title: Update 2: Noble refutes Iceberg's claims, says auditors will sign off on accounts, will lift trading halt on Feb 27
summary: Noble Group, a commodities trading firm, has responded to allegations made by Iceberg Research, stating that the claims are "materially and factually inaccurate." The company's auditors, Ernst & Young, have completed their review and will sign off on the year-end accounts. Noble will lift the trading halt on February 27, as previously scheduled. The company denies overstating profits due to unrealised commodities contracts and asserts that its core businesses are in robust health. Iceberg Research claims that Noble's profits are overstated by at least $3.8 billion, but Noble maintains that its profit recognition policy is conservative and risk-managed.

site_title: South Korea Q4 household mortgage loan growth hits record high
summary: South Korea's household mortgage loan growth reached a record high of 10.2% in Q4, surpassing the previous record since 2008. Mortgage loans rose to 460.60 trillion won, with overall household credit growing 6.6% to 1,088.98 trillion won. This robust growth in mortgage loans indicates a recovering property market but raises concerns about heavy household debt in Asia's fourth-largest economy.

site_title: Malaysia's Sime Darby Q2 net profit plunges 47%
summary: Malaysia's Sime Darby Bhd, the world's largest listed palm oil producer, reported a 47% decline in its second-quarter net profit to 437.4 million ringgit, mainly due to weak commodity prices. Revenue increased 0.3% to 10.74 billion ringgit. The decline follows a 15% drop in palm oil prices in 2014.

images.alt_text: Sime Darby Bhd, the world's biggest listed palm oil producer, announced on Thursday a 47 per cent tumble in its second-quarter profit, dragged by weak commodity prices.

site_title: Thailand to hold 4G auction as planned
summary: Thailand will proceed with its planned auction for fourth-generation (4G) mobile spectrum in September as scheduled, despite concerns of a delay. Deputy Prime Minister Pridiyathorn Devakula announced the decision, stating the industry regulator will oversee the bidding process. The move aims to help shares of top mobile operators recover from losses caused by speculation of a delay.

site_title: Australia researchers create 'world first' 3D-printed jet engines
summary: Australian researchers at Monash University have successfully created two 3D-printed jet engines, dubbed a "world-first." The engines were produced using a template from French aircraft engine maker Safran, and demonstrated the potential of 3D printing to produce high-quality products. The achievement has garnered interest from major manufacturers and engineering firms, with Safran and Airbus recognizing the quality of the printed materials. This breakthrough highlights the significance of 3D metal printing in producing aircraft-quality components.

site_title: Cyber thugs taking data hostage
summary: A Northern California marriage therapist, Valerie Goss, fell victim to ransomware that encrypted her files, demanding $500 in Bitcoin to restore access. Despite the threat, she refused to pay and instead bought a new computer and fortified it with security software. Cybersecurity experts agree that paying the ransom is often futile, with no guarantee of data recovery. Ransomware has made a comeback, targeting smartphones and mobile devices, and experts warn that people should be cautious of suspicious links and updates to prevent infection.

site_title: Australia: Shares pull back from 7-yr high amid sluggish economy, earnings
summary: Australian shares retreated 0.5% from a 7-year high amid weak economic data and mixed corporate earnings reports. Business investment fell more than expected in the fourth quarter, while companies' spending plans were slightly weaker than anticipated. Major index movers such as Qantas and Ramsay Health Care posted upbeat profits, while Transfield Services fell 10% due to disappointing earnings. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5916.60 points.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks dragged down by techs, banks
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.7% in mid-morning trading on February 26, 2015, dragged down by technology and financial shares. The main TAIEX index dropped to 9,632.79, with the electronics sub-index falling 0.8% and the financial sub-index 0.4%. The Taiwan dollar rose 0.3% to T$31.429 to the US dollar.

site_title: End of stamp-duty concession may push S-Reits to acquire assets overseas: Moody's
summary: Moody's warns that the end of Singapore Reits' (S-Reits) stamp-duty concession on March 31, 2015, may prompt them to acquire assets overseas due to increased costs for local properties. The stamp duty will increase the total purchase consideration for a S$100 million property by S$246,000, potentially weakening the trust's leverage. Smaller-balance-sheet S-Reits may be particularly affected, as fully debt-funded acquisitions will exceed the increase in their asset base. This could lead to S-Reits shifting their focus to overseas markets.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.90 points to 1813.88. The market saw 47.12 million lots traded worth RM27.7 million, with 106 gainers outnumbering 67 losers.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Thursday, snapping a five-day winning streak, after profit taking. The Nikkei 225 index added 0.01% to 18,587.87, driven by higher oil prices and gains in energy companies. The dollar strengthened to 118.82 yen, while the euro bought US$1.1361. US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen provided no fresh clues on a potential rate increase, signaling the central bank's patience.

site_title: Lee Kuan Yew still in ICU, remains sedated
summary: Former Singapore Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew remains sedated and in intensive care at Singapore General Hospital, where he was first admitted on Feb 5 with severe pneumonia. His doctors have restarted him on antibiotics and are closely monitoring him. Lee, 91, is on mechanical ventilation and is a member of parliament for Tanjong Pagar GRC. His condition has not been updated since the last statement from the Prime Minister's Office.

site_title: Lenovo website breached, hacker group Lizard Squad claims responsibility
summary: Lenovo's website was hacked by the group Lizard Squad, which claimed responsibility on its Twitter page. The hacking occurred days after the US government advised Lenovo customers to remove the pre-installed "Superfish" software, which makes devices vulnerable to attacks. The website displayed a defacement page with a slideshow and song, while hackers posted screenshots of an email between Lenovo employees. CloudFlare, a security firm, seized the hacked domain and restored service before Lenovo recovered it. The "Superfish" program is vulnerable to SSL spoofing, allowing remote attackers to read encrypted web traffic.

site_title: Malaysia Maybank Q4 net up 11.5% on higher Islamic banking income
summary: Malayan Banking Bhd (Maybank), Malaysia's largest bank, reported an 11.5% rise in fourth-quarter profit to 1.93 billion ringgit (S$726.6 million), driven by higher interest income and Islamic banking income. Revenue rose 16.8% to 9.7 billion ringgit. The bank's net profit was up from 1.73 billion ringgit in the same quarter last year.

images.alt_text: Malayan Banking Bhd (Maybank), Malaysia's largest bank by assets, posted on Thursday an 11.5 per cent rise in fourth-quarter profit, driven by higher interest income and Islamic banking income.

site_title: China: Shares mixed in morning trade
summary: Chinese shares were mixed on Thursday morning, with the Shanghai Composite Index down 0.21% and the Shenzhen Composite Index up 0.13%. Trading remained sluggish following a week-long holiday. The benchmark indexes closed at 3,222.15 and 1,600.32, respectively.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks dropped 0.26% in early trade on February 26, 2015, following Wall Street's mixed corporate earnings. The benchmark Hang Seng Index fell 65.19 points to 24,713.09.

site_title: Australia business investment at 3yr low, outlook tough
summary: Australia's business investment fell to a three-year low in the fourth quarter of 2014, with a 2.2% decline to A$37.47 billion. The drop is attributed to miners retrenching due to sliding commodity prices, and analysts predict a further decline in investment to A$32 billion by 2017. This has led to speculation of another interest rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia, with a 2% cash rate expected next week, amid a sluggish economic growth.

images.alt_text: Australian business investment fell to a three-year low last quarter as miners retrenched in the face of sliding commodity prices, a black mark for the economy that adds to the case for further cuts in interest rates.

site_title: Indonesia's central bank says no target level for rupiah
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, does not have a target level for the rupiah, but will intervene in the foreign exchange market to manage volatility. The rupiah fell to a 10-week low due to the strengthening US dollar, not due to Bank Indonesia's interest rate cut last week. The bank's Governor Agus Martowardojo said the focus is on improving domestic conditions, and the central bank remains on alert for global financial changes, including the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy normalization.

site_title: Global Invacom's FY14 earnings down 37% on higher expenses; dividend proposed
summary: Global Invacom reported a 36.5% decline in net profit to US$5.1 million for FY14, despite a 15.9% increase in revenue to US$134.1 million. Higher administrative expenses, research and development costs, and one-off fees contributed to the decline. Excluding these costs, the group would have recorded a net profit of US$8.9 million. Global Invacom proposed a first and final dividend of 0.525 Singapore cent per share for FY14.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, Centurion, Global Invacom, Pacific Radiance, Banyan Tree, StarHub, Sheng Siong
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies reported varying quarterly results, with Noble Group halting trading after allegations of overstated profits, and Global Invacom reporting a 36.5% slump in net profit. Centurion Corp's net profit soared to S$72.97 million, driven by a fair-value gain on investment properties. Banyan Tree's net profit increased 13% despite a 6% drop in revenue. StarHub posted a 10% increase in quarterly net profit, while Sheng Siong reported a 26.5% increase in net profit. Pacific Radiance's net profit fell 69% due to softer market conditions.

site_title: Noble overstated commodity values by at least US$3.8b: Iceberg Research
summary: Singapore-listed Noble Group Ltd overstated the value of commodities it holds by at least US$3.8 billion, according to a report by Iceberg Research. This finding impacts Noble's performance indicators, causing its shares to fall 13% in two trading sessions. The company has yet to comment on the report, which is its second this month raising questions about Noble's accounting practices. Trading in Noble's shares was halted pending an announcement, and the company is set to report its results later in the day.

site_title: Dollar slips as Yellen signals steady path on rate hike
summary: The US dollar fell against other major currencies as Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen signaled a steady path on interest rates, indicating no hurry to raise rates this year. Yellen's testimony provided no fresh clues on the timing of a potential rate increase, which is seen as occurring in June. The recent dollar decline suggests investors were hoping for more from Yellen, but a rate hike in June remains a realistic possibility.

site_title: Brent falls towards US$61 as US crude stocks weigh
summary: Brent crude oil prices fell towards US$61, reversing previous gains, due to bulging US crude stockpiles. Despite earlier gains of over 30% in nearly two weeks, oil prices were weighed down by rising US crude stocks, which reached a seasonal record high of 434.1 million barrels. Refineries trimmed output, contributing to the stockpile growth. Production exceeds demand in the US, according to analyst Ric Spooner, highlighting a conflict between supply and demand.

images.alt_text: Brent crude fell towards US$61 on Thursday, reversing previous gains as a bulging US crude stockpiles offset glimpses of an oil demand recovery.

site_title: Banyan Tree's Q4 profit rises 13%, but revenue hit by weaker European demand
summary: Banyan Tree reported a 13% increase in net profit to S$4.13 million for Q4 2014, driven by a gain on revaluation of investment properties in Seychelles. Revenue dropped 6% to S$91.83 million due to weaker European demand, particularly from China projects and hotel operations affected by the European market slowdown.

site_title: First industries to get sectoral manpower plans identified
summary: The Singapore government has identified the first sectors to receive sectoral manpower plans under the SkillsFuture movement. These sectors include healthcare, early-childhood care, social services, biopharmaceuticals, food services, and retail. The plans will outline required skillsets, career tracks, and talent attraction and development strategies. The goal is to uplift small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and provide opportunities for Singaporeans to develop their careers across the economy, with a focus on lifelong learning and industry collaboration.

site_title: Pacific Radiance's Q4 profit falls 69% in difficult operating climate
summary: Pacific Radiance, a provider of offshore marine services in Asia, reported a 69% decline in Q4 net profit to US$5.05 million due to softer market conditions. Revenue fell 12% to US$37.21 million, while full-year net profit rose 20% to US$68.32 million. The company secured long-term charters worth over US$200 million for its newbuilds, indicating it is well-positioned to weather the challenging business environment.

site_title: Donald Trump serious about 2016 presidential run: Washington Post
summary: Businessman Donald Trump is reportedly serious about running for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination, citing the country's "serious trouble." Trump, 68, has hired prominent political advisers and has expressed a desire to delay his TV plans for next year. He joins a growing field of potential candidates, including Marco Rubio, Scott Walker, and Jeb Bush. Trump has previously toyed with a presidential run but has never entered the race.

site_title: Insurer AIA Group profit rises 22% on China sales
summary: AIA Group Ltd, Asia's third-largest life insurer, reported a 22% rise in annual profit to a record US$3.45 billion, exceeding analysts' expectations. The company attributed the growth to strong sales in its core markets of Hong Kong and China, with a 24% increase in the value of new business to US$1.85 billion. Under CEO Mark Tucker, AIA has grown its life insurance network and become the largest foreign insurance player in mainland China. The company's profit rise is seen as a positive sign for the Asian insurance industry.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open lower on Thursday after mixed earnings in US
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index down 3.88 points to 3,436.95, following mixed corporate earnings in the US. Genting Singapore broke its S$1 resistance on Wednesday but remained flat at S$0.98. Noble halted trading after a second attack by short-seller Iceberg Research. Despite a 5-day rally, investors are cautious ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Centurion's Q4 profit gets major boost from fair value gain on investment properties
summary: Centurion Corp reported a Q4 net profit of S$72.97 million, a 170% increase from the previous year, driven by a S$40.31 million fair value gain on its investment properties. Revenue rose 74% to S$26.11 million, boosted by new student accommodation assets in the UK and increased capacity for workers' accommodation. The company's accommodation business accounted for 92% of the net profit, and its balance sheet remains healthy with S$63.1 million in cash and cash equivalents.

site_title: Google unveils reorganisation in Europe
summary: Google is reorganizing its European operations amid a tougher regulatory environment, simplifying its structure and responding to customer and policymaker needs. The move comes as Google faces pressure on compliance with the "right to be forgotten" rule and an ongoing antitrust investigation by EU officials. The reorganization, led by executive Matt Brittin, aims to unify two separate divisions and respond to competitive pressures from Silicon Valley rivals. The changes also come as Google faces tax pressures and controversy over its content moderation policies in various European countries.

site_title: Australian PM strikes conciliatory note over Indonesia executions
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott spoke with Indonesian President Joko Widodo about the looming execution of two Australian convicted drug traffickers, Myuran Sukumaran and Andrew Chan. Abbott said Widodo "absolutely understands" Australia's position and is "carefully considering Indonesia's position." The Indonesian leader has denied clemency, despite repeated pleas for mercy. The conversation was seen as a positive sign of the friendship between the two countries, but executions are still planned to be carried out by firing squads.

site_title: UK consumers more confident as pay grows, inflation falls: survey
summary: British consumers have become more confident in their finances, with economic optimism reaching its highest level since September, according to a YouGov survey. Faster pay growth and low inflation are contributing factors, with only 12% of consumers reporting worsening finances over the last month. This rebound in optimism comes ahead of the national election in the UK.

site_title: Ukraine central bank abruptly reverses currency trading ban
summary: Ukraine's central bank unexpectedly banned most currency trading on February 25, 2015, only to reverse the decision overnight, causing market chaos. The ban halted trading between banks, putting the currency's value in limbo. The International Monetary Fund expressed readiness to assist Ukraine with foreign currency issues. The ban's reversal led to a surge in dollar buying by the central bank, but traders warned that demand for dollars would be pushed back, potentially driving the currency lower.

images.alt_text: People walk past a board showing currency exchange rates in central Kiev on Feb 25, 2015. Ukraine's central bank defended its decision on Wednesday to ban most foreign currency trading for the rest of the week, after sharp criticism of the move by Prime Minister Arseny Yatseniuk.

site_title: A look at history makes a case for loan default and Grexit
summary: A 1957 EU treaty's goal of an "ever-closer union" among Europeans is under threat due to the Greek economic crisis and EU's own shortcomings. The IMF's intervention in Greece's debt crisis exposed cracks in the eurozone, with the Fund lending to a country not fully accountable for its debt. The crisis highlights the EU's refusal to contemplate debt reduction, resulting in uncertainty and aggravating the contraction in Greek output. The IMF's admission that Greece's debt is unsustainable but proceeded with the program due to fear of global economic repercussions. A Greek default and exit from the eurozone could allow Greece to correct past mistakes and put its economy on a path to recovery, with the EU potentially following suit to unravel the currency union and provide debt reduction for distressed economies.

site_title: Qantas back in black after stemming losses
summary: Qantas has posted a strong first-half net profit of A$203 million, reversing a net loss of A$235 million in the same period in 2013. The airline's underlying profit before tax was A$367 million, driven by lower fuel prices and cost-cutting measures. Thousands of jobs were axed, aircraft deliveries were deferred, and growth at Jetstar was frozen as part of a five-year cost-cutting strategy. The result vindicates CEO Alan Joyce's strategy to slash A$2.0 billion in costs and improve the airline's financial position for growth.

site_title: Citigroup unit probed by more authorities over money laundering
summary: Citigroup's Banamex USA unit is under investigation by multiple authorities, including the US Treasury and California Department of Business Oversight, over possible breaches of anti-money laundering laws. The probe follows a 2013 loss on loans to Mexican homebuilding companies and a 2014 disclosure of losses from apparent fraud in lending to a supplier of Pemex. Citigroup is cooperating with the investigations and has reduced its estimated legal costs to $4 billion. The company is also preparing for the departure of CEO Manuel Medina-Mora, who will retire in June.
