images.alt_text: Citigroup Inc said additional government authorities have started probes of possible breaches of anti-money laundering laws at its Banamex USA unit.

site_title: Morgan Stanley reaches US$2.6 billion mortgage deal with US
summary: Morgan Stanley agreed to pay US$2.6 billion to settle probes into its creation and sale of residential mortgage-backed securities. The settlement follows previous regulatory actions against the firm, including a US$1.25 billion payment last year and a US$275 million settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The agreement cuts 2014 income from continuing operations by US$2.7 billion, or US$1.35 a share. This is the fourth time in the past five quarters that Morgan Stanley has reduced earnings following an earnings announcement.

site_title: EU gives France until 2017 to cut deficit; Italy, Belgium in clear
summary: The European Commission gave France a two-year extension to reduce its budget deficit, allowing it to avoid a fine and setting a new deadline of 2017. France had repeatedly missed EU-imposed deficit reduction targets, but the Commission deemed its recent reforms in the right direction. The decision has raised questions about the credibility of EU budget rules, with some policymakers calling it a step too far. France will be given more time to meet EU rules, with the Commission recommending a 0.5-per cent structural deficit cut this year and a major reform plan to be presented in April.

site_title: Fiery Yellen fights back as Republican lawmakers lambaste Fed
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen clashed with Republican lawmakers in a House Financial Services Committee hearing, accusing the central bank of prioritizing Democratic causes over the economy. Yellen defended the Fed's actions, citing its role in addressing long-term issues like unemployment and income inequality. She also rejected claims of a liberal bias, stating she was discussing problems, not making policy recommendations. The tense exchange highlights growing pressure on the Fed's independence, with Republicans seeking to rein in the central bank's authority and Yellen's predecessor, Ben Bernanke, showing less tenacity in similar hearings.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen on Wednesday fended off a stream of aggressive questions from Republican lawmakers who accused the central bank of making Democratic political causes a higher priority than its stewardship of the US economy.

site_title: Brent crude up 5% as Saudi sees improved demand for oil
summary: Brent crude oil futures rose 5% on Wednesday, driven by Saudi Arabia's oil minister stating improved demand for oil. Chinese factories increased production, and US refined product inventories fell, offsetting a larger-than-expected US crude inventory build. Brent April crude settled at $61.63 a barrel, while US April crude settled at $50.99 a barrel. Analysts saw the report as relatively bullish, despite the large crude inventory build, citing the drawdowns in refined product categories as supportive.

site_title: Gold rebounds from 7-week low on Yellen's dovish tone on rates
summary: Gold prices rebounded from a 7-week low on Wednesday after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen indicated flexibility in raising US interest rates, weakening the dollar. US gold futures rose 1% and silver prices climbed over 3%. Yellen's comments kept interest rate hike timing uncertain, boosting investor sentiment.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: US President Trump has announced a 50% tariff on copper imports, which is expected to affect the refined metal. This move has caused oil prices to rise by over 2% as investors weigh the market outlook and its impact on global trade. US stocks also edged down from records amid concerns about further tariff threats, including those against Canada.

site_title: Europe: Stocks finished mixed
summary: Europe's main stock markets finished mixed on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 retreating 0.21% to 6,935.38 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 edged up 0.04% to 11,210.27 points. Paris's CAC 40 was down 0.09% to 4,882.22 points. The mixed performance was attributed to bank and healthcare sectors, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

images.alt_text: Frankfurt's DAX 30 index edged up 0.04 per cent to 11,210.27 points, while in Paris the CAC 40 was down 0.09 per cent to 4,882.22 points.

site_title: Firms to get up to S$15k for hiring, training new ITE and poly grads
summary: Singapore's government has launched the Earn and Learn work-study programme, which provides up to S$15,000 in grants to employers who hire and train fresh polytechnic and ITE graduates. The programme also offers a S$5,000 sign-on bonus to each graduate. The initiative aims to match graduates to employers, enabling them to build on their skills and knowledge and ease their transition into the workforce. The programme is set to launch in late March and will cover four sectors, with more sectors and companies to be added over time.

site_title: Scheme to help S'pore furniture firms venture overseas
summary: Singapore's furniture industry is thriving, with revenue rising 2.8% to S$6.24 billion in 2014. To support companies expanding overseas, the Singapore Furniture Industries Council (SFIC) has partnered with the Local Enterprise Association Development (LEAD) scheme, which will provide up to 70% funding for in-market consultants to target markets in Australia, Europe, and the Philippines. Nine local SMEs have pledged to participate in the three-year program, aiming to deepen the industry's global footprint.

site_title: UK oil sector seen shedding 15,000 jobs in months
summary: The UK offshore oil and gas industry is expected to shed 15,000 jobs in the next few months due to reduced investment plans due to lower oil prices. Consultant Ian Wood, who has reviewed the industry, recommends lowering the effective tax rate to 40% to encourage companies to continue investing. Currently, the rate is around 50%, and companies such as BP and Total have cut spending plans. The government has proposed cutting the supplementary tax, but Wood believes it needs to cut it further to drive change.

site_title: Room for more left-leaning policies in S'pore, but no free-for-all: panel
summary: Singapore's Budget 2015 marked a shift to the left with the introduction of the Silver Support Scheme, a permanent initiative providing quarterly cash payouts to elderly poor citizens. The scheme is considered a significant step towards mitigating inequality, with a focus on intergenerational transfers and conditional need-based assistance. While the government has room to implement more left-leaning policies, it will maintain a prudent approach, avoiding traditional welfare models. Experts believe the government will continue to roll out social policies, citing economic benefits of a happier middle class.

site_title: China's slowdown bottoming out, according to Australian gauges
summary: China's economy is showing signs of a soft landing, according to Australian gauges. BHP Billiton and the Reserve Bank of Australia's chief, Glenn Stevens, signal a moderate recovery in Chinese demand for steel in 2015. China's preliminary purchasing manager's index rebounded, and officials are preparing measures to counter a housing market slump. The Australian dollar gained after the release, and policy makers forecast growth in China of 6.75% in 2015 and 6.5% in 2016. Despite China's economic slowdown, Australian exporters and policy makers believe housing demand will help avert an abrupt slump in expansion.

site_title: NYC rents rising at rate outpacing inflation
summary: New York City rents have risen faster than inflation over the past three years, with the median rent increasing 3.4% to $1,200 per month, and 4.3% when including utility costs. Despite this, the median household income for renters remained relatively stable at $41,500. About 30% of renters are considered "severely rent burdened" and spend at least half of their income on housing, with the federal government standard for affordable housing at 30%. The city's housing officials are urging action to address the housing affordability crisis through public investment in affordable housing.

site_title: RBS plans to scale back its investment bank: sources
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland plans to scale back its investment bank, with restructuring chief Rory Cullinan taking over responsibility from Donald Workman. The bank aims to reduce its assets and simplify its business, bolstering capital and generating better returns. RBS plans to significantly scale back its operations in Asia, leaving about 200 staff, and exit several European markets. The move is part of the bank's efforts to support the domestic economy and increase its assets in Britain to 80% of its global business.

site_title: Where will the new oil be found to meet demand?
summary: A new oil supply is needed to meet global demand, with the world's proven oil reserves estimated at 1.4 trillion barrels. The Middle East is a key region for future oil plays, with countries like Saudi Arabia, Iraq, and Venezuela holding significant reserves. The Arctic region is also being explored, with estimates suggesting 166 billion barrels of oil equivalent. Shale oil reserves, particularly in the US and Russia, are expected to continue contributing to global oil supplies. However, many of these new fields are uneconomic at current prices, and the global oil market is shifting towards a more balanced supply and demand dynamic.

site_title: Minister urges aviation sector to continue raising productivity
summary: Singapore's Senior Minister of State for Finance and Transport, Josephine Teo, urges the aviation sector to increase productivity amid a tight labor market and persistent cost pressures. Modest passenger growth is expected this year, with 54.1 million passengers at Changi Airport in 2014, and the sector must adapt to innovation-driven growth. The government has recognized 16 projects boosting productivity, including those by Rolls-Royce and MAJ Aviation, and has implemented incentive programs, such as the SkillsFuture initiative, to encourage lifelong learning and skills acquisition.

site_title: StarHub Q4 earnings up 10%
summary: StarHub reported a 10% increase in quarterly net profit to S$94.2 million, driven by higher sales of new iPhones and growth in mobile services, with revenue rising 5% to S$647.4 million. Despite a 16% decline in broadband revenue, the company added 8,600 subscribers and saw a lower average monthly churn rate. Mobile services grew nearly 3% and fixed network services rose 3.7%, while pay TV revenue remained flat.

site_title: Petrobras loses investment grade in Moody's downgrade
summary: Moody's Investors Service downgraded Petrobras, Brazil's state-run oil company, to Ba2 from Baa3 due to concerns over a corruption scandal and liquidity pressures. The downgrade reflects the company's struggle to meaningfully reduce its high debt burden over the next several years.

site_title: US: Stocks flat following mixed earnings
summary: US stocks finished flat on Wednesday, following mixed corporate earnings and a second day of congressional testimony from Fed Chair Janet Yellen. The Dow Jones Industrial Average edged to a record, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index slipped slightly. Despite a record-breaking close, investors remained cautious amid ongoing US-EU trade tensions and uncertainty over future market movements.

site_title: In brief
summary: Vallianz Holdings reported a 100% increase in net profit to US$18.5 million for the 2014 financial year, with revenue growing over seven times to US$153.7 million. FSL Trust reversed a Q4 loss into a profit of US$7.49 million, while Penguin International's Q4 profit fell 8% to S$5.17 million. YHI International's full-year earnings dropped 20.4% to S$7.03 million, and TIH's net profit plummeted to S$591,000.

site_title: Swiss firms cut working hours to counter franc's strength
summary: Swiss companies, such as DISTEC AG, are cutting working hours to counter the strength of the Swiss franc, which has made their goods more expensive abroad. The move aims to reduce costs and maintain competitiveness. The franc's surge in value has been a challenge for Swiss industrial companies with high local costs.

site_title: Former BT journalist to helm SICCI
summary: The Singapore Indian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SICCI) has appointed 36-year-old former Business Times journalist Malminderjit Singh as its executive director, effective March 1. Singh, who will concurrently serve as a director of two SICCI subsidiaries, brings five years of experience covering shipping, SMEs, and Indian businesses in Singapore. SICCI Chairman Dr R Theyvendran praised Singh's in-depth knowledge and youth, citing the need for rejuvenation in the organization. The appointment is seen as timely, given SICCI's new board and the changes in the Singapore economy.

site_title: Japan Inc's 233t yen cash hoard fuels overseas buying spree
summary: Japanese companies are on a record-breaking overseas buying spree, with $28 billion in purchases so far this year, driven by a massive cash hoard of 233 trillion yen and a weakening yen. Companies like Canon, Japan Post, and Itochu Corp are paying double the global average premium for takeovers, with a median valuation of 23 times earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization. The trend is expected to continue as Japan's economy is forecast to grow 1% this year, making foreign acquisitions more attractive.

site_title: India's Budget: Expectations versus fiscal prudence
summary: India's upcoming budget is expected to focus on sustainable high growth, a stable tax regime, and boosting business sentiments. The government aims to strike a balance between expectations and fiscal prudence, with key areas including reviving the investment cycle, increasing foreign investment, and implementing policy reforms to improve ease of doing business. A Goods and Services Tax (GST) is also anticipated to be introduced to increase revenue collection. The budget will be a litmus test for the BJP government, with the world watching to see if it can translate words into actions and accelerate reforms momentum.

site_title: Fonterra seen raising price it pays to milk suppliers
summary: Fonterra, New Zealand's largest dairy exporter, is expected to raise its farmgate price to as much as NZ$5 (S$5.10) per kg milk solids, up 6% from NZ$4.70, due to lower production and global dairy price rises. This lift provides relief to Fonterra's farmer shareholders, who have seen incomes slashed after a deep cut in farmgate prices. Global dairy prices have risen 26% this year, driven by reduced supply from New Zealand and increased demand from South-east Asian and Middle Eastern buyers.

site_title: Singapore consumer confidence down 2.1% in February
summary: Singapore consumer confidence fell 2.1% to 120.7 points in February, the lowest since 2014. Only 27% of respondents believe their families are "better off" financially now, and 29% expect improvement in a year. Consumer sentiment towards buying major household items is also low, with only 20% saying it's a good time to buy. The ANZ-Roy Morgan survey attributed the decline to "sombre" personal financial situations and "overhang of supply-side restructuring".

site_title: Ringgit firmer on Fed's pledge to be patient on rate hike
summary: The Malaysian ringgit strengthened 0.6% to 3.6210 a dollar after the Federal Reserve pledged to be patient on raising interest rates, increasing the likelihood of a rate hike in the second half of the year. The US central bank's "patient" stance was seen as bullish for equities and a risk-on environment. The ringgit's implied volatility and sovereign bond yields also declined, with the yield on three-year debt falling to 3.43% and the yield on 10-year debt falling to 3.87%. This suggests the ringgit is undervalued and should return to its fundamentals.

site_title: ECB unveils new 20-euro banknote
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) unveiled the new 20-euro banknote, set to enter circulation on November 25, 2015. The note features a "portrait window" with a transparent Europa image, making it harder to forge. The ECB aims to ensure the euro notes remain resilient against counterfeiting, reinforcing trust among citizens. This is the ninth euro denomination to be phased in, replacing those in circulation since 2002, with more notes to follow, including the 50-euro, 100-euro, 200-euro, and 500-euro notes.

images.alt_text: ECB chief Mario Draghi said the new note, which will start circulating on Nov 25, will have a new security feature in the form of a "portrait window" to make it more difficult to forge.

site_title: S'pore households' net worth grows a slower 2.3%
summary: Singapore households' net worth grew 2.3% to S$1.47 trillion in 2014, but at a slower pace than previous years. Residential property assets declined 1.1% to S$819.6 billion, mainly due to public housing, while private housing assets rose 2.2% to S$425 billion. Household liabilities increased 5.1% to S$294 billion. Experts expect the record number of new home completions to boost assets but also increase liabilities.

site_title: Draghi can now focus on deflation fight amid lull in Greek talks
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi can now focus on implementing a 1.1 trillion-euro quantitative-easing program to combat deflation in the eurozone. A lull in Greek bailout talks has freed the ECB from immediate concerns about funding the country's banks. Data from Germany, Spain, and Italy will show a continued slump in consumer prices, with forecasters predicting a near-record pace of price falls. Draghi is under pressure to unveil details of the QE program, which aims to address the region's economic woes and inflation concerns.

site_title: Cap Gemini, Carlyle had eye on US tech firm CSC
summary: French consulting company Cap Gemini SA and private equity firm Carlyle Group LP expressed interest in acquiring US tech firm Computer Sciences Corp (CSC) in a potential buyout. Talks between the parties started late last year but have since stalled, with no clear indication of whether they will resume.

site_title: Yellen's comments help lift stocks
summary: US Federal Reserve Chief Janet Yellen's comments on interest rate policy have lifted stocks, with the Straits Times Index rising 3.22 points to 3,440.83. Yellen stated that the Fed will consider interest rate policy on a meeting-to-meeting basis, giving markets a sense of stability. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 closed at new all-time highs. In contrast, Genting Singapore fell 6.2% after reporting worse-than-expected Q4 figures, while the Singapore Exchange rose 0.02% after its CEO announced he will not seek a contract extension.

site_title: HSBC bosses reject calls to quit
summary: HSBC's Chairman Douglas Flint and CEO Stuart Gulliver rejected calls to quit over the bank's Swiss tax scandal, citing collective responsibility for failings in the mid-2000s. The bank admitted control and compliance issues in its Swiss private bank, leading to fines and investigations. Flint acknowledged a "terrible list" of scandals, including a US$1.9 billion fine and a US$611 million penalty for money laundering and currency market manipulation. Gulliver denied wrongdoing over his own tax affairs, but the scandal has damaged HSBC's reputation and raised questions about his moral authority to lead the bank's transformation.

images.alt_text: HSBC Chairman Douglas Flint and Chief Executive Stuart Gulliver told a panel of UK lawmakers they shared collective responsibility for failings at HSBC's Swiss bank that allowed clients to dodge taxes.

site_title: Marriott opens to great fanfare in hotel-starved Haiti capital
summary: Marriott International has inaugurated a new 175-room hotel in Port-au-Prince, Haiti's capital, marking a significant boost to the country's meager hotel offerings. The US$45 million project, facilitated by the Clinton Foundation, was attended by former US President Bill Clinton and Haitian President Michel Martelly. Despite Haiti's political crisis, the hotel's chairman, Denis O'Brien, believes it will attract tourists. The hotel's construction was challenging, but Marriott's president Craig Smith said the staff, mostly Haitian locals, are eager to showcase the country's hospitality.

site_title: Future-proofing Singapore: the endeavour continues
summary: Singapore's government has released its 2015 budget, focusing on future-proofing the country's economy. The budget aims to deepen skills and capabilities, promote innovation, and strengthen economic and social infrastructure. Key initiatives include the extension and simplification of the Capability Development Grant for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), as well as the introduction of a new International Growth Scheme to support SMEs expanding overseas. The government also introduced a Silver Support Scheme to provide income supplements for senior citizens and increased social spending to ensure social cohesiveness. Revenue measures, including a top marginal personal income tax rate increase, aim to strengthen Singapore's revenue position.

site_title: US to allow spouses of high-tech foreign workers to apply for work permits
summary: The US government has finalized a rule allowing spouses of high-tech foreign workers to apply for work permits, starting May 26. The regulation, part of President Barack Obama's immigration package, affects over 179,000 people in the next year and 55,000 in subsequent years. The change aims to alleviate hardships on families of H-1B visa holders, who have been unable to work due to long waiting periods for green cards. This move follows similar accommodations in Australia and Canada, and is seen as a relief by those affected, such as software engineer Swapnil Gupta.

site_title: Rotary's Q4 earnings soar on better margin, lower taxation
summary: Rotary Engineering's Q4 FY14 net profit surged to S$11.79 million, more than doubling from the same period last year, driven by an 8 percentage point improvement in gross profit margin. Revenue declined 31% to S$125.68 million due to project completion. The company warned that protracted weaknesses in oil prices may affect its business due to increased competition. Despite this, Rotary remains confident in the long-term fundamentals of the oil and gas industry and will focus on improving productivity and executing current projects.

site_title: First Faberge Imperial egg created in 99 years
summary: The first Faberge Imperial egg in 99 years was unveiled in Qatar, featuring 139 fine white pearls, over 3,300 diamonds, and other precious gemstones. Commissioned to mark the 100th anniversary of the last Imperial egg, the "Faberge Pearl Egg" is valued at an estimated US$2 million, with several interested buyers. The egg was created by Faberge in association with the Al Fardan jewellery group, known for its pearls, and is the first of several eggs to be unveiled by Faberge since World War I.

site_title: EU energy union seen saving consumers 40b euros a year
summary: The European Union is expected to save consumers up to 40 billion euros (S$61.5 billion) a year by implementing a better energy connection strategy, according to the European Commission. The plan aims to increase consumer options, integrate renewable supplies, and reduce the need for expensive imports. Climate Action and Energy Commissioner Miguel Arias Canete stated that Europe is losing up to 40 billion euros annually due to inadequate energy connections. The Commission plans to invest 200 billion euros in EU energy infrastructure by 2020, with an estimated 40 billion euros needed to achieve a 10% goal for cross-border links.

site_title: An artificial hand almost as good as the real one
summary: European surgeons and engineers have developed a mind-controlled bionic hand that restores function almost as well as a flesh-and-blood transplant. The technique, tested on three Austrian beneficiaries, avoids the risk of rejection associated with transplants. The patients, who suffered injuries to the brachial plexus, regained control over their hands after the procedure, with outcomes comparable to those of a transplant. This breakthrough offers a safer alternative to traditional transplant methods, paving the way for further research and potential applications.

site_title: HK budget reinforces long-term economic development
summary: Hong Kong's Financial Secretary John C Tsang has delivered a 2015-16 budget aimed at promoting economic development and alleviating public burden. The budget includes six one-off relief measures totaling HK$34 billion, such as reducing salaries and profits tax for taxpayers and waiving property rates. Tsang also pledged targeted support for the cultural and creative sector, and introduced initiatives to promote human resources development, healthcare, and retirement protection. The government also plans to support sectors affected by the "Occupy Central" movement and promote Hong Kong's pillar industries, including finance and tourism.

site_title: DreamWorks Animation sells HQ after loss
summary: DreamWorks Animation reported a fourth-quarter loss of US$263.2 million due to writing down films and cutting production. The studio sold its headquarters for US$185 million and refinanced a credit line to boost its cash by about US$235 million. The company plans to reduce production to two films a year and eliminate 500 jobs to improve the quality and profitability of its pictures.

site_title: FDA to speed up rules on cleaning endoscopes
summary: The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) plans to expedite label changes for medical devices linked to a "superbug" outbreak in California, potentially including new warnings and stricter cleaning instructions for reusable duodenoscopes. The outbreak, which may have exposed 179 patients to a deadly, drug-resistant strain of bacteria, prompted the FDA to speed up modifications to the label. The agency is working with manufacturers, including Pentax Medical, Fujifilm Holdings Corp, and Olympus Corp, to update the instructions for disinfecting the devices.

site_title: New office space in Manila set for record
summary: Manila's office space supply is expected to break records for the next few years, with developers adding 466,354 square meters last year. This is near the all-time high of 467,030 sqm in 2009, and a total of 1.85 million sqm is expected to be added between 2015 and 2017. The demand for office space has driven up average lease rates by 8% to 816 pesos per sqm, and the vacancy rate in business hubs has fallen to 4-5.5%. Global firms such as Google and HSBC are relocating business processes to the Philippines due to lower operating costs and an English-speaking workforce.

site_title: Postal Savings Bank of China plans US$25b IPO: report
summary: Postal Savings Bank of China plans to raise up to $25 billion through an initial public offering in 2016, becoming the latest Chinese bank to seek funds via the equity markets. The bank, which has 40,000 branches and over $5.58 trillion in assets, aims to introduce strategic investors who will invest $6 billion in exchange for 15% of the bank's equity to improve corporate governance. The bank has received approval from the Ministry of Finance and is expected to list on a bourse, although the exact listing venue has not been disclosed.

site_title: Boeing has buyers lined up for 10 of its overweight 787 Dreamliners: sources
summary: Boeing has secured buyers for 10 overweight 787 Dreamliners, dubbed "terrible teens" due to assembly struggles and weight issues. The planes, valued at around $1 billion, were originally rejected by customers due to their limited range. The sale is a significant step forward for Boeing, which had been struggling to clear inventory from its storage facilities. The sale of these aircraft is expected to bring in much-needed revenue for the company.

site_title: Boost for cyber security with Singtel's ASOC
summary: Singtel launched its Advanced Security Operations Centre (ASOC) in Singapore, a partnership with Nasdaq-listed FireEye, to enhance cyber security protection against advanced attacks in the Asia Pacific region. The ASOC provides organisations with latest technology, expertise, and intelligence to detect, protect, and respond to cyber threats. With 50 security professionals and global access to FireEye SOCs, Singtel aims to become the top cyber security player in the Asia Pacific region within three years and one of the top global players within five years.

images.alt_text: Mr DeWalt (left, with Dr Yaacob, Singtel Group CEO Chua Sock Koong and Mr Chang) said Singapore has the potential to "lead as a safe haven for cyber domains" and become "the cyber epicentre of the world"

site_title: Higher operating margins lift Sheng Siong's Q4 profit
summary: Sheng Siong Group reported a net profit of S$11.8 million for its Q4 2014, up 26.5% from S$9.3 million a year ago, driven by higher operating profit margins and revenue growth of 4.7% to S$178.4 million. The company declared a final dividend of 1.5 cents a share and plans to expand its retail network in Singapore. Gross profit margins increased to 24.3% due to lower costs and stable selling prices.

site_title: AirAsia X slips 3% after posting wider-than-expected losses
summary: AirAsia X reported a full-year net loss of RM520 million, exceeding analyst expectations. The airline's shares slipped 3.2% due to a "hard landing" caused by costs running ahead of revenue. To turn the business around, management plans to focus on maximizing revenue, reducing costs, and managing capacity. Analysts predict continued losses for another year or two, but some see moderation in yields as a sign of an upward inflection point. The airline has raised US$109 million through a cash call and recently effected a management change.

site_title: Funds see end to emerging market bond rally as currencies tumble
summary: Foreign investors are pulling out of emerging market bonds as currencies tumble, ending the recent rally. Domestic notes from emerging-market governments have returned 2.6% this year, but investors say the spreads are too small to justify the exchange-rate risk. Fidelity Worldwide Investment and Pictet Asset Management warn of another selloff, citing yields that are within 0.50 percentage points of equivalent dollar-denominated bonds. This could lead to significant losses, similar to those seen in 2005.

site_title: China said to be readying moves to counter housing market slump
summary: China is preparing measures to counter a housing market slump, including reducing downpayment requirements for second-home purchases and allowing homeowners to sell properties without paying sales tax after two years. The government aims to support the economy amid signs of a deepening decline in the real estate industry. The moves could be implemented if the economic downturn continues or worsens, and are in addition to existing policies such as an interest rate cut in November.

images.alt_text: China's new-home prices posted a record year-on-year decline in January, according to a Bloomberg Intelligence analysis.

site_title: Dozens injured as train hits truck stuck at rail crossing in US
summary: A commuter train crashed into a truck stuck on railroad tracks in Oxnard, California, injuring nearly 30 people, including four critically injured. The train's engineer, credited with quickly pulling the emergency brake, was among the injured. The truck's driver, a 54-year-old man from Arizona, was arrested on a felony hit-and-run charge. The accident occurred at a hazardous rail crossing with a high accident prediction value, with 13 crashes involving trains and pedestrians or vehicles at the crossing since 1976.

site_title: QC rules still apply for conversions to serviced apartments
summary: Developers in Singapore seeking to convert private residential projects to serviced apartments may face a dead end as the Singapore Land Authority (SLA) will still require them to sell the entire project within the two-year stipulated timeframe or pay extension charges. Despite this, some developers hope to exempt themselves from the deadline by converting to serviced apartments, which could potentially be exempt from QC conditions if the market recovers or authorities relax on regulations. However, detailed evaluation and additional criteria may apply, and strata division is not allowed in serviced apartments, requiring developers to extinguish strata titles before conversion.

site_title: Drugmaker Takeda to zoom in on emerging markets
summary: Takeda Pharmaceutical, Asia's largest drugmaker, has streamlined its Singapore operations to focus on emerging markets. The company has relocated its emerging-markets business unit headquarters, regional research and development centre, and vaccine business unit to a new Biopolis office. This move reflects the company's strategy to prioritize emerging markets, which is expected to drive growth and expansion.

images.alt_text: Asia's largest drugmaker Takeda Pharmaceutical has streamlined its Singapore operations in a move that reflects its focus on emerging markets.

site_title: Budget 2015 addresses social goals, but is also business-friendly
summary: Singapore's Budget 2015 focuses on social goals but also offers business-friendly measures. The budget addresses low-income and middle-income households, promoting social inclusion and progressivity. Companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), will benefit from productivity-inducing measures, skills upgrading, and targeted schemes for mergers and acquisitions. The government aims to boost topline growth through innovation, internationalisation, and skills upgrading, with measures such as the SkillsFuture scheme and enhanced tax allowances for M&As. The budget also includes cost-saving measures to help companies adjust to a tight labour market.

site_title: New SGX CEO must accommodate all stakeholders
summary: The new CEO of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) must balance various stakeholder demands, including dismantling the current commercial model, improving listing quality, and introducing new products. Key priorities include raising the quality bar for listings, attracting more IPOs, and introducing interesting products that investors want to trade. The new CEO should also prioritize prompt investigations into wrongdoing and strategic business collaborations. Notably, none of the respondents mentioned over-regulation or banning computerized trading, highlighting the need for a balanced approach to regulation.

images.alt_text: Many stakeholders with an interest in the stock market on the other hand - among them brokers, retail investors and corporate finance people involved in IPOs - would wish for greater vibrancy and consideration for retail interests.

site_title: Vital for money to flow back to Greek banks
summary: Greece's banks face a significant outflow of 25 billion euros since January, with deposit outflows jumping to 3 billion euros last week. The European Central Bank has lent multi-billions to banks to cover withdrawals, totaling 108 billion euros. The Greek government must implement proposed economic reforms within four months to justify the compromise with creditors, including counter direct tax evasion and improving state efficiency. The reforms aim to reduce debt and stimulate growth, but a potential default could lead to an exit from the eurozone, with a 33% chance of occurring, according to economists.

site_title: UOB's charity art auction draws S$750,000
summary: UOB raised S$750,000 for charity through a 20-minute ink painting auction at its annual Chinese New Year Commercial Banking client dinner. The painting, valued at S$500,000, was sold to businessmen Ma On May and Ma Wong Ching for S$500,000, with S$250,000 pledged by UOB at the start. The funds will support The Business Times Budding Artists Fund and the Sage Counselling Centre for the elderly. This is the largest donation by UOB to the Budding Artists Fund, and marks the bank's continued support for the arts and charitable causes.

site_title: QT Vascular narrows FY14 loss to US$34.17m
summary: QT Vascular narrowed its FY14 net loss to US$34.17 million from US$34.52 million, despite a doubling in revenue to US$13.16 million. The increase in revenue was mainly due to sales of its medical devices in the US. However, higher expenses, including research and development costs, led to the loss. Excluding one-off items, the company's net loss would have been US$28.1 million. Shares fell half a cent to S$0.31 following the announcement.

site_title: Over 50 brands to take part in new travel fair
summary: A new travel fair, Travel Revolution 2015 - The Event, has gathered over 50 travel brands in Singapore, including Contiki, Singapore Airlines, and the Tourism Authority of Thailand. The fair aims to rival the National Association of Travel Agents Singapore (Natas) event, bringing together outbound travel agencies, tour operators, airlines, hotels, and more.

site_title: SGX expected to stay the course after captain departs
summary: SGX's CEO, Magnus Bocker, will leave the market operator in June after his contract ends. Despite this, analysts expect the company to stick to its current strategy, citing a lack of significant impact on operations. Analysts also highlighted daunting challenges for Bocker's successor, including improving liquidity and fostering regional ties. The company's shares closed at S$8.20, slightly lower than the previous day.

site_title: Anthem breach may affect as many as 18m people
summary: Anthem, the second-largest US health insurer, reported a massive cyber breach affecting 8.8-18.8 million people who were members of other Blue Cross Blue Shield plans. The breach, which was first reported earlier this month, may include records of 78.8 million customers, with incomplete records preventing a full link to plan affiliation. Security experts warn that healthcare and insurance companies are vulnerable to cybercriminals seeking to steal personal information. Anthem is working to notify affected individuals and secure the compromised database.

site_title: Ann Taylor, Chico's seek buyers to overhaul their ageing brand image
summary: Ann Taylor and Chico's FAS Inc are seeking buyers to overhaul their aging brand image, as the companies face challenges from younger shoppers who prefer trendy clothing. Ann Inc's CEO, Liz Dunn, notes that women in their 40s are no longer dressing "frumpily" and instead prioritize looking youthful. Private-equity firms like Sycamore Partners are interested in acquiring the companies, but may struggle to adapt to the cultural shift. If sold, Ann or Chico's could be broken up into more valuable brands, such as Lou & Grey and White House Black Market, which could be invested in and revitalized.

site_title: Expenses, one-off costs lower Kingsmen's FY14 profit to S$17m
summary: Kingsmen Creatives reported a 3.3% decline in net profit to S$17.15 million for FY14 due to higher costs, including one-off expenses from a legal case in China. Revenue rose 13.6% to S$336.41 million, driven by strong contributions from most divisions, including Kingsmen Middle East. The group expects 2015 to be busy with new contracts secured.

site_title: China's Feb flash PMI up but export orders down
summary: China's factory sector activity rose to a four-month high in February, with the HSBC/Markit Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 50.1, but export orders shrank at their fastest rate in 20 months. Domestic demand picked up slightly, while input and output prices fell. Employment in factories declined for the 16th straight month. Economists expect further policy easing to support growth, citing weak foreign demand and deflationary pressures. China's economy grew 7.4% in 2014, its slowest expansion in 24 years, and growth is expected to cool further to 7% in 2015.

site_title: Target says to outline investments, cost-cuts next week
summary: Target Corp plans to disclose investment and cost-cut plans at an analyst meeting on March 3, CFO John Mulligan said. The company aims to fund investments with cost reductions, with opportunities to reduce costs across the enterprise, potentially including job losses.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close up 0.11%
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 0.11% higher on Wednesday, following record-setting gains on Wall Street and relief over a Greek debt deal. The Hang Seng Index rose 28.21 points to 24,778.28, driven by global market sentiment.

site_title: Qingjian, Samsung sign MOU on smart homes
summary: Qingjian Realty (South Pacific) Group and Samsung Asia signed a memorandum of understanding to integrate smart living technology into new housing developments in Singapore, with Sembawang EC being the private developer's first project equipped with the new technology. The partnership aims to create smart homes with features such as smart appliances and devices that can adjust to users' needs, enhancing the living experience.

site_title: China expands tax breaks, vows more fiscal support
summary: China's cabinet announced an expansion of an income-tax break for companies with annual taxable income of 200,000 yuan, aiming to boost fiscal support for a cooling economy. The move aims to cut firms' costs and spur employment, saving companies more than 40 billion yuan a year. Additionally, the government will speed construction of 100 large hydro projects and allocate over 90% of central government funds by the end of June. The expansion is seen as a response to China's slowing economy, which logged 7.4% growth last year, its worst in 24 years.

site_title: US$ eases as rate hike may not be imminent
summary: The US dollar fell against a basket of currencies after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen suggested the central bank would not rush into raising US interest rates. Yellen's testimony to Congress disappointed investors who had positioned themselves for a clearer signal on when rates would rise. The dollar index dropped 0.25% to 94.245, while sterling rose to an eight-week high against the dollar. The Fed still appears to be on track to raise rates later this year, but the timing will depend on economic data.

site_title: Tough road for Greece after bailout extension
summary: Greece secured a four-month extension to its bailout program, but the German and Greek parliaments must still approve the deal. The new government presented reform proposals to tackle tax evasion, corruption, and efficiency drives, but must meet creditor demands to avoid a national bankruptcy and chaotic exit from the eurozone. Greece faces trouble making debt payments to the IMF and European Central Bank in the spring and summer, with a funding gap expected to be discussed with EU/IMF partners immediately.

images.alt_text: Mr Varoufakis said that Greece has no immediate problem with government liquidity, but faces trouble in making debt payments to the IMF and European Central Bank in the spring and summer.

site_title: US new-home sales hold steady in January
summary: US new-home sales held steady in January at an annual rate of 481,000 units, near the highest pace since mid-2008. This is 0.2% below the upwardly revised December rate and above analysts' expectations. January sales were the strongest since June 2008, with year-over-year growth of 5.3%. The median and average prices of new homes fell 2.6% and 8.0% respectively, while the market had a 5.4-month supply at January's sales pace.

site_title: Australia to impose fees on foreigners buying homes
summary: Australia plans to charge foreign nationals A$5,000 for properties under A$1 million and A$10,000 for each additional A$1 million, aiming to raise A$200 million annually. The government will also set up a register and fine those breaking foreign investment laws up to a quarter of the property's value. The move aims to curb a significant influx of foreign capital into the property market, particularly from China, which accounted for 41% of foreign investment in 2013. Experts doubt the fees will make housing more affordable, citing concerns they will not benefit first-time buyers.

site_title: Yellen's testimony maddeningly unclear on interest rates
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's testimony provided little clarity on interest rates, sparking mixed market reactions. She praised recent job growth and steady inflation, fueling speculation about an imminent rate hike, but also highlighted concerns about labor market participation and wage growth. Yellen emphasized the Fed's need to wait for economic indicators to justify a rate increase, potentially leaving markets uncertain about the timing of a policy change. This ambiguity is seen as a strategic move by the Fed to maintain flexibility, but may also catch investors off guard.

site_title: HP says it'll miss profit forecasts on strong US dollar
summary: Hewlett-Packard (HP) forecasted to miss profit estimates due to a strong US dollar, which is expected to impact revenue from overseas sales. The company, set to split into two companies, cited a rising US dollar and the cost of the separation as factors. HP's profit before certain items is projected to be 84-88 cents per share, missing analysts' estimates of 95 cents. The company also announced a two-year cost of $2 billion for the split, which includes $1.3 billion in charges for fiscal 2015 and $500 million in 2016.

site_title: 2 Greek banks dropped from top European equity index
summary: Greek banks Bank of Piraeus and Eurobank will be dropped from the STOXX 600 European equity index, effective March 23. The demotion follows a 65% decline in shares since February 2014, attributed to concerns over Greece's debt pile. The removal will result in a decrease in liquidity for the stocks, with 10.1 million shares of Piraeus and 47.5 million shares of Eurobank being sold. National Bank of Greece and Alpha Bank will remain in the index, while other companies will be added.

site_title: JPMorgan eyes US$1.4b in cost savings in 2015 mainly in consumer, investment banking
summary: JPMorgan Chase plans to cut annual expenses by US$1.4 billion, primarily in consumer and investment banking, to comply with new capital requirements. The bank expects to reduce expenses to US$57 billion in 2015, down from US$58.4 billion in 2014. JPMorgan aims to lower US$2.8 billion in its investment bank, mainly through job cuts and pay cuts, while its consumer bank will see a US$2 billion reduction. The moves are aimed at maintaining profitability despite shrinking trading revenues and increased regulatory burdens.

site_title: Tesla S tops Consumer Reports car list for 2nd straight year
summary: Consumer Reports named the Tesla S its top car for the second straight year, praising its "technological tour de force" and 426 km range without a charge. Subaru led three categories, including compact car, mid-sized sedan, and small SUV. The Tesla S topped the list for luxury electric vehicles, while the Chevrolet Impala and Buick Regal also made the top 10, beating out Toyota and Lexus models. The magazine credited Detroit vehicles for breaking through in new categories, citing improved performance, technology, and reliability.

site_title: EU unveils plans for historic single energy market
summary: The European Union unveiled plans for a single energy market to reduce reliance on Russian supplies and cut annual import costs of 400 billion euros. The proposal includes completing the single market, increasing energy security, boosting efficiency, and reducing fossil fuel use. EU member states may face challenges in centralizing energy policy, but the goal is to reduce the bloc's vulnerability to global insecurity, particularly tensions with Russia. The plans aim to promote new energy sources and increase research in the sector.

site_title: Petrol companies ordered to explain latest price hikes
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore has ordered four petrol companies - Caltex, Esso, Shell, and Singapore Petroleum Company - to explain their recent price hikes, which exceeded the increase in government duty. The move comes after the Consumers Association of Singapore accused the companies of profiteering. The investigation aims to determine if the price increases were justified and if the companies were taking advantage of consumers. The outcome will provide clarity on the situation and may lead to further action if necessary.

site_title: US: Stocks dip from record highs
summary: US stocks dipped from record highs in opening trade on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 11.82 points (0.06%) to 18,197.37. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined, down 1.71% and 0.17% respectively, amid mixed earnings reports. Traders are awaiting Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's congressional testimony, following her dovish remarks on Tuesday that pushed US stocks to record closes.

site_title: Modern solution to the problem of financing small firms
summary: Europeans are increasingly using peer-to-peer lending platforms, similar to those in the US, to fund businesses rather than personal needs. In contrast to US platforms like Lending Club, UK sites like Funding Circle provide funding for genuine businesses. A Cambridge University report estimates the European market for online alternative lending could reach €7 billion this year, a near sevenfold increase in three years, bridging the gap between bank loans and capital markets.

site_title: Sony to separate more units in turnaround push
summary: Sony Corp plans to separate more businesses, including its lucrative devices unit, as part of a turnaround push under CEO Kazuo Hirai. The company aims to boost accountability and increase the independence of each unit. Chips, batteries, and audio/video units are expected to be split off, with TV manufacturing needing to be profitable to stay part of the company. Sony targets its highest earnings in 20 years, focusing on games, image sensors, and entertainment to drive a turnaround, with projected operating profits of 400 billion yen by April.

site_title: HSBC says more clean up work to do after "terrible" list of problems
summary: HSBC Chairman Douglas Flint stated that the bank is halfway through major reforms following a series of scandals, including helping wealthy customers conceal assets in a Swiss private bank. The bank has admitted to compliance and controls failures, adding to a "terrible list" of failures, including fines for money laundering and currency market manipulation. HSBC was fined $1.9 billion by US authorities two years ago and $611 million by regulators in November for similar issues. The bank still has more work to do to ensure it does not contribute to future failures.

site_title: Dubai financial zone adjusting regulation to boost wealth managers
summary: Dubai's Dubai Financial Centre (DIFC) is adjusting regulations for investment firms handling wealthy clients' money to boost wealth management business. New rules allow firms to classify clients as professional with less regulatory protection, potentially cutting costs and attracting more business from the Middle East and Asia. The changes, effective April 1, except for a provision increasing the minimum assets for one type of professional client, aim to make DIFC a more competitive hub for wealth management. The move is seen as a step to grow DIFC's wealth management business, which has been slower to develop compared to European cities.

site_title: Philippines to send Chinese energy experts home
summary: The Philippines will end Chinese technical involvement in running its power grid by July, with all 16 Chinese technicians being sent home due to national security concerns. Energy Secretary Jericho Petilla cited concerns about the National Security Advisor and Filipinos' ability to perform the work as reasons for the decision. The State Grid Corporation of China will retain its 40% stake in the National Grid Corporation of the Philippines, with two Chinese remaining as board members. This move comes amid worsening relations between the Philippines and China over the South China Sea dispute.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Wednesday
summary: Notable news stories include Vietnam's reaction to the US Trump tariff announcement, the Asian garment industry's concerns about higher US tariffs, and Malaysia's plan to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Citigroup predicts a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index. In Thailand, Thaksin is confident his daughter's suspension as PM in an ethics case will be cleared by the court. The Asean region has downplayed the priority of Myanmar's election, while the UK economy shrinks for the second month.

site_title: Petra Foods Q4 net profit down 22.3%
summary: Petra Foods' Q4 net profit declined 22.3% to US$12.4 million, largely due to a depreciation in regional currencies. Revenue remained flat at US$131.2 million, with a 5% increase in constant exchange rates. For the full year, net profit more than doubled to US$48.8 million, while revenue was 0.9% lower at US$504 million. The company declared a total dividend of 5.77 US cents for the 2014 financial year.

site_title: DBS, POSB to launch SMS queue system
summary: DBS and POSB will launch an SMS queue system, allowing customers to sit comfortably and avoid waiting in line. This system will enable customers to use the time before their turn as they choose. The SMS queue system is set to improve customer experience and reduce waiting times for banking services.

site_title: Cybercrime ring controlling millions of PCs crippled
summary: A cybercrime ring using 3.2 million hacked computers worldwide to steal banking information has been disrupted by European police and technology companies. The operation, coordinated by Europol, targeted the Ramnit botnet, a network of computers infected with malware. Seven servers were shut down overnight, and the criminals have lost control of the infrastructure. The malware was installed through spam emails or infected websites, allowing culprits to take control of PCs for criminal activities. The investigation is ongoing, with no possible arrests of suspects announced.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open
summary: European stock markets remained steady on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index dipping 0.10% to 6,942.06 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 edged up 0.02% to 11,208.27 points. The FTSE 100 had reached a record high on Tuesday after eurozone finance ministers backed Greece's bailout extension, and the US also saw record highs on Wall Street as Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen took a cautious approach to raising interest rates.

site_title: Maersk to divest Danske Bank stake
summary: AP Moeller-Maersk A/S plans to divest its 20.05% stake in Danske Bank A/S, a move aimed at focusing on the company's core businesses. The Danish bank will be offered to Maersk shareholders, with AP Moeller Holding purchasing a 15% stake. The stake is valued at approximately $5.45 billion. The decision is part of CEO Nils Smedegaard Andersen's strategy to sell non-core divisions and concentrate on oil and shipping businesses.

site_title: Rotary Engineering's Q4 profit more than doubles to S$11.79m, revenue plunges 31%
summary: Rotary Engineering's Q4 FY14 net profit more than doubled to S$11.79 million, driven by improved gross profit margin and productivity. Revenue plunged 31% to S$125.68 million due to lower business activities. The company's FY14 net profit also more than doubled to S$50.08 million, with a final dividend of 2.5 cents per share declared for the quarter. Despite lower revenues, Rotary's productivity efforts and improved project execution contributed to the significant increase in net profit.

site_title: EFG flags far lower penalty to settle US tax probe
summary: Swiss private bank EFG International expects a lower than expected US fine of $11.4 million to settle a tax probe, indicating it's close to ending a long-running investigation. The bank's estimate is significantly lower than the initially anticipated $21.4 million fine. EFG's full-year profits were hit by charges and provisions of $30 million due to the US programme. The bank's chairman and other officials declined to comment on the settlement's status or expected completion date. This development suggests that other Swiss banks, including UBS and Credit Suisse, may also be nearing the end of their investigations.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall 0.10%, snaps five-day winning streak
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.10% on Wednesday, snapping a five-day winning streak, after investors locked in profits. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 18,585.20, down 18.28 points from the previous day's close. This marked a fresh 15-year high, but the loss was attributed to investors taking profits. The Topix index remained flat, edging down 0.04%.

site_title: China iron ore futures post biggest daily loss in 2-1/2 months
summary: China's iron ore futures plummeted 2.4% to 479 yuan (US$77) on their worst day in over two months, amid lackluster buying interest from steel mills. Analysts expect prices to remain stagnant until the construction season begins in March. Activity in China's factory sector edged up, but export orders shrank, suggesting a need for policy easing and infrastructure projects to boost demand.

site_title: Singapore: Stocks close marginally higher on optimism US rates won't be raised soon
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 3.22 to 3,440.83 on Wednesday, driven by optimism that the US Federal Reserve won't raise interest rates soon. The gains followed the Fed chief's testimony to the Senate Banking Committee, which fueled market confidence. Jardine Matheson contributed to the rally, while Genting Singapore's disappointing earnings weighed on the market.

site_title: Singtel cyber security centre launched
summary: Singtel launched its Advanced Security Operations Centre (ASOC) in Singapore, a major step towards becoming a regional cyber security provider. The ASOC, in partnership with FireEye, combines security expertise with Singtel's regional data infrastructure, offering organisations advanced threat protection and swift response capabilities. The centre has 50 security professionals and access to global FireEye SOCs, providing 24/7 "follow-the-sun" support. The ASOC enhances Singtel's existing network operations centre, providing end-to-end visibility and enhanced security protection against advanced attacks in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Russia will use International Space Station till 2024
summary: Russia will continue using the International Space Station until 2024, according to Roscosmos, the country's space agency. The decision follows previous plans to stop financing the ISS in 2020. Russia aims to create its own space station after the ISS is mothballed and plans to launch manned missions to the Moon by 2030. The move marks a continuation of cooperation with NASA, with Russia and the US providing most of the financial backing for the ISS.

site_title: China hails Xi's 'Four Comprehensives'
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has declared a new "Four Comprehensives" political theory, aiming to consolidate power and advance his brand of Communist thought. The theory includes four main objectives: building a moderately prosperous society, deepening reform, governing the nation according to law, and strictly governing the Party. The concept was first mentioned by Xi in December, but Wednesday marked its mass promotion. The move is seen as part of Xi's efforts to solidify his rule and promote his vision for China's future.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 2.82 points to 1,815.86. A total of 1.7 billion lots were traded, worth RM1.9 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 427 to 379.

site_title: Japan may ease rules to help banks compete better in online payments: source
summary: Japan is considering relaxing rules on bank holding companies to allow lenders to invest more freely in IT ventures, competing with non-bank online payment services like Alibaba's Alipay and Apple's Apple Pay. The rule changes would also enable bank holding companies to allocate assets and functions more freely among subsidiaries. Japan's Financial Services Agency will discuss the rule changes in March, with a potential bill submission early next year. The move aims to help Japanese banks adapt to changing business needs and navigate rapid digital advancements.

site_title: China: Stocks decline after holiday break
summary: Chinese shares declined after a week-long holiday, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 0.6% to 3,228.84. Casino stocks in Hong Kong plummeted, while the manufacturing purchasing managers' index rose to 50.1, beating expectations. Investors remain cautious, citing concerns over the economy's growth, and call for further monetary easing measures. Trading on the Shanghai exchange was 20% below its 30-day average, with the CSI 300 Index losing 1.2%.

site_title: Starhub Q4 profit up 10% to S$94.2 million
summary: StarHub posted a 10% increase in Q4 net profit to S$94.2 million, driven by higher revenue from equipment sales and strong demand for new iPhones. Revenue rose 5% to S$647.4 million, with ebitda margin increasing to 33.8%. The company recommended a final dividend of 5 Singapore cents per share. Service revenue declined 0.5% due to a 16% fall in broadband business, but mobile, pay-TV, and fixed network segments saw increases of 3%, 0.2%, and 4%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Starhub posted a 10 per cent jump in fourth quarter net profit to S$94.2 million from S$85.7 million a year ago.

site_title: Indonesia's Lippo Group to invest US$500m in new online retail platform
summary: Indonesia's Lippo Group plans to invest US$500 million in a new online retail platform targeting the domestic market, aiming to reach sales of US$1 billion within one to two years. The platform hopes to be the "Indonesian version of Alibaba." Lippo Group's director, John Riady, made the announcement.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 7-year peak, NZ shares hit record high
summary: Australian shares reached a 7-year peak, closing 0.3% higher at 5944.9, while New Zealand's NZX 50 index surged to a record high, gaining 2.1% to 5842.3. The gains were driven by rises in oil and metals prices, despite mixed company earnings. This is the third straight day of gains for Australian shares.

site_title: Kingsmen Creatives' FY14 profit slides 3.3%
summary: Kingsmen Creatives reported a 3.3% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$17.15 million for FY14, despite a 13.6% rise in revenue to S$336.41 million. The decline was attributed to a one-off settlement for costs related to a legal case in China. Despite this, the company remains optimistic about 2015, with Executive Chairman Benedict Soh stating that all offices are bullish about the year ahead and expect to secure new contracts. Earnings per share decreased to 8.84 Singapore cents from 9.21 cents previously.

site_title: Cheung Kong, Hutchison say shareholders approve restructuring plan
summary: Cheung Kong Holdings Ltd and Hutchison Whampoa Ltd, controlled by Li Ka-shing, have received shareholder approval for a restructuring plan that will create two separate listed companies: one focusing on property and the other on telecoms, retail, and energy. The companies' shares will resume trading in the afternoon. This move aims to boost their value and attract more investors.

site_title: Sheng Siong Q4 net profit up 26.5% to S$11.8m
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singapore grocery chain, reported a net profit of S$11.8 million in its fourth quarter, up 26.5% from last year, driven by higher operating profit margins. Revenue rose 4.7% to S$178.4 million. The company also declared a final dividend of 1.5 cents a share, up from 1.4 cents last year. Full-year net profit and revenue were up 22.3% and 5.6%, respectively.

site_title: China preparing measures to counter housing market slump
summary: China is preparing measures to counter a housing market slump, including reducing down-payment requirements for second-home purchases and allowing homeowners to sell properties without paying sales tax after two years. The government's efforts come as new-home prices posted a record year-on-year decline in January. These measures are contingent on the economy's need for support, and their implementation will depend on the severity of an economic downturn. China's previous efforts to curb property speculation and rein in price gains have been unsuccessful, with interest-rate cuts and eased curbs failing to revive the property industry.

site_title: Hot stock: Genting down 8%, breaks through S$1 support, after dismal results
summary: Genting Singapore's share price plummeted 8% to S$0.965 after reporting dismal revenue and earnings, with net profit falling 30% to S$118.9 million. This is the stock's lowest point in four years, with analysts citing below-average win percentage and VIP rolling volume as major contributors. Despite this, analysts believe Genting's share price may not fall further, with potential positive surprises including a higher dividend payout or resumption of share buybacks.

site_title: Hong Kong aims to get third runway ready by 2023 as demand soars
summary: Hong Kong aims to build a third runway by 2023 to boost capacity to 100 million passengers and 9 million tons of cargo by 2030, addressing growing demand from regional rivals. The new facility will help Hong Kong International Airport maintain its status as a major aviation center. The project, costing HK$150 billion, follows Singapore's plans to develop a fifth terminal and other countries' investments in airports to tap Asia's growing travel demand.

site_title: Mobily's CEO removed after accounting probe
summary: Mobily, a Saudi Arabian telecommunications operator, has removed its CEO Khalid al-Kaf after an accounting probe. Al-Kaf was suspended in November and offered to resign on February 21, but his position was discharged on February 24. The company has also announced it will not pay a dividend for the fourth quarter of 2014, citing a loss of 2.28 billion riyals. The move follows a restatement of earnings and an investigation into accounting practices, which has led to a significant decline in the company's stock price, down 64% from its eight-year high.

site_title: Singapore Budget Reaction: PAP Seniors Group seeks clearer implementation plans
summary: The PAP Seniors Group welcomed Singapore's Budget 2015, but sought clearer implementation plans for its initiatives aimed at supporting seniors. The group suggested waiving the 10% fee for individual-directed learning for those facing financial difficulty, creating a special category for older workers under the SkillsFuture Study Awards, and improving career counselling for mid-career workers. They also pushed for the Silver Support Scheme to be flexible, simple, and paid directly into bank accounts, and called for a comprehensive information kit covering various areas of senior welfare.

site_title: Uber plans to hire hundreds in China to expand as rivals merge
summary: Uber plans to hire hundreds of people in China to boost growth amid the merger of two largest taxi-hailing applications. The company is recruiting for operations manager and recruiter positions through LinkedIn. Uber aims to expand its business in China, where trip and user numbers have seen "double digit" growth. The company currently operates in nine Chinese cities and plans to expand to more cities, with no specific number of jobs announced. This move comes as Uber invests heavily in its success in China, a key focus for the company.

site_title: Update: Hong Kong pledges US$4.4 billion sweeteners in post-protest budget
summary: Hong Kong unveiled a HK$34 billion budget with sweeteners to help businesses affected by pro-democracy protests, aiming to rebuild confidence and maintain its competitive edge. The government has warned of economic stability as a top priority, with a 2.2% growth in the fourth quarter of last year. The budget includes measures such as tax cuts and increased child allowances, and a 2015-16 land sale programme to provide 16,000 new homes. The government forecasts a 1-3% growth this year, beating earlier estimates.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong unveiled HK$34 billion (S$6 billion) worth of sweeteners in its budget on Wednesday, including measures to help businesses hit by pro-democracy protests, as it strives to rebuild confidence amid fears the city is losing its competitive edge.

site_title: Seoul: Shares close at 5-month high, won rallies on Yellen testimony
summary: South Korean shares reached a 5-month high on February 25, 2015, closing at 1,990.47 points after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's testimony failed to provide clear hints on interest rate hikes. A survey also showed China's manufacturing activity edged up to a 4-month high, contributing to the gains. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rose 0.7%.

site_title: Hong Kong GDP growth slows in fourth quarter on political unrest
summary: Hong Kong's GDP growth slowed in the fourth quarter to 0.4% due to domestic political unrest and a sluggish global economy. Pro-democracy demonstrations in 2014 affected tourism and other industries. The government attributed the slowdown to prolonged political bickering and weakness in Europe and Japan. The slow growth highlights the challenges faced by Hong Kong's economy amidst domestic and international uncertainties.

site_title: Japan Inc's US$2 trillion cash fuels overseas purchases
summary: Japan's $2 trillion cash reserves are fueling a record-breaking overseas buying spree, with Japanese companies paying double the global average premium for acquisitions. Since January, $28 billion in purchases have been made abroad, led by Canon, Japan Post, and Itochu. Despite a weaker yen, economists predict it will continue to decline, giving companies an incentive to invest now. Japanese companies, including Japan Tobacco and Kirin, are targeting growth through takeovers abroad, with some seeking to expand into new markets and product categories.

images.alt_text: Japanese companies are on an overseas buying spree.

site_title: Thai Jan exports fall by most in 5 months, adding pressure on govt
summary: Thai exports fell 3.46% in January, the largest drop in five months, and imports tumbled 8.7%, renewing pressure on the military government to boost the economy. Exports to China and Japan dropped 20% and 7.5%, respectively, mainly due to weak agricultural export prices. This is the fourth consecutive month of declining imports, which contributed to a 0.7% economic growth last year, the weakest since 2011. The government's plans for infrastructure projects are also facing delays.

site_title: Gold rebounds from 7-week low as Yellen flags flexibility
summary: Gold prices rebounded to above $1,200 an ounce on Wednesday after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen indicated flexibility in raising US interest rates, weakening the dollar and boosting gold futures. China's Lunar New Year holiday return also lifted gold prices, with premiums on the Shanghai Gold Exchange rising. Yellen's comments were seen as "dovish," but analysts predict the rally won't be sustainable due to the expected US interest rate hike.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.29% higher on February 25, 2015, following record-setting gains on Wall Street and relief over a Greek debt deal. The benchmark Hang Seng Index gained 72.21 points to 24,822.28 points.

site_title: Quick Take: Expect Fed rate normalisation in Q2 2015, says UOB
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen signaled the central bank is moving closer to a rate hike, but remains "patient". Economist Alvin Liew from UOB expects the Fed to hike interest rates around mid-2015, possibly starting in the June FOMC meeting. Yellen's comments indicate a shift away from calendar-based guidance, instead focusing on data-dependent decisions. The Fed has kept its benchmark rate near zero since 2008, and a rate hike would be a significant change.

site_title: Seoul: Shares hit 3-month high, won firmer after Yellen
summary: South Korean shares reached a 3-month high on February 25, 2015, after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's comments on interest rate hikes. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) climbed 0.75% to 1,990.91 points, driven by optimism over China's factory activity and Greece's reform proposals. The South Korean won also firmed against the dollar, while offshore funds contributed to the market's gains.

site_title: Hong Kong forecasts GDP to expand 1-3% in 2015
summary: Hong Kong forecasts its economy to expand 1-3% in 2015, according to financial secretary John Tsang's annual budget speech. This estimate is slightly lower than a Reuters poll of analysts, which predicted a 2.7% growth.

site_title: Takeda consolidates Singapore business with an eye on emerging markets
summary: Takeda Pharmaceutical has consolidated its Singapore operations, moving its emerging markets business unit headquarters to a new office in Biopolis. The move signals the company's focus on emerging markets, a key pillar of its long-term strategy. The company expects to grow its emerging markets business by 10% and plans to accelerate the registration and launch of innovative pipeline products in gastroenterology, diabetes, and oncology. The new office will increase staff strength by 50% and host a new laboratory for vaccine development against infectious diseases in the region.

site_title: Hong Kong pledges US$37m for businesses hit by pro-democracy protests
summary: Hong Kong has pledged US$37 million to support businesses affected by the pro-democracy protests, which have paralyzed parts of the city since November 2014. The measures include waiving licence fees for 26,000 restaurants and promoting Hong Kong to investors and tourists. The government aims to rebuild confidence in the city's economy, a priority after the protests unnerved authorities in Beijing.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong announced measures totalling HK$290 million (US$37 million) on Wednesday to help businesses hit by more than two months of pro-democracy protests as the government seeks to rebuild confidence in the Asia financial centre.

site_title: Macau casinos plunge on weak gambling over Lunar New Year
summary: Macau casino shares plummeted in Hong Kong trading following weak gambling over the Lunar New Year holiday period. Analysts attributed the decline to a Chinese government crackdown on corruption, stricter travel rules, and fewer high-rollers entering the territory. Wells Fargo and Credit Suisse lowered their forecasts for Macau gross gaming revenue in February, with a 49-51% drop expected. The decline led to significant drops in shares of MGM China Holdings, Galaxy Entertainment Group, and Sands China, with declines of up to 8.4% in some cases.

site_title: Australia plans to charge fees to foreigners buying real estate
summary: Australia plans to charge foreign nationals A$5,000 for properties under A$1 million and an additional A$10,000 for each additional A$1 million, raising A$200 million annually. A register will be established to track foreign home-buyers, and those breaking laws may face fines up to a quarter of the property's value or be forced to sell. The move aims to improve housing affordability amid high property prices, particularly in cities like Sydney and Melbourne, where foreigners have been driving up prices.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Wednesday after US Fed testimony
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Wednesday after US Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen signaled a hike in interest rates is unlikely before mid-year, boosting the Straits Times Index 2.61 points to 3,440.22. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.51% and the Nasdaq Composite climbed 0.14% as markets rallied following Yellen's comments, which also suggested the Fed is preparing for a rate hike this year.

site_title: In Japan, robot dogs are for life - and death
summary: In Japan, robot dogs, known as AIBOs, have been treated as pets and have even been given funeral services when they become obsolete. The devices, equipped with artificial intelligence, were first released in 1999 and were popular among owners who formed strong bonds with them. However, Sony discontinued the AIBO line in 2006, leaving owners with repair options. A company called A FUN now employs former Sony engineers to fix and restore AIBOs, but a shortage of spare parts has led to a waiting list. The treatment of AIBOs as living entities highlights the growing attachment people have towards robots and may foreshadow the blurring of lines between humans and technology.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks edge up, memory chips, construction gain
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index rose 0.33% to 9661.20, led by gains in memory chip makers and construction. The electronics subindex increased 0.64% due to semiconductor gains, while shares of Nanya Technology Corp and Inotera Memories Inc rose 2.45% and 0.76% respectively following reports of potential Apple Inc product launches. Construction and transportation also gained 0.48% and 0.46% respectively. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$31.470 to the US dollar.

site_title: China: Shares up slightly in morning trade
summary: Chinese shares rose slightly on Wednesday, the first trading day after a week-long holiday, with the Shanghai Composite Index increasing 0.10% to 3,250.10. The Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up 0.08% to 1,612.04. The market awaited preliminary manufacturing data for February, but traders seemed unfazed by US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Singapore consumer confidence down amid personal finance worries: ANZ survey
summary: Singapore's consumer confidence index fell 2.1 percentage points to 120.7 in February, mainly due to reduced confidence in personal finances over the next 12 months. Only 27% of respondents said their families are better off financially, and 29% expect to be better off in a year. Less than half of Singaporeans believe they will see "good times" economically over the next 12 months or five years, with only 44% expecting Singapore to do well in the next 12 months. This suggests a somber outlook for consumer spending in Singapore.

site_title: Oil prices up ahead of US supply report
summary: Oil prices rose ahead of a US supply report, with West Texas Intermediate (WTI) gaining 1 cent to $49.29 and Brent crude rising 24 cents to $58.90. Analysts expect further US inventory increases, exacerbating the global supply glut and driving down prices. The US Department of Energy will release the official stockpiles report later Wednesday. The Keystone XL oil pipeline veto by President Barack Obama is seen as insignificant to crude oil prices in the short term. A drop in US crude production is needed to reverse the global supply glut.

site_title: China Feb flash HSBC PMI at 4-month high but export orders shrink
summary: China's factory sector activity reached a four-month high in February with a flash HSBC/Markit Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) of 50.1, but export orders shrank at their fastest rate in 20 months.
