The new export orders sub-index fell to 47.1, down three points from January. Despite a marginal growth, the survey suggests manufacturers face headwinds from weak foreign demand and deflationary pressures, raising concerns about further policy support. China's economy grew 7.4% in 2014, its slowest expansion in 24 years, and economists expect growth to cool further to 7% in 2015.

site_title: Genting Singapore falls to lowest in nearly 5 years
summary: Genting Singapore shares plummeted to their lowest in nearly 5 years after reporting a 30% drop in fourth-quarter profit, primarily due to poor performance from high rollers. The casino operator's shares fell 6.7% to 97.50 Singapore cents, leading to a significant trading volume of nearly 22 million shares. This is the largest single-day decline for the company since May 2010.

site_title: China's Lunar New Year retail growth slows to 11%: Ministry
summary: China's retail sales during the Lunar New Year holiday period grew 11% to 678 billion yuan, slower than the 13.3% growth seen last year. E-commerce and online platforms played a significant role in driving sales. This slowdown in retail growth may put pressure on policymakers, who are already concerned about China's slowing GDP growth. The Ministry of Commerce attributed the slower growth to various factors, including increased competition and higher costs.

images.alt_text: Growth in China's retail sales during the Lunar New Year holidays slowed to 11 percent from 13.3 per cent during the same period last year, the Ministry of Commerce said on Wednesday.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mostly higher on Fed comments, Greek reforms
summary: Asian stocks rose on Wednesday following US Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen's comments that hinted a rate hike may not occur before June, easing market concerns. Greek reforms backed by eurozone finance ministers provided a lifeline for Athens, allowing it to avoid a disastrous default. Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, and Wellington all rose, while Shanghai and Hong Kong fell. The euro held steady, and oil prices remained flat ahead of a US energy inventory report.

site_title: Tesla tops US best car list for second year
summary: Consumer Reports named Tesla's luxury electric sedan, the Tesla S, the top car in the US for the second year, praising its technological advancements and reliability. The magazine also recognized three Subaru models, including the Impreza, Legacy, and Forester, for their performance, safety, and value. Other top picks included the Buick Regal, Chevrolet Impala, and Toyota's Prius and Highlander. The rankings highlight the growing performance and reliability of American-made vehicles, with Detroit brands breaking through in new categories.

site_title: Malaysia's AirAsia X shares hit record low after Q4 loss
summary: Malaysia's AirAsia X shares plummeted 8% to a record low of 57 sen after the long-haul budget airline reported a Q4 net loss of 168.43 million ringgit (S$62.8 million). The airline attributed the loss to higher operating costs and foreign exchange losses. This is a significant decline from the same period last year, when it reported a net profit. The airline's Q4 loss is the first in its history.

site_title: Justify pump price increases, says Case to petrol companies in Singapore
summary: The Consumers Association of Singapore (Case) has sent letters to major petrol companies in Singapore, asking them to justify the recent price increases, which were larger than the size of tax hikes. The move comes after Case accused the companies of profiteering. The letters, sent on February 25, 2015, require the companies to provide explanations for the price hikes. This follows concerns over rising oil prices and the impact on consumers.

images.alt_text: Petrol companies here have been asked to justify their increase in pump prices, after they were accused of profiteering by the nation's consumer watchdog.

site_title: Noble slump fails to draw short sellers after Iceberg report
summary: Noble Group Ltd, a Singapore-listed commodities trader, saw short interest decrease to 0.2% of outstanding shares after an anonymous report, Iceberg Research, alleged accounting irregularities. The company denied the allegations and released a statement saying directors and management are "comfortable" with the balance sheet. Despite the report, Noble shares gained 0.9% and analysts maintain a long-term positive stance, citing the company's inexpensive valuation and improving financial health. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is reviewing the report, but no concrete action has been taken yet.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Vallianz, QT Vascular, Singapore Exchange, Genting, Wheelock, Chip Eng Seng
summary: Vallianz Holdings reported a 117% increase in net profit to US$18.5 million and revenue more than doubled to US$153.7 million for the financial year ended Dec 31, 2014, due to the consolidation of Rawabi Swiber Offshore Services. QT Vascular narrowed its net losses to US$34.2 million, with revenue more than doubling to US$13.2 million. Genting Singapore's net profit fell 36% to S$89.2 million, while Wheelock Properties saw its net loss widen to S$103.1 million. Chip Eng Seng Corporation posted a 383.9% increase in net profit to S$167.6 million.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: The full list of infographics
summary: The Singapore government's Budget 2015 was delivered in Parliament, featuring a range of measures aimed at preparing the country for the future. The budget includes a hefty package of goodies, the most generous since the global financial crisis, with a focus on education, healthcare, and infrastructure. The government also announced a sizeable deficit, with the majority of funds coming from savings and low interest rates. The budget will be debated in Parliament, with key topics including reserve returns, reserve returns, and the impact of the budget on various sectors.

site_title: Air New Zealand posts 6% drop in interim profit
summary: Air New Zealand reported a 6% drop in interim profit to NZ$133 million (US$100 million) for the six months to December. Normalized earnings rose 20% to NZ$216 million. Despite the drop, the airline remains on track for "significant" earnings growth in the second half, driven by low fuel prices. Chairman Tony Carter said the result demonstrated Air New Zealand's ability to generate sustainable profits, and CEO Christopher Luxon praised the airline's stake in Virgin Australia, which provides exposure to the Australian domestic market.

site_title: Hillary Clinton highlights gender pay gap ahead of likely presidential bid
summary: Hillary Clinton emphasized the pay gap between men and women in a speech to female technology executives, hinting at her likely 2016 presidential bid. She criticized technology companies for fostering a "Wild West environment" that discourages women in the industry. The former US secretary of state noted that less than a quarter of software developers are women, highlighting the issue of gender inequality. Clinton plans to make this a main theme in her campaign, targeting predominantly female audiences with three upcoming speeches.

site_title: QT Vascular slightly narrows FY14 losses
summary: QT Vascular narrowed its net losses for FY14 to US$34.17 million, down from US$34.52 million in the previous year, driven by a 102% increase in revenue to US$13.2 million. The increase in revenue was mainly due to sales of its medical devices in the US. However, higher expenses, including business activities and litigation costs, led the company into the red. QT Vascular's medical devices are used to treat vascular diseases.

site_title: Ringgit rises most in two weeks on Yellen rate outlook comments
summary: Malaysia's ringgit rose 0.6% to 3.6210 a dollar, its largest gain in two weeks, after US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen signaled a likely interest-rate increase in the second half of the year. Yellen's comments were seen as "bullish" for equities, leading to a risk-on environment. The ringgit has dropped 13% in six months, but Bank Negara Malaysia Governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz believes it is undervalued and should return to its fundamentals. The yield on three-year sovereign bonds fell to 3.43%, the lowest level since November 2013.

site_title: Growing US public support for fight against IS: poll
summary: US public support for the fight against the Islamic State (IS) group has grown, with 63% approving of the air campaign in Iraq and Syria, compared to 57% in October. The public is divided on sending US ground troops, with 47% favouring and 49% opposing. Support for the US military campaign is split by gender and party affiliation, with more Republicans and men in favour. However, 58% believe the military campaign is not going well, indicating skepticism about its effectiveness.

site_title: Britain not ready for pension changes, insurance body says
summary: Britain's government and regulators are not ready for pension reforms set to launch on April 6, according to the Association of British Insurers. Director-General Huw Evans said critical pieces of the jigsaw are missing, including rules on customer communication and tax rules. Industry observers view the reforms as being introduced with haste, giving pensioners more choice but potentially rushing them into making quick decisions. Evans urged caution, saying April 6 marks the start of the new pension freedoms, not the beginning.

site_title: Finding the right balance
summary: Private banks must carefully balance the use of investment leverage and derivative solutions in client portfolios to avoid pitfalls such as currency and term mismatches, and misuse of leverage. Clients should review and identify imbalances with their private banks, particularly in low interest rate environments. To successfully navigate the market, private banks must adhere to fundamental tenets, including KYC, account planning, and prudence in advising on balance sheet construction and liability management. Effective use of leverage can align client and bank interests, but requires striking a balance to avoid misusing derivative solutions.

site_title: Oil turns lower on expectations of crude oil inventory rise
summary: Crude oil futures fell on Tuesday as expectations of a rise in US crude inventories countered supportive news of Libyan oilfields being shut. US April crude fell 17 cents to settle at $49.28 a barrel, while Brent April crude fell 24 cents to settle at $58.66 a barrel. A Reuters survey estimated US crude stocks rose 4 million barrels last week, with industry group the American Petroleum Institute reporting a 8.9 million barrel increase to 437 million barrels. The market remains bearish due to an over-supplied market, with a senior oil analyst stating the fundamental backdrop is still bearish.

site_title: South Korea's February consumer sentiment picks up to 3-month high
summary: South Korea's consumer sentiment index reached a 3-month high in February, reaching 103, its highest since November 2014. The Bank of Korea's survey found consumers are more positive about the coming months, with a median expected inflation rate of 2.6% for the next 12 months. This marks the second consecutive month the index has surpassed 100, indicating a fragile but improving economy. Policymakers are optimistic about the recovery, which is expected to gain momentum from improvements in advanced economies and low oil prices.

site_title: New York City to have US$1.6b budget surplus
summary: New York City is expected to have a budget surplus of $1.6 billion for fiscal years 2015 and 2016, primarily due to higher-than-anticipated tax revenues. This surplus is attributed to the city's "solid" economic recovery, with tax revenues predicted to be $3.5 billion higher through 2019. Mayor Bill De Blasio's spending plans, which include universal pre-school and affordable housing, are seen as a positive development, with Comptroller Scott Stringer noting that the city's economic recovery is a "boon" for the budget.

site_title: Fed's Yellen faces heat from both sides of political divide
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen faced intense questioning from both Democratic and Republican lawmakers during a Senate Banking Committee hearing, highlighting the central bank's waning independence. Senator Elizabeth Warren urged Yellen to assess the Fed's staff leadership, amid rising threats to the Fed's authority. Meanwhile, Republicans are pushing to rein in the Fed, while Democrats are demanding more transparency. The hearing came as the Fed releases its semi-annual economic and monetary policy report to Congress, underscoring the growing pressure on the institution.

images.alt_text: Tough questions aimed at Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen from a rising force in the Democratic Party on Tuesday showed how the U.S. central bank is facing increasing pressure from both sides of the political aisle.

site_title: UK oil industry may lose 15,000 jobs in months, Ian Wood says
summary: UK oil industry workers may see 15,000 jobs lost in the next few months due to reduced investment plans following a decline in oil prices. Ian Wood, author of a state-backed review, says lower tax rates may not be enough to drive change, requiring a further 10-point reduction. The North Sea industry is experiencing a steep decline in output, with companies such as BP and Total curbing spending plans and freezing pay. The government aims to cut the effective tax rate to 50% to stimulate investment, but Wood believes a reduction to 40% or less is needed to drive change.

images.alt_text: Workers relying on the UK offshore oil and gas industry may see 15,000 jobs vanish in months as North Sea explorers cut investment plans on weaker prices, according to Ian Wood, author of a state-backed review of the business.

site_title: Europe: Stocks finish higher, London hits record
summary: Europe's main stock markets ended higher on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 reaching a record high, up 0.54%. Greece's ATHEX index rose 9.81% after eurozone finance ministers backed a four-month bailout extension. Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris's CAC 40 also increased, with Frankfurt's index up 0.67% and Paris's up 0.50%. The gains came as investors focused on the ongoing US-EU trade talks and the potential impact on markets.

site_title: Fukushima operator finds new source of radiation leak into sea
summary: Tokyo Electric Power Co Inc, the operator of the Fukushima nuclear power plant, has discovered a new source of radiation leakage into the sea. Highly contaminated water was found on the roof of a plant building, which likely leaked into the sea through a gutter during rain. This finding comes four years after the 2011 tsunami caused meltdowns at the plant. The radiation levels are not considered a significant threat, as they are controlled by monitoring radiation in sea water, and no meaningful changes have been observed. Removal of contaminated gravel and blocks is planned by March.

site_title: Italy's unions to push for stable contracts at Fiat after labour reform
summary: Italian unions will meet Fiat Chrysler Automobiles to discuss granting permanent contracts to hundreds of short-term employees, following a government move to ease labor rules. This move aims to encourage firms to hire, especially young people, as part of Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's labor reform efforts. The outcome will be a test of Renzi's strategy to boost employment, particularly among young Italians.

site_title: HP profit dips, sees impact from strong dollar
summary: HP reported a 4% drop in profits to $1.4 billion in the first quarter of fiscal 2015, citing a strong dollar as a major factor. Revenue fell 5% to $26.8 billion due to currency changes. Despite this, HP's CEO Meg Whitman said the company's turnaround remains on track, with growth in operating profit margins and increased investment in innovation. However, the strong dollar is expected to have a significant impact on HP's finances this year, with revenue from overseas earnings likely to be reduced.

site_title: Australia pleads for mercy for drug traffickers to be executed in Indonesia
summary: Australia's foreign minister has appealed to Indonesia's president to show mercy for two Australian drug traffickers set to be executed. The executions, which include 11 convicts on death row, have strained relations between the two countries. Despite repeated pleas from Australia, Brazil, and France, President Joko Widodo has denied clemency. The rejection of the Australians' latest legal appeal has led to disappointment and increased tensions between the nations.

site_title: Sony Pictures names new head of movie group
summary: Sony Pictures Entertainment has named Tom Rothman as the new chairman of its motion picture group, replacing Amy Pascal who stepped down following a cyberattack. Rothman, who previously led Fox Filmed Entertainment, will oversee the company's film business and is expected to drive growth. His appointment comes after Pascal apologized for racially insensitive emails leaked during the hack, which was blamed on North Korea. Rothman's contract as CEO of Sony Entertainment has also been extended.

images.alt_text: Sony Pictures Entertainment on Tuesday named Tom Rothman as new chairman of its motion picture group, a major move after a massive cyberattack devastated the entertainment giant.

site_title: Vallianz's profit more than doubles; revenue surges on consolidation of Saudi acquisition
summary: Vallianz Holdings reported a net profit of US$18.5 million and revenue of US$153.7 million for the 2014 financial year, more than doubling its profit and growing revenue seven times. The growth was attributed to the consolidation of Rawabi Swiber Offshore Services (RSOS), a Saudi Arabia-based company acquired by Vallianz in 2013. Despite a decline in oil prices, the company sees opportunities in shallow-water oil field development and production activities, and expects new charter contracts in target markets.

images.alt_text: Vallianz provides offshore support vessels (OSVs) and integrated offshore marine solutions to the oil and gas industry.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 hit records after Fed testimony
summary: US stocks hit records after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen pledged a cautious approach to raising interest rates, signaling the Fed is deep in preparation for a rate hike this year. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 92.35 points, while the S&P 500 gained 5.82, and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 7.15, all reaching new highs. Yellen ruled out a rate hike until June at the earliest, citing cyclical weakness in the US labor market and falling inflation.

site_title: Android dominant in two-horse smartphone race: IDC
summary: Google's Android dominated the global smartphone market in 2014 with an 81.5% market share, while Apple's iOS held 14.8%. The fourth quarter showed a slight increase in Apple's market share. Alternative platforms, including Windows Phone and BlackBerry, saw little progress, with Windows Phone losing 0.6% market share and BlackBerry nearly disappearing. Despite this, Microsoft is making moves in the low-end market with cheaper Lumia phones, and Tizen is launching in India, indicating a potential threat to Android's dominance.

site_title: Commitment from generation to generation
summary: Asia's high net worth individuals (HNWIs) are increasingly seeking private banking services, driven by changing attitudes towards wealth management and a growing emphasis on long-term planning. Unlike traditional "old money" families in Europe, many Asian HNWIs are new to private banking, but are seeking bespoke advice and trust from experienced banks. This shift is reflected in studies showing that Asian HNWIs now prioritize wealth preservation and legacy planning over wealth creation. As a result, private banks are adapting to meet the growing demand for trust and long-term guidance from these clients.

site_title: Despite free album furore, U2 tops iTunes listening
summary: U2's free album, Songs Of Innocence, dominated iTunes listening in January 2015, with 23% of users listening to at least one track, surpassing second-placed Taylor Swift. The band claimed vindication for its strategy, which was met with backlash from some users who resented the album being automatically added to their libraries. Research by Kantar Group showed that virtually all U2 listeners heard a track from the album, with lead singer Bono stating that the experiment worked and the songs "still matter" to people. The deal with Apple was reportedly worth $100 million.

site_title: Maintaining competitive edge key as Hong Kong delivers budget
summary: Hong Kong is set to unveil budget measures to support low-income families and boost the labor market, amid concerns over losing its competitive edge due to the pro-democracy protests. The government is expected to announce economic growth for the fourth quarter of last year, which was disrupted by protests. Finance Secretary John Tsang is likely to prioritize maintaining economic stability over bold new initiatives.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.18% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.18% higher on Wednesday, following record-setting gains on Wall Street and relief over a Greek debt deal. The Nikkei 225 index rose 32.86 points to a fresh 15-year high. The Dow and S&P 500 also reached new all-time closes after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen pledged a cautious approach to raising interest rates. European stocks rose strongly after eurozone finance ministers backed an extension of Greece's bailout, due to expire on Saturday.

site_title: A year to widen your investment horizons
summary: A volatile 2015 is expected to see global economic growth and asset prices remain relatively constructive, despite uncertainty in Europe and China. Oil prices plummeting and low inflation will boost disposable income and keep inflation in check, allowing central banks to loosen monetary policy. However, investors are advised to widen their investment horizons to areas less travelled, such as emerging markets, to achieve better returns, as traditional asset classes are expected to generate lower investment returns in 2015.

site_title: Overcoming key challenges in family office investing
summary: Family offices (FOs) face unique challenges in investing, including misaligned resource allocation, behavioral biases, and over-allocation to funds. To overcome these, FOs should adopt a culture of self-awareness, identifying and challenging biases, and judiciously using external resources, such as private banks and external advisers. Effective liquidity management is also crucial, with a focus on preparing a thoughtful family cash flow budget and having a credit facility in place. By recognizing these challenges and seeking collaboration with experienced professionals, FOs can improve their investment outcomes and processes.

site_title: JPMorgan to cut costs, charge for some deposits
summary: JPMorgan Chase plans to slash expenses by nearly $5 billion through 2017, cutting costs in corporate and investment banking, and consumer and community banking. The bank will also charge institutional clients for some deposits, aiming to reduce non-operating deposits by up to $100 billion by the end of 2015. This move is driven by new regulations requiring JPMorgan to hold more capital against these deposits, deemed "systemically important" by regulators. The bank also plans to reduce its branch count by about 300 through the end of 2016.

site_title: Abe turns to TPP trade talks veteran to lead farm ministry
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe re-appointed Yoshimasa Hayashi as farm minister, five months after his predecessor quit over donations scandal, amidst ongoing Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade talks. Hayashi's reappointment is seen as a positive move to ease protections for the agriculture industry and strengthen the government's stance in negotiations. The government plays down the impact of the resignation, citing Hayashi's previous experience in the role, and analysts predict limited disruption to farm policies. Abe aims to wrap up the TPP agreement this year, which could link nations with $28 trillion in annual economic output.

site_title: Consider using universal life insurance in succession planning
summary: Entrepreneurs in Asia often manage their businesses hands-on, but succession planning is crucial for the business's continuity. A recent study found that 67% of family-owned businesses in South-east Asia have made arrangements for succession, but 21% do not. Universal life insurance (ULI) can address legacy planning concerns, ensuring business liquidity and wealth equalisation. ULI policies provide a guaranteed death benefit and allow for accumulation of cash value, which can be used to settle debts and taxes. This can be particularly useful for highly leveraged businesses and those with complex family structures.

images.alt_text: Mr Lee: "A succession plan is necessary for the smooth transfer of wealth to heirs and the continued success of your business, especially if your children are involved in the business."

site_title: Growing business
summary: Asia's private banks experienced a strong 2014, driven by solid net new money inflows and volatile macro environment. UBS and Credit Suisse posted record net new money and double-digit growth in assets under management in Asia. UBS' Asia-Pacific AUM rose 23.3% to $73 billion, while Credit Suisse's AUM grew 24% to $143 billion. Other banks, such as Citi, Barclays, and DBS Private Bank, also reported significant growth in AUM. Despite increased regulatory expectations, the industry views volatility as an opportunity for growth, with many banks expecting to expand their presence in Asia.

site_title: More tax hikes 'inevitable, but not imminent'
summary: Singapore's government has announced a surprise hike in top personal income tax rates to 22% from 20%, as part of efforts to strengthen the country's revenue base. Observers say the move is likely to be followed by a rise in Goods and Services Tax (GST) rate, although this may not happen anytime soon. The government aims to review domestic taxes to bolster the country's fiscal position for the long term, with Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasizing the need for a more progressive tax system.

site_title: Digitalising in the new era
summary: Private banks face a unique opportunity in the Asia-Pacific and Latin America regions, driven by the growing number of ultra-high net worth individuals and the increasing adoption of digital channels. As the global economy shifts towards developing countries, private banks must reinvent themselves to meet the needs of this new client base. With the rise of digital technologies, banks must focus on innovation, efficiency, and client-centric services to remain competitive. Successful banks will prioritize process, product, and service innovation to generate growth and save resources, while maintaining trust and security as fundamental values.

site_title: France to double fund to help local authorities with Swiss franc surge
summary: France is doubling a fund to help local authorities deal with the surge in value of the Swiss franc, increasing it to 3 billion euros. The additional 1.5 billion euros will be split equally between banks and the state, with funds available for 15 years. This move aims to mitigate the impact of the Swiss franc's appreciation on local authorities.

site_title: Realising the investment potential of China firms
summary: China's investment potential has attracted many investors due to its rapid economic rise and emerging industrial and service sectors. However, challenges such as corporate governance issues and moderating economic growth need to be addressed. Experts Ayaz Ebrahim and Olivier Carcy advise investors to focus on companies with strong management quality and diversify their portfolios. They recommend investing in private sector Chinese companies for listed equities and state-owned companies for fixed income. Despite unique risk factors, China's economic integration and potential for management rebalancing could lead to superior long-term returns.

images.alt_text: China's rapid economic rise and the emergence of large industrial and service sectors have created a wide range of investment opportunities and instruments.
Mr Choi: "Investors need to think about other risk factors that are unique to China."

site_title: Magnus Bocker not renewing contract; exit set for end-June
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) CEO Magnus Bocker is leaving the company by the end of June amid widespread unhappiness over the moribund stock market. Despite presiding over a booming derivatives business, Bocker cited a desire to take on new challenges. The board of directors is assessing internal and external candidates to replace him, with executive search firm Spencer Stuart assisting in the process. Industry insiders attributed challenges to declining trading volumes and a lack of investor interest, as well as regulatory hurdles.

site_title: Moscow lying 'to my face,' says Kerry
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry accused Russian leaders of lying "to my face" about Moscow's involvement in the Ukraine conflict, calling it a "propaganda" exercise reminiscent of the Cold War era. Kerry refused to comment on sending US weapons to Ukraine, instead focusing on denouncing Russia's "overt and extensive" propaganda efforts.

site_title: ECB unveils new 20-euro banknote
summary: The European Central Bank unveiled the new 20-euro banknote, set to enter circulation on November 25, 2015. The new note features a "portrait window" with a transparent image of Europa when held against the light, designed to prevent counterfeiting. This is the ninth euro denomination to be introduced since 2002, with plans for new 50-euro, 100-euro, 200-euro, and 500-euro notes to follow. The ECB has printed over 4.3 billion 20-euro banknotes, which will be gradually phased in to replace existing notes.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank unveiled Tuesday the new 20-euro banknote, nine months before it starts circulating from November.

site_title: Sibor rises to 0.734% - almost double the year-ago rate
summary: The Singapore interbank offered rate (Sibor) has risen to 0.734% on February 24, 2015, nearly double the rate one year ago due to US dollar strength. Economists expect Sibor to reach near 1% by the end of the year, driven by US dollar forecasts and higher interest rates. Local interest rates have also increased, with the three-month SOR reaching a 52-week high of 0.944%. Experts attribute the rise to US dollar strength, tight liquidity, and external factors such as Greece.

site_title: Eyeing Asian and emerging markets
summary: Asian and emerging markets underperformed globally in the final quarter of 2014 due to the US dollar's strength and oil price decline. However, countries with reform agendas, such as India, Indonesia, and the Philippines, outperformed. Deutsche Bank remains neutral on the asset class, citing ongoing risks, but is positive on India, China, and the Philippines, and constructive on Chinese interest rate sensitives. To upgrade the asset class, Chinese policy, Fed clarity, less US dollar strength, and a reversal of earnings downgrades are needed.

site_title: What investors should know about risk-based investment products
summary: Investors should be aware of risk-based investment products that manage risk while generating stable returns. The 1997 Asian financial crisis showed that pursuing higher risk does not always lead to greater returns, with fixed income investors experiencing better returns with lower risk. Three risk-driven investment concepts to consider include: (1) managing volatility, (2) diversifying portfolios, and (3) using alternative investments. These strategies can help investors navigate conservative risk appetites and achieve stable returns in today's market.

site_title: Fed mulling over hike on 'meeting by meeting' basis
summary: The Federal Reserve is considering interest rate hikes "on a meeting by meeting basis" as Fed Chair Janet Yellen signaled a subtle change in the central bank's approach to rate-setting. The Fed will likely drop the word "patient" from its statement, indicating a shift in flexibility, but no guarantee of a rate hike. Economic conditions are improving, with strong job growth and a post-crisis expansion, which may lead to a rise in interest rates later this year, possibly as early as June.

site_title: Better science behind new dietary guidelines
summary: The US government is revising dietary guidelines based on new evidence from randomized controlled trials, a more rigorous form of scientific research. The previous low-fat guidelines were based on flawed epidemiologic studies, but recent research found no significant difference in mortality rates among men who followed low-fat diets. Cholesterol levels did decrease, but only by a small margin, and there was no correlation with clinical outcomes. The government committee is urging a repeal of the guideline limiting daily cholesterol intake to 300 milligrams, citing that "cholesterol is not a nutrient of concern for overconsumption."

site_title: Audience and academy move further apart
summary: The Oscars ceremony has become increasingly disconnected from moviegoers, with the audience failing to resonate with the awards. The 2015 ceremony saw a 14.9% drop in viewership to 36.6 million, the lowest since 2009. Despite the presence of notable black presenters and performers, the film "Birdman" won Best Picture, seen by fewer than 5 million ticket buyers in North America. This trend reflects the Academy's detachment from the movies that box-office analysts believe are popular, with the ceremony favoring smaller, lesser-known films.

site_title: US regulators probing 10 banks over pricing of precious metals: report
summary: US regulators are investigating at least 10 major banks, including HSBC, Barclays, and JPMorgan Chase, over possible price rigging in precious metals markets. The Department of Justice and Commodity Futures Trading Commission are scrutinizing the price-setting process for gold, silver, platinum, and palladium in London. This comes amid increased regulatory scrutiny since the 2012 Libor interest rate scandal, and follows lawsuits filed last year alleging a conspiracy to manipulate precious metals prices.

site_title: BOJ chief gets needed ally in war on deflation
summary: Japan's BOJ governor Haruhiko Kuroda received strong support from the Lower House for his monetary easing program, with the approval of Yutaka Harada as a Policy Board member. However, Kuroda is concerned about diluting his 2% annual inflation target, which may damage the fight against deflation. This move comes as support for Kuroda's policy within and beyond the board appears to be waning.

site_title: HK mulls over limiting number of Chinese tourists
summary: Hong Kong's leader, Leung Chun-ying, announced plans to restrict the number of Chinese tourists entering the city, following a public backlash over the influx of mainland visitors. The move comes after a decline in mainland visitors over Chinese New Year, with a 1.09% drop in numbers. Residents have expressed frustration with the growing number of Chinese traders and tourists, leading to violent clashes and protests. Leung said the government will continue to discuss tightening the visitor scheme to control the influx of visitors, which has put pressure on everyday life for Hong Kong residents.

site_title: Hitachi to buy Italian rail firms for US$2.1b: reports
summary: Hitachi plans to acquire Italian rail firms Finmeccanica's rail and traffic signal businesses for an estimated $2.1 billion. The deal includes AnsaldoBreda and Ansaldo STS, the world's number two traffic signal company. Hitachi aims to expand its overseas presence and challenge major international railways firms. The acquisition is expected to boost Hitachi's annual rail-related sales to over $400 billion yen, making its rail operations global and gaining Italian rail car production facilities.

site_title: Wall St's best stock pickers pin rut on Fed
summary: Wall Street's top stock pickers are struggling due to an "easy money" climate engineered by the Federal Reserve, which has artificially inflated prices of lower-quality US stocks. Many managers, including Robert D'Alelio and Donald Yacktman, have seen their performance decline over the past five years, as investors shift to low-cost index funds. Despite this, some managers, like Royce Funds, remain confident in their approach and believe that fundamentals will eventually be rewarded. Experts predict a prolonged period of active investing, as the economic cycle ages and market corrections are due.

site_title: J&J to pay more to settle suits over hip implants
summary: Johnson & Johnson's DePuy unit has agreed to extend the deadline for settlement claims over defective hip implants, pushing total compensation to approximately $3 billion. The new settlement will cover more than 90% of current hip-removal suits, with patients eligible for up to $300,000 each. The total cost of the settlements will exceed $4 billion by the time all implant cases are resolved. The decision comes after a series of court rulings and jury verdicts found the implants to be defectively designed and caused metal poisoning in patients.

site_title: ECB masks risk to euro area corporate debt
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) monetary stimulus has led investors to become too optimistic about its effects on euro area corporate debt, according to Warsaw-based mutual fund Millennium TFI SA. Corporate Eurobonds have not accounted for risks such as an economic crisis in Europe and difficult talks with Greece, and are due for a correction. The average yield on non-junk company Eurobonds has dropped to 1.23% from 2.08% last year, and Poland's zloty corporate bonds are up 14.4% this year.

site_title: Macau casino shares fall on plan to review number of mainland visitors
summary: Macau casino shares fell after a senior official announced plans to review restrictions on mainland Chinese tourists to ease overcrowding. Galaxy Entertainment Group led declines, falling 2.5% to HK$41, as the city aims to diversify away from its reliance on casinos. Macau's casino revenue slumped for the eighth straight month in January, and talks will be held between Macau and mainland authorities to analyze capacity and impact on residents' quality of life.

site_title: US policy of 'strategic patience' needs to have credible backing
summary: US President Barack Obama has outlined his foreign policy principles in a new National Security Strategy document, shifting away from "anticipatory" military action and embracing a more restrained approach. The strategy, released in February 2015, proposes a nuanced response to global threats, including the rise of ISIS and assertive Russian policy. Obama advocates for "strategic patience" in addressing security problems, resisting the urge to overcommit and making decisions based on fear. This approach differs from former President George W Bush's policies, which emphasized preemptive military action.

site_title: Towards an Asia-style monetary framework
summary: The global economy is shifting towards a more managed system of world money, influenced by Asian-style monetary frameworks. This move is driven by the recognition of the effectiveness of capital controls, currency fluctuations, and foreign reserve policies in maintaining stability. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has acknowledged the legitimacy of these measures, and countries are adopting them to counter market instability and boost economic performance. The trend also involves combining monetary and financial stability policies, and supplementing monetary policy with macroprudential tools to address asset bubbles. This shift bodes well for a more cooperative and cohesive financial system over the next decade.

site_title: 1MDB's bonds trading at risk premiums of junk bonds
summary: 1Malaysia Development Bhd's (1MDB) bonds are trading at junk bond premiums due to uncertainty over the state investment fund's plans to wind down and sell off assets. Investors demand a 441 basis-point premium, compared to similar maturity Treasuries. 1MDB needs to show progress in asset sales and avoid fire-sale prices to regain market confidence. The group faces challenges in servicing its debt, with its 2023 bonds losing 9.8% this year, and potential cross-defaults on its other debt.

site_title: EU reviews Cargill's US$440m deal for ADM chocolate unit
summary: The European Commission has opened an in-depth investigation into Cargill's planned $440 million acquisition of Archer Daniels Midland's chocolate business, citing concerns it could lead to higher prices. The deal, aimed at expanding Cargill's production capacity in North America, could delay its closure if ultimately approved. The Commission has until July 8 to investigate, citing potential competition concerns in the supply of industrial chocolate to customers in Germany and Britain, where Cargill, ADM, and Barry Callebaut are main suppliers.

site_title: Nobel Design Q4 profit up 47% at S$9.4m
summary: Nobel Design Holdings reported a 47% increase in Q4 net profit to S$9.42 million, driven by a 20% jump in revenue to S$44.8 million. The company's full-year net profit rose 16% to S$22.1 million, while its supply chain division saw a 26% sales increase to S$37.7 million. The group also invested in marketing and logistics, resulting in a drop in profitability. Nobel Design owns 25% of Cove City Ltd, which launched its London project Marine Wharf East in September 2014.

site_title: US Feb consumer confidence down
summary: US consumer confidence fell to 96.4 in February, the lowest since September, after a multi-year high in January. Economists had expected a reading of 99.6. Meanwhile, home prices in 20 US cities rose 4.5% in the year ended in December, with the S&P/Case-Shiller index increasing 4.5% from December 2013. The US services sector expanded in February at its fastest pace since October, with a Purchasing Managers Index of 57.0, indicating robust growth.

site_title: US West Coast ports work to clear biggest ship backlog since 2004
summary: US West Coast ports, which handle nearly 40% of the country's imports, are experiencing their largest backlog of ships since 2004, with 35 vessels queued up outside the ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach. The backlog, caused by a nine-month labor dispute, is expected to take six to eight weeks to clear. Despite a tentative labor contract agreement, retailers will continue to divert shipments to East and Gulf Coast ports, citing the need for a reliable supply chain. The cargo backlog affects products including patio sets, clothing, and shoes for spring sales.

site_title: Boom time ahead for equipment suppliers, yards
summary: The Ballast Water Management Convention 2004 is imminent, with 44 states ratifying the convention representing 32.86% of the world's merchant fleet tonnage. Shipowners are urged to prepare for strict regulations, which will require the installation of ballast water management systems on approximately 57,000 ships. This could lead to a boom in equipment suppliers and shipyards, as well as opportunities for private equity investors in the shipping sector. The process of retrofitting is estimated to take nearly four years, with experts warning of potential bottlenecks and commercial disadvantages for ships that fail to comply on time.

site_title: NZ economy seen growing 3% this year amid global uncertainty: forecast
summary: New Zealand's economy is forecast to grow by 3% this year, driven by domestic demand, despite slowing growth in key export markets and dry conditions affecting agriculture. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) is expected to maintain the official cash rate at 3.5% due to moderate growth and subdued inflation, but may use macro-prudential tools to control the soaring Auckland housing market.

site_title: UN panel urges more drone use in peacekeeping missions
summary: A UN panel has recommended the widespread use of drones in peacekeeping missions, with the capacity for aerial visualization being a must-have for every mission. The panel, led by Jane Holl Lute, also suggested increased cyber security measures and the use of "green" technology. The UN has already begun using drones in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and plans to use them in Mali. The recommendations were well-received by troop contributing countries, but some nations raised concerns about data storage and sharing. The UN aims to own the information gathered by drones and establish strict rules for their use.

site_title: Land area for new China housing drops 25% in 2014
summary: China's land area for new property developments decreased by 25.5% in 2014, reaching 1,510 square kilometers, compared to 2013. This drop highlights the housing downturn in China, which was exacerbated by weakening demand and a glut of unsold homes. The sluggish housing sector accounted for 15% of China's annual economic output, contributing to the country's 24-year low economic growth of 7.4% in 2014.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng's Q4 earnings more than quadruple to S$167.6m
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corp, a Singapore-based property and construction group, reported a 383.9% increase in net profit to S$167.6 million for Q4 2014, driven by strong contributions from property developments. Full-year net profit rose 282.6% to S$280.7 million, with revenue increasing 120.1% to S$1.1 billion. The company plans a cautious approach due to cooling measures and economic uncertainty, but anticipates rising demand for development projects in the East Coast area.

site_title: BHP Billiton H1 profit almost halves
summary: BHP Billiton reported a 47.4% decline in its first-half net profit to $4.26 billion, largely due to falling prices for its two main commodities, iron ore and oil. Despite the slump, the company boosted its interim dividend by 5.1% and reduced capital spending by 40%. CEO Andrew Mackenzie attributed the decline to a preparation for lower prices, citing increased focus on efficiency and lower investments. The company plans to demerge non-core assets into South32, which will be listed in Sydney, London, and Johannesburg, to simplify the business and cut costs.

images.alt_text: "We started to prepare for a sustained period of lower prices almost three years ago by increasing our focus on efficiency and lowering our investment," said Mr Mackenzie.

site_title: A budget for SG50: going local to go global
summary: Singapore's 2015 Budget focuses on economic restructuring, promoting productivity and innovation, while strengthening its social security system. The government emphasizes lifelong learning through the SkillsFuture initiative, covering training subsidies and mentoring programs. The budget also refines productivity support measures and spurs innovation and internationalization efforts for businesses. Despite global economic challenges, the government aims to sustain past economic successes and promote further growth. The comprehensive approach to SkillsFuture aims to support all Singaporeans in achieving their aspirations.

site_title: Hedge funds, money managers raise bullish oil bets as drillers idle rigs
summary: US hedge funds and money managers have increased their bullish oil bets for the first time in five weeks, citing curbed new drilling by producers. This comes as US rigs have tumbled 35% since December 5, to the lowest level since 2011, and outlays for exploration are expected to fall by over $116 billion in 2015.

site_title: Japan insurers' push abroad raises angst over yen, hedging costs
summary: Japan's life and non-life insurers have reduced their investments in Japanese government bonds to 42.9% and 18.6% of their assets, respectively, due to low domestic interest rates and rising hedging costs amid a weakening yen. Insurers are seeking higher returns to meet payouts in a rapidly ageing society, but face risks from a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. The Bank of Japan's stimulus programme has encouraged insurers to invest in riskier assets, including foreign bonds, but timing will be crucial for investment.

site_title: Will CDL be able to pull off new growth strategy?
summary: CDL, a Singapore property group, is shifting its focus towards fund management and overseas acquisitions after struggling in the local market. The group, led by executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng, has syndicated the cash flow from its Quayside Collection project, raising over S$1 billion, and appointed a new CEO to drive its transformation. CDL aims to expand in the US, UK, Japan, China, and Australia, and stabilize earnings through fee income from fund management, which will also enhance returns on equity. However, the group's success in adopting this new strategy is uncertain, with concerns over its ability to build a strong management bench and decentralize management.

site_title: Wall St, law firms plan to bolster online security
summary: Wall Street banks and big law firms are planning to form a legal group to share information about digital security issues, following a year of discussions. The group would be affiliated with the Financial Services Information Sharing and Analysis Center, which already shares threat information among banks and brokerage firms. The move comes as hackers increasingly target law firms to gather information about corporate clients, and federal authorities encourage companies to share information about hackings with each other and law enforcement. The group is expected to be voluntary, but many large law firms are likely to join, with access to resources and security threat information.

site_title: Oil turns lower in Asia, US crude stays below US$50
summary: Oil prices fell in Asia on Tuesday, with US crude staying below $50. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate (WTI) dropped 29 cents to $49.16, while Brent crude fell 17 cents to $58.73. Global oversupply, driven by US crude stockpiles at record levels, contributed to the decline. Oilfields in eastern Libya resumed pumping, and Oman plans to increase output, further boosting global supplies. Analysts expect the market to remain oversupplied for most of 2015, with prices likely to remain volatile.

site_title: Carney pledges to return inflation to 2%
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney pledged to return inflation to 2% within a "reasonable horizon" as the UK's inflation rate remains below target. The pound strengthened to a seven-year high against the euro after Carney's comments, with investors pricing in a potential interest rate hike by April 2016. BOE officials, including Martin Weale, also expressed concerns about labour-cost pressure and the need for policy tightening. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) recommended further action to rein in mortgage lending and recommended extending stress tests to more financial institutions.

site_title: Indonesia to crack down on corporate tax avoidance
summary: Indonesia plans to crack down on corporate tax avoidance via transfer pricing, aiming to recoup 200 trillion rupiah (S$21 billion) in lost state income. This move is crucial for President Joko Widodo's administration, which plans to double infrastructure spending this year. The lost income would cover more than two-thirds of the increased spending. The tax office suspects companies are using transfer pricing to reduce profits earned in Indonesia. The move is expected to help the government meet its infrastructure spending goals.

site_title: Asia-Pacific's pension funds find new ways to spend 'risk budget'
summary: Pension funds in Asia-Pacific are adapting to severe headwinds by increasing their risk appetite. A State Street survey found 88% of respondents expect to boost their investment risk over the next three years. To balance growth and risk, pension funds are diversifying into alternative assets such as direct loans, real estate, and single-manager hedge funds. This shift aims to drive higher returns while controlling costs and minimizing risk exposure, a delicate balancing act amidst weak investment returns, a shrinking workforce, and longer life expectancy of retirees.

site_title: Is oil returning to US$100 or dropping to US$10?
summary: Oil prices are unlikely to reach $100 per barrel in the near future, contradicting predictions by some analysts, including T Boone Pickens. Instead, prices may stabilize around $50-70 per barrel, driven by increased supply and slower global economic growth. The supply increase, fueled by fracking, has outpaced demand, making a rapid return to $100 per barrel unlikely. External influences, such as major economic downturns, are needed to drive prices back up to $100 per barrel.

site_title: Transport operators up on announced infrastructure investment
summary: Singapore transport operators saw a boost after the finance ministry announced a major infrastructure investment plan, including improvements in public transport. ComfortDelGro surged 3.8%, while its peers SBS Transit and SMRT rose 1.4% and 1.7%, respectively. The investment aims to meet Singapore's future economic and social needs.

site_title: HK budget goodies seen for labour market, the low-income
summary: Hong Kong's annual budget is expected to unveil measures to support low-income families and boost the labour market, but bold initiatives may be unlikely due to an uncertain economic outlook. The government aims to maintain economic stability after pro-democracy protests. Proposed measures include a salary tax rebate, property rate waiver, and increased tax allowance for parents. The city risks losing its competitive edge, as warned by the government.

site_title: India's retail dilemma: too few nice malls
summary: India's retail sector faces a severe shortage of attractive malls, hindering expansion plans for foreign and domestic retailers. Many malls struggle with poor design, inefficient management, and lack of popular attractions. Despite the growth of the economy, India's mall space is limited, with only 77.6 million square feet, and one in every six stores is empty. Retailers are looking at alternatives, such as leasing standalone shops or investing in online services, as the shortage of physical retail space persists.

site_title: Genting Q4 net down as pool of VIP gamblers shrinks
summary: Genting Singapore's Q4 net profit fell 36% to S$89.2 million due to a shrinking pool of VIP gamblers and a low luck factor. Revenue slipped 8% to S$637.9 million. The company's mass market slot segment showed a favorable trend, with better margins and less volatility. Net profit, including perpetual capital securities, fell 30% to S$118.9 million.

site_title: New EU buy-in rule will raise corporate funding costs, says study
summary: The European Union's new buy-in rule for failed trades on capital markets is expected to raise corporate funding costs by "several billions of euros" annually, according to a study by the International Capital Market Association. The rule, set to be implemented in 2016, would require trading venues or disappointed buyers to appoint a third party to rescue failed trades, passing costs on to the seller. This could lead to higher prices for government bonds and corporate bond markets drying up.

site_title: Millennials still prefer print for pleasure and learning
summary: Millennials, aged 18-29, prefer reading in print over digital, despite being digital natives. Studies show the highest print readership rates among this age group, with many college students still buying print versions of e-textbooks and preferring print for pleasure and learning. Researchers attribute this preference to the physicality of print, which allows readers to build mental maps, remember page layouts, and avoid distractions. In contrast, digital reading is often marked by skimming, multitasking, and poor comprehension. The preference for print is also driven by the high cost of digital textbooks and the desire for a more tactile learning experience.

site_title: Global trends to influence Asian financial assets
summary: Asian financial assets are expected to be influenced by central bank actions and low oil prices. Central banks' surprise actions, such as the European Central Bank's asset purchase program and the Swiss National Bank's decision to float the Swiss franc, may create moderate volatility. Low oil prices will support Asian equities, particularly in countries like China and India, due to lower export prices and government reforms. The article forecasts higher-than-consensus 2015 growth for the world and emerging markets, with a growth rate of 3.8% and 6% respectively, driven by increased trade and lower energy prices.

site_title: India's logistics firms expand as e-commerce market booms
summary: India's logistics firms are expanding due to the growing e-commerce market. Blue Dart Express, a unit of DHL Express, is adding a Boeing 757 freighter to its fleet and building warehouses for sellers on Amazon and Flipkart. This expansion is part of the company's efforts to meet the increasing demand for online shopping in the country of 1.2 billion people. Other logistics companies are also investing in their services to cater to the growing e-commerce sector.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sarine Technologies' FY14 net profit of US$27.2 million (S$37 million) met expectations but fell short of the market's US$28.8 million. The company expects Indian manufacturers' output to remain low, but its innovative products are expected to spur a resumption of equipment demand. Noble Group's FY14 net income forecast of US$527 million was met, with the company expected to highlight its deleveraged balance sheet following the sale of Noble Agri.

site_title: US industry lobbyists take aim at proposed FAA drone rules
summary: US industry lobbyists, including Amazon and Google, are pushing back against proposed FAA drone rules, arguing that cutting-edge technologies make some limitations unnecessary. The proposed rules would restrict commercial drone flights to 500 feet, daytime hours, and require constant line of sight. Industry representatives claim that breakthrough safety features could make drone flights safe and dependable, and they will use the 60-day public comment period to convince regulators to reconsider. The FAA's final rules could take 9-3 years to complete, and companies can apply for exemptions under strict rules until then.

site_title: Budget 'helps construction sector, but challenges remain'
summary: Singapore's construction sector is expected to benefit from Budget 2015, with increased focus on infrastructure development and higher-skilled job training. However, smaller companies may struggle to compete with larger firms, potentially leading to consolidation or acquisitions. The government's deferral of foreign worker levy increases and reduction in levy for higher-skilled workers provide a temporary reprieve. Despite this, industry players warn that the sector faces long-term challenges and may require further government incentives to absorb rising labor costs.

site_title: Homes sell so fast in Stockholm that buyers bid before public showing
summary: Stockholm's housing market has become extremely competitive, with homes selling out quickly. Buyers must bid on apartments before public showings, as the sale process often takes just one or two days. Housing prices have reached a record, driven by high demand and low interest rates, which have been lowered by the Riksbank to minus 0.1%. Experts warn that the rapid price growth and high household debt pose a threat to the economy, with the central bank urging policymakers to address the issue.

site_title: Entrepreneurs, venture capitalists hail venture debt initiative
summary: Entrepreneurs and venture capitalists in Singapore have welcomed the government's proposal for a venture debt initiative, which aims to provide 50% risk-sharing with banks to fund startups with minimal collateral. However, concerns remain about the limited scope and challenges in implementation, particularly in getting enough bank partners to participate. The government's Budget 2015 also focuses on startups seeking at least S$1 million in funding, which may not benefit early-stage companies. Despite these challenges, the government's moves are seen as a step towards creating a supportive environment for innovation and entrepreneurship in Singapore.

site_title: FCC plan to legislate equal Internet access to all raises passions
summary: The US Federal Communications Commission (FCC) is set to vote on rules aimed at ensuring equal Internet access for all, a move that has sparked intense debate over the importance of "net neutrality". The proposed rules, which would bar "paid prioritisation" and other forms of discrimination, are likely to face challenges in court and attempts to nullify them in Congress. Supporters of net neutrality argue it ensures freedom and innovation, while critics claim it will stifle investment and cost consumers more.

site_title: German economy gets boost from consumers, exports
summary: Germany's economy regained its position as Europe's economic powerhouse in the fourth quarter, driven by domestic spending, exports, and a decline in energy costs. The country's GDP expanded 0.7% and private consumption increased 0.8%, with real wages rising 1.6% in 2014. The European Central Bank's quantitative easing program has also contributed to the economic growth, making German exports more competitive. The euro-area economy expanded 0.3% in the same period, but growth prospects are clouded by Greece and the risk of deflation.

site_title: More evidence that HSBC is now too big to regulate
summary: HSBC's CEO Stuart Gulliver is facing scrutiny over his personal banking arrangements, including a Swiss account he set up in 1998 with $7.6 million, which he claims was for "reasons of confidentiality" and "provided no tax or other advantage." The bank has been accused of tax evasion and money laundering, and regulators are threatening to issue international arrest warrants. The bank's earnings report showed a 17% decline in full-year pretax profit, and investors have trashed the company's share price. Experts say HSBC should face criminal charges and that its size and opacity make it too big to regulate.

site_title: Charlie Hebdo to print 2.5m copies after Denmark shooting
summary: Charlie Hebdo, the French satirical weekly, has published a new issue under heavy police protection after being attacked in January. The issue, titled "C'est Reparti!" or "Here We Go Again!", features a pack of dogs chasing a small dog with a Charlie Hebdo copy, and over 2.5 million copies are slated to be printed. The attacks in Denmark have led to increased security measures across Europe, with police deploying heavily armed forces to protect sensitive sites. The issue's publication comes five weeks after the Paris bloodbath, which killed 12 people, including nine journalists.

site_title: As expected, impact of Budget 2015 on S-Reits is minimal
summary: Singapore's Reits welcomed the extension of tax incentives, with the FTSE ST Reit index rising 0.6% to 804.29. Analysts expected minimal impact, despite the removal of stamp duty concessions and the lapse of stamp duty remissions. Reits with domestic exposures rose, while those with overseas exposure saw a potential 14-17% drop in profit and dividend. The Reit sector faces headwinds, including a challenging operating landscape and uncertainty over interest rate movements.

site_title: AirAsia, ANA offer support for Skymark: minister
summary: Transport Minister Akihiro Ohta announced that AirAsia and ANA Holdings have applied to support Skymark Airlines, which filed for bankruptcy protection in January. Skymark is seeking a partner to help it restructure and emerge from bankruptcy, with a restructuring plan expected to be presented by the end of May. The airline's shares surged 15% after the announcement, and are set to be delisted on March 1. Skymark's liabilities total 71 billion yen, and it is also seeking other partners to aid in its turnaround.

site_title: Wilting consumer sentiment in Malaysia tilts ad expenditure
summary: Malaysia's advertising expenditure (adex) declined 11% year-on-year in the fourth quarter, with free-to-air TV and newspapers reporting double-digit drops. The decline is attributed to weak consumer sentiment, weak property sales, and the impact of the new 6% Goods & Services Tax (GST). Despite this, Pay-TV and cinema segments saw growth, with Pay-TV increasing 10% and cinemas growing 16%. Analysts expect media companies to experience a "decent earnings recovery" once consumer sentiments normalize.

site_title: US regulator calls for rigorous review of risky ETFs
summary: US Securities and Exchange Commission Democratic member Kara Stein has called for a more transparent and rigorous review process for listing riskier exchange-traded funds (ETFs) before they can be approved. Stein's concerns stem from the complexity of the funds and potential harm to investors who may not fully understand how they operate. The SEC approved a rule change allowing seven new ETFs from AccuShares Investment Management to list on the Nasdaq stock market exchange, which Stein believes could harm retail investors. She urges a more thorough review process for similar products.

site_title: Eurozone backs Greek reform plan, aid extension
summary: Greece secured a four-month extension of its financial rescue package after its eurozone partners approved a reform plan that watered down key leftist measures. The plan, signed by Marxist Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis, includes measures to improve tax enforcement and fight corruption, but does not include a halt to privatisations or a significant boost to welfare spending. The reform plan has been deemed "sufficiently comprehensive" by the European Commission and the International Monetary Fund, paving the way for a successful conclusion of the review.

site_title: CPF makes investing simple for older workers
summary: Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) is introducing changes to boost retirement adequacy and simplify investing for older workers. From next year, those aged 55 and above can earn up to 6% guaranteed interest on their first S$30,000 of CPF savings. The government will also increase the CPF salary ceiling to S$6,000 and the annual contribution cap for the Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS) to S$15,300. These changes aim to aid older workers in building up more funds for retirement, but some experts suggest the government should review the CPF Investment Scheme structure and consider private employer involvement.

site_title: Do bank mergers within the same market work?
summary: A recent bank merger in Malaysia between CIMB, RHB, and MBSB collapsed, highlighting the challenges of in-market mergers. Despite touted benefits of size and increased market shares, these deals often struggle to deliver value due to difficulties in retaining key personnel, staff severance, systems integration, and political implications. The market reaction to the collapse, with stock prices rising despite declining markets, suggests that investors view the risks as greater than the benefits. Ultimately, most in-market deals are a cost play, requiring exceptional management skill to eliminate duplication and reduce costs, but this can be a difficult and uncertain process.

site_title: Denmark's currency loses appeal for top commercial fund
summary: Denmark's biggest commercial fund, PFA Pension A/S, has lost appeal for krone-denominated assets due to low returns. Central bank efforts to prevent the krone from strengthening have led to record currency-market interventions and interest rate cuts. Yields on government bonds are negative, and the fund's liabilities are krone-denominated, limiting its ability to shift investments. The fund's chief investment officer, Poul Kobberup, says Danish assets are no longer attractive, citing more favorable returns in the US, UK, and Sweden.

site_title: Bird spit coffee? Asian firms seek global appetite for China delicacy
summary: Asian firms are seeking to expand the global market for China's prized bird's nests, made from swiftlets' saliva, to increase profit margins. The nests, valued at up to $2,500 per kg, are traditionally consumed in China and are now being mixed into coffee and cereal. Companies are investing in marketing and product diversification, such as coffee and skin care, to attract new consumers. The industry is expected to double in sales to $10 billion by 2020, with Malaysia and Indonesia being the largest producers of raw nests.

site_title: Wheelock's Q4 loss widens, but profit up 7.7% for FY14
summary: Wheelock Properties, a luxury property developer in Singapore, reported a widened net loss of S$103.1 million in Q4 2014, despite a 7.7% increase in full-year net profit to S$43.1 million. Revenue fell 7.2% in Q4 and 15.4% for the year. The company proposed a dividend of six cents per share. Notably, Wheelock recognized a book gain of S$434 million from its investment in 68 Holdings, driven by a significant increase in the company's share price. The group expects subdued local market conditions in 2015.

site_title: Mutual funds net buyers of S'pore plays in Nov-Feb
summary: Mutual funds were net buyers of Singapore stocks for the three months to Feb 18, with net buys totaling about S$1.51 billion. In the consumer goods sector, there were S$252.4 million of net sells, mainly due to Olam International, while Thai Beverage Public Co was the top buy with S$81 million. This data, provided by ShareInvestor and Ipreo, offers insight into fund managers' focus, but may not reflect the entire picture of trading by alternative investors and institutional money managers.

site_title: Elderly in HK vie for jobs as Asia's worst ageing crisis looms
summary: Hong Kong is facing an aging crisis with 2/3 of its elderly population relying on government benefits and struggling to find work. The city is expected to have the highest share of population aged 65 and over in Asia by 2050. Despite a budget surplus of HK$62 billion, the government is under pressure to address the issue, with Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying calling for increased fiscal firepower. The prospect of higher interest rates also poses a risk to revenue from property transactions, which has kept government coffers flush.

site_title: StanChart in biggest fall since Oct, after HSBC's lacklustre results
summary: Standard Chartered fell 5.6% in London trading, its largest intraday drop since October, after HSBC reported weaker-than-expected fourth-quarter profit. The bank's shares have declined 29.5% in the past year, the worst performance among Britain's largest lenders. CEO Peter Sands faces investor concerns about raising capital buffers amid a commodities slump and higher loan losses. Standard Chartered makes three-quarters of its earnings from Asia, and its full-year earnings are due on March 4.

site_title: Greece bailout extension backed by eurozone
summary: Eurozone finance ministers approved a four-month extension to Greece's financial lifeline, backed by a list of reforms demanded by creditors. The reforms include tightening tax collection and government spending, and cracking down on corruption. The deal is contingent on approval from parliaments in several countries, including Germany, and must be finalized by the end of April. The extension is seen as a temporary measure to keep Greece afloat and in the single currency, with the country's debt worth 175% of annual economic output.

site_title: Aozora to raise 50b yen from Japan banks for real estate funds
summary: Aozora Bank Ltd plans to raise 50 billion yen (S$571.5 million) from Japanese banks to invest in real estate funds, targeting 2-3% annual returns. The Tokyo-based bank aims to establish the funds over three years, with initial investments of 10 billion yen. This move diversifies assets for local banks seeking higher returns amidst record-low interest rates and a shrinking population. Aozora's goal is to create financial products for regional lenders and other investors, capitalizing on Japan's property market revival sparked by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's efforts to end deflation.

site_title: Share of govt revenue from COE, ARF to rise to 10% (Amended)
summary: Singapore's government expects COE (Certificate of Entitlement) and ARF (Additional Registration Fee) revenue to reach 10% of total revenue in FY2015, up from 8% the previous year. Vehicle quota premiums are projected to increase by 38.7% and motor vehicle taxes by 17%, driven by expected spikes in car registrations and tightening of CEVS (Carbon Emission-based Vehicle Scheme) bands and surcharges. This will contribute to a 6.9% and 2.9% share of total revenue, respectively, alongside personal income tax (12.2%), corporate income tax (18.4%), and the goods and services tax (14.3%).

site_title: Sibor rises to 0.734% - almost double the year-ago rate
summary: The Singapore interbank offered rate (Sibor) has risen to 0.734%, nearly double the year-ago rate, due to continued US dollar strength. Experts predict further US dollar strength and higher interest rates, with forecasts ranging from 0.8% to 0.95% for the three-month Sibor by the end of the year. Another benchmark interest rate, the three-month SOR, also reached a 52-week high of 0.944, up over 5% from last week. This rise is attributed to the SGD weakness and firmer US short-term interest rates.

site_title: Diversifying effectively in a divergent market
summary: In a diverging market with increased volatility, diversifying effectively is crucial for investors to navigate the uncertain economic environment. UBS advises holding a well-diversified portfolio of equities, bonds, and alternatives, with a focus on US dollar and eurozone equities, and investment-grade corporate bonds. A core-satellite approach, which splits investments into a core portfolio and satellite investments, can help achieve a well-balanced portfolio. Investment mandates, which delegate analysis and day-to-day investment decisions to a financial partner, can also help overcome "home bias" and reduce performance volatility.

images.alt_text: Mr Ang: "An added advantage of investment mandates is that it helps investors to overcome 'home bias', the common disposition of investors to stick to their home markets."

site_title: France warns of nuclear industry shake-up after Areva's expected loss
summary: France's energy minister Ségolène Royal warned of a shake-up in the country's state-controlled nuclear energy industry due to Areva's expected 2014 net loss of 4.9 billion euros. The French government, which owns 87% of Areva and nearly 85% of EDF, is considering new funds to support the companies. The industry's travails underline the challenges faced by the global nuclear sector since the Fukushima disaster in 2011, with analysts predicting a decline in nuclear's share of electricity supply in Europe and growth in countries like China, India, and Russia.

site_title: TSE orders firms to appoint at least 2 outside directors
summary: The Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE) has ordered listed firms to appoint at least two outside directors by June, aiming to improve corporate governance and attract foreign investors. The move is part of Japan's efforts to change corporate culture and attract double the foreign direct investment by 2020. The new rules, which apply on a "comply or explain" basis, follow criticism from US investor Daniel Loeb and a survey showing 38% of firms had boards consisting entirely of insiders. This is a cultural turning point for Japan, where companies prioritize employee welfare over shareholder returns.

site_title: Trek's full-year profit surges on revenue jump
summary: Trek 2000 International reported a 152.7% surge in net profit to $2.55 million for the full year ended Dec 31, 2014, driven by increased sales of ThumbDrives, security solutions, FluCard, and Wi-Fi memory modules. Group revenue grew 52.8% to $112.9 million, with the core ICS division accounting for 90% of revenue. The company also expanded its focus to the consumer SSDs market through a joint venture and plans to grow its licensing revenue streams. A final dividend of 0.5 Singapore cent per share was recommended.

site_title: Amex 'anti-competitive' but ruling may not help consumers
summary: US Federal Judge Nicholas G Garaufis ruled that American Express engaged in anti-competitive practices by charging merchants higher fees, which resulted in higher prices for consumers. The ruling may lead to lower card company fees for retailers, but it's unlikely to benefit consumers, as retailers will pocket the savings and pass on the costs through higher retail prices. This outcome is similar to past regulations, such as the Durbin Amendment, which reduced merchant fees but did not lead to lower prices for consumers. American Express is appealing the decision, and the judge's ruling may not increase competition or lead to lower retail prices as expected.

site_title: Deutsche Bank signs multi-billion-dollar IT deal with HP
summary: Deutsche Bank has signed a 10-year, multi-billion-dollar IT deal with Hewlett-Packard (HP) to outsource its wholesale banking IT infrastructure. Under the agreement, HP will provide dedicated data centre services, while Deutsche Bank will retain IT architecture, application development, and information security. The exact contract value was not disclosed.

site_title: Hong Kong mulls restrictions on Chinese tourists
summary: Hong Kong's leader Leung Chun-ying announced plans to restrict the number of Chinese tourists entering the city, following a public backlash over the influx of mainland visitors. The move comes after a decline in mainland visitors during the Lunar New Year period, attributed to a frosty reception. The restriction will be discussed with Chinese authorities at the National People's Congress in March, amid growing anger among Hong Kongers over Chinese traders and wealthy mainland visitors.

site_title: The future may be cheaper than thought
summary: Government economists have consistently overestimated interest payments on 10-year Treasury bonds, leading to a misrepresentation of the government's fiscal burden. This systemic error has resulted in forecasts suggesting higher debt payments than necessary, potentially leading to unnecessary budget cuts. Recent forecasts, however, suggest that interest rates may be lower than predicted, potentially reducing the debt-to-GDP ratio by six percentage points by 2025. This could alleviate fiscal pressures, but uncertainties remain, and a correction in forecasting models is recommended to accurately assess future debt payments.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed ahead of Yellen testimony
summary: US stocks were mixed in early trade on Tuesday ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's testimony before Congress. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 28.71 points, while the S&P 500 edged up 0.36 points. The Nasdaq Composite Index, however, dropped 6.26 points. Yellen stated that a rate hike is "unlikely" before June, citing the need to assess the economy.

site_title: SGX CEO Magnus Bocker to leave end June 2015
