summary: SGX CEO Magnus Bocker will leave the company by end June 2015, as his current contract expires. Bocker has been CEO since 2009. The board is moving forward with a CEO succession plan, assessing internal and external candidates. No details on the new CEO have been announced.

images.alt_text: SGX announced on Tuesday that its CEO, Mr Magnus Bocker, will not seek extension of his appointment beyond his current contract, which will be completed on 30 June 2015.

site_title: Local stocks rise with hope of a Greek fix
summary: Singapore stocks rose 16.31 points, or 0.48%, to close at 3,437.61 on Tuesday, driven by hopes of progress in the Greek debt crisis. The Straits Times Index was buoyed by gains from blue chips such as DBS Group Holdings, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank. Commodity counters, however, saw weakness due to soft crude palm oil prices, with Golden Agri-Resources and Noble Group retreating.

images.alt_text: The Straits Times Index (STI) of large-cap stocks rose 16.31 points, or 0.48 per cent, to reverse its Monday decline and close at 3,437.61.

site_title: Genting Singapore's Q4 profit slumps 36%
summary: Genting Singapore's Q4 profit plummeted 36% to S$89.2 million, with net profit falling 30% to S$118.9 million. Revenue declined 8% to S$637.9 million. The gaming business saw respectable growth in mass and premium mass segments, but the VIP segment was impacted by low win percentages and rolling volumes.

site_title: Rate hike unlikely before June: Yellen
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated that a rate hike is unlikely before June due to the US labor market's cyclical weakness and falling inflation. The Fed continues to monitor the economy, citing frailties in China and Europe, but remains patient before tightening policy. Yellen emphasized the need for sustainable improvements in labor market conditions and a return to normal inflation before considering a rate hike. The Fed's next meeting is scheduled for June 16-17, with the goal of normalizing monetary policy later this year.

site_title: Tokyo exchange orders firms to appoint at least two outside directors
summary: The Tokyo Stock Exchange has ordered companies listed on the exchange to appoint at least two outside directors by June, in an effort to improve corporate governance and attract foreign investors. This move is seen as a "cultural turning point" by Japan Exchange Group Inc's CEO Atsushi Saito, following criticism of Japan's corporate culture prioritizing employee welfare over shareholder returns. The goal is to attract double the foreign direct investment by 2020, as part of the government's efforts to change corporate culture under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 9.29 points to 1,818.68. The market saw a gain of 432 to 409 gainer-to-loser ratio, with a total volume of 2.18 billion lots worth RM2.12 billion.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Tuesday
summary: Singapore news updates include a surprise reaction from Vietnam to the US tariff announcement, while the Asian garment industry prepares for higher tariffs. In other news, Malaysia plans to seize RM3 billion of assets from Daim Zainuddin, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and Citigroup predicts a 1,150 MSCI global equity index target by mid-2026. Thai Prime Minister Thaksin remains confident his daughter's suspension will be cleared in an ethics case, and ASEAN has deemed Myanmar's election a low priority. The UK economy also shrank for the second month, causing a fresh blow to Labour leader Starmer.

site_title: JTC launches Tuas South site for sale by tender
summary: JTC Corporation launched a 0.7-hectare site at Tuas South Street 6 for sale by tender under the first half 2015 industrial government land sales (IGLS) programme. The site, zoned for Business-2 development, has a 20-year tenure with a maximum gross plot ratio of 1.0. This is the first confirmed list site launched according to schedule, regardless of demand.

images.alt_text: JTC Corporation on Tuesday launched a 0.7-hectare site at Tuas South Street 6 (Plot 46) for sale by public tender under the first half 2015 industrial government land sales (IGLS) programme.

site_title: Singapore: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's shares closed higher on Tuesday, with the STI rising 16.31 points to 3,437.61. Volume reached 1.07 billion shares worth S$1.25 billion, with 226 gainers outnumbering 194 losers.

site_title: Wheelock Properties' Q4 loss widens, but full-year profit rises
summary: Wheelock Properties reported a widening net loss of S$103.1 million in Q4 2014, down from S$91.3 million, due to a 7.2% decline in revenue to S$26.90 million. However, full-year net profit rose 7.7% to S$43.1 million. The company attributed the decline to stringent government policies and tightened mortgage lending practices. Despite challenging market conditions, Wheelock Properties is poised to capitalize on opportunities with prudent financial management and a strong cash position. The company proposes a six cents per share dividend.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall on HSBC results, weak casino operators
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.4% to 24,750.07 points, ending a six-session winning streak, due to weak results from HSBC and casino operators. HSBC's annual pretax profit slid 17% and its earnings target was cut, while casino shares declined 2.7% as investors locked in gains. Mainland China markets reopen on Wednesday, and other Hong Kong-listed companies, including conglomerate Hutchison Whampoa, are due to announce results later this week.

site_title: Russia, India, Turkey among central banks likely to ease rates
summary: Central banks in Russia, India, and Turkey are expected to ease interest rates this year, while the US, Brazil, Mexico, and Nigeria are likely to raise rates. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise its benchmark interest rate to 0.5-0.75% by year-end, while Brazil and Mexico will follow. Nigeria's central bank will raise rates by 1 percentage point, driven by a better economic outlook. Russia, on the other hand, is poised for a significant rate cut to 11% by year-end, after a recent rate hike.

site_title: IMF's Lagarde expresses reservations about Greek reform plan
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde expressed reservations about Greece's reform plan, stating it lacks necessary detail. The plan is deemed sufficient for continuing aid but requires more specificity in areas such as combating tax evasion and corruption, pensions, and value-added tax policy. Euro zone finance ministers agreed to allow a Greek request for a bailout extension, pending approval by member state parliaments.

site_title: Greenback hits 2-week high against yen
summary: The US dollar reached a two-week high against the yen on Tuesday, rising 0.6% to 119.51 yen, ahead of Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen's testimony on interest rate hikes. Yellen's appearance may signal a more dovish stance, potentially limiting the dollar's gains. The New Zealand dollar dropped 1% against the US dollar, while the Australian and Canadian dollars also fell. Investors await reactions to Greece's reform proposals and the impact of Yellen's testimony on the US interest rate outlook.

site_title: Seoul: Shares climb to fresh 2½ month high; won aimless ahead of Yellen comments
summary: South Korean shares rose to a 2½ month high on Tuesday, closing 0.4% up at 1,976.12 points, driven by fading concerns over Greece's euro zone status. However, gains were capped by a decline in crude oil prices. The won drifted lower against the dollar, awaiting clues from Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's testimony.

site_title: Ukraine peace deal only way forward: EU's Mogherini
summary: European Union's foreign policy chief Federica Mogherini says a European-brokered ceasefire deal in Ukraine is the only way to secure peace, despite fighting continuing. The deal, intended to end 5,600 deaths, has been supported by the UN Security Council. Mogherini urges making diplomatic and economic pressure work to keep the deal alive.

site_title: Europe: Stocks firm at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the opening on Tuesday, with the FTSE 100 gaining 0.01%, DAX 30 adding 0.02%, and CAC 40 firming 0.07%. Greece submitted a "comprehensive" list of reforms to Brussels, aiming for a four-month bailout extension. Eurozone finance ministers will discuss the reforms in a conference call. The markets largely unaffected by Greece's delayed reform submission, with most indices rising on Monday after a tentative bailout extension agreement.

site_title: UK inflation, other risks could mean rate hike in near future: BoE's Forbes
summary: Bank of England policymaker Kristin Forbes suggests that inflation pressures and other risks may necessitate an interest rate hike in the near future. However, she believes these risks are currently manageable and do not justify a change in interest rates. Forbes noted that external factors such as declining oil and food prices, as well as a strengthening sterling, are driving down inflation, which is currently at 0.3%. The Bank of England's rate-setters voted to keep rates at 0.5% in their last two meetings, citing a lack of sufficient inflationary pressures.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close 0.74% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks reached a 15-year high, closing 0.74% higher, driven by a weaker yen ahead of US Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen's Congressional testimony and a Greek reform package. The Nikkei 225 index ended at 18,603.48, while the Topix index rose 0.36% to 1,508.28.

site_title: Greece pledges to respect privatisations, avoid budget derailment
summary: Greece has pledged to respect ongoing privatisations and avoid budget derailment, submitting reform plans to EU and IMF creditors. The plans include tax policy reforms, spending controls, pension fund consolidation, and public sector wage grid adjustments. The government aims to balance its objective of avoiding pension cuts with the need to achieve savings and eliminate loopholes. The reforms must be approved by creditors to pave the way for a four-month bailout extension.

site_title: At least five drones fly over Paris during night: security source
summary: At least five drones were spotted flying over central Paris landmarks, including the Eiffel Tower and the US embassy, in the early hours of Tuesday. Police were unable to catch the operators, raising concerns about a possible coordinated action. Authorities are investigating the incident, but the motives and identities of the drone operators remain unknown.

site_title: South Korea expects to see effect of low oil prices over medium-term
summary: South Korea's economy is expected to see the effects of low global oil prices in the medium-term, with an estimated $33 billion in income transfer from oil-producing companies. Vice Finance Minister Joo Hyung-hwan stated that lower oil prices should trickle down to consumption and investment, but this has yet to be seen in the local economy.

site_title: Singapore's 2015 Budget highlights the government's institutional and governance strength: S&P
summary: Standard & Poor's praises Singapore's 2015 budget for its focus on long-term fiscal challenges, institutional governance, and addressing immediate capacity constraints in transport and health services. The budget aims to boost economic growth, retrain workers, and support an aging population. Key measures include investments in economic growth, retraining, and increased funding for healthcare. These initiatives are expected to maintain Singapore's credit strengths despite an aging population at a fast rate in Asia. The rating remains AAA/Stable/A-1+.

site_title: Japan Inc shops abroad to duck bleak domestic prospects
summary: Japanese companies are rapidly acquiring foreign businesses to mitigate the bleak domestic prospects due to Japan's aging population and deflationary pressure. The value of outbound acquisitions in 2015 already exceeds $27 billion, nearly half of last year's total. This trend counters Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's efforts to boost the stagnant economy. Analysts attribute the rush to overseas growth to the fear of further yen weakness, making foreign targets more expensive if buyers don't act now.

site_title: Magnus Bocker to leave SGX after June
summary: Magnus Bocker, CEO of Singapore Exchange (SGX), will not extend his contract beyond June 30. The board is assessing internal and external candidates for his successor, with Spencer Stuart facilitating the process. Bocker, who has been CEO since 2009, is stepping down to take on new challenges. The announcement comes after a nearly 15-year tenure.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 7-year closing high as investors cheer earnings
summary: Australian shares hit a 7-year closing high on Tuesday, rising 19.0 points or 0.3% to 5,927.0, driven by promising results in the mining, finance, and healthcare sectors. This is the highest close since May 2008. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.5% or 31.4 points.

site_title: Gold hovers near 7-week low ahead of Yellen speech
summary: Gold prices slipped to a near seven-week low ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's Senate testimony, amid expectations of interest rate hikes this year. Investors are looking for signs on interest rate hikes and the US economy's strength. Gold has fallen nearly 6% this month, erasing January's 8.4% gain. Yellen's testimony may influence the Fed's decision on interest rate hikes, with some analysts predicting the metal could drop to $1,000 by year-end.

images.alt_text: Gold slipped to a near seven-week low on Tuesday as investors looked to Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's Senate testimony for signs of when the US central bank could raise interest rates.

site_title: Australia Post says Japan Post arrival will hurt vital services
summary: Australia Post warns that Japan Post's arrival in the country will lead to "cherry-picking" of profitable services, potentially forcing the state-owned firm to cut vital services for the first time in 30 years. CEO Ahmed Fahour stated that if Japan Post enters the market without restrictions, it may prioritize profitable services, leaving regional and rural areas without care. Australia Post faces a decline in letter volumes due to competition from email and other electronic services, resulting in its first annual loss since 1989.

site_title: Japan eyes later pilot retirement amid shortage
summary: Japan is considering relaxing pilot retirement rules to allow pilots to fly until age 67, amid a shortage created by growing air travel demand. The current rule requires pilots to retire at 64, following international standards. The shortage has led to thousands of cancelled flights last year, prompting the need for a change.

site_title: Greece has sent reform plans, a "valid starting point": EU source
summary: Greece has submitted its economic reform plans to the European institutions and the International Monetary Fund, meeting a condition for extending its bailout programme for an additional four months. The plans, which include measures to combat tax evasion and corruption, are deemed sufficient by the European Commission to be a "valid starting point" for a successful conclusion of the review. The Commission expressed encouragement over Greece's strong commitment to reform, paving the way for the potential extension of the bailout.

site_title: Indonesia's smaller coal miners to take hit from royalty hike: official
summary: Indonesia plans to double coal royalties, affecting smaller and newer firms producing low-quality coal, which could struggle with halved prices since 2011. The increase, expected to be introduced in March, will mainly impact companies with newer mining licenses, while larger firms with Contracts of Work will be unaffected. The move aims to promote economic growth and increase non-tax revenue from coal and minerals to US$4.05 billion in 2015.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's plan to roughly double coal royalties next month is expected to hurt most for smaller and newer firms producing low-quality coal, government and industry officials say, with many struggling as prices have halved since 2011.

site_title: Brokers' Take: Overhang for Reits lifted; MAS consultation paper may provide further catalyst
summary: The Singapore government extended tax incentives and concessions for Reits until March 2020, providing relief to investors and enhancing the city-state's reputation as a dynamic Reit hub. DBS Group Research sees this move as a positive catalyst, but notes that stamp-duty remission will expire on March 31, 2015. The analysts expect a moderate pace of acquisitions, with the largest impact on the industrial space, and will monitor the MAS consultation paper for further clarity on corporate governance and agency issues. DBS's top Reit picks include Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust and Ascendas Reit.

site_title: Modi to replace crowded slums with 20 million homes
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi aims to provide affordable homes to 170 million urban slum dwellers by 2022, with a plan to build 20 million homes over seven years. The "Housing for All" program, which requires $2 trillion in financing, seeks to boost economic growth and increase productivity among low-income individuals. Modi's government plans to ease rules and reduce costs for private developers, and may raise tax breaks on housing loans. While experts question the feasibility of the target, a successful implementation could add up to 2.84 rupees to the GDP for every rupee spent on building a house.

site_title: Japan lower house approves reflationist Harada for BOJ board
summary: Japan's lower house approved Yutaka Harada, a 64-year-old professor, to join the Bank of Japan's policy board, seen as supportive of Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's push for radical stimulus. Harada's appointment may give Kuroda a stronger grip on the divided board, but his views on inflation targeting may complicate debate. Harada expressed that the focus of monetary policy should be on stimulating the economy, not achieving an inflation target, which could lead to a shift in the BOJ's policy.

site_title: Land area for new China real estate developments falls 25% in 2014: Xinhua
summary: China's land area for new property developments decreased by 25.5% in 2014, falling to 151,000 hectares from 2013. This marks the extent of the country's housing downturn, which was driven by weakening demand and a glut of unsold homes. The sluggish housing sector contributed to China's 24-year low economic growth of 7.4% in 2014. Average new home prices in major cities continued to fall for the ninth consecutive month in January, further indicating a market in the doldrums.

site_title: LG Electronics plans OLED TV partnership with China, Japan firms
summary: LG Electronics plans a partnership with Chinese and Japanese firms to make OLED TV panels more widely available, aiming to improve picture quality and reduce power consumption. The move follows efforts by companies like Sony, which has expressed openness to using OLED displays, and comes as liquid crystal displays (LCD) remain the dominant technology. Analysts say OLED technology needs broader adoption to take off, and the recent introduction of quantum dot technology could further undercut sales. LG Display is the only mass-producer of OLED TV panels, currently facing competition from LCDs.

site_title: Hitachi to buy Italian railways firms for over US$2b: media
summary: Hitachi is set to acquire Italian railways firms Finmeccanica's rail and traffic signal businesses for an estimated $2.1 billion, expanding its overseas presence and challenging major international railways firms. Finmeccanica will sell its rail car unit AnsaldoBreda and Ansaldo STS, the world's number two traffic signal company, to Hitachi. The acquisition is expected to boost Hitachi's annual rail-related sales to over $400 billion yen and push its rail operations global, gaining Italian rail car production facilities.

site_title: AirAsia X to cut unprofitable routes
summary: AirAsia X to cut unprofitable routes, but ruled out Australia, citing it as "not cost-efficient". The airline will focus on adding new routes that generate more profit.

site_title: Asia: Markets tentative, awaiting word on Fed rate outlook
summary: Asian markets remained cautious on Tuesday, awaiting the Federal Reserve's rate outlook under Chair Janet Yellen. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index inched down 0.1% as investors awaited her testimony before Congress. Oil prices stabilized, while the Nasdaq had its longest nine-session gain since 2010. Yellen's dovish tone is uncertain, with some economists predicting a shift towards a "lower for longer" policy. Treasury yields and the dollar could rise if she maintains a dovish stance, challenging risk appetite globally.

site_title: With conditions, Schaeuble paves way for German vote on Greece
summary: Germany's Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble requested a parliamentary vote on a possible loan extension to Greece, contingent on reform proposals being accepted by the European Central Bank, European Commission, and International Monetary Fund. The loan extension is subject to Greece submitting a list of economic reform plans and the three institutions approving them. A vote is expected if the conditions are met, with a deputy German finance minister expressing confidence that parliament will support the extension. The vote could pave the way for a four-month extension of Greece's bailout program.

images.alt_text: Germany's Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble has paved the way for a possible parliamentary vote this week on a loan extension to Greece, Handelsblatt reported on Tuesday.

site_title: German economy gets boost from consumer spending as exports rise
summary: Germany's economy experienced a boost in the fourth quarter, with a 0.7% expansion in gross domestic product, driven by strong consumer spending and rising exports. Private consumption climbed 0.8%, capital investment rose 1.2%, and exports jumped 1.3%. The country's economic resurgence contrasts with other European nations, such as France and Italy, and has lifted hopes for the region's economy, despite ongoing risks including Greece's debt crisis and the risk of deflation.

images.alt_text: Germany restored its position as Europe's economic powerhouse last quarter as domestic spending surged and trade contributed to growth.

site_title: Australian PM feels 'at height of powers'
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott expressed confidence after a poll showed his government at a four-month high and narrowing the gap with the opposition Labor Party. Despite 77% of respondents viewing him as arrogant, Abbott felt "energized" and at the "height of his powers." He survived a leadership challenge earlier this month and has been given until June to turn the tide before potential further action.

site_title: Indonesia plans alternative sukuk structures to boost volumes
summary: Indonesia plans to boost Islamic bond volumes by introducing new assets, including state goods and services, to support sukuk transactions. The country aims to increase its sukuk capability and reshape its Islamic finance industry, seeking to catch up with more mature markets in Malaysia and the Middle East. Authorities plan to encourage consolidation and build a new regulatory system to support the growth of the sector.

site_title: Oil holds below US$50 as US supplies seen worsening global glut
summary: US oil prices fell below $50 a barrel as global inventories expanded, with crude stockpiles likely rising by 3.75 million barrels last week. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) has no plans for an emergency meeting, despite a 50% drop in oil prices last year. US production surged to 9.28 million barrels a day, and inventories have increased 20% above the five-year average level.

site_title: JPMorgan to start charging some big clients deposit fees: WSJ
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co plans to charge large institutional clients deposit fees, citing new rules that make holding money for clients too costly. The fees will not affect retail customers but will impact corporate clients, hedge funds, and foreign banks. The specifics of the plan are set to be unveiled on Tuesday at the bank's annual strategy outlook with investors. This move is expected to affect some of the bank's largest clients, including private-equity firms and financial firms.

site_title: German metalworkers, management agree 3.4% wage hike
summary: Germany's powerful metalworkers' union, IG Metall, has agreed to a 3.4% wage increase with management, benefiting four million workers. The deal, which applies to workers in Baden-Wuerttemberg and expected to be adopted nationwide, came after hours of talks and follows weeks of warning strikes. The agreement, which includes pay rises until March 2026, was seen as an important step by the union, which had initially demanded 5.5% pay rises.

site_title: Indian markets riding for a fall unless budget delivers
summary: Indian markets are at risk of a sell-off unless the government's upcoming budget delivers on promised capital spending and fiscal restraint. The rupee's stability is also a concern, as a downturn could lead to its return to 2013 levels. Despite a strong election victory for Prime Minister Narendra Modi, the economy is struggling to gain momentum, and corporate sector growth is slowing down. Experts warn that India's equity markets are overvalued and that risk-adjusted returns are better in the US. A balanced budget is needed to kick-start the investment cycle.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.5 points to 1812.01 on Tuesday, driven by gains outweighing losses 91 to 50. Volume reached 49.32 million lots worth RM10.66 million.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed ahead of Greek reforms, Fed chair remarks
summary: Asian stocks were mixed on Tuesday as investors awaited Greece's proposed reforms to win an extension on its bailout. Tokyo's Nikkei index rose 0.13%, while Seoul rose 0.51% and Hong Kong fell 0.51%. The eurozone finance ministers will discuss Greece's proposals on Tuesday afternoon. US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's Congressional testimony is also in focus, with stocks mixed on Monday. A bailout extension would only offer temporary relief, with reforms deemed satisfactory by the "troika" of the European Commission, European Central Bank, and International Monetary Fund needed by April.

site_title: Critics tear their hair out over Malaysia PM's wife
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak's wife, Rosmah Mansor, drew criticism for her comments on the high cost of house calls for hairdressers and tailors, which she claimed is RM1,200 and RM500 respectively. The 63-year-old is often mocked for her luxury lifestyle, with reports of her expensive shopping sprees and jewelry purchases. Critics say she is out of touch with ordinary citizens struggling to make ends meet, with the minimum wage in Malaysia being RM900 per month. Her comments have sparked widespread social media ridicule.

images.alt_text: The wife of Malaysia's prime minister, who is widely mocked over reports of her taste for luxury, drew fresh scorn on Tuesday after she complained about the rising cost of house calls from hairdressers and tailors.

site_title: Stocks to watch: S-Reits, Asian Pay Television Trust, Rex, SIIC Environment, Food Empire
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam extended income-tax and GST concessions for Singapore Reits for five more years but allowed stamp-duty concessions for local property purchases to lapse after March. This may slow Reits' acquisitions and cause yields to dip. Asian Pay Television Trust reported a 21.6% drop in profit, while Rex International signed a deal to buy a 30% stake in a North Sea licence. SIIC Environment's fourth-quarter earnings more than doubled due to joint venture results. Food Empire's losses widened due to weak oil prices and conflict in Ukraine.

site_title: Oil turns lower in Asia, US crude stays below US$50
summary: Oil prices in Asia declined on Tuesday as a weak rebound failed to hold, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate falling to $49.16 and Brent crude to $58.73. Global oversupply, fueled by US crude stockpiles at historic levels and Libyan oilfield production, continues to pressure prices. Analysts predict volatility will persist, with Barclays stating the market is forecast to remain oversupplied for most of 2015. A closely watched US weekly crude stockpile report is due on Wednesday, with expected inventories to rise by 3.75 million barrels.

images.alt_text: Oil turned lower in Asia Tuesday as a feeble rebound failed to take hold, with prices under pressure in an oversupplied market.

site_title: Hot stock: ComfortDelGro up 2.8% after announced major reinvestment in public transport
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singapore transport operator, surged 2.77% in early trading to S$2.97 after Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam announced a major reinvestment in public transport in the government's Budget statement. The company's peers, SBS Transit and SMRT, also rose. ComfortDelGro's recent record profit and growth prospects were cited as reasons for the stock's increase, despite a downgrade from OCBC to hold. The company's shares are now trading at a higher fair value of S$3.07.

site_title: French president Hollande vows stiffer penalties for hate speech
summary: French President Francois Hollande announced plans to introduce tougher penalties for "racist, anti-Semitic or homophobic" remarks, calling for faster, more effective sanctions against hate speech. He stated that such speech should come under criminal law rather than press laws and that anti-Semitism should be treated as an aggravating circumstance in the prosecution of all offenses.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 6.93 points to 3,428.23. Volume was 39.4 million shares worth S$76.8 million, with 67 gainers and 58 losers. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on February 24, 2015, due to concerns over Greece's debt situation and its potential impact on the global economy. The Hang Seng Index fell 55.11 points, or 0.22%, to 24,781.65. Markets in mainland China were closed for the Lunar New Year holiday.

site_title: Kaisa warns of 'substantial decline' in FY14 earnings
summary: Chinese property developer Kaisa Group Holdings has warned of a "substantial decline" in FY14 earnings, citing a preliminary review of available financial information. The company's debts total over $10 billion and it needs to restructure borrowings to proceed with a rescue deal. Kaisa's shares are listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, but its bonds traded in Singapore have faced issues, including a missed $26 million interest payment in January. The warning is part of a broader financial struggle for the company.

site_title: US probes 10 banks over precious-metals pricing, WSJ reports
summary: US officials are investigating at least 10 banks, including HSBC, Barclays, and Goldman Sachs, for possible price rigging in precious-metals markets. The Justice Department's antitrust division and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission are examining price-setting for gold, silver, platinum, and palladium in London. The investigation is ongoing, with prosecutors looking into allegations of price manipulation and market manipulation. The banks under scrutiny are among the largest and most influential in the industry, and the probe could have significant implications for global markets.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise after long Lunar New Year holiday
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 1% on the first trading day after the Lunar New Year holiday, driven by tech and Apple Inc suppliers. The TAIEX index gained 96.61 points to 9626.12, with semiconductor and electrical component stocks rising 1.56 and 1.39% respectively. Apple touch-screen maker TPK Holding Co Ltd and iPhone assembler Pegatron Corp led the gains, while rubber and food stocks fell 0.24 and 0.17% respectively. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$31.570 to the US dollar.

site_title: Seoul: Shares edge higher; won flat ahead of Yellen testimony
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.32% to a 2-1/2 month high, despite a drop in crude oil prices, as fears of Greece leaving the euro zone eased. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index reached 1,974.78 points. Greece will present its reform plans to the euro zone by Tuesday, after missing the initial deadline.

site_title: Asian Pay Television Trust posts final distribution of 2.13 cents per unit for Q4
summary: Asian Pay Television Trust reported a 21.6% drop in profit to S$16.3 million for Q4 2014, mainly due to higher depreciation and operating expenses. Total revenue rose 4% to S$81.8 million. The board declared a final distribution of 2.13 cents per unit for the quarter, consistent with 2014 distribution guidance. The company reaffirmed a similar distribution guidance for FY2015 of at least 8.25 cents per unit.

site_title: Engineering its own success
summary: Poh Group, a Singaporean company, has successfully farmed seawater fish with man-made seawater, enabling it to set up farms in various environments, including the desert. The company, led by Chairman Poh Kay Ping, aims to farm high-value seafood products such as garoupa, cod, and salmon. Poh Group's research has also led to a US$130 million project to farm shrimp in Oman. The company's focus on aquaculture is seen as a strategic move, as it aligns with its goal of developing the mineral resource industry in Mongolia and other emerging markets.

site_title: Indonesia to crack down on corporate tax avoidance: head of tax office
summary: Indonesia plans to crack down on corporate tax avoidance via transfer pricing, aiming to recoup 200 trillion rupiah (S$21.2 billion) in lost state income, mainly in the commodities sector. The new head of the tax office, Sigit Priadi Pramudito, says the tax office will adjust tax bills and take companies to tax court if suspected of underpricing sales to related entities. The move is part of Indonesia's revised state budget, which targets tax revenue of 1,489.3 trillion rupiah this year, a 30% increase from last year's collection.

images.alt_text: Indonesia will crack down on corporate tax avoidance via transfer pricing this year to try and recoup 200 trillion rupiah (S$21.2 billion) in lost state income mainly in the commodities sector, the new head of the tax office told Reuters.

site_title: Google Wallet partners up to battle Apple Pay
summary: Google has partnered with Softcard to make Google Wallet a pre-installed "tap to pay" app on Android smartphones sold in the US market by AT&T, T-Mobile, and Verizon. The goal is to counter Apple Pay and provide more Android users with tap and pay benefits. Google is also acquiring Softcard's technology and intellectual property to enhance Google Wallet. This move strengthens Google's position in the mobile payments space, but analyst Bryan Yeager notes that the industry will remain competitive and fragmented for the next few years.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Tuesday, following recent advances to 15-year highs due to caution over a Greek debt deal. The Nikkei 225 index was up 0.01% at 18,468.39. The euro remained under pressure, and the dollar was at 118.87 yen. Individual stocks, such as Hitachi, eased due to reports of a basic accord with Finmeccanica. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.13% following lacklustre housing data.

site_title: British government body urges 3% rise in minimum wage
summary: The British government body, the Low Pay Commission, recommended a 3% rise in the minimum wage to 6.70 pounds (US$10) an hour, the largest real-terms increase since 2007. The increase is expected to boost morale among Britain's lowest earners ahead of a national election in May. The decision follows last year's 3% increase and aims to make up ground lost during the financial crisis. The wage rise will take effect in October and is seen as a positive move for the lowest-paid workers.

site_title: American Airlines says it won't participate in Skymark Airlines restructuring
summary: American Airlines has decided not to participate in the restructuring of Japan's bankrupt Skymark Airlines Inc, citing its partnership with Japan Airlines as a reason. The decision comes after studying the current environment surrounding Skymark, with the company focusing on Asia's competitive landscape.

site_title: Bumitama Agri posts 30% fall in Q4 profit
summary: BUMITAMA Agri reported a 30% drop in Q4 profit to 266.4 billion Indonesian rupiah (S$28 million) due to lower selling prices, higher costs, and other expenses. Earnings per share fell to 152 rupiah from 216 rupiah a year ago. The decrease was attributed to various factors including withholding tax expenses and loss from fair value changes in biological assets.

images.alt_text: Bumitama Agri on Tuesday reported a 30 per cent drop in net profit to 266.4 billion Indonesian rupiah (S$28 million) for its fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2014.

site_title: The secret tax lives of the rich and famous
summary: Celebrities often struggle with taxes due to complex financial situations. They can deduct necessary expenses, but the line between legitimate business costs and personal perks can be blurry. Many entertainers receive income in unusual ways, such as from autograph signings or reality TV appearances, which must be reported on tax returns. Additionally, income from multiple sources, including foreign countries, can lead to tax complications. Without proper financial planning, celebrities may face penalties and tax liabilities, and may even be tempted to cheat the system.

site_title: Football: Europe's elite see 20% rise in shirt deals
summary: Europe's top football leagues saw a 20% rise in shirt sponsorship deals last year, reaching $1.05 billion. The English Premier League and La Liga led the growth, with Manchester United and Barcelona securing major deals. The Middle East, particularly the UAE, became the main sponsor, with Emirates airline accounting for $120 million. Other European countries, such as Germany and the US, also saw significant increases in sponsorship revenue.

site_title: Dole owner Murdock rambles in testimony about company buyout
summary: Dole Food Co owner David Murdock testified in a Delaware Court defending his 2013 $1.6 billion buyout of the world's largest fruit and vegetable producer. Shareholders accuse Murdock of stealing the company from them, claiming he dominated the board before privatization. Murdock's testimony focused on his unusual memory, passion for nutrition, and dislike of age-related discussions. The trial, which lasted over five hours, aims to establish Murdock's role in the management buyout and determine whether he was justified in the $13.50 per share deal.

site_title: Oil falls 2% on glut worries; heating oil up on tight supply
summary: Oil prices fell 2% on Monday, with crude oil futures down $1.36 to $49.81 a barrel, amid worries about oversupply and a strong dollar. However, heating oil futures rose 5% to $2.24 a gallon due to operational issues at US refineries. The market is concerned about record-high US crude inventories and a slowdown in US drilling activity. Analysts believe a bottom has been set for oil prices, with Brent at $55 a barrel and WTI at $45 a barrel.

site_title: AirAsia, ANA offer to support Skymark, transport minister says
summary: AirAsia and ANA Holdings Inc have offered to support Skymark Airlines Inc, a Japanese carrier that filed for bankruptcy protection in January. Skymark shares surged 15% after Transport Minister Akihiro Ohta confirmed the airline's efforts to find a partner for restructuring. Skymark aims to present a plan by the end of May with Integral Corp's assistance. ANA, Japan's largest airline, and AirAsia, a low-fare carrier, have expressed support, while American Airlines Group and Delta Air Lines have declined involvement.

images.alt_text: AirAsia Bhd and ANA Holdings Inc have both applied to support Skymark Airlines Inc, the Japanese carrier that filed for bankruptcy protection in late January, Transport Minister Akihiro Ohta said today. The stock jumped.

site_title: Sting operation highlights Modi's anti-corruption agenda
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government has launched a sting operation targeting corruption in the coal, power, and oil ministries, arresting five people and recovering stolen documents. The investigation, initiated by National Security Advisor Ajit Doval, has also detained seven others, including officials from influential companies like Reliance Industries and Cairn India. The operation aims to prevent confidential documents from falling into the hands of private companies and media outlets, with Modi's government vowing to tackle corruption and boost economic growth.

site_title: Honda looks to new CEO to emerge from crisis-filled Ito era
summary: Honda's CEO, Takanobu Ito, will step down later this year, handing over the reins to Managing Officer Takahiro Hachigo. Ito cited the company's quality issues, including record recalls involving deadly Takata air bags and flaws with the popular Fit compact car, as a reason for his departure. Hachigo, who has similar roots to Ito, has pledged to focus on product development and technologies to turn Honda's fortunes around. The move comes after Honda cut its profit forecasts for the second time in as many quarters due to recalls and quality missteps, leading to a fresh start under Hachigo's leadership.

images.alt_text: Honda Motor Co's chief executive officer will step aside later this year as Japan's third-largest carmaker reels from one of the biggest setbacks over quality in its history.

site_title: France seeks to delay deficit target until 2018
summary: France is seeking to delay its budget deficit target from 2015 to 2018, citing the need to keep austerity measures out of the 2017 presidential election campaign. The EU Commission will decide on the request in March, with Commissioner Guenther Oettinger expressing concern over the impact on the Stability Pact's credibility. This move comes after France has repeatedly stated it will only meet the 3% GDP deficit target by 2017.

site_title: Oscars TV ratings slump
summary: The Oscars' US telecast saw a 16% decline in TV ratings from last year, averaging 36.6 million viewers, the lowest in six years. Critics panned host Neil Patrick Harris' performance, citing a lack of surprises and predictability in the awards. Some praised his opening number and jokes, but many found his skits, including a skit about best picture winner Birdman, to be awkward and embarrassing. The decline in ratings and lukewarm reviews may be attributed to the relative lack of mass-appeal movies among nominees and the predictability of the awards.

site_title: Changing the manufacturing game
summary: Manufacturers are urged to adopt "Informed Manufacturing," a state of operations using social, mobile, analytics, and cloud technologies to respond to global market pressures. This involves integrating highly intelligent cyber-physical systems, known as the Internet of Things, to create adaptable and flexible production lines. Four key elements of Informed Manufacturing are products, people, processes, and infrastructure, which converge to create a data-driven business model. However, barriers to entry include ROI considerations, data security concerns, and lack of comprehensive regulations, prompting manufacturers to develop distinct information-management strategies and business plans to build long-term capabilities.

site_title: Rex's Norway entity to join in North Sea prospect drilling by Lundin
summary: Rex International Holding's Norway entity, Lime Petroleum Norway, has signed a deal with Lundin Petroleum Norway to acquire a 30% stake in licence PL338C in the North Sea. The deal is pending regulatory approval and will see Lundin's stake reduced to 50%. The prospect to be drilled, Gemini, is located 10km from the Edvard Grieg production platform, and Rex's CEO believes hydrocarbons are present based on scans. Following the transfer, OMV will hold a 20% stake.

site_title: Homeland Security shutdown nears amid immigration impasse
summary: The US Department of Homeland Security is on the verge of a partial shutdown due to a funding impasse. The Senate failed to pass a Homeland Security spending bill, blocking a $39.7 billion funding bill, amid disagreements over President Barack Obama's decision to ease deportation for undocumented immigrants. A shutdown would affect 30,000 employees, including border patrol agents and Coast Guard members, and have a direct impact on national security and the economy. The Obama administration is seeking a court order to suspend a Texas judge's order delaying immigration plans. A shutdown would also disrupt training for new border patrol officers and grant programs, with some employees facing potential back pay.

site_title: Burkina police seize 1,300 tonnes soda cans with fake dates
summary: Burkina Faso authorities seized 1,300 tonnes of soft drinks with false expiry dates, including Coca-Cola and Fanta, imported from Tunisia. The drinks were found to be past their sell-by date, with solvents used to alter the original dates. At least 12 people, including the director of the importing company, were arrested. The incident highlights ongoing problems of fraud and counterfeiting in the poor West African country.

site_title: American TV outlets compete in original programmes
summary: US TV outlets are competing to produce original programs, with major networks like Time Warner, Netflix, and Amazon investing heavily in new shows. Netflix plans to spend $3 billion on content this year, while Amazon has invested $1.3 billion in television programming. The number of original cable and online programs has doubled in the past five years, with traditional operators like Time Warner and Viacom also increasing their spending. The competition for original content is driving up costs, with analysts warning that the oversupply of funding may not be sustainable in the long term.

site_title: US commissioner calls for more rigorous review of risky ETFs
summary: US Securities and Exchange Commission Democratic member Kara Stein has called for a more rigorous review process before approving rule changes to list riskier exchange-traded funds (ETFs) that she believes could harm retail investors. Stein's three-page dissent over a rule change approved last week allows seven new ETFs from AccuShares Investment Management to list on the Nasdaq stock market exchange. The ETFs use "Paired Class Shares" that move in opposite directions, requiring investors to be extra vigilant in monitoring their investments. Stein advocates for a more transparent and thoughtful review process to prevent similar products from entering the market.

site_title: Euro weakens as wary market watches Greek debt plan
summary: The euro weakened against the dollar as traders awaited Greece's response to a bailout program. Greece's new government said it would miss a deadline to provide reforms, potentially forcing a bailout extension. Without an extension, Greece could run out of money and be forced out of the single-currency bloc. The dollar strengthened ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's testimony, with traders hoping for insight into the Fed's plan to raise interest rates this year. The Eurozone's economic uncertainty weighs on the euro's value.

site_title: German business confidence rises as QE outweighs Greece fears
summary: German business confidence rose for a fourth consecutive month, increasing to 106.8 in February, driven by faster economic growth and optimism over European Central Bank stimulus. Fears of a worsening Greek crisis were outweighed by this growth, according to the Ifo institute's business climate index.

site_title: Budget 2015: Business reactions
summary: The Singapore International Chamber of Commerce and the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce & Industry welcomed the 2015 budget's focus on developing skills and competencies via SkillsFuture, a bold step towards sustained innovation and productivity improvement. The government's measures to promote skills-based learning, industry collaboration, and sectoral manpower plans are seen as beneficial for businesses. However, the labour movement expressed concerns about the potential for higher costs and a tighter labour policy, with some businesses deferring foreign worker levies and increasing CPF contributions.

site_title: US small businesses turn to digital tools to monitor staff's desktops
summary: US small businesses are increasingly using digital tools to monitor employees' desktops, citing concerns over productivity and maintaining a family-friendly work environment. Merial Currer, owner of Patriot Scuba, uses ActivTrak to monitor her four full-time employees, who have not shown any resistance. This approach allows her to ensure employees stay off inappropriate websites, particularly those involving children, in a precautionary measure to protect her business's family-oriented image.

site_title: Understanding US millennial homebuyers
summary: US millennial homebuyers are expected to increase their spending in the housing market, a welcome relief for real estate agents. The article, however, does not specifically address millennial homebuyers. Instead, it highlights various real estate news from around the world, including rising mortgage rates, record-breaking Manhattan rents, and rebounding homebuyer demand in the UK. A more relevant article would be needed to provide a concise summary on US millennial homebuyers.

site_title: As US office space shrinks, so does workers' privacy
summary: US office space is shrinking, coinciding with rising rents as companies cut costs. DAFNA Sarnoff, a former American Express vice-president, experienced this trend, moving from a desirable office to a smaller tech startup with an open office environment. The shift is attributed to companies looking to reduce expenses, with Manhattan rents reaching a record high. Experts expect further increases in office costs, impacting workers' privacy and workspaces.

site_title: In defence of the Swiss National Bank
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) ended its 4-year peg of the Swiss franc to the euro, sparking criticism for lack of warning, but analysts argue the decision was correct and overdue to address exchange rate distortion and economic imbalances in Europe. The unpegging led to a 20% Swiss franc rise against the euro, showcasing Switzerland's safe-haven status. The SNB's massive euro holdings and high balance sheet ratio of 85% of GDP pose new challenges, including deflationary pressures and economic growth concerns.

site_title: Restructured Beyonics seeking investment opportunities
summary: Beyonics Technology, a Singaporean private equity-backed contract manufacturer, has turned profitable after restructuring. The company, which was acquired by Shaw Kwei & Partners in 2011, has ended its long-standing relationship with Seagate and now focuses on higher-margin businesses in the medical and automotive sectors. With no debt, Beyonics is looking for investment opportunities and has cash in the bank. The company aims to consolidate its manufacturing sites and upgrade them, and is targeting precision engineering manufacturers in the auto and medical sectors.

site_title: Perks for donations, handouts to lighten load on needy
summary: Singapore's government is introducing tax incentives and handouts to help needy households cope with living costs. The government will increase cash handouts under the GST Voucher scheme, lower concessionary levy for foreign domestic maids, and extend tax deductions for donations. The measures aim to "multiply every dollar that the community is giving" and benefit 1.4 million Singaporeans.

images.alt_text: Bigger tax incentives will be dangled to fuel the spirit of giving, with the government taking the lead by bumping up its handouts to help needy households cope with the costs of living.

site_title: Inflation in January stays negative mainly due to crude oil slump
summary: Singapore's inflation rate dropped to minus 0.4% in January, the lowest since December 2014, mainly due to a decline in crude oil prices and lower food and services inflation. Private road transport costs fell 5% and accommodation costs 1.9% in January. Economists attribute the low inflation to factors such as a cooling property market and medical subsidies. Experts expect inflation to remain muted for the first half of the year, with some predicting a rebound to positive levels by mid-2015.

site_title: Higher tax rates for top 5% of income-earners
summary: Singapore is increasing tax rates for the top 5% of income-earners, with the top marginal rate rising to 22% for those earning above S$320,000. However, this is offset by a higher CPF salary ceiling, which increases the salary cap from S$5,000 to S$6,000. The move is expected to raise S$400 million in revenue annually, with Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam citing the need for a "calibrated" approach to balance competitiveness with progressive taxation.

site_title: Jubilee Budget sets course for Singapore's future
summary: Singapore's Jubilee Budget 2015 focuses on long-term economic and social changes, including a more progressive CPF system and the introduction of a SkillsFuture Credit. The government aims to support seniors through the Silver Support Scheme, providing quarterly cash payouts to those in need. The SkillsFuture push includes a S$500 credit for all citizens 25 and up, with further top-ups to be made at regular intervals. The budget does not include significant short-term goodies, differing from previous budgets.

site_title: When things can't get any worse, they turn negative
summary: Negative interest rates have emerged as a new economic phenomenon, where lenders pay borrowers to lend money. This occurs when bond prices rise, causing the interest rate to fall below zero. Two explanations for negative interest rates are the easy-money policies of central banks and a weak global economy that has suppressed inflation and credit demand. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates, but negative rates could occur in the US if economic conditions warrant it. Some experts question the profitability of negative interest rates, citing the potential for capital flight and the need for investors to protect their principal.

site_title: Rex increases stake in Trinidad & Tobago asset
summary: Rex International has increased its stake in the Cory Moruga Block in Trinidad and Tobago to 83.8% after acquiring a 63.8% working interest for US$1.5 million and S$200,000. The acquisition was funded from the proceeds of a share placement deal in September last year. This brings Rex's total indirect interest in the onshore block to 83.8%.

site_title: Greece delays sending reforms to euro zone till Tuesday
summary: Greece has delayed sending its economic reform plans to the euro zone until Tuesday, missing a Monday deadline for the list which is a condition for extending the country's financial lifeline. The reforms include measures to tackle a "humanitarian crisis," crack down on tax evasion and corruption, and restructure the public sector. Euro zone finance ministers will consider Greece's plans, which include a 1.8 billion euro spending plan on relief measures. Germany, the biggest contributor to Greece's bailouts, insisted that any extra spending must be offset by savings or higher taxes.

images.alt_text: Greece will present its economic reform plans to the euro zone on Tuesday, a government official said, missing a Monday deadline for the list which is a condition for extending the country's financial lifeline.

site_title: Building deep skills complements productivity drive
summary: The Singapore government's SkillsFuture initiative is a key plank in this year's budget, with a S$1 billion annual investment over five years to help Singaporeans acquire deeper skillsets valued by industry. This complements the ongoing productivity drive, focusing on building labour productivity and sustaining real wage growth in a globalized economy. The government also provides support for SMEs to innovate, internationalize, and collaborate with industry peers, aiming to shift Singapore from value-adding to value-creating.

site_title: DFS Furniture valued at up to £654m in IPO
summary: DFS Furniture Ltd, a UK sofa retailer, will be valued at up to £654 million in its initial public offering (IPO). The company will offer shares at 245-310 pence apiece and is expected to list on March 11. DFS aims to reduce its indebtedness and raise £98 million for debt reduction and cheaper financing. The IPO follows a year of significant London IPOs, with companies raising about $6 billion. DFS is the UK's leading upholstery market with a 26% share, and CEO Ian Filby plans to take the company to "world-class" status.

site_title: US: Stocks pause ahead of Fed testimony
summary: US stocks finished little changed on Monday ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's congressional testimony. The Dow Jones declined 0.13% to a record high, while the S&P 500 slipped 0.03% and the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.10%. Housing data showed existing-home sales slowed to a nine-month low in January. Tech stocks like Apple rose, while Boeing fell after being downgraded by Goldman Sachs. Bond prices rose, with yields on the 10-year and 30-year US Treasuries decreasing.

site_title: Oscar's night of dazzling surprises
summary: The 87th Academy Awards ceremony saw a surprise victory for Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu's "Birdman," which won four awards, including Best Picture and Best Director. The film's sweep was notable, as was the strong showing of other underdog films, such as "The Grand Budapest Hotel" and "Whiplash." The ceremony also highlighted issues of diversity and representation in the film industry, with winners using their acceptance speeches to raise awareness about social causes. The event marked a year of anxiety in the movie industry, but also underscored the power of the Oscars in promoting films and their creators.

site_title: Aussie mining services stocks dive after poor results, profit warnings
summary: Australian mining services stocks plummeted after poor results and profit warnings. Macmahon Holdings Ltd and UGL Ltd saw their shares drop by 41% and 15% respectively, with Macmahon cutting its revenue forecast by up to a third due to lost contracts. The decline is attributed to a resources downturn, with iron ore prices halving in the past year and oil prices halving in six months. The industry's struggles are expected to continue, with analysts warning that forecasts for 2015 should be revised downward.

site_title: Using trade deals to spur investment
summary: Singapore officials are negotiating two mega-regional trade agreements, the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) and the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP). These agreements aim to increase trade, investment, and economic growth by lowering barriers and creating more flexible market access. The TPP, which includes 12 Pacific Ocean nations, and the RCEP, which links Asean members with dialogue partners, will provide deeper integration provisions, such as improved intellectual property laws, food regulations, and trade facilitation measures. Successful completion of these agreements is expected to benefit countries like Singapore and Vietnam, promoting economic growth and opportunities for inward and outbound investment.

site_title: Thailand's Central Group plans to invest 37b baht in 2015
summary: Thailand's Central Group plans to invest 37 billion baht (S$1.5 billion) in 2015, with 80% going towards opening new shopping malls and acquisitions, and the remaining 20% for improvement. The company aims to accelerate revenue growth to 15% this year, with a focus on cross-border trade and diversifying revenue sources. Central Group plans to open six new shopping malls, 300 new food stores, and nine new hotels with over 1,800 rooms, targeting markets in Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia, and Malaysia.

site_title: Existing home sales hit nine-month low in January
summary: Existing US home sales plummeted 4.9% in January to a 4.82 million annualized rate, the lowest since April, due to a tight supply forcing up prices. The median home price rose 6.2% to $199,600. A lack of supply, combined with low mortgage rates and improving labor market, is expected to sustain demand. Economists predict a modest recovery, but a "disappointing" one, with the number of homes on the market dropping for a second straight month.

site_title: Greece seeks bailout extension with new reform plan
summary: Greece's new anti-austerity government has submitted a preliminary list of reform proposals to Brussels in a bid to secure a four-month extension to its debt bailout. The list, submitted by Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis, aims to quash concerns that Greece may backtrack on its commitments to cut spending and pass reforms. If approved, the extension would prevent a run on banks and a eurozone exit, but if rejected, Greece's safety net would collapse, putting the government at risk of running out of cash.

site_title: Investors seek concrete details in India budget
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is set to unveil his first full-year budget on February 28, with investors and analysts eagerly awaiting details on his plans to boost local manufacturing, improve infrastructure, and cut back on food and fuel subsidies. The government aims to hit a budget deficit target of 4.1% of GDP, with capital expenditure projected to reach at least 2% of GDP, up from 1.8% in the previous budget. The budget will also address concerns over subsidies, revenue projections, and market borrowing, with expectations that the government will cut spending on subsidies and increase revenue collection.

site_title: Singtel, HK Land drag STI lower
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 14.36 points, or 0.4%, to 3,421.30 on Monday, weighed down by selling of Singtel and Hongkong Land. Singtel dropped 2.8% to S$4.16, while Hongkong Land's US$0.18 drop to US$7.63 cut 3.4 points off the index. Other blue chips like DBS rose S$0.20 to S$19.65, but gains were limited by the selling of the two stocks.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Marco Polo Marine's Q1 FY15 core profit fell short of estimates due to lower utilization of its tug-and-barge fleet and a transitional deployment of an offshore support vessel. Despite this, the company's fundamentals support its rig ambitions, driven by young rigs' preference, oil prices' long-term uptrend, and Indonesia's potential for offshore drilling. Libra Group's Mechanical & Electrical subsidiary, Kin Xin Engineering, secured upgrades to its licenses, enabling it to tender for unlimited public government projects and potentially drive eight times growth in earnings.

site_title: Lenovo buries spyware at core of PCs
summary: Lenovo has been embedding spyware, or adware, in its PCs, allowing it to track customers' online moves, intercept secure web sessions, and render computers vulnerable to hackers. The spyware, developed by Superfish, was inserted at the core of Lenovo's operating system, making it undetectable by anti-virus products. The discovery has raised concerns about the security of devices, with experts warning that malicious code can now be easily concealed at the lowest level of a machine, allowing hackers to steal sensitive information and control users' digital experiences.

site_title: Short-sell attacks likely to have less impact as market learns and adapts
summary: A short-selling report by Iceberg Research on Noble Group's accounting practices has had a limited impact on the market, with Noble's shares recovering 3.3% in the past two trading sessions. Unlike the 2012 attack on Olam International by Muddy Waters, which led to a months-long sell-off, Noble's response has been calm and confidence-inspiring, with analysts reaffirming their positive stance on the company. The market appears to have adapted to such attacks, with companies and regulators better prepared to deal with the fallout, suggesting a decrease in the "shock and awe" impact of short-selling reports.

site_title: Weak ringgit makes Sime Darby's buy more pricey
summary: Sime Darby acquired New Britain Palm Oil Ltd (NBPOL) for £1.07 billion, but the acquisition is more costly due to the depreciated Malaysian ringgit, which has lost 7% against the British pound since October. The conglomerate expects to own 60-70% of NBPOL, with a debt-equity ratio increasing to 0.48x. Sime Darby is confident the acquisition will pay off in the long term, enabling expansion and moving up the value chain upstream, despite concerns over gearing and capital expenditure.

site_title: Budget for the future
summary: The 2015 Singapore Budget focuses on strengthening social support for retirement and middle-income families. Key measures include increasing the CPF retirement savings by raising the monthly salary ceiling from S$5,000 to S$6,000 in 2016 and restoring CPF contribution rates for workers aged 50-55. The budget also introduces a one-off tax rebate of 50% capped at S$1,000 for middle-income taxpayers and increases the top marginal tax rate for high-income earners starting from YA 2017. The government aims to address income inequality and ensure the sustainability of social safety nets through these measures.

site_title: Gung-ho attitude breaks down walls
summary: Poh Kay Ping, founder of Poh Tiong Choon Logistics, credits his gung-ho attitude to his years in the US, where he pursued his own interests and built his business from scratch. He believes that seizing opportunities is key to success. This mindset has allowed him to break down walls and achieve his goals, differing from the family business approach. His story highlights the importance of taking initiative and pursuing one's passions.

site_title: CPF changes to boost savings and returns
summary: The Singapore government will implement changes to the Central Provident Fund (CPF) scheme starting January 1, 2016, to boost savings and returns for working Singaporeans. The CPF salary ceiling will rise to S$6,000, affecting around 544,000 members, and the contribution cap for the Supplementary Retirement Scheme will increase to S$15,300 for citizens and permanent residents. The government will also offer higher interest rates on CPF savings and introduce a Special Employment Credit scheme to encourage companies to re-hire older workers. These changes aim to help working Singaporeans meet their basic needs in later years.

site_title: Lessons on coming down from the glamour of the Oscars
summary: A new study by researchers Heeyon Kim and Michael Jensen found that winning an Oscar can have a negative impact on an individual's personal life, including a higher divorce rate among male winners (205% higher than non-nominees) and a lower divorce rate among female winners (85% lower than non-nominees). The study also found that male nominees without an Oscar win have a 96% higher divorce rate compared to those without a nomination. The researchers suggest that sudden status changes can lead to negative consequences, similar to what can be observed in corporate workplaces, where executives who fail to achieve their career goals may experience personal and professional withdrawal.

site_title: US Supreme Court to hear Abercrombie hijab case
summary: The US Supreme Court will hear the Abercrombie & Fitch hijab case, which accuses the clothing company of rejecting a Muslim job applicant, Samantha Elauf, due to her wearing a hijab. Abercrombie argues its store policy prohibits sales staff from wearing "caps," while the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission claims she was discriminated against. The case could have deep ramifications for hiring practices, with the court expected to decide whether employers must warn job applicants about characteristics that could hurt their candidacy.

site_title: Shoppers urged to be extra vigilant at Mall of America
summary: The US Secretary of Homeland Security, Jeh Johnson, urged shoppers to be "particularly careful" while visiting the Mall of America in Minneapolis after it was targeted for a terrorist attack in a video posted by the radical Islamist group Al-Shabab. The mall has increased security measures, but Johnson emphasized the importance of public vigilance. The threat was not specific, but the video message could prompt extreme action from people living nearby, particularly in Minneapolis, which has a large Somali population.

images.alt_text: Mall of America officials said they had tightened security after Al-Shabab, an extremist group in Somalia that is linked to Al-Qaeda, posted a 75-minute video on Saturday.

site_title: SodaStream struggles to keep afloat in bubbly water business
summary: SodaStream is struggling to maintain its market share in the DIY soda business, with declining sales in the US and stagnant penetration in households. The company is attempting to shift focus to the growing market for bubbly water by introducing new fruit flavorings and expanding its product offerings. Despite sales increases in sparkling waters, SodaStream faces stiff competition and high costs for its carbonation canisters, making it challenging to regain its footing in the market. The company's CEO, Daniel Birnbaum, acknowledges the challenges but remains optimistic about its future prospects.

site_title: ASME sees little cost relief
summary: The Association of Small and Medium Enterprises (ASME) says the Singapore government's latest budget offers little relief for businesses, despite extended tax rebates and scheme enhancements. The corporate income tax rebate cap has been lowered to S$20,000, while the Wage Credit Scheme's co-funding level has been reduced to 20%. ASME president Kurt Wee warns that businesses must innovate and "level up" to stay competitive, as the government aims to maintain a tight labour market.

images.alt_text: "Generally, I think the Budget is continuing to point to a potentially higher cost environment," said Kurt Wee, president of the Association of Small and Medium Enterprises (ASME). "We're not cutting levy although we're deferring it, and we're increasing Central Provident Fund (CPF) contributions

site_title: FY14 shortfall smaller than projected at 0.03% of GDP
summary: The Singapore government reported a smaller-than-estimated budget deficit of S$0.13 billion for fiscal year 2014, accounting for 0.03% of GDP, thanks to higher operating revenue and investment returns. This was in line with expectations from private-sector economists. In contrast, the FY13 surplus was revised upwards to S$5 billion from S$3.92 billion.

site_title: Sweetening the deal for firms to innovate and expand abroad
summary: The Singapore government is introducing two new schemes to encourage companies to innovate and expand abroad, with a focus on productivity growth. The government will offer a 10% concessionary tax rate for larger companies expanding abroad and raise its support under internationalisation grants to 70% for three years. Additionally, the government will broaden a tax incentive for manpower expenses and boost incentives for companies scaling up through acquisitions. The measures aim to cost S$240 million and are expected to boost innovation, particularly among small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

images.alt_text: The government is pushing more Singapore companies to go overseas and innovate - and will introduce two new schemes, while amping up existing incentives, to make it happen.

site_title: Libya's Zueitina port resumes oil exports; pipeline to Hariga port being tested
summary: Libya has resumed oil exports from the eastern port of Zueitina after a nearly year-long suspension, with a pipeline test underway to restart exports from the Hariga port. The resumption is expected to bring in badly needed revenues for the oil producer struggling with a public finance crisis. Oil exports have fallen to less than 200,000 barrels a day due to the pipeline blast and power struggle, with most oilfields stopped working.

site_title: Asahi Kasei to acquire Polypore for US$3.2b
summary: Asahi Kasei Corp, a Japanese chemicals maker, agreed to acquire Polypore International for US$3.2 billion, valuing Polypore at US$60.50 per share. The deal aims to expand Asahi Kasei's battery business and boost capacity overseas. Polypore is also selling about US$1 billion in assets and liabilities to 3M Co.

site_title: Germany gets its way in bailout clash with Greece
summary: Germany successfully negotiated a bailout extension deal with Greece, forcing Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras to swallow virtually all of Germany's demands. The deal includes a reduction in austerity measures, but Greece will still be required to implement significant reforms. The agreement has raised concerns about the future of the eurozone, with strained ties between Athens and Berlin and the potential for further negotiations. Germany's Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble's public rejection of Greek proposals has also damaged trust between the two countries.

site_title: S$500 to kick off each SkillsFuture account
summary: Singapore is launching a national SkillsFuture movement, providing every citizen aged 25 and above with an initial S$500 credit for education and training. The government will also increase spending on continuing education and training to S$1 billion annually from 2015 to 2020. The program aims to promote lifelong learning and mastery of skills, with initiatives including study awards, fellowships, internships, and career guidance. The goal is to empower Singaporeans to chart their own journey in life and gain fulfillment at work, regardless of age or academic qualifications.

site_title: Petrol duty raised, CEVS refined
summary: Singapore's petrol excise duties were raised by up to 45% to yield S$177 million annually, with Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam citing the goal of encouraging less car usage and reducing carbon emissions. Despite the increase, pump prices will remain lower than the previous two-and-a-half years due to falling oil prices.

images.alt_text: Petrol excise duties were raised by up to 45 per cent on Monday, with the change to yield S$177 million a year.

site_title: BOA leads charge into Treasuries as banks build US$2t holdings
summary: US banks, particularly Bank of America, are investing heavily in ultra-safe bonds, with their holdings surpassing $2 trillion. This is partly due to rules requiring banks to hold high-quality assets, as well as a lack of consumer demand for borrowing. Despite strong job growth and rising wages, banks are prioritizing cash reserves over lending, with consumer lending contracts for four straight years at Bank of America and four of the past six years at JPMorgan Chase. This may indicate that the US recovery isn't as robust as suggested by upbeat data.

site_title: Bucks to the future
summary: Singapore's Budget 2015 focuses on advancing sustainable aviation, with the establishment of a centre in the Asia-Pacific region. The government also aims to boost employment rates for graduates, with early data showing better employment outcomes. DPM Gan will visit the US for trade talks, while a new grant of up to S$100,000 is available for tariff-hit businesses. The country is also poised to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging, according to a study. Additionally, the government is offering assistance to workers who need to upskill or reskill due to crisis situations.

site_title: Obama believes US can avoid a war with Islam
summary: US President Barack Obama has stated that the US can avoid a war with Islam, following a low-key response to recent terror incidents in Europe. His decision not to attend a unity rally in France and to label the Jewish victims as "a bunch of folks" shot by "zealots" has raised eyebrows in Washington and Europe. Obama believes the attacks are not related to Islam, instead suggesting they are driven by individuals and groups committed to a broader cause. This response has been interpreted as a realpolitik strategy to distance the US from European imperialism's legacy.

site_title: Temasek to contribute more to govt coffers
summary: Temasek Holdings will contribute more to the Singapore government's coffers as it is included in the Net Investment Returns (NIR) framework, starting from 2017. The government will spend up to 100% of expected long-term returns on Temasek's net assets, including realised and unrealised capital gains. This move is expected to bolster fiscal resources, with an estimated additional S$3.4 billion annually. Temasek's investment strategy remains unchanged, and the government is working with Temasek to develop an approach to project its expected long-term returns.

site_title: Silver Support to pay out S$600 on average each quarter
summary: Singapore's Silver Support scheme will provide an average of S$600 every three months for life to lower-income retirees, starting in the first quarter of 2025. The programme targets the bottom 20% of seniors aged 65 and above, with payouts ranging from S$300 to S$750. The scheme aims to supplement incomes in retirement and is part of the country's fourth pillar of social security, along with Workfare, home ownership, and healthcare assurance. The programme is expected to benefit 150,000 seniors and cost the government S$350 million annually.

images.alt_text: Lower-income retirees stand to receive an average of S$600 every three months for life under the Silver Support scheme to be rolled out in the first quarter of next year.

site_title: Sino Construction unit builds power plants in South Korea
summary: Sino Construction's power generation subsidiary, Magnum Modular Power Generation, is building micro power plants (MPPs) in South Korea, with initial construction payments made for the first plant. The company aims to roll out 150 MPPs in 36 months, focusing on attractive tariffs and a liberalised market. Construction of the first MPP is contingent on regulatory approval from the city of Pohang and the Korea Power Exchange. This move is driven by a global trend of preferential tariff rates for renewable fuel sources, offering Magnum Modular flexibility and long-term stability.

site_title: Oman to boost output of crude
summary: Oman plans to boost crude output to 980,000 barrels per day this year, a 4% increase from 2013, in response to the global price rout. The country aims to continue executing future projects and exploration activities to be prepared for a potential market turn-around. Oman estimates a worldwide crude surplus of one million barrels per day, and the country's budget relies heavily on oil revenue, with a projected deficit of 2.5 billion rials ($8.84 billion) in 2015.

site_title: US$150m Manhattan triplex to set luxury-condo record
