summary: A US$150 million Manhattan triplex at the former Sony Building has set a new record for the most expensive residential listing in the city, surpassing a US$130 million penthouse at 520 Park Ave. The luxury condo market is experiencing a surge in prices, with developers offering unique units to stand out from the crowd. This marks the highest price ever paid for a condominium in the city, at US$100.5 million for a duplex penthouse at One57.

site_title: Tax incentives for S-Reits extended but not stamp duty remissions
summary: Singapore has extended tax incentives for S-Reits for five more years, including tax exemption on foreign-sourced income and reduced withholding tax on distributions. However, stamp duty remissions for local property purchases will lapse after March this year. The move aims to promote Reit listings in Singapore amidst Asian competition, with the industry welcoming the extensions despite the removal of stamp duty concessions, which will have limited impact on most Reits.

site_title: Fortifying Singapore's four pillars of social security
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam presented a budget with a focus on social empowerment, progressivity, protection, and inclusiveness. The budget includes measures such as a Silver Support Scheme for the elderly, enhanced CPF contributions, and increased subsidies for education. The corporate sector will benefit from extended Wage Credit Scheme and deferred foreign worker levies. The government also introduced a Productivity Innovation Credit scheme, SkillsFuture Credit for skills development, and revenue-enhancing measures such as including Temasek Holdings in the net investment return framework and increasing the top marginal rate of personal income tax.

site_title: Of adequacy and adaptability
summary: Singapore's "SG50 Budget" maintains fiscal prudence despite a generous surplus cushion, offsetting a S$6.7 billion deficit. The budget focuses on demographic, productivity, and income gap realities, with measures such as calibrated hikes to top income tax rates and expanded net investment revenues. It also addresses structural adequacy issues, including productivity and innovation, and boosts human capital through the "SkillsFuture" drive. The budget provides relief to seniors and middle-income households, including a universal medical insurance coverage and pension adequacy measures, while addressing affordable housing for low-income groups.

site_title: Oil tankers idling for months off Delaware waters
summary: A tanker carrying 650,000 barrels of Angolan crude dropped anchor off Delaware Bay in November and idled for nearly 11 weeks, discharging oil at a slow rate. The prolonged stopover has puzzled traders and raised concerns about the welfare of the sailors aboard. Reasons for the prolonged stopover are unclear, and the situation has sparked criticism. The incident is unusual, as tankers typically complete shipments quickly to avoid delays and lost revenue. An investigation is needed to determine the cause of the delay and ensure the sailors' well-being.

site_title: Swiss franc nears 5-week low on Greek debt deal
summary: The Swiss franc dropped over one percent against the dollar, nearing a five-week low, as Greece-related safety flows waned after a conditional loan extension was reached. Despite this, the euro remained under pressure, up 0.5 percent against the franc, due to ongoing uncertainty. Eurozone ministers agreed to extend Greece's financial rescue package by four months, removing the immediate threat of Greece's exit from the single currency bloc. However, questions remain over the short-term extension's impact on Athens' solvency.

site_title: 2 UK ex-ministers accused in undercover sting
summary: Two UK ex-ministers, Malcolm Rifkind and Jack Straw, have been accused of offering to use their positions for payment. An undercover investigation found Straw offered £5,000 a day in exchange for services, while Rifkind promised "useful access" to British ambassadors worldwide. Straw suspended himself from the Labour party, while Rifkind denied wrongdoing and referred himself to the Parliamentary Commissioner for Standards. The allegations come just months before the general election, echoing past "cash for access" scandals.

site_title: US: Stocks dip ahead of Yellen hearing, Greece plan
summary: US stocks declined ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's update on monetary policy, with the Dow Jones falling 62.77 points to 18,077.67 and the S&P 500 dropping 4.50 points to 2,105.80. The Nasdaq composite Index also fell 0.42 points to 4,955.54. Greece faces a deadline to deliver reform proposals required by its EU bailout extension.

images.alt_text: US stocks retreated from record highs in opening trade on Monday ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's expected update of US monetary policy in Congress this week.

site_title: S'pore Q4 domestic wholesale trade dips
summary: Singapore's domestic wholesale trade contracted 12.9% in Q4 2014 compared to the previous year, primarily due to a 32.3% decline in general wholesale trade and steep falls in ship chandlers and bunkering, as well as petroleum and petroleum products industries. However, telecommunications and computers saw the strongest growth, increasing 17.8%. Excluding petroleum, wholesale trade fell 7% compared to 2013, but adjusted for price changes, it rose 5.7%.

site_title: S$6.67b FY15 forecast deficit to fund future investments
summary: Singapore's fiscal year 2015 budget forecast a deficit of S$6.67 billion, or 1.7% of GDP, primarily to fund S$6 billion in future investments. Half of the funds will go to Changi Airport development, while significant boosts are made to employment credit, productivity, and research initiatives.

images.alt_text: Mr Tharman said "there is no draw on past reserves" to fund the overall deficit in FY15.

site_title: Honda president to step aside following record vehicle recalls
summary: Honda president Takanobu Ito will step down as president after record vehicle recalls, citing quality lapses. Ito, 61, will become an adviser, while 55-year-old managing officer Takahiro Hachigo will take over. The changes come after Honda cut profit forecasts due to recalls tied to Takata air bags and new hybrid systems. Ito had previously scrapped Honda's target of selling 6 million vehicles annually by 2017 due to quality issues. Hachigo will oversee the company's quality and production.

site_title: Jubilee Budget sets course for Singapore's future
summary: Singapore's 2015 Jubilee Budget focuses on building the country's future, with measures to calibrate the economy, equip the workforce with future skills, and provide greater assurance in retirement. The budget includes an increase in government spending, a shift towards stronger collective responsibility, and a more progressive CPF system. The government also offers support for innovation and internationalization, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises, and introduces the Silver Support Scheme to help seniors in need. The budget aims to reduce reliance on foreign manpower and increase the use of skills and expertise in every job, with a projected increase in overall spending to 19.5% of GDP over the next five years.

site_title: HSBC says CEO paid taxes after opening Swiss account
summary: HSBC CEO Stuart Gulliver has been paying taxes on his earnings globally, including bonuses held in a Swiss account, despite using the account for confidentiality reasons. The bank set up the account in 1998 to hold bonus payments while working in Hong Kong, and Gulliver paid Hong Kong taxes on the bonuses. He has also paid UK taxes on his earnings since moving to the UK in 2003. The move comes amid HSBC's efforts to toughen internal controls and cut clients at its Swiss private bank following a report detailing its handling of tax evaders and criminals.

site_title: Weak global dairy market unlikely to pick up soon
summary: The global dairy market remains weak due to oversupply and decreased demand, particularly in China, where consumption has dried up after high prices cut domestic demand. Analysts predict the market won't improve for another six months, with a possible seasonal rise in production in the European Union and the US in the spring. Heavy investment in modern dairy farms in China and EU farmers' expansion plans ahead of milk quota abolition also contribute to the market's weakness.

site_title: SIA slips a notch on Fortune's list of 50 most-admired companies
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) dropped to 19th spot on Fortune's list of 50 most-admired companies, down one position from last year. Despite this, SIA remained the highest-ranked Asian company and the only one from Singapore. It ranked second among airlines, behind Delta Air Lines. The rankings were based on industry expert responses and a survey of 4,100 executives, directors, and analysts. SIA's share price closed down 1.22% at S$12.11.

site_title: EU launches competition probe into GE-Alstom deal
summary: EU competition regulators launched a probe into General Electric's planned 12.4-billion-euro acquisition of Alstom's energy business, citing it would eliminate one of three main competitors, potentially leading to higher prices and less choice for customers in the 28-nation bloc.

site_title: Prada up in HK on sales recovery forecast
summary: Prada shares rose 3.9% in Hong Kong trading, the highest close in two weeks, after reporting a slight fall in full-year sales due to reduced demand for luxury products in China. The company expects same-store sales growth to speed up this year.

site_title: Target cuts free-shipping eligibility to US$25 for online orders
summary: Target Corp reduced its free-shipping eligibility for online orders to US$25, a cut from US$50, in an effort to compete with Amazon.com and Wal-Mart Stores Inc. The move follows a positive response to the company's holiday shopping season promotions.

images.alt_text: Target Corp cut its eligibility for free-shipping of online orders by half to US$25 as the company focuses more on its online division to better compete against Amazon.com Inc and traditional rival Wal-Mart Stores Inc.

site_title: Silver Support Scheme is first step to a minimum pension guarantee
summary: Singapore's government introduced the Silver Support Scheme, a permanent programme providing up to S$750 per quarter to needy seniors throughout their retirement, aiming to address retirement adequacy. The scheme shares the burden of retirement with society, enhancing social protection for low-income Singaporeans. While some may be concerned about weakening personal responsibility, social welfare systems can strengthen society by protecting individuals against risks that market systems alone cannot address. The scheme aims to improve retirement adequacy among pioneers and will be followed by measures to encourage individual savings for retirement among working Singaporeans.

site_title: Go forth and multiply
summary: The Singapore government has announced budget measures to encourage internationalization by local companies, with a focus on small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Foreign revenue from top 1,000 companies and SMEs has increased steadily, and the government aims to sustain this trend with tax incentives and grants. The International Growth Scheme, Mergers and Acquisition (M&A) allowance, and enhanced double tax deductions will be introduced to support companies in expanding their international presence. The measures are expected to boost economic growth and make Singapore an attractive destination for foreign investment.

images.alt_text: Businesses of all sizes should be rejoicing over the goodies distributed in this year's Budget announcement. Particularly, the measures targeted at helping Singapore companies internationalise send a clear message that local businesses need to look beyond the domestic market in order to achieve breakthroughs in growth.

site_title: Key budget numbers
summary: Singapore's Budget 2015 highlights key budget numbers, including a 3.6% increase in the Goods and Services Tax (GST) and a 1.5% increase in the income tax rate. The government also announced a new grant of up to S$100,000 for tariff-hit businesses and plans to establish a centre for sustainable aviation in Asia. Additionally, the government emphasized the importance of future-proofing careers to address potential crises, with the Workforce Singapore and Singapore Business Federation offering support.

site_title: Gold fever fading as US$4b erased from funds
summary: Speculators cut their net-long wagers on gold by 18% to 110,164 futures and options contracts, the largest decline in 15 weeks, amid a strengthening dollar and record valuations for global equities. The US dollar reached its highest level in a decade, with the dollar-traded index climbing 0.4%, while the S&P 500 Index rose 0.6% to a record. This month's losses in exchange-traded products (ETP) backed by gold reached $4 billion, as investors shifted to equities as a more attractive risk asset.

site_title: Yoshida's games strategy makes Sony the winner
summary: Shuhei Yoshida, president of Sony's worldwide game studios, has led the company's successful turnaround with his inclusive approach to game development. Since 2008, he has fostered independent game developers, supporting hits like Journey and Tokyo Jungle. This strategy has contributed to the PlayStation 4's record-breaking 19 million units sold and Sony's shares rising 81% in the past 12 months. Yoshida's focus on content has helped Sony compete with Microsoft and Nintendo, as gamers increasingly choose consoles based on software availability. His approach has also led to Sony's expansion into virtual reality and live streaming.

images.alt_text: Mr Yoshida says his strategy to court independent games developers with money and production support paid off because it led to great games and a vibrant industry.

site_title: IMF joins call to boost the economic role of women
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has released a report urging governments to boost the economic role of women, citing that policies limiting women's participation in the workforce are hindering global economic growth. The report states that increasing female labor force participation could boost GDP by 5% in the US, 9% in Japan, and more significantly in other countries. The IMF joins other international organizations in calling for policy changes to address these gender gaps and promote economic growth.

images.alt_text: IMF managing director Christine Lagarde suggested last year that "quotas" might be a way to ensure that women secured key posts in government and the private sector, but has now appeared to soften the stance, saying a multi-pronged, culture-specific approach was needed.

site_title: A more nuanced approach to restructuring
summary: Singapore will slow the pace of foreign worker inflows, deferring planned levy hikes, but Deputy Prime Minister Tharman emphasized the government's commitment to restructuring. The move aims to give companies time to adapt to a tight labor market. Levy hikes for manufacturing and construction sectors will be delayed, while levies for skilled workers will be raised in 2016 and 2017. The government will also phase out a transition support package, introducing measures to promote innovation and internationalization. This shift marks a subtle change in approach, focusing on quality growth rather than labor cost control.

site_title: Maersk may reward shareholders as oil unit suffers: analysts
summary: Danish conglomerate AP Moller-Maersk is considering a second share buyback scheme to reward shareholders, amid its oil unit's struggles due to a slump in oil prices. The company's net profit is expected to rise 9.8% to $1 billion, boosted by a 59% rise in container shipping. Analysts predict the company may announce a $1 billion share buyback and further divestments from its portfolio to finance growth and cash distribution.

site_title: SMEs hail Budget initiatives to help with restructuring, growth
summary: SMEs in Singapore welcomed the Budget 2015 initiatives, including the extension of the Wage Credit Scheme, income tax rebate, and deferral of foreign worker levies. OCBC's head of global commercial banking, Linus Goh, stated that these measures will help ease the burden of SMEs as they strive to improve productivity amidst rising business costs. Industry leaders expressed optimism about the government's comprehensive plan to create greater value, deepen skill sets, and spur innovation in the economy, with potential for growth in emerging markets.

site_title: Singapore Budget Reaction: Incremental demand for office spaces by new reit listings will be marginal: JLL
summary: Singapore's budget has proposed extending tax concessions for listed real estate investment trusts (reits) and terminating stamp duty remission on properties. However, experts at Jones Lang LaSalle predict marginal demand for office spaces from new reit listings, as the large office supply already exists. The non-extension of stamp duty remission will not have a significant impact on the real estate market. The government's tax concessions will be extended to March 31, 2020, and the stamp duty remission will lapse on March 31, 2015.

site_title: France fines drivers who pick up fares through Uber's low-cost service
summary: France has fined drivers who use Uber's low-cost service, dubbed "UberPool," for operating without proper licenses. The fines were imposed after the company was deemed to be operating as "illegal chauffeurs." This decision comes as Uber continues to face regulatory challenges in France, following similar bans in cities like Rome and Rio de Janeiro. The fines are part of an effort by French lawmakers to regulate the ride-hailing service and ensure compliance with local laws.

site_title: Singapore Budget Reaction: A Budget for businesses and individuals: Stanchart
summary: Singapore's Budget 2015 aims to address concerns about the domestic economy and business prospects, with measures including SkillsFuture to build skills, a freeze in foreign workers' levy, and changes to the Central Provident Fund (CPF) for retirement adequacy. The government also proposes an increase in income taxes for top earners to address higher development and operating expenditure. For individuals, there are enhancements to GST vouchers and measures to help the middle class through indirect taxes. The budget aims for inclusive growth and addresses business and individual concerns.

site_title: Singapore Budget Reaction: Government has responded to challenges facing SMEs
summary: The Singapore government has responded to challenges facing small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) with various proposals in the 2015 budget. The government has increased the M&A tax allowance to 25% from 5% and lowered the qualifying shareholding threshold to 20%, providing significant help for SMEs seeking inorganic growth and consolidation. The government has also introduced a new tax incentive scheme for companies targeting internationalization efforts and extended the Wage Credit Scheme to 2017 to attract and retain workforce. Experts welcome these measures, citing their potential to boost SME growth and competitiveness in a tough global business environment.

site_title: US existing home sales hit nine-month low, supply weak
summary: US existing home sales fell 4.9% to 4.82 million units in January, the lowest level in nine months, due to a shortage of properties on the market. Despite declining mortgage rates, tight inventories and elevated house prices limited sales. Economists had forecast a 4.97-million unit pace. The inventory of unsold homes decreased 0.5% from a year ago, with insufficient equity and economic uncertainty forcing potential sellers to stay in their homes.

site_title: SIIC more than doubles Q4 earnings
summary: SIIC Environment's Q4 earnings more than doubled to 65.9 million yuan, driven by a higher share of results from joint ventures and associates, despite a 34.5% drop in revenue. The firm's net profit increased to 31.3 million yuan, up from 4.4 million yuan a year ago. The boost was largely attributed to its newly acquired associate and joint venture, which contributed 18.4 million yuan to the earnings.

site_title: UK retail sales growth plummets in Feb, weakest since Nov 2013: CBI
summary: UK retail sales growth plummeted in February, the weakest since November 2013, according to a CBI survey. Sales growth fell to +1 from +39 in January, beating economists' forecasts of +34. Retailers cut orders with suppliers at the fastest pace since May 2013 and expect to reduce staff at the sharpest rate in over five years. Despite this, sales expectations for March remained positive, with forecasters expecting a boost to household incomes from falling inflation to support spending.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Monday
summary: Singapore Wrap Monday. Key stories include Vietnam's surprise at US tariff rates, the Asian garment industry's concerns, and Malaysia's plan to seize Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, while Citigroup forecasts a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index. In politics, Thailand's Thaksin is optimistic about his daughter's court case, and the ASEAN region agrees Myanmar's election is not a priority. The UK economy contracted for the second consecutive month, causing fresh concerns for Labour leader Starmer.

site_title: Hang Seng Bank's profit tumbles 43%
summary: Hang Seng Bank Ltd reported a 43% drop in 2014 profit to HK$15.1 billion (US$1.95 billion), down from HK$26.7 billion in 2013. The earnings were lower due to an accounting gain of HK$9.52 billion in 2013, which is now being sold down. The result contrasts with a record 2013 profit.

site_title: Singapore Budget Reaction: Not quite a typical election budget but still, a generous one: OCBC
summary: Singapore Budget 2015 is considered a generous one despite not being a typical election budget, according to OCBC Bank's Selena Ling. The budget includes a softer touch for businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, and more help for the needy and elderly. Key highlights include a tweaking of the net investment returns framework to allow for more spending, estimated at 1% of GDP annually over the next five years. The budget also includes fiscal goodies for households, but some measures aligned with economic restructuring were not granted.

site_title: HSBC's 2014 profit down by 17%
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc reported a 17% decline in full-year profit to $18.7 billion in 2014, missing analyst estimates of $21.5 billion. Operating costs rose 6.1% to $37.9 billion. CEO Stuart Gulliver attributed the decline to higher costs and the need to focus on profitable markets. The bank also saw a 38% drop in investment bank profit to $5.9 billion. The decline in profit comes amid new regulations and rising compliance costs.

site_title: Singapore Budget Reaction: A budget about strengthening social safety net for elderly and needy: EY
summary: Singapore's Budget 2015 aims to strengthen the social safety net for the elderly and needy, while promoting equal opportunities and lifelong learning. The budget also focuses on supporting SMEs and creating a sustainable economy. Key initiatives include affordable education and sharper productivity and innovation measures. Experts from Ernst & Young praise the comprehensive nature of the budget, stating it is a "jubilee budget" with something for everyone, including individuals and businesses. The budget is seen as a step towards maintaining a vibrant, future-ready economy.

site_title: Singapore Budget Reaction: Venture debt risk-sharing initiative sets stage for high-tech hub: UOB
summary: The United Overseas Bank (UOB) has welcomed Singapore's budget, citing a venture debt risk-sharing initiative that sets the stage for the country to become an international hub for high-tech ventures. The program aims to diversify financing options for start-ups and SMEs, particularly those in the Asian market, with a potential market size of US$2.2 billion in the next five years. UOB's Managing Director Eric Tham sees high-tech SMEs from China, India, and Singapore as having the most potential for venture debt.

site_title: Oil prices fall on oversupply and refinery strike concerns
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday due to concerns over oversupply and a potential refinery strike in the US, pushing Brent futures down to around $59 a barrel. The largest US refinery strike in 35 years entered its fourth week, and cold weather on the US East Coast has raised fears of tight heating oil supplies. A stronger dollar also made dollar-traded commodities like oil more expensive. Despite a slowdown in US drilling, oil production growth is expected to reach 440,000 barrels per day by the fourth quarter of 2015.

site_title: The impact of Budget 2015
summary: Singapore's Budget 2015, announced on February 23, 2015, focused on various sectors, including sustainable aviation, education, and trade. The government established a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific, and provided a new grant of up to S$100,000 for businesses affected by tariffs. The budget also emphasized the need for graduates to stay calm, as early data showed better employment rates. Additionally, the government highlighted the potential for Singapore to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging, and offered training assistance through the Singapore Business Federation.

site_title: Food Empire's losses widen in Q4
summary: Food Empire reported a widening loss of $12.1 million in Q4, down from $226,000 a year ago, due to weak oil prices and foreign exchange losses in Russia and Ukraine. Revenue fell 22.3% to $57.6 million. The group's full-year net loss was $13.2 million, down from a $11.7 million profit in 2013. Food Empire may consider rationalizing operations in Russia and Ukraine if the situation continues, while diversification into Asia is showing progress.

images.alt_text: FOOD Empire sank deeper into the red in the fourth quarter, as weak oil prices and the conflict between Russia and Ukraine continued to take a toll on the group.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Temasek to be included in net investment returns framework
summary: Singapore will include the total expected returns from Temasek Holdings in its net investment returns (NIR) framework, allowing the government to spend up to 50% of the expected long-term real returns on its net assets. This change, announced by Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, aims to provide a more comprehensive view of the government's investment performance. The updated NIR framework was implemented in 2009 and will impact the government's financial planning and budgeting.

site_title: Japan farm minister quits over political funding allegations
summary: Japanese Farm Minister Koya Nishikawa resigned due to allegations he accepted improper political donations from a sugar industry association while involved in negotiations over agricultural tariffs in the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade talks. This marks the third cabinet resignation by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government in less than six months, following two female ministers who quit over financial impropriety. Nishikawa's resignation is seen as a blow to Abe's efforts to reform Japan's agricultural policies, which are part of a broader push for structural reforms to spur economic growth.

site_title: Singapore Budget Reaction: Initiatives critical in nurturing new generation of businesses: KPMG
summary: Singapore Budget 2015 initiatives aim to nurture a new generation of businesses through productivity adoption, innovation, and internationalization. KPMG's Head of Tax, Tay Hong Beng, praises the budget for its forward-looking approach, but notes that it would be sweeter if it included incentives for internal branding recognition. The budget provides assistance to businesses to help them innovate and venture abroad, but critics suggest that more should be done to support pioneering businesses contributing to the Singapore economy, particularly during the SG 50 celebration.

site_title: Greece reform list received in Brussels
summary: Greece has submitted a list of economic reforms to extend its bailout program by four months, as demanded by its creditors. The European Union, European Central Bank, and International Monetary Fund had set a deadline for the new left-wing Greek government to present the reforms after last-chance talks on Friday. The list's details have not been disclosed, but its submission is seen as a step towards extending the bailout program.

site_title: German business confidence inches higher in February: Ifo
summary: German business confidence rose to its highest level in seven months in February, reaching 106.8 points, according to the Ifo economic institute. This marks the fourth consecutive monthly increase, surpassing its previous high in July 2014. The robust economy remains resilient despite geopolitical uncertainty.

images.alt_text: German business confidence rose to its highest level in seven months in February, as Europe's biggest economy remains robust in the face of geopolitical uncertainty, the Ifo economic institute said on Monday.

site_title: Singapore Budget Reaction: AWARE welcomes 'redistributive policies'
summary: The Association of Women for Action and Research (AWARE) welcomed Singapore's redistributive policies in the 2015 budget, citing increased assistance for low-income groups and a commitment to taxation of the top 5% earners. AWARE praised the government's recognition of collective responsibility, fairness, and the need for universal basic pension and reduced childcare and early childhood education costs.

site_title: Singapore Budget Reaction: OCBC exploring ways to return wage credit scheme payout to staff
summary: OCBC Bank is exploring ways to return the Wage Credit Scheme payout from the government to its employees for 2015, following the extension of the scheme for two years by Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam. The bank received positive feedback from employees last year when it gave a S$3 million payout to 1,500 eligible employees, and plans to continue this practice. The payout will benefit around 25% of OCBC Bank's and its securities subsidiary's total staff strength in Singapore.

images.alt_text: OCBC Bank is exploring various ways of giving back the Wage Credit Scheme payout from the government to its employees again this year following the announcement by Singapore's finance minister that the scheme would be extended for another two years.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Overall Budget Balance for FY2015 projected at a deficit of S$6.7b
summary: Singapore's overall budget balance for fiscal year 2015 is projected to be a deficit of S$6.7 billion (1.7% of GDP), mainly due to investments in Changi Airport Development Fund and other funds. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam stated that excluding these investments, the budget would be close to balance. The government has sufficient surpluses from previous years, with no draw on past reserves to fund the deficit.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Govt spending to hit 5-yr average of 19% of GDP
summary: Singapore's government spending is projected to reach 19-19.5% of GDP on average over the next five years, said Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam. This is 1% higher than current revenues. The government expects a "very small" deficit of S$0.1 billion. The budget aims to balance spending and revenue growth, with a focus on investing in key sectors such as healthcare and infrastructure. The move is seen as a sustainable approach to managing the country's finances.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Foreign maid levy concession halved to S$60 from May 2015
summary: Singapore's government will halve the foreign domestic worker concessionary levy to S$60 per month starting May 1, 2015, benefiting 144,500 households. The move aims to support middle-income families caring for children and elderly parents, costing the government approximately S$125 million annually. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam announced the changes, which extend the levy to households with children under 16, up from under 12.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Top marginal tax rate for higher income-earners to be raised to 22%
summary: Singapore's government is raising the top marginal tax rate for higher income-earners to 22% for those with a chargeable income above S$320,000. This change will apply starting 2016 and is expected to raise S$400 million in additional revenue annually. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam described the move as "calibrated" and not significantly impacting competitiveness. The changes aim to enhance progressivity and strengthen future revenues.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Monday, up 1.52 points to 1,809.39. The index saw 2.47 billion lots traded worth RM1.84 billion, with 428 gainers and 382 losers.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Healthcare spending to hit over S$13 billion in 2020
summary: Singapore's healthcare spending is expected to rise from S$9 billion in 2015 to S$13 billion in 2020, with Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam stating it will continue to increase beyond this decade.

site_title: Saudi telecoms regulator cuts call connection fees by 40%
summary: Saudi Arabia's telecommunications regulator has cut call termination fees by 40%, from 0.25 riyals to 0.15 riyals per minute. The move is seen as benefiting Zain Saudi, the smallest mobile network operator. The fee reduction aims to increase competition in the market.

site_title: Singapore: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Singapore shares closed lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index down 14.36 points to 3,421.30. Volume reached 1.07 billion shares worth S$1.28 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 224 to 214. This marks a reversal from the previous 5-day rally, which was driven by GDP data ahead.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: CPF contribution for workers aged 55 and above to go up
summary: The Singapore government has announced a change to the Central Provident Fund (CPF) contribution rates. For workers aged 55-60, the employer contribution rate will increase by 1 percentage point, starting from January 1, 2016. For workers aged 60-65, the increase will be 0.5 percentage points. The changes aim to support workers in their retirement years.

site_title: Budget 2015 at a glance
summary: Singapore's Budget 2015 focuses on economic growth and sustainability. Key highlights include the establishment of a centre to advance sustainable aviation in the Asia-Pacific region, improved employment rates for graduates, and trade talks with the US. The government also introduced a new grant of up to S$100,000 for businesses affected by tariffs. Additionally, Singapore is seen as a potential hub for advanced chip packaging, and initiatives like the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) aim to support workers in future-proofing their careers. These measures aim to drive economic growth and resilience.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: S$3b injection into new Changi Airport Development Fund
summary: The Singapore government announced the creation of a new Changi Airport Development Fund with an initial S$3 billion injection, according to Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam. This fund will support the development of Changi Airport. No further details on the fund's objectives or timeline were provided.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Petrol duty rates to go up 15-20 cents per litre immediately
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam announced a 15-20 cents per liter increase in petrol duty rates, effective immediately, to encourage less car usage and reduce carbon emissions. The changes will yield the government approximately S$177 million annually. To ease the transition, a one-year road tax rebate of 20-100% will be provided for cars, motorcycles, and commercial vehicles using petrol, costing the government S$144 million. The move aims to maintain lower pump prices despite falling oil prices.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Tax deduction for donations to be raised in Jubilee Year
summary: The Singapore government has announced plans to raise the tax deduction for donations from 250% to 300% in the Jubilee Year, and extend the existing 250% tax deduction for donations for another three years. This change aims to encourage philanthropy and support charitable causes.

images.alt_text: The government will raise the tax deduction for donations made in this Jubilee Year from 250 per cent to 300 per cent, Tharman Shanmugaratnam, Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister, said on Monday.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Silver Support to cost an estimated S$350m in first year
summary: Singapore's Silver Support Scheme, a progressive social support system, is estimated to cost S$350 million in the first year. The scheme, to be implemented around Q1 2016, provides a quarterly supplement of S$300 to S$750 to eligible seniors aged 65 and above, aiming to support the bottom 20-30% of seniors. The scheme is similar to Workfare, which supports the bottom 20-30% of Singaporean workers. The government will spend approximately S$1 billion annually on the system.

site_title: Singapore Budget Reaction: The government has delivered a "People's Budget': Deloitte
summary: Singapore's government has delivered a "People's Budget" with increased subsidies for lifelong learning, Silver Support, and a more progressive CPF scheme. The budget aims to strengthen the country's social security system with measures such as raising CPF contribution rates for older workers and introducing the Silver Support Scheme. The government also increased taxes on the wealthy to help subsidize the budget. The overall deficit is expected to be S$0.1 billion. The budget is seen as a positive step towards investing in the future and supporting the bottom 20% of Singaporeans aged 65 and above.

images.alt_text: "The Government promised a 'People's Budget' and they certainly delivered: a birthday budget that invests in the future with enhanced subsidies for lifelong learning, Silver Support and a more progressive CPF scheme; but with increased taxes on the wealthy to help subsidise."

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Personal income tax rebate of 50% to benefit 1.5 million taxpayers
summary: Singapore's 2015 budget introduced a 50% personal income tax rebate for 1.5 million taxpayers, costing the government S$717 million. The rebate, capped at S$1,000, primarily benefits middle and upper-middle income groups. The measure is part of the government's efforts to support the economy.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Key policy measures
summary: Singapore's 2015 budget focuses on building the country's future, driven by innovation and higher incomes from deep skills and expertise. The budget includes key initiatives such as a slower pace of foreign worker tightening, a Transition Support Package, and more support for innovation and R&D. The government also aims to invest in "skills of the future" and empower individuals to learn and develop throughout life, with a focus on skills development and industry collaboration. Additionally, the budget includes measures to strengthen retirement assurance and support middle-income families, as well as investments in economic and social infrastructure.

images.alt_text: A budget focused on building Singapore's future, was how Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam summed up his close to two-and-a-half-hour long speech in Parliament on Monday.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: S&CC rebates this year to cost S$80 million
summary: The Singapore government will provide rebates for service and conservancy charges (S&CC) worth S$80 million, with one to three months of rebates to be introduced. One-room HDB households will receive three months of rebates, while three-room households will receive two months of rebates. This move aims to alleviate the financial burden on low-income households.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Carbon Emissions-based Vehicle Scheme extended until June 2017
summary: Singapore's Carbon Emissions-based Vehicle Scheme (CEVS) will be extended until June 30, 2017, to encourage the take-up of carbon-efficient vehicles. Introduced in 2013, the scheme has seen over 65% of cars registered in 2014 qualify for rebates, while 5% paid a surcharge. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam expressed encouragement over the scheme's results, aiming to promote environmentally friendly transportation in the country.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: M&A enhancements to cost S$100m over 5 years
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam announced a S$100 million spending plan over five years to enhance mergers and acquisitions (M&A) in Singapore. The tax allowance for acquisition costs will increase to 25% from 5%, and the International Enterprise Singapore's Internationalisation Finance Scheme will be extended to support M&A for overseas expansion. The government will also increase the maximum loan quantum under the scheme to S$30 million from S$15 million.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: CPF salary ceiling to be raised to S$6,000 from S$5,000
summary: The Singapore government has announced plans to raise the Central Provident Fund (CPF) salary ceiling from S$5,000 to S$6,000, benefiting at least 544,000 CPF members. The change will take effect from January 1, 2016, along with a raise in the contribution cap for the Supplementary Retirement Scheme. These changes aim to encourage voluntary retirement savings and complement the CPF.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: CPF contribution for "working years" to go up, Silver Support scheme introduced
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister, Tharman Shanmugaratnam, announced key changes to the country's Central Provident Fund (CPF) system. Contributions during the "working years" will increase, while the CPF salary ceiling will be raised to S$6,000. The government will also introduce the Silver Support scheme to supplement the incomes of older Singaporeans with limited resources in retirement.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Extra 1% interest on first S$30,000 of CPF balances from age 55
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman announced that from January 1, 2016, Central Provident Fund (CPF) members aged 55 will receive an extra 1% interest on the first S$30,000 of their balances, in addition to the existing 1% interest on the first S$60,000. This will increase the interest for those with lower balances, with a 20% increase in monthly payouts. The move aims to benefit those with lower retirement savings, with around 60% of CPF members aged 55 and older set to earn 6% interest on their retirement savings.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: CPF contribution rate for those aged 50-55 to be restored
summary: The Singapore government will restore the Central Provident Fund (CPF) contribution rates for workers aged 50-55 to the same level as younger workers, starting from January 1, 2016. The contribution rate will increase by two percentage points, with one point from the employer and one point from the employee. This change aims to provide more support to workers nearing retirement.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Subsidies for mid-career Singaporeans to be enhanced
summary: Singapore's government will enhance education and training subsidies for mid-career Singaporeans aged 40 and above, with subsidies to be at least 90% of training costs for courses funded by the Ministry of Education and Workforce Development Agency. The government will also introduce SkillsFuture Study Awards and Fellowships to develop specialist skills and corporate leaders, respectively.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Singapore Reits to enjoy income tax and GST concessions for 5 more years
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam announced that income tax and GST concessions for real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) will be extended for five more years to attract listings. The concessions will be enhanced to facilitate fund-raising by special purpose vehicles. However, stamp duty concessions for the purchase of local properties will lapse after March 31, 2015. The move aims to anchor the sustainable growth of the S-Reit industry, which has already acquired a critical mass of local assets.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Adjusted levies for manufacturing, construction sectors
summary: Singapore's government announced adjustments to levies for manufacturing and construction sectors in the 2015 budget. The manufacturing sector will keep current levy rates unchanged for two years, while the construction sector will experience two further adjustments between 2015 and 2017. This move aims to manage manpower costs for these sectors.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: More wage-offset credit for workers aged 65 and above
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam announced an additional special employment credit (SEC) of up to 3% of wages for workers aged 65 and above in 2015, on top of an 8.5% wage offset. This measure will cost about S$50 million and is part of a S$500 million top-up to the SEC Fund. The move aims to support older workers in the workforce.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Capability Development Grant to be enhanced at cost of S$600m
summary: The Singapore government will enhance the Capability Development Grant (CDG) over three years at an estimated cost of S$600 million, starting from 2015. The grant supports innovation activities and currently supports 1,200 projects annually. The application process will be simplified for projects below S$30,000, and the funding support level will be extended to 70% of costs until March 2018. The government aims to promote industry collaborations through expanded Spring Singapore's Collaborative Industry Projects and Partnerships for Capability Transformation schemes.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Foreign worker levies' pace of increase to be refined
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance, Tharman Shanmugaratnam, announced that the government will refine the pace of increase in foreign worker levies due to the slowdown in foreign worker inflows. This move aims to address the tight labor market, allowing firms to devise new ways to survive and grow. The government expects a "very small" deficit of S$0.1 billion in the budget.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close flat
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed flat on Monday, ending the Lunar New Year break, with the Hang Seng Index adding 4.68 points to 24,836.76 on HK$49.36 billion in turnover.

site_title: Update: Oil prices fall over worries about US oversupply
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday due to concerns about oversupply in North America, with Brent futures testing support around $60 a barrel and US contracts hovering around $50.50. US crude inventories are at record highs, and analysts predict a continued decline in US rig count. A cold spell in the US could also prevent crude prices from rising further, with refineries experiencing reduced output due to the weather.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: CPF salary ceiling, contribution for older workers, to go up
summary: The Singapore government has announced enhancements to the Central Provident Fund (CPF) in the 2015 budget. The salary ceiling will be raised to benefit middle-income Singaporeans, and contribution rates for older workers will be increased. Additionally, CPF interest rates will be enhanced further in retirement to benefit those with lower balances. The government expects a "very small" deficit of S$0.1 billion in the budget.

site_title: Malaysia's Danajamin to guarantee bond, sukuk market
summary: Malaysia's Danajamin Nasional Bhd, the country's sole specialized credit guarantor, plans to introduce partial guarantees to encourage issuers in the conventional and Islamic bond markets. The move aims to deepen and stretch the market with new products, as Malaysia prepares to remove mandatory credit ratings in 2017. The firm has provided guarantees for over $1.92 billion of issuance, with 45% in sukuk, and will expand its use of partial and temporary credit guarantees. This aims to promote diversity in the market and support issuers with projects that need long-term financing.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: "Very small" deficit of S$0.1 billion expected
summary: Singapore is expected to have a "very small" deficit of S$0.1 billion for the financial year 2014, close to a balanced position, according to Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam. This is lower than the government's earlier estimate of an overall deficit of S$1.2 billion. The country recorded a surplus of S$3.9 billion in FY2013.

site_title: UK raises US$769m through Lloyds shares sale
summary: Britain's finance ministry raised £500 million (US$769 million) through the sale of a 1% stake in Lloyds Banking Group, cutting its holding to below 24%. This sale moves Lloyds closer to private ownership, with the government having previously held a 41% stake. The sale is part of efforts to reduce the national debt and recover taxpayer money invested in the bank during the 2007-2009 financial crisis.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: National Research Fund to get S$1 billion top-up this year
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam announced a S$1 billion top-up for the National Research Fund in Singapore's 2015 budget, aiming to enhance the economy's long-term potential through research and development investments.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open higher on tentative Greek deal
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened higher on Monday after eurozone ministers agreed to extend Greece's bailout by four months. London's FTSE 100 rose 0.40%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 increased 0.90%, and Paris's CAC 40 added 0.85%. The tentative deal lifted investor confidence and boosted markets.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Spending on continuing education to push average spending to S$1bn per year
summary: Singapore's government plans to increase spending on continuing education and training from S$600 million to S$1 billion per year by 2020 through its SkillsFuture initiative. Every Singaporean will receive a lifelong SkillsFuture credit to help pay for courses, with top-ups at regular intervals. The government will also top up the National Productivity Fund by S$1.5 billion this year to meet the increased expenditure.

images.alt_text: Spending on continuing education and training in Singapore will increase from about S$600 million per year over the last five years, to an average of over S$1 billion per year from now to 2020, Tharman Shanmugaratnam, Deputy Prime Minister, and Minister of Finance, said on Monday.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Stronger support for innovative SMEs
summary: Singapore's 2015 budget provides stronger support to small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) who innovate and venture abroad. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam announced the move to support SMEs in developing new processes, leveraging big data, and expanding internationally. The government aims to boost productivity and encourage innovation, with a focus on supporting SMEs beyond traditional norms.

site_title: Hot stock: Interest in NOL may continue on new development from West Coast ports
summary: Shares of Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) stabilized after surging due to its plans to divest its logistics business. However, the company's core liner business may experience a rebound due to a recent five-year contract deal between US West Coast dock workers and their employers, averting a shutdown that could have significantly impacted NOL's revenues. This development may offer traders a reason to bid up the stock again, according to CMC Markets analyst Nicholas Teo.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Infrastructure spending to grow by 50% to reach S$30b
summary: Singapore is set to invest S$30 billion in infrastructure by the end of the decade, a 50% increase from the current S$20 billion. This "major reinvestment" aims to meet the country's economic and social needs, with projects including Changi Airport's Terminal 5, public transport improvements, and healthcare expansions. The last significant infrastructure investment in proportion to GDP was in the 1990s, when the government developed Jurong Island and other major projects.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Jubilee Budget to tackle future challenges
summary: Singapore's Budget 2015 focuses on equipping the economy with future skillsets and securing retirement adequacy for its aging population. The SkillsFuture initiative, announced last year, aims to equip Singaporeans with employable skills, with details to be revealed in the budget. The government will also introduce the Silver Support Scheme to help needy elderly with insufficient retirement savings. Amid restructuring pains, the budget is expected to provide support for companies, including the Productivity and Innovation Credit scheme and the Wage Credit Scheme. The government has a fiscal surplus, estimated to be S$10-12 billion, allowing for increased expenditure on big-ticket items.

site_title: Honda, in unexpected move, says CEO Ito to step down
summary: Honda Motor Co announced that CEO Takanobu Ito will step down in late June, making way for Managing Officer Takahiro Hachigo. Hachigo, 55, has held various roles, including in the US, China, and Britain, and joined Honda in 1982. This move comes after Honda has faced quality issues and recalls of its popular Fit hybrid subcompact.

images.alt_text: Honda Motor Co, in an unexpected move, said on Monday that Chief Executive Officer Takanobu Ito would step down in late June, making way for Managing Officer Takahiro Hachigo after six years in the top post.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Citizens aged 25 and above to get S$500 in SkillsFuture Credit from 2016
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam announced that all Singaporeans aged 25 and above will receive an initial SkillsFuture Credit of S$500 from 2016, with further top-ups at regular intervals. The credits, which won't expire, can only be used for education and training.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Govt to phase out Transition Support Package
summary: Singapore will phase out the Transition Support Package (TSP) over time, starting with the Wage Credit Scheme (WCS), Corporate Income Tax (CIT) rebate, and Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) bonus. The TSP, which was initially estimated to disburse S$5.3 billion, is now expected to cost S$7.5 billion over three years. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam announced the plan to phase out the TSP, which was launched in 2013 to support businesses during the transition to a more dynamic economy.

site_title: Japan's ANA joins bid to rescue bankrupt Skymark Airlines
summary: Japan's All Nippon Airways (ANA) has joined a group of firms bidding to rescue bankrupt Skymark Airlines, which filed for bankruptcy protection in January due to a cancelled $2.2 billion jet order. ANA's rescue plan includes code-sharing and joint fuel procurement, while a Tokyo-based investment fund has agreed to extend a 9.0 billion yen loan. Other firms, including Orix and H.I.S., have also expressed interest in backing Skymark's rehabilitation. Skymark plans to present its rehabilitation plan to the Tokyo District Court by May 29.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Levy increases for S Pass, Work Permit Holders, to be deferred
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister, Tharman Shanmugaratnam, announced that the government will defer this year's round of levy increases for S Pass and Work Permit Holders in every sector. This decision comes after the significant slowdown in foreign workforce growth. The government cited this slowdown as an opportunity to adjust the pace of tightening measures, allowing for a more measured approach to managing the foreign workforce.

site_title: Seoul: Shares hit 2-1/2 mth high on Greece relief; won falls
summary: South Korean shares reached a 2-1/2 month high on Monday, closing at 1,968.39 points after a compromise deal between Greece and its creditors prevented a potential default. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rose 0.35%, while the South Korean won fell 0.85% against the dollar, reaching 1,108.7 per dollar. The decline in the won was attributed to investors playing catch-up to offshore rate falls during a recent holiday break.

site_title: Oil prices rebound in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices rebounded in Asia, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate (WTI) rising 7 cents to $50.88 and Brent crude gaining 14 cents to $60.36. The rebound follows a 4.66% decline in WTI and 2.1% drop in Brent last week. Analysts attribute the increase to speculative buying, but warn that the rebound is unlikely to hold due to a global oversupply of oil. A US oil refinery strike and increased production in Libya and Oman have contributed to the oversupply.

site_title: Greece debt wrangling hands surprise to euro bears
summary: The eurozone has shown resilience amid Greek debt wrangling, defying euro bears. Despite a provisional deal to extend Greece's bailout, the euro was headed for its best month since November against major peers. Strategists have maintained their year-end euro-dollar forecast, citing the European Union's strengthened institutions and regulations as a buffer against shocks. This is in contrast to 2010, when the EU was more vulnerable to market volatility, according to ANZ Bank New Zealand's senior currency strategist, Sam Tuck.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly higher on Greek debt deal
summary: Asian stocks rose Monday, driven by a Greek debt deal extension, with Tokyo's Nikkei up 0.81% and Sydney up 0.52%. The eurozone's conditional four-month bailout eased concerns over Greece's future. European finance ministers gave Athens until Monday to present proposals. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 reached fresh records on Wall Street.

site_title: S.Korea's Daebo International Shipping in court receivership
summary: South Korea's Daebo International Shipping Co Ltd filed for court receivership due to poor dry bulk market conditions, citing weaker demand from China and an oversupply of ships. This is the third known bulk shipper bankruptcy this month, following Winland Ocean Shipping Corp in the US and Copenship in Denmark. The Baltic dry index has slumped by nearly two-thirds in the past 15 months, reaching an all-time low. The industry downturn is attributed to the combination of lower steel demand in China and the huge volume of new tonnage coming on line.

site_title: Julianne Moore, Eddie Redmayne win Oscar's top awards
summary: Julianne Moore won the Oscar for Best Actress for her role in "Still Alice," her first Academy Award after four nominations. Eddie Redmayne won Best Actor for his portrayal of Stephen Hawking in "The Theory of Everything," his first Oscar and following Golden Globe and SAG wins. Both actors received widespread recognition for their performances, with Moore and Redmayne being favored to win after earlier award wins.

site_title: Japan's top union body aims for biggest pay rise in 20 years
summary: Japan's peak labor union body, Rengo, is seeking the largest pay rise in 20 years, aiming for a 4% increase in monthly wages, excluding overtime and bonuses. The proposed bump will consist of 2% for base pay and 2% linked to seniority or time served. The request is made amid 18 consecutive months of stagnant salaries, with inflation-adjusted wages dropping due to the government's economic stimulus measures. The union's president, Nobuaki Koga, believes a higher wage increase is necessary to boost real wages and prevent social chaos.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015: Focused on Singapore's future
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam announced Singapore Budget 2015 will focus on building the country's future, with major steps in four areas: investing in skills, restructuring the economy, investing in infrastructure, and strengthening retirement assurance. The budget aims to empower individuals to learn and develop throughout life, promote innovation and internationalization, and support the next generation of business successes.

site_title: Australia: Shares end 0.5% higher as banks support
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 5,908, driven by gains in financials, despite disappointing earnings from resources firms. Shares in Australian mining services firms fell after warning of revenue struggles due to declining commodity prices. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 0.09%. Analysts expect the market to trade around 5,650-5,750 points in the near-term.

site_title: Thailand jails two on royal insult charge
summary: Thailand has sentenced two individuals, Patiwat Saraiyaem and Porntip Mankong, to 2.5-year prison terms for insulting royalty in a university play. The convictions come amid a military junta's campaign to suppress perceived royal insults, amidst heightened anxiety over the health of King Bhumibol Adulyadej and royal succession. Thailand's lese-majeste law, the world's harshest, makes insulting the monarch or heir punishable by up to 15 years in prison. The pair were arrested last August over a satirical play and both admitted to the charges, leading to reduced sentences.

site_title: Korean tech startups offer life beyond Samsung
summary: South Korean tech startups are gaining popularity as a viable alternative to traditional conglomerates like Samsung and LG. With the government's push to foster a "creative economy," the number of new venture firms has more than doubled since 2009, reaching 30,053 in the latest data. Startups like StyleShare, created by 26-year-old Yoon Ja-Young, have found success with apps and websites, and the country's hyper-connected population provides fertile ground for tech businesses. However, challenges remain, including the need to expand internationally and the high stakes of failure in a society where experience counts.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks up 0.81% by break after Greek debt deal
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.81% by break on Monday, driven by a Greek debt deal extension that gave Athens four months of breathing room. The Nikkei 225 index gained 148.89 points to 18,481.19, while the Topix index of all first-section shares rose 0.46% to 1,507.23. Investors are in "risk-on mode," but analysts caution that Greece's problems will persist, potentially affecting the market in June.

site_title: Ringgit resumes drop as concern mounts on 1MDB debt obligations
summary: Malaysia's ringgit currency resumed its losses as markets reopened, falling 0.5% to 3.6388 USD due to concerns over 1Malaysia Development Bhd's (1MDB) debt obligations. The state investment company may require a 3 billion ringgit cash injection to repay borrowings, according to reports. 1MDB plans to seek refinancing from available sources, and the government is expected to be involved in the refinancing process to maximize shareholder value. The currency's drop has raised concerns about a potential government bailout, affecting the country's sovereign rating outlook.

site_title: Singapore Airlines ranked 19th in Fortune's '50 Most Admired Companies'
summary: Singapore Airlines dropped to 19th in Fortune's '50 Most Admired Companies' list, but remained the highest-ranked Asian company and the only one from Singapore. The airline ranked seventh in the industry list, with Delta Air Lines ranking first and Southwest Airlines ranking 39th. Fortune's survey was based on ratings from 668 companies across 29 countries, with a score in the top half of its industry required to be listed.

site_title: South Korea central bank chief says policy currently focused on growth
summary: South Korea's central bank chief, Governor Lee Ju-yeol, stated that the current monetary policy is focused on recovering economic growth rather than stabilizing inflation. This comment led to a rise in three-year treasury bond futures, with analysts expecting another interest rate cut. Lee emphasized the need for policies that stabilize markets and aid small to medium-sized companies, without specifying a direction for interest rates.

site_title: Gold near seven-week low after Greek debt deal
summary: Gold prices fell to a seven-week low at $1,201.98 an ounce after a deal was struck over Greece's debt, easing concerns about the safe-haven metal. The agreement removes the risk of Greece running out of money, allowing the new government to negotiate longer-term debt relief. A stronger US dollar and public holidays in China also put pressure on prices. Investors remain cautious about gold's price outlook, with hedge funds cutting their bullish stance for the third straight week.

site_title: Singapore inflation inches down to -0.4% in January
summary: Singapore's inflation eased to -0.4% in January, down from -0.1% in December, driven by sharp price declines in oil-related items, lower food, and services inflation. Private road transport cost fell 5.0% and accommodation cost declined 1.9%. Core inflation, excluding accommodation and transport costs, edged down to 1% from 1.5%. The decline was attributed to reduced electricity tariffs and lower inflation in these sectors.

images.alt_text: Singapore inflation eased to -0.4 per cent in January from -0.1 per cent in December, mainly due to a sharp price declines of oil-related items as well as lower food and services inflation.

site_title: 'Birdman' wins Best Picture, Best Director
summary: "Birdman" won the Oscar for Best Picture and Best Director, Alejandro González Iñárritu, at the 87th Academy Awards. The film, starring Michael Keaton, collected four awards, including Best Original Screenplay. The win marked a victory for smaller, artistically ambitious films over Hollywood's typical blockbuster fare. Iñárritu's career had stalled since 2006's "Babel," and the film's themes echoed his own personal struggles, with Keaton having once played Batman. The win was seen as a fitting victory for a film that challenged the industry's obsession with superhero films.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge closer to 7-year highs
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 5,909.3 points, edging closer to 7-year highs, despite weak earnings reports from resources and energy companies. The Dow and S&P500 ended at record highs on Friday after a Greek finance deal, boosting sentiment. Financials led gains, with high-dividend stocks like National Australia Bank and Westpac up 0.6%. Analysts expect modest returns over the next 12-18 months.

site_title: Nomura most bullish on Indonesia, Singapore developers in 2015
summary: Nomura is most bullish on Indonesian and Singapore property developers in 2015, citing better-than-expected marketing sales for Indonesian developers and lower prices in Singapore that will stimulate demand. Four stocks, including CapitaLand and City Developments, have seen consensus upward revisions and undemanding valuations, trading at discounts to historical averages. This optimism suggests potential policy easing in the second half of 2015 for Singapore developers.

site_title: China to launch test flights for C919 plane
summary: China's State-owned Commercial Aircraft Corporation of China (COMAC) has completed the basic assembly of its medium-range C919 large passenger aircraft and is expected to launch test flights this year. The aircraft has secured 450 orders from 18 customers, aiming to match Boeing and Airbus in the global market. COMAC is keen to prove China's capabilities in commercial aircraft development, overcoming past challenges related to inexperience and a shortage of local talent.

site_title: Asia: Stocks advance to five-month high after Greek bailout deal
summary: Asian stocks rose to a five-month high, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index gaining 0.1% to 145.21, after the US equity gauges reached records and Greece reached a provisional deal on its bailout program. Euro-area finance ministers agreed to keep aid flowing for four months in return for budget targets, giving investors time to work out longer-term financing details. The deal is subject to validation by the International Monetary Fund and the European Commission.

site_title: Kaisa creditors need to halt repayments, Sunac manager says
summary: Kaisa Group Holdings, a Chinese homebuilder, needs creditors to suspend payments to enable debt restructuring and avoid bankruptcy. A manager hired by the company's buyer, Sunac China Holdings, says that meeting interest and principal obligations could derail debt talks. Sunac has proposed a deal to buy Kaisa, but needs creditors to agree to a "satisfactory" resolution of debts. Kaisa faces $5.7 billion in repayments to creditors this year and has seen its debts more than double to $65 billion. A deal would need to balance the interests of creditors, minority shareholders, and Sunac, and could involve concessions from creditors.

site_title: Australian PM Abbott announces fresh security crackdown
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott announced a national security crackdown in response to a hostage siege in Sydney that left three dead in December. The measures include denying welfare payments to those seen as potential threats, stripping passports of dual nationals, and curtailing travel overseas. Abbott stated that some freedoms must be curtailed to combat the growing threat from radical groups such as Islamic State. New laws will target those who support radicals, including recipients of welfare and "hate preachers," and payments to individuals assessed as a threat to security could be cancelled.

site_title: Thailand's Central Group to invest US$1.14 billion in 2015
summary: Thailand's Central Group plans to invest US$1.14 billion in 2015, primarily expanding its businesses at home and in Southeast Asia. The conglomerate aims for 15% revenue growth to 287 billion baht, up from 6.6% in 2014. Central Group operates several retail businesses, including shopping malls, department stores, and hotels. The investment is part of the company's efforts to diversify and expand its presence in the region.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.14 points to 1,811.01 on Monday, driven by a higher volume of 80.45 million lots worth RM13.66 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 107 to 57, indicating a positive trading session.

site_title: Euro loses steam after rising on Greek debt deal as caution lingers
summary: The euro held steady at $1.1381 on Monday after initially rising in relief over a conditional loan extension deal for Greece, but lost steam as caution towards the debt saga persisted. Euro zone ministers agreed to extend Greece's financial rescue package by four months, with Greece required to submit a list of reforms and receive approval from the troika by April. The euro's gains were modest, and market players will be watching Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's testimony for hints on when the US central bank may begin raising rates.

site_title: S Korea central bank to beef up risk management to head off volatility
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, plans to strengthen its risk management processes to mitigate the impact of future financial crises. The bank will consider using its massive foreign reserves to stabilize local markets if global markets experience volatility, but will only do so in a crisis situation after assessing costs. The bank aims to maintain financial stability amid low confidence in the domestic economy, which is expected to improve as the global economy recovers. The Bank of Korea's Governor Lee Ju Yeol will address lawmakers' questions on the central bank's policy and economic issues.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.89% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.89% higher on Monday, following the eurozone's decision to extend Greece's bailout by four months. The Nikkei 225 index rose to 18,495.32, while US stocks also reached new highs, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 reaching record levels. The eurozone's agreement eases concerns over Greece's future in the eurozone, with the condition that Greece sets out key reform commitments by Monday.

site_title: China: Markets closed for holiday from Feb 18 to Feb 24
summary: China's stock, bond, foreign exchange, and commodity futures markets are closed from February 18 to 24 for the Lunar New Year holiday. Markets will resume trade on February 25. Meanwhile, global stock markets experienced volatility, with US stocks edging down from records amid tariff threats, and European stocks rising due to mining and healthcare sectors. US-EU trade talks remain a focus, while Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sarine Technologies, Noble, Wilmar, IFS Capital, Transcorp
summary: Sarine Technologies' Q4 FY14 net profit declined 12.8% to US$3.89 million due to lower gross margin and higher operating expenses. Noble Group clarified it does not plan to raise funds after being hit by a short attack. Wilmar International received the final regulatory approval for its Goodman Fielder acquisition. IFS Capital expects a higher loss for Q4 FY14 due to loan loss provisions. Transcorp Holdings' shares rose 49.6% on unusual trading activity.

site_title: Would you like some bacon to go with that?
summary: Little Caesars and Starbucks recently introduced new bacon-based menu items, including a deep-dish pizza wrapped in over three feet of bacon and a 540-calorie bacon breakfast sandwich. Despite a devastating 2014 for the pork industry due to a diarrhoea virus, pork prices have plummeted, leading analysts to predict more bacon debuts in restaurants. American bacon sales have soared for five straight years, reaching an all-time high of $4.4 billion in 2024, with over 864 million pounds sold. The pork industry sees no signs of a backlash, with bacon remaining a popular and indulgent treat.

site_title: Mercedes recalls 147,000 cars in US for engine fire risk
summary: Mercedes-Benz is recalling 147,000 mid-size sedans and station wagons in the US from 2013-2015 due to a risk of engine fires. The issue lies in a rubber seal that can fall onto the exhaust system, causing an under-hood fire. US dealers will notify owners and repair the cars in mid-March. This is part of a broader recall for similar issues in Europe and China, affecting 149,000 additional vehicles.

site_title: Modi bets on GM crops to boost farm output
summary: India's federal government has resumed field trials for genetically modified (GM) crops, reversing an earlier ban. The trials, led by scientists associated with the Indian Agricultural Research Institute, are focused on boosting farm productivity, particularly in edible oils and vegetables. The goal is to increase crop yields and meet the country's growing food demands. The trials are seen as crucial to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's goal of improving farm productivity, but have sparked opposition from grassroots groups and environmental groups like Greenpeace, who raise concerns about the potential risks to food safety and biodiversity.

site_title: US gas prices rise on strike, refinery outage: Lundberg survey
summary: US gas prices rose 13 cents over two weeks, increasing to $2.33 per gallon, after a nine-month slide ended in January. The surge is attributed to a steelworkers' strike and a refinery explosion in California, which halted production. Gasoline prices are down 26 cents from their lowest point, with the highest price recorded in Los Angeles at $2.91 per gallon and the lowest in Salt Lake City at $1.91 per gallon.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 16.94 points to 3,452.60 on Monday, driven by gains. The market saw 48.2 million shares traded worth S$111.5 million, with 104 gainers and 45 losers. This marks the third consecutive day of gains, ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Seoul: Shares touch 2-1/2 month high on Greek relief; won falls
summary: South Korean shares reached a 2-1/2 month high on Monday, driven by relief after Greece and its creditors agreed on a four-month bailout extension. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rose 0.34% to 1,968.06 points, surpassing its 120-day moving average. Gains were broad-based, with 15 of 17 major industry sectors trading in positive territory, led by Lotte Group's subsidiaries and insurance company. The South Korean won fell 0.7% against the US dollar.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks lower 0.46% in early trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.46% in early trade on Monday, following regional markets that rose due to an EU deal to avoid a Greek default. The benchmark Hang Seng Index dropped 114.03 points to 24,718.05. The decline reversed earlier gains.

site_title: BOJ under pressure as some board members question inflation target
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) faces pressure from some board members questioning its 2% inflation target due to a slowdown in underlying prices and falling oil prices. Despite keeping monetary policy steady, the BOJ's core consumer inflation projection for fiscal 2015 was cut to 1.0% from 1.7% due to the global oil price slump. Economists view the BOJ's timeline as too ambitious, and the central bank may need to reconsider its policy options later this year if inflation fails to accelerate.

images.alt_text: Three members of the Bank of Japan's policy board expressed doubts the central bank can meet its inflation target because of a slowdown in underlying prices and falling oil, pointing to chinks in the BOJ's strategy to spark sustainable growth.

site_title: Disney's Magic Kingdom one-day passes breach US$100 mark
summary: Disney's Magic Kingdom one-day passes have reached $105, becoming the first theme park to breach the $100 psychological barrier. All other Walt Disney parks in Orlando and California remain below $100, with Epcot, Animal Kingdom, and Hollywood Studios priced at $97. The price increase may impact attendance, but Disney benefits from stronger hotel and restaurant revenue. Other US theme parks, such as Universal and SeaWorld, have yet to reach $100. The price change is part of Disney's efforts to test triple-digit pricing, with the company's stock reaching record highs after recent quarterly results.

site_title: HK securities regulator in test case to wind-up China Metal Recycling
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) is set to wind up China Metal Recycling Holdings Ltd in a court case that tests laws to sanction mainland Chinese companies listed in its market. The SFC alleges China Metal Recycling (CMR) overstated its financial position, with 38% of its 2009 gross profits being fictitious. The move aims to recover value for shareholders and creditors, but reaching CMR's assets on the mainland will be difficult due to limited authority.
