The case could set a precedent for the SFC's ability to force rogue listed companies into liquidation, but a tougher battle ahead may involve securing CMR assets in China.

site_title: Mall of America patrons told to be careful on terror threat
summary: The US Homeland Security Secretary, Jeh Johnson, warned Mall of America patrons to be "particularly careful" after a video from the al-Shabaab terror group threatened attacks in Canada, the US, and the UK. The threat was made after the group attacked a shopping mall in Kenya in 2013, and authorities increased security at the Mall of America in Bloomington, Minnesota. There is no credible threat against the mall, and Johnson emphasized the importance of public awareness in enhancing security.

site_title: HSBC chief kept millions in Swiss account: report
summary: HSBC chief executive Stuart Gulliver kept approximately $7.6 million in a Swiss account in 2007, despite vowing to reform the scandal-hit bank. The account was held in the name of Worcester Equities Inc, a Panama-registered company, and Gulliver was listed as the beneficial owner. Gulliver's lawyers claim he used the account to hold bonus payments prior to 2003 and that Hong Kong tax had been paid on this income. The revelation comes ahead of HSBC's annual report and amid ongoing investigations by British and Swiss authorities.

site_title: Shipping delays to cost Honda 25,000 cars in Feb
summary: Honda Motor Co. expects to lose about 25,000 vehicles in February due to shipping delays caused by a labour dispute at US West Coast ports. The company has praised a tentative agreement between shipping companies and the International Longshore and Warehouse Union, which will end the dispute after nine months. The union ratification of the agreement will affect trade between Asia and 29 US West Coast ports.

site_title: China calls the shots in Asia's currency war
summary: China is under pressure to devalue its currency, the yuan, amid growing fears of a global currency war and deflationary forces in the region. Asian central banks, including Indonesia, Singapore, and India, have cut interest rates to spur growth, with China seen as a key factor in the region's policy making. A weaker yuan could boost China's export earnings, but analysts warn that it could also lead to capital outflows, property price collapses, and a vicious cycle of bad debts. China's central bank has allowed the yuan to gradually decline, but a devaluation is considered a low-probability but high-impact event.

site_title: Global dairy crisis simmers as supply overwhelms
summary: A global dairy crisis is ongoing due to oversupply and low international milk prices, down by around 50% since last year. China, a key market, has reduced demand, leading to excess milk powder stocks. Analysts predict the market won't improve until the spring, with some major players avoiding the international market this year. EU farmers are expanding production, but prices are still low, and Russia's food embargo has accelerated a decline in EU milk prices.

site_title: Global outlook improving but China slowdown among risks: IIF
summary: Global economic growth is expected to accelerate slowly this year and in 2016, with advanced nations outpacing emerging economies due to China's slowdown. The Institute of International Finance (IIF) flags concern over further turbulence in financial markets as the US Federal Reserve tightens interest rates. Lower oil prices are expected to contribute to global growth, with mature economies, such as the US and euro area, driving growth this year. Emerging economies, including India, are expected to lag but recover in 2016. The IIF warns of a risk of disorderly adjustment in financial markets, particularly in countries with weak macroeconomic policy frameworks.

site_title: Oversupply of ships and China slowdown send freight shipping prices to an all-time low
summary: Freight shipping prices have plummeted to a historic low, with the Baltic Dry Index (BDI) dropping to 509 points, its lowest level since 1985. The oversupply of ships and lower demand from China, particularly after Beijing removed an export tax rebate, have contributed to the decline. Experts caution against seeing this as a warning for the global economy, as the BDI is now considered a poor guide to the overall health of the world economy.

site_title: Oil and metal prices drift lower
summary: Commodity prices drifted lower last week due to supply and demand patterns, as well as uncertainty over Greece's eurozone future. Crude oil prices fell to US$60.69 a barrel, while gold dropped to US$1,208.25 an ounce. Metal prices also retreated, with copper, aluminum, and zinc prices declining. The US crude stockpiles offset weak Libyan supplies, and the threat from Islamist extremists in Libya is expected to tighten the oil glut.

site_title: American Express card rules violate US antitrust law: judge
summary: A US federal judge ruled that American Express Co. violated US antitrust law by prohibiting merchants from steering consumers to use lower-cost credit cards, dealing a second major setback for the company in February. The decision, made by Judge Nicholas Garaufis, was a victory for the US government and 17 states, which sued American Express in 2010 over allegations of anti-competitive practices. The judge found that American Express's rules imposed concrete harms on competition in the credit and charge card network services market, and he will decide on remedies later.

site_title: Arctic oil drilling firms face tougher US rules to stop spills
summary: The US Interior Department has proposed new Arctic oil drilling rules requiring companies to boost safety practices to prevent spills in the Arctic Ocean. The rules, which apply to Royal Dutch Shell and other oil drilling companies, mandate the use of specialized equipment, a backup rig, and containment domes, as well as halting drilling 45 days before the season ends. The proposal aims to address safety concerns following Shell's 2012 drilling mishaps, with public comment to begin in 60 days.

site_title: Snapshot of the Singapore economy
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to tackle future challenges with the introduction of the Jubilee Budget. The budget aims to address emerging issues such as sustainable aviation and advanced chip packaging. A new centre will be set up to advance sustainable aviation in the Asia-Pacific region. Additionally, the government is offering a grant of up to S$100,000 to businesses hit by tariffs. The budget also emphasizes the importance of workers future-proofing their careers to prepare for potential crises. These initiatives aim to drive growth and resilience in the Singapore economy.

site_title: Malaysian lenders look to Plan B after passing on three-way merger
summary: Malaysian lenders CIMB Group Holdings, RHB Capital, and Malaysia Building Society Bhd (MBSB) are shifting focus to alternative growth strategies for their Islamic businesses after scrapping a proposed three-way merger. The merger, worth US$190 billion, was scrapped due to weak economic conditions. MBSB plans to convert into a full-fledged Islamic lender, aiming to double its corporate loan book by 2020. CIMB and RHB have established Islamic units and are reviewing their operations to expand in Islamic finance, with CIMB seeking new sharia-compliant products and RHB aiming to double its sharia financing assets by 2017.

site_title: Time to answer questions about pay of directors
summary: A recent poll in Singapore found that 53% of Americans consider discussing individual director remuneration at a dinner party to be taboo, echoing similar discomfort around director remuneration disclosures in Singapore. Only 31% of listed companies disclosed directors' annual fees and remuneration in 2014, with average annual fees ranging from S$68,250 for non-executive directors to S$2,686,028 for executive directors. Companies need to recognize the importance of full disclosure, proof of pay-for-performance linkage, and responsible long-term incentives to maintain transparency and boost shareholders' confidence.

site_title: Japan Inc sees no need for 2% inflation or more easing: Reuters poll
summary: Japan Inc. is content with current inflation levels, with 70% of companies saying they see no need for additional monetary easing despite declining oil prices. A Reuters poll of 483 firms found that most want consumer inflation to be higher than 0.5%, but four-fifths are satisfied with levels under 2%. Analysts expect the Bank of Japan to increase stimulus later this year to support economic growth and inflation. BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda has softened the central bank's inflation target, citing the impact of oil price drops and a potential virtuous cycle for capital spending.

images.alt_text: Japan Inc sees no need for an aggressive pursuit of a 2 per cent inflation goal or additional monetary easing, a Reuters poll showed - a stance that supports the central bank's recent softer tone on achieving its consumer price target in the near future.

site_title: The hidden costs of being an Uber driver
summary: Uber drivers face significant financial costs, including the company's 20% commission, petrol, car maintenance, insurance, and taxes. The median income for UberX drivers is estimated to be around $19 per hour, requiring drivers to work over 80 hours a week to reach the $74,000 annual figure previously cited. As independent contractors, drivers are responsible for their own taxes, including self-employment income tax, Social Security, and Medicare taxes. Additionally, they must also pay for expenses such as car wear and tear, and may be required to purchase health insurance.

images.alt_text: A more recent study commissioned by Uber reported that the typical Uber X and Uber Black drivers make about US$19 an hour after paying Uber's 20 per cent commission.

site_title: Surge in secondary office space seen as tenants relocate
summary: Singapore's secondary office space is expected to increase by 680,000 sq ft this year, driven by tenants relocating from expiring leases. However, analysts say this surge is unlikely to add to the vacancy rate, citing healthy demand and outstripped supply. The increase in secondary space is a result of tenants seeking better technical specifications in newly completed office buildings. Analysts project a 1.5-2.5% increase in prime office rents and a 3-5% rise in Grade A rents, with rents expected to moderate in 2016 as new office space comes on stream.

site_title: Egyptian govt may launch IPO of Food Industries
summary: Egypt is considering listing state-owned Food Industries Holding Company in an initial public offering (IPO), which could raise between 3-4 billion Egyptian pounds (S$535-714 million). Supplies Minister Khaled Hanafi announced the plan, which would be a rare IPO of a government holding company.

site_title: No bubble in sight as Nasdaq nears its 15-year-old peak
summary: The Nasdaq Composite Index is near its 15-year-old peak, with analysts attributing its 125% rise over the last five years to the Federal Reserve's near-zero interest rates, maturation of technology companies, and the rise of Apple Inc. Unlike the dotcom bubble, fund managers see few signs of a bubble in technology stocks. The slowdown in initial public offerings and increased willingness to invest in startups have contributed to the rally. However, concerns remain about the aging of some of the largest companies in the Nasdaq, and investors are cautious despite the index's proximity to its all-time high.

site_title: Former Barclays brokers win case to keep US$4m in signing bonus
summary: A US arbitration panel has ruled in favor of two former Barclays stockbrokers, Ileana Platt and Rafael Urquidi, who sought to keep nearly US$4 million in signing bonuses. The panel rejected Barclays' claim, citing the firm's failure to meet its recruitment promises. The brokers alleged that Barclays reneged on its pledges when it stopped serving Latin American clients, leaving them stranded. The decision is a rare rebuke of a common practice among brokerage firms, where signing bonuses are structured as loans that must be repaid if the broker leaves before the loan term is over.

site_title: The problem with productivity and how to parse it out
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen will testifying before Congress this week, discussing the economy and potential rate increases. Economists project a 1.8-3% annual growth rate in productivity, which could influence the timing and pace of rate hikes. Productivity measures the economy's efficiency and affects standard of living, but its drivers, such as innovation and technology, are difficult to predict. Recent productivity growth has been sluggish, with output per hour rising by 0.6% in the last four years, and economists disagree on whether the US can recapture the vibrancy of the 1995-2004 period.

site_title: Tat Hong's third-gen strikes out
summary: Andrew Ng, the 32-year-old son of Tat Hong CEO Roland Ng, has established a family investment holding company called Triplestar. The company has invested around S$10 million in a healthcare clinic, a drillship builder, and a childcare center. Ng looks for established small to medium-sized enterprises to invest in, often to support companies facing succession issues or provide access to new markets. He prefers to invest in a more personal and family-oriented way after leaving investment banking in 2013.

site_title: Potash global price war looms as Belarus muscles in
summary: Belarus is escalating a global price war in the potash industry, threatening the market's stability, as the Eastern European country seeks to strengthen its share of the US$20 billion market. Belarus, which supplied 20% of global exports last year, is running mines at almost full capacity, offering lower prices in some regions. This move comes after Russia's PAO Uralkali unexpectedly terminated its relationship with Belarus's state-owned producer Belaruskali, which used to control 40% of exports. The price war is expected to continue, with Belarus offering discounted prices to China and Brazil, and other suppliers facing increased competition.

site_title: Food companies aim to reinvent diet foods
summary: US food companies are shifting away from weight-management foods as consumers prioritize simpler ingredients and healthier lifestyles. Brands such as Lean Cuisine, Healthy Choice, and Special K are rebranding with new products that focus on "healthy eating" and "healthy lifestyles". Companies like Nestle and Kellogg are introducing new ethnic flavors, higher protein content, and gluten-free options to cater to changing consumer preferences. However, experts caution that these changes may not necessarily lead to weight loss, as consumers may be seduced by the "health halo" of these products.

site_title: Greece scrambling to compile reforms list
summary: Greece's coalition government is racing against a Monday deadline to compile a list of economic reforms in exchange for a four-month extension of its bailout from the EU, ECB, and IMF. The reforms aim to address Greece's massive debt burden, high unemployment, and economic stagnation. Greek Premier Alexis Tsipras has promised to cancel austerity measures, but critics warn that the left-wing government's promises may not be enough to win over creditors, particularly Germany. The deadline comes as Greece's government debt has risen to 181% of GDP and the country faces a run on its banks.

site_title: Looking for upside in Europe
summary: The euro area's profit margins are at historical highs, with consumer discretionary, consumer staples, and telcos showing the best prospects as profit margins recover. However, disparities exist among sectors, with some having low margins. Factors affecting euro-area sector margins include low input costs, operating leverage, and lower interest rates. Companies with high fixed costs and robust expected sales growth, such as healthcare, consumer staples, and technology, are expected to benefit the most. A weaker euro will benefit sectors with high overseas contribution to total revenues, including consumer discretionary, industrials, IT, and healthcare.

site_title: Labour deal in US averts shutdown of 29 West Coast ports
summary: US West Coast dockworkers and employers have reached a five-year contract deal, averting a shutdown of 29 ports that could have cost the US economy $2 billion a day. The deal includes a compromise on arbitrator firing, allowing a panel to hear grievances instead of a single arbitrator. The agreement brings an end to a nine-month standoff that reduced productivity by as much as half and caused significant economic disruption, including delayed shipments of citrus fruit, Mardi Gras beads, and vital car parts. The deal is expected to have a significant impact on the US economy, particularly for workers, farmers, and businesses affected by the dispute.

site_title: New York hotel glut leading to slowdown in room-rate hikes
summary: New York City's hotel construction surge, resulting in a 21% increase in room count over the past five years, is slowing room-rate hikes. The city's hotel supply has reached over 100,000 rooms, with 27,000 more planned or under construction, putting pressure on prices. As a result, room rates are expected to rise only 1.5% in 2015, compared to 7.5% in San Francisco and 5.2% nationwide. Companies like Hilton Worldwide Holdings and Hyatt Hotels Corp are anticipating challenges in the market due to the increased supply.

site_title: UOB marks SG50 with painting
summary: UOB has created a painting to commemorate SG50, using contemporary Chinese brush ink and traditional rice paper canvas. The 1.5m-by-1m painting depicts the Singapore River and Boat Quay, where the country's economic growth began. Proceeds from the auction will be donated to the BT Budding Artists Fund and Sage Counselling Centre, with UOB initially pledging S$250,000. The goal is to raise S$500,000, with the auction taking place at the bank's Chinese New Year dinner on Feb 24.

site_title: Sri Lanka mulls future of ex-leader's white elephants
summary: Sri Lanka's new government is considering the future of several white elephant projects initiated by former president Mahinda Rajapakse, including a US$210 million airport, a US$361-million Chinese-funded harbour, and a US$15.5 million conference centre. The projects, which were built to boost Rajapakse's rural constituency, are now saddled with loans of nearly a billion dollars and are unlikely to generate significant returns. The government plans to sort out the loans and keep the projects open, but will likely write off investments and focus on repaying debts over time.

site_title: Euro area banks eye mergers as new rules close in
summary: Euro area banks are considering mergers as profits decline and regulatory requirements increase. The European Central Bank's new rules aim to make banks stronger, but may inadvertently encourage consolidation. Euro-zone banks have significant assets, but low profitability, with average returns on assets less than 0.1%. The ECB's stress test identified 25 failing banks, and Italy's government has approved a decree to convert cooperative lenders into joint-stock companies, making them more attractive to investors. Potential merger targets include Italian banks Banca Monte dei Paschi and Commerzbank, with a possible three-way combination in Italy and a deal between Commerzbank and ING Groep NV in Germany.

images.alt_text: New rules intended to make European banks stronger may end up encouraging them to get bigger, too.

site_title: CapitaLand engages community with new campaign
summary: CapitaLand has launched a new campaign "A Stage for Life" to reinforce its commitment to the community, focusing on building people and communities. The campaign will be launched this year with charity walk events and a digital campaign #BuildSG2065, allowing the public to submit ideas on Singapore's architectural landscape 50 years in the future. The company will also donate over 500 artefacts from the Raffles Hotel Museum Collection to the National Collection. The charity walk will allow participants to "earn" donations for selected charities, with a budget commitment of over S$2 million.

site_title: Dividend growth will underpin US equity outlook
summary: US stocks are expected to continue their upward trend driven by sustained dividend growth. The S&P 500 Index is forecast to exceed 2,400 by 2017, with dividend growth projected to remain at double-digit levels. This is attributed to the unique financial climate, where income assets are in high demand and capital is chasing limited income. The US equity market has consistently offered high dividend growth, making it an attractive asset class in the current environment.

site_title: Plan to help Croatians with Swiss franc mortgages
summary: Croatia's banking association proposes a plan to help Croatians with Swiss franc mortgages they can no longer afford. The plan would allow mortgage holders to transfer their properties to the state, becoming tenants, with the banks covering the costs of debt relief. Mortgage holders would have the option to buy back the properties at a discounted price or give back the keys in exchange for a debt write-off. This measure aims to address the issue of 60,000 Croatians holding Swiss franc loans, mostly for housing, and totaling 27 billion kuna (S$5.41 billion).

site_title: Purchase of Salix adds gastrointestinal drugs to Valeant stable
summary: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International Inc agreed to buy Salix Pharmaceuticals Ltd for about US$10.1 billion, adding gastrointestinal drugs to its portfolio. The deal, valued at US$158 per share, marks a comeback for Valeant after a failed bid for Allergan Inc last year. Salix, which treats ulcerative colitis and travellers' diarrhoea, will restate its 2013 and 2014 results due to accounting issues. The acquisition is part of Valeant's strategy to slash research and development costs to boost profits.

images.alt_text: Valeant is a serial acquirer, using an advantageous tax structure to make purchases and then slashing research and development costs to boost profits; before Salix, Valeant had completed US$19.2 billion of deals in the past five years, including the purchase of Bausch & Lomb Inc in 2013.

site_title: Swollen US meat inventories mirror demand headwinds
summary: US meat inventories reached record highs in January due to decreased demand on the West and East Coasts. Pork inventories surged 18% to 596.5 million pounds, while beef stocks reached a record 490.9 million pounds. Chicken inventory also rose 6% to 730.1 million pounds. Analysts attribute the increase to difficulties in moving meat off the West Coast, which has been disrupted by a labor dispute. This could keep domestic meat prices in check until the backlog is cleared, potentially taking several weeks or months.

site_title: Fight with Uber is a personal one for its German nemesis
summary: Berlin taxi drivers, led by Richard Leipold, are fighting against Uber's rise, claiming the ride-hailing service is breaking local laws and stifling competition. Leipold, who has driven a cab since 1973, estimates he has carried over 100,000 passengers and owns eight cars. He has spearheaded a lawsuit against Uber, threatening to shut down the service in the city. The stakes are high, as taxi driving can provide a ticket to Europe's middle class and homeownership. Uber argues that the current system creates a monopoly, but Leipold sees it as a personal attack on his livelihood and that of his fellow drivers.

site_title: Venezuelans face acute shortage of basic necessities amid oil rout
summary: Venezuela faces an acute shortage of basic necessities, including milk, toilet paper, and soap, due to the country's economic crisis. The government, led by President Nicolas Maduro, blames businesses for the shortages, claiming they are trying to "wage economic war" against him. However, many businesses argue that the government's economic controls have hurt them. The inflation rate soared to 68.5% last year, and shortages have become a daily reality, with some people paying others to wait in line for essential items. The government has restricted news coverage of the shortages, exacerbating the situation.

site_title: Deutsche Bank, Santander may fail Fed stress tests: report
summary: Deutsche Bank AG and Banco Santander SA may fail Federal Reserve stress tests of their US operations due to inadequate risk measurement processes. Deutsche Bank Trust Corp, a unit of Deutsche Bank, will likely receive a warning about its processes, while Santander's US unit may also fail despite adequate capital. If they fail, the US units may be restricted from paying dividends to their European parents or shareholders. This is the second straight failure for Santander's US unit, following last year's rejection of Royal Bank of Scotland Group and HSBC Holdings' US units.

site_title: Stolen SIM keys are powerful spy tools for US, UK agencies
summary: The US and British spy agencies allegedly hacked into European SIM card manufacturer Gemalto to gain encryption keys for a large share of mobile phones, allowing them to secretly monitor global communications without warrants or wiretaps. Experts warn this could be a "scorched earth policy" where all encryption keys are compromised, putting the privacy of millions worldwide at risk.

images.alt_text: One security firm founder said that the revelations could end up hurting manufacturers or carriers if they fail to take steps to correct any security weaknesses.

site_title: EU court to rule on ECB challenge to UK clearing
summary: The European Union's top court will rule on the European Central Bank's challenge to the UK's clearing houses, which could reduce London's role as the bloc's top financial centre. The ECB argues that clearing houses handling more than 5% of euro-denominated securities should be based in the single currency area. If the ECB prevails, clearers may be forced to relocate, potentially fueling euroscepticism in Britain and impacting the country's EU membership referendum in 2017.

site_title: Buying increases, selling remains low
summary: In the Singapore Exchange (SGX), buying activity increased while selling remained low during the holiday-shortened week of Feb 16 to 18. Nine companies made 16 purchases worth S$22.8 million, while one company made one disposal worth S$0.26 million. The buying was driven by companies that recently announced earnings results, including Pacific Century Regional Developments, Sembcorp Marine Limited, and Goodland Group. Insider purchases were also reported, with notable buys by Perennial Real Estate Holdings, Oxley Holdings, and Artivision Technologies. The buyback activity was sharply up from the previous week, with seven companies posting 18 repurchases worth S$10.1 million.

site_title: Restructuring for the next lap
summary: Tat Hong Holdings, a crane supplier, is restructuring amid a slowdown in its major Australia and Singapore markets. Revenue fell 7% to S$154.9 million and net profit dropped 63% to S$4.5 million in the third quarter. The company is selling assets, shifting operations to other countries, and focusing on areas like China, where it is growing. Tat Hong CEO Roland Ng aims to "get rid of baggage" and "run further" as the company looks to reposition itself for the next lap.

site_title: Nestle plans to hike work hours for Swiss staff
summary: Nestle plans to increase working hours for its Swiss staff, aiming to boost productivity amid the Swiss franc's surge in value following the central bank's removal of its cap. The company's director for Europe, Luis Cantarell, mentioned an increase from 42 to 44 hours, but not paying wages in euros, even for workers commuting from neighboring euro zone countries. This move aims to protect profits from the strong franc currency, which has raised concerns about Switzerland's export-reliant economy.

site_title: Eyes on Yellen's testimony on state of US economy
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen will testify before the Senate and House of Representatives on the state of the US economy, with market attention focusing on interest rates. Despite the recent strong January employment report, markets are pricing in no first rate hike until September, but Fed talk keeps alive the possibility of a first move by midyear. Yellen must balance a hawk/dove split within the Fed without shocking Wall Street. Meanwhile, Greece's issues remain unresolved, with officials needing to draw up a list of acceptable reforms by Monday, and the matter of financing Greece beyond June still pending.

site_title: US stock market could see big gains in 2015
summary: The US stock market may experience significant gains in 2015, with the S&P 500 potentially surpassing its average annual return of 7%. This year marks the sixth consecutive year without a 20% correction, making it ripe for a bull market. Historically, the "goat" animal spirit, which includes 1979, 1991, and 2003, has seen positive returns in 78% of instances since 1900. Factors such as the success of the Greek deal and central-bank policy will influence the market's trajectory, with some strategists predicting a rate hike and its impact on the market.

site_title: Japan January inflation seen easing; factory output to rise
summary: Japan's core inflation is seen slowing for a sixth month in January, with a 0.3% year-on-year increase, far from the Bank of Japan's 2% target. Despite this, factory output is expected to rise 2.7% in January, driven by a recovery in exports and capital spending. The Bank of Japan is counting on exports to offset weak private consumption and low oil prices. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda has expressed no immediate need to ease policy, citing steady progress towards the 2% target.

site_title: Internet providers, advocacy groups say proposed US rules are too vague
summary: The US Federal Communications Commission is set to vote on new rules for high-speed Internet service, which include a "general conduct" provision aimed at ensuring net neutrality. However, internet providers and advocacy groups criticize the provision as too vague, arguing it could lead to costly litigation and stifle investment. The FCC will review potential violations based on seven elements, including impact on competition, innovation, and free expression, but details of these criteria remain unclear. The rules' vagueness has drawn criticism from both sides, with some arguing it could require companies to consult the FCC for every new service.

site_title: Outgoing Fed official warns of danger of verbal mishaps
summary: Outgoing US Federal Reserve President Charles Plosser warns that verbal missteps by the Fed may lead to a volatile market reaction when raising interest rates, potentially causing snap-backs. He believes the gap between market expectations and Fed forecasts is "not trivial" and that the Fed needs to effectively communicate its intentions to avoid volatility. Plosser suggests that the Fed may need to address its "patient" language to signal a more aggressive series of rate hikes, potentially sooner than expected, to close the gap between market and Fed expectations.

site_title: HK delegates seek mainland security laws to counter protests
summary: Two Hong Kong delegates to China's parliament are pushing to implement mainland security laws to counter protests. The proposal, sparked by the "Occupy Central" protests, aims to address foreign intervention and secession. The move comes after pro-democracy activists and politicians were infuriated by Beijing's refusal to grant a fully democratic election for Hong Kong's leader in 2017. The proposal faces opposition, but the annual National People's Congress meeting is scheduled to begin in March, allowing the proposal to be considered.

site_title: Prada to watch costs after 2014 sales drop
summary: Prada reported a 1% dip in annual revenue to 3.55 billion euros (US$4 billion) in the financial year ended Jan 31, due to declining sales in Greater China and Europe. Despite opening more than 50 new shops, the company's retail sales were broadly unchanged year-on-year. Prada attributed the decline to a "more uncertain and complex" environment, particularly in Hong Kong and Macau, and vowed to contain costs to protect profit margins. The company plans to open fewer shops than initially planned in 2015.

site_title: Tough job for Petronas new boss
summary: Petronas' new boss, Shamsul Azhar Abbas, sparked controversy with his views on meritocracy and the distribution of oil resources in Malaysia. His comments were seen as out of line with the state's favoritism towards ethnic Malays, challenging the country's powers-that-be. Abbas' stance resonated with a larger swathe of Malaysians, but his position as the chief of Petronas, the country's largest contributor to government coffers, added to the criticism. His views remain a subject of debate in Malaysia.

site_title: Taking heart
summary: M1 launches a S$200,000 annual fund to support students from low-income families at 10 primary schools. The telco's first financial aid fund aims to provide supplementary support. Meanwhile, Love from the STARS charity gala will raise S$6 million for local charities on May 10, featuring international stars. The THK Charity Buddha Donation Drive collected S$200,000, supporting self-funded programmes serving 44,300 people. Singapore aims to sign a carbon credits transfer agreement with its first Asean country by end-2025, amid efforts to increase carbon offsetting legislation and sustainable investments.

site_title: US West Coast ports begin tackling backlog after deal
summary: US West Coast ports resumed full operations after a tentative labour deal was reached between the International Longshore and Warehouse Union and a group of shippers, easing months of disruptions to trans-Pacific trade. The deal, announced on Friday, was reached after nine months of negotiations and is subject to ratification by the union and shipping lines. The agreement aims to clear the backlog of cargo containers, estimated to take six to eight weeks, and restore normal freight traffic. The White House called the deal "a huge relief" for the economy and businesses, with President Obama urging cooperation to clear the port backlogs.

site_title: High-frequency trader Virtu Financial files for IPO again
summary: Virtu Financial, a high-frequency trading firm, has filed a new prospectus for an initial public offering (IPO) to raise $100 million, according to a US regulatory filing. The company plans to list on Nasdaq and will be controlled by its founder Vincent Viola. Virtu made $723 million in revenue and $190 million in net income in 2014, with only one losing day in its six-year operation. The company's strategies aim to lock in returns through precise hedging, and it claims to be profitable every day despite losing a small percentage of trades.

site_title: Petrobras refinery cracker unit should be fixed by March 7: union
summary: Brazil's state-run oil company Petrobras plans to complete repairs to a broken catalytic cracking unit at its REDUC refinery by March 7, according to the union representing workers. The unit, which produces gasoline and liquefied petroleum gas, was shut down unexpectedly on February 9 due to problems and a leak of catalysts. The stoppage forced Petrobras to cut oil processing by about 7,000 cu m a day for over 10 days. The repairs were reportedly planned, but the company has declined to disclose the duration of the work.

site_title: Google to offer children-friendly YouTube Kids app
summary: Google to launch YouTube Kids app, a children-friendly platform featuring age-appropriate videos, channels, and playlists, starting February 23. The app will include parental controls for time, sound, and searches. Partners include DreamWorks TV, National Geographic, and The Jim Henson Co. The move aims to expand YouTube's audience beyond adults, following the acquisition of Launchpad Toys Inc. and the launch of the Toontastic storytelling tool. The app will be available on Android devices in the US through the Google Play store.

site_title: Euro fluctuates as Greece still has hurdles to clear
summary: The euro fluctuated between gains and losses after a finance ministers' agreement to keep Greece's bailout funds flowing in exchange for economic reform conditions. The agreement, set to be approved by the "Troika" on Monday, aims to keep Greece afloat as it faces a potential cash shortage by next month. The euro rose 0.1% to $1.1381, while hedge funds cut bearish bets on the euro against the US dollar. A Greek official confirmed that tax increases and pension cuts had been averted in the accord, potentially freeing up funds to meet election pledges.

site_title: Fresh nuclear leak detected at Fukushima plant
summary: A fresh leak of highly radioactive water has been detected at the Fukushima nuclear plant, with contamination levels up to 70 times greater than usual. The leak, detected by sensors, prompted Tokyo Electric Power Co (Tepco) to shut the gutter that pours rain and ground water into the Pacific Ocean. The incident is the latest challenge in decommissioning the crippled plant, which suffered meltdowns and explosions after a tsunami in 2011. The International Atomic Energy Agency has previously suggested discharging treated waste water into the sea as a safer way to deal with the crisis.

site_title: Luxury carmakers leave their marque beyond just wheels
summary: Luxury carmakers, including Bentley, Ferrari, Porsche, Lamborghini, and Maserati, are expanding their product lines to include goods unrelated to cars, such as fragrances, furniture, skis, and hotel suites. This strategy helps retain customer loyalty, capture aspirational buyers, and capitalize on the booming luxury market. Brands like Porsche and Ferrari have successfully integrated their luxury lifestyle with their automotive products, while others, like Bentley, are cautious not to overextend their branding. By keeping prices high and retail outlets limited, luxury carmakers maintain their exclusive appeal and exclusivity, with Ferrari and Porsche Design serving as notable exceptions.

images.alt_text: Rodney Foster gets cosy at the driver's seat of his Bentley while wearing shirts sold by the carmaker. "Bentley represents a lifestyle," he said. Several luxury carmakers, including Bentley, have been expanding the lines of goods they sell that have little to do with cars. Bentley also lends its name to furniture, skis, handbags and hotel suites.

Rodney Foster gets cosy at the driver's seat of his Bentley while wearing shirts sold by the carmaker. "Bentley represents a lifestyle," he said. Several luxury carmakers, including Bentley, have been expanding the lines of goods they sell that have little to do with cars. Bentley also lends its name to furniture (above), skis, handbags and hotel suites.

site_title: Spain to speed up visa approvals for Chinese tourists
summary: Spain is speeding up visa approvals for Chinese tourists, aiming to tap into the growing Chinese market. The move comes after Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy announced in 2015 that visa applications from China would be processed within 48 hours. To boost traffic, the government is also negotiating with airlines to offer reduced fees and promoting Spain as a hub for travel to Latin America.

site_title: US oil-worker union widens biggest plant strike since 1980
summary: The United Steelworkers union, representing 30,000 US oil workers, has called for a nationwide strike at 12 refineries and 3 other facilities, the largest strike since 1980. The union, which includes workers at 200 refineries, fuel terminals, pipelines, and chemical plants, has rejected seven contract offers from Royal Dutch Shell Plc, which represents companies including Exxon Mobil and Chevron. The strike, which began on February 1, aims to address safety concerns and prevent fatigue among workers. The union's president, Leo Gerard, said the industry's refusal to address safety issues led to the expansion of the strike.

site_title: How Oscars number-crunchers keep winners secret
summary: PriceWaterhouseCoopers accountants Brian Cullinan and Martha Ruiz will keep the winners of the Oscars secret for two days, tallying up the votes of the 6,100 Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences (AMPAS) members. They print out all the results for security and memorize the winners by heart as a double fail-safe. The results will be finalized and placed in briefcases escorted by armed guards until the ceremony on Sunday evening, when only they will know the winners of the 24 categories, including the coveted best picture award.

site_title: Google's YouTube to launch subscription music service in 'few months'
summary: Google's YouTube is set to launch a paid monthly subscription service called YouTube Music Key in a few months, according to Robert Kyncl, the head of content and business operations. The company is fine-tuning the experience before the launch, which aims to provide users with ad-free music streaming and exclusive content.

site_title: Jubilee Budget to tackle future challenges
summary: Singapore's Budget 2015 aims to equip the economy with skills for the future and secure retirement adequacy for a rapidly aging population. The SkillsFuture drive, announced last August, will provide Singaporeans with employable skills and a roadmap for sector-focused frameworks. The government will also introduce the Silver Support Scheme, a S$8 billion package for needy elderly people, and consider changes to the Central Provident Fund (CPF) scheme. Amid restructuring pains and low productivity, the Budget is expected to feature expansionary measures, including enhanced support for companies and a more selective approach to assistance.

site_title: IS expands to Libya
summary: The Islamic State (IS) has expanded its presence to Libya, seizing territory and oil reserves in the North African country. Following Muammar Gaddafi's ouster in 2011, IS has become a major player in the lawless nation, where rival governments and militias are battling for control. The group has claimed responsibility for attacks, including a car bombing that killed 40 people, and has set up training camps and a headquarters in the eastern town of Derna. The US and other Western countries have ruled out military action, instead seeking a political solution to address the growing threat.

site_title: US refinery strike widens to include Shell JV
summary: US refinery workers on strike for 20th day, joining picket lines at the nation's largest refinery, with 15 plants affected, including 12 refineries with 5th of US crude processing capacity. The strike, led by the United Steelworkers union, seeks improved wages and safety. This is the largest refining sector strike since 1980, with companies relying on temporary workers to maintain operations. The stoppages have forced companies to rely on trained temporary workers to keep plants running close to normal.

images.alt_text: Strikes are underway or have been called at 15 US plants, including 12 refineries.

site_title: Taking on Qualcomm in China gives Ceva a boost
summary: Ceva Inc, a chip design company, is seeing a boost in its stock price after successfully catering to Chinese customers, particularly those using its technology in low-end phones. The company's revenue rose 4% in 2014, its first increase since 2011, and its share price has climbed 52% since October. Ceva is targeting the Chinese market, where Qualcomm, the world's largest mobile phone-chip maker, dominates. However, Chinese chip designers using Ceva's technology are poised to take market share from Qualcomm, which was fined $975 million by Chinese antitrust regulators.

site_title: A good year for the sure-footed
summary: Key industries and experts discuss the outlook for 2015 in Singapore and the Asean region. Neeraj Swaroop, CEO of Standard Chartered Bank Singapore, sees strong potential for wealth management and investment products due to the rising middle class and internationalisation of the Chinese renminbi. Jarek Ziebinski, CEO of Leo Burnett Asia-Pacific, emphasizes the need for integrated communications companies with data-driven creativity. Lim Soon Hock, Managing Director of PLAN-B ICAG Pte Ltd, expects challenges but sees opportunities for business acceleration and turnaround. Experts in human resources, law, IT, and logistics also share their outlooks, with a focus on talent management, regional integration, innovation, and customer experience.

site_title: History through a Budget lens
summary: Singapore's 2015 budget focuses on advancing sustainable aviation, with a new centre set up in the Asia-Pacific region. Employment rates for graduates are also improving, with early data showing better job prospects. The government aims to establish Singapore as a global hub for advanced chip packaging. Additionally, the budget includes a new grant of up to S$100,000 for businesses affected by tariffs, and offers support for workers who need to future-proof their careers. The government also emphasizes the importance of staying calm during economic crises, with resources available to help workers and businesses.

site_title: Oil prices fall in New York
summary: Oil prices in New York fell to near the $50 dollar line, with West Texas Intermediate settling at $50.32 a barrel, down 82 cents from Thursday. Brent crude in London remained flat at $60.22 a barrel. US and Canadian output rose despite weak market conditions, contributing to the gap between the two benchmarks. Analysts attribute the market pressure to stress on Brent-related crude, while expecting overall demand to decline due to refinery adjustments.

site_title: US, Latin America worry over Venezuela tensions
summary: US and Latin American nations express concern over Venezuela's arrest of Mayor Antonio Ledezma, accusing the government of using intimidation to divert attention from its economic challenges. Ledezma was detained on alleged involvement in a coup plot, with Maduro claiming it was financed by the US. The US condemned the arrest, saying it undermines democratic dissent. Regional leaders, including Chile's President Michelle Bachelet and Colombia's President Juan Manuel Santos, also voiced concern, calling for respect for human rights and due process.

site_title: Greece working out reforms to keep bailout alive
summary: Greece is racing against time to finalize reform proposals to keep its loan lifeline open under an EU debt deal. The hard-left government has until Monday to convince European creditors that it can implement credible fiscal reforms, which will take the struggling Greek economy "out of sedation." The government has proposed measures to make the Greek civil service more effective and combat tax evasion, but critics say the deal has compromised Greece's anti-austerity ambitions and will lead to a four-month extension of its debt bailout, with no new money to tide it over.

site_title: Moody's downgrades Russia debt to 'junk' level
summary: Moody's downgraded Russia's debt to 'junk' level, citing a deep recession in 2015 and continued contraction in 2016 due to the Ukraine crisis and falling oil prices. The rating cut to Ba1, from Baa3, reflects diminishing government fiscal strength and rising risk of capital flight. Moody's warns of constrained domestic demand and exacerbation of Russia's chronic underinvestment. The downgrade follows a week of fighting in Ukraine and criticism from the US, which accuses Russia of undermining the global order.

images.alt_text: Moody's cut Russia's debt rating by one notch into 'junk' territory Friday, saying the Ukraine crisis and the fall in oil prices and the rouble will further undermine Russia's economy.

site_title: Layoffs spark General Motors strike in Brazil
summary: General Motors workers in Brazil went on strike after 794 staff were suspended and offered temporary layoffs, with the union rejecting the proposal. The 3,000 workers at the Sao Jose dos Campos plant in southeastern Sao Paulo state downed tools in protest, and 2,000 afternoon shift workers were set to decide if they would join the stoppage. The strike is a response to GM's ultimatum, despite previous agreements to retain personnel. The dispute follows a similar strike by Volkswagen workers in the same region last month, which was also over planned layoffs.

site_title: FDA issues warning on scopes after 'superbug' outbreak
summary: The FDA has issued a warning to doctors and hospitals about the difficulty in sanitizing duodenoscopes, which have been linked to a 'superbug' outbreak in California, killing two patients and infecting nearly 200 others. The devices, used to drain fluids from pancreatic and bile ducts, are prone to bacterial contamination due to their intricate design. This is the latest in a string of lethal superbug episodes linked to the scopes, following similar outbreaks at hospitals in Chicago and Seattle. The FDA has received at least 75 reports of incidents involving over 135 patients.

site_title: Contract negotiators for US West Coast ports reach tentative deal: source
summary: Contract negotiators for US West Coast ports reached a tentative deal with shipping companies and terminal operators, ending a nine-month labor dispute that caused cargo backups and snarled trans-Pacific trade. The deal, brokered by US Labor Secretary Thomas Perez, was reached after the US economy was at risk of billions of dollars in losses. The 20,000 dockworkers will receive a new five-year labor contract, with terms to be ratified by both parties. The settlement aims to clear the backlog of cargo containers and restore normal freight traffic, which had been delayed by up to two weeks.

images.alt_text: Shipping companies and terminal operators reached a tentative deal on Friday with the International Longshore and Warehouse Union on a new contract for 20,000 dockworkers at 29 US West Coast ports, capping months of contentious labor talks, a source close to the negotiations told Reuters.

site_title: Car battery maker sues Apple for 'poaching' staff
summary: Apple has been sued by A123 Systems, a car battery developer, for allegedly poaching five employees with non-compete clauses in their contracts. The lawsuit claims Apple's "Titan" project, which reportedly involves hiring hundreds of people, is a car that incorporates iPhone and iPad technology. Analysts believe an "iCar" is unlikely but suggest Apple may work on an improved technology platform for connected vehicles. Apple has not commented on the lawsuit or the project.

site_title: BP loses bid to cap fine for oil spill
summary: US District Judge Carl Barbier rejected BP's bid to cap the maximum civil fine for the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill, leaving BP potentially liable to pay $13.7 billion under the Clean Water Act. The judge agreed with the federal government that the maximum civil penalty is $4,300 per barrel spilled, despite BP's argument that the 1990 Clean Water Act capped fines at $3,000 per barrel. The decision sets the stage for the final step in the civil trial, determining the amount BP must pay.

site_title: Indonesia recalls envoy to Brazil amid row over execution
summary: Indonesia has recalled its ambassador to Brazil after Brazil postponed a ceremony sealing the appointment amid a row over the execution of a Brazilian national for drugs trafficking. Indonesia's President Joko Widodo has pledged no clemency for drug offenders, despite pleas from several countries. The move follows a diplomatic spat with Australia over the fate of two Australian members of the "Bali Nine" drug trafficking ring set to be executed this month. Indonesia also withdrew its ambassador from the Netherlands due to the execution of two of its citizens.

site_title: Saudi king in post-coronation giveaway
summary: Saudi King Salman has announced a post-coronation giveaway worth an estimated $32 billion to ordinary Saudis, including bonuses, investments, and grants to various organizations. The move has boosted consumer spending and helped to alleviate concerns over the kingdom's economic uncertainty. However, analysts warn that the government's reliance on oil revenue and the drop in global prices may lead to a record deficit of $44.5 billion in 2015. The move has been welcomed by Saudis, who view the royal largesse as part of a social contract between rulers and loyal citizens.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P hit records after Greece earns bailout extension
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 hit new records on February 20, 2015, after eurozone ministers agreed to extend Greece's bailout by four months. The Dow gained 154.67 points, while the S&P 500 rose 12.85 points. The bailout, which removes the threat of a Greek default, was met with cautious optimism from analysts, who noted a lingering cloud over the eurozone.

site_title: Quick fix-its
summary: Express treatments in the aesthetics industry offer quick, fuss-free options for busy individuals. CryoSculpt Body Slimming and Tightening uses fat cavitation and radio frequency treatment to reduce fat and tighten skin, with average shrinkage of 1.5 to 4 inches. The "Hollywood Facial" combines microdermabrasion, laser genesis, and glycolic peel to rejuvenate and repair skin. V-Shape Facial Contouring with Botulinum Toxin A injections creates a slimming and shaping effect by inactivating masseter muscles. Prices range from S$230 to S$680 per session, with treatments recommended every 3-6 months for optimal results.

site_title: Sri Lanka mulls future of white elephants
summary: Sri Lanka's new government is considering the future of a string of white elephants, including a multimillion-dollar airport and a lavish cricket stadium, built by former President Mahinda Rajapakse to boost his rural constituency. The projects, which were largely funded by loans, have failed to attract airlines and players, resulting in significant losses. The government estimates it needs to repay over $1 billion in loans, with Deputy Minister Eran Wickramaratne stating that some investments should be "written off" due to their lack of return.

site_title: Functional arm candy
summary: Three Singapore-based designers, Michele Ng, Soh Szetiong, and Rosie Jansen, have created functional and stylish arm candies, including camera bags, duffels, and baby bags, that cater to various needs and lifestyles. Michele Ng's Aide de Camp bags combine practicality with fashion, featuring padded pockets and stroller straps, while Soh Szetiong's 72 Smalldive bags prioritize durability and versatility. Rosie Jansen's Tribe Bags offers luxury baby bags with a focus on quality, functionality, and style, which have gained popularity among celebrities and discerning individuals.

site_title: Investors seek to relive dotcom boom
summary: Investors are pouring billions of dollars into startups, driving valuations to multibillion-dollar heights. Snapchat and Pinterest are poised to raise funds, with Snapchat potentially doubling its $10 billion valuation. Other popular startups, such as Uber and Lyft, have also received significant investments, with Uber's valuation reaching $40 billion. The frenzied pace of investors is reminiscent of the dotcom boom and bust of the early 2000s, but many investors remain optimistic, seeking the next "unicorn" company.

site_title: Yahoo's chief unveils tools for mobile-applications developers
summary: Yahoo's CEO Marissa Mayer unveiled a suite of development tools for mobile applications that integrates its advertising services with features acquired from analytics startup Flurry Inc. The tools aim to help developers add marketing spots and native ads, enabling better tracking and data sharing. Mayer emphasized the potential of mobile in driving growth, as 25% of Yahoo's revenue came from wireless devices in 2014. The move is part of her efforts to revamp the company's mobile services, which have been under pressure to show progress in her turnaround effort.

site_title: Urban farmers
summary: Singaporean urban farmers are revolutionizing the country's food system by growing edible gardens in land-scarce areas. Thomas Lim, 31, and William Ho, 49, are two examples of individuals who have made the transition from traditional careers to urban farming. Lim works as an urban farmer for Edible Garden City, growing food plants on rooftops and in backyards, while Ho runs a 2.7-hectare quail farm, producing 30,000 eggs a day. Meanwhile, Chelsea Wan, 31, and Ryan Ong, 22, are also pioneering the urban farming movement, with Wan working at Jurong Frog Farm and Ong managing D'Kranji Farm Resort, an agri-tainment farm. These urban farmers aim to promote sustainable living, reduce reliance on imports, and provide fresh produce to the community.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Three Singaporean companies received updates on their financial performance and outlook. Sembcorp Industries (SCI) posted a 10.4% year-on-year drop in revenue but a 7.5% rise in net profit, leading to an upgrade to a "buy" rating by OCBC Investment Research. Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) sold its logistics business for US$1.2 billion, resulting in a 50% boost to its net book value per share and reduced net gearing. PACC Offshore Services Holdings reported a Q4 2014 net loss, but remains a "buy" target due to its proposed maiden dividend and efforts to cut costs.

site_title: Greece wins eurozone bailout deal with strict conditions
summary: Greece secured a four-month eurozone bailout extension with strict conditions, ending weeks of tension. The deal requires Greece to submit a list of economic reforms by Monday for review by eurozone partners. Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis described the agreement as a "new era" for Athens, while Eurogroup head Jeroen Dijsselbloem emphasized the need for trust-building between Greece and its partners. The agreement came after intense negotiations, with Germany insisting on maintaining austerity commitments.

site_title: Bondholders sanguine about Greece
summary: Greece is set to hold 11th-hour funding talks with its euro-area membership, with bondholders surprisingly optimistic about the country's chances of securing a deal. Despite 50% exit risk predictions, the Bloomberg Greece Sovereign Bond Index shows a 24% increase from its five-year average, indicating a decrease in market fear. The Greek government has proposed dialing back on austerity measures, and while Germany has rebuffed the proposal, the door remains open for an agreement, with markets showing signs of calmness.

site_title: Pervasive bad behaviour seen in complex debt
summary: US investigators have found pervasive bad behavior in the complex debt market, including dealers lying to clients and striking improper deals such as parking debt. The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has identified these issues, which include selling bonds to accomplices to skirt capital and internal rules. The market's opacity allows for misconduct, and regulators are taking action, including using technology to police markets and holding individuals and employers accountable. The SEC is also examining auctions to ensure fairness and has brought charges against former traders, including a case against a Jefferies Group trader that raised the specter of criminal charges for certain types of alleged dishonesty.

site_title: AusGroup unveils key changes to its exco
summary: AusGroup has announced key changes to its executive committee as part of a strategic review of its fabrication business in Australia. Michael Bourke has resigned and ceased to manage fabrication and manufacturing units, while Christopher Dargie has been appointed to the executive management of the Singapore business. The company cited historically tied demand to trends in downstream construction markets and the completion of major fabrication packages in the LNG sector as reasons for the review and changes. The restructuring aims to better manage overheads and support maintenance strategies.

site_title: Signs pointing to Fed entering currency war?
summary: The Federal Reserve's minutes from its January meeting have raised questions about the central bank's intentions to raise interest rates, with policymakers citing the dollar's rising value as a "persistent source of restraint" on exports. The strong dollar, which has climbed to its strongest in more than a decade, has prompted concerns that the Fed may not be able to increase rates without damaging the US economy. The minutes suggest that officials are inclined to keep rates near zero for longer, citing the negative impact of the dollar's strength on net exports.

site_title: No news of progress in US port dispute
summary: US port dispute continues, with no progress in talks between the Pacific Maritime Association and the International Longshore and Warehouse Union. The 20,000 longshoremen's work slowdown has caused massive container ships to back up around key ports, affecting businesses such as potato producers and online retailers. The Port of Oakland remains closed, and deliveries of goods like Nintendo's hot new game console are being held up. Without a deal, the situation could turn into a full-blown strike, impacting the global economy.

site_title: Emirates rejects Delta's apology over 9/11 comments
summary: Dubai's Emirates rejected a Delta Air Lines apology for remarks perceived as linking Gulf carriers with the 9/11 attacks in 2001, escalating a bitter trade row between US and Gulf airlines. The US airlines' dossier claimed Gulf carriers received $40 billion in subsidies, prompting the US government to renegotiate or scrap an Open Skies trade pact.

site_title: Olympics: Rio mayor bets big on broken-down port area
summary: Rio de Janeiro Mayor Eduardo Paes is renovating the city's seedy waterfront area, Porto Maravilha, ahead of the 2016 Olympics. The 8.2 billion reals (S$3.9 billion) project involves demolishing the elevated highway, building bike paths, pedestrian walkways, and new infrastructure. While the plan has attracted commercial projects, critics question the focus on development at the expense of building neighborhoods. The city faces challenges, including a slowing economy and a corruption scandal, but Mayor Paes believes a revitalized downtown will give Rio a "soul" and attract residents.

site_title: Thodey to step down as CEO of Telstra after six years
summary: Telstra announced a leadership change, with CFO Andrew Penn taking over as CEO on May 1, succeeding David Thodey after nearly six years. Thodey will step down on the same day.

site_title: Thai govt mulls public vote on sale of O&G concessions
summary: Thailand's military government is considering a public vote on the sale of oil and gas concessions amid opposition to contract terms. The junta, led by Deputy Prime Minister Prawit Wongsuwan, is weighing the move after a rare public forum on the issue. Critics, including former Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva and National Reform Council member Rosana Tositrakul, are seeking a bigger cut of taxes and royalties for the government. The decision could be influenced by an upcoming election in early 2016, potentially allowing Abhisit to regain public attention.

site_title: NY fashion week ends with a dazzling show by top designers
summary: New York Fashion Week concluded with a star-studded event featuring collections from top designers Ralph Lauren and Calvin Klein. Ralph Lauren showcased cashmere elegance with refined silhouettes, while Calvin Klein presented urban eroticism with edgy leather and patchwork shearling clothes. Celebrities like Kanye West and Sienna Miller attended the shows, with West even meeting with designer Ralph Lauren and posing for photos. The event ended with a rapturous applause for Lauren, who emphasized "sharp black silhouettes" in his collection.

images.alt_text: STRUTTING THEIR STUFF: A creation from the 'very sexy' collection of Ralph Lauren and another from Calvin Klein (above), which offered cashmere elegance, in New York.
STRUTTING THEIR STUFF: A creation from the 'very sexy' collection of Ralph Lauren (above) and another from Calvin Klein, which offered cashmere elegance, in New York.

site_title: The thinking man's golf course
summary: The Laguna Phuket Golf Club in Thailand has undergone a $4 million, 18-month redesign, led by Canadian golf architect Paul Jansen. The 6,144-meter course features environmentally conscious design elements, including Zoysia grass, reduced water usage, and recycled trees. The layout offers strategic risk-reward holes, such as the "villainous" bunker on the 6th hole and the uphill 10th hole. The course has been praised by European and Asian Tour professional Shiv Kapur as a "championship standard" layout that requires strategic thinking, reminiscent of famous championship courses.

site_title: Passengers injured in Swiss train collision
summary: A train collision occurred in the Swiss town of Rafz north of Zurich, leaving passengers injured and train carriages overturned. The accident happened at the Rafz train station, about 30 kilometers north of Zurich. Ambulances responded to the scene, and train service on the line between Bulach and Schaffhouse was suspended. The police and media did not provide further details about the incident.

site_title: Twin cyclones wreak havoc in north Australia; no casualties reported
summary: A powerful cyclone, Marcia, made landfall in north-east Australia on February 20, 2015, as a category 5 system, causing widespread destruction and damage. No casualties were reported, but tens of thousands of homes were affected, with 48,000 left without power. The storm severed communications to a northern island and disrupted rail lines, essential for Queensland's commodities export-driven economy. Authorities warned of heavy rains and flooding, and the worst of the winds had eased by evening, downgrading the cyclone to a category 2.

site_title: Britain defends response to HSBC tax scandal
summary: British Finance Minister George Osborne defended his government's response to the HSBC tax scandal, stating that allegations of tax evasion should be left for tax officials to investigate. Osborne described the allegations as "very serious" but emphasized the importance of not interfering in legal issues. The scandal, known as "SwissLeaks," involves HSBC's Swiss division helping clients dodge taxes on 180 billion euros in accounts across 200 countries. Osborne expressed his desire to see more prosecutions and announced plans for new international data-sharing schemes to combat tax evasion.

site_title: Beating that CNY sugar rush
summary: Diabetic patients in Singapore can enjoy Chinese New Year festivities without feeling left out by making dietary adjustments. Consuming high-sugar foods like sweets, pastries, and refined carbohydrates can spike blood sugar levels. Instead, patients can opt for "good" carbohydrates like brown rice, wholemeal bread, and whole-grain noodles. Moderate alcohol consumption is also advised, with guidelines recommending 14 units weekly for men and 7 units weekly for women. A balanced approach to eating and drinking can help mitigate the negative effects of CNY feasting on blood sugar levels and overall health.

site_title: US factory activity edges up in Feb: Markit
summary: The US manufacturing sector expanded in February at its fastest rate since November, with Markit's preliminary Manufacturing Purchasing Managers Index rising to 54.3, up from 53.9 in January. The economy remains expanding, but at a slower pace. Factory output growth increased for the second consecutive month, while employment growth slowed to its weakest rate since July. Input prices contracted for a second month, and factory orders fell to the lowest level since January 2014.

site_title: Embracing a future of wearable health technology
summary: Singapore is poised to leverage wearable health technology to boost its position as a leading global medical technology hub. The benefits of wearable devices include improved health monitoring, reduced healthcare costs, and enhanced remote care systems. However, challenges such as cost, data privacy, and sustainability must be addressed. To overcome these issues, stakeholders can consider tax incentives, transparency in data handling, and incentives for sustainable use. Integration with the existing healthcare system is also crucial for widespread adoption, and Singapore's aging population and changing demographic profile make it an ideal location for embracing this technology.

site_title: Khaw Boon Wan sees Singapore housing supply rising 11% in three years
summary: Singapore's housing supply is expected to rise 11% in three years, with over 100,000 HDB and 67,000 private units added by 2018, reaching a total of 1.43 million units. This increase aims to balance the market, with property prices adjusting to the new supply. However, an analyst warns that this rapid growth may lead to a glut in the private market, particularly in areas bought for investment, potentially affecting rental rates.

images.alt_text: The supply of housing in Singapore will increase by about 11 per cent in about three years with the addition of more than 100,000 HDB and 67,000 private units.

site_title: Hedge funds buy into N America O&G firms
summary: Hedge funds, including Elliot Management Corp and Omega Advisors Inc, are buying stakes in North American oil and gas companies, betting on a rebound in oil prices. Despite a 50% drop in oil prices since last June, many energy company stocks are considered undervalued. Activist investors aim to push companies to change their strategy, potentially through asset sales or share buybacks, to boost their balance sheet and cash out profitably. Several hedge funds, including Elliot and Omega, have disclosed stakes in Continental Resources Inc, Marathon Oil Corp, Laredo Petroleum Inc, and Sanchez Energy.

site_title: Japanese store to sell Kiss-inspired spicy buns
summary: A Japanese convenience store, Circle K Sunkus, is releasing a spicy steamed bun inspired by Kiss's 40th anniversary, commemorating the band's tour of Japan. The "Chili Tomato Man" bread, dubbed "Hotter than Hell," will go on sale nationwide on February 24. This limited-edition item is a nod to Kiss's iconic 1974 album title.

site_title: In Myanmar, cash is very much still king
summary: Myanmar's financial sector is undergoing significant changes, with the country liberalizing its banking system. Foreign banks, such as OCBC and UOB, have entered the market, and automated teller machines have increased. However, cash remains king, with most transactions taking place in cash due to a lack of trust in banks. The government aims to modernize its financial sector, but experts predict that change will be gradual, with many businesses continuing to rely on cash transactions for the next five years.

site_title: Shaping an Asian brand of philanthropy
summary: The Asia Philanthropy Circle (APC), launched in January, aims to build a distinctly Asian model of philanthropy focusing on action and impact. Led by experienced philanthropists, the donor platform brings together Asian philanthropists to address regional social challenges and shape national policies. The APC seeks to evolve a uniquely Asian type of philanthropy, considering the region's cultural, family, and religious contexts. It aims to foster a more personal relationship between grantors and grantees, promoting collective action and greater impact.

site_title: Greece pins hopes on Merkel for compromise
summary: Greece's left-wing Syriza government is seeking a compromise with Chancellor Angela Merkel, hoping she'll persuade the German Parliament to extend the country's bailout. After rejecting a request for a six-month borrowing extension, Germany says Greece must meet conditions of the existing bailout program to receive further aid. Despite this, European markets remain optimistic about a short-term finance deal, with a Merrill Lynch survey showing 51% of regional specialists expect the European economy to strengthen in the next year. However, some economists warn that Greece's debt position is unsustainable, increasing the chances of a Greek default and exit from the eurozone.

site_title: Pimco MD steps down less than a year after rejoining firm
summary: Pimco managing director Paul McCulley has stepped down less than a year after rejoining the firm, citing his mission being complete. McCulley's departure comes as the firm hires new professionals, including global economic adviser Joachim Fels, amid record redemptions and departures of co-chief investment officers. Meanwhile, Citigroup's co-president Manuel Medina-Mora is retiring on June 1, and the bank has cut CEO Michael Corbat's pay by 9% due to a US$400 million loan fraud and declining stock performance.

site_title: Walmart raises minimum US wage
summary: Walmart has announced a minimum US wage hike to $9 an hour this year and $10 in 2016, potentially pressuring other low-wage employers in the retail and fast-food sectors to follow suit. The move comes in a tightening labor market where low-skilled workers can easily switch between companies. Analysts expect retailers like Target and fast-food chains to reassess their pay policies.

site_title: Wall Street now in the middle of a humbling transformation
summary: Wall Street is undergoing a humbling transformation, driven primarily by new rules and regulations aimed at strengthening capital held by big banks. Bonuses have shrunk, revenue growth has stalled, and entire business lines are being cut. The rules require banks to effectively spend a portion of their limited capital on every risk taken, encouraging them to focus on lower-risk operations and de-emphasize trading desks. Despite profits remaining high, the industry is rethinking every business line, and some investors are questioning whether the biggest banks should be broken up.

site_title: Dow, S&P 500 dip as market eyes Greece talks
summary: The Dow and S&P 500 opened lower on Friday as markets awaited talks between Greece and the eurozone on extending a bailout program. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 27.23 points (0.15%) to 17,958.54, while the S&P 500 dropped 2.26 points (0.11%) to 2,095.19. Finance ministers in Brussels were set to discuss a proposal to extend Greece's loan program, amid opposition from Germany on austerity measures. No resolution was expected, with analysts citing "deep differences of opinion."

site_title: Scene-stealers
summary: Designers showcased luxurious gowns at New York Fashion Week, aiming to impress the fashion elite ahead of the Oscars. The event featured grandiose gowns with old Hollywood glamour, rich brocades, and shimmering dresses inspired by classic films. Designers like Badgley Mischka drew inspiration from iconic films, such as Blood and Sand, to create dramatic and sophisticated looks. The featured designs aimed to make a career-defining statement and garner publicity, as stylists searched for the perfect Oscars dress for their A-list clients.

site_title: Germany says Greek loan extension request a "good signal"
summary: Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokeswoman, Christiane Wirtz, described Greece's loan extension request as a "good signal" that allows for further talks. The proposal, made by Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis, was deemed insufficient by Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble on Thursday. Wirtz stated that euro zone finance ministers will continue negotiating on the basis of the Greek proposal, aiming to reach an agreement with Greece. The talks will provide a basis for further discussions, but the current form of the proposal is not sufficient.

images.alt_text: A spokeswoman for German Chancellor Angela Merkel said the latest Greek request for an extension of its loan agreement with Europe was a "good signal"and provided a basis for further talks, but was not sufficient in its current form.

site_title: Eurozone business activity hits seven-month high: Markit survey
summary: Eurozone business activity reached a seven-month high in February, with the Markit Economics Composite Purchasing Managers Output Index (PMI) rising to 53.5 points from 52.6 in January. The services sector PMI jumped to 53.9 points, while manufacturing edged up to 51.1. Analysts welcomed the report, citing signs of improving economic activity, with the European Commission raising its 2015 eurozone growth forecast to 1.3 per cent. However, some remain cautious, noting that the Greek debt crisis remains a concern.

site_title: Five aspects of data that just won't change in 2015
summary: A 2015 article discusses five data aspects that won't change in the coming year. These include the challenges of big data, the difficulty of laying people off, the prevalence of companies getting worse at layoffs, the persistence of companies getting worse at layoffs, and the struggle of companies getting worse at layoffs. These issues will remain unchanged by 2016, but can be tackled by those who address them, potentially leading to fun and success in 2015.

site_title: Alstom to cut half of jobs at Swiss rail factory: labour group
summary: Alstom, a French engineering group, plans to cut 50-60 jobs at its Neuhausen factory in Switzerland, approximately half of its workforce, due to increased competition from European facilities. The move comes after Switzerland's central bank lifted the franc's cap against the euro, prompting export-reliant firms to warn of declining profits. The factory, which produces train wheels, will undergo restructuring over the next two years.

site_title: Indonesia's Lion Air cancels flights leaving Jakarta
summary: Indonesia's Lion Air, the country's largest low-cost carrier, cancelled all flights from Jakarta's Soekarno-Hatta International Airport on February 20, 2015, due to "foreign object damage" in three planes. The airline cited the reason for the cancellations, which also caused widespread delays during the peak Chinese New Year holiday season, with frustrated passengers storming the duty manager's office on Thursday. The situation has improved, with police deployed to control passengers, and the airline will investigate potential violations or breaches.

images.alt_text: Lion Mentari Airlines cancelled all of its flights due to leave Jakarta on Friday evening as police were deployed to the airport to control frustrated passengers, some of whom had been stranded since Wednesday.

site_title: JGBs flat, BOJ operation results offset soft US bonds
summary: Japanese government bond prices remained steady on Friday, with the 10-year cash JGB yield flat at 0.390% and the five-year yield unchanged at 0.115%. The Bank of Japan's bond-buying operations offset falls in US Treasuries, with the BOJ purchasing 1.18 trillion yen of JGBs. Limited sales of short maturities and solid prices for longer maturities supported the market, despite some selling pressure ahead of a 40-year JGB auction.

site_title: London skyscraper to rise again after AXA real estate deal
summary: AXA Real Estate has acquired the partially built "Pinnacle" skyscraper in London's financial district for 300 million pounds. Construction is set to resume by the end of this year, with completion scheduled for 2018. The building, originally planned as the tallest tower in the City financial area, was halted in 2012 due to funding issues.
