summary: Calgary home sales have plummeted for the second consecutive month, with a 44% decline in January sales compared to the same period in 1988. The drop is attributed to the rapid decline in crude oil prices, which has roiled Alberta's housing market. This trend is also seen in Edmonton, with sales down 28% over the same period. The Canadian Real Estate Association warns that the housing market is up to 30% overvalued, highlighting the need for policymakers to intervene to prevent further market instability.

site_title: Varoufakis still holds important cards
summary: Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis still holds significant leverage in negotiations over the country's bailout package extension, despite being outnumbered by other European governments. He's considering introducing capital controls to protect Greek banks from capital flight, a move that has gained IMF approval. Greece may print its own currency, the New Drachma, and adopt a parallel currency regime if talks with creditors break down. The outcome of the negotiations will have implications for the European single currency, with Chancellor Angela Merkel under pressure to avoid concessions that could strengthen anti-euro parties.

images.alt_text: Yanis Varoufakis, the game theorist-turned-finance minister of Greece, seems outnumbered and outmanoeuvred in his 18-against-1 fight with other European governments over the country's future in the euro bloc.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares rose on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 19.75 points to 3,435.66. Trading volumes reached 642.4 million shares, valued at S$779.5 million. The rally comes ahead of GDP data release, marking a 5-day gain.

site_title: Genting HK expects weaker FY14 profit of at least US$330m
summary: Genting Hong Kong expects its 2014 net profit to be at least US$330 million, a drop from the comparable year-ago figure of US$521 million. This decrease is largely due to a drop in gains from the disposal of shares in Norwegian Cruise Lines, from US$452 million in 2013 to US$153 million in 2014. The company's associate unit, Norwegian Cruise Lines, reported a US$338.4 million profit for the full year, with Genting Hong Kong's share of the profit expected to be around US$95 million.

site_title: Greece says will submit loan extension request on Wednesday
summary: Greece's government plans to submit a request for an extension to its loan agreement with the eurozone on Wednesday. The request is separate from its full bailout program and is aimed at finding common ground with eurozone finance ministers. Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis' initial draft text was rejected at a meeting earlier this week. The Greek government is determined to find a solution, but will not back down on "red lines" or non-negotiable issues.

images.alt_text: Greece's government confirmed it would ask on Wednesday for an extension to its loan agreement with the eurozone, which it distinguishes from its full bailout programme.

site_title: Swiss franc: traders once bitten, twice shy
summary: Swiss traders are hesitant to re-enter the carry trade market due to previous losses. The Swiss franc's negative interest rates made it an attractive currency for borrowing, which was then used to invest in higher-yielding assets. This strategy would have generated more returns than using euros or yen. As a result, traders are "once bitten, twice shy," indicating they are cautious about re-engaging in the market.

images.alt_text: MR JORDAN: The SNB head said he's ready to intervene in currency markets to weaken the franc because its strength creates "headwinds" by making the economy less competitive.

site_title: Malaysia Jan inflation cools more than expected to 1.0% year-on-year, lowest since 2009
summary: Malaysia's consumer price index in January rose 1.0% year-on-year, the lowest since 2009, due to lower fuel prices. The inflation rate fell short of economists' forecasts of 1.9%. The Statistics Department attributed the decline to the transport category. The drop in global oil prices contributed to the decrease in inflation.

site_title: UK wage growth accelerates as unemployment rate declines
summary: The UK unemployment rate fell to 5.7% in the fourth quarter, its lowest in over six years, as pay growth accelerated to 2.1%, outpacing inflation. The Bank of England has held interest rates steady, but officials predict a "fairly sharp" inflation pickup once oil prices rise. Economists expect the BOE to hike rates faster than expected, potentially as early as February 2026. The pound jumped after minutes showed officials predicting higher inflation.

site_title: Greece faces resistance to extra bank funds
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to review how much support it can offer to Greece's struggling banks, amid resistance from Germany to increasing emergency lending assistance. Greece faces pressure to agree to an extended aid-for-reform program after talks with eurozone creditors broke down. The ECB's refusal to increase lending could lead to a funding squeeze, potentially requiring capital controls to limit withdrawals. The situation is fragile, with deposit outflows reaching up to 500 million euros, and the ECB's chief economist warning that funding is for the short term only.

site_title: Thailand extends Bangkok airport expansion period to 2020
summary: Thailand's Airports of Thailand PCL has extended the expansion period of Bangkok's Suvarnabhumi international airport to 2020 from 2017, increasing passenger handling capacity to 85 million by 2020. The $4 billion expansion project will begin in 2016, with a focus on increasing capacity by over 50% to 70 million in 2019. The expansion aims to address the airport's overcrowding, which was boosted by an aggressive expansion by budget airlines.

images.alt_text: Airports of Thailand PCL, the country's largest airport operator, said on Wednesday its board has approved an extension for expanding capacity at Bangkok's Suvarnabhumi international airport to 2020 from 2017.

site_title: China's Web giants do battle over 'hong bao' ahead of New Year
summary: China's web giants Alibaba and Tencent are competing to offer electronic "hong bao" (red envelopes) ahead of the Lunar New Year. The tradition of giving money in red envelopes has turned into a lucrative business, with both companies offering digital versions. Tencent's WeChat has been successful with its virtual envelopes, while Alibaba's Alipay is also offering digital gifts via Sina Weibo. The competition has led to a digital battle, with both companies launching lotteries and offering large sums of money to attract users, resulting in a surge in mobile payment transactions.

site_title: SNB seen cutting rates to shield economy after franc shock
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) is expected to cut interest rates in an effort to shield the economy from the effects of the franc's surge following the removal of its currency cap in January. Twenty-six economists predict the SNB will lower rates, with some forecasting the deposit rate could drop as low as minus 5%. The SNB's president, Thomas Jordan, has indicated that the economy may shrink in one quarter and forecasts slower growth, citing the need to avoid an all-out recession and deflation.

site_title: Qatar Airways denies staff need permission to marry
summary: Qatar Airways' CEO Akbar al-Baker denied claims that staff need permission to marry, calling them "untrue" and "a load of bullshit." The claims, made by the International Transport Workers' Federation in 2013, alleged that the airline requires female staff to obtain prior permission to get married and reserves the right to dismiss workers who are pregnant. Al-Baker defended Qatar Airways' progressive employment practices, stating that staff have "all the rights they require." The airline has over 19,000 employees.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.22 points to 1,807.87. Volume reached 897 million lots worth RM887.4 million, with 381 gainers outnumbering 276 losers.

site_title: MAS says reviewing statements in research report on Noble
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is reviewing a research report by Iceberg Research alleging that Noble Group used aggressive accounting to mislead investors. Noble Group has rejected the allegations, stating they are unfounded. The MAS will take action if there are breaches of the Securities & Futures Act. The report's findings have raised concerns about the firm's practices and potential compliance issues.

site_title: A horny question
summary: The Chinese New Year has sparked a debate over the correct animal to represent the year, with goats, sheep, and rams being featured on various hongbao designs and merchandise. Despite goats being the traditional representation, sheep are gaining popularity due to their cute and huggable appearance. Research suggests that the goat is the most likely correct representation, but ultimately, the distinction may not matter to the general public.

site_title: Asia FX sentiment less bearish amid hopes of Greek deal
summary: Asian FX sentiment has become less bearish, with emerging currencies such as Thailand's baht and Malaysia's ringgit experiencing a surge in optimism, the highest in four months. The Thai baht has gained 1.1% against the dollar, driven by stock inflows, while the Malaysian ringgit found relief from oil price rebound. However, pessimism on the Indonesian rupiah rose after the central bank cut interest rates, and pessimism on the Chinese yuan and Indian rupee remained high due to debt discussions and economic uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Sentiment towards most emerging Asian currencies became less bearish in the last two weeks with the view on Thailand's baht and Malaysia's ringgit at its best in four months, amid hopes of a new Greek debt deal.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: US President Trump's 50% copper import tariff is set to cover refined metal. Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weigh market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. Stocks in Europe declined due to bank and healthcare sector losses, with US-EU tariffs in focus. The US stock market edged down from records amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and similar operating loss for the second half of the year. London's Heathrow airport is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Athens to request extension of loan agreement on Thursday morning
summary: Greece will request an extension of its loan agreement from euro zone partners on Thursday morning, according to a government official. The request comes as the country's new government refuses to seek an extension of the EU/IMF bailout program due to austerity demands, instead opting to extend a loan agreement. The current program expires on February 28.

site_title: PM Lee Hsien Loong going home this morning, two days after surgery
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong is recovering at home after undergoing a prostate gland surgery two days ago. He shared on Facebook that he had just met with his doctors and was heading home for Chinese New Year. The post marked his return to normal life after a brief medical absence.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close at seven-year high
summary: Tokyo stocks reached a seven-year high on Wednesday, closing 1.18% higher at 18,199.17. The Nikkei 225 index and Topix index rose 212.08 and 20.60 points, respectively. The gains were driven by hopes for an end to Greece's debt stand-off and a weaker yen supporting exporters.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close up 0.19%
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.19% on Wednesday, closing at 24,832.08 on turnover of HK$28.93 billion, as investors head into the Lunar New Year holiday. The benchmark Hang Seng Index gained 47.20 points.

site_title: JPMorgan tops list of risky banks: US government study
summary: A US government study ranked JPMorgan Chase & Co as the most risky bank to the financial system, with a systemic risk score of 5.05% in 2013. Citigroup ranked second, followed by Bank of America and Goldman Sachs. The study used metrics such as size, interconnectedness, and complexity to determine the risk. The findings aim to inform regulators' efforts to finalize rules for capital buffers for large banks to make them more resilient and contain systemic risk.

site_title: Southeast Asia stocks: Indonesia at record high after rate cut; most others up ahead of holidays
summary: Indonesia's key stock index reached a record high of 5,415.38 after the central bank unexpectedly cut its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 7.5 per cent, boosting domestic demand and optimism about the economy. Other Southeast Asian stocks also rose, with Malaysia's composite index down 0.1 per cent, and Thailand's SET index up 0.7 per cent. Asian shares rose ahead of Greek bank emergency funding talks, while Singapore shares finished 0.6 per cent higher.

site_title: BOJ Kuroda says he sees no immediate need to ease again
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda announced no immediate need to expand monetary stimulus, citing inflation heading towards the 2% target. Despite temporary pressure from slumping oil prices, Kuroda stressed the BOJ's resolve to ease policy if necessary. The BOJ maintained its stimulus programme, printing 80 trillion yen annually, and revised its view on exports and output. Core consumer inflation was 0.5% in December, and the economy is recovering moderately, on track to hit 2% inflation next fiscal year.

site_title: Singapore January consumer prices set to fall for third month
summary: Singapore's consumer price index (CPI) is expected to decline 0.3% in January from a year earlier, marking the third consecutive month of a drop, according to a Reuters poll. Lower oil prices and transportation costs contribute to the forecast. Core consumer inflation eased to 1.3% in January, the slowest pace since January 2013. The data release is scheduled for Monday, following Singapore's central bank's unexpected easing of monetary policy in late January due to the plunge in oil prices.

site_title: China to crank up oil product exports, add to supply glut
summary: China has increased its oil product export quotas for state-run refiners to 9.75 million tonnes, a 20% rise from the initial limit set for 2014, amid a supply glut. This move is expected to further depress margins for processing crude into fuel, particularly in Asia. China's exports of jet fuel and gasoline are expected to increase, while diesel exports are forecast to remain steady or fall. The increase in exports comes as new refineries in the Middle East add capacity, putting pressure on fuel prices.

site_title: Global policy easing spreads to Southeast Asia, will Thailand be next?
summary: Southeast Asia's central banks are easing policy to combat deflationary pressures, following Indonesia's surprise rate cut and Singapore's rate easing. Thailand is expected to lower interest rates in March, despite the military government's preference for spending to boost growth. Malaysia and the Philippines are unlikely to cut rates, with the Philippines citing a robust economy and Malaysia concerned about capital outflows. The region's economies grew at 4.5% in 2014, the slowest since 2009, and inflation has fallen to 1.0% in January, providing room for rate cuts.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.21% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.21% in opening trade on February 18, 2015, following news that Greece would ask for an extension of its bailout agreement, boosting hopes for a debt agreement with creditors. The Hang Seng Index increased 51.17 points to 24,836.05.

site_title: Islamic finance body IILM takes sukuk programme above US$2b
summary: The International Islamic Liquidity Management Corp (IILM) has increased its Islamic bond programme above US$2 billion for the first time, after auctioning US$490 million worth of three-month sukuk and US$500 million of six-month sukuk. The outstanding sukuk programme, rated A-1 by Standard and Poor's, now totals US$2.05 billion. The IILM, a consortium of Asian, Middle Eastern, and African central banks, began the programme in 2013 to address Islamic banks' short-term liquidity needs. The programme permits maturities of up to one year and may eventually expand issuance to US$2 billion or more.

site_title: Hot stock: Singapore's Noble shares rise one per cent in opening trade
summary: Shares of Singapore's Noble Group rose 1% in opening trade on Wednesday, a day after the company released a rebuttal to a report questioning its accounting practices. Noble shares had lost nearly 13% in the previous two trading sessions. The company's board and management stated that its balance sheet fairly represents its book value under International Financial Reporting Standards. Iceberg Research had previously reported that Noble used aggressive accounting to mislead investors.

site_title: Stocks to watch: NOL, Noble, Sembcorp Industries, Breadtalk
summary: NEPTEUN Orient Lines (NOL) sold its logistics business to Kintetsu World Express for $1.2 billion, aiming to strengthen its financial position. Noble Group responded to allegations of aggressive accounting, stating its financial reports are in line with International Financial Reporting Standards. Sembcorp Industries reported a 7.5% rise in net profit to $240.62 million, driven by higher contributions from utilities businesses. Breadtalk posted a 30.8% drop in profit to $3.85 million, citing weaker demand and high costs.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened higher on Wednesday, driven by renewed optimism over a potential end to Greece's debt stand-off. London's FTSE 100 rose 0.23%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 gained 0.33%, and the CAC 40 index in Paris rose 0.60%. Greece's finance minister, Yanis Varoufakis, said the country will request a six-month extension of its European loan agreement without signing up to a full bailout. This move aims to create stability for negotiations between Greece and Europe, amid a looming deal to avoid a catastrophic Greek exit from the eurozone.

images.alt_text: Europe's main stock markets opened higher on Wednesday on hopes of an end to Greece's debt stand-off, dealers said.

site_title: Oil halts rising streak as US stockpiles seen worsening glut
summary: Oil prices fell for the first time in four days, dropping 0.9% in New York as US crude inventories are forecast to increase further, contributing to a global glut that drove prices almost 50% lower in 2014. US oil supplies rose to a record level of 417.9 million barrels, and production is expected to slow in the coming years due to well exhaustion. The US Energy Information Administration report is expected to influence market sentiment, with analysts predicting a base for oil prices.

site_title: Why 50,000 Chinese auditors are worrying the world's bond buyers
summary: China's provinces are turning to international fundraising amid a crackdown on local government debt, with 50,000 auditors investigating the issue. The nation's provinces have issued a record amount of debt, totaling 17.9 trillion yuan (US$2.9 trillion) as of June 2013. This has led to a decrease in take-up for onshore yuan notes and an increase in offshore debt issuance. Investors are cautious, with some expressing concerns about the uncertainty surrounding debt reclassification and the potential for more local governments to inflate their borrowings.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Wednesday
summary:
Here's a summary of the article content in 100 words or less:

Vietnam expressed surprise over US President Trump's tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate. The Asian garment industry is bracing for higher US tariffs. In Malaysia, an agency plans to seize approximately RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Citigroup predicts a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index. Thaksin Shinawatra remains confident that a Thai court will clear his daughter's suspension as PM in an ethics case. The UK economy shrank for the second month, dealing a blow to Starmer's government.

images.alt_text: Iceberg Research, whose report on commodity trading firm Noble Group is now under investigation by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), took to the development coolly, even while Noble welcomed the review.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index up 19.57 points to 3,435.48. Volume was 53.4 million shares worth S$71.9 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 86 to 48. This marks the 5th consecutive day of gains ahead of the release of GDP data.

site_title: BOJ maintains stimulus, revises up view on output
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its massive stimulus, increasing base money at an annual pace of 80 trillion yen ($671 billion) to support the economy's recovery. The BOJ revised its output view, signaling confidence in a sustained recovery without additional monetary stimulus. However, it cautioned about private consumption weakness, particularly in some areas. The decision maintains the BOJ's stance since October last year to prevent deflation from delaying a sustained recovery.

site_title: Hot stock: NOL rises on planned divestment of APL Logistics
summary: NOL shares rose on Wednesday after the company announced plans to divest its logistics business, APL Logistics, to Japanese logistics company Kintetsu World Express for approximately US$1.2 billion. The sale aims to strengthen NOL's financial position and focus on its core liner shipping business. APL Logistics generated about US$1.66 billion in revenue and US$80 million in core earnings for NOL in the 2014 financial year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.53 points to 1806.54. Volume reached 18.9 million lots worth RM7 million, with 66 gainers outnumbering 57 losers.

site_title: Berkshire eliminates Exxon stake amid plunge in oil prices
summary: Berkshire Hathaway, led by Warren Buffett, eliminated its $3.7 billion stake in Exxon Mobil due to the significant decline in oil prices, which have fallen by about half since June. This move comes after Berkshire increased its investment in Deere & Co and disclosed a stake in 21st Century Fox. The decision reflects the challenges of picking stocks, as noted by analyst Cliff Gallant, and follows other stock picks by Buffett that faltered last year, including International Business Machines and Tesco.

site_title: Cambridge Industrial Trust in S$19.9m Jurong property deal with Unicable
summary: Cambridge Industrial Trust (CIT) has entered into a S$19.9 million sale-and-purchase agreement to acquire a property in Jurong from Unicable. The 8,000 sqm property has a remaining land tenure of 26 years and will be leased to Unicable for five years. CIT plans to fund the acquisition through cash and existing debt facilities, with the deal expected to be completed by Q2 2015. The acquisition is seen as a strong yielding and quality asset that will provide a steady income stream and enhance CIT's portfolio.

site_title: Russia lures Asia oil buyers as Mideast scraps for share
summary: Russia increased its share of oil shipments to Asia by 25% last year, reaching 8.7%, as Middle Eastern producers, including Saudi Arabia and Qatar, ceded market share. This surge in Russian sales helps the country weather the conflict in Ukraine, sanctions, and collapsing energy prices. The shift to Asia is driven by European demand weakness and the US's growing energy self-sufficiency, with Asia forecast to become the largest consuming region this year.

site_title: Japan Post makes US$5.07b bid for Australia's Toll
summary: Japan Post has made a $5.07 billion bid to acquire Australia's Toll Holdings, recommending shareholders accept the offer to create one of the world's largest logistics companies. The proposal, a 49% premium to Toll's closing price, would see the Melbourne-based transport logistics giant run as a division within Japan Post and retain the Toll name. The deal, pending approval from Australian authorities, aims to expand Japan Post's global footprint and create a powerful logistics company.

site_title: Asia: Stocks head for five-month high on optimism about Greece
summary: Asian stocks rose, heading for a five-month high, amid speculation Greece will reach a resolution with its creditors. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index gained 0.3% and the S&P 500 Index closed above 2,100 for the first time in history. A possible six-month extension of Greece's loan agreement boosted investor optimism. Japan's Topix index also advanced 1.2%, while US 10-year note yields approached a 2015 high.

site_title: Oil rally seen reversing as unstoppable US supply deepens glut
summary: US oil production reaches a record high, but experts predict the oil rally will reverse due to deepening global supply glut. Despite the US drillers idling record number of rigs, inventories will continue to expand, and producers will need to discount to sell barrels. Analysts at UBS, Bank of America, and Commerzbank expect Brent crude to fall to $40-$45 per barrel within the next three months. The market's reliance on sentiment rather than fundamentals will lead to a reversal of the recent price surge.

site_title: China Development Bank to list units worth US$2b: IFR
summary: China Development Bank (CDB) plans to list two subsidiary units in Hong Kong, worth over US$2 billion, to expand its international business amid slowing domestic growth. CDB Leasing, covering aviation, transport, and infrastructure, and CDB Securities, handling bond offerings, are expected to be listed by the end of the year. This move aims to shift CDB's focus from a government-focused bank to a commercial lender, with ambitions to invest in Africa and other international markets.

site_title: IMF says uneven, fragile global growth poses challenges to developing Asia
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns of uneven and fragile global growth, posing challenges to developing Asia. IMF Deputy Managing Director Naoyuki Shinohara cites weak investment as a key factor. The global economy is expected to experience subpar growth, with diminishing prospects in China, Russia, the euro area, and Japan. Shinohara also flags the risk of high dollarization in emerging Asia, which limits exchange rate flexibility and constrains central banks' ability to act as lenders of last resort. He suggests actively promoting "de-dollarization" to mitigate these risks.

images.alt_text: The global economy faces the prospect of subpar growth, despite a boost from the recent drop in oil prices, with diminished prospects in China, Russia, the euro area and Japan.

site_title: China, Taiwan, South Korea: Markets closed
summary: Financial markets in China, Taiwan, and South Korea are closed on Wednesday due to a public holiday. Meanwhile, in Europe, stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector losses, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. US-EU trade talks are in focus.

site_title: Indonesia sukuk diverges from Malaysia on oil: Islamic Finance
summary: Indonesia's dollar sukuk yield has fallen to a 21-month low of 3.72% due to cheaper oil, while Malaysia's 2021 debt yield has climbed to 2.98%, its highest since September. Indonesia's default risk has dropped to 148 basis points, while Malaysia's has risen to 122 basis points. Analysts attribute Indonesia's improved budget position to its recent overhaul of a fuel-subsidy program, while Malaysia is facing a drop in revenue and higher budget deficit target. The divergence in yields is expected to boost confidence in Indonesian credit, with the country planning to return to the global sukuk market in the first half of the year.

site_title: Apple patent lets iPhone be part of VR reality display
summary: Apple has been awarded a patent for a headset that allows iPhones to be part of augmented or virtual reality displays. The patent, titled "Head Mounted Display Apparatus For Retaining A Portable Electronic Device With Display," depicts a large eyeglass-style frame with a smartphone seated directly before the wearer's eyes. This setup would enable users to watch what's happening around them while still seeing the screen, with the option for picture-in-picture. The technology could revolutionize the way people interact with virtual reality displays.

images.alt_text: Apple on Tuesday was awarded a patent on a headset that could let iPhones be part of augmented or virtual reality displays.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close mixed
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed mixed on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.60% to 6,898.13 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 closed down 0.25% at 10,895.62 points. Paris's CAC 40 was stable, gaining a slight 0.04% to 4,753.99 points. The mixed performance was attributed to mining and healthcare sectors, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: US household debt levels rise in Q4
summary: US household debt levels rose $117 billion to $11.83 trillion in the fourth quarter, according to the New York Federal Reserve Bank. Student loan balances increased by $31 billion to $1.16 trillion, while the overall loan delinquency rate remained unchanged at 4.3%. Auto loan delinquency rates also rose, from 3.1% to 3.5%.

site_title: Greece eyes EU loan deal without painful bailout duties
summary: Greece is set to request a six-month extension to its European loan agreement, without signing up to the painful bailout duties, as Brussels pressures Athens to reach a deal. Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis said the extension would provide stability for negotiations on a new agreement. The move comes amid tensions with the EU, where influential German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble has expressed skepticism about Greece's demands. A deal is needed to avoid a catastrophic Greek exit from the eurozone, with the European portion of the $270 billion bailout expiring at the end of February.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.65% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.65% higher on Wednesday, driven by a fresh record close on Wall Street and the yen's drop against other major currencies. The Nikkei 225 index rose 116.89 points to 18,103.98. US stocks also reached new highs, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gaining 0.16% and 0.11% respectively. The Bank of Japan's policy meeting is set to conclude later Wednesday, with investors expecting no further easing measures.

site_title: Sony steps up in wearable space with SmartEyeglass
summary: Sony has begun taking orders for SmartEyeglass, its Internet-linked eyewear, ahead of Google's revised Glass strategy. SmartEyeglass connects to smartphones, displaying text, images, or information onto real scenes. Available in March in several countries, the eyewear will be priced at $840 in the US and $670 in Europe. Sony sees potential for augmented reality and professional use cases, and is encouraging developers to create applications for the device.

site_title: Swiss franc surge puts strain on WHO's US$4b budget plan
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is facing a financial strain due to the surge of the Swiss franc, which has increased salary costs by 12% this year. The WHO's proposed budget of over $4 billion for 2016 and 2017 is being revised to adjust for the franc's strength, but no consensus has been reached. The rise in the franc's value poses a risk to jobs in Geneva, with some organizations, such as Unicef, already planning to cut costs. The WHO has 1,900 employees in Geneva and is considering moving jobs to other locations.

site_title: Luxury carmaker Rolls-Royce to develop a sports utility vehicle
summary: Rolls-Royce Motor Cars will develop a sports utility vehicle (SUV) as part of its diversification strategy, entering the luxury off-roader market where rivals Bentley and Jaguar have already made plans. The decision was made after consulting with clients, with no launch date specified. This move follows Rolls-Royce's gradual expansion of its model range, which has included the Ghost II and Wraith Coupe. The luxury SUV is expected to compete with Bentley's upcoming model, set to hit showrooms in 2016.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble shares surge nearly 4.3% in trading; group welcomes MAS review
summary: Noble Group shares surged 4.3% in trading after the commodity trading firm defended itself against allegations of aggressive accounting. The allegations, made by Iceberg Research, claimed Noble mislead investors by treating certain companies as associates, resulting in a S$1.05 billion market value slump. Noble welcomed the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) review and stated it will fully cooperate with the investigation. The firm reported its results according to International Financial Reporting Standards and emphasized that its annual financial statements were audited by Ernst & Young.

images.alt_text: The stock, which opened at S$1.055, was the most heavily traded one by volume, with more than 21.2 million shares changing hands by 10.15am.

site_title: Uber files second complaint against French law
summary: Uber has filed a second complaint to the European Commission against a French law that allegedly favors regular taxis. The law, which requires Uber to notify the Commission of its operations, has not been implemented. Uber claims the law puts it at a disadvantage, and the company is seeking an investigation. This is the second complaint filed by Uber against France, following a November complaint. The European Commission has received the complaint and is assessing the situation.

site_title: Aztech's Q4 profit down nearly 91%
summary: Aztech Group reported a 91% year-on-year decline in Q4 net profit to S$280,000, due to higher expenses and lower revenue. Revenue fell 7% to S$77.34 million, with the electronics segment contributing to the increase while material supply and marine logistics segments saw declines. The company expects to expand its F&B Retail business and offer new marine and shipyard services in FY2015, while maintaining cost management and product innovation. A final dividend of 0.5 Singapore cent per share is proposed, payable May 20, 2015.

site_title: US: Stocks edge higher; S&P 500 hits new record
summary: US stocks edged higher on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 reaching a new closing high, despite the latest Greek debt talks ending without an agreement. The S&P 500 gained 3.35 points (0.16%) to 2,100.34, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 28.23 (0.16%) to 18,047.58. The rebound followed news that Greece might be open to a compromise extension of its current bailout package.

site_title: US oil workers threaten to expand strike to California port
summary: US oil workers at the Port of Long Beach are threatening to expand a national oil workers' strike to the California port, which has been dealing with cargo delays since last year. United Steelworkers members are negotiating their own contract with Tesoro Logistics LP and may join the strike if they do not reach an agreement. The potential expansion would add to the port's problems amid labor negotiations between terminal operators and longshoremen.

site_title: How a liquidity squeeze could push Greece out of the euro
summary: A liquidity squeeze between Greece and its creditors risks triggering a simultaneous cash and credit crunch, potentially driving the country out of the euro area. The Greek government, companies, and lenders have lost access to international markets due to uncertainty over the country's future. If a compromise is not reached, bailout funds from the euro-area nations, IMF, and ECB's ELA will cease, leaving the state unable to service its debt obligations. This could lead to a de facto exit from the euro area, with the country using a new currency or equivalent to survive.

site_title: UK inflation slows more than forecast to record low 0.3%
summary: UK inflation rate slowed to a record low of 0.3% in January, dropping more than forecast, due to declining food and fuel prices. This is the lowest rate since 1960, and economists expect inflation to rebound starting this year and potentially lead to interest rate hikes by the Monetary Policy Committee. The Bank of England cut its near-term inflation projections and governor Mark Carney said the rate could fall below zero in the coming months.

site_title: Oscars telecast: Come for the music, stay for the movies
summary: The 87th Academy Awards will feature a musical lineup aimed at attracting a younger audience without alienating adult viewers. Lady Gaga, Tim McGraw, Adam Levine, and Tegan and Sara will perform, with the telecast's producers seeking to capitalize on the success of last year's ceremony. Host Neil Patrick Harris will help bridge the gap between young and old audiences, and the show's musical numbers will be tied to the nominated films. The goal is to make the Oscars more entertaining and appealing to a new generation of viewers, while still honoring the film industry.

site_title: BreadTalk Q4 net dives
summary: BreadTalk Group reported a 30.8% decline in net profit to S$3.85 million for its fourth quarter, due to softer demand in mainland China and intense competition in Singapore. Revenue increased 5.3% to S$155 million. The company recommends a final dividend of 1 cent per share, totaling 1.5 cents for 2014. BreadTalk shares closed at S$1.52, down 1.5 cents.

site_title: Greece, EU search for an honourable solution
summary: European Union finance ministers are urging Greece to stay in an international bailout, offering enticements and veiled threats, as financial markets slip on fears of disruption if Athens' credit lines expire in 10 days. A compromise plan by French Finance Minister Michel Sapin proposes a smaller budget surplus, but Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis dismissed the argument that his government is forced to accept the deal. A deal must be reached by Friday to avoid a bank meltdown and potential eurozone exit, with investors warning of severe economic and financial instability.

site_title: US to allow export of armed drones
summary: The US will allow the export of armed drones to some allied countries as part of its counterterrorism efforts. This move is part of the country's global fight against extremists in various regions, including Afghanistan, Pakistan, and Syria. The decision comes after the US has sold armed drones only to close ally Britain, with other countries such as Italy, Turkey, and Persian Gulf nations expressing interest in acquiring the technology. The US aims to ensure responsible use of the drones, consistent with national security, foreign policy, and international standards.

images.alt_text: The United States said on Tuesday that it will allow for the first time the widespread export of armed drones to some allied countries as part of its global counterterrorism fight.

site_title: Russian wanted over US$300m Nasdaq hacking extradited to US
summary: A Russian national, Vladimir Drinkman, 34, has been extradited to the US to face charges related to a $300 million hacking scheme that targeted Nasdaq and other companies, including 7-Eleven, Carrefour, and JC Penney. Drinkman was arrested in 2012 and charged with international hacking and data breach scheme, with losses estimated at over $300 million. He appeared in court in Newark, New Jersey, to face US criminal charges.

site_title: Ford guns for China's app addicts, seeks WeChat tie-up
summary: Ford is in talks with Tencent Holdings to integrate its popular WeChat app into its cars in China, a move to cater to the country's tech-savvy drivers. The app, with 500 million active monthly users, would allow drivers to access WeChat functions safely and hands-free through voice commands or limited button use. Other automakers, including Daimler and Nissan, are also exploring similar integrations to gain market share in China's slowing economy.

images.alt_text: Making WeChat and other apps convenient, safe and legal to use while driving could help auto- makers gain market share in China

site_title: Greece faces resistance to extra emergency funds for banks: sources
summary: The European Central Bank faces resistance from Germany to providing extra emergency funds for Greek banks, which are struggling due to rising deposit outflows. Despite this, the ECB is unlikely to lower the ceiling on emergency lending assistance, which could lead to financial difficulties for Greek banks that are close to using up the full 65 billion euros granted so far. This development increases pressure on Athens to sign up to an extended aid-for-reform programme.

site_title: Putin lets consumers feel the pain as slump deepens in Russia
summary: Russian households are bearing the brunt of the economic crisis, with retail sales expected to decline by 8% due to the 44% slump in the rouble and soaring prices. The government's anti-crisis plan focuses on supporting lenders and industry, but neglects key sectors like trade, construction, and services. With inflation forecast to peak at 17%, Russia risks a drawn-out recession, with consumer spending accounting for half the economy. The government's public finances have deteriorated, with the oil price needed to balance the budget tripling in the past decade.

images.alt_text: Household consumption accounted for most or all expansion in GDP between 2010 and 2013, the World Bank says. It contributed 3.8 percentage points to GDP gains in 2012 and 2.3 percentage points the following year. Now most consumer indicators are flashing red.

site_title: Snapchat seeks new funding at up to US$19b valuation
summary: Snapchat is seeking up to US$500 million in funding, valuing the company at up to US$19 billion, according to a Bloomberg report. Executives are in talks with fund managers, with the goal of raising US$500 million. The Los Angeles-based company allows users to send disappearing messages and has not commented on the matter. This funding round would follow previous investments in the company, which has seen significant growth in recent years.

site_title: Norway gets caught in currency race to bottom: Nordic Credit
summary: Norway's economy, the richest in Scandinavia, is facing pressure to cut interest rates amid a strengthening currency. Banks predict a rate cut in March to weaken the krone and counter the impact of plummeting oil prices, which have dropped 46% since June. Norway's central bank, Norges Bank, is expected to signal another rate cut to respond to quantitative easing in Europe. The country's economy relies heavily on oil and gas, making it vulnerable to the decline in crude prices. A rate cut is seen as necessary to support the economy's growth.

site_title: Future of NOL sinks deeper into doubt
summary: The NOL Group's sale of APL Logistics to sustain its loss-making shipping business has raised doubts about the future of its shipping arm, APL. The sale appears puzzling, as APL is a profit-making unit. The decision may pave the way for NOL to eventually get rid of its other assets.

site_title: Funds buy Ezion, sell Frasers Centrepoint Trust
summary: Global mutual funds sold slightly more Singapore shares than they bought in the three months to Feb 11, with a net sell of S$1.15 billion and a net buy of S$1.1 billion. The top stock sold was Frasers Centrepoint Trust with S$168.4 million, while the top stock bought was Ezion Holdings with S$483.7 million. This trend indicates a shift in market sentiment, with funds favoring Ezion over Frasers Centrepoint Trust.

site_title: CapitaLand Q4 net profit surges 187% (Amended)
summary: CapitaLand, a Singaporean real estate investment trust, reported a 187% year-on-year surge in net profit after tax and minority interests for the fourth quarter, reaching S$409.4 million. Revenue grew 67% to S$1.52 billion, driven by the sale of Westgate Tower and higher revenue from shopping malls and serviced residences. The company's operating profit jumped 54% to S$283.6 million, while net fair value gains rose 17% to S$461.8 million. CapitaLand remains confident in its long-term outlook for core markets Singapore and China, with plans to expand into new growth markets and increase asset under management.

site_title: Copenhagen police confirm identity of attacks gunman
summary: Copenhagen police have confirmed the identity of the gunman behind the weekend's double shooting as 22-year-old Omar El-Hussein, a Danish-born man of Palestinian origin. El-Hussein killed a filmmaker and a Jewish man in separate incidents, with five police officers also injured. The suspect had initially tried to enter a cultural centre hosting a debate on Islam and free speech, where he was later shot dead by police. Two firearms were used in the attack outside a synagogue, both found on El-Hussein's body.

images.alt_text: Copenhagen police late Tuesday confirmed the identity of the suspected gunman behind the weekend's double shooting as 22-year-old Omar El-Hussein.

site_title: Bordeaux 2014 wines signal recovery after bad year
summary: Bordeaux 2014 wines have shown improved quality after cool, wet weather in 2013, according to growers. Yields recovered, with some estates reporting 38 hectolitres per hectare, compared to 20 in 2013. The improved outlook coincides with renewed appetite for vintages from the earlier part of the decade, with the Liv-ex Fine Wine 50 Index tracking Bordeaux experiencing its first back-to-back monthly gain since March 2013. The wines are expected to be presented to merchants in early April.

site_title: US hedge funds unload Alibaba shares in fourth quarter
summary: Several major hedge funds, including Omega Advisors, Appaloosa Management, and Jana Partners, sold or reduced their stakes in Alibaba Group Holding Ltd in the fourth quarter of 2014, amid the company's surprise revenue miss. Meanwhile, Dan Loeb's Third Point and John Paulson's Paulson & Co increased their stakes. The shares have plummeted 27.6% since their peak in November, and some investors remain optimistic about Alibaba's long-term potential.

images.alt_text: Alibaba shares, which opened at US$92.70 at their market debut on Sept 19, took a sharp drop last month after the company reported lower-than-expected revenues for the third quarter.

site_title: Hubris and the reality of Europe
summary: The European Union's single market and economic union have failed to deliver the expected prosperity, leading to low growth, increasing political tensions, and economic instability. The eurozone's flawed political structure, driven by too much free-market faith and hubris, has contributed to the crisis. The EU's economic union was justified as both a free-market project and a "next step" in creating an ever closer Europe, but it ultimately led to inefficient capital allocation, unsustainable public deficits, and severe debt overhangs. Without progress to a more complete economic union, the currency union risks another lost decade of weak growth and low inflation.

site_title: Lady Gaga, actor Taylor Kinney get engaged
summary: Lady Gaga, 28, has announced her engagement to actor Taylor Kinney, 33, after a Valentine's Day proposal at a New York restaurant. The couple met in 2011 while filming a video in Nebraska, where Gaga wore her mother's wedding dress. Kinney, who has acted in TV shows like Chicago Fire and films like Zero Dark Thirty, gave Gaga a simple heart-shaped ring. The engagement was revealed on Instagram, with Gaga expressing her excitement to marry the man who "gave me his heart."

site_title: Euro struggles as Greek debt talks collapse
summary: The euro has lost ground against the US dollar after Greek debt talks collapsed, fueling fears of Greece's potential exit from the eurozone. Greece's new government, led by Yanis Varoufakis, is seeking a six-month bridging loan to negotiate a new deal, while eurozone nations, led by Germany, insist on sticking to the current bailout package. The eurozone's 240 billion euro lifeline expires at the end of the month, and the Bank of Japan is set to meet without announcing fresh stimulus.

site_title: Trading slows ahead of CNY holidays
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 11.25 points to 3,415.91 on Tuesday, with low trading volume of 995 million units worth S$936 million, due to the President's Day holiday and Chinese New Year holidays. Noble Group's shares fell 5.4% to S$1.05 after a short-selling attack by Iceberg Research, but Macquarie Equities Research maintained its "outperform" rating. Transcorp Holdings surged 35% to 17.8 cents after a query from the Singapore Exchange. The market is expected to remain range-bound until key events such as Greece's debt negotiations and the Fed chair Janet Yellen's testimony.

site_title: Finance and insurance sector drives GDP engine
summary: The finance and insurance sector in Singapore drove the country's economy, outperforming all other sectors in terms of growth and productivity for the fourth quarter and 2014 as a whole, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry. The sector grew 10% in the fourth quarter and 7.7% for the full year, contributing the most to the country's gross domestic product. Despite easing growth forecasts, the sector's gains were still significant, with the insurance industry and fund management seeing notable increases in productivity.

images.alt_text: Skyline of the Marina Bay Financial Centre.

site_title: MAS must be creative in crafting crowdfunding rules
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed making equity crowdfunding a sophisticated investor-only market, sparking criticism from industry players who argue that the restriction goes against the crowdfunding concept. MAS aims to address the risk of securities sale to the investment public, but advocates for a more liberal regulatory regime propose alternative safeguards, such as cooling-off periods and dispute resolution mechanisms. MAS should consider creative rules to protect investor protection while allowing small businesses and startups to access investors.

site_title: SGX-CBA crowdfunding JV a move in the right direction
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Clearbridge Accelerator Pte Ltd (CBA) have formed a joint venture to create the world's first equity-based crowdfunding platform in Asia, targeting pan-Asian investors. The platform aims to support entrepreneurs and SMEs in accessing capital more easily, with the goal of boosting Singapore's entrepreneurial finance ecosystem. The platform is expected to be operational by mid-year and will focus on accredited investors, with a focus on companies with commercially viable products and services and revenue-generating potential. This move is seen as a strategic step towards positioning Singapore as a leading innovation capital in Asia.

site_title: Kingsford Waterbay to open for viewing this weekend
summary: Kingsford Development, a Chinese-owned company, will open its 1,165-unit riverfront project, Kingsford Waterbay, to the public this weekend. The 99-year leasehold private residential project, located near Hougang MRT Station, features riverfront views and water-themed recreational facilities. The development's showflats will open on February 21, with prices starting at S$1,000-1,050 per square foot. The project's location near the integrated transport hub and childcare centre makes it an attractive option for potential buyers.

images.alt_text: Units offered at Kingsford Waterbay fronting Sungei Serangoon comprise 1,157 units of one to five-bedroom apartments, six units of strata terrace houses, and two units of strata semi-detached houses

site_title: NOL to sell APL Logistics to Japan's KWE for US$1.2b
summary: NEPTUNE Orient Lines (NOL) agreed to sell its logistics business, APL Logistics, to Japan's KWE for US$1.2 billion. The sale, pending shareholder and regulatory approval, will halve NOL's net gearing and allow the company to focus on its liner shipping business. APL Logistics contributed US$1.66 billion in revenue and US$80 million in core earnings in 2014, representing 19% and 25% of NOL's consolidated revenue and core Ebitda, respectively. The sale price represents a 15x multiple to APL Logistics' reported core Ebitda, surpassing valuations of similar logistics businesses.

images.alt_text: Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) has agreed to sell its profitable logistics business, APL Logistics, to Japanese logistics group Kintetsu World Express (KWE) for US$1.2 billion.

site_title: Oil at US$53; Kuwait sees price rise continuing
summary: Oil prices held near US$53 a barrel in New York, following a 3.1% rise on February 13. Kuwait's oil minister predicted a continued price rebound due to a shrinking surplus. Oil futures remained unchanged after floor trading was closed for a holiday on Monday.

images.alt_text: Oil is rebounding from the lowest prices in almost six years as US drillers cut the number of rigs in service to the fewest since August 2011.

site_title: Home prices in top China cities stabilising in January
summary: China's major cities experienced a stabilizing trend in home prices in January, with average new home prices down 0.4% from December, marking the ninth consecutive monthly drop. However, nationwide recovery is unlikely in the near term due to a massive overhang of unsold homes in lower-tier cities. The property sector accounts for 15% of China's GDP, and economists predict further growth slowdown to around 7% this year.

site_title: Rolls-Royce implicated in Petrobras bribery claim
summary: Rolls-Royce has denied being approached by Brazilian authorities regarding bribery allegations made by a former Petrobras manager. The company was named in the plea bargain statement as having paid bribes on a contract worth $100 million. Former manager Pedro Barusco alleged that Brazilian politicians skimmed billions through overpriced contracts. Rolls-Royce has a zero-tolerance approach to wrongdoing and will cooperate with authorities. The company is under investigation by Britain's Serious Fraud Office over bribery concerns in China and Indonesia.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers have issued updates on Singapore-listed companies Noble Group, Raffles Medical, and CWT Ltd. Noble Group's share price reacted negatively to a negative report from ICEBERG Research, but analysts Macquarie Research maintain their "outperform" rating. Raffles Medical's FY2014 net profit was below expectations, with analysts DMG & Partners cutting their 2015 forecast earnings per share. CWT Ltd's FY2014 revenue and profit increased, but analysts OCBC Investment Research adjusted their fair value and rating to "buy" due to expected growth in its Logistics Services segment.

site_title: Silicon Valley emerges as transportation hub with Apple's electric vehicle
summary: Silicon Valley is emerging as a transportation hub, driven by companies like Apple, Google, and Facebook, which are investing in electric vehicles, self-driving cars, drones, and space exploration. Apple is reportedly developing an electric vehicle, code-named Titan, while Tesla Motors, led by Elon Musk, is shaking up the electric-vehicle market. Other startups, such as RelayRides and Flywheel, are also disrupting traditional car-sharing models. Traditional automakers, like Ford and Daimler, are also investing in technology, highlighting the shift towards software-defined vehicles.

site_title: Why some US firms take one big hit on Venezuelan businesses
summary: US companies operating in Venezuela are taking a significant hit due to the country's crumbling currency system. To mitigate losses, some firms, like Ford Motor Co, have taken a one-time writedown of their Venezuelan investments, effectively valuing them at zero. This move allows them to avoid ongoing losses and maintain a foothold in the market. Companies such as PepsiCo and Kimberly Clark have also taken similar charges, while General Motors Co has signaled it may deconsolidate its Venezuelan operations in the future. The move is rare and allowed under a narrow exception for government-imposed uncertainties.

site_title: Why central bank easing won't be so easy in China
summary: China's central bank governor Zhou Xiaochuan faces a daunting task in keeping the economy stable amid a slowdown. The US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike and Europe's Greece crisis add to the uncertainty. Chinese currency instability is growing, with capital outflows estimated at $50 billion a month, and the yuan's weakness limiting the PBOC's ability to lower rates. The country's credit bubble is also at risk of swelling, with the government potentially needing to add fresh stimulus to support growth.

site_title: Mainland brokerages, asset managers driving HK office rents
summary: Chinese financial services companies are driving up office rents in Hong Kong, as some foreign banks scale back operations or seek cheaper rents to cut costs. Mainland brokerages and asset managers have leased over 148,000 square feet of prime office space in Hong Kong, a 51% increase from 2013. Chinese firms are expanding in the city, seeking lower rents and a strategic location for their internationalisation. Average rents this year are expected to rise 5%, with some firms opting for smaller spaces under 10,000 sq ft, and vacancy rates remain low at 3.7%.

site_title: Singapore bond investors back to chasing yields
summary: Singaporean bond investors are resuming their pursuit of yields after a quiet January. In the past two weeks, there have been 18 new bond deals worth S$1.5 billion, accounting for 46% of the year's total. Investors are shifting from risk-free Singapore Government Securities to high-yield corporate bonds, with the Markit iBoxx SGD corporates high yield index reaching a high of 125.7597. This trend is partly driven by a near-miss payment of a bond coupon from Chinese property company Kaisa, which heightened market volatility.

site_title: Italian lender UniCredit to sell property assets worth 2.5b euros
summary: Italian lender UniCredit plans to sell 2.5 billion euros of property assets, including office buildings, bank branches, and residential units in Italy, Germany, and Austria, to strengthen its balance sheet. The sale is part of CEO Federico Ghizzoni's plan to curb risk, reduce assets, and cut expenses. Non-binding bids are expected for a portfolio of three office buildings in Rome, with international investors showing interest in core assets. The sale is expected to generate 220 million euros in savings between 2014 and 2018.

site_title: Turkish Airlines said to be considering A380 lease from MAS
summary: Turkish Airlines is considering leasing two Airbus A380 superjumbos from Malaysia Airlines (MAS), giving the carrier a test run at the world's largest plane. MAS, which operates six A380s, no longer needs the capacity. Senior management will ask for approval from the board in coming days to enter formal talks with MAS. The move aims to expand Turkish Airlines' fleet and explore the A380's potential.

site_title: COE premiums for all car types take a dip
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums for all car types decreased in the latest round of bidding, with Category A cars experiencing the largest drop. COE premiums for cars below 1,600 cc fell from S$62,002 to S$57,199, while those for cars above 1,600 cc and open category E cars also decreased. However, commercial vehicles and motorcycles in Categories C and D saw an increase in premiums, defying the trend. The market expects a substantial increase in COE quota, but demand remains low due to financing restrictions and uncertainty over future COE prices.

site_title: Jakarta holds key to keeping S-E Asia safe in war on terror
summary: Indonesia is crucial in preventing the spread of ISIS in Southeast Asia, as the group has attracted recruits and sympathizers in Indonesia, Malaysia, and Singapore. The country's history with militant Islamic groups, such as Jemaah Islamiyah, has shown that sustained retribution and international support can help counter terrorist threats. However, the lack of laws allowing detention without trial hampers Jakarta's anti-terror efforts. Mainstream Muslim leaders must also prevent radicalization in religious schools and encourage counter-narratives to extremist preachers. Indonesia's firm stance against terror is key to preventing a second front in the war on terror.

site_title: ValueMax posts lower profit, revenue
summary: ValueMax Group, a Singaporean pawnbroker, reported a 3.9% dip in net profit to S$9 million for its full year ended Dec 31, 2014, with earnings per share falling to 1.69 cents. Revenue dropped 8.1% to S$324.5 million due to decreased sales of pre-owned jewelry and gold, while pawnbroking revenue remained stable. The company attributed the decline to challenging business environment, including rising interest rates, competition, and increasing operating costs, with shares closing half a cent higher at S$0.375.

site_title: China's growth seen slowing to between 6.9% and 7.1% this year
summary: China's economic growth is expected to slow to 6.9-7.1% this year due to sluggish demand and deflation risks, according to a central bank official. The slowdown is attributed to a sagging property market and decreased state investment. The news raises pressure on policymakers to address the issue, which could have significant implications for the country's medium-term economic prospects.

site_title: War takes its toll as Ukraine GDP plunges 15.2% in Q4
summary: Ukraine's GDP plummeted 15.2% in Q4, its worst recession since 2009, amid war devastation. The state statistics office reported the decline, excluding Crimea and areas of military operations. Ten months of fighting have destroyed infrastructure and industrial output sank 16.8% in the last three months of 2014. A ceasefire came into effect, following a US$17.5 billion bailout and truce agreement. The country's industrial base remains severely impacted, with the eastern regions generating almost a quarter of its industrial output.

site_title: Confidence among US homebuilders declines in February to four-month low
summary: US homebuilders' confidence fell to a four-month low in February, with a National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo sentiment gauge of 55, down from 57 in January. A slump in customer traffic, attributed to winter weather, led the decline. Despite this, wage growth and a strengthening job market are expected to spur demand for residential real estate. Mortgage rates remain near historically low levels, with the average 30-year fixed mortgage rate at 3.69%.

site_title: Asian dollar sukuk sales poised to set records
summary: Malaysia's state-owned oil company Petronas plans to sell up to $7 billion of Islamic notes, the largest foreign currency sukuk, which would take the total outstanding amount to $19 billion. The move is expected to set a record for Asian dollar sukuk sales and is seen as a way for Petronas to raise funds despite a slump in crude prices. Other Malaysian issuers, including Cagamas and the Export Import Bank, also plan to sell sukuk this year.

site_title: Services trade growing in importance
summary: Services trade in Singapore has grown more important, accounting for 26.7% of total trade, up from 19.7% in 2004. The trade promotion agency, International Enterprise Singapore, will now include services trade data in its reviews. Total services trade grew 2.4% last year, with services exports rising 3.6% and imports increasing 1.2%. The growth was driven by expansion in financial, travel, and business services.

site_title: Bank Indonesia unexpectedly cuts interest rate to bolster growth
summary: Bank Indonesia unexpectedly cut its main interest rate to 7.5% from 7.75% to bolster the country's economy, which has been impacted by a cooling inflation rate and falling commodity prices. The move aims to support growth ahead of potential interest-rate increases in the US, which could lead to fund outflows from emerging markets. The central bank also reduced the rate it pays lenders on overnight deposits.

site_title: Serial Q4 net up 52%, expects better 2015
summary: Serial System, an electronics components distributor, reported a 52% increase in net profit to $4.6 million in Q4 2014, driven by higher sales in its core market Hong Kong. Revenue rose 23% to $267.7 million. Executive chairman Derek Goh targets $5-10 billion in revenue within the next decade and plans to semi-retire at 65. He revealed passing up an investment in Alibaba in the early 2000s, which has since become worth over $200 billion. Serial expects better financial performance in 2015, barring unforeseen circumstances, and will focus on cost-cutting and reducing overlaps.

site_title: Politics of monetary easing likely to shrink BOJ's wiggle room
summary: Japan's Bank of Japan (BOJ) is set to meet on Wednesday amid concerns over the "politics" of monetary easing, which may limit further actions due to fears of yen falls and retaliatory actions. The yen's 30% depreciation since the BOJ's easing has hit Asian nations, including South Korea, which is facing a competitive threat from the yen's weakness. Analysts warn of the dangers of "easing wars" in Asia, with China also experiencing a strong renminbi appreciation against the yen. The BOJ may be constrained in its policy decisions due to domestic criticism and the impact on the yen, which has led to rising prices and erosion of real incomes in Japan.

images.alt_text: The Japanese flag flies over the Tokyo headquarters of the BOJ, the monetary-easing programme of which has sunk the value of the yen, and pulled down Asian economies such as South Korea's.

site_title: Koh Brothers Q4 profit slips 2%, revenue 17% higher
summary: Koh Brothers Group reported a 2% decline in net profit to S$6.2 million for the Q4 2014, due to losses from joint venture companies. Revenue increased 17% to S$102.3 million, driven by its real estate division. Gross profit rose 56% to S$14.7 million, and a special dividend of 0.3 cents per share and a final dividend of 0.5 cents per share are recommended for shareholders.

site_title: Study: Plain, non-branded cigarette packs may deter smoking
summary: A study in the journal Addiction found that plain, non-branded cigarette packs may deter non-smokers from taking up the habit and reduce the number of cigarettes smokers get through. Researchers suggest standardised packaging could lead to a decrease in smoking rates. Britain plans to introduce standardised packaging in 2016, following Australia's lead two years prior. Studies showed a decline in smoking in outdoor areas and fewer smokers leaving their packs visible after Australia's introduction. The impact on young potential smokers is likely to be the most significant initial effect.

site_title: Strong family ties are the bedrock of society: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of strong family ties in society, stating that social policies and grants alone cannot achieve this. The government has implemented initiatives such as the Marriage and Parenthood package, affordable childcare, and targeted housing grants to encourage families. Lee also urged Singaporeans to strengthen their national family and support vulnerable citizens, warning against relying too heavily on the state. He called on citizens to prioritize family connections during the Chinese New Year festival.

site_title: Foreign debt burden at heart of Russian economic worries
summary: Russian companies face significant debt repayments, estimated at US$550 billion, due to foreign debts. However, analysts suggest that the debt burden may be less than initially thought, with companies having substantial assets that can help cover repayments. In 2015, net private sector debt repayments were around US$40 billion, and many debts are actually loans from fellow Russians operating offshore. The situation is further complicated by Western sanctions and potential downgrade to "junk" status, but Russia's large foreign assets, worth almost a trillion dollars, may mitigate the strain.

site_title: NSA hides spying programs in hard drives made by top PC manufacturers
summary: The US National Security Agency (NSA) has developed a method to hide spying software in hard drives made by top PC manufacturers, including Western Digital, Seagate, and Toshiba, allowing the agency to eavesdrop on a majority of the world's computers. Kaspersky Lab discovered this capability, which was used in 30 countries, primarily targeting government and military institutions, telecommunication companies, and energy companies. The NSA's ability to conceal spyware in hard drives could further damage its surveillance capabilities and lead to greater backlash against Western technology, particularly in countries like China.

site_title: Sembcorp's Q4 profit up 7.5%, boosted by gains in utilities business
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a 7.5% profit increase in its fourth-quarter earnings to S$240.62 million, driven by gains from its utilities business, particularly in China and the UK. The utilities segment saw a 44% gain in earnings to S$109.40 million. Despite the challenges in the oil services sector due to low crude prices, Sembcorp's diversified business model helped it achieve a profit rise.

site_title: ANZ Q1 cash profit up 3.5% in tougher conditions
summary: ANZ Banking Group reported a 3.5% increase in first-quarter cash profit to A$1.79 billion, driven by a strong domestic performance. However, lower trading income and higher expenses hurt revenue growth. The bank warned that 2015 would be a "slightly tougher, more volatile" environment. Despite the challenges, ANZ's cash profit rose due to its robust domestic performance, contrasting with the more volatile international market.

site_title: Fireworks in US-China relations - in a good way for Chinese New Year
summary: US and Chinese pyrotechnicians collaborated on a Chinese New Year fireworks display in Brooklyn, showcasing the increasingly intertwined economic, cultural, and political relationship between the two countries. The display, designed by a Chinese designer and engineered by US-based Fireworks by Grucci, features Chinese-made explosives and American-made hardware. The event highlights the growing cultural exchange between the countries, with the US-China Cultural Institute promoting the display as a symbol of China's rising influence and desire to be included in the mainstream.

site_title: Transocean CEO steps down, dividend slashed on oil slump
summary: Transocean CEO Steven Newman steps down amid a decline in crude oil prices, with shares falling 76% since his 2010 takeover. The company slashes its annual dividend by 80% to 60 cents a share, aiming to conserve capital. Newman's departure comes as the energy sector faces a wave of consolidation due to the oil slump. The company's board recommends lowering its dividend, following similar moves by Diamond Offshore Drilling and Noble Corp.

site_title: Brokers temper expectations for H1
summary: Singapore brokers expect a subdued market outlook for the first half of 2015, with UOB-Kay Hian guiding for a "subdued" market. The broker's net profit rose 7.4% in Q4, driven by higher lending activity, but commission income declined 6.5%. The company recommends a 5 cents dividend, down from 6.5 cents last year, and expects interest income to rise 29% to S$32.5 million. Global market sentiment remains cautious amid geopolitical and macroeconomic concerns, with regional stock prices at historic low valuations.

site_title: German investor confidence at a high after Nov turnaround
summary: German investor confidence reached its highest level in a year in February, rising to 53.0 from 48.4, driven by the imminent arrival of central-bank stimulus and a strong German economy. The ZEW Centre for European Economic Research attributed the increase to growth at the end of last year and a gauge of current situation climbing to 45.5 in February. Despite concerns over the Ukraine crisis and Greece's new government, investors remain relatively sanguine on Greece, with a measure of expectations for the euro area rising to 52.7.

site_title: ShopBack eyes S-E Asia's US$60b e-commerce market
summary: ShopBack, a Singapore startup, is expanding into the US$60 billion e-commerce market in South-east Asia. Since its launch in August 2014, the platform has seen 50% month-on-month growth in shopping transactions and amassed 30,000 users in Singapore and Malaysia. ShopBack offers cashback rewards to users when shopping at affiliated online stores, with a 50% cashback rate on certain purchases. The company aims to tap into the region's growing e-commerce market, which is still in its early stages of development.

site_title: Fraser Centrepoint awards contracts worth S$774m
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited has awarded main contracts worth S$774 million for two projects: Frasers Tower in Cecil Street and Northpoint City in Yishun Central. The Frasers Tower contract went to Hyundai Engineering & Construction Co for S$287 million, while Lum Chang Building Contractors secured the Northpoint City contract valued at S$487 million. Both projects are slated for completion in 2018, featuring energy-efficient designs and unique concepts. Frasers Tower will have 688,000 sq ft of net lettable area, while Northpoint City will include a 920-unit residence, mall, and bus interchange.

site_title: Japan household spending drops fastest in 8 years
summary: Japan's household spending declined at its fastest pace in 8 years in 2014, falling 3.2% from the previous year, due to the country's first sales tax hike in nearly two decades and bad weather. The average household spent 251,481 yen ($2,865) per month, marking the first year-over-year decline since 2011. The government has called on companies to raise workers' pay to boost spending, as analysts point to wage hikes as key to sustaining a recovery.

site_title: Doubts over China commodity demand, local consumption led to RBA rate cut
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) lowered interest rates for the first time in 17 months due to doubts over China's demand for raw materials and domestic spending growth. The decision aims to revive confidence and encourage hiring in an economy with high unemployment. The RBA also expressed concerns over the Australian dollar's value, which is considered too high. The move is seen as a response to weak investment intentions outside the mining industry and a slowdown in China's growth.

site_title: Obama faces battle over trade deals
summary: President Barack Obama is facing opposition from a coalition of progressive Democrats and Tea-Party Republicans who oppose fast-track powers for the president, citing concerns that the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) and Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) will harm ordinary Americans. The White House and Republican leaders are mobilizing to pass the Trade Promotion Authority (TPA), which would give Congress an up-and-down vote on trade deals. The outcome is uncertain, with some Democrats demanding that the president commit to ensuring that trading partners do not engage in currency manipulation.

site_title: Robust start points to stronger year for NODX
summary: Singapore's NON-OIL domestic exports (NODX) started 2015 with a 4.3% year-on-year growth in January, exceeding expectations. The growth is attributed to a 2.8% increase in non-electronics NODX, while electronics NODX rose 0.4%. This marks a strong start for NODX, which had no growth in 2014. The International Enterprise Singapore forecasts NODX to grow 1-3% in 2015, despite a cautious outlook for the global economy.

site_title: Tsipras needs to slow ambitious timetable
summary: Greece's new Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras faces significant challenges in fulfilling electoral promises to rapidly change the country's economic management and its ties with European partners. Despite initial strong opposition to continuing talks with the "troika," officials from Tsipras' Syriza party engaged in discussions to secure bridge financing for Greece. The Greek government must navigate complex politics, find natural allies, and make compromises to remain in the eurozone, as it discovers that its efforts will be difficult and require patience.

site_title: Asian refiner margins rise, glut concerns emerge
summary: Asian refiners boost inventories, potentially ending a recent rally that lifted crude prices from six-year lows. Refining margins have risen sharply, raising concerns of a build-up in crude and oil products. The expected ramp-up of large new refineries in the Middle East and China's scaled-down buying for its strategic petroleum reserves could exacerbate the glut. Morgan Stanley and Vitol expect "large inventory builds and pricing pressure for oil markets" in the second quarter, while a slump in Chinese crude demand could hit the market in spring.

site_title: India firms disappoint with 6% earnings fall
summary: India's largest companies saw a 6% decline in earnings in the latest quarter, surpassing expectations and marking the first decline in 18 quarters. This is the third consecutive quarter of disappointing earnings, since Prime Minister Narendra Modi's election in May last year. Over half of Indian firms undershot earnings forecasts, including major companies like Reliance Industries and Tata Motors. The decline adds pressure on the Modi government ahead of its budget presentation later this month.

site_title: Bad and good news from the cruise industry
summary: The Costa Concordia captain, Francesco Schettino, was sentenced to 16 years in prison for manslaughter and other offenses related to the 2012 shipwreck. The incident led to global attention, but the cruise industry has shown resilience with predicted strong growth, with 23 million passengers expected to sail this year, a 4% increase from 2014. The Cruise Lines International Association (CLIA) released its annual report, highlighting the industry's economic importance, with a global economic output of over $117 billion and 900,000 jobs. The industry is expected to expand into new markets, including Asia and Australia, while focusing on unique design and amenities.

images.alt_text: Captain Schettino in the court during his trial in Grosseto this month. Most seem agreed that the awful shambles on board the big cruise ship that night was not just the fault of one person.

site_title: Scientists flag rise of short term ozone-eroding gases
summary: Scientists at Leeds University have raised concerns about the rise of short-term ozone-eroding gases, known as "very short-lived substances" (VSLS), which deplete the Earth's protective ozone layer. These gases, including man-made chemicals not covered by the UN treaty, pose a significant threat to the ozone layer. Researchers have highlighted the impact of VSLS through two computer models, emphasizing the need for urgent action to address this environmental issue.

site_title: Indonesia's central bank cuts rate to spur growth
