Independent local artists and foreign artists, such as Korean sculptor Park Seung Mo, have created various works, including paintings, sculptures, and prints, often expressing admiration for the founding father of modern Singapore. Despite Lee Kuan Yew's personal dislike of "hagiography," some artists view their tributes as a way to pay respect and gratitude.

site_title: Low-margin project drags Boustead Q3 net down 36%
summary: Boustead Singapore reported a 36% decline in net profit to S$11.8 million in its Q3 2014 results due to a low-margin large property project. Revenue increased 37% to S$177.9 million, with the real estate solutions segment contributing significantly. The company proposed spinning off its real estate solutions segment to unlock value for shareholders. Despite a challenging business climate, Boustead has a healthy balance sheet and net cash position, enabling it to ride out the cycle and capture opportunities.

site_title: UOB Q4 net profit up 1.7% to S$786m
summary: UOB Group reported a 1.7% increase in Q4 net profit to S$786 million, driven by broad-based growth across core income streams. This brings its full-year profit to S$3.25 billion, a new high and an 8% increase from last year. Total income rose 11% to S$7.46 billion, led by healthy loan growth and higher trading and investment income. The group's liquidity and funding position remained sound, with a steady loan-to-deposit ratio and stable asset quality. The board recommended a final dividend of 50 cents and a special dividend of five cents per share.

site_title: Accordia Golf's DPU 9.6% below forecast on weaker yen
summary: Accordia Golf Trust (AGT) posted a lower-than-forecast distribution per unit (DPU) of 3.91 Singapore cents for the period from Aug 1 to Dec 31, 2014, due to a weakening Japanese yen. The trust's distributable income of 3.9 billion yen (S$44 million) exceeded forecast by 1%. AGT plans to acquire golf-course related assets valued at 50 billion yen in Japan by end of March 2017 to drive DPU growth, targeting a 50 billion yen asset under management (AUM) growth.

site_title: Bills on use of underground space tabled
summary: The Singapore government has tabled two Bills to clarify the use of underground space, aiming to facilitate planning and development. The State Lands (Amendment) Bill specifies the maximum depth of underground space a landowner can use, up to 30m below the Singapore Height Datum. The Land Acquisition Act will be amended to allow for the development of public projects requiring specific strata of space. Both Bills will be debated in Parliament before a vote.

site_title: JLL: S'pore office-rent growth strongest, home price fall largest in Asia-Pac in 2014
summary: Singapore recorded the largest price decline in luxury residential markets in the Asia-Pacific region in 2014, with luxury home prices falling 6.1% year-over-year. Meanwhile, office rents in the central business district (CBD) jumped 14.9% year-over-year, making it the strongest growth in the region. The market is expected to see an ongoing price correction, with weak buyer sentiment and new supply contributing to the decline.

site_title: 'Papa' Pez dispenses sagely advice
summary: Singapore artist Jeffrey Koh created sculptures of Pez candy dispensers with the head of Lee Kuan Yew, the country's founding father, dispending advice instead of candy. The project, titled "Papa," took half a year to complete and was sold out, with prices ranging from S$950 to S$2,200. Koh aimed to raise awareness about Mr. Lee's contributions to modern Singapore and is apolitical but respects his legacy. The sculptures are now available for sale through Flabslab's Facebook page.

site_title: UN aviation agency eyes support for crash victims' families
summary: The United Nations' International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) is recommending that states provide support to families of victims of air disasters, including assistance with obtaining visas to access accident sites and repatriation of remains. The recommendation, which is not mandatory, aims to strengthen support for crash victims' families and send a message that states should care for their citizens. The move comes as ICAO members debate strategies for preventing planes from being shot down or disappearing in conflict zones. The recommendation is part of a broader effort to improve emergency preparedness and response.

site_title: 26 big China state firms to be probed this year
summary: China's top anti-corruption watchdog will inspect 26 major state-owned firms, including PetroChina, China Telecom Group, and China National Nuclear Corp, after the Chinese New Year holidays. The inspections aim to curb corruption and keep those in power "in awe." The move is part of President Xi Jinping's crackdown on corruption, following the removal of over 70 senior officials at state firms in 2014. The inspections will also focus on financial institutions and backbone state-owned firms.

site_title: PAS spiritual leader Datuk Nik Aziz dies
summary: Datuk Nik Abdul Aziz Nik Mat, a spiritual leader of the PAS party in Malaysia, died at his home in Pulau Melaka on Thursday evening at 9:40 pm. He was 84 and had been readmitted to the hospital due to prostate cancer. Nik Aziz, who was a prominent figure in Malaysian politics, served as the Kelantan government for 23 years and remains popular among supporters despite his passing.

site_title: Europe still favoured for yields and international firms
summary: European stocks are seen as a buying opportunity due to high dividend yields of 3.5% and the presence of international companies. Despite the possibility of a Greek default, fund managers believe the region's relatively strong balance sheets and surplus cash will help companies navigate a deflationary environment. European earnings growth expectations are low, but may surprise positively due to corporate activity, a lower euro, and pricing power. Key stocks to consider include BMW, Continental, Unilever, and Ashtead, which benefit from a weak euro and international presence.

site_title: Aerospace industry shifts manufacturing investment to US
summary: The aerospace industry is shifting manufacturing investments to the US, reversing a decade-long trend of production jobs flowing to China and other emerging economies. According to a study by ICF International, 28 US manufacturing investments were made between 2012 and 2013, compared to eight in China and eight in Mexico. This shift is driven by companies like Boeing and Airbus, which are reducing outsourcing and increasing in-house production to reduce costs and offset falling inflation-adjusted plane ticket prices.

site_title: Netflix faces some challenges to its global ambitions
summary: Netflix faces challenges expanding globally as it seeks to overcome cultural barriers and compete with local streaming services. The company has successfully launched in 50+ countries but faces competition in Europe, where it has struggled to match its US offerings. Complaints of uneven selection and the absence of popular shows like House of Cards have led some viewers to use virtual private networks to access the US version. Despite efforts to address these issues, Netflix's European expansion remains a significant challenge.

images.alt_text: NETFLIX already streams popular films, television series and, increasingly, its own original entertainment to 57 million subscribers in more than 50 countries.

site_title: Rising price of cocoa forces chocolate makers to charge more
summary: The price of cocoa has surged, forcing chocolate producers to raise prices and reduce package sizes. This increase in costs affects Valentine's Day chocolate sales, making kisses potentially more expensive. To cope, some manufacturers are offering thinner bars or fewer chocolates per package, providing a lower-priced option.

site_title: Credit Suisse boosts asset cuts amid concerns over capital
summary: Credit Suisse boosted its asset cuts to boost capital, citing concerns over stricter leverage requirements in Switzerland. The bank posted a 921 million franc net income in Q4, up from a 476 million franc loss in the previous year. Credit Suisse cut bonuses and executive pay, and proposed a 70 US cent per-share dividend, payable in cash or stock. The bank aims to reduce its Tier 1 capital to assets ratio to 4% by year-end and cut its total leverage exposure to 930-950 billion francs.

site_title: Swiber wins US$310m contract
summary: Swiber Holdings, an offshore construction and support services provider, secured a US$310 million engineering, procurement, construction, installation and commissioning (EPCIC) contract from a national oil company in South Asia, marking its second-largest contract win.

site_title: Wilmar sees stable earnings this year as Q4 profit rises 8.7%
summary: Wilmar International reported a 8.7% increase in Q4 net profit to US$401 million, driven by strong profitability in its palm and laurics segment. The company attributed the growth to lower feedstock costs and stable downstream businesses. Despite a 12.3% decline in full-year profit, Wilmar guided for stable and resilient earnings this year. The company proposed a final dividend of S$0.055 and reported a 66% drop in pre-tax profit for its oilseeds and grains segment.

site_title: A new breeze is blowing in Indian politics
summary: The Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) has achieved a historic victory in the Delhi assembly elections, winning 67 of 70 seats and reducing the BJP's count to three and the Congress to zero. The AAP's focus on improving the lives of the poor and dispossessed resonated with voters, who were also drawn to the party's clean image and straight campaign. The BJP's attempts to discredit the AAP backfired, and the party's national appeal appears to be diminishing. The AAP's victory has significant implications for Indian politics, with some analysts predicting a new kind of politics emerging in the country.

site_title: Sembmarine keeps itself on an even keel
summary: Sembcorp Marine reported a 1% increase in net profit to S$560 million for the year ended Dec 31, 2014, driven by a 6% growth in group turnover to S$5.8 billion. The rig building sector contributed to the higher revenue, with eight jack-up rigs delivered and another 10 in the work in progress or planning stage. Despite a 12% decline in associate and joint venture income, the company secured S$4.2 billion in new contracts and maintained a total outstanding order book of S$11.43 billion.

site_title: Hedge funds exiting housing mortgage debt as prices rise
summary: Hedge funds that invested in residential mortgage debt after the 2008 financial crisis are reducing their bets as housing prices rise. Returns at these funds averaged 10.2% last year, down from 13% in 2013. Firms such as Pine River Capital Management and Canyon Partners are exiting investments in uninsured and government-backed home loan securities to seek higher returns through private equity funds or direct property purchases, like single-family rental houses. This shift indicates a changing market sentiment as rising housing prices reduce the potential for significant gains.

site_title: Global oil layoffs top 100,000 as job pilgrims' dreams shatter
summary: Global oil layoffs have surpassed 100,000, with job losses impacting workers in Australia, Brazil, and other countries. The decline in oil prices, now below $50 a barrel, has led to widespread job cuts, with some companies announcing spending cuts of over $40 billion. Workers in the commodities industry, including engineers and oil rig staff, are facing uncertainty and pressure to find new jobs, with many considering relocation. The situation is particularly dire in Australia, where energy companies are delaying or canceling projects, leaving workers without employment.

site_title: Robots can build cars; now they're learning not to crush you
summary: Robots are advancing in their ability to interact safely with humans, with companies like ABB, Fanuc, and Kuka introducing new sensors that reduce the risk of injury. These sensors enable robots to mimic human movements, learn from humans, and even recognize and interact with people. The electronics industry is a key target for robot adoption, with estimates suggesting 500,000 robots could be needed by 2020. The growth of robotics is attracting new players, including tech giants like Google and Amazon, which see robots as a "great opportunity" for the next 20-30 years.

site_title: SIA to lower fuel surcharges from Feb 26
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will lower its fuel surcharges for tickets issued from February 26, following a trend of carriers cutting surcharges due to sharply lower jet fuel prices. Fuel surcharges will decrease by US$5 to US$83 per sector, depending on distance and cabin class. The move aims to reduce fuel costs, which accounted for nearly 40% of SIA's operating expenses in the third quarter. Other airlines, such as Qantas and Japan Airlines, have already removed or reduced fuel surcharges.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will cut its fuel surcharges for tickets issued from Feb 26 onwards, joining a list of carriers that have already done so in light of sharply lower jet fuel prices.

site_title: Top tech execs to skip Obama cybersecurity summit
summary: Top tech executives from Google, Yahoo, and Facebook will not attend President Barack Obama's cybersecurity summit, instead sending their top information security executives. The companies have clashed with the Obama administration over government spying and protecting user privacy. The summit aims to combat hackers, improve cybersecurity, and establish a national standard for data breaches. Apple's CEO Tim Cook will attend, while other tech industry representatives, including Microsoft and MasterCard executives, will participate in a break-out panel. The White House has announced an executive action to encourage companies to share information across industry sectors.

site_title: Thailand approves 77.23b baht investment deals
summary: Thailand's investment agency approved 23 projects worth 77.23 billion baht, mainly in renewable energy and aviation, in a bid to boost the country's economy. The projects include 11 renewable power plants and eight aviation deals worth a combined 65 billion baht. The approval comes after the military seized power in May to end months of political turmoil and aims to accelerate project approval to encourage private investment. The Board of Investment has also introduced new policies to promote high-value-added sectors and provide tax exemptions to investors.

site_title: Mist of half-truths hanging over Greece
summary: Greece's debt crisis has been misinterpreted as an insurmountable challenge, with investors demanding high risk premiums. However, a closer examination reveals that Greece's debt is manageable, with 75% held by public agencies offering favorable terms. Greece's debt servicing costs are relatively low, averaging 4.3% of GDP, and the country has returned to economic growth. The European Commission is softening its stance on budgetary discipline, and debt rescheduling and coupon reductions may be feasible. A backtracking Greek government may receive more favorable concessions, but a hard stance could lead to a eurozone crisis and potentially even Greece's expulsion from the eurozone.

site_title: Talks to continue after Greece, eurozone fail to clinch debt deal
summary: Greece's new leftist government and eurozone finance ministers failed to reach an agreement on a debt deal after seven hours of talks in Brussels. Talks will resume on Monday, with markets hoping Athens will secure bridging finance. Economists debate the prospects of Greece exiting the euro, while international creditors continue to pressure the nation for a solution to its massive debt repayment problem.

site_title: Swiss govt drafts law for EU immigration quota
summary: The Swiss government has proposed a draft law to limit EU immigration following a successful referendum, but plans to engage in talks with the EU to avoid violating treaties on free movement of people. The proposed law would set yearly limits for EU workers, favoring Swiss nationals in hiring, with exceptions for difficult-to-fill jobs. The move follows criticism from industries reliant on EU skilled workers, and the government seeks to balance its response to the referendum with EU obligations.

site_title: Bunker supplier implicated in OW scandal loses licence
summary: Singapore's Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) has revoked the bunker-supply and bunker-craft operator licences of two companies, Tankoil Marine Services and Hong Fatt Oil Trading, for breaches of their licence terms. The move follows an investigation into the companies, which revealed discrepancies and wrongful declarations in their records and transfers of bunker between tankers without approval. The ban bars the companies from operating as bunker suppliers and bunker craft operators in the Port of Singapore. This is a further twist in the OW Bunker scandal, which has hit the bunker trade globally.

site_title: Swiss bank's problems erode HSBC's profit and reputation
summary: HSBC's Swiss private bank, which had a $553 million profit in 2008, saw a significant drop in profits, falling to a loss in 2013. The bank's number of accounts decreased from 30,000 in 2007 to 10,343 in 2014. HSBC admitted to failings in compliance and controls, and has since transformed its Swiss business to prevent tax evasion and money laundering. The bank has shed clients who did not meet new standards and spent more on compliance. HSBC's profits have fallen every year since 2008, with the bank attributing the decline to poor integration after its 1999 purchase of Republic National Bank of New York and Safra Republic Holdings.

site_title: City Buzz
summary: Alain De Botton's "Essays In Love" is a thought-provoking book about love that explores its complexities through a realistic and philosophical lens. The book, reissued by Picador Classic, tells the story of a man and a woman who meet on a flight and experience the full arc of falling in and out of love. Meanwhile, online florist You And No Other offers a unique and pricey Valentine's Day option, where customers can order flowers with a lifelong commitment clause. Italian restaurant Procacci has introduced a new Valentine's Day menu and offers a three-course meal for S$180++. The Gathering outdoor festival features eight bands on Valentine's Day, and Uli Jon Roth's Sky Academy clinic offers a unique music experience for couples.

site_title: Ex-CEO of China Sky to pay civil penalty, give up 10% of his shares
summary: Former China Sky Chemical Fibre CEO Huang Zhong Xuan has agreed to pay a civil penalty of S$2.5 million and give up 10% of his shares after admitting to making misleading public disclosures and failing to disclose required information to the market, breaching the Securities and Futures Act. The settlement, agreed upon with the Monetary Authority of Singapore, will benefit existing China Sky shareholders and raise the net asset value per share. Huang has also agreed not to serve as a director or be involved in the management of any Singapore-listed entity for three years.

site_title: Charity concert to raise funds for 6 groups
summary: A charity dinner and concert, "Love from the STARS," will be held in Singapore on May 10 to raise S$6 million for six local beneficiaries, including elderly care and children with cancer. The event, sponsored by corporates and featuring international stars Jackie Chan, Wakin Chau, and Jonathan Lee, marks Singapore's 50th birthday (SG50). Singapore Power is the main sponsor and presenter, committing S$500,000, and Singapore Press Holdings is the media partner. The funds raised will support six local charities, including All Saints Home and the VIVA Foundation for Children with Cancer.

site_title: Go paperless, reduce broking commissions,
summary: A Singaporean investor urges the Singapore Exchange to adopt a novel method of calculating brokerage charges based on investment size, rather than the current minimum commission. This change would benefit small investors who face high fees. Additionally, the author suggests eliminating paper statements and switching to online statements unless customers request otherwise, citing environmental benefits and cost savings.

site_title: Cautious bids again for EC site tender
summary: Singapore's latest executive condo (EC) site tender in Woodlands saw seven bids, with top bidder Hao Yuan Investment offering S$277.98 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr). This is the lowest bid since July 2011. Developers are cautious in their bids due to lower projected sale prices for ECs, with some estimating breakeven costs between S$600 and S$640 psf. The tender comes amid a growing stock of unsold EC units, with 2,400 launched and 6,000 in the pipeline.

site_title: Changi Airport must retain personalised services amid technology push, says transport minister
summary: Changi Airport must maintain personalized services despite the push for technology, said Minister for Transport Lui Tuck Yew. The airport plans to roll out more self-service options, but will prioritize warm and personalized services. Changi Airport is working on strengthening its position as a regional hub with the construction of Jewel and Terminal 4, which may cause temporary disruptions. The airport group has assured that safety will not be compromised during construction. Personalized services remain constant despite transformational changes, with 24 awards given to exceptional staff for their exemplary service.

site_title: Abe urges Japanese firms to pass along benefits of Abenomics via higher basic pay
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe urged employers to raise workers' wages to pass on the benefits of Abenomics, as the Tokyo stock market reached a seven-year high and the yen fell to its lowest in a month. Analysts see personal consumption as the missing link in Japan's recovery, and higher wages are necessary to boost consumer spending. This comes as the yen's decline is expected to further increase firms' export profitability, following a surge in corporate performance.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers' take on Singapore REITs. CIMB Research downgrades Far East Hospitality Trust to "reduce" due to weak Q4-14 results and intense competition in the mid-tier hotel segment. DMG & Partners maintains "buy" on Croesus Retail Trust, citing strong Q2-15 revenue and NPI growth. UOB KayHian holds ComfortDelGro Corp, citing promising fundamentals but a 20% year-to-date rise in stock price.

site_title: Qatar Airways raises capacity, brings in A350
summary: Qatar Airways is expanding its presence in Singapore by introducing the Airbus A350, starting with one aircraft on June 16, and progressively replacing its Boeing 787s. The airline will offer 36 business class seats, up from 22 on its B787, and increase overall capacity by 67% to over 11,880 seats weekly. This move aims to cut down transit time for passengers connecting to Europe and the US, and is expected to attract more corporate traffic.

site_title: Working 18 hours a day for 2 1/2 months on each figurine
summary: Singaporean figurine maker Christopher Pereira spent 18 hours a day for 2 1/2 months creating a single figurine of Lee Kuan Yew, a labor-intensive process that yielded 40 unique designs. Pereira aims to differentiate himself and preserve Lee Kuan Yew's legacy. The figurines, priced from S$200 to S$10,000, are available for sale on his Facebook page, with plans to open his own Minister Mentor Museum once financially stable.

images.alt_text: Mr Pereira started making his LKY figurines in 2009, drawing on his experience working as a designer at Universal Studios in Singapore and Los Angeles.

site_title: 1MDB close to sealing deal with Krishnan
summary: 1MDB, a state-owned investment company in Malaysia, is close to agreeing on a deal with billionaire Ananda Krishnan to raise cash and repay debt. The company, which is led by Prime Minister Najib Razak's advisory board, plans to announce the deal by next week. Krishnan may take a stake in energy assets or provide a loan to help 1MDB repay a RM2 billion loan owed to several lenders. The agreement could pave the way for listing Edra Global Energy Bhd and reduce borrowings. 1MDB's debt stood at RM41.9 billion as of March 2014.

site_title: No bubble or overvaluation yet, says tech investor
summary: Tech investor Tim Draper says the world is not in a tech bubble, despite high valuations of companies like Apple and Snapchat. Draper notes that individual investors are valuing "interesting" tech companies fairly, but warns that overvaluation may occur in the future. He emphasizes the importance of a long-term approach for big corporations to partner with venture capitalists and invest in startups, citing that incubation periods of at least three years are required for success.

site_title: Flood of global liquidity depresses Australian yields
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) cut interest rates to a record low of 2.25% in February 2015 due to a flood of global liquidity, which has depressed Australian yields. This has eroded the country's competitiveness, with foreign funds pouring money into Australia's booming services sector and commodity-rich economy. As a result, Australian government bonds now pay less than the overnight cash rate, and yields on 10-year paper have fallen to 2.38%, a record low. The effects are felt across the economy, with the insurance industry and small investors struggling to find attractive returns.

site_title: Ministers slam WP MPs for 'dereliction of duties'
summary: Singapore's National Development Minister Khaw Boon Wan criticized the Workers' Party-run Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council for financial mismanagement and incompetence. The government plans to amend laws to give greater oversight and enforcement powers over town councils. A plan is also to withhold service and consultancy charges grants worth S$7 million until problems are fixed. The government aims to strengthen the town council framework, holding MPs accountable for running their town councils.

site_title: Nam Cheong Q4 hit by lower margins
summary: Nam Cheong, a Malaysian offshore marine group, reported a 42% year-on-year slump in net profit to RM41.1 million for Q4 2014, driven by falling gross and operating profit margins. Revenue jumped 29% to RM523.9 million, with the shipbuilding segment posting a 32% surge in revenue.

site_title: Retro groove
summary: LongPlay, a vinyl-only bar in Singapore, has opened its doors to offer a unique music experience. Located between Haji Lane and Arab Street, the bar features a 3,000-record library spanning various genres. Patrons can enjoy live music and curated playlists by veteran DJ Marvin Kam, who also runs a consultancy firm for bars and F&B establishments. The bar's design by Neri&Hu features dark wood, steel, and concrete, with vinyl-inspired steel tables and leather upholstered seats. Drinks are inspired by music, and the menu includes cocktails named after iconic musicians and songs.

site_title: China prepares for Chinese New Year
summary: China is preparing for Chinese New Year, with 1.3 billion people expected to travel, shop, and celebrate with family and friends on February 19. The holiday is expected to generate 2.8 billion trips, including 295 million on trains, and spending is estimated to reach 610.7 billion yuan (S$132.9 billion). The People's Bank of China is taking measures to ensure liquidity, including injecting cash into the system, to mitigate the impact of increased spending. The holiday also coincides with a week of initial public offerings, which may further strain the economy.

images.alt_text: Migrant workers riding home for the upcoming Chinese New Year in Fengkai county, Guangdong province. About 2.8 billion trips will be made, according to government estimates.

site_title: Can China's economy function without corruption, some wonder
summary: China's anti-corruption campaign, launched by President Xi Jinping, is slowing the country's economy due to officials' reluctance to make decisions without bribes. Over 100,000 officials have been disciplined since the campaign began, and many more are hesitant to act, fearing investigations and loss of promotions. This has led to stagnating projects and a decline in investment, particularly in luxury goods and high-end services. Economists debate whether the campaign will ultimately make China's economy more efficient, but others argue it will have a lasting negative impact on economic growth.

site_title: Volatile trading hits CAO's Q4 earnings
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a 67.2% drop in Q4 earnings to US$4.43 million due to volatile oil trading conditions. Revenue remained largely unchanged at US$4.32 billion, while trading volumes increased 54.3% to 3.95 million tonnes of jet fuel. The company also took provisions for doubtful debts and impairment losses, leading to a 50.5% decline in share of profits from associates. For the full year, CAO's net profit fell 30% to US$49.2 million.

site_title: China's new home prices bottomed in Jan after 8-month fall: surveys
summary: China's new home prices appear to have bottomed in January after an 8-month decline, with some developers raising prices in major cities like Shanghai and Chongqing. Industry surveys suggest prices may have risen 0.64% in first- and second-tier cities and 0.2% nationwide. While a recovery is patchy, the central bank's rate cut and reserve requirement adjustments have boosted confidence. However, prices may still slide in February due to the Chinese New Year holidays. Any modest rise in new home prices could be positive for sentiment, as the property industry accounts for 15% of China's GDP.

site_title: Views on improving S'pore's stock market
summary: The Securities Association of Singapore (SAS) has expressed its views on improving Singapore's stock market, following an appeal letter from remisiers to Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam. SAS agrees that the market needs to function effectively and supports measures to protect investors' interests, including increasing transparency and liquidity. The association suggests that sustained investment of domestic pension monies and a minimum public offer size of at least 25% could benefit the market. SAS also opposes the establishment of a third board for long-suspended counters and continuous all-day trading, citing concerns about exposing investors to potential losses.

site_title: NTU to set up structural biology research lab
summary: NTU is launching the NTU Institute of Structural Biology (NISB) with a $30 million investment, led by Professor Daniela Rhodes. The institute will employ over 70 researchers and be equipped with cutting-edge tools, including a cryo transmission electron microscope. The facility aims to tackle pressing health problems such as aging and cancer by understanding protein structures at the atomic level. The NISB will be modeled after the MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology in the UK and will be part of NTU's Life Sciences cluster.

site_title: Whippersnapper and the whip
summary: The film adaptation of 50 Shades of Grey, directed by Sam Taylor-Johnson and starring Dakota Johnson and Jamie Dornan, has received largely negative reviews. Despite its explicit content, the movie fails to live up to the expectations of its 100 million fans, with wooden performances, laughable dialogue, and a lack of chemistry between the leads. The film's inability to convey the intensity and power of the original book's imagination has led to a disappointing cinematic experience. The movie has been rated C- by critics.

site_title: RHB Capital managing director resigns
summary: RHB Capital's managing director, Kellee Kam, has resigned after more than three years at the helm of the Malaysia-based financial services group. His departure comes after the company canceled a merger plan with two other banks. Kam will serve a three-month notice period. The resignation follows a period of significant change in the Malaysian banking sector, including the retirement of OCBC's CEO and the appointment of a new CEO, Tan Teck Long.

site_title: Pound near 7-year highs on BOE inflation report
summary: The Bank of England's quarterly report has lifted sterling to seven-year highs, with investors factoring in a potential interest rate hike in early 2016. The report stated inflation will return to its 2% target in two years, and BOE governor Mark Carney expects a rate increase. Sterling rose to US$1.5340, while gilt yields surged. In Asia, several currencies slumped, including the Indonesian rupiah, Malaysian ringgit, and Singapore dollar, amid uncertainty over a Greek debt deal and economic forecasts.

site_title: No right time to remove tax breaks for Reits
summary: Singapore's tax breaks for Real Estate Investment Trusts (S-Reits) are set to expire on March 31, 2015. The government is expected to decide on extending these concessions in the upcoming Budget 2015. The tax breaks have been instrumental in the growth of the S-Reit market, with 28 listed S-Reits and a total market capitalization of S$67 billion. Industry players and investors are anxious about the fate of these tax breaks, with some arguing that they should be extended or redefined to maintain Singapore's lead in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Singapore's legal sector: The fight for market share
summary: Singapore's legal sector continues to experience growth, but faces challenges from increased competition and pricing pressure. Clients are seeking flexible fees, more practice area specialisms, and better regional coverage, driving firms to adapt their offerings. Pricing pressure has become a significant challenge, with clients increasingly looking for cost-effective lawyers. New entrants to the market, such as UK firms Simmons & Simmons and Reed Smith, are gaining traction, but face competition for top talent. Meanwhile, firms are expanding into niche areas, including TMT and insurance law, to meet client demand for greater specialism.

site_title: Banks, Jardine, ComfortDG push STI down
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 25.4 points to 3,419.17, driven by selling of ComfortDelGro, Jardine stocks, and three banks. High volume trading contributed S$1.3 billion to turnover, led by United Engineers, Singtel, and ComfortDelGro. The decline was attributed to investors selling stocks after a rise in anticipation of results.

site_title: Apple bans bonded labour at supplier factories worldwide
summary: Apple has banned bonded labor at supplier factories worldwide, requiring suppliers to pay recruitment fees for employees instead of charging them to new hires. The company, which has faced criticism for worker conditions, conducted 633 audits covering 1.6 million workers in 19 countries and found that 92% of workers complied with a 60-hour workweek limit. Apple aims to improve working conditions and combat human rights issues, with the company bearing the costs of recruitment fees.

site_title: Norway's SWF buys 45% stake in Times Square office tower
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund (SWF) acquired a 45% stake in the 40-storey office tower 11 Times Square in midtown Manhattan for $1.4 billion, becoming the largest foreign property buyer in America after Canada. This deal marks the fund's latest push into US real estate, with a target to invest 5% of its assets in properties. The purchase comes as foreign investors continue to snap up NYC real estate, driving prices to records.

site_title: F&N posts Q1 earnings of S$35.2 million
summary: Frasers and Neave (F&N) posted a net profit of S$35.2 million for the first quarter ended Dec 31, 2014, down 77.6% from the previous year. Excluding exceptional items, continuing operations' net profit was S$35.7 million, a 0.8% decrease. Revenue rose 9.7% to S$655 million, driven by growth in beverages and dairies sectors. However, printing and publishing revenue fell 3% due to lost print titles and lower print volume. The company's earnings per share fell to 2.5 cents.

site_title: US challenges sweeping Chinese export subsidies
summary: The US launched a legal challenge to Chinese export subsidies, targeting billions of dollars of exports in industries such as steel, shrimp, and medical products. US Trade Representative Michael Froman claimed Chinese companies received unfair advantages through free services, cash grants, and other incentives. The request for consultations marks the first step in a World Trade Organization dispute. The US estimates suppliers received over $1 billion in support from the Chinese government over three years, affecting industries and thousands of families.

site_title: On a global search for yield
summary: Investors are seeking yield in cyclical stocks, as valuations of these assets are at a 10-year low relative to defensives. Reits, typically seen as yield-focused, are considered pricey due to forex loss and hedging cost risks. Despite this, Eastspring Investments' Margaret Weir is buying Reits like Hutchison Port Holdings Trust, citing increasing port throughput and room for tariffs to increase. She's also looking at other cyclical stocks, such as telcos and Chinese banks, and notes that valuations are becoming increasingly hard to find due to low interest rates and loose monetary policies.

site_title: Ong Beng Seng-linked company negotiating sale of dormitory
summary: A privately-owned vehicle linked to Hotel Properties' managing director Ong Beng Seng is negotiating the sale of Homestay Lodge, a 6,000-bed dormitory in Kaki Bukit, for approximately S$125 million. The property, completed in 2001, sits on 200,000 square feet of land with a 14-year remaining lease term. Several parties, including property fund manager Pamfleet Group, have expressed interest in the asset, which offers high yields due to the acute shortage of dormitory space and increasing bed rates.

site_title: Whistleblower says he tried to alert British tax officials in 2008
summary: A former HSBC employee, Herve Falciani, has claimed he attempted to alert British tax officials in 2008 about tax evasion by the bank's Swiss arm. However, he said he received no response. The leaked documents, shared with authorities in 2010, have led to a scandal and criticism of the tax authority's handling of the information. British officials have recovered 182 million euros in taxes, but only one prosecution has been made. The leak has also raised questions about Prime Minister David Cameron's appointment of HSBC's former head as trade minister.

site_title: Biosensors Q3 profit falls 33%, hit by lower licensing revenue
summary: Biosensors International reported a 33% fall in net profit to $7.44 million in Q3 2015, driven by lower licensing revenue and unfavorable foreign exchange impact. Revenue declined 6% to $77.5 million, with product revenue remaining relatively unchanged. Licensing and royalties revenue from Terumo decreased 46%. Despite weaker results, CEO Jose Calle noted improvement in operations following cost reduction measures and expects cautious outlook due to competition, pricing pressure, and currency fluctuations.

site_title: Goldman pushes for investment treaty with China
summary: Goldman Sachs is urging the US to quickly complete an investment treaty with China, seeking to open the country's market to American banks and firms. The financial giant is pushing ahead despite concerns from Silicon Valley companies about the potential use of Chinese technology by state-owned firms. The move comes after a letter from 51 US CEOs, including Ford and Wal-Mart, calling for action on the treaty. Goldman Sachs' Asia-Pacific chairman, Mark Schwartz, believes the moment for a deal is now, and the company will host a conference with US and Chinese executives to drive home the need for action.

site_title: Chinese drone maker sees sales doubling
summary: Chinese drone maker SZ DJI Technology Co plans to double sales in 2015 as it pushes for clearer regulations on unmanned flights. The company is working with the US and Chinese governments to establish rules for commercial and recreational drone use. With 2,800 employees and a valuation significantly higher than its 2014 valuation, DJI aims to capitalize on growing demand for drones in various industries.

site_title: Chan: Movies come first, family later
summary: Jackie Chan, the 60-year-old actor and film director, is set to be released from jail on February 13, but his release won't be a family affair. Chan prioritizes his film career, stating that movies come before family for him. He is currently promoting his latest film, Dragon Blade, a $65 million historical martial-arts epic, and has a busy regional tour ahead. Chan's co-stars, including John Cusack and Adrien Brody, praise his generosity, work ethic, and human side, which belies his action hero image.

site_title: Stiff upper-lip sleuthing
summary: The film "Kingsman: The Secret Service" is a spy spoof that combines cool and crude elements, showcasing a cheeky and entertaining storyline. Directed by Matthew Vaughn, the movie follows a young agent, Eggsy Unwin, as he joins the secret spy agency Kingsman to take on a megalomaniacal villain, Richmond Valentine. The film features a mix of action, humor, and references to other spy movies, with a focus on attitude and entertainment value. With a talented cast, including Colin Firth and Taron Egerton, "Kingsman" is a fun and unpredictable ride, despite some inconsistencies.

site_title: Rowsley investing US$275m in Myanmar real estate tie-up
summary: Rowsley, a Singapore-listed firm, has invested US$275 million in a 50% stake in a Myanmar real estate project, HAGL Myanmar Centre, in Yangon. The project includes a mixed development with office blocks, a hotel, retail mall, and residential apartments. Rowsley's CEO, Lock Wai Han, sees the project addressing Yangon's severe shortage of top-grade office space, hotels, and modern malls. This investment is Rowsley's first real estate deal after switching to an integrated real estate group, and it joins other Singapore firms, such as Oxley Holdings and Keppel Land, betting on Myanmar's booming real estate market.

site_title: Tiong Woon's Q2 profit down; Sin Heng's earnings up
summary: Tiong Woon Corporation reported a 57% fall in net profit for its Q2 due to lower oil prices and decreased revenue. Its gross profit fell 27% to S$12.7 million. In contrast, peer Sin Heng Heavy Machinery's net profit jumped 15,500% to S$4.81 million, driven by a gain from the sale of a rental crane and lower operating expenses. The companies attributed the differing results to the decline in oil prices and its impact on the construction industry.

site_title: M'sia Q4 economy defies oil slump to grow 5.8%
summary: Malaysia's economy grew 5.8% in the fourth quarter of 2014, its fastest pace in four years, driven by strong construction and manufacturing activity. However, analysts expect the full impact of weaker global oil and gas prices to hit the economy in the coming months. Strong growth may help mitigate dissent over opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim's imprisonment, but the government faces pressures over debt and a sovereign downgrade risk. Full-year growth was 6%, exceeding forecasts.

site_title: BOE sees strong growth but ready to cut rates if needed
summary: The Bank of England expects stronger economic growth due to lower oil prices, but sees little need to raise interest rates this year. Governor Mark Carney anticipates inflation to fall below zero in the coming months, but notes that this doesn't necessarily indicate deflation. The BOE may even cut interest rates if inflation proves weaker than expected, indicating a cautious approach to monetary policy.

site_title: LKY of heroic proportions
summary: Singaporean caricaturist Chan Shiuan has created a series of digital prints featuring Lee Kuan Yew, the country's founding father, in various fictional characters, including Yoda and Magneto. The 27-year-old artist quit her job as an air stewardess to pursue full-time art in 2013, and her debut project was well-received, resulting in 150 back-orders. The prints, priced at S$10, feature Lee Kuan Yew's likeness digitally rendered on A3 canvases, with the artist aiming to make his likeness accessible to everyone.

site_title: Wine fraud website in April to track the real McCoys
summary: Wine consultant Maureen Downey is launching a website, Winefraud.com, in April to educate fine wine lovers on how to spot counterfeit bottles. The site will feature tutorials, a gallery of authentic wines for comparison, and expert advice on identifying fake wines. Downey estimates the value of counterfeits sold by convicted wine counterfeiter Rudy Kurniawan to be around $130 million, with the total value potentially reaching hundreds of millions of dollars. The website will offer subscription-based levels, with fees in the hundreds of dollars, to provide collectors with expert authentication and insider information on fake wines.

site_title: M'sian biodiesel producers want level playing field with Indonesia
summary: Malaysian biodiesel producers are seeking new incentives from the government after Indonesian makers of the biofuel were promised a significant increase in subsidies. The move comes as biodiesel demand took a hit due to lower crude oil prices, wiping out profit margins for blending palm oil into diesel. Malaysian representatives are set to meet the plantation industries and commodities minister to discuss tax incentives or other measures to support the ailing sector, which is struggling to compete with Indonesia's subsidies.

site_title: IMF chief unveils 4-year US$40b aid programme for Ukraine
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde announced a 4-year aid program worth US$40 billion for Ukraine, with nearly half coming from the International Monetary Fund. The program includes US$17.5 billion from the IMF and additional resources from the international community. Ukraine agreed to implement reforms, including energy tariff increases, bank restructuring, and anti-corruption measures, to stabilize its finances. The program aims to support Ukraine's economic growth and address the country's deep recession and financial struggles.

site_title: New job numbers challenge Fed, GOP
summary: The US economy has shown signs of gaining momentum, with the creation of over a million new jobs in the last three months, the most impressive three-month gain in nearly 20 years. Average hourly earnings rose 0.5% last month and 2.2% over the past year, suggesting that wage stagnation may be ending. The Labor Department report also indicates that the labor force grew by 700,000 as more Americans returned to work, edging up the unemployment rate from 5.6% to 5.7%. This development challenges the Republican narrative that President Obama's policies were responsible for the weak recovery, and may force the party to modify their campaign messages.

site_title: Will it be Boyhood or Birdman?
summary: The 87th Academy Awards are set to take place on February 22, with "Birdman" and "Boyhood" vying for Best Picture. Both films have dominated awards season, with "Birdman" winning acting and technical awards, and "Boyhood" sweeping Best Actress and Supporting Actress categories. Richard Linklater and Alejandro G. Inarritu are in a two-horse race for Best Director, while Michael Keaton and Eddie Redmayne are contenders for Best Actor. Julianne Moore is a likely winner for Best Actress, and JK Simmons is favored for Best Supporting Actor.

images.alt_text: Linklater's guts, vision and determination to film - for two weeks every summer over 12 consecutive summers - the otherwise normal story of a boy growing up, ageing naturally along with other members of his family in the film Boyhood (above) puts him neck-and-neck with Inarritu who directed Michael Keaton in Birdman, a film based on a quirky tale about a washed-up Hollywood star in search of redemption on the Broadway stage.

Linklater's guts, vision and determination to film - for two weeks every summer over 12 consecutive summers - the otherwise normal story of a boy growing up, ageing naturally along with other members of his family in the film Boyhood puts him neck-and-neck with Inarritu who directed Michael Keaton in Birdman (above), a film based on a quirky tale about a washed-up Hollywood star in search of redemption on the Broadway stage.

site_title: US Dec business inventories rise less than expected
summary: US business inventories rose 0.1% in December, less than expected, suggesting a slower fourth-quarter growth pace. This could lead to a revised GDP growth estimate of as low as 1.7% when the government publishes its revision later this month. Meanwhile, business sales fell 0.9% in December, and consumer spending barely rose in January, indicating a softer start to the first quarter. Despite this, economists expect robust employment gains and cheaper petrol prices to provide a stimulus to consumer spending.

site_title: PAS spiritual leader Nik Aziz dies
summary: Former PAS spiritual leader Datuk Nik Aziz Nik Mat, 84, has died on Thursday evening after suffering a stroke and prostate cancer. Nik Aziz, born on January 10, 1931, was a prominent figure in Malaysian politics, serving as Kelantan Mentri Besar for 23 years. He was a key figure in PAS and a renowned Islamic scholar. Nik Aziz passed away at the Universiti Sains Malaysia Hospital in Kubang Kerian, with his son confirming the news on Twitter.

images.alt_text: Former Kelantan Mentri Besar Datuk Nik Aziz Nik Mat has died on Thursday evening. He was 84.

site_title: Honda CEO battles to stay on the job for another two-year term
summary: Honda CEO Takanobu Ito is resisting efforts to oust him for his radical overhaul of the company's traditional supply chain, with some former executives and suppliers criticizing his focus on cutting costs and finding new technologies. Ito, who took over in 2009, has been under pressure since mass recalls over quality issues and has faced opposition from retired executives who want him removed. Despite the criticism, Ito is determined to see his reforms through and has a 70% chance of keeping his job, according to a Honda divisional head.

site_title: US Dec business inventories disappoint
summary: US business inventories rose 0.1% in December, less than expected, supporting views of slower-than-expected fourth-quarter growth. Inventories are a key component of GDP and their contribution to growth may be lowered by at least 0.5 percentage points. The trade deficit was also larger than estimated, and business sales fell 0.9% in December, the largest drop since January 2014. The inventory-to-sales ratio is at its highest level since 2009, suggesting businesses may cut back on inventory in the months ahead. This may lead to a revised GDP growth estimate of as low as 1.7% for the fourth quarter.

site_title: Consumer sentiment declines for 2nd straight week
summary: Consumer confidence in the US declined for the second consecutive week, falling to a five-week low of 44.3 in the period ended Feb 8. The decline is attributed to Americans' perceptions of their finances and the economy, despite increased employment opportunities and signs of wage growth. The Bloomberg index of consumer comfort also decreased, with a gauge of sentiment among Americans in the South reaching a six-week low. Despite this, confidence among those earning $75,000-$100,000 per year reached its highest level since July 2007.

site_title: GLP takes yen-denominated loan in currency hedge move
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has signed a 5-year, 20 billion yen (S$227 million) loan to hedge against long-term currency exposure in Japan. The loan has a fixed interest rate of 1.02% per annum and will be used for general corporate funding requirements. GLP's CFO, Heather Xie, stated that the company will maintain financial stability and flexibility to pursue growth opportunities amid volatile global currency markets. The loan provides a lower cost of funding, further reducing the company's long-term currency exposure.

site_title: Banks & regulators must counter tax cheats and stay business-friendly
summary: HSBC has faced a new tax evasion scandal, with documents revealing its Swiss subsidiary facilitated tax evasion and money laundering for clients from over 200 countries, including politicians and corporate executives. The bank has acknowledged past compliance failures and overhauled its private banking business, but faces intense pressure and potential fines. Regulators are calling for investigations, and the scandal raises concerns about data security and client confidence. To balance anti-money laundering efforts with competitive business services, institutions must strike a balance between raising barriers and maintaining services for legitimate clients.

site_title: ECB raises pressure on Greece as Tsipras meets EU peers
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) urged Greece to extend an international bailout deal or risk a bank collapse, as new Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras met with EU leaders. The ECB's Governing Council discussed keeping Greek banks afloat, and ECB executive board member Peter Praet signaled that the central bank could cut emergency liquidity assistance if Greece fails to reach a deal with creditors. Greece's tax revenues fell short of the budget target, and the country's bailout expires at the end of the month, potentially leading to a Greek exit from the euro zone and wider financial turmoil.

site_title: Pop Art iconography a hit with collectors
summary: Sukeshi Sondhi, a Singapore-based Indian painter, has gained popularity with her Pop Art-style screenprint paintings of Lee Kuan Yew, titled "An Icon and a Legend." The collection features multiple depictions of the former Singapore Prime Minister, emphasizing his iconic status. Sondhi's works have been a hit with collectors, with some purchasing multiple pieces to gift to others. Her paintings range from S$800 to S$5,000, available for purchase via her website. The collection highlights the artist's connection to Singapore and her admiration for Lee Kuan Yew's charisma.

site_title: Singtel posts solid Q3 results with help from regional associates
summary: Singtel posted an 11% increase in net profit to S$970 million in Q3, driven by growth in Singapore, Australia, and regional markets. The telco's mobile customer base grew 9% to 543 million, and mobile data revenues increased with better networks, technology, and content. Despite a weaker Australian dollar, the company's Ebitda was stable, and the group's combined mobile customer base saw a 28% increase in pre-tax earnings from associates. The company's share price rose 4 cents to S$4.18, with revenue and Ebitda expected to remain stable for the rest of the year.

site_title: US retail sales weak, consumer spending gauge barely up
summary: US retail sales increased 0.1% in January, barely rebounding from a 0.3% drop in December, suggesting slow economic growth at the start of the first quarter. Despite cheaper gasoline prices and robust employment gains, households are prioritizing debt repayment and savings over discretionary spending. Core retail sales, which accounts for most of consumer spending, fell short of economists' expectations. The economy added over a million jobs in the past three months, but growth remains sluggish due to sputtering growth in Asia and Europe.

site_title: Europe: Stocks up on Ukraine truce
summary: European stocks reached multi-year highs on Thursday, driven by a Ukraine peace agreement, Swedish economic stimulus measures, and hopes for a Greek debt deal. Germany's DAX rose 1.8% and France's CAC 1.1%, while Sweden's OMXS30 index hit a record high. The Greek stock market also surged 4.3% as investors awaited a deal with international creditors. The pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index rose 0.8% and the Euro STOXX 50 index advanced 1.5%. The agreement between Germany, France, Russia, and Ukraine aimed to end fighting in eastern Ukraine.

site_title: Chow Tai Fook to invest US$2.6b in S.Korean casino resort
summary: Hong Kong-based Chow Tai Fook Enterprises Ltd plans to invest US$2.6 billion in a casino resort near South Korea's Incheon airport, targeting Chinese tourists. The project, set to be built in two stages between 2015-2019 and 2019-2022, will include a foreigner-only casino, hotel, shopping, and entertainment facilities. The investment is part of South Korea's efforts to expand its casino industry, which has seen a surge in Chinese tourists, with over half of its business coming from Chinese visitors. Approval from the central government is expected this year.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher after Ukraine peace deal
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by hopes of a Ukraine peace deal, despite disappointing retail sales and unemployment data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 32.88 points to 17,895.02, while the S&P 500 gained 8.86 to 2,077.39. A ceasefire agreement was reached in Minsk after marathon negotiations involving France, Germany, Russia, and Ukraine. However, German Chancellor Angela Merkel warned that much work remains to ensure the deal's success. US retail sales fell 0.8% in January, and new unemployment claims jumped to over 300,000.

site_title: Europe at 'turning point' in bailout row,warns Tsipras
summary: Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras warned that Europe is at a critical crossroads as he prepares to discuss the country's bailout at a Brussels summit. Tsipras said Greece must prove it can find a solution, respect democracy, and combine it with European rules. He will confront European leaders, particularly German Chancellor Angela Merkel, with Greece's demands to change its bailout. Tsipras claims his government has a plan that can satisfy both Greeks and European partners, focusing on structural reforms and growth. A make-or-break meeting is set for Monday.

site_title: China to keep growth in reasonable range this year
summary: China aims to maintain its economic growth within a reasonable range in 2015, according to the Politburo. The central bank has warned of strong headwinds to growth and is prepared to fine-tune policies to prevent a downturn. This comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. The Politburo has reaffirmed a prudent monetary and fiscal policy approach for the year.

site_title: US jobless claims up more than expected
summary: US jobless claims rose 25,000 to 304,000 for the week ended Feb 7, exceeding economists' forecasts of 285,000. Despite this, the four-week moving average of claims fell to 289,750, indicating a strengthening labor market. The economy has added over 1 million jobs in the past three months, and labor market slack reached its lowest level since 2007 in December.

site_title: Lum Chang Q2 profit doubles on gains from weaker ringgit
summary: Lum Chang's Q2 net profit more than doubled to S$7.25 million due to a currency gain of S$1.98 million linked to the weaker ringgit. This is a result of translating the company's ringgit-denominated payables, which reversed the S$516,000 loss from the previous year. Gross profit rose 19% to S$13.9 million as revenue declined less than costs.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets were steady at the open on Thursday, despite Greece's bailout talks breaking up without an agreement. London's FTSE 100 edged up 0.06%, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 dipped 0.05%. The CAC 40 index in Paris slipped 0.20%. The markets await the European Union summit in Brussels, where Greece will feature, along with discussions over the Ukraine crisis and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks down at the close of trading
summary: Malaysian shares declined at the close of trading, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 9.88 points to 1,789.07. The trading volume reached 1.68 billion lots, valued at RM2.51 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 436 to 326.

site_title: Bangkok: Stocks close marginally higher
summary: Bangkok's stock market closed marginally higher on Thursday, with the SET Index rising 0.52 points to 1613.40. This marks a slight increase from the previous day's close. The market's performance was not significantly affected by global economic trends, including US-EU trade talks and rising US stock records.

site_title: Sweden sets interest rate below zero
summary: Sweden's central bank set its base interest rate to -0.1% to combat stagnant price levels, aiming to bring inflation closer to its 2% target. The move is a radical step to prevent deflation, as prices have been stagnant since 2012. The bank will buy 10 billion kronor (US$1.18 billion) in government bonds to encourage investment and lending, and lower the cost of lending in Sweden. However, some economists expressed concerns about household debt levels and potential risks of bad investments.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine Q4 profit down 4.6%, rig building revenue falls
summary: Sembcorp Marine Ltd reported a 4.6% decline in Q4 net profit to S$174.05 million, mainly due to lower rig building revenue. The company's full-year profit was S$560.13 million, beating forecasts. A final cash dividend of 8 cents per share was declared, up from 6 cents last year.

images.alt_text: Singapore's Sembcorp Marine Ltd said on Thursday its net profit in the fourth quarter fell 4.6 per cent, as revenue from rig building activity dropped and as the year-ago quarter was boosted by a tax write-back.

site_title: Boustead Q3 net profit down 36% despite revenue increase
summary: Boustead Singapore reported a 36% decline in net profit to S$11.8 million for its third quarter, despite a 37% revenue increase to S$177.9 million. The drop was attributed to a large design-and-build project with low margins. The company's shares closed at S$1.805, up 0.5 cent.

site_title: Oil bounces back towards US$56
summary: Oil prices rebounded to US$56 a barrel, rising over US$1, after a two-day decline due to a weaker dollar and industry spending cuts. Analysts attribute the rebound to a softer dollar making dollar-priced commodities cheaper for holders of other currencies. Volatility in the oil market has increased, with prices swinging in a wide range this month. French oil major Total announced cost-cutting measures to cope with weaker oil prices, while US crude stocks reached a record weekly high.

site_title: Taiwan recovers last missing victim of TransAsia crash
summary: Taiwanese rescuers recovered the remains of the last missing passenger in the TransAsia plane crash, bringing the death toll to 43. The plane crashed into a river on February 4 after take-off from Taipei's Songshan airport, killing 15 people. Investigations are ongoing to determine the cause of the crash, with initial findings suggesting pilot error may have played a role. The airline's pilots were temporarily banned from flying after failing a flight skills test, and the airline will cancel 44 flights on Friday. Compensation for the victims has been offered by the airline.

site_title: Hilton Worldwide to buy 5 hotels for US$1.76b
summary: Hilton Worldwide agreed to buy 5 hotels, including San Francisco's Parc 55, for US$1.76 billion using proceeds from the sale of New York's Waldorf Astoria. The acquisitions include two hotels in Orlando, Florida, and two in Key West, with the goal of accelerating room-revenue growth in these markets. Hotel occupancies in these areas have outperformed the US average, making them attractive targets for Hilton's expansion. The deal is expected to close this month, with the remaining US$100 million from the Waldorf sale used to purchase additional properties within the next six months.

site_title: Courts Asia's Q3 profit hit by soft retail market, ringgit weakness
summary: Courts Asia reported a 35.8% fall in Q3 net profit to S$4.02 million, due to weaker sales in Singapore and Malaysia, and currency losses linked to the ringgit's weakness. Revenue fell 5% to S$193 million. The company incurred higher finance expenses, including 34.3% more interest from a syndicated loan in Malaysia. The decline is attributed to a softer retail market and exchange losses.

images.alt_text: FURNITURE store Courts Asia on Thursday reported a 35.8 per cent fall in net profit for its fiscal third quarter amid weaker sales, and currency losses linked to the ringgit.

site_title: Sin Heng Q2 profit leaps amid stronger margins
summary: Sin Heng Heavy Machinery reported a significant jump in Q2 net profit to S$4.81 million, driven by a gain on disposal of property, plant and equipment and stronger gross margins. This represents a 15,325% increase from the same period last year. Gross profit rose 43% as revenue outpaced costs, while "other operating expenses" fell due to lower unrealised fair value losses on forward currency contracts.

site_title: Singapore: Shares close lower
summary: Singapore shares fell 25.40 points to close at 3,419.17 on Thursday, marking a lower day. The market saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, but ultimately declined. Losers outnumbered gainers 301 to 152. Volume was 1.03 billion shares worth S$1.26 billion.

site_title: Hao Yuan tops bids for Woodlands EC site
summary: A 99-year leasehold executive condominium site in Woodlands, Singapore, attracted seven bids, with Hao Yuan Investment securing the top bid of S$103.79 million (S$278 per square foot per plot ratio). The second-highest bid was from Allgreen Properties at S$99.98 million (S$268 per square foot per plot ratio). The site can accommodate an estimated 390 EC units, with the lowest bid from KBD Ventures at S$70.9 million.

site_title: Wilmar Q4 profit up 8.7% to US$401m
summary: Wilmar International reported a 8.7% increase in net profit for the fourth quarter, reaching US$401 million, driven by better performances in key segments and associate contributions. Revenue fell 7.3% to US$10.8 billion, mainly due to lower average selling prices in consumer products.

images.alt_text: WILMAR International on Thursday said net profit for the fourth quarter rose 8.7 per cent, "riding on better performances in most key segments as well as higher contributions from associates".

site_title: Thailand eyes fast trains to tourist hotspots
summary: Thailand plans to build high-speed railway links connecting Bangkok to tourist destinations like Pattaya and Hua Hin, modeled after Japan's bullet trains. The Thai government, led by Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha, is seeking funding from the state and private sector to stimulate growth in the economy, which has struggled since a military coup last May. The proposed rail project, valued at 400 billion baht (US$12.23 billion), is seen as a strategic move to boost trade and tourism, with China expected to provide funding and support.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Thursday
summary: Singapore Wrap Thursday: Key stories include Vietnam's surprise at US Trump tariff announcement, the Asian garment industry's concerns about higher tariffs, and Malaysia's plan to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, while Citigroup sets a mid-2026 target for the MSCI global equity index. Additionally, Thaksin Shinawatra is confident his daughter will be cleared in an ethics case, and the Asean region has downplayed the significance of Myanmar's upcoming election. The UK economy also shrank for the second month in a row.

site_title: Seoul to launch premium taxi service to take on Uber
summary: Seoul plans to launch a premium taxi service in August to compete with Uber, adding to the challenges faced by the US company in the fourth-largest Asian economy. The city government will partner with taxi associations to launch the service with 200 luxury and mid-sized sedans, and promote services connecting users with registered taxis via smartphone apps. The move comes after Seoul spurned Uber's driver registration proposal and reiterated its pledge to ban the company. This is the latest in a series of challenges Uber faces in South Korea, where it has been battling bans in other cities.

site_title: Taiwan: Shares end higher
summary: Taiwan's shares rose 0.36% on Thursday, closing at 9,496.31, driven by a 34.09-point increase. The weighted index surpassed the previous day's close.

site_title: Parliament: Current COE bidding system allows for flexibility
summary: The current COE bidding system in Singapore allows for flexibility, with both car dealers and individual buyers able to place bids. This system, according to Senior Minister of State for Transport Josephine Teo, remains the most flexible approach.

site_title: Biosensors posts 33% fall in Q3 net profit to US$7.44m
summary: Biosensors International reported a 33% fall in Q3 net profit to US$7.44 million, mainly due to lower licensing revenue and unfavorable foreign exchange impact. Total revenue slid 6% to US$77.5 million, while product revenue remained relatively unchanged. Despite this, the company's operating income broke a stagnant growth pattern, with improvements in operations following cost reduction measures. CEO Jose Calle attributed the weaker results to licensing revenue and foreign exchange, but noted sales growth in key divisions, including the Cardiac Diagnostic segment and Terumo distribution business.

site_title: Korean Air boss' daughter guilty of breaking aviation law in 'nut rage' case
summary: A South Korean court found Heather Cho, daughter of Korean Air Lines chairman Cho Yang-ho, guilty of breaking aviation law after ordering a flight to return to the gate due to the way she was served nuts in first class. Cho, former head of in-flight service, was convicted on charges of violating the Aviation Law and faced a potential three-year prison term. The court's sentence is expected to be announced soon.

site_title: Ex-CEO of China Sky to pay civil penalty of S$2.5m, give up 10% of shareholding
summary: Former China Sky Chemical Fibre CEO Huang Zhong Xuan will pay a S$2.5 million civil penalty and surrender 10% of his shareholding after admitting to making misleading public disclosures and failing to disclose required information. The settlement will benefit existing China Sky shareholders and increase the net asset value per share. Huang has also agreed not to assume a company director role for three years. The offer is expected to be approved by China Sky's board of directors, following an investigation by the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close up 0.44%
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.44% to close at 24,422.15, following gains in Shanghai and despite a weak US lead. The benchmark Hang Seng Index added 107.13 points to its value, with turnover reaching HK$73.28 billion. Mainland China's Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also rose, driven by gains in the mining and healthcare sectors.

site_title: Singapore Q4 GDP growth seen likely to be revised higher
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to have grown 1.7% in the fourth quarter, higher than the initial estimate of 1.5%, according to a Reuters poll of 11 economists. The growth rate, based on an annualized, seasonally-adjusted basis, is also expected to be 2.1% from the third quarter. This revision is due to better-than-expected manufacturing output in December. The full-year 2014 GDP growth is forecast to be 2.9%, down from 3.9% in 2013, while 2015 growth is expected at 3%. The revised GDP data will be released on February 17.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close at seven-year high
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index closed at a seven-year high, reaching 17,979.72, after a weak yen and upbeat machinery order data lifted the market. The Topix index also rose 1.52%, driven by concerns about floundering Greek debt talks being shrugged off by investors. This marks the best close since late July 2007.

site_title: SIA to cut fuel surcharges for tickets issued Feb 26 onwards
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will reduce fuel surcharges on tickets issued on or after February 26, 2015. Fuel surcharges will decrease by $5-$83 per sector, depending on distance and class of travel. This move comes as fuel prices have declined in recent months, with jet fuel accounting for a significant portion of SIA's expenditure.

site_title: Malaysia growth quickens in pick-up that may already be waning
summary: Malaysia's economy unexpectedly accelerated to 5.8% growth in the fourth quarter of 2014, beating estimates of a 5% increase. However, the pickup is likely to be short-lived due to a weakening currency and potential default by the state investment company. Private consumption and investment have driven growth, but exports are slowing due to low oil prices. The economy is projected to expand 4.5-5.5% this year, down from an earlier forecast of 6%.

site_title: Delays, flight disruption as Paris airport workers strike
summary: Paris airport workers, represented by the CGT union, went on strike to protest a salary freeze amidst the company's reported net profit of at least 358 million euros. The 24-hour strike began on Thursday, causing delays and flight disruptions at Roissy-Charles de Gaulle airport, with 20% of flights expected to be postponed or cancelled on Friday. The strike comes months after a similar work stoppage by Air France pilots, and employees are demanding a share of the profit.

images.alt_text: Paris airport workers were due to go on strike on Thursday to protest a salary freeze, in a work stoppage that will lead to delays and flight disruption.

site_title: China eases rules on foreign banks' yuan trades
summary: China's foreign exchange regulator, SAFE, has eased rules allowing foreign banks without full yuan business licenses to buy or sell foreign currencies against the yuan. Foreign banks can now open special yuan accounts for currency dealings and withdraw cash. However, each bank's outstanding funds in its yuan account cannot exceed 20% of its registered capital or operational capital. This move aims to boost the yuan's global clout, but analysts expect gradual changes to its full convertibility.

site_title: Seoul: Won falls to more than 5-wk low; shares hit by Greek woes
summary: The South Korean won fell to a five-week low, reaching 1,110.7 to the dollar, amid uncertainty over Greece's debt future and global risk aversion. South Korean shares also declined, with the KOSPI index closing 0.21% lower. The decline follows similar drops in regional peers, as investors shunned riskier assets.

site_title: Malaysia's GDP growth picks up to 5.8% year on year in Q4
summary: Malaysia's GDP growth accelerated to 5.8% in Q4 2014, exceeding expectations, according to the country's central bank. This marks the fourth quarter of growth, indicating a strong economic performance. The data suggests Malaysia's economy is resilient and capable of withstanding external economic challenges.

site_title: Global oil layoffs top 100,000 as job pilgrims' dreams shatter
summary: Global oil layoffs have surpassed 100,000, affecting workers in oil-related businesses worldwide, particularly in Australia, Brazil, and Scotland. The decline in oil prices has led to job cuts, with companies such as BP and Royal Dutch Shell announcing spending cuts of over $40 billion. Workers in the commodities industry are facing uncertainty, with many being laid off or forced to take unpaid leave. The situation is expected to worsen, with oil prices projected to drop to the $20 range by April, according to Citigroup.

site_title: Malaysia says will not extend tax exemption for palm oil exports after Feb
summary: Malaysia will not extend its zero export duty policy on crude palm oil after February and will announce a new tax regime on February 16. The export tax rates will depend on palm oil prices when the duty resumes in March. The country aims to spur demand and reduce bloated stockpiles.

site_title: Angry Birds fly into Singapore to teach preschoolers
summary: Angry Birds, the popular mobile game, has partnered with a Singapore preschool to launch an interactive educational program for kindergarten children. The "Angry Birds Playground" features a giant indoor treehouse, touch screens, and educational games based on the Finnish National Curriculum. Developed with partners like NASA and National Geographic, the program aims to make learning fun and engaging for children aged 3-6. The preschool, Dreamkids Kindergarten, expects classes to start filling up from mid-March, marking the fourth global location for the Angry Birds Playground.

site_title: Tankoil among two bunker suppliers banned from operating in Singapore
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has revoked the bunker supplier and bunker craft operator licences of Hong Fatt Oil Trading and Tankoil, effective February 9, 2015. The move was taken after routine checks revealed discrepancies and wrongful declarations in records kept on board their bunker tankers. The companies were found to have breached terms and conditions of their licences, including transfers of bunkers without approval. MPA will take firm action against any licensee who acts in contravention of their licences, including suspending or revoking their bunker licences.

site_title: Parliament: Singapore to amend Town Councils Act
summary: Singapore's government plans to amend the Town Councils Act to strengthen regulatory oversight and enforcement, addressing weaknesses in the current framework. The amendments will clarify that town councils are subordinate to public law and government agencies, improve corporate governance and financial accountability, and introduce stricter penalties for non-compliance. The changes aim to ensure accountability and safeguard residents' interests. Senior Minister Lee Yi Shyan will table the bill after next month's Committee of Supply debate.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall for a fourth straight session
summary: Australian shares fell 0.44% on Thursday, their fourth consecutive drop, due to weakness in banks, resources, and consumer staples. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 25.5 points to 5,743.6, while New Zealand's NZX 50 index fell 0.7%. Muted earnings guidance from major companies also contributed to the decline.

site_title: China: Stocks rise for fourth straight day, led by telecom shares
summary: China's stocks rose for the fourth consecutive day, led by telecom shares, after the central bank improved short-term liquidity. The CSI300 index gained 0.3% to 3,442.87, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.5% to 3,173.42. However, thin trading volume suggests investor caution in a slowing economy.

site_title: Korean Air heiress jailed in 'nut rage' case
summary: Cho Hyun-Ah, daughter of Korean Air's chairman, was jailed for one year for her involvement in the "nut rage" incident, where she forced a flight to return to the gate after being served macadamia nuts she didn't want. The incident sparked a public backlash against South Korea's elite business families. Cho had pleaded not guilty to most charges but was found guilty of violating aviation safety law and obstructing justice. The sentence was seen as a rare punishment for those in the country's powerful chaebol families, who often appear above the law.

site_title: IMF, Ukraine in preliminary deal for US$17.5b aid
