summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and Ukraine have reached a preliminary deal on a new financial rescue plan worth $17.5 billion, according to IMF Chief Christine Lagarde. The agreement, which includes an extended fund facility, aims to support Ukraine's economic reform program. The deal is seen as a significant step towards stabilizing the country's economy amid ongoing conflict.

images.alt_text: The International Monetary Fund and conflict-torn Ukraine have reached a preliminary deal on a new financial rescue plan worth US$17.5 billion, the organisation's chief Christine Lagarde said on Thursday.

site_title: Update: Asia-Pacific partners help power up Singtel profit
summary: Singtel, a Singapore Telecom, reported a 11.2% increase in third-quarter net profit to S$970 million, driven by higher mobile data revenue and contributions from mobile partners in Australia and elsewhere. Revenue rose 3.8% to S$4.43 billion. The company's combined mobile customer base reached 543 million, up 9.0% from the previous year. Singtel's share of post-tax profit from associates, including Telkomsel in Indonesia and Bharti Airtel in India, increased 29% to S$458 million.

site_title: Chinese mobile data usage to make great leap forward
summary: Chinese mobile data usage surged 49% in 2014, reaching 200 megabytes per user, a modest average compared to global standards. The country's biggest carrier, China Mobile, expanded its 4G coverage to over 90 million subscribers. Domestic smartphone makers like Coolpad, Lenovo, and ZOPO offered affordable 4G handsets, while Apple and Samsung focused on premium segments. By 2017, 4G-capable devices are expected to triple to 405.9 million units, with rural areas driving demand as technology becomes more affordable.

site_title: Japan's Rakuten Q4 operating profit rises 73%, beats estimates
summary: Japan's Rakuten Inc reported a 73% increase in operating profit for its October-December quarter, beating analyst estimates. The company's profit rose to 33.28 billion yen, surpassing the 31.2 billion yen average estimate. This growth was attributed to sales growth at its shopping portal and Internet finance division. Despite this, Rakuten's shares ended 0.36% lower ahead of the earnings release.

site_title: Update: NTU announces S$30m institute focused on finding healthcare cures
summary: NTU announces a new S$30 million institute focused on structural biology research to find cures for human diseases. The NTU Institute of Structural Biology (NISB) will be operational in 2016 and will utilize cutting-edge imaging equipment to study protein molecules. Led by Daniela Rhodes, a renowned expert in the field, the institute aims to resolve pressing health problems such as ageing and cancer through groundbreaking drug and vaccine discoveries. The grant for the institute was secured by Rhodes in 2013.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB said to be in final stages of talks with Ananda Krishnan
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB is close to agreeing on a deal with billionaire T. Ananda Krishnan to raise cash to repay debt, with final details still being discussed. The state-owned investment company, led by Prime Minister Najib Razak, plans to announce the agreement by next week. The deal may involve Ananda taking a stake in energy assets or providing a loan, helping 1MDB repay a RM2 billion loan owed to several lenders, which will come due at the end of February.

site_title: Credit Suisse says introducing measures to deal with strong franc
summary: Credit Suisse has introduced measures to deal with the strong Swiss franc, citing a 3% net adverse impact on profit in 2014. Despite this, the bank's fourth-quarter net profit exceeded analyst estimates at 921 million Swiss francs (US$991.07 million). CEO Brady Dougan expects the measures to more than offset the impact by the end of 2017.

site_title: Malaysia's Q4 current account surplus narrows to RM6.1b
summary: Malaysia's current account surplus narrowed to RM6.1 billion in Q4 2015, down from RM7.6 billion in the previous quarter. Net direct investment posted an outflow of RM0.2 billion, while net portfolio investment outflow totaled RM20.4 billion. These results contrast with previous quarters, indicating a shift in the country's economic dynamics.

site_title: Broker's take: Nomura reiterates 'buy' call on Singtel
summary: Nomura Research has reiterated its "buy" call on Singtel, citing growth and improvement in the company's fiscal third-quarter results. The Australian wireless business showed a 4% service revenue growth year-on-year, driven by increased average revenue per user and subscription growth. Singtel's Singapore business experienced mixed trends, while associate earnings have found stability, up 4% quarter-on-quarter and 24% year-on-year. Nomura maintains its target price of S$4.30 for the stock, which was up 0.24% at S$4.15 following the announcement.

site_title: NTU sets up new S$30m institute of structural biology
summary: Nanyang Technological University (NTU) has established a new S$30 million institute of structural biology, the NTU Institute of Structural Biology (NISB), to advance life sciences research in Singapore. The institute, set to open in 2016, will be led by international expert Daniela Rhodes and feature state-of-the-art imaging instruments. The institute aims to promote innovation and breakthroughs in healthcare through multidisciplinary collaborations and will initially be funded by a S$24 million Ministry of Education research grant.

site_title: Oil prices rise in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices rose in Asian trade, with US West Texas Intermediate increasing 64 cents to $49.48 and Brent crude gaining 34 cents to $55.00, but gains were capped due to concerns about US stockpiles. Analysts, including Michael McCarthy, attributed the optimism to market sentiment, but noted that fundamentals remain unchanged.

site_title: Gold ticks up from 5-wk low as Greek debt drama unfolds
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,220 an ounce after hitting a five-week low, driven by uncertainty over Greece's debt negotiations with European lenders. The metal is seen as a safe-haven asset, and its recovery suggests markets are expecting a positive outcome or discounting Greece's possible exit from the euro zone. The US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike in June may further strengthen the dollar and hurt demand for gold.

site_title: China: Shares mixed in morning trade
summary: Chinese shares were mixed in morning trade on Thursday, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 0.17% to 3,152.39, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.10% to 1,534.93. The decline was attributed to cautious investor sentiment ahead of the Chinese New Year holiday.

site_title: Icahn values Apple at more than US$1 trillion
summary: Activist investor Carl Icahn has valued Apple at more than $1 trillion, suggesting the stock should trade at $216 per share, significantly higher than its current price. This valuation, based on a 20 times price-to-earnings ratio and Apple's net cash of $22 per share, would make Apple worth $1.3 trillion. Icahn, who owns 53 million shares worth $6.5 billion, believes this valuation is conservative, particularly if Apple introduces a TV in the near future.

site_title: Gold rebounds from one-month low as Greek talks reach impasse
summary: Gold prices rebounded from a one-month low after European leaders failed to agree on Greece's bailout programme, with bullion rising 0.4% to $1,223.57 an ounce. The impasse risks leaving Greece without funding by the end of this month, when the current bailout expires. Despite a stronger dollar and prospects for higher US rates, gold climbed 3.3% this year due to the Greek crisis and stimulus in Europe and Asia. Talks on the bailout programme will resume next week.

site_title: Rio Tinto plans US$2b buyback as H2 profit dives
summary: Rio Tinto plans a US$2 billion share buyback despite reporting a 30% decline in second-half profit. The move comes as the miner faces pressure to please investors amid a slump in iron ore prices. Underlying earnings fell to US$4.19 billion, above analysts' forecasts of US$3.76 billion. Rio Tinto's Australian shares have fallen 10.3% over the past year, but the company's buyback aims to boost investor confidence and ward off a potential takeover from rival Glencore.

images.alt_text: Global miner Rio Tinto said it would return $2 billion to shareholders through a buyback despite reporting a 30 per cent slide in second-half profit on Thursday, its worst half year profit in two years.

site_title: Honda betting what's popular in China also sells well in Japan
summary: Honda is launching the Jade minivan in Japan, initially designed for China's extended families, with a focus on flexible fold-down space for camping or golf clubs instead of third-row seats. The car features anti-collision technology and a hybrid powertrain. Sales begin on Feb 13, starting at 2.72 million yen. This move reflects China's growing importance to global car sales, with Honda planning to sell the Jade in other Asian markets. The trend is seen as a shift from modifying US or European models for other markets.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.26% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.26% higher on Thursday, following a 0.26% drop in the previous session. The Hang Seng Index rose 62.57 points to 24,377.59. The gains were attributed to a lack of significant news, allowing traders to recover from the previous day's losses.

site_title: Ringgit extends declines as Greece concern damps risk appetite
summary: Malaysia's ringgit fell to a one-week low after European lawmakers failed to agree on a bailout plan for Greece, dampening risk appetite and concern about the nation's potential default and exit from the euro. The currency dropped 0.5% to 3.6185 a dollar, its lowest level since February 3, and has lost 2% in four days. Despite a 5.9% GDP growth in 2014, the nation's economy is expected to moderate due to the oil price slump and softer global outlook.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly down as Greece talks break up
summary: Asian markets declined, with most equity markets falling after Greece's bailout talks broke up without agreement. Japan's Nikkei rose 1.78% due to a yen retreat against the dollar. Eurozone finance ministers failed to reach a deal on Greece's 240 billion euro EU-IMF rescue program, which expires at the end of February. The euro slipped, while the US dollar held above 120 yen. Analysts predict the US Federal Reserve may hike interest rates by mid-year, boosting the dollar.

site_title: Tesla CEO Musk says market cap could match Apple's US$700b by 2025
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk predicts the company's market capitalization could reach $700 billion by 2025, matching Apple's, based on 50% annual revenue growth and a price-to-equity ratio of 20. Musk also forecasts Tesla's revenue to grow to $6 billion this year, up from $3.2 billion in 2014. The production of Tesla's Model 3 is expected to begin by the second half of 2017.

site_title: Hot stocks: Rowsley, Swiber rise on corporate deals; Singtel on active trade
summary: ROWSLEY Ltd and Swiber Holdings Ltd rose in morning trading after securing corporate deals, with Rowsley shares up 2.6% at 19.9 Singapore cents and Swiber shares up 1.1% at 18.5 cents. Singtel also edged up one cent to S$4.15 on active trade, following an 11% rise in third-quarter net profit.

site_title: Quick take: Eurogroup on Greece disappoints: ABN AMRO
summary: The Eurogroup, a gathering of European finance ministers, failed to reach an agreement on how to keep Greece's bailout funds flowing, disappointing expectations. The meeting was two hours late and lacked a clear plan for next steps. Despite this setback, economists believe a long-term deal is possible, with key elements including a new reform program, debt relief, and a lower primary surplus target. Talks will resume next week, and a new deal is expected to be based on the current bailout program, with some differences in wording.

site_title: Amazon.com rival Jet.com raises US$140 million in new funding
summary: Jet.com, an Amazon rival, raised $140 million in new funding, increasing its cash reserves to take on Amazon. The round, led by Bain Capital Ventures, includes new investors like Google Ventures and Goldman Sachs. CEO Marc Lore plans to use the funds to expand operations and build a real-time trading system, offering 10 million products with guaranteed lowest prices. An annual membership will cost $50, compared to Amazon's $99. Jet will start shipping in March, with a wider rollout in the late spring, and will use software to reduce shipping costs.

images.alt_text: Jet.com Inc. raised US$140 million in a new funding round before rolling out its service, building up its cash hoard to take on rival Amazon.com Inc.

site_title: China's top anti-graft regulator to inspect 26 state companies
summary: China's top anti-graft regulator has announced an inspection of 26 state-owned enterprises, including energy companies like China National Petroleum Corp. and State Grid Corp. of China, following similar probes last year that found graft and abuse of power. The inspections aim to tackle corruption and ensure accountability within the state-owned sector.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Thursday, down 8.26 points to 1790.69. Volume was 21.34 million lots worth RM28.66 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 78 to 68.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened flat on Thursday, down 1.28 points to 3,443.29, with 34 million shares traded worth S$50.8 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 61 to 54. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, but traders appear to be cautious amid US-EU trade tensions and Trump's tariff threats.

site_title: IMF 'very close' to agreement on Ukraine bailout, Lagarde says
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is "very close" to an agreement on a bailout for Ukraine's war-damaged economy, according to managing director Christine Lagarde. Ukraine's prime minister Arseniy Yatsenyuk and US Treasury officials also indicate a possible agreement on an international bailout. The country faces a 5% economic shrinkage forecast this year and needs about $15 billion of fresh funding. A first loan tranche from the new bailout may arrive in early March, bolstering the struggling currency. Ukraine's economy has been severely impacted by the conflict with pro-Russian separatists since last year.

site_title: UK house price growth slowest since May 2013: RICS
summary: UK house prices rose at their slowest annual pace since May 2013, with a 12-month price balance of +7 in January, down from +12 in December. London house prices fell for a fifth consecutive month, marking a six-year low. The slowdown is attributed to political uncertainty ahead of a national election, with buyers and sellers pausing for thought. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) also reported slow progress in bringing new houses to the market, with a shortage of housing across all tenures.

site_title: UK tax authority denies failings over HSBC client files
summary: The UK tax authority, HMRC, denied failing to take adequate action against British HSBC clients who hid money in Swiss accounts. HMRC CEO Lin Homer said data on 3,600 individuals was "incomplete" and "dirty," and her department dealt with serious cases. Despite criticism, Homer claimed HMRC acted effectively and secured one conviction and $206 million in unpaid tax. The HSBC leak, which revealed 100,000+ Swiss accounts, sparked a political outcry in Britain ahead of a general election.

site_title: Australian jobless jumps to highest since 2002; Aussie drops
summary: Australia's unemployment rate surged to 6.4% in January, the highest since 2002, as jobs were lost along the eastern seaboard. The Reserve Bank of Australia cut interest rates to a record low to support the economy, which is expected to expand below its potential. The number of full-time jobs dropped by 28,100, while part-time employment rose by 15,900. The Australian dollar fell to 76.64 US cents, and traders predict another rate cut in March. The government's internal fighting and falling commodity prices, including a 50% slump in oil prices, are also contributing to the economic woes.

site_title: Euro rally fades as Greek deal hangs in the balance
summary: The euro dropped to 135.95 yen and US$1.1314, losing ground after a marathon meeting of euro zone finance ministers failed to agree on a final statement or a way to continue talks with Greece. The lack of clarity on Greece's debt agreement has been a major overhang for the market, with investors hesitant to buy the euro. The dollar index held near a three-week high, while commodity currencies, such as the Canadian and Australian dollars, also declined. The next test for the Australian dollar is employment data due Friday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Swiber, Rowsley, Singtel, LMIR Trust
summary: Singapore stocks are expected to see potential upside on Thursday, driven by corporate actions and quarterly earnings releases. Rowsley Ltd and Swiber Holdings Ltd announced new deals, with Rowsley investing $275 million in a Myanmar development and Swiber securing a $310 million EPCIC contract. Singtel reported an 11% rise in third-quarter net profit, while Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust saw a 26.8% increase in distribution per unit. These strong results could benefit investors, particularly in the real estate and telecommunications sectors.

images.alt_text: Stocks that could see potential upside on Thursday include Rowsley and Swiber, both of which announced new corporate deals.

site_title: Swiber bags US$310m contract to work on new gas field in South Asia
summary: Swiber Holdings Ltd secured a US$310 million EPCIC contract in South Asia, its second-largest contract, to develop an offshore gas field. The project involves eight platforms and pipelines, with engineering work starting immediately and completion by March 2017. The contract is expected to contribute to the group's earnings per share in the current financial year. This is Swiber's new record high order book, rising to US$1.6 billion.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 1.40% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 1.40% higher on Thursday, driven by the yen's decline against the dollar, boosting Japanese exporters. The Nikkei 225 index rose to 17,899.40, despite Greek debt talks ending without agreement, and the euro drifting lower. The dollar was at 120.17 yen, down from 120.35 yen in US trade Wednesday.

site_title: Euro slips as Greek stalemate continues; Japan fuels Asia stocks
summary: The euro slipped 0.2% to $1.1313 after European lawmakers failed to reach an agreement on Greece's bailout funds. Asian stocks rose, with Japan's Topix index jumping 1.5% and the MSCI Asia Pacific Index climbing 0.6%. US crude oil rose 1% to $49.32. Talks in Brussels on Greece's bailout program are set to resume next week, with officials saying they are moving towards an agreement. The discussions have been stalled due to a Greek refusal to accept an extension of the existing bailout program.

site_title: India's gold smuggling boom fades as curbs loosened
summary: India's gold smuggling business has significantly declined as the government has eased import curbs, reducing premiums from $160 to $1 per ounce. The country, which accounted for a quarter of global gold demand, is now expected to see a 50% increase in imports from overseas. The easing of controls has led to a decrease in smuggling, with customs officers shifting their focus to other illegal imports. Jewelers predict Prime Minister Narendra Modi will cut the 10% import tax in his upcoming budget proposal, further reducing the allure of smuggling gold.

site_title: LMIR Trust posts 27% jump in Q4 DPU to 0.71 cent
summary: LMIR Trust, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, reported a 27% jump in its distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter of 2014 to 0.71 Singapore cent. The increase was driven by higher rental income from its malls in Indonesia, with gross rental income growing 9.3% to 284 billion rupiah. The trust's portfolio occupancy remained high at 94.7%. With a resilient economy outlook and stable business fundamentals, the trust plans to explore its sponsor's pipeline of quality assets and opportunistic third-party acquisitions to grow its portfolio in the coming years.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust DPU from Aug 1-Dec 31 is 9.6% below forecast
summary: Accordia Golf Trust reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 3.91 Singapore cents for the period from Aug 1 to Dec 31, 2014, 9.6% lower than forecast due to a weakening Japanese yen. The distributable income of 3.9 billion yen exceeded forecast by 1%, while operating profit was 3.6% below forecast. The better-than-expected distributable income was driven by an increase in non-recurring cash flows.

site_title: SGX issues 'trade with caution' note on UOL
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has issued a "trade with caution" note on UOL Group following a 6.4% rise in its share price on Wednesday. UOL claimed it was unaware of reasons for the trading activity, prompting the SGX to advise shareholders and investors to exercise caution. The exchange will investigate the matter and work with regulatory agencies to maintain a fair market.

site_title: US-listed Macau junket denied Hong Kong dual listing
summary: US-listed Macau junket operator Iao Kun Group Holding Co Ltd had its Hong Kong dual listing application rejected due to declining performance and uncertain outlook. The Hong Kong stock exchange cited "overall market conditions and the near-term industrial outlook in Macau" as reasons for the rejection. Macau's gaming revenues have slumped for eight months, and February revenues are expected to plummet 40% year on year due to Beijing's crackdown on corruption. The rejection puts pressure on Iao Kun to squeeze profit from the mass market of lower-spending players, potentially affecting ancillary non-gaming services.

images.alt_text: Gambling revenue in Macau has slumped for eight months in a row and February revenues are expected to plunge 40 per cent year on year

site_title: Japan Dec core machinery orders rise 8.3% m-o-m
summary: Japan's core machinery orders rose 8.3% in December, exceeding economists' forecast of 2.4%, and companies expect a 1.5% increase in January-March. This follows a 1.3% increase in November. The Cabinet Office raised its assessment of machinery orders, indicating a gradual recovery. Compared to last year, core orders rose 11.4%, higher than the median estimate of 5.9%. This encouraging sign suggests capital expenditure will help the economy.

site_title: Twitter buys agency that grooms social media stars
summary: Twitter has acquired Niche, a startup that acts as a talent agency for social media stars, in a deal valued at over $30 million. Niche, which has offices in San Francisco and New York City, has worked with Twitter since 2013 and boasts over 6,000 social media creators in its stable. The acquisition aims to help brands partner with online influencers and create "moments" that resonate with their target audience. Twitter director of product management Baljeet Singh stated that the deal will help brands connect with online audiences.

site_title: Nam Cheong Q4 net profit slumps 42% on higher S&A expenses
summary: Nam Cheong reported a 42% year-on-year slump in net profit to RM41.1 million for the fourth quarter, driven by higher selling and administrative expenses. Revenue jumped 29% to RM523.9 million, largely due to recognition of revenue from platform supply vessels. Gross profit margin remained stable, but the shipbuilding segment's margin fell to 15% from 21% a year ago, mainly due to lower margins from build-to-order vessels.

site_title: Seoul: Won slides to five-week low on weakening yen; shares lower
summary: The South Korean won dropped to a five-week low against the dollar on February 12, 2015, due to the weakening yen. The won was quoted at 1,106.2 to the dollar, with the yen/won cross rate at 9.2129, maintaining a gap above the perceived danger threshold of 9.1. This raised concerns of potential intervention by financial authorities to stabilize the won's value.

site_title: Banks to face stricter forex fixing rules if reform lags: Financial Stability Board
summary: Financial institutions involved in foreign exchange rate fixing must reform their practices to avoid stricter rules, warned Guy Debelle, deputy governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia. The Financial Stability Board made recommendations to clean up the fixings, but progress has been patchy. If these recommendations are not implemented, regulatory action will increase. The WM Company is expanding the window for fixing calculations to five minutes, but banks are slow to charge clients for fixing services, creating an incentive for inappropriate behavior. Significant progress is needed in separating fixing business from regular dealings and executing fix business within institutions.

site_title: Oil down after record US crude stocks; Brent below US$55
summary: Oil prices dropped 3% on Wednesday as US crude stocks hit a record high of nearly 418 million barrels, surpassing the 1982 record. The glut in oil supplies has prevented prices from forming a bottom, and analysts predict further price declines. Benchmark Brent oil fell below $55 a barrel, while US crude closed at $48.84 a barrel. Analysts predict Brent could fall to $53 a barrel and US crude could go below $47.50 a barrel.

site_title: Singtel posts 11% rise in quarterly net profit
summary: Singtel, Southeast Asia's largest telecommunications operator, reported an 11% rise in third-quarter net profit to S$970 million, exceeding analyst forecasts. The company attributed the strong performance to home market growth and higher contributions from regional associates. This marks a significant increase from the S$872 million net profit in the same period last year.

site_title: Rents on private condos, HDB flats still under pressure: consultants
summary: Rentals for private condos in Singapore increased by 0.2% in January, reversing 11 consecutive months of decline, according to SRX flash estimates. However, HDB rents slid by 0.5% in the same period. Consultants consider the January rise in private condo rents as a blip due to monthly fluctuations, with no signs of a rebound. The increase was mainly driven by a 1.9% rise in the Rest of Central Region (RCR).

site_title: Australia's Telstra H1 net profit soars 21.7%
summary: Telstra, Australia's largest telecom, reported a 21.7% jump in first-half net profit to A$2.1 billion, driven by strong mobile revenue and expansion in Asia. Total revenue rose 1.6% to A$13.0 billion, with mobile business revenue increasing 9.6% to A$5.3 billion. The company's acquisition of Pacnet, a major submarine communication cable owner, is expected to increase its reach and customer base in the Asia-Pacific region. CEO David Thodey attributed the success to improved customer service and strategic investments in new businesses and growth in Asia.

images.alt_text: The country's dominant telecom said profit in the six months to December 31 came in at A$2.1 billion (US$1.6 billion), compared to A$1.7 billion in the previous corresponding period.

site_title: US becomes hot spot for aerospace manufacturing
summary: The US has become a hot spot for aerospace manufacturing, with 28 investments between 2012 and 2013, compared to eight in China and Mexico. A decade ago, Mexico led the pack with 10 investments, but the industry has shifted towards the US in the last three years. Companies like Boeing and Airbus are moving production in-house to US plants to reduce costs and offset falling plane ticket prices. The US is now competing with emerging markets like China, India, and Brazil for aerospace investments, with regions like the Florida panhandle stepping up efforts to win companies.

site_title: Number of US financial advisers fell for fifth straight year
summary: The number of US financial advisers fell for the fifth straight year, with 285,000 advisers in 2014, a 1.9% drop from 2013. The industry has lost 39,000 advisers since 2008, with nearly half of all financial advisers over 55. Cerulli Associates expects nearly 100,000 brokers to retire over the next decade. Only two segments of the wealth management industry saw growth: registered investment advisors and dually registered or hybrid advisers.

site_title: IMF sees slower Myanmar economic expansion next year
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) forecasts Myanmar's economy to grow 7.8% in the fiscal year ending March 31, down from 8.3% in 2013, due to a slowdown in its agricultural sector. The IMF warns that government wage hikes could spur inflation, while central bank reserves are vulnerable to a slowdown in foreign direct investment. The fund advises the government to prioritize spending and increase tax revenues to contain the budget deficit. Myanmar is making progress in modernizing its financial sector, but faces challenges ahead, particularly with parliamentary elections set to take place later this year.

site_title: Euro zone, Greece fail to agree way forward following meeting
summary: Euro zone finance ministers failed to agree on a way forward with Greece after hours of discussions in Brussels, extending an international bailout until their next meeting on Monday. The meeting, chaired by Jeroen Dijsselbloem, explored a possible extension of the current program, but no conclusion was reached. Dijsselbloem stated that more time is needed to come to a decision, leaving Greece's future uncertain.

images.alt_text: Euro zone finance ministers were unable to agree with Greece a final statement or a way to continue talks until their next meeting on Monday

site_title: JPMorgan hands Asia Pacific banking duties to Aguzin
summary: JPMorgan has handed over Asia Pacific corporate and investment banking and treasury services to Nicolas Aguzin, effective immediately. Aguzin previously shared the duties with Greg Guyett and Tom DuCharme. The move is part of a broader restructuring, with the two men considering other executive roles at the bank. The decision was made by global co-heads of corporate and investment banking, Carlos Hernandez and Jeff Urwin.

site_title: New Zealand manufacturing activity slides in January
summary: New Zealand's manufacturing activity declined sharply in January to a two-year low, with the Bank of New Zealand-Business NZ's seasonally adjusted performance of manufacturing index (PMI) falling to 50.9. This is the lowest reading since December 2012, indicating a contraction in activity. Production fell into contraction for the first time since April 2012, while new orders and deliveries slowed.

site_title: Fisher floats changes to fix Fed's New York, Washington bias
summary: US Federal Reserve President Richard Fisher criticized the Fed's structure, citing conflicts of interest and regulatory capture in New York and Washington. He suggested revamping rules, including rotating the New York Fed's permanent vote every two years and increasing the number of regional Fed presidents voting on monetary policy. Fisher also proposed transferring oversight of Wall Street banks to supervisors from another district Fed bank to address concerns of regulatory capture.

site_title: URA guidelines to offer more flexibility in design of landed homes
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) in Singapore has introduced new guidelines, known as the Envelope Control guidelines, to offer more design flexibility in the construction of landed homes. The guidelines, effective from May 11, remove floor-to-floor height limits and basement protrusion requirements, allowing developers and owners to create more open layouts and designs. This change aims to preserve the low-rise character of landed housing estates while giving homeowners and architects more freedom to design their properties creatively.

site_title: Rowsley in proposed JV to build Myanmar project worth US$550m
summary: Rowsley Ltd, a real estate firm part-owned by billionaire Peter Lim, has entered into a joint venture with Vietnam's Hoang Anh Gia Lai to develop a US$550 million mixed-use project in Yangon, Myanmar. Rowsley will invest US$275 million for a 50% stake in the project, with HAGL making further investments and undertaking construction. The project, valued at 640,000 sq m, includes office towers, a retail mall, and a five-star hotel, with the first phase expected to be completed by end-2015.

site_title: Swiss government proposes draft law to curb immigration from EU
summary: The Swiss government has proposed a draft law to limit immigration from the European Union, following a 2014 referendum that imposed quotas on immigration. The law aims to set annual limits for EU workers, favor Swiss nationals in hiring, and maintain free movement of people under EU-Swiss agreements. The EU has expressed concerns that the measure could violate treaties, and the Swiss government plans to engage in talks to resolve the issue. The draft law must be written into law within three years.

site_title: Microsoft buys smartphone calendar app Sunrise
summary: Microsoft has acquired Sunrise, a popular mobile calendar application, in a deal reportedly valued at around $100 million. The acquisition comes as Microsoft releases mobile versions of its Outlook calendar and email programs. Microsoft aims to create more meaningful experiences in mobile email and calendaring across platforms, following its recent purchase of Acompli, a company specializing in handling email on mobile devices. Sunrise applications will remain free for users.

site_title: Obama says special forces could target IS leaders
summary: US President Barack Obama announced he would not hesitate to send special forces to kill Islamic State leaders, calling for Congress to authorise military operations. He proposed a joint resolution that would provide a firmer legal basis for the ongoing campaign, but with limitations, including no "enduring offensive ground combat operations." Obama assured that local forces on the ground would lead the fight, and he would not drag the US into another prolonged ground war in the Middle East.

site_title: Facebook, partners unveil alliance on cyber security
summary: Facebook, along with Yahoo and other tech firms, unveiled the "ThreatExchange" to share information and thwart cyberattacks. The platform allows partner companies to query and publish threat information, making systems safer. Pinterest, Tumblr, Twitter, and Yahoo are among the participating companies, with new partners including Bitly and Dropbox. The move comes as the US government aims to improve cybersecurity coordination, with plans for a new intelligence center. The goal is to make the internet safer and facilitate information sharing without fear of liability.

site_title: Taiwan prisoner crisis ends in suicide with hostages unharmed
summary: A 14-hour siege at a prison in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung city ended with six armed inmates killing themselves, ending the hostage situation without harming the warden or head guard. The inmates, serving sentences ranging from 25 years to life, had demanded a car to leave the prison. Negotiations with the government, including the involvement of the prisoners' families, led to the inmates' decision to end the standoff. The warden was held hostage throughout the ordeal, but was released unharmed. The incident highlights concerns over prison treatment in Taiwan.

site_title: Anwar in jail raises unity challenge for Malaysia opposition
summary: Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim was sentenced to five years in prison and banned from politics for five years after being found guilty of sodomy. The imprisonment of Anwar, leader of the Pakatan Rakyat coalition, has raised concerns about the unity of the coalition and its ability to challenge the ruling Barisan Nasional coalition. With Anwar's imprisonment, the coalition must now choose a new leader and pursue an inclusive agenda to stay relevant. The longer-term challenge for Pakatan Rakyat is to move beyond Anwar and develop winnable policies to challenge Barisan Nasional in the next election.

site_title: New York City building officials charged in bribery cases
summary: More than a dozen New York City buildings inspectors and clerks have been charged with taking bribes in exchange for clearing complaints, expedited inspections, and removing tenants from buildings. The bribes, totaling hundreds of thousands of dollars, were paid in exchange for favorable treatment, including home mortgage payments, sport utility vehicles, and luxury cruises. The investigation, which lasted nearly two years, exposed widespread corruption in the city's real estate industry, threatening tenant safety and government integrity.

site_title: US, China to discuss repatriation of Chinese fugitives
summary: US officials will meet Chinese counterparts in August to discuss repatriating Chinese officials with billions of dollars in allegedly stolen government assets. The lack of an extradition treaty between the US and China has made America an attractive destination for fugitives. Officials will share intelligence on suspected corrupt officials and discuss ways to send them back to China, with alternatives to extradition including deportation for US immigration law violations.

site_title: US: Stocks flat as market eyes Greece talks
summary: US stocks ended flat on Wednesday as investors awaited developments in Greece's debt talks, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dipping 0.04% to 17,862.14. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index were essentially unchanged. Greece's finance ministers met in Brussels, ready to consider debt relief plans, but emphasized the need for austerity reforms. In other news, PepsiCo reported strong fourth-quarter earnings and announced a new share repurchase program, while Apple rose 2.3% after activist shareholder Carl Icahn revived his call for the company to buy back more stock.

site_title: BitTorrent teams with studio for original online video
summary: BitTorrent partners with Rapid Eye Studios to produce original online video for young adults, aiming to challenge Netflix and Amazon Prime. The exclusive alliance will debut content on BitTorrent's platform for 1-3 months, with 90% of revenue going to content creators. The first season of a show titled "Children Of The Machine" is set to launch late this year, with ad-supported and premium versions available. This move helps BitTorrent establish a presence in Hollywood and further legitimise its image.

images.alt_text: BitTorrent Originals will debut content to be shown exclusively on the platform for one to three months.

site_title: SwissLeaks whistleblower says he tried to report tax evasion in 2008
summary: A former HSBC employee, Herve Falciani, claimed he tried to report tax evasion to British authorities in 2008, but saw no action taken. Falciani, a whistleblower, said he sent an email and made phone calls to the relevant department but was met with inaction. The leak of documents has sparked a scandal, with British tax officials recovering $135 million in taxes since 2010, but only one prosecution. The revelation has also raised questions about Prime Minister David Cameron's appointment of HSBC's former head, Stephen Green, as trade minister.

site_title: China's Baidu posts jump in revenue as mobile traffic grows
summary: Baidu Inc, China's dominant search engine, reported a 47.5% rise in quarterly revenue to 14.05 billion yuan (US$2.26 billion) for the fourth quarter, driven by growth in mobile traffic. Mobile revenue accounted for 42% of total revenue, up from 36% in the previous quarter. This growth is attributed to the increasing importance of mobile internet in China.

site_title: Trian backs off call to split DuPont in two
summary: Trian Fund Management, led by Nelson Peltz, has backed off its demand to split DuPont in two, but still supports electing new directors to address the company's underperformance. Trian had proposed splitting DuPont into a "growth co" and a "cyclical/cash co." DuPont has rejected the proposal, citing it as "costly and high risk." The company has also criticized Peltz for rejecting a prior compromise. Trian holds a 3% stake in DuPont and will focus on electing new directors to work collaboratively with the existing board to determine the best course of action.

site_title: Malaysian palm-oil shipments tumble most in seven years in January
summary: Malaysia's palm-oil exports plummeted 22% in January, the largest decline in seven years, due to a 12% drop in prices and a record global oilseed supply. The plunge in energy prices reduced demand for palm oil, which may shift to soya-bean oil. Soya-bean oil prices fell to a six-year low, making it an attractive alternative. The decline in demand and production, which contracted for the fifth straight month, may lead to a surplus of palm oil, according to analysts.

site_title: Paris launches lawsuit over Fox News 'no-go zones'
summary: Paris City Hall has launched a lawsuit against Fox News for defamation over reports that claimed parts of the French capital had "no-go zones" that police and non-Muslims avoided. The reports, which were widely criticized, were aired in the wake of last month's attacks on Paris. Fox News anchor later apologized for "regrettable errors," and the network plans to invoke all applicable laws to defend itself against the lawsuit.

images.alt_text: Paris City Hall on Wednesday decided to launch a lawsuit over reports by US news channel Fox News that there were "no-go zones" in the French capital that police and non-Muslims avoid.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close lower
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed lower on Wednesday, with London's FTSE-100 down 0.16% to 6,818.17 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 down 0.02% to 10,752.11 points, and Paris' CAC 40 down 0.35% to 4,679.38 points. The decline was attributed to bank and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks in focus. Despite this, the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records.

site_title: Booking an HDB flat? You'll need a loan eligibility letter
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) requires applicants of Build-to-order (BTO) flats to produce a valid HDB loan eligibility (HLE) letter when booking a flat, starting from the February 2015 BTO exercise. The HLE letter states the loan quantum and monthly instalments, ensuring buyers are within their budgets. This change aims to prevent overstretching finances and may also encourage buyers to consider non-mature estates.

site_title: Far East H-Trust posts 9.9% drop in Q4 DPS
summary: Far East H-Trust reported a 9.9% year-on-year drop in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.28 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2014. The Reit manager attributed the decline to softer hotel and serviced residence performances. The company expects a challenging operating environment in 2015, with an estimated 3,000 new hotel rooms coming on-stream.

site_title: Sinking of bauxite-carrying ship raises moisture concerns
summary: A Malaysian ship carrying bauxite sank off Vietnam in January, raising concerns about the stability of the cargo due to excess moisture, which could cause liquefaction. Marine insurers have issued warnings, advising shipowners to consider the risk, despite bauxite not typically liquefying. Malaysia has plugged the gap left by Indonesia's export ban, with shipments up 2,000% last year. The port of Kuantan is preparing new regulations on cargo testing to address the issue, but exports to China are still expected to reach 10 million tonnes this year.

site_title: Acquisitions to drive DPU growth for rest of FY2015: CRT
summary: Croesus Retail Trust (CRT) reported a 3% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) in its fiscal second quarter, driven by yield-accretive acquisitions. Net property income jumped 48.8% year-on-year to 1.2 billion yen, while gross revenue leapt 51.7% to 1.95 billion yen. The trust expects positive rental reversions at Mallage Shobu, its largest property, to drive DPU growth in the second half of fiscal 2015.

site_title: ComfortDelGro's full-year profit up 7.7% at S$283.5m
summary: ComfortDelGro's net profit for the year ended Dec 31, 2014, rose 7.7% to S$283.5 million, driven by a 8.1% increase in revenue to a record S$4.05 billion. This growth was also influenced by currency translation.

site_title: Brian Williams, the least trusted man in America
summary: Brian Williams, the current NBC Nightly News anchor, has faced severe criticism for his credibility as a journalist after a military newspaper revealed that he had repeatedly embellished his 2003 war-reporting from Iraq. Williams initially claimed to have been on a helicopter hit by RPG fire, but later changed his story, and soldiers involved in the incident disputed his account. He apologized and stepped aside from anchoring the Nightly News, and NBC News suspended him for six months without pay. The incident has raised questions about Williams' integrity and trustworthiness as a news anchor, following the decline of trust in media in recent years.

site_title: Malaysia reduces power tariffs as global fuel costs decline
summary: Malaysia is reducing electricity tariffs by 5.8% or 2.25 sen per kilowatt hour for businesses and consumers starting March 1 to June 30, as global fuel prices decline. The move is expected to save Malaysian power producers RM727 million, which will be passed on to commercial and industrial users, and domestic consumers. The reduction in fuel costs has given the government the opportunity to cut costs for businesses and consumers.

site_title: Seoul plans Singapore-style casino resort
summary: Seoul plans to develop a Singapore-style casino resort near Incheon Airport, costing 5-6 trillion won, to attract Chinese visitors and gamblers. The project, set to be completed by 2019, will include a casino, shopping mall, and hotels, with a focus on attracting mass consumers rather than high rollers. The move aims to draw 10 million Chinese tourists annually by 2020, despite China's anti-graft campaign driving away high rollers. The project is part of a larger effort to develop integrated resorts near the airport, with two other projects already underway.

site_title: DBS gives S$1,000 to each staff for SG50
summary: DBS Group Holdings announced a S$1,000 hongbao to each of its 18,000 employees to celebrate SG50 and reach S$50 billion in market capitalisation. The bank's net profit rose to a record S$4.05 billion in 2014, and CEO Piyush Gupta emphasized the importance of companies connecting with society and providing opportunities for egalitarian growth. DBS has also launched various initiatives, including a S$100 million SG50 programme, a S$50 million foundation, and a S$25 million donation to the National Gallery Singapore.

site_title: Greece in bailout showdown with EU
summary: Greece's left-wing government is in a standoff with European partners over its bailout, with finance ministers meeting in Brussels to discuss a new debt programme. The ministers are willing to listen to Greece's plans but require completion of austerity reforms. No solution is expected at Wednesday's talks, with negotiations likely to continue at the next meeting on Monday. Greece's 240 billion euro bailout is at stake, with the country's future in the EU-IMF programme hanging in the balance.

site_title: JTC launches integrated industrial devt
summary: JTC Corporation launched JTC Space @ Tuas, a first-of-its-kind integrated industrial development in Singapore. The facility, which opened on February 11, 2015, features different factory space types and supporting facilities catering to the oil & gas, precision engineering, and general manufacturing industries. Rohag Singapore, a machining and fabrication works provider, is one of the tenants moving into the new facility, aiming to enhance productivity with improved equipment layout. The development aims to support firms in Singapore's manufacturing sector.

site_title: Greek, Chinese leaders discuss investment, cooperation
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras spoke with Chinese Premier Li Keqiang, discussing new investments and cooperation between the two countries. China expressed interest in investing in Greece, and the two leaders agreed to deepen economic, commercial, and cultural ties. Greece is seeking to cancel key terms of its bailout program, including the sale of strategic national assets, and China had previously offered economic support to Greece.

site_title: Greeks turning the tables on Eurogroup
summary: Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis is poised for an improbable victory in the Brussels Eurogroup, despite being the underdog. Varoufakis has successfully stoked hostility among his peers by criticizing debt unsustainable to Italy and Germany, while giving succour to opposition parties in Spain, Portugal, and France. His strategy relies on the contagion of Greek uncertainty, making the euro area fragile and unpredictable. German Chancellor Angela Merkel and other EU leaders are keen to avoid a Greek exit, which could lead to the collapse of the euro area. Varoufakis is likely to secure concessions from the Eurogroup in the near future.

site_title: Productivity push for process, construction & maintenance sector
summary: A productivity council is being set up in Singapore's process, construction and maintenance (PCM) sector to improve management practices and encourage companies to adopt productivity and safety measures. The council, led by industry experts, will establish a centre of excellence for training and certification, and a data-sharing portal to reduce project scheduling overlaps. The move aims to support the energy and chemicals sector, which is expected to become more complex as it advances and seeks higher efficiency and product yields. The council's initiatives are expected to boost the sector's productivity and competitiveness.

site_title: New GDP calculation transforms India into a Tiger economy
summary: India's GDP growth has been revised to 7.4% for fiscal 2014-15, surpassing China's growth rate, after switching to market prices for calculation instead of factor costs. The new calculation puts India's GDP at around $2.1-2.2 trillion, and has upgraded 2013-14 and 2012-2013 GDP growth rates. Manufacturing sector growth has been particularly impressive, with a 6.8% growth rate, despite an index of industrial production (IIP) showing a slower growth rate. The revised GDP numbers are seen as a positive sign for Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government, which aims to boost economic growth and create jobs, and will be presented in the upcoming budget.

site_title: Euro weakens with focus on Greek debt talks
summary: The euro hit a seven-year low against the pound before a eurozone finance ministers' meeting on Greece's debt talks. The euro weakened 0.25% against the dollar and 0.4% against the pound, while the dollar rose 0.4% against the yen. Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis will present demands for an end to the international bailout and a new debt restructuring deal. A failure to find common ground could lead to volatile trading, with a sell-off in the euro possible if talks break down.

site_title: Colliers Int'l names new CEO for Asia-Pacific ops
summary: Colliers International has appointed David Hand as chief executive of its Asia-Pacific operations, replacing Piers Brunner. Hand joins after 18 years at JLL, where he held various leadership roles. The move comes as Colliers prepares to split from parent FirstService Corp to focus on commercial property acquisitions. The company will change its name to Colliers International Group Inc and FirstService will become a new public company, with Jay Hennick serving as executive chairman of both.

site_title: Apple first company to be worth over US$700b
summary: Apple became the first company to reach a market value of over $700 billion, closing at $122.02 per share, with its market value rising to $710 billion. Analysts believe Apple has room to grow due to its powerful iPhone cycle, upcoming smartwatch launch, and expanding Apple Pay system. The company's record quarterly profit of $74.6 billion was driven by iPhone sales, and analysts predict strong demand for the Apple Watch and solar-powered data centre investments.

site_title: China sales reveal Amway billionaires
summary: Amway Corp chairman Steve Van Andel and his siblings David Van Andel, Barb Van Andel-Gaby, and Nan Van Andel own half of Alticor Inc, valued at $4 billion, after inheriting their father Jay Van Andel's stake in 2004. Their father's legacy and the company's early push into China, a $18 billion direct-selling market, contributed to their wealth. The siblings' diverse pursuits, including education and philanthropy, are also highlighted.

site_title: Two men charged as Australia foils 'imminent' terror attack
summary: Two men, Omar Al-Kutobi, 24, and Mohammad Kiad, 25, were charged in Australia after police foiled an "imminent" terror attack in Sydney, seizing an IS flag, machete, and video detailing the plot. The planned attack was due to occur on Tuesday, with police believing it was "consistent with the messaging coming out of IS". The men, reportedly devout Muslims, were refused bail and the case was adjourned until Thursday due to security issues.

site_title: Sembcorp buys into India wind and solar firm
summary: Sembcorp Industries has acquired a 60% stake in Indian renewable energy firm Green Infra for 10.6 billion rupees (S$231.5 million), tripling its global renewable energy generation capacity to over 1,000 megawatts. The deal marks Sembcorp's entry into the solar sector and will be funded through internal funds and debt financing. The acquisition is expected to have a minimal impact on Sembcorp's earnings per share and net asset value for the current year.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Industries is expanding its renewable energy business and, for the first time, branching into solar power.

site_title: KepLand China, Vanke to develop prime Chengdu site
summary: Keppel Land China has signed an agreement with China Vanke to jointly develop a 16.7-hectare prime residential site in Chengdu, China. This marks the two companies' second joint venture and Keppel Land China's sixth project in Chengdu. The collaboration follows their successful first joint venture on The Glades at Tanah Merah in Singapore.

site_title: OCBC misses Q4 expectations as bad debt allowances double
summary: OCBC reported a 11% quarterly profit of S$791m, despite a significant increase in bad debt allowances to S$154m, up from S$68m. The bank attributed the rise to a more cautious approach to lending, particularly in the commodities and oil-and-gas sectors. OCBC noted no systemic weakness in these sectors, which have been impacted by falling prices. The bank's results signal caution over souring loans, similar to its competitor DBS.

site_title: US private equity firms scramble to hire young investment bankers
summary: US private equity firms are aggressively recruiting young investment bankers, with some extending job offers as early as February for summer 2016 positions. These junior bankers, often recent college graduates, are being courted for their potential to join private equity firms, which offer higher pay packages, including salaries up to $300,000 per year. The recruitment process has become increasingly frenzied since the financial crisis, with some firms starting interviews 18 months before the job starts. The scramble is driven by the desire to attract top talent from investment banks, which are raising salaries and offering additional benefits to retain workers.

site_title: Support for customer flows helped Citi in Swiss franc fiasco
summary: Citi has recovered somewhat from losses following the Swiss franc unpegging in January, with the bank's trading rooms "doing very, very well" in the second half of the month. The bank's Asia-Pacific head of markets and securities services, Patrick Dewilde, attributed the recovery to the bank's willingness to service customer flows, which outweighed the impact of volatility. Citi is focusing on cross-border needs and has set clear targets internally to improve execution efficiency and automate flows business. The bank aims to increase the proportion of its flows business that can be automated and build a "creative solutions" side of the business.

site_title: Jon Stewart to leave The Daily Show after 16 years
summary: Jon Stewart, host of The Daily Show, will leave the show after 16 years, citing a desire to pursue other projects. Stewart, 52, has hosted the award-winning program since 1999, offering a satirical take on news. The show has been a launchpad for numerous comedians, including Stephen Colbert and John Oliver. Stewart's departure was announced during a taping, with Comedy Central praising his comedic brilliance and legacy as a "comic genius."

images.alt_text: Stewart has announced that he will be leaving The Daily Show later this year

site_title: Extra runway at Heathrow could attract budget airlines, says hub's chief
summary: Heathrow airport's CEO, John Holland-Kaye, suggests a third runway could attract 30 new airlines, including budget operators like EasyJet, due to increased competition and lower fares. EasyJet CEO Carolyn McCall previously stated a third runway at Heathrow would boost competition and drive down fares. The proposed £18.6 billion new runway or £13.5 billion lengthening of the northern runway would surpass Gatwick's £9.3 billion proposal. The Airport Commission's final recommendations are due this year, with good cross-party support for the project.

site_title: IEA sees only partial rebound in oil prices
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) forecasts that global oil prices will recover partially from their current range of $50-$60 per barrel, but remain below $100 per barrel. The agency expects US shale oil production growth to slow to a trickle this year, but rebound in 2020, reaching 5.2 million barrels per day. Non-OPEC output is forecast to rise modestly to 60 million barrels per day in 2020, while global demand is expected to rise to 99.1 million barrels per day, 1.1 million barrels per day below its previous forecast.

site_title: Building a stronger S'pore Inc
summary: Singapore's national brand has earned a global reputation for economic success and strong governance, but local companies' brands have not fared as well. Only two Singapore brands made the world's top 500 global brands in 2014. To build a strong brand, Singapore companies need to invest in marketing, design, and R&D, and leverage the Singapore brand and nearby markets. The government can support brand-building efforts through measures such as tax incentives, with a proposed Singapore Pioneer Business Package recognizing successful local brands.

images.alt_text: Only two Singapore brands - Singapore Airlines and DBS - were named among the world's top 500 global brands in 2014.
Only two Singapore brands - Singapore Airlines and DBS - were named among the world's top 500 global brands in 2014.

site_title: China's booming healthcare sector draws investors
summary: China's booming healthcare sector is attracting investors, with private equity firms such as TPG Capital and IHH Healthcare Bhd investing in hospitals, pharmaceutical companies, and device makers. The sector is expected to treble in spending to eight trillion yuan over the next five years due to China's rapidly ageing population. Despite risks such as weak hospital infrastructure and a lack of doctors, investors are optimistic about the sector's potential, with valuations for some firms steadily increasing. The sector's growth has surpassed that of the hot Internet sector, with M&A deal values reaching a record US$18.5 billion in 2014.

site_title: Greece, OECD agree to work together on reforms
summary: Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras announced plans to work with the OECD to draft a programme of reforms to boost growth in the debt-laden country. The programme will be based on a popular mandate, and will include emergency social measures that would break the conditions of the bailout if implemented. Greece wants to renegotiate its bailout commitments and is seeking a successor programme focused on structural overhauls rather than fiscal measures. The OECD will work with Greece to implement its reform goals, but German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble stated that there are no plans to discuss a new accord or give Greece more time.

site_title: Aussie govt woes hurting business confidence: bank chief
summary: The head of Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) has warned that uncertainty over the country's leadership and policies is hurting business confidence. The bank posted a 8% increase in H1 cash profit to A$4.6 billion. This criticism is unusual for a business leader, coming as Prime Minister Tony Abbott survived a challenge to his leadership. The warning reflects the impact of the ongoing government infighting on the business community's confidence in Australia's economic future.

site_title: The logic of an empty US$100m New York pad
summary: A record number of superwealthy buyers are paying record-setting prices for new developments in Manhattan, with some expecting their investments to appreciate in value even if they sit empty for most of the year. These buyers, often using shell companies, are drawn to the city's opulent finishes and extraordinary views. The surge in demand is driven by the increasing allure of Manhattan property for the global elite, with developers scrambling to meet the demand.

site_title: Poland's dream of shale gas riches begins to dim
summary: Poland's hopes of becoming a major shale gas producer are dwindling as Western firms, including Chevron, pull out due to poor results and high costs. Despite initial estimates suggesting up to 1.92 trillion cubic meters of exploitable deposits, Poland's geology is structured differently from US deposits, making extraction technologies ineffective. Only 15 firms remain in the exploration process, with Polish officials remaining hopeful for new discoveries, but acknowledging the challenges. Poland's energy dependence on Russia remains a concern, with the government aiming to tap its shale gas deposits by 2020 to reduce dependence.

site_title: Apple in big solar power deal, market cap closes over US$700b
summary: Apple has signed a deal to purchase 130 megawatts of electricity from a California solar farm, valued at US$850 million, to power its new campus and offices in Silicon Valley. The deal, which will be the largest in the industry to provide clean energy to a commercial user, is expected to save Apple significant amounts of money. The solar farm, which has a capacity to power 60,000 homes, will also power an existing Apple data centre in Newark, California. Apple's stock market value surpassed US$700 billion for the first time, driven by record sales of big-screen iPhones and a December-quarter profit.

site_title: Australia puts limits on foreign buying of land for agriculture
summary: Australia has tightened rules on foreign ownership of agricultural land, requiring regulatory approval for purchases over A$15 million from March 1. The change aims to protect the country's food security amid concerns over foreign control. The new rules also prevent multiple purchases below the threshold, and the Australian Taxation Office will conduct a review of all land ownership in June. The move is seen as a bid by Prime Minister Tony Abbott to tighten his grip on power after narrowly surviving an internal party challenge.

site_title: US airlines blame unfair competition for losing market share to Gulf carriers
summary: US airlines have lost at least five percentage points of their share of flight bookings to the Indian subcontinent and South-east Asia since 2008, largely due to unfair competition from Gulf carriers. The combined share of bookings by Delta, United, and American Airlines has fallen to 34% in 2014 from 39% in 2008, while Gulf carriers have increased their share to 40%. US airlines claim the Gulf carriers have received government subsidies, totaling over $40 billion, to gain an unfair advantage.

site_title: S'pore's biggest integrated startup space launched
summary: Singapore's largest integrated startup space, BASH (Building Amazing Startups Here), was launched on February 11, 2015, to provide business traction and market access to innovation-driven tech-product startups. The 25,000 sq ft facility, driven by Infocomm Investments Pte Ltd, offers a prototyping lab, mentorship, and community networks to grow startups. The first run of a corporate-accelerator programme, targeting high-growth digital media startups, is set to start by mid-year, with partners including Singapore Press Holdings and Plug and Play.

site_title: Out soon: Samsung Galaxy S with 3-sided display
summary: Samsung plans to release two new Galaxy S smartphones in March, including a model with a 3-sided display and another with a front-facing display. The phones will feature all-metal bodies, advanced processor chips, and 5.1-inch screens. The company aims to recapture its innovation edge and revive earnings, which have slumped for three straight quarters. This move comes after Apple's success with larger-screen iPhones and Samsung's loss of global market share.

site_title: Emirates chairman tells US airlines to improve service before pointing finger
summary: Emirates chairman Sheikh Ahmed Bin Saeed Al Maktoum has urged US airlines to improve their service before criticizing their business practices, saying they should focus on providing a better experience for passengers rather than trying to limit competition. The airline has outgrown the US market, carrying over 10 million passengers on US flights since 2004, and has ordered 140 A380 superjumbos. Sheikh Ahmed emphasized that offering a good service can attract passengers, even if it means paying a bit more.

site_title: In Thailand, the ghosts business thrives
summary: In Thailand, the concept of ghosts is deeply ingrained in daily life, with over 100 types of ghosts believed to exist. Kapol Thongplub, a popular radio host, has been discussing ghost stories for over two decades, becoming the country's leading ghost expert. His business ventures, including restaurants and cafes, capitalize on the fascination with the supernatural. While some, like science professor Jessada Denduangboripant, dismiss the notion of ghosts, Kapol claims to have never seen one, relying on his "sixth sense" to sense their presence.

site_title: Sim Lian's Q2 earnings fall 61%; KSH Holdings posts 14.6% increase in Q3 profit
summary: Sim Lian Group's Q2 net profit fell 61% to S$25.5 million due to a 56% drop in revenue, primarily from reduced property development contributions. In contrast, KSH Holdings reported a 14.6% increase in Q3 net profit to S$11.4 million, despite a 28.6% drop in revenue. Both companies expect challenging private residential property markets and focus on building stable recurring income.

site_title: MAS seeks more bite to oversight of derivatives, securities
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed legislative amendments to strengthen its oversight of derivatives and securities trading, aiming for greater transparency and enforcement powers. The proposals include reporting short-selling, publication of aggregate short positions, and enhanced penalties for market misconduct. MAS will also regulate OTC derivatives trading platforms and introduce simplified definitions of securities and derivatives. The proposals follow a comprehensive review of the Securities and Futures Act and are open for public feedback until March 24.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) building at Shenton Way on March 13, 2014.

site_title: Dubai's Emirates aims to hire over 11,000 staff
summary: Dubai's Emirates Group plans to hire over 11,000 staff by March 2016, a 6% increase, to support the addition of 20 aircraft to its fleet and expanded operations. The move aims to maintain its position in the global aviation industry.

site_title: Still time for Greece to end debt standoff, but no Plan B yet: Austria
summary: Austria's finance minister Hans Joerg Schelling says Greece has time to end its debt standoff with European partners before the end of February, but no alternative plan is being considered. Greece's new leftist government is trying to cancel a deeply unpopular bailout program, which could lead to a critical phase if not resolved. Schelling ruled out Greece leaving the EU or eurozone, but acknowledged that if a solution is not reached, a Plan B would likely be needed.

site_title: IBM, SoftBank to bring supercomputer to Japan
summary: IBM and SoftBank announced a partnership to bring the Watson supercomputer to Japan, aiming to develop new applications for robotics and services. The move marks the first time Watson will use a non-Latin alphabet, specifically Japanese, to deliver cognitive and natural language capabilities. The alliance seeks to collaborate on improving capabilities in mobile phones, robots, and other areas, with the goal of transforming entire industries and professions.

site_title: China Fishery, Pacific Andes dive on proposed rights issue
summary: China Fishery Group and its largest shareholder Pacific Andes Resources Development saw their stocks plummet following China Fishery's proposed rights issue of up to 1.71 billion new shares at 17.3 Singapore cents apiece. The issue was met with a negative market reaction, with China Fishery's stock diving 28% and Pacific Andes falling 7.3%. The proposal, intended to raise funds to redeem senior notes, was opposed by some directors and a private equity firm, Carlyle Group, which will not subscribe to the issue.

site_title: Obama seeks war mandate from Congress to fight ISIL
summary: US President Barack Obama has submitted a draft authorization to Congress to use military force against the Islamic State (ISIL), limiting operations to three years and excluding US troops from "enduring offensive ground combat." The proposal also seeks to repeal the 2002 Iraq war authorization. Obama's plan must be approved by both the Senate and House of Representatives, amid expected debate between Democrats and Republicans.

site_title: Coca-Cola looks to home as US outpaces rest of world
summary: Coca-Cola is shifting its focus to the US market, where sales rose 2% in the fourth quarter, the largest domestic gain in two years. The company's international divisions saw sluggish sales due to a strong US dollar and local economies. North American sales, fueled by juice and tea sales, outperformed international divisions. Emerging markets, particularly Asia, have seen growth stall. Coca-Cola's CEO Muhtar Kent highlighted the US as the most exciting emerging market, and the company aims to pare $3 billion in annual costs to boost productivity.

images.alt_text: North American sales rose 2 per cent in Q4, the biggest domestic gain in two years.

site_title: Buy your own kingdom - it's the ultimate 'I have arrived' statement
summary: Wealthy buyers are increasingly seeking private islands as a symbol of luxury and exclusivity, with the top 20 island areas for real estate investment including Bermuda, Bahamas, and British Virgin Islands. The global population of high-net-worth individuals is expected to grow 22% by 2018, fueling demand for extraordinary real estate. Private islands typically cost between $1 million and $10 million, with a few rare ones commanding up to $60 million. Exclusivity, proximity to the mainland, and security of ownership are key factors driving the island real estate market.

images.alt_text: Buck Island, a freehold private island estate off the south-east corner of Tortola in the British Virgin Islands, is listed at US$25 million.

site_title: In brief
summary: Karin Technology Holdings reported a 71.9% increase in H1 net profit to HK$31.8 million due to higher revenue in its components distribution segment and consumer electronics products segment. Fortune Reit sold Hong Kong property Nob Hill Square to Tower Key Limited for HK$648 million, while Marco Polo Marine's Q1 profit more than doubled to S$7.41 million despite a 12% dip in revenue.

site_title: 2014 visitor figure misses STB forecast
summary: Singapore's tourism industry experienced a 3.1% decline in visitor arrivals to 15.1 million in 2014, the first decline since 2009, due to uncertain global economy and currency volatility. Despite this, tourism receipts remained flat at S$23.5 billion, with per capita spending rising. The decline was attributed to decreased arrivals from markets such as China and Indonesia, while arrivals from Hong Kong, South Korea, and Vietnam grew. The Singapore Tourism Board plans to ramp up marketing efforts to drive demand, focusing on secondary cities in China and Indonesia, and to market Singapore as a mono-destination.

site_title: Chinese economy more sustainable now, says China central bank
summary: China's economy is now more sustainable, according to Chinese Central Bank vice governor Yi Gang, citing rising domestic consumption. Despite posting its slowest economic growth in 24 years in 2014, China's central bank has taken steps to stimulate growth, including reducing reserve requirements for banks. The central bank is also monitoring the property market and shadow banking sector, which accounts for 71% of China's economy. Finance officials at the G20 meeting expressed an uncertain outlook for global growth, vowing to use monetary and fiscal policy to prevent stagnation.

site_title: Four more banks face NY forex rigging probe
summary: New York's financial regulator has sent subpoenas to four major banks - Goldman Sachs, Credit Suisse, BNP Paribas, and Societe Generale - as part of its probe into possible foreign exchange rate rigging through computer programs. The probe, led by superintendent Benjamin Lawsky, seeks information on discretionary actions by the banks in implementing algorithms. The investigation follows a global probe that fined six banks a total of $4.3 billion for manipulating the foreign exchange market. The US Department of Justice is now pushing the banks to plead guilty to criminal charges.

site_title: Europe launches prototype 'space plane'
summary: The European Space Agency (ESA) has successfully launched a prototype 'space plane' called the Intermediate eXperimental Vehicle (IXV) from its base in Kourou, French Guiana. The 5-metre, two-tonne wingless demonstrator will undergo an 18-minute sub-orbital flight to a height of 400km before descending and splashing down in the Pacific. The IXV aims to demonstrate the feasibility of re-entry and will be used to test the performance of a spacecraft returning to Earth. This marks a significant step in ESA's space strategy, filling a gap in its capabilities.

site_title: Oversupply pushes oil towards US$55
summary: Oil prices slipped towards US$55 a barrel on Wednesday due to expectations of persisting oversupply in world markets. The American Petroleum Institute reported a 1.6 million barrel increase in US crude stocks last week, bringing them to a record high. International Energy Agency forecasts continued supply growth in the US to 2020, leading to a weak market and lower oil prices. Analysts predict oil prices will stabilize below US$100 a barrel, with some expecting a decline towards US$40.

site_title: China's review of foreign investment fuels concern
summary: China is reviewing foreign investments for national security threats, fueling concern among global companies. The review process, part of a proposed Foreign Investment Law, will be conducted by an inter-ministerial body and could lead to the biggest overhaul of China's rules governing foreign investment since the 1970s. The US Chamber of Commerce in China has expressed concerns over the strengthened national security measures, calling for the review process to be limited to national security risks and not national interest or economic security.

site_title: Switzerland slides into deficit on surprise revenue fall
summary: Switzerland's government reported its first federal budget deficit in nearly a decade, with a shortfall of 124 million Swiss francs (118.5 million euros or US$133.8 million) in 2014. The deficit was caused by a 9% drop in key tax revenue, which was lower than forecast. The Swiss government had initially predicted a budget surplus of 121 million francs. The move is seen as a blow to the country's economic growth, which is expected to slow due to the strong Swiss franc.

site_title: The Greek austerity myth(ology)
summary: The article discusses the Greek austerity myth and how it relates to the eurozone. Despite concerns of a potential debt crisis, Greece is the only country in the eurozone that hasn't shown the same level of economic fundamentals as other peripheral countries. The article concludes that Greece's refusal to implement reforms and poor export performance make it a unique case, and a Greek default or exit from the eurozone is less likely than previously thought.

site_title: Companies should comply with SGX's MTP as soon as possible
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) requires companies listed on its mainboard to maintain a minimum trading price (MTP) of 20 cents per share by March 2, 2016. Companies failing to comply will be placed on a watchlist for three years, with the option to transfer to the Catalist board. Failure to meet MTP may result in delisting, but a transfer to Catalist is possible. SGX advises companies to consider share consolidations to meet the MTP requirement.

site_title: US: Stocks open lower ahead of key Greece meeting
summary: US stocks opened lower on Wednesday ahead of a key eurozone meeting where Greek finance ministers will consider a proposal to avoid a sovereign debt default. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 44.13 points to 17,824.63, while the S&P 500 dipped 1.93 to 2,066.66. Strong earnings from Pepsico were unable to spark buying interest due to anxiety about the Eurogroup meeting's potential impact. The meeting is expected to unveil a plan to win stop-gap financing, which has been opposed by the new Greek government.

site_title: Bangkok: Shares rebound from 2 sessions of losses
summary: Thailand's SET index rose 0.64% on Wednesday, snapping two sessions of losses, to finish at 1,605.11. This follows a rebound from losses in previous sessions. The article does not provide further context or explanations for the SET index's movements.

site_title: European stocks decline as investors await Greek bailout talks
summary: European stocks declined as investors awaited Greek bailout talks, with the Stoxx Europe 600 Index falling 0.3% to 371.82. Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis' meeting with euro-area counterparts in Brussels raised concerns, and the yield on three-year Greek notes jumped 115 basis points to 20.66%. Benchmark equity indexes in Spain and Portugal slid at least 0.9%. Investors are waiting for a solution, with some expecting a compromise, but risks remain for equity investors.

site_title: The Hour Glass' profit rises, Cortina's declines
