site_title: Contingency plans needed for Greece's possible euro exit
summary: A possible Greek euro exit could test the fire-walls separating Greece from the rest of the euro area, prompting contingency plans from financial markets and central banks worldwide. Greece's new prime minister Alexis Tsipras and finance minister Yanis Varoufakis are unlikely to compromise, increasing the risk of a parallel domestic currency or a euro exit. The situation is complex, with unresolved dilemmas and geopolitical tensions, and may lead to a volatile outcome, potentially affecting the European Monetary Union and global markets.

images.alt_text: If Mr Tsipras backed down and agreed to extend the international bailout programme beyond the Feb 28 deadline, that would give comfort to his country's leading creditors.

site_title: McDonald's India reducing salt, calories in burgers and fries
summary: McDonald's India is reducing salt and calories in its burgers and fries to cater to a growing demand for healthier fast food options. The changes, made gradually to maintain consistency and customer satisfaction, include a 10% reduction in sodium in sauces and buns, and a 20% reduction in sodium in fries. The goal is to offer healthier alternatives to its traditional menu, in line with the company's global initiative to reduce sodium levels in its food by 2020.

site_title: GSS Energy to make SGX debut on Thursday
summary: GSS Energy is set to debut on the Singapore Stock Exchange (SGX) on Thursday, despite a muted oil price environment. The company is restructuring to expand its presence in the energy sector, leveraging low oil prices. This move is seen as timely, as the company aims to capitalize on the current market conditions.

site_title: Smartphone app will guide you around Gardens by the Bay this CNY
summary: A new smartphone app, ListenIN, will debut at Gardens by the Bay in Singapore over Chinese New Year, providing visitors with a personalized audio guide that delivers multi-language content directly to their smartphones. The technology, developed by Citrine Wireless and Equation Summit, uses positioning technology to allow visitors to explore the attraction at their own pace. The app will also be deployed at other local attractions, with plans to expand to other countries in the future, potentially making existing audio technologies obsolete.

site_title: Hamburg Port sees fall in seaborne trade with Russia accelerating
summary: Hamburg Port expects a drastic decline in seaborne trade with Russia this year, accelerating due to the weak rouble and sanctions over Ukraine. The port's seaborne trade with Russia dropped 7.8% to 662,000 standard boxes in 2014, with car parts exports particularly affected. Meanwhile, trade with China rose 9.8%, helping Hamburg's total container volume reach a record 9.7 million standard boxes. The port expects container traffic to reach 10 million TEUs this year, surpassing a 2007 record.

site_title: Richter's hot streak may extend to UK
summary: GERHARD RICHTER, a 83-year-old German abstract painter, may extend his winning streak in UK art sales with 20 post-war and contemporary art pieces valued at £58.3 million (S$120.4 million) going up for auction in London. Christie's, Sotheby's, and Phillips are offering the works, with a total estimated value of £319.8 million.

site_title: New foreign aid charter signals much more active overseas role for Japan
summary: Japan has adopted a new Development Cooperation Charter, expanding its foreign aid scope to include middle-income nations, not just poorer countries. The revised charter links aid to Japan's National Security Strategy, allowing for a broader view of foreign aid. The move aims to increase Japan's active role in international development, but no specific details on the scope and size of aid were disclosed.

site_title: Bitcoin 'fraud' spurs HKMA warning over virtual currency
summary: Hong Kong's central bank, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), has warned people against investing in virtual currencies, citing a potential bitcoin scandal in which a local exchange, MyCoin, may have absconded with US$387 million in client funds. The case "may involve fraud or pyramid schemes" and highlights the risks associated with the highly speculative and unregulated nature of Bitcoin. The HKMA has long urged caution when dealing with Bitcoin, citing concerns over money laundering and extremist financing.

site_title: 'Disappointments' to hit office Reits: Nomura
summary: Nomura has downgraded its outlook for Singapore's office Reits, predicting potential disappointments in the next 12 months. Disappointments could come from lower-than-expected returns from redevelopment projects, such as the Golden Shoe Car Park and Suntec City Mall's asset enhancement. Nomura has also downgraded its call on Suntec Reit and CapitaCommercial Trust (CCT), recommending a switch to CCT's sponsor CapitaLand. Analysts predict that CCT's CapitaGreen may struggle to achieve its targeted rent of S$12 to S$14 per square foot per month.

site_title: Stingy Korean firms hike dividends to avoid tax
summary: South Korea's new tax law compelling big companies to spend "excess" cash on dividends is prompting traditionally tight-fisted firms to boost payouts. As of February 6, the average dividend increase among 45 companies was 22% per share, despite a 10% drop in 2014 operating profit. Companies such as Samsung Electronics and Hyundai Motor are under pressure from shareholders to hike dividends, and the country's dividend yield remains low at 1.2%, the lowest among major countries.

site_title: US airlines' criticism of Gulf carriers spurs backlash
summary: US airlines, including American, United, and Delta, have criticized Gulf carriers, citing unfair government subsidies that provide a competitive advantage. Emirates, Qatar Airways, and Etihad have responded, arguing that US bankruptcy laws allowed them to shed debt and cut costs. Emirates President Tim Clark denied receiving subsidies, claiming his airline has repaid over $2.8 billion in investments. US airlines seek a review of air treaties with Persian Gulf nations, concerned that the carriers' rapid growth is hurting European carriers and capturing more traffic than needed.

site_title: OW Bunker fallout could lead to exit of Opet S'pore
summary: Opet Trade (Singapore), a subsidiary of Turkey's KOC Holding, is set to exit the fuel oil-and-bunker fuel markets in the second half of the year due to its large exposure to the collapsed Danish marine fuel supplier, OW Bunker Far East. The company has already contacted trading counterparties to close off accounts, settle outstanding payments, and will likely leave the markets by the end of the year. Opet's Singapore office, which has been exposed to other insolvencies, is also expected to shut down.

site_title: Hoopla over Harper Lee's 2nd novel
summary: HarperCollins announced Harper Lee's second novel, sparking controversy over the 88-year-old author's mental state. The news, revealed a week ago, has delighted fans but raised concerns among writers and critics. Lee's first novel, To Kill a Mockingbird, was published over half a century ago and became a classic. The publication of her second novel has left many wondering if Lee is still of sound mind, with some questioning her ability to write another book.

site_title: S'pore, Canada top in financial services' regulatory environments
summary: Singapore has emerged as a global leader in providing a top-notch regulatory environment for financial services, ranking alongside Canada as the only two jurisdictions to achieve "tier one" status. The country excelled in ease of doing business, regulatory environment, and operational risks, but trailed in crime prevention and consumer protection. A survey of over 200 financial professionals found that Singapore and Canada were the only two places to receive the highest ratings for regulatory environments, with the US and UK ranking lower.

site_title: Wake-up call for Modi as BJP is trounced in Delhi local polls
summary: Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) was trounced in Delhi local polls, with the Aam Aadmi Party led by Arvind Kejriwal winning 66 seats, a significant swing from the BJP's 3-seat victory in the previous election. Modi conceded defeat, congratulating Kejriwal on the win and assuring federal government support. The outcome may embolden opposition parties, undermining Modi's support and complicating his moves to increase foreign investment and spur land purchases.

site_title: China's January inflation drops to five-year low
summary: China's inflation rate dropped to a five-year low in January, falling 0.8% year-on-year, with food inflation being the primary driver behind the decrease. Despite seasonal distortions from the Lunar New Year, analysts believe underlying disinflationary pressures have risen, reflecting weakening demand and worsening overcapacity in industries. This could lead to further monetary policy easing and delay consumer purchases. China's economy is expected to slow, with the government potentially lowering its GDP target to 7% this year due to structural rebalancing and external headwinds.

site_title: Universal health coverage a great leveller: WHO chief
summary: World Health Organization (WHO) Director-General Dr. Margaret Chan emphasizes the importance of universal health coverage as a powerful social equalizer and ultimate expression of fairness. She notes that growing inequalities in income and access to social services have reached historic levels, and that well-functioning and inclusive health systems contribute to social cohesion and stability. Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong presents the country's health-care model, which includes mandatory personal savings, a national health insurance scheme, and a co-payment component, and outlines plans to expand comprehensive outpatient treatment and provide universal medical insurance.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Cache Logistics Trust acquires three Australian warehouses for A$75.6 million (S$79.6 million), entering the Australian warehouse market. Yoma Strategic Holdings sees Q3FY15 results broadly in line with expectations, but downgrades to "hold" due to full valuation. Parkson Retail Asia reports in-line H1FY15 core profits and upgrades to "add" with a target price of S$0.92, driven by potential for higher earnings in H2.

site_title: US$ strengthens; euro buffeted by Greek events
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the euro, sinking below $1.13 in morning trade but recovering to $1.1296 by midday, amid higher US Treasury yields and concerns over Greece's debt deal. The euro's decline was fueled by official comments and media reports on the progress of discussions over a new debt deal for Greece. The US dollar's resurgence was also driven by a quieter week of trading and overnight gains for commodity-dependent currencies.

site_title: The case for abandoning the euro - at least for now
summary: A renowned economist, Peter Jay, has long argued that the euro is unsustainable due to the lack of fiscal union among member states. He believes that countries should abandon the euro and revert to national currencies to allow for exchange rate adjustments and competitiveness. Jay's concerns have been echoed in recent years, particularly with the Greek exit from the eurozone. However, devaluation is not a panacea for countries like Greece, and the euro's weakness may have unintended consequences, such as exacerbating economic instability. Jay's argument highlights the need for a more integrated economic framework in Europe.

site_title: US pushing for banks to admit forex manipulation
summary: The US Justice Department is pushing major banks, including Barclays, JPMorgan Chase, and Citigroup, to plead guilty to manipulating foreign currency prices. Following a long-running investigation, prosecutors are seeking guilty pleas from these banks, which could carry a symbolic stigma but limited practical fallout. New York state regulators have also uncovered evidence of electronic trading platforms that drove up currency prices for clients. Negotiations are underway, with banks preferring a subsidiary to take the fall for wrongdoing. The case may add to criticism of prosecutors not charging top Wall Street executives, but it represents a last opportunity for the Justice Department to shape its white-collar legacy under Attorney General Eric Holder.

site_title: Deflation is better than its reputation
summary: Deflation, often viewed as a negative economic phenomenon, may actually boost household purchasing power when nominal wages remain unchanged or rise. This is because deflation increases the real value of income, encouraging consumption. However, the impact of deflation on the economy is complex and influenced by factors such as debt, asset prices, and financial institutions' balance sheets. Central banks may struggle to curb money supply, as restrictive monetary policies could lead to higher interest rates, unsustainable government deficits, and reduced asset prices. The article concludes that deflation's effects on the economy are not as clear-cut as previously thought, and policymakers must carefully consider the potential consequences of their actions.

images.alt_text: Financial institutions enjoy the luxury of liquidity. They can go for balance sheet improvement or lending to the business sector. Deflation in itself does not play any significant role in their choice.

site_title: Korean casino expands as more Chinese arrive
summary: South Korea's largest casino operator, Paradise Co, plans to expand its casinos and increase the number of gambling tables by over 10% as the number of Chinese visitors surges. The expansion aims to capitalize on China's crackdown on Macau and tougher visa rules. With 6.1 million mainland Chinese visitors to South Korea last year, a 42% increase, Paradise will add 26 tables and expand floor space at three of its casinos, including doubling the size of one in Jeju Island. The expansion is expected to boost gaming revenue as Chinese gamblers seek alternative markets.

site_title: Anwar's sodomy conviction upheld
summary: A Malaysian court upheld a sodomy conviction for Anwar Ibrahim, the country's opposition leader, with a five-year prison sentence. The decision marks the culmination of a long-standing legal battle and a high-stakes struggle for political supremacy. Anwar had been sentenced by a lower court last year, and the Federal Court rejected prosecutors' request for a longer sentence. The conviction is seen as a significant setback for Anwar and his opposition party, with implications for the country's political landscape.

site_title: UK's general election outcome to leave investors in the lurch
summary: The UK's general election outcome is expected to leave investors uncertain, with banks including Morgan Stanley and Deutsche Bank warning of potential instability. A Conservative-led government may lead to a British exit from the EU, while a Labour-led one risks increasing the budget deficit. Polls suggest a possible minority government or coalition, raising concerns about investment and economic growth. The prospect of a referendum on EU membership unnerves investors the most, with economists predicting a potential decline in the pound and increased interest rates.

site_title: Accepting the inevitable on sulphur
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) has agreed that the global 0.5% sulphur in fuel cap is more likely to be implemented from 2020 rather than 2025, citing concerns over the lack of availability of compliant fuel. The ICS chairman, Masamichi Morooka, stated that the shipping industry should prepare for the implementation of the cap, as the EU has already agreed to a 0.5% limit within 200 miles of their coasts. The ICS believes that the global cap will "dramatically increase the cost of marine fuel" but notes that the shipping industry is rapidly adopting abatement technology, making the cap's implementation less of an issue in the long run.

site_title: Need to market bus transport in US to save on rail lines
summary: A 2009 report from the Federal Transit Administration found that public transit in the US suffers from an image problem, leading to the construction of new rail infrastructure despite buses being faster. This issue is exemplified in Governor Andrew Cuomo's proposed AirTrain link from La Guardia Airport in New York, which may cost $450 million-$1 billion but won't be faster than existing bus service. The report highlights a perverse outcome where transit agencies prioritize train infrastructure over bus service due to riders' perceived preference for trains over buses.

site_title: HSBC under fire over 'tax dodging' client data
summary: HSBC, the world's second-largest bank, is under fire for allegedly helping wealthy clients evade taxes through its Swiss private bank. US authorities are investigating whether the bank assisted Americans in hiding millions of dollars in assets, and a deferred prosecution agreement with the bank may be reopened. British lawmakers plan an inquiry into the bank's practices, and HSBC's CEO has stated that past practices are unacceptable and the bank has no appetite to deal with tax-evading clients. The bank's admission of failing has renewed scrutiny on former executives, including Stephen Green, who was executive chairman between 2006 and 2010.

site_title: Politics may hinder clean-up job by new Petrobras chief
summary: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff appointed Aldemir Bendine, a banker, as the new head of Petrobras, amidst efforts to clean up the state-run company's books. Rousseff's choice signals she wants to maintain control over Petrobras, potentially hindering the company's ability to release a realistic estimate of graft-related losses. The company faces a US$22 billion loss and a potential US$54 billion debt crisis, which could lead to investors declaring the company in default. Rousseff's approval rating is already low, and analysts expect her to downplay the extent of the losses to maintain control.

site_title: 800 Super Holdings H1 profit up on stronger sales
summary: 800 Super Holdings reported a 95.4% jump in net profit for its first half of 2015, reaching S$4.62 million, compared to S$2.36 million the same period last year. Revenue increased 23.7% to S$64.5 million. The strong sales performance is attributed to the company's growth in waste management.

site_title: Valuetronics posts 10.3% rise in Q3 profit
summary: Valuetronics, a Singapore-based design and manufacturing partner, reported a 10.3% increase in Q3 profit to HK$39.2 million, driven by a 3.4% rise in revenue, mainly from its industrial and commercial electronics sector. However, consumer electronics revenue fell 6.4% due to a slowdown in demand. The company attributed challenges to the CE segment to aggressive pricing by LED lighting customers and plans to manage reliance on the segment while focusing on growth from its ICE customers.

site_title: US: Stocks up in early trading
summary: US stocks rose in early trading on Tuesday, driven by hopes for a Greek default deal and solid earnings from Coca-Cola. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 83.87 points to 17,813.08, while the S&P 500 rose 9.80 to 2,056.54. The Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 24.13 to 4,750.14. Coca-Cola's 3.5% rise was attributed to its 44 cents per share earnings, beating analyst estimates. The Greek stock market surged 8% on optimism about a Brussels meeting.

site_title: US wholesale inventories up marginally
summary: US wholesale inventories rose 0.1% in December, a marginally lower increase than economists' forecast of 0.2%. The rise was attributed to lower crude oil prices weighing on petroleum stock values. This suggests that fourth-quarter growth may be revised lower, indicating a slower economic pace.

site_title: UBS falls after warning profit may be hurt by franc, interest rates
summary: UBS Group AG fell 3.4% in morning trading after reporting lower-than-expected earnings from its wealth management division, citing the strong franc and negative interest rates as a major concern. The bank doubled its dividend, but underlying earnings missed estimates. UBS attributed the decline to its wealth management unit, which saw lower gross margin and net new funds. The bank's investment bank, however, reported a 24% profit increase. Despite the disappointing results, the bank aims to boost its adjusted return on equity to 10% this year and 15% from 2016.

site_title: Newsweek Twitter feed seems hijacked by pro-IS hacker
summary: Newsweek's Twitter feed was hijacked by pro-Islamic State (IS) hackers, displaying messages in support of the group and referencing the "Je Suis IS" hashtag. The hijacking appeared similar to the hacking of the US Central Command Twitter feed last month. The hijacked feed was restored shortly after, with an empty logo, but not before displaying images and messages in support of IS. The incident occurred just days after the deadly attacks at French weekly Charlie Hebdo.

site_title: Job openings in US rose in December to highest since 2001
summary: US job openings rose to 5.03 million in December, the highest level since 2001, with an increase of 181,000 from the previous month. This marks the fifth consecutive month of hiring growth, fueling confidence and driving sales. The strong hiring pace is expected to boost wage growth, which has been slow to materialize during the recovery.

site_title: Michelin pledges extra cost cuts after full-year profit decline
summary: Michelin reported an 8.5% profit decline in 2014, with net income falling to 1.03 billion euros. Revenue dropped 3.4% to 19.55 billion euros, missing forecasts. The company attributed the decline to weaker demand and stiffer competition, particularly in the North American truck tyres sector. Michelin pledged to step up cost-cutting efforts, aiming to save 1.2 billion euros by 2016, with a focus on accelerating its competitiveness plan.

images.alt_text: Mr Senard said the competitiveness plan will also be accelerated, pledging 1.2 billion euros of savings in the 2012-2016 period, an increase of 200 million euros.

site_title: G-20 confronts income inequality scourge
summary: The G-20 finance chiefs expressed concern over mounting income inequality, stating it may threaten economic and political stability. The gap between rich and poor has widened, with the richest 10% earning 9.5 times more than the poorest 10% in OECD countries. The officials vowed to strive for inclusive growth and address income inequality through policies. This marks the first time the G-20 has explicitly mentioned income disparity in a communique.

site_title: In brief
summary: Otto Marine warned of a full-year loss due to cost overruns and low vessel utilisation. Stamford Land's Q3 profit fell 15% as revenue eased, while 800 Super Holdings' H1 profit doubled on stronger sales. UG Healthcare's H1 profit fell 17% due to weaker revenue, and Grand Banks' Q2 profit plummeted 78.4% in the absence of year-ago gains.

site_title: HSBC condemns past practices
summary: HSBC's private bank head has condemned past practices that may have allowed clients to dodge taxes, amid investigations by US authorities and British lawmakers. The Swiss private bank admitted failings in compliance and controls, and British Business Secretary Vince Cable questioned how quickly the business stopped such practices. HSBC faces pressure to explain its conduct, with some claiming the issues may have continued recently.

site_title: KL needs to work towards rebuilding M'sians' trust in judiciary and govt
summary: Malaysia's highest court upheld Anwar Ibrahim's sodomy conviction with a five-year jail term after a seven-year court battle. The Malaysian government defended the independence of the judiciary, stating that exhaustive due process was followed. The verdict came after nine judges and 20 lawyers were involved in the case. The government called on all parties to respect the legal process and judgment. This decision is seen as a setback for opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim, who is a key figure in Malaysian politics.

site_title: Microsoft, Samsung settle contract dispute over patent royalties
summary: Microsoft and Samsung have settled a contract dispute over patent royalties, with terms remaining confidential. The lawsuit, filed in 2014, claimed Samsung owed Microsoft $6.9 million in interest on delayed patent royalties. Samsung countered that Microsoft's acquisition of Nokia violated its 2011 collaboration deal. The settlement also ends Samsung's request for arbitration with the International Court of Commerce. The terms of the settlement have not been disclosed.

site_title: US fracking slump threatens Indian guar industry
summary: India's guar gum industry is facing a crisis due to the US fracking slump, with orders dwindling and prices plummeting. India is the world's largest producer and supplier of guar gum, used to extract shale oil and gas, but a fracking boom has led to a glut, contributing to crude's 48% slide in the past year. Indian companies, including Vikas WSP Ltd, are idling 40% of their capacity and expecting sales to drop, with some factories shutting down. The industry's woes are a ripple effect of the global economy's response to the drop in crude prices.

site_title: S'pore startup ConneXionsAsia raises US$8m Series A funding
summary: ConneXionsAsia, a Singapore startup, has raised US$8 million in Series A funding to expand its platform that repurposes workplace insurance in Asia. Founded in 2013, the company offers companies a platform to efficiently manage existing corporate healthcare spend by lowering insurance coverage and investing in wellness services. The funding, led by NSI Ventures, will support regional growth, technology investment, and hiring talent. ConneXionsAsia plans to expand to 12 countries in Asia and grow revenues from US$6 million to over US$100 million by 2019.

site_title: US West Coast ports resume full operations
summary: US West Coast ports resumed full operations on Monday after shipping companies halted loading and unloading of freighters for the weekend due to chronic cargo backups. The planned resumption of federally mediated contract talks was postponed until Wednesday. The White House urged the sides to settle the dispute, which has affected the US commercial supply chain, with potential losses estimated at $2 billion per day. The ports, which handle nearly half of US maritime trade, have been plagued by labour tensions and congestion, with 23 vessels waiting to be unloaded outside Los Angeles and Long Beach.

site_title: Some firms paying insurers to take on ballooning pension costs
summary: Companies are transferring pension risk to insurers, paying billions to avoid increased costs due to longer lifespans. Dozens of deals are expected this year, with demand potentially exceeding insurers' capacity. Investment banks may sell "death derivatives" as a result. The transfer market is expected to grow as interest rates rise, making deals more affordable. Companies are caught between retaining pension risk and unloading it, with low interest rates a major deterrent.

site_title: Rate cut seen inflating Australia housing bubble
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia's benchmark interest rate cut has led to an increase in Australian homebuyers, with 70% of mortgage broker Geoff Schippers' clients now considering purchasing a property. This surge in demand is attributed to the low interest rate, motivating people to enter the market after previously being on the sidelines. The rate cut is seen as inflating the housing bubble, with potential long-term consequences for the market.

site_title: US warns G20 against using exchange rates to boost exports
summary: The US Treasury Secretary Jack Lew urged G20 nations not to use exchange rates to boost exports, emphasizing the need to maintain a level playing field for US workers and firms. A draft G20 communique acknowledged uneven global growth and rising financial market volatility, while welcoming quantitative easing by the European Central Bank. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates this year, contrasting with monetary policies diverging among other major economies.

site_title: Britain, Germany 'actively discussing' extending EU Russia sanctions
summary: Britain and Germany are actively discussing extending EU sanctions on Russia, with British Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond favoring rolling over existing measures until the end of the year. The sanctions regime is to be maintained unless there is a breakthrough in the Ukrainian peace process. Hammond stated that Germany is "robust" on this issue and is exploring the possibility of an extension after planned Ukraine peace talks on Wednesday.

site_title: Otto Marine warns of full-year loss
summary: Otto Marine warned of a full-year loss for the 2014 financial year due to a cost overrun for vessel construction, low utilization, and delayed charter commencements in the offshore chartering segment. The company expects to report a loss, citing these factors as major contributors.

site_title: Greek bonds up for first time in 5 days amid hopes of compromise
summary: Greek government bonds rose for the first time in five days amid hopes of a compromise between Greece and its international creditors. Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis proposed a short-term funding program and plans to implement 70% of existing reforms. The move is seen as a willingness to compromise, leading to a 172 basis point drop in three-year note yield to 19.36%. A resolution is expected, possibly by the end of this month, before the current bailout expires.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Tuesday
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Notable stories include Vietnam's surprise at US Trump tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate, and the Asian garment industry bracing for higher US tariffs. Malaysia is set to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Citigroup forecasts a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index. Thai Prime Minister Thaksin remains confident his daughter will be cleared in an ethics case. The Asean region has downplayed the Myanmar election, while the UK economy shrinks for the second consecutive month, a blow to Starmer's government.

site_title: UG Healthcare H1 profit falls 17% on weaker sales (Amended)
summary: UG Healthcare reported a 17% decline in net profit for the first half of 2015, to S$2.41 million, due to weaker revenue of 3.5% to S$25.1 million. Costs remained steady. The decline is attributed to a weaker sales performance.

site_title: Emirates hiring 11,000 shows growth ambitions of Gulf carrier
summary: Emirates plans to hire 11,000 staff by March 2016, increasing its workforce by 6% and adding to its 75,000 employees. Half of the new hires will join as cabin crew, while the rest will be distributed across various departments. The airline's growth ambitions are driven by its expansion of route networks and delivery of over 20 new aircraft this year, with a total order of 140 double-decker A380s. This move aims to underscore Emirates' position as the world's leading global airline.

images.alt_text: Emirates Group plans to add 11,000 staff to businesses spanning the world's No 1 international airline to ground-handling, underscoring the company's growth ambitions as it draws fire from carriers feeling squeezed out of the market.

site_title: UK pension deficit hits record high
summary: The UK's private sector pension plans have reached a record high deficit of £367.5 billion, up from £266.3 billion in December, according to the Pension Protection Fund. The funding ratio fell to 77.6% and 5,175 schemes are in deficit due to record-low bond yields. This is the third consecutive month of pension deficit growth, posing a challenge for the UK's pension system.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 0.46 points lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 0.46 points lower at 1,811.12 on Tuesday, with 2.47 billion lots valued at RM2.29 billion traded. Losers outnumbered gainers 434 to 373.

site_title: From March 2016, CPF savings cannot be used to buy stocks on SGX watch-list
summary: The CPF board announced that starting March 1, 2016, CPF savings held under the CPF Investment Scheme will not be allowed to purchase securities on the Singapore Exchange's watch-list, safeguarding members' savings from potential de-listing. This restriction aims to prevent CPF savings from being at risk if companies under the watch-list fail to exit the SGX.

site_title: Stamford Land Q3 profit down 14.7% on weaker sales
summary: STAMFORD Land Corporation reported a 14.7% decline in net profit for its fiscal third quarter, to S$12.8 million, due to weaker sales. Revenue fell 18.8% to S$67.8 million. The decline was attributed to the company's weaker sales performance.

site_title: SBS Transit's full-year profit up 27.8% at S$14.3m
summary: SBS Transit's net profit for the year ended Dec 31, 2014, grew 27.8% to S$14.3 million, driven by non-bus businesses and a 12.2% revenue increase to S$951.0 million. The bus operation incurred a loss of S$13.5 million, but revenue from the segment rose 10.5% due to increased ridership and fares. The rail business saw a 19.5% revenue increase to S$197.0 million. A one-tier final dividend of 1.05 cents has been proposed.

images.alt_text: The core bus operation on its own continued to suffer losses, with a loss of S$13.5 million incurred for 2014.

site_title: Samsung Elec 2015 dividend likely less than in 2014: source
summary: Samsung Electronics is likely to pay out a smaller amount in dividends this year compared to 2014, according to a source with direct knowledge of the matter. The company's 2014 dividend payout was influenced by exceptional circumstances to boost shareholder value, but this year's payout is expected to be lower. The average increase in dividend payouts among 45 firms in South Korea was 22% per share, while Samsung's 2014 payout was up 40% per share. The company had previously guided for a "special increase" in the end-2014 dividend, leading some investors to expect lower payouts in 2015.

site_title: Liongold Q3 loss widens on expenses
summary: Liongold Corp reported a widened net loss of S$12.5 million in its fiscal third quarter, up from S$10.9 million in the same period last year, due to increased expenses. The company attributed the rise in expenses to a S$10.5 million loss on the disposal of subsidiaries. Liongold faces challenges from weak gold prices, depressed share prices, and a challenging fundraising environment.

site_title: Singapore: Shares finish the day higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 16.22 points to close at 3,434.24 on Tuesday, with a trading volume of 973.6 million shares worth S$1.12 billion. Gainers outpaced losers 207 to 204. This marks the fifth consecutive day of gains, ahead of upcoming GDP data.

site_title: SNB faces deflation challenge as Swiss prices plunge
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) faces a deflation challenge as prices in Switzerland plummet due to the strength of the franc. The SNB's decision to abandon its 1.20 euro ceiling has led to a 20% price cut on luxury brands and cheaper imports, threatening to deepen a drop in the inflation rate, which is expected to remain below zero this year. This move highlights the challenge central-bank officials face in stoking consumer-price growth.

site_title: Greece readies reform deal as debt meeting looms
summary: Greece's leftist government is finalizing a reform deal with EU creditors ahead of crucial talks this week. Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras aims to secure stop-gap financing and an austerity-free reform agreement to run from September 1. The talks come as Greece faces a confidence vote in parliament and time is running out to convince creditors. The reform deal is seen as a key step in liberating Greece from a "toxic" bailout.

site_title: Apple said to offer 750m Swiss francs of bonds in debut
summary: Apple plans to sell 750 million Swiss francs ($810 million) of bonds in its debut offering in the currency. The 500 million francs of bonds maturing in 2024 will have a 0.375% coupon, while the 250 million francs of notes due in 2030 will have a 0.750% coupon. The move allows Apple to take advantage of record-low Swiss funding costs. This is Apple's 12th bond sale since April 2013, with the company issuing over $39 billion in bonds to date.

site_title: Observers call for Town Councils Act to have more bite
summary: Observers in Singapore are calling for stronger penalties in the Town Councils Act to give it more enforcement power. The existing Act is criticized for being "without bite" due to lack of clear penalties for non-compliance. Minister Khaw is set to address the need for a stronger legislative framework in Parliament. This comes after critics pointed out that the Act outlines numerous rules but fails to specify consequences for those who don't follow them.

images.alt_text: National Development Minister Khaw Boon Wan speaks during an interview in Singapore, on Dec 20, 2010. Observers speaking to The Business Times ahead of Thursday's Parliament sitting have recommended that clear and strong penalties be spelt out if the Town Councils Act is to have any teeth.

site_title: Grand Banks Yachts Q2 profit down 78% from absence of year-ago gains
summary: Grand Banks Yachts reported a 78.4% decline in Q2 net profit to S$58,000 due to the absence of year-ago gains from doubtful debt recoveries. Revenue rose 33.6% to S$12.7 million, driven by the sale of two inventory yachts. The company attributed the decline in other operating income to the recovery of doubtful debts in the previous quarter.

site_title: Update: Anwar Ibrahim found guilty in sodomy trial
summary: Malaysia's highest court found opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim guilty of sodomy, upholding a five-year jail term. The verdict, seen as politically motivated, follows a ruling by the Court of Appeal last year. Sodomy is illegal in Malaysia, carrying a jail term of up to 20 years. The guilty verdict is a significant blow to Anwar Ibrahim, who has been a prominent figure in Malaysian politics for decades.

site_title: Greek defence minister says Greece has Plan B if EU rigid on deal
summary: Greek Defence Minister Panos Kammenos stated that if Greece fails to secure a new debt agreement with the euro zone, it will explore alternative funding sources, including the US, Russia, China, or other countries. This plan, referred to as Plan B, is a contingency measure if the EU and Germany refuse to ease austerity measures. Kammenos, leader of the Independent Greeks party, emphasized the desire for a deal but acknowledged the need for a Plan B in case negotiations fail.

site_title: Millennium & Copthorne Hotels' profit falls; no special dividend
summary: Millennium & Copthorne Hotels Plc reported a 36.3% decline in full-year profit to £188 million (S$388 million) due to a 22.4% drop in revenue to £826 million. The company cited the sale of its Glyndebourne condominium development in Singapore as a contributing factor to the previous year's profit. No special dividend will be paid this year.

site_title: Seagate to invest US$470m in Thailand over next 5 years
summary: Seagate Technology Plc plans to invest 15.3 billion baht (S$635.5 million) in Thailand over the next five years to expand capacity at its existing facility in Nakhon Ratchasima province. The investment will include building a new facility, expected to be operational by 2016. Seagate has two plants in Thailand, with its Nakhon Ratchasima facility being its largest hard drive campus in the world.

site_title: Japan's SoftBank net profit boosted by Alibaba listing
summary: SoftBank's nine-month net profit rose 15.9% to a record high of 579.4 billion yen, driven by its 33% stake in Alibaba, which listed in New York last year, generating a $5 billion gain. However, net profit dived 79.1% in the December quarter due to losses at US wireless carrier Sprint. Revenue soared 41% to 6.4 trillion yen, but operating profit fell 16.2% to 788.0 billion yen due to costs and absence of one-off gains. SoftBank left its annual operating profit estimate unchanged at 900 billion yen.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on Greek debt fears, profit-taking
summary: Australian shares fell for a second day, dropping 14.3 points or 0.25% to 5800.6, amid concerns about Greek debt negotiations and uninspiring economic data. The decline follows a two-week run of gains. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.25% to 5784.1. The drop is attributed to investors cutting exposure due to uncertainty in the global market.

site_title: China central bank says to support growth but avoid over stimulating economy
summary: China's central bank said it will fine-tune monetary policy to support growth without over-stimulating the economy, citing downward pressures. The People's Bank of China will use quantitative and pricing tools to maintain liquidity levels and reasonable credit growth. The central bank reaffirmed its pledge to keep the yuan stable. This move comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Oil price fall allows states to 'reassess fiscal policies': G20
summary: The G20 leading economies stated that the recent decline in oil prices will provide a "boost" to global growth, allowing states to reassess their fiscal policies to sustain economic activity. However, growth remains "uneven" and the recovery is "slow" in some economies, particularly in the eurozone and Japan. The group warned of the risk of stagnation in some advanced economies due to low inflation and demand weaknesses. They also committed to deepening cooperation against terrorism financing and urged countries to comply with international standards. This reassessment aims to sustain economic activity and address global growth concerns.

site_title: Fragrance Group Q4 profit drops 40% on weaker fair value gains
summary: Fragrance Group reported a 40.4% drop in net profit for the fiscal fourth quarter to S$79.7 million, mainly due to a weaker fair-value gain on its investment properties. The group's other operating income fell 47.2% and gross profit slipped 6.4% to S$44.2 million, driven by lower selling prices of property development units.

site_title: China stocks end up, low inflation raises policy easing prospect
summary: Chinese stocks rose for a second day, driven by lower-than-expected inflation and a weakened economy. The CSI300 index gained 1.8% and the Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.5% as investors anticipated further monetary easing. Despite this, concerns about the economy's bottoming out kept investors cautious. Factory deflation and a five-year low in consumer inflation highlighted the persistent weakness in the economy. Analysts expect policy easing to follow, but investors remain wary.

site_title: Japan foresees revenue shortfall in surplus target year 2021
summary: The Japanese government forecasts a US$345 billion revenue shortfall in the fiscal year to March 2021, despite aiming to return to a primary budget surplus. Despite growth policies, the debt burden remains a challenge, and the ministry projects a 40.8 trillion yen shortfall, widening from a 36.9 trillion yen shortfall forecast for the coming fiscal year.

site_title: Facebook brings Internet push to India, ties with Reliance Comm
summary: Facebook has partnered with Reliance Communications in India to offer a free Internet.org app, providing access to over 30 web services, including job listings, healthcare, and education sites, as well as Facebook's social network. This marks the first time Facebook has added services beyond its own website, targeting low-income and rural users. The service is available via the Android operating system and follows previous launches in Zambia, Tanzania, Kenya, Ghana, and Colombia.

images.alt_text: Facebook Inc has tied up with India's Reliance Communications Ltd to offer free access to a handful of online services in India, broadening its campaign to boost Internet use in the developing world.

site_title: Denmark suffers deflation shock first time in 60 years
summary: Denmark experiences deflation for the first time in 60 years, with consumer prices falling 0.1% in January from a year earlier. The drop is attributed to lower transport and clothing costs. To combat capital inflows, the central bank has cut the benchmark deposit rate to minus 0.75%, aiming to deter speculators. Despite the deflation, economists consider it a positive development for the Danish economy, as it may support purchasing power. The central bank maintains the krone's peg to the euro within a 2.25% tolerance band.

site_title: UBS says trebles dividend for 2014 after rise in quarterly profit
summary: UBS reported a net profit of 963 million Swiss francs (S$1.41 billion) for the fourth quarter of 2014, exceeding analysts' forecast of 937 million francs. The bank's capital targets were reached, allowing it to pay shareholders 0.75 francs per share for the year, a three-fold increase from 2013. The payout was also made possible by the completion of a change in legal structure, which enabled the return of excess capital to investors. The bank had previously settled past scandals, including a US$1 billion payment in 2014.

site_title: Singaporean couples plan to spend over US$100 each on Valentine's Day: survey
summary: Singaporean couples plan to spend over US$100 each on Valentine's Day, surpassing the spending habits of most countries polled in a recent Groupon survey. 33% of respondents stated they would spend between US$100 and US$199, with dinner at a nice restaurant being the primary way to celebrate. This is higher than the 19% of Australians who planned to spend similarly.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end the day flat
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day flat, reversing early losses, with the Hang Seng Index edging up 7.10 points to 24,528.10. Shanghai stocks, however, rallied as Chinese inflation data showed a near five-year low, sparking speculation of fresh monetary easing measures. The Shanghai Composite Index jumped 1.50% to 3,141.59, while the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 1.55% to 1,512.49.

site_title: Hong Kong warns over digital currencies amid alleged bitcoin fraud
summary: Hong Kong's central bank has warned people against investing in digital currencies, citing a potential bitcoin scandal involving a Hong Kong-based exchange, MyCoin, which allegedly absconded with US$387 million in client funds. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority described the case as "potentially the biggest bitcoin scandal" since last year's Mt.Gox bankruptcy. The warning comes amid concerns over the speculative nature of bitcoin and its potential use for money laundering and extremist financing.

site_title: Russian business woos Japan despite sanctions
summary: Russian business lobby group seeks Japanese investment amid economic struggles due to Western sanctions linked to the Ukraine crisis. Moscow hopes to tempt Japan with oil and gas as the US and Europe delay further measures. Alexey Repik, President of the Russian-Japanese Business Council, emphasized the potential for a "sunrise" of cooperation between the two nations. Russian businesses aim to replace lost funds and capitalize on Japan's resource-poor status.

site_title: Thai cops arrest ringleader of 'anti-monarchy' network
summary: Thai police arrested Hasadin Uraipraiwan, the ringleader of an 'anti-monarchy' network, on Tuesday. The network, known as the Banpodj Network, published audio recordings defaming the royal family. Uraipraiwan was charged under Thailand's strict lese majeste legislation and handed over to military custody. The network's activities have raised concerns about the politicization of Thailand's royal slur law, targeting opponents of the coup.

site_title: Taiwan pays homage to TransAsia plane crash victims
summary: Taiwan honors the 40 victims of the TransAsia plane crash, with flags flown at half-mast across the country. A memorial service is scheduled, while divers continue to search for the last three missing victims in the Keelung River. Investigators are still trying to determine the cause of the crash, which occurred after the right engine "flamed out" about two minutes after takeoff. The incident has led to cancellations of over 120 domestic flights and a retraining program for all TransAsia pilots.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down 0.33%
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 0.33% lower on Tuesday, driven by a firm yen and concerns over Greece's bailout talks. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 59.25 points to 17,652.68, while the Topix index edged up 0.20% to 1,427.72.

site_title: DBS chief: not approached for StanChart CEO job, not keen to leave
summary: DBS Group Holdings CEO Piyush Gupta stated that he has not been approached for the CEO position at Standard Chartered and is not interested in leaving his current role. Gupta's name had been mentioned as a potential replacement for embattled CEO Peter Sands. He expressed his satisfaction with his current position and ruled out any approaches.

site_title: China auto sales climb 10% in January on SUV and minivan demand
summary: China's auto sales rose 10% in January, driven by demand for SUVs and minivans. Retail deliveries of passenger vehicles reached 2.07 million units, with SUV sales surging 62% and minivan sales advancing 22%. This growth is expected to continue, with forecasts predicting a 7% expansion in vehicle sales this year. However, local authorities are stepping up restrictions to limit deliveries, citing concerns over smog and traffic congestion. General Motors' sales fell 2.4% in January, while Toyota Motor Corp boosted deliveries by 11%.

site_title: Oil prices fall as IEA predicts gradual rebound
summary: Oil prices fell in Asian trading hours after the International Energy Agency (IEA) predicted a gradual rebound over the next five years, with prices recovering from around $50-55 per barrel to $73 per barrel in 2020. US benchmark WTI fell 68 cents to $52.18, and Brent crude eased 80 cents to $57.54. The IEA attributed the price drop to a surge in global reserves and weak demand, but predicts market rebalancing occurring "relatively swiftly" with increases in inventories and tightening.

site_title: Canon to buy Sweden's Axis Communications for US$2.8b
summary: Canon Inc. agreed to purchase Sweden's Axis Communications AB for 23.6 billion Swedish kronor (US$2.8 billion). The acquisition is Canon's largest-ever, and the offer price is 340 kronor per share, about 50% higher than Monday's closing price. This deal aims to diversify Canon's printer business, as traditional camera sales decline.

site_title: Taiwan's China affairs chief steps down over court ruling
summary: Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council chief, Wang Yu-chi, resigned after objecting to a court ruling clearing a former deputy, Chang Hsien-ya, of leaking sensitive information to mainland China. Chang had been under investigation since 2014, but prosecutors found insufficient evidence. Wang's resignation was in response to the decision, but he stated he respected it. The move does not appear to impact cross-strait relations, which have seen increased talks and business ties in recent years.

site_title: Singapore's healthcare model strengthened to deal with ageing population, changing disease patterns: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's healthcare model has been strengthened to address an ageing population and changing disease patterns. The government has made four shifts to achieve universal health coverage: providing comprehensive outpatient treatment, replacing MediShield with MediShield Life, right-siting healthcare services, and encouraging healthier lifestyles. MediShield Life will offer better protection with subsidised premiums for lower- and middle-income groups. The director-general of the World Health Organisation praises Singapore's move as a powerful social equaliser, but notes that universal health coverage requires a supportive environment, a home-grown approach, and a country's unique culture and institutions.

site_title: India PM Modi concedes defeat in Delhi state elections
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi conceded defeat in Delhi state elections, with anti-corruption campaigner Arvind Kejriwal's Aam Aadmi Party winning a landslide victory. Early results showed the AAP ahead in 66 seats, while the BJP won just three. Modi congratulated Kejriwal on his win and assured the national government's support. The defeat marks a setback for Modi's efforts to consolidate power and push through economic reforms, and a significant victory for the AAP, which is set to form a new government in Delhi.

site_title: Asia: Stocks hit by Greek fears, China data spurs Shanghai
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday due to concerns over Greece's debt crisis, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Sydney falling 0.64%, 0.19%, and 0.32%, respectively. Shanghai bucked the trend, gaining 0.38% after China reported inflation at its lowest level in over five years. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis are seeking bridging loans to renegotiate the country's bailout, but European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker expressed skepticism about a new deal.

site_title: Japan high school girls on mobiles seven hours a day: survey
summary: High school girls in Japan spend an average of 7 hours a day on their mobile phones, with nearly 10% using over 15 hours, a survey by Digital Arts found. Boys average 4 hours of mobile phone use daily. The survey, which polled 618 children, highlights growing concerns over youngsters' addiction to portable technology. Heavy phone use has been linked to neurological changes similar to those caused by alcohol or cocaine dependency, and nearly all Japanese high schoolers (96%) have a mobile phone.

site_title: Parliament to discuss strengthening of Town Councils Act on Feb 12
summary: The Singapore Parliament will discuss strengthening the Town Councils Act on February 12, following a critical audit of Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council (AHPETC) that highlighted financial and accounting system deficiencies, lack of transparency, and mismanagement of public funds. The Minister for National Development, Khaw Boon Wan, aims to introduce a motion to strengthen the legislative framework for Town Councils and hold them accountable for good management. The move comes in response to concerns over the "toothless" current Act.

site_title: Resale prices of condos dipped 0.2% in January over December: SRX flash estimate
summary: Resale condo prices in Singapore dipped 0.2% in January, according to SRX flash estimates. Year-on-year, prices have dropped 6.5% since January 2014. The median transaction over X-Value (TOX) stood at negative S$10,000, indicating buyers are overpaying or underpaying. Non-landed private residential prices continue to face downward pressure, with a 25.9% increase in resale volume compared to the same period last year.

site_title: DBS takes one-off commodity charges in China: CEO
summary: DBS Group Holdings, Singapore's largest bank, took one-off commodity charges in China in its fourth quarter results. CEO Piyush Gupta stated that these charges were not a major concern, as the bank's overall portfolio remains solid. Despite a small rise in core net profit, the bank fell short of analysts' estimates due to increased provisions for non-performing loans in China and Singapore.

site_title: Gold adds to gains as fears over Greece hit equities
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,242.90 an ounce, extending gains for a second session, amid worries over Greece's potential withdrawal from the eurozone and escalating conflict in Ukraine. Investors sought safe-haven assets as risk appetite declined and global equities fell. The probability of Greece leaving the eurozone has increased, prompting European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker to warn against Tsipras' demands. A stronger US dollar also contributed to gold's gains, making dollar-denominated gold more expensive for holders of other currencies.

site_title: BlackRock holds 51m, 3.3% of KepLand shares
summary: Keppel Land (KepLand) announced that BlackRock Inc. now holds approximately 51 million shares, representing 3.3% of the total issued shares. This increase comes from an announcement on Monday, when BlackRock held 50.8 million shares. Keppel Corp is an associate of BlackRock due to holding 5% or more of its shares, requiring BlackRock to disclose its dealings in shares during the offer period.

site_title: G20 pledges decisive monetary, fiscal action if needed: draft text
summary: The G20 pledged to act decisively on monetary and fiscal policy if needed to combat stagnation, citing risks of low inflation, sluggish growth, and demand weakness. The draft communique welcomed the European Central Bank's quantitative easing and noted some emerging markets are slowing down, while low-income developing countries continue to grow. The G20 will keep fiscal policy flexible and monitor commodity markets closely, while also pledging to put debt on a sustainable path and "stick to previous exchange rate commitments".

site_title: Malaysia Dec factory output up 7.4% y-o-y, beats forecast
summary: Malaysia's industrial production index rose 7.4% in December, beating forecasts of a 4.3% growth, driven by positive growth in manufacturing, mining, and electricity sectors. Exports rose 2.7% due to electrical and electronic products. The index also rose 5.8% for the fourth quarter and 4.7% compared to the July-September period. This positive growth indicates a strong economy, contrary to concerns about slowing production due to commodity price declines.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's industrial production index in December rose 7.4 per cent from a year earlier, far exceeding market expectations, data from the Statistics Department showed on Tuesday.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down; TransAsia rebounds
summary: Taiwan's main stock index fell 0.15% to 9,407.26, while TransAsia Airways Corp rebounded 1.33% after heavy losses following a recent crash. The transport subindex rose 0.95% due to TransAsia's gain.

site_title: URA releases residential site at Sturdee Road for sale
summary: The Urban Revelopment Authority (URA) has released a residential site at Sturdee Road for sale under the Confirmed List of 1st Half 2015 Government Land Sales Programme. The 6,111.5 sq m site can yield approximately 270 residential units, with a maximum gross floor area of 21,391 sq m and a building height of 30 storeys. The lease period is 99 years, and the tender will close on March 24, 2015.

site_title: Ringgit drops most in Asia as oil declines after three-day gain
summary: Malaysia's ringgit dropped 0.6% to 3.5820 a dollar, its largest decline since January 20, amid a decline in oil prices. The currency has lost 10% in six months due to the drop in Brent crude, which has fallen 48% since June. Despite factory output beating economists' estimates in December, the decline in oil prices cut earnings for the region's only major oil exporter. The government revised its 2015 fiscal deficit target to 3.2% of GDP due to the decline in oil prices.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's ringgit fell the most among Asian currencies as oil resumed a decline following a three-day gain.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.19% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.19% lower on Tuesday, following losses in the US and Europe due to concerns over Greece's debt obligations and potential eurozone exit. The Hang Seng Index fell 45.96 points to 24,475.04.

site_title: Broker's take: Nomura maintains 'buy' on DBS shares
summary: Nomura maintains its "buy" rating on DBS shares with a target price of S$24.30, representing a 25% upside from the current price. The bank's Q4 FY2014 net profit of S$838 million was in line with consensus estimates, driven by strong loan growth and a 10 basis point year-on-year increase in net interest margin. Nomura analysts believe DBS's strong operating leverage will benefit the bank as short-term interest rates rise, offering the bank strong operating leverage.

site_title: Investors exit South Korea as corporate profits disappoint for 17th straight quarter
summary: Overseas investors have pulled a net $771 million from South Korea's stocks in 2015, the only outflow among six Asian emerging markets, due to disappointing corporate profits for the 17th straight quarter. Seventy-four percent of Kospi index companies reported lower-than-estimated earnings, leading to concerns about the economy's growth. The Bank of Korea cut its 2015 growth forecast, and investors are finding more attractive stocks in India and Taiwan. South Korea's stock market is valued at a 32% discount to the MSCI Asia Pacific Index, with a projected yield of 1.6%, lower than peers in Taiwan and China.

site_title: Taiwan's China affairs minister quits over espionage row
summary: Taiwan's China affairs minister Wang Yu-chi resigned after prosecutors cleared a former deputy, Chang Hsien-yao, of espionage allegations. Wang had accused Chang of leaking national secrets to China, but Chang denied the claims. The investigation found insufficient evidence, leading to Chang's clearance. Wang cited disagreement with the decision but accepted it, stating he would take responsibility. The move comes amid growing public anxiety over China's influence on Taiwan, following recent trade pact protests and local election losses for the China-friendly Kuomintang party.

images.alt_text: Taiwan's China affairs minister Wang Yu-chi resigned Tuesday after prosecutors decided not to indict a former deputy whom he had accused of spying for Beijing.

site_title: Broker's take: Nomura maintains 'buy' on CapitaLand shares, downgrades CCT, Suntec Reit
summary: Nomura maintains a "buy" rating on CapitaLand shares, citing its historical performance and potential for future growth. The brokerage firm downgrades its ratings on CapitaCommercial Trust (CCT) and Suntec Reit to "reduce" due to potential vacancies and lease expirations. Nomura analyst Min Chow Sai notes that office Reits have outperformed the Singapore market and may face challenges in the next year. CapitaLand's stake in CapitaGreen and potential sale could raise earnings per share, making it a better risk-reward proposition for investors.

site_title: KPMG to work with PwC on OW Bunker Far East debts
summary: KPMG has agreed to work with PwC to collect debts owed to marine fuel company OW Bunker Far East, which has a US$330 million outstanding debt. OW Bunker filed for bankruptcy in Denmark in November after revealing losses of at least US$125 million. KPMG was appointed as liquidator of OW Bunker's Singapore-based subsidiary, and a cooperation agreement was signed with PwC to facilitate the collection of receivables owed to the company.

site_title: Malaysia new tax to slow mortgages from '07 Low: Islamic Finance
summary: Malaysia's Islamic home loans are forecast to slow due to a new 6% tax and tighter capital rules. Banks predict a 3-5% decline in property transactions in 2015, as inflation rises to 3.5% and oil prices slump. The government's tax and regulatory changes are discouraging housing demand, with Prime Minister Najib Razak reducing economic growth estimates. This slowdown follows the 35-year maximum loan tenor reduction from 45 years in 2013.

site_title: India GDP seen surging 7.4% in data that has puzzled economists
summary: India's GDP is forecast to surge 7.4% in the fiscal year through March 31, according to a revised method, contradicting economists' expectations. The Statistics Ministry attributed the growth to a 7.5% increase in October-December. The revised data has raised concerns about inflation and the Reserve Bank of India's ability to lower interest rates, as Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government prepares its first full-year budget on February 28. The uncertainty surrounding the data may limit the central bank's room to cut interest rates, which are currently priced in at 75 basis points by December.

site_title: China: Shares lower in morning trade
summary: Chinese shares declined in morning trade on Tuesday, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 0.21% and the Shenzhen Composite Index edging down 0.02%. January inflation data showed its lowest level in over five years, contributing to the market's decline.

site_title: Draghi fuels junk sales as issuers go to Europe: credit markets
summary: Mario Draghi's trillion-euro stimulus plan has boosted Europe's junk-debt market, with speculative-grade borrowers issuing the equivalent of $19.1 billion of bonds in Europe this year, more than double the amount sold in 2014. European companies are favoring euro-denominated bonds due to cheaper yields, which are 2.26 percentage points lower than those in the US. The European Central Bank's intervention has made the market more appealing, with some borrowers opting for euro-denominated bonds instead of dollar-denominated ones, citing lower costs.

site_title: Payment performance of Singapore firms improves in Q4 2014
summary: Singapore firms' payment performance improved in Q4 2014, with overall prompt payments jumping 4.10 percentage points to 50.07% after three consecutive quarters of decline. Payment delays decreased by 3.03 percentage points to 38.89%, with four of five industries experiencing a fall in slow payments quarter-on-quarter. However, year-on-year payment delays worsened. The rebound in payment performance is seen as a positive trend for the country's economy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.24 points to 1812.74 on Tuesday, with 98 gainers outpacing 64 losers. The country's shares opened higher despite global market fluctuations, including US-EU trade talks and a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks.

site_title: Australia: Shares down as Greece fears, pre-earnings caution weigh
summary: Australian shares fell 14.9 points or 0.3% to 5800.0, extending a two-day decline, amid concerns over Greek debt negotiations and cautious investor sentiment ahead of the domestic earnings season. The likelihood of a "Grexit" from the euro zone increased after Greece ruled out extending its bailout deal and reversed some reforms. This added to pre-earnings caution, with IG markets strategist Stan Shamu saying investors are questioning whether to buy at current levels.

site_title: Hot stock: DBS shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: DBS shares opened 15 Singapore cents lower at S$19.3 on Tuesday, trading at a high of S$19.45 before falling 0.154% to S$19.42. The bank posted a fourth-quarter net profit of S$838 million, up 4% from the previous year, but missed analysts' estimates due to higher bad debt provisions and lower trading income.

site_title: US West Coast port operations resume after partial shutdown
summary: US West Coast port operations resumed on Monday after a partial shutdown, with shipping companies resuming cargo loading and unloading operations after a weekend halt due to chronic cargo backups. The White House urged both sides to redouble efforts to settle a dispute that has affected the US commercial supply chain, with potential losses estimated at over $2 billion a day in the event of another 10-day shutdown. Full port operations were restored, but a planned resumption of federally mediated contract talks was pushed back until Wednesday.

site_title: Barclays plans to raise junior bankers' pay to retain talent: Bloomberg
summary: Barclays plans to increase pay for junior investment bankers by up to 40% in an effort to retain talent. The move is expected to lead to a narrowing compensation gap between mid-level and junior employees. Barclays' overall bonus pool is anticipated to shrink, while other European banks are also reviewing pay increases. Similar salary hikes are being considered by Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, and Bank of America, with US rivals offering higher pay than their European counterparts.

site_title: China studies linking bond markets with Hong Kong, SCMP reports
summary: China is studying a "bond connect scheme" to link its bond markets with Hong Kong, expanding access to the world's third-largest debt market and promoting the use of the yuan. The proposal, submitted by Hong Kong's Treasury Markets Association and the Asia Securities Industry & Financial Markets Association, aims to give foreign investors access to China's capital markets. The connection would further boost the use of the yuan and provide more opportunities for Chinese bonds. The move follows the establishment of a trading link between Hong Kong and Shanghai stock exchanges last November.

images.alt_text: China is studying linking the nation's bond markets with Hong Kong, giving foreign investors access to the world's third-largest debt market, the South China Morning Post reported.

site_title: Philippine exports fall for the first time in 11 months in December
summary: The Philippines' exports fell for the first time in 11 months in December, dropping 2.5% from the previous month, according to the country's statistics office. Total exports in 2014 rose 9.0% to $61.8 billion, but the growth was below the government's target of 6.5-7.5%. Electronics exports, which account for half of total exports, grew 9.9% in December, while other major exports such as machinery and woodcrafts declined. Japan remained the country's top export destination, followed by the US and China.

site_title: China Jan inflation comes in at 0.8%, missing forecasts
summary: China's consumer inflation slowed to 0.8% in January, missing forecasts and reinforcing signs of economic weakness. This is the 35th consecutive monthly decline in producer prices, largely due to falling global energy and materials prices. The central bank may consider further stimulus steps to ward off deflationary risks. Analysts had expected 1.0% annual consumer inflation and 3.8% fall in producer prices, both of which were also missed.

site_title: Australia business conditions lacklustre in Jan: survey
summary: Australia's business conditions remained lacklustre in January, with a National Australia Bank survey showing its index of business conditions at +2, unchanged from December. Despite this, a falling currency boosted business confidence to +3, as miners were encouraged by the lower local dollar.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, Lum Chang, Valuetronics, Pacific Andes, China Fishery
summary: DBS posted a 4% increase in Q4 net profit to S$838 million, missing analysts' estimates due to higher bad debt provisions and lower trading income. Lum Chang disposed of 12.45 million shares of Old Court House Propco for S$41 million. Valuetronics saw a 10.3% increase in Q3 net profit to HK$39.2 million. Pacific Andes Resources Development and China Fishery Group reported a 11.7% and 13.7% fall in net profit respectively for the first quarter.

site_title: US lawmakers seek to tackle currency cheating with trade bill
summary: US lawmakers are introducing a bipartisan bill to combat currency manipulation by trading partners, similar to previous bills. The legislation would treat currency undervaluation like foreign subsidies, allowing US companies to seek compensatory duties on imported goods. If countries fail to adopt policies to eliminate currency misalignment, they would face consequences. The bill aims to address a broader debate on using trade deals to punish currency cheats, particularly in free trade agreements like the Trans-Pacific Partnership. Negotiators hope to finalize TPP talks within months, but the Obama administration is cautious about attaching currency provisions.

site_title: Lego says knockoffs threaten success of toys designed for girls
summary: Lego is accusing three companies of making knockoffs of its popular Lego Friends line, which has attracted more girls to the traditionally boy-targeted product. The line, introduced in 2012, has grown 20% a year and features girls in various settings. Lego is seeking US government help to combat the counterfeits, which threaten the success of the product. The company's success with Lego Friends has been a notable shift in its traditionally male-dominated market.

site_title: Poll gives UK Cameron's Conservatives small lead before May election
summary: A UK poll conducted on February 6-8 shows Prime Minister David Cameron's Conservative Party leading the opposition Labour Party by three percentage points, with 34% to Labour's 31%. This narrow lead is within the margin of error of most opinion polls and marks the most unpredictable election in modern British history. Analysts believe the Conservatives need a lead of up to seven percentage points to win outright under Britain's winner-takes-all voting system.

site_title: Pacific Andes Q1 net profit down 11.7% to HK$128.2m
summary: Pacific Andes Resources Development reported a 11.7% decline in Q1 net profit to HK$128.2 million, down from HK$145.2 million last year. Earnings before interest and taxes fell 21.6% to HK$466.9 million, and gross profit decreased 22.3% to HK$309.1 million. Revenue dropped 25.3% year-over-year to HK$1.81 billion, largely due to reduced contributions from its fishery and fish supply division.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index up 1.02 points to 3,419.04. Volume reached 44.4 million shares worth S$86.1 million, with 71 gainers outnumbering 69 losers. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Shares in Petronas listed units give up gains after CEO appointment boost
summary: Shares in Petronas listed units lost gains after the appointment of Wan Zulkiflee Wan Ariffin as CEO, a move seen as a boost to the company. Petronas Chemical Group Bhd fell 0.95% and Petronas Dagangan Bhd shed 1.6%. The benchmark index also declined 0.12%. The news overshadowed the appointment, which was seen as a positive step for the company.

site_title: Lum Chang to dispose of interest in Old Court House Propco for £19.9m
summary: Lum Chang, a construction company, disposed of its entire 12.45 million shares in Old Court House Propco (OCHP) for £19.9m, generating a £11.4m gain. OCHP owns a mixed-use property in London. The proceeds will be used to fund future investments. This marks Lum Chang's opportunity to realise its investment in OCHP.

site_title: Valuetronics Q3 net profit up 10.3% to HK$39.2m
summary: Valuetronics reported a 10.3% increase in third-quarter net profit to HK$39.2 million, driven by a 23% rise in ICE revenue. Revenue rose 3.4% to HK$596.2 million, with ICE customers contributing to the growth. However, CE revenue decreased 6.4% due to a slowdown in demand. The company expects to manage its reliance on the CE segment and benefit from ICE growth, with earnings per share down 1.9% for the nine months ended Dec 31, 2014.

site_title: Record snowfall hits Boston, cancels flights
summary: A third winter storm in two weeks paralyzed parts of the northeastern US, cancelling hundreds of flights and shutting down schools and public buildings in Boston. The storm dumped up to two feet of snow, surpassing the city's record 30-day snowfall total, and caused over 1,840 flight cancellations. Schools and non-essential employees were closed, and winter storm warnings remained in effect for the northeast. The storm also impacted other areas, including North Weymouth and Norwell in Massachusetts, and Amsterdam in New York state.

site_title: US to remain world's top source of oil supply growth up to 2020: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts the US will remain the world's top source of oil supply growth until 2020, despite a recent collapse in oil prices. US shale oil production is forecasted to reach 5.2 million barrels per day by 2020. In contrast, Russia's production is expected to contract by 560,000 barrels per day from 2014 to 2020, making it the industry's top loser. Global oil demand is predicted to rise in 2016 to 29.9 million barrels per day.

images.alt_text: The United States will remain the world's top source of oil supply growth up to 2020, even after the recent collapse in prices, the International Energy Agency said, defying expectations of a more dramatic slowdown in shale growth.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.28% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.28% lower on Tuesday following global market drops due to concerns over a Greek default and exit from the eurozone. The Nikkei 225 index fell 49.26 points to 17,662.67. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.53% on Monday, while the Athens stock market closed nearly 5% lower. Investors worry about Greece's 315 billion euros in debt, with German Chancellor Angela Merkel awaiting a "sustainable" proposal from Greece.

site_title: China Fishery net profit down 13.7% to US$13.5m in Q1
summary: China Fishery Group reported a 13.7% decline in net profit to US$13.5 million for Q1 FY2015, down from US$15.7 million. Revenue decreased 14.7% to US$123.9 million, mainly due to a 21.1% drop in contract supply business revenue. The company's China Fishery fleet revenue declined marginally by 0.8%. The decline is attributed to the termination and non-renewal of long-term supply agreements.

site_title: DBS Q4 net profit misses forecasts on bad debt charges
summary: DBS Group Holdings, Singapore's largest bank, reported a 4.5% rise in core fourth-quarter net profit to S$838 million, but missed forecasts due to higher bad debt provisions (40% increase to S$211 million) and lower trading income. The bank's full-year net profit rose 10% to a record S$4.046 billion. DBS attributed the decline in trading income to less favourable market conditions. Despite the miss, DBS's record-breaking full-year earnings were driven by a strong performance in the previous year, when a stake sale boosted net profit.

site_title: Malaysia's Anwar awaits fateful court ruling
summary: Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim awaits a court ruling on his appeal against a five-year sodomy conviction. If the appeal fails, Anwar, 67, could face imprisonment and potentially not emerge until 72. The case is seen as politically motivated, with many observers believing Anwar's defense successfully debunked the charge. The conviction could backfire on the ruling United Malays National Organisation (UMNO), potentially leading to Anwar's removal and further disarray among the opposition alliance. Anwar remains cautiously optimistic about the outcome.

site_title: US: Stocks drop on fears of Greek default
summary: US stocks dropped on Monday, following European markets, amid growing fears of a Greek default and exit from the eurozone. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.53%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 0.42% and 0.39%, respectively. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras vowed to stand by his anti-austerity promises, raising concerns about a potential default of 315 billion euros. European markets also fell, with the Athens stock market closing down nearly 5%.

site_title: Twitter says government data queries rising
summary: Twitter reported a 40% increase in government data queries in late 2014, with notable rises from Turkey and Russia.
