Lower oil prices could boost global demand, but may also lead to higher prices as firms cut back on supply. The IMF warned that divergent monetary policies could lead to volatility and capital outflows from emerging markets, particularly oil-exporting countries. Managing Director Christine Lagarde cautioned against overemphasizing the impact of cheap oil on inflation and employment goals, and urged countries to pursue deeper reforms to raise growth paths.

site_title: Oil rally holds, promising second weekly gain
summary: Brent crude oil prices rose almost $2 higher on Friday, tracking its second weekly gain, due to fighting in Libya and stronger US economic signals. Prices remain 50% below peak levels from last year and no rapid recovery is expected. The US oil-rig count declined by 199 in January, and concerns over Libya's oil exports boosted prices. US jobs data is expected to show firm job growth, a positive signal for demand. However, many analysts forecast price gains to be short-lived and limited due to rising global inventories and steady OPEC supply.

site_title: Japan's trading houses to step up asset sale to defy resource slump
summary: Japan's top trading houses, including Mitsui & Co and Marubeni Corp, plan to increase asset sales to offset declining income from resource businesses and fund shareholder returns. The companies, which have faced significant writedowns due to the global commodity slump, aim to accelerate asset recycling to 1 trillion yen over the next three years. Smaller peer Mitsubishi Corp, however, maintains its annual profit guidance despite an impairment loss. The move is seen as a response to the need for financial discipline and a shift away from aggressive investment strategies.

site_title: China says hard work required to ensure stable trade in 2015
summary: China's trade ministry stated that the country must work hard to maintain stable growth in exports and imports in 2015, amid forecasted softening of export growth and shrinking imports. To support the sector, authorities will stabilize imports of raw materials and encourage purchases of consumer goods and high-tech equipment. The export sector, a main driver of China's economy, has struggled due to unsteady foreign demand and rising labor costs. Exports still contribute 18% to China's overall economic growth, employing 180 million people.

site_title: Family money puts its faith in European technology
summary: European family offices have nearly doubled their direct investments in technology companies between 2008 and 2014, reaching 9% of total portfolios. With average assets under management of $890 million, each office has around $80 million to invest. This influx of capital is filling a funding hole for European start-ups, bringing the benefits of long-term horizons to the continent's fledgling tech companies. Low interest rates have driven wealthy families to invest in tech, providing a boost to the European tech industry.

site_title: Brazil's Petrobras set to pick new CEO amid corruption scandal
summary: Brazil's Petrobras is set to appoint a new CEO amid a corruption scandal that has led to the resignation of nearly all senior managers. The company's board will choose new leadership on Friday, following a 60% decline in shares since September. The new CEO faces restoring confidence and renewing access to capital markets, while the government aims to maintain $200 billion of investment over five years to bolster the economy. The scandal has also affected suppliers, with thousands fired and new oil output delayed. A new team will tally corruption-related losses and publish audited results by April.

site_title: Tsunami drill unfolds across 40 countries from Asia to Americas
summary: Forty countries along the Pacific Ocean are conducting tsunami drill simulations from Asia to the Americas, testing early warning systems and evacuation procedures. The UN-backed initiative aims to improve disaster preparedness and response. Participants will receive simulated tsunami warnings and practice evacuation routes. The exercise tests a new data product to forecast tsunami height, energy, and direction. The goal is to enhance communication and coordination among governments and communities to better prepare for and respond to tsunamis and other natural disasters.

site_title: Taiwan pilots "faced problem with one engine, restarted the other"
summary: A TransAsia plane crashed into a river in Taipei, killing 35 people, after one engine failed and the pilots attempted to restart the other. Data showed the plane suffered from a lack of thrust before stalling, with warnings of stalling issued five times. The pilots reduced acceleration on one engine, turned it off, and attempted to restart it, but it did not gain enough thrust. The cause of the restart is unclear, with a fuller report expected in 30 days.

site_title: Eurogroup to hold emergency Greece meeting on Wednesday
summary: Eurozone finance ministers will hold an emergency meeting in Brussels on Wednesday to discuss Greece's debt stand-off with its new anti-austerity government. The meeting comes as Greece's 240-billion-euro bailout is set to expire on February 28, and leaders of the 28 European Union nations will meet the following day for a summit. Greek Finance Minister Yaris Varoufakis will formally present the government's demands for debt reduction, amid a chill in relations with Dutch Finance Minister Jeroen Dijsselbloem. A further Eurogroup meeting is scheduled for February 16.

site_title: US and Europe must stand together over Ukraine: Biden
summary: US Vice President Joe Biden urged the US and Europe to stand together over Ukraine, condemning Russia's military actions as an attempt to redraw the European map. Biden stated that the US and Europe must provide financial assistance and support to Ukraine as it pursues reforms, despite the ongoing military conflict. He made no mention of possible US arms supplies, sparking concern among European leaders. Biden's comments came as Russia rolled its troops through the Ukrainian countryside, fueling tensions between the two nations.

site_title: LCD Global swings to profitability in Q2 on strong results from associates, JVs
summary: LCD Global Investments reported a net profit of S$9.98 million in Q2 2014, reversing a net loss of S$209,000 in the same period last year. Revenue decreased 6% to S$13.97 million due to weaker performance at a serviced residence in Laos and entertainment outlets in Singapore. However, the company's share of results from associates and joint ventures increased to S$10.68 million, driven by a joint venture in China that recognized profits for 463 apartments. This was partly offset by lower commission income from Knight Frank.

site_title: Palm makes biggest weekly gain in six years on Indonesian subsidy boost
summary: Malaysian palm oil surged 1.51% to a three-week high, its biggest weekly gain in six years, on optimism over Indonesia's biodiesel subsidy boost. The benchmark April contract ended at RM2,347 (US$663) per tonne, with prices climbing over 9% for the week. The Indonesian government's plan to increase subsidies could make blending profitable, boosting market sentiment.

site_title: SingHaiyi Q3 profit down 36.7%, but rental income stable
summary: SingHaiyi Group's Q3 net profit dropped 36.7% to S$2.5 million due to absence of year-ago development sales. However, rental income remained stable. The company also announced changes to its San Francisco project, shifting from a continuing care retirement community to a 511-unit residential condominium for better investment returns. Net profit for the nine months to December fell 57.4% to S$5.3 million.

site_title: Low oil prices have yet to rattle North Dakota small businesses
summary: North Dakota small businesses remain confident despite low oil prices, which have dropped by 50% since June. The state's oil patch is a significant contributor to the local economy, but small businesses, including hotels, plumbers, and contractors, are expected to continue thriving. New businesses, such as coffee shops and health food stores, have opened or are set to open, showing resilience in the face of economic uncertainty. The labor market remains tight, with over 2,000 job openings, but many business owners are optimistic about demand for their products and services.

site_title: Exceptional gains boost SIA's Q3 net profit to S$202.6 million
summary: Singapore Airlines' net profit for the third quarter of 2015 rose to S$202.6 million, a quadrupling from the previous year. The airline recorded an exceptional gain of S$56.2 million, driven by the remeasurement of its retained interest in Tiger Airways. Revenue increased to S$4.1 billion, but operating profit softened to S$146.3 million. The company expects yields to remain under pressure due to competition and a potential slowdown in global economic activity. SIA will focus on customer service and cost discipline to compete on all fronts.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 24.78 points to 3,431.36. Trading volume reached 1.08 billion shares valued at S$1.23 billion, with 228 gains and 170 losses.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 10.04 points to close at 1,813.25 on Friday, with 1.92 billion lots valued at RM2.15 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 512-291.

site_title: Malaysia's CIMB to cut investment banking operating costs by 30%
summary: Malaysia's CIMB Group Holdings plans to cut investment banking operating costs by 30% this year as part of a plan to reassess its investment banking presence in Asia-Pacific. The move comes after the lender grew aggressively and now faces weaknesses in its business. CIMB aims to achieve a return on equity of over 15% by 2018, with consumer banking contributing 60% of its income. The plan is part of a broader effort to adapt to a changing market environment.

site_title: Wage cuts and discounts as Swiss companies respond to franc strength
summary: Swiss companies are responding to the strong Swiss franc by cutting prices, asking for supplier discounts, and adjusting staff hours to protect profits. The removal of the 1.20-per-euro cap has led to a surge in the currency, prompting firms to take measures to mitigate losses. Small and medium-sized companies are particularly affected, with some cutting wages, hours, and jobs. Analysts warn that the move could lead to recession, with exports sliding and unemployment rising, but global players with diverse revenue streams are expected to be spared a major hit.

site_title: Singapore's life insurance business up 3% in Q4 to S$764.3m
summary: Singapore's life insurance industry saw a 3% increase in Q4 2014 to S$764.3 million in total weighted new business premiums, driven by higher uptake in single premium products. The full-year total weighted new business premiums remained unchanged at S$2.8 billion, mainly due to a higher base in 2013. The industry paid out S$6.79 billion to policyholders and beneficiaries, with S$6.19 billion for matured policies and a 13% increase in death, critical illness, or disability claims.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Friday
summary: Singapore's top news stories include a surprise Vietnam reaction to US tariff announcements, a Malaysian agency planning to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, and China's GDP growth expected to slow. In markets, Citigroup predicts a 1,150 MSCI global equity index by mid-2026. In politics, Thai Prime Minister Thaksin remains optimistic about clearing his daughter's suspension in an ethics case. The UK economy shrinks for the second month, and ASEAN agrees Myanmar's election is not a priority, with Malaysia stating their stance.

site_title: Contactless card payments treble in Britain during 2014
summary: Contactless card payments in Britain increased by 200% to £2.32 billion (US$3.6 billion) in 2014, accounting for 75.8% of retail sales, up from 51.6% a decade ago. This growth solidifies contactless payments' mainstream presence, according to the UK Cards Association.

site_title: Cheaper oil 'golden opportunity' to forge EU energy union: commissioner
summary: European Commission Vice President Maros Sefcovic views lower oil prices as a "golden opportunity" to advance the EU's energy union plans, which include reducing carbon emissions, investing in technology, and developing a single European energy market. The EU has outlined five "pillars" of energy policy to achieve this goal. With low oil prices, the Commission aims to "reset" energy policies and create a more efficient and sustainable energy system across the continent.

images.alt_text: Cheaper global oil prices present a "golden opportunity" for the European Union to advance its plans for a continent-wide energy union, a senior European Commission official said on Friday.

site_title: TransAsia engines failed before crash: aviation authority
summary: A TransAsia Airways ATR 72-600 crashed in Taiwan, killing at least 35 people. An investigation by the Aviation Safety Council found that both engines failed to produce thrust before the plane crashed into a river. The failure occurred for a period of time, according to Thomas Wang, director of the agency. The cause of the failure is still under investigation.

site_title: China clamps down on foreign casinos wooing Chinese gamblers
summary: China is cracking down on foreign casinos targeting Chinese gamblers, as part of its broader anti-corruption campaign. The Ministry of Public Security will focus on casino operators from neighboring countries with offices in China, aiming to stop them from luring citizens to gamble abroad. The move is expected to hit Macau's casino industry, where high-stakes gamblers have been deterred by stricter travel rules. Shares of Macau casino operators rose following the news, but analysts warn that the crackdown will make it harder for new players to find customers.

site_title: Global markets: Bumper week for shares, oil and euro as payrolls due
summary: Global markets experienced a strong week, with world shares heading for their strongest week since October, driven by anticipation of US jobs data. Oil is poised for a near 20% rebound, and the euro is on track for its biggest weekly rise since 2013. European stocks dipped, while bonds rose as investors squared up positions ahead of the US jobs data, which is expected to show 234,000 new jobs in January, above the 200,000 mark.

site_title: Greece won't accept any deal concerning existing bailout at Eurogroup
summary: Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis announced that Greece will not accept any deal at the Eurogroup meeting that keeps the current international bailout program in place. Instead, Greece will ask for a "bridge agreement" until Athens can present a new debt and reform program. The Greek government expects a tough stance from eurozone partners and will not accept any deal not related to a new program. This move indicates a significant shift in Greece's position on its bailout, potentially leading to a re-evaluation of its economic future.

images.alt_text: Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis will not accept any deal at next week's Eurogroup meeting that keeps the current international bailout programme in place, a Greek government official said on Friday.

site_title: Statoil keeps payout as cutbacks respond to depressed oil price
summary: Norwegian oil major Statoil plans to slash costs and cut investments in response to depressed oil prices. The company will reduce capital expenditure by a tenth this year, focusing on projects already sanctioned, and aims to cut costs to cover its quarterly dividend payment. Statoil will cut exploration in Angola and Norway, but continue to drill in Canada, Britain, Tanzania, and Norway. The company's net debt to capital employed ratio is expected to remain below 30%, and it may sell assets or take on fresh borrowings to cover the shortfall.

images.alt_text: Norwegian oil major Statoil vowed to protect dividend payments and said it was braced for a long period of depressed crude prices as it set out plans on Friday to slash costs and cut investments.

site_title: Tokyo investors look to support for share prices next week
summary: Tokyo investors are optimistic about next week's market, driven by strong corporate earnings reports in Japan and receding fears of a Greek crisis. The weaker yen is also having a positive effect, with upward revisions to earnings. While US employment reports may impact the market, strategist Juichi Wako of Nomura Holdings expects Tokyo to remain in good shape.

site_title: Indonesia's forex reserves rise to US$114.3b at end-January
summary: Indonesia's foreign exchange reserves rose to US$114.25 billion at the end of January, supported by government bond issuance, which included US$4 billion bonds with yields of 4.200% and 5.200%. This marks a 2% increase from the end of December, when reserves stood at US$111.86 billion.

site_title: Fitch downgrades Garuda to 'BBB+ (idn)'; revises outlook to negative
summary: Fitch Ratings Indonesia downgraded PT Garuda Indonesia Tbk's national long-term rating to 'BBB+(idn)' from 'A-(idn)' due to a sustained weakness in the airline's financial profile, driven by currency mismatch and a high fixed-cost structure. The outlook is revised to Negative, reflecting Fitch's expectation that Garuda's financial metrics will remain in breach of negative rating triggers in the coming 12-18 months. The downgrade affects Garuda's outstanding IDR2trn bonds due in 2018.

site_title: Update: Oil extends gains, euro recovers on ECB assurances
summary: Global markets continued to fluctuate on Friday, with oil prices extending gains and the euro recovering from earlier losses. The euro edged lower after ECB assurances that Greek banks will retain access to crucial funds, while oil prices rose after a volatile week. Asian markets, including Tokyo, Seoul, and Sydney, also rose, with Sydney experiencing a record 12th straight session of gains. In contrast, Shanghai sank and Hong Kong slipped. The US benchmark West Texas Intermediate for March delivery rose $1.06 to $51.54, while Brent crude for March gained $1.17 to $57.74.

site_title: Update: Pilot's body found still clutching controls of crashed Taiwan plane-media
summary: The pilot of the doomed TransAsia plane, Liao Chien-tsung, 42, was still clutching the controls when his body was found after the crash that killed 35 people. The pilot steered the plane between apartment blocks and commercial buildings before ditching it in a river. Taipei's mayor praised the pilot's hero actions. The crash occurred when the plane lurches nose-up, clipped an overpass and a taxi, and crashed upside down into a shallow river after taking off on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: The pilot of a doomed TransAsia plane, hailed as a hero for his actions in the final moments before a crash that killed 35 people, still had his hands on the controls when his body was found, media reported on Friday.

site_title: Australian billionaire Rinehart selling 15% Fairfax Media stake: reports
summary: Australian billionaire Gina Rinehart is selling 14.99% of her stake in Fairfax Media Ltd, a newspaper publisher, for A$0.87 per share. The sale, managed by Morgan Stanley, is a result of the iron ore price halving since mid-2014, forcing Rinehart to reassess her investments. Rinehart, the country's richest person, has been Fairfax's biggest shareholder since 2012, sparking speculation of a potential takeover. The sale comes as Fairfax shares reach their highest close since June 2014.

site_title: China corruption watchdog accuses state energy firms of serious violations
summary: China's top graft-busting body, the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection, has accused two state-owned energy conglomerates of serious violations, including bribery and manipulation of coal prices. China Shenhua Group, the country's top coal producer, is under scrutiny for taking bribes and exploiting coal pricing power for personal gain. The CCDI has launched an intensifying crackdown on corruption in the country's energy sector.

site_title: Impairment losses push HPH Trust into the red in Q4, FY14
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPH Trust) reported a net loss of HK$18.6 billion in the fourth quarter of FY14, primarily due to impairment losses of HK$19 billion against a cash generating unit in Hong Kong. Excluding the impairment impact, net profit would have risen 16.5%. The full-year earnings were also negatively impacted, with a net loss of HK$17.19 billion. Revenue increased 2.2% in the fourth quarter and 1.9% for the full year, driven by growth in transshipment and US empty cargoes.

site_title: UK trade deficit widens in Dec as cheap oil imports surge
summary: Britain's goods deficit widened in December due to a surge in cheaper oil imports, exceeding forecasts of a 9.1 billion pound gap. The deficit grew to 10.154 billion pounds, while exports edged up 0.1% and imports jumped 2.7%, driven by a 40% increase in oil imports from Norway. The fourth quarter deficit narrowed to 29.4 billion pounds, down from the third quarter. The data suggests the UK economy may not meet its goal of boosting exports to drive growth, with domestic demand remaining a key driver of recovery.

site_title: Siemens cuts 7,800 jobs in chief Kaeser's cost-cutting drive
summary: Siemens AG is cutting 7,800 jobs, about 2% of its global workforce, as part of CEO Joe Kaeser's cost-cutting drive to revive profits. The majority of the cuts will be at the company's German operations, with 3,300 jobs lost. The move aims to slash 1 billion euros in costs, as the company's health-care and energy generation divisions, once key assets, have seen profits fall 27% in the past year.

site_title: This Is 30
summary: A 30-year-old writer reflects on turning a milestone age, realizing they've been living a prolonged adolescence. They've started to let go of childish habits, such as unfriending social media acquaintances and being punctual. They've also become more confident in expressing disagreement and less concerned with social etiquette. The writer sees 30 as a turning point, acknowledging the inevitable aging process and embracing the rewards that come with it, including wisdom and experience.

site_title: China steel recycling seen as growing threat to iron ore demand
summary: China's efforts to increase steel recycling are expected to significantly impact global iron ore demand, potentially worsening a worldwide supply glut. The country aims to generate 200 million tonnes of scrap per annum by 2020, which could lead to a decline in iron ore demand from 2017. Analysts predict that China's scrap steel collection rate will rise to 20-30% by 2020 and 2030, putting further pressure on global suppliers, particularly mega miners like Vale, Rio Tinto, and BHP Billiton.

site_title: Swiss central bank's forex reserves edge higher in January
summary: The Swiss National Bank's foreign exchange reserves increased to 498.398 billion Swiss francs in January, up from 495.130 billion in December. This marks the first indication of the central bank's currency holdings since it scrapped the Swiss franc cap last month. The increase is attributed to the removal of the cap, which the SNB estimated would have cost 100 billion francs to defend in January alone.

site_title: French public deficit edges higher by end-2014
summary: France's public deficit rose to 85.6 billion euros by end-December 2014, up from 74.9 billion euros the previous year. Excluding investments, the deficit decreased to 73.6 billion euros, primarily due to a 10 billion euro cut in state spending. This improvement was better than forecasted, with a projected end-of-year deficit of 87 billion euros.

site_title: China's 2014 gold demand slides 25% after 'extraordinary' year
summary: China's gold demand fell 25% in 2014 to 886.1 metric tons, down from a record 1,176.4 tons in 2013, due to a stable gold price and an anti-graft drive that hurt demand for luxury goods. Demand for bars, coins, and jewelry also declined, but production rose 5.5% to a record 451.8 tons. The decline was attributed to the lack of a price collapse in 2014, which had driven demand to an "extraordinary" level in 2013.

images.alt_text: China's gold consumption fell 25 per cent in 2014 as the price collapse that triggered an "extraordinary" surge in buying the year before wasn't repeated, the China Gold Association said.

site_title: Rocket Internet buys 30% stake in takeaway rival Delivery Hero
summary: Rocket Internet AG acquired a 30% stake in Delivery Hero for 496 million euros. The transaction involves both primary and secondary shares of Delivery Hero, and the companies have a history of asset swaps. Rocket Internet's Foodpanda delivery service competes with Delivery Hero's 90,000+ restaurants worldwide. The deal solidifies Rocket Internet's presence in the market and expands Delivery Hero's reach.

site_title: China: Stocks fall in longest weekly losing streak since May
summary: China's stocks fell for the longest weekly losing streak since May, with the Shanghai Composite Index slipping 1.9% to 3,075.91, as concerns over an economic slowdown deepened and new share sales drew capital from existing shares. Utilities and commodity producers led declines, while property and automotive stocks rose. The benchmark index's weekly loss reached 4.2% amid preparations for initial public offerings next week.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares down on profit-taking pressure
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.4% on Friday as investors took profits, despite a brief boost from the Chinese central bank's liquidity easing earlier in the week. Analysts expect further monetary easing to boost the economy, but caution remains due to uncertainty. The Hang Seng index closed at 24,679.39, while the China Enterprises Index fell 0.8%. Investors remain cautious, waiting for further rate cuts from the mainland.

site_title: Southeast Asia: Indonesia heads for record close, palm oil shares lead
summary: Southeast Asian stock markets rose on Friday, with Indonesia's benchmark index nearing a record close, driven by gains in palm oil shares. Indonesia's government approved a plan to increase biodiesel subsidies, boosting palm oil stocks. Singapore's Straits Times Index also gained, while Thailand's SET index edged higher. Despite a rebound in oil prices, traders remain wary ahead of the US nonfarm payrolls report and ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Taiwan plane black boxes reveal both engines failed to provide thrust
summary: A TransAsia plane crashed into a river in Taipei, killing 35 people, after both engines failed to provide thrust during take-off. Black box data revealed the right engine entered an "auto-feather" state, reducing thrust, and the left engine also failed to gain enough thrust after attempts to restart it. The pilot, hailed as a hero, attempted to save the aircraft until the last minute before ditching it in the river. Eight people remain missing, and investigators are continuing the search.

images.alt_text: The blackbox data and voice recorders of a TransAsia plane that crashed into a river in Taipei showed that the pilot called "mayday" and announced an engine flameout 35 seconds after noticing engine failure, aviation authorities said on Friday.

site_title: Hyundai Motor family raises US$1.1b with stake sale
summary: Hyundai Motor Group patriarch and heir-apparent, Chairman Chung Mong-Koo and Vice Chairman Chung Eui-Sun, sold 5.02 million shares of its logistics arm, Hyundai Glovis, for US$1.1 billion, reducing their stake to 29.99% from 43.39%. The sale was made to comply with new anti-trust rules aimed at curbing intra-group transactions. The Chung family sold the shares at 230,500 won each, after initially calling off the sale last month.

site_title: GM says Jan China auto sales down 2.4% y-o-y
summary: General Motors reported a 2.4% decline in Chinese auto sales for January, with 339,781 vehicles sold. This follows a 31.9% year-on-year rise in December and a 5.3% rise in November. Despite a 12% increase in 2014, GM's investment in China is expected to reach $12 billion between 2014 and 2017 to boost manufacturing capacity.

site_title: A single SME authority not viable: Spring Singapore
summary: Spring Singapore has dismissed the SME Committee's recommendation for a single SME authority, citing differing expertise among agencies. The chairman, Philip Yeo, stated that a single authority would not be effective, comparing it to seeking a general practitioner for all medical issues. The SME Committee had proposed a single authority to manage SME issues and policy implementation across the government, but Spring Singapore believes a more tailored approach is needed.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip ahead of US jobs data
summary: European stocks dropped 0.3% on Friday ahead of the US non-farm payrolls report for January, which is expected to show a 234,000 job gain at a 6-1/2-year low unemployment rate of 5.6%. This beat economists' expectations of a 252,000 job gain in December. The dip in European shares followed a recent multi-year high, with the FTSEurofirst 300 index closing at 1,483.49 points. The report's focus on the US economy has overshadowed the European market, with investors watching the potential impact of US-EU trade tensions on global markets.

site_title: Malaysia, Indonesia to seek resolution of sea disputes
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak and Indonesian President Joko Widodo agreed to establish a new mechanism for resolving maritime border disputes between the two nations, which have lingered for years. Disputes center on energy-rich seabeds and other maritime borders, with Indonesia seeking to crack down on illegal fishing. The leaders also discussed labor issues, agreeing to ensure Indonesian workers come to Malaysia through official channels. A memorandum was signed to explore Proton's involvement in developing an Indonesian national car brand.

site_title: Taiwan plane blackbox reveals "mayday" call 35 seconds after noticing engine failure
summary: A TransAsia plane crashed into a river in Taipei on February 4, 2015, killing 31 people. The blackbox data revealed the pilot called "mayday" 35 seconds after noticing engine failure. The flameout occurred when the fuel supply to an engine was interrupted or there was faulty combustion. The blackboxes stopped recording about one minute after the announcement. The cause of the crash is still under investigation.

site_title: Inflationary pressures to continue easing in eurozone: ECRI
summary: Inflation pressures in the eurozone are expected to continue easing in the coming months, according to the Eurozone Future Inflation Gauge (EZFIG). Consumer prices in the eurozone fell 0.6% in January, a record low, and the EZFIG edged lower to 95.5 in December. The European Central Bank has announced a sovereign bond-buying program to combat falling prices. Germany recently recorded a negative inflation rate, and the eurozone's mild inflation pressures have faded lately.

site_title: Ford says Jan China auto sales up 19% y-o-y
summary: Ford Motor reported a 19% year-over-year increase in January auto sales in China, with 112,599 vehicles sold. This follows a 13% rise in December and a 2% gain in November. Ford attributes its growth in China to manufacturing capacity constraints, with plans to add new plants in the country.

site_title: Japan automakers hit production snags as US port dispute drags on
summary: Japanese automakers, including Toyota, Subaru, Honda, and Nissan, are facing production disruptions due to the ongoing US port dispute, which has caused delays and increased costs. The dispute, which began in October, has led to the use of air cargo to ship car parts to US plants, resulting in additional costs for companies like Subaru. Without a resolution, production would have come to a halt in mid-February, according to Subaru's chief financial officer. The situation has also affected other industries, including McDonald's Japan, which temporarily shipped fries by air.

site_title: German industrial production rises as recovery gathers momentum
summary: German industrial production rose 0.1% in December, its fourth consecutive month, driven by a 2% increase in basic-goods production. The Economy Ministry reported the increase, beating Bloomberg's median estimate of a 0.4% gain. The Bundesbank predicts the economy has overcome its weak phase, with factory orders rising 4.2% in December and business confidence improving for the third consecutive month. The European Central Bank's quantitative-easing pledge is expected to bolster the economy through a weaker euro, making exporters more competitive.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close 0.82% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.82% on Friday, driven by gains on Wall Street and reassurances from the European Central Bank. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 17,648.50, while the Topix index edged up 0.50%. The gains followed a strong performance on US stocks, which reached fresh records despite trade tensions. The European Central Bank's support for Greek lenders also boosted investor confidence.

site_title: Ringgit leads Asia FX gains ahead of US job data, most set for weekly rise
summary: Malaysia's ringgit led gains among emerging Asian currencies on Friday, with most units set for weekly rises due to optimism over Greek debt woes and oil price rebounds. The ringgit rose 2.3% against the dollar, its largest weekly appreciation since 2013, while other currencies including China's yuan, South Korea's won, and Singapore's dollar also gained. However, investors are cautious ahead of US job data, with economists expecting a slower-than-expected increase in US employment, which could lead to a short-term pullback in the dollar's strength.

site_title: Indonesia approves threefold rise in biodiesel subsidies in boost to palm oil companies
summary: Indonesia's government approved a threefold rise in biodiesel subsidies, aiming to boost palm oil demand. The subsidy increase, from 1,200 to 3,600 rupiah per liter, could take effect next month. The move is expected to protect Indonesia's fledgling biofuel industry, which has seen dwindling demand due to low crude oil prices. Shares of Singapore-listed palm oil companies jumped on the news, citing the agreement by an energy parliamentary committee and the Energy and Mineral Resources Ministry.

site_title: Australian PM to face leadership vote after party-room revolt
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott will face a party-room vote next week after a group of lawmakers sought to oust him following weeks of criticism over policy decisions. Communications Minister Malcolm Turnbull is the most likely challenger, but Abbott remains confident and has spoken to Deputy Leader Julie Bishop, who has vowed to stand with him. If Turnbull doesn't stand, experts warn the government could "trundle towards annihilation" in the next election.

site_title: Chinese yuan to reverse weakening trend, rupee seen easing as dollar rallies
summary: The Chinese yuan is expected to appreciate over the next year, reversing its recent weakening trend, due to China's large trade surplus. Despite expectations of further monetary easing, the yuan is likely to strengthen, trading at 6.241 as of Friday. China's economy is expected to slow further to around 7% growth in 2015, impacted by a cooling property market, industrial overcapacity, and slowing investment.

site_title: SMEs expected to create S$8b value-add through upgrading projects: Spring
summary: Spring Singapore's upgrading projects with 9,000 SMEs are expected to create S$8 billion value-add for the economy and 22,000 jobs. Approximately 90% of the 9,000 SMEs helped are micro and small enterprises with annual revenue of S$10 million or less. This initiative is part of SPRING's efforts to support 160,000 SMEs in 2014.

site_title: Study on M'sia-S'pore Rapid Transit System to start after JB terminal is decided
summary: Malaysia and Singapore will begin the second phase of a study on their planned Rapid Transit System (RTS) after determining the location of the Johor Baru terminal. The RTS, set for completion by 2018, will connect the Malaysian city to Singapore's Thomson MRT line. The project's progress coincides with the expected announcement of the High Speed Rail (HSR) terminal location in Singapore. Meanwhile, transport connectivity between the two countries is being enhanced with increased cross-border bus services and a review of new landing points. The project is being co-coordinated by Malaysian and Singaporean officials.

site_title: Australia: Shares rally, match a record 12th session
summary: Australian shares reached a seven-year peak, ending up 0.1% at 5,820.2, as the S&P/ASX 200 index gained 9.6% in 12 consecutive sessions, matching the longest winning streak on record seen in 2008. The utilities and energy sectors drove the gains, while the New Zealand market was closed for a public holiday.

site_title: Asian shares tread cautiously ahead of US payrolls
summary: Asian shares rose cautiously on Friday ahead of the US nonfarm payrolls report for January, with MSCI's Asia-Pacific index up 0.1% and Japan's Nikkei stock average 0.8% higher. Investors remained wary due to concerns over US economic data, with European financial spreadbetters expecting a weak start to trading. Oil prices rebounded, but traders sought a "Goldilocks" number from the US jobs report, neither too strong nor too weak, to avoid sparking interest rate tightening.

site_title: Thai Airways aims to return profit in 2016 after restructuring
summary: Thai Airways plans to return to profit in 2016 after restructuring, cutting operating costs and capacity by 20% this year. The airline will sell and decommission 44 aircraft, reducing its fleet to 95 by the end of 2015. Thai Airways aims to sell up to 15 billion baht (US$460.83 million) in bonds to refinance debt. The airline has sufficient cash flow to run its business.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.31% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.31% in early trade on Friday, following a strong lead from Wall Street, with the Hang Seng Index reaching 24,843.20. The move comes amid a recent recovery in oil prices.

site_title: Oil rallies another US$1, but no rapid recovery seen
summary: Crude oil prices rose over $1 a barrel on Friday, rebounding from near-six-year lows, driven by conflict in Libya and expectations of increased oil demand. Benchmark Brent crude futures closed at $57.57 a barrel, a 4% increase from the previous day. Despite the rally, no rapid recovery is expected due to rising global inventories and steady OPEC supply.

site_title: CICC sees China loans surging to highest since crisis stimulus
summary: China's new lending may have surged to the highest monthly total since a 2009 stimulus program, reaching 1.6 trillion yuan in January, according to a note by investment-bank analysts at China International Capital Corp. The estimate surpasses the 1.35 trillion yuan median in a Bloomberg survey of economists. The surge in lending comes as China cut banks' reserve requirements to aid the nation's faltering growth, following a similar stimulus program implemented during the 2008-2009 financial crisis.

site_title: Indonesia plans tax amnesty to lure money back from Singapore
summary: Indonesia plans a tax amnesty to lure back funds from Singapore, aiming to narrow its current-account deficit. The government will revise rules to allow repatriated money to be tax-free and offer tax breaks to companies keeping funds onshore. The move aims to revive Indonesia's slowing economy, which has been weighed down by a current-account deficit and a weakening rupiah. The tax amnesty is expected to target wealthy Chinese Indonesians who moved funds to Singapore after 1998 ethnic riots.

site_title: Indonesia revises 2015 budget assumptions, sees 5.7% growth and US$60 a barrel oil
summary: Indonesia's parliament agreed on revised 2015 budget assumptions, including 5.7% growth and $60 oil price, after economic growth in 2014 was reported at 5.02%. The revised budget also includes higher inflation (5%) and a 6.2% yield on 3-month treasury bills. The budget revision is expected to reflect President Joko Widodo's reform agenda and will be subject to parliament's approval later this month.

site_title: South Korea prepares for US rate rise by easing levy on capital inflows
summary: South Korea is preparing for possible US interest rate hikes by easing controls on foreign-currency borrowings. The government will exclude one-year or longer foreign-currency debt from a levy, which discourages hot money inflows, and add non-banking firms to the list. The move aims to mitigate potential capital flight and maintain macroeconomic stability. The changes will be implemented in July, with Vice Finance Minister Joo Hyung-hwan stating the government has little reason to drastically retune its policies. This move comes ahead of expected US interest rate increases later this year.

site_title: China's yuan firms as dollar dips following strong all round gains
summary: China's yuan rose against the dollar on Friday, reaching its strongest midpoint in two weeks at 6.1261 per dollar, following the dollar's dip in global markets. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate firmer than the previous fix, but the spot market opened at 6.2390 per dollar, weaker than the midpoint. Despite the rebound, analysts expect further monetary easing from Beijing to boost yuan liquidity, with JP Morgan predicting a possible interest rate cut in the first quarter.

site_title: China: Shares lower in morning trade
summary: Chinese shares fell 0.51% in morning trade on February 6, 2015, despite a monetary easing announcement, with the Shanghai Composite Index closing at 3,120.41. The Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.10%. The declines occurred despite a cut in bank reserve requirements.

site_title: Australia: Shares, at record high, pare gains on central bank gloom
summary: Australian shares dropped from a seven-year high on Friday after a central bank report expressed gloomy economic prospects, despite a surge in oil prices overnight. Energy stocks had reached a record high earlier in the week, driven by a 6% increase in oil prices. Investors cashed in their profits after a weeks-long rally, bringing the market back down. The central bank's report highlighted economic uncertainty, which outweighed the positive impact of rising oil prices on the market.

site_title: Shenzhen stocks beats Shanghai peers most since 2008
summary: Shenzhen's stock market has surpassed Shanghai's in performance, with the Shenzhen Composite Index rising 6.2% over the past month, outperforming Shanghai by 13 percentage points since 2008. This is attributed to the higher concentration of technology and consumer industry stocks, which are expected to drive growth momentum. The Shenzhen-Hong Kong link, set to replicate the Shanghai-Hong Kong connect, is expected to further boost the market. Analysts predict the Shanghai index will extend its outperformance, but some warn that gains may be short-lived, citing cheap valuations and the need for earnings to bottom out.

site_title: Philippine central bank says no urgency to modify monetary policy stance
summary: The Philippine central bank's Governor Amando Tetangco stated there is no urgency to modify the monetary policy stance due to slowing inflation and sustained strong growth. The consumer price index rose 2.4% in January, its slowest rise since August 2013. The central bank is expected to keep the key policy rate at 4.0% and the special deposit account rate at 2.5% when it meets on February 12.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall, Hyundai Mobis down more than 4%; won firmer
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.33% to 1,946.31, underperforming regional peers, due to offshore fund sell-offs. Hyundai Mobis shares plummeted 4.3% after the Chung family promised a two-year lock-up period, scuppering prospects of Hyundai Glovis divestment. The won edged up against the dollar, while energy counters rallied. The country is easing controls on overseas borrowing, preparing for a potential US rate hike. Investors await the US nonfarm payrolls report and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Oil extends gains, euro recovers on ECB assurances
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% on Friday as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. The euro recovered after the European Central Bank assured Greek banks would have access to necessary funds. A strong rally on Wall Street provided support to regional markets, despite ongoing tensions over Greece's debt. The focus shifts to US January jobs data, which could influence Federal Reserve monetary policy and oil prices.

site_title: Stocks to watch: FJ Benjamin, Great Eastern
summary: Retailer FJ Benjamin posted a net profit of S$1.24 million for Q2 2014, up from S$586,000 a year earlier, despite a 17% revenue drop. Great Eastern Holdings reported a 25% rise in net profit to S$207.8 million for Q4 2014, driven by higher mark-to-market gains and insurance business growth.

site_title: Gold eyes worst week in seven ahead of US jobs data
summary: Gold prices are expected to post its biggest weekly loss in almost two months ahead of the US jobs data on Friday, following steep gains at the start of the year. A strong US jobs number could strengthen expectations for the Federal Reserve to hike interest rates by mid-year, negatively impacting gold prices. Spot gold remained nearly flat at $1,264.55 an ounce, with the metal losing 1.4% so far this week.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index rising 6.15 points to 3,412.73. Volume reached 56.9 million shares worth S$82.2 million, with 96 gainers outnumbering 46 losers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.87 points to 1806.31 on Friday, with gains outnumbering losses 122 to 51. Volume reached 30.9 million lots worth RM17.8 million.

site_title: Greek finance minister met with 'scepticism' in Berlin debt talks
summary: Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis met with German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble in Berlin, but failed to reach an agreement on Greece's massive debts. Schaeuble expressed "scepticism" over Varoufakis' proposals, citing disagreements on debt forgiveness and a haircut. Despite this, the two agreed that Greece should remain in the eurozone. The meeting comes as Greece's new anti-austerity government seeks to renegotiate its 240-billion-euro EU-IMF bailout, which has been criticized for choking growth in the economy.

site_title: Korean bonds send message on rates as monetary easing spreads
summary: South Korean government bonds are signaling a potential rate cut by the Bank of Korea, mirroring global monetary easing trends. The yield on three-year sovereign debt fell below benchmark borrowing costs, echoing previous moves before rate cuts in August and October. Analysts expect at least one rate reduction in 2015, with some predicting as many as two cuts. The Bank of Korea's policy board meets on February 17, and some predict a cut in February or March due to slowing exports and inflation.

site_title: Australia central bank cuts growth, inflation forecasts
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia, has cut its forecasts for economic growth and inflation this year. The bank now predicts 2.25-3.25% GDP growth, down from a previous estimate of 2.50-3.50%. Unemployment is expected to rise above 6.0% until mid-2017. The bank attributed the lower forecasts to a transition away from a mining investment boom and subdued non-mining business investment. Interest rates were also cut to a record low of 2.25% to kickstart the economy. The bank expects inflation to remain below 3.0% this year.

site_title: HK jewellery giant branches into 'black gold'
summary: Hong Kong-based Chow Tai Fook, the world's largest jewellery company, is expanding into China's oil trading business. The company, owned by the Chow family, has set up Chow Tai Fook Energy Co Ltd, with former Sinopec Corp executive Gao Jianfeng as its president. As China's state-controlled oil sector is expected to be relaxed, Chow Tai Fook is positioning itself to take advantage of the opportunities. The move marks the group's entry into the energy sector, alongside its existing property business.

site_title: Euro holds up on relief over Greek bank funding
summary: The euro held steady against the dollar on Friday after a rally on assurances that Greek banks would receive emergency funding. The euro rose to US$1.1465 in Tokyo trade, reversing a slump from the previous day. The European Central Bank's emergency liquidity assistance programme was seen as a key factor in calming market fears. However, National Australia Bank warned that the euro could still be sold if the US jobs report disappoints, and the US dollar slipped to 117.35 yen against 117.55 yen in US trade.

images.alt_text: The euro held up against the dollar in Asia on Friday after rallying on assurances Greek banks will get emergency funding.

site_title: Pilot's body found still clutching joystick of crashed Taiwan plane: media
summary: The pilot of TransAsia Flight GE235, 42-year-old Liao Chien-tsung, was still clutching the joystick in the cockpit when his body was found after the plane crashed into a river, killing 31 people. The pilot had steered the plane between apartment blocks and commercial buildings before ditching the aircraft. The death toll would have been worse if the plane had crashed into the buildings it narrowly missed. 15 people survived, and 12 remain missing; the voice and data recorders have been recovered, providing more information about the plane's final moments.

site_title: DBS hires ex-HSBC banker to lead Indonesian unit
summary: DBS has hired Paulus Sutisna, a former HSBC banker, as the head of its Indonesian unit. Sutisna, 50, has over 25 years of experience in banking and will also be a member of DBS management. DBS CEO Piyush Gupta stated that Sutisna's extensive experience and connections in Indonesia will help strengthen the bank's franchise in the country and deliver greater value to clients. This move is part of DBS's efforts to accelerate its organic growth plans in Indonesia.

site_title: Hutchison in talks with Chinese firms over ports assets sale: report
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing's Hutchison Whampoa Ltd is in talks with a Chinese consortium to sell a 40% stake in its ports business, valued at HK$160 billion (S$27.7 billion), to China Merchants Holdings, COSCO Pacific, China Shipping Terminal Development, and State Development & Investment Corp. Hutchison holds an 80% stake in Hutchison Port Holdings, the world's largest port container. The sale talks began in the middle of last year but have slowed due to concerns over the price being "excessively overvalued" and Mr. Li's restructure of his business empire.

site_title: YuuZoo to develop social e-commerce network for China's JW Lottedi malls
summary: YuuZoo Corporation has partnered with JW Lottedi Mega Malls in China to develop a social e-commerce network for the malls. The network, which will be available to 700 million customers, will allow merchants to sell products online and in-store. The first Mega Mall, set to open in August, will feature 600 merchants and will be marketed through various channels, including television advertising and in-store promotions. The partnership is expected to generate significant new revenues for YuuZoo, with the company investing 3 billion RMB (US$480 million) in new properties.

site_title: RadioShack files for bankruptcy; Sprint to take over some stores
summary: RadioShack filed for US bankruptcy protection on Thursday, citing 11 consecutive unprofitable quarters. The company has a deal to sell up to 2,400 stores to hedge fund Standard General, with Sprint Corp to operate up to 1,750 stores under the agreement. RadioShack aims to avoid liquidation and has agreements to close underperforming stores and sell remaining assets to other buyers.

site_title: ECB said to allow Greek banks 59.5 billion euros emergency cash
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has agreed to allow Greece's central bank to provide up to 59.5 billion euros in emergency funding to Greek lenders, following the ECB's decision to end a waiver on Greek debt quality. This move aims to prevent a financial crisis, as Greece's newly elected government faces doubts over concluding its aid program. The ECB will review the funds every two weeks, and failure to comply may result in a bank missing a payment and facing bankruptcy.

site_title: South Korea to ease some controls on foreign debt
summary: South Korea plans to ease controls on overseas borrowing by financial firms, a move seen as preparation for US interest rate hikes. Vice Finance Minister Joo Hyung-hwan announced the plan, which excludes foreign-currency debt with maturities over one year from a bank levy rule. The debt levy system will now also apply to credit firms, brokerages, and insurers, expanding its reach. The changes aim to simplify regulations and reduce the burden on financial institutions.

site_title: US businesses ask White House to help on China cybersecurity rules
summary: US businesses, including the US Chamber of Commerce and 16 other lobbies, have asked the White House to help overturn new Chinese cybersecurity regulations that would force US tech companies to hand over secret source code and adopt Chinese encryption algorithms. The policies are seen as a threat to US market opportunities in China and could crimp investment in research and development, hurting US jobs. The letter also expressed concerns about restrictions on cross-border data flows and market barriers for foreign financial services and telecommunications companies.

site_title: China central bank official says RRR cut not start of strong stimulus: Xinhua interview
summary: China's central bank lowered bank reserve requirements by 50 basis points, citing economic and liquidity conditions, but not as part of a strong stimulus, according to Lu Lei, head of the People's Bank of China's research department. The move was seen as an ordinary policy operation, with the upcoming Spring Festival holiday expected to trigger strong cash demand. The cut was made to fill a funding gap, but the central bank noted that foreign exchange reserves and open market operations alone were not enough, indicating a cautious approach to monetary policy.

site_title: Draghi's bond buying plans ripple across Atlantic: Euro Credit
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) quantitative easing program has led to a surge in demand for US government bonds, driving down yields on Treasuries and boosting the appeal of higher-yielding US bonds. This has defied expectations of higher interest rates from the Federal Reserve. US 30-year bond yields have fallen to a record 2.219%, while 10-year yields may drop to as low as 1% or 30-year yields reach 1.5%. The ECB's plan to buy government debt has also influenced European bond markets, with 10-year German yields falling to a record 0.297%.

site_title: European defence ministers oppose sending weapons to Ukraine
summary: European defence ministers opposed sending weapons to Ukraine, citing a potential transatlantic split and fearing it could fuel the conflict. German Defence Minister Ursula von der Leyen and Italian Defence Minister Roberta Pinotti stated that lethal weapons would not bring a solution and could escalate the situation. US Defence Secretary Chuck Hagel declined to support sending defensive lethal weapons, while NATO's top military commander, General Philip Breedlove, cautioned that arms would not resolve the issue and urged a diplomatic approach.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up 1.09%
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.09% on Friday, driven by gains on Wall Street and assurances about Greek banks' access to emergency liquidity funding. The Nikkei 225 index increased 191.56 points to 17,696.18. The euro rebounded against the US dollar and yen, following a week of decline due to the European Central Bank's decision not to allow Greek banks to use government debt as collateral. The dollar was at 117.51 yen, awaiting a key US jobs report.

site_title: Hong Kong bourse sees Shanghai trading link quota filled by end-Q1
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange expects its trading link with Shanghai to reach its 300 billion yuan (US$48 billion) quota by the end of March, potentially pressuring China to lift the limit to prevent a near halt in the scheme. The quota has been filled by nearly one third of investors, including banks, hedge funds, and Hong Kong-based funds, despite regulatory and technical issues. A decision to raise or remove the quota would be a major vote of confidence for the pilot programme, but Beijing may be hesitant due to concerns over market volatility.

site_title: UK lawmakers accuse PWC of promoting multinational tax dodges
summary: UK lawmakers accused PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) of promoting tax avoidance by multinational companies, claiming the firm misled lawmakers on its activities. The Public Accounts Committee, led by Margaret Hodge, stated that PwC's testimony in 2013 was "misleading" and that the firm promotes mass-marketed tax avoidance schemes. PwC denied the claims, but agreed to support tax reform. The accusations come amid growing outrage over tax evasion by companies like Google, Apple, and Starbucks. The UK government is urged to review accountancy practices and regulate the tax-advice industry.

site_title: Twitter revenue nearly doubles, user growth misses mark
summary: Twitter reported revenue nearly doubling to $479 million in the fourth quarter, up 97% from the same period last year. The company's quarterly loss decreased to $125 million, down from $511 million a year ago. However, the number of active monthly users fell short of expectations, growing to 288 million, four million fewer than predicted. About 80% of users accessed the service via mobile devices. Twitter shares rose 7% to $44.38 in after-market trades following the earnings release.

site_title: Lawmakers call for railway safety funding
summary: Lawmakers are calling for increased funding to address the issue of railway safety, particularly at road-level rail crossings. US Representative Sean Patrick Maloney has filed legislation to boost federal funding to $100 million annually for four years to move crossings to safer locations. The issue has been highlighted by federal regulators and experts, who note that the US is behind other developed nations in upgrading rail infrastructure. The move comes after a deadly commuter train collision near New York, which killed people and raised concerns about the prevalence of such accidents.

site_title: UK hiring slows as skills shortages bite, recruiters say
summary: The UK's hiring market has slowed, with permanent placements growing at its lowest rate in nearly two years, according to the Recruitment and Employment Confederation. Despite this, pay continued to rise rapidly as businesses struggle to find qualified applicants. The industry body attributes the pay increase to competition for skilled workers, which has driven up salaries. This finding may have implications for the Bank of England's upcoming forecasts, as it suggests that wages may be stronger than previously thought.

site_title: Tigerair Australia sale to Virgin Australia completed
summary: Tigerair Australia has completed the sale of its 40% stake to Virgin Australia for A$1, as previously announced in October 2014. The transaction marks the end of Tigerair Australia's ownership in the low-cost airline.

images.alt_text: Tigerair has completed the sale of its 40 per cent stake in loss-making low-cost Tigerair Australia to Virgin Australia, it said in an announcement on Friday.

site_title: US: Wall St climbs with energy rebound, Pfizer deal
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday as energy shares rebounded due to increased oil prices and a boost in demand from China. The S&P energy index jumped 1.5%, while Pfizer's acquisition of Hospira Inc for $15 billion contributed to the market's gains. The S&P 500 closed 1.03% higher, while the Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.2%. Despite some concerns over Greece's debt, weekly jobless claims fell less than expected, adding to the upbeat tone.

site_title: US office supplies retailers say merger will keep them competitive
summary: US office supplies retailers Staples and Office Depot are planning a $6.3 billion merger, citing increased competition from giants like Walmart, Target, and Amazon. The deal, announced on Wednesday, aims to create a retailer nearly twice as large as the combined Office Depot and OfficeMax. Regulators, including the Federal Trade Commission, will closely evaluate the deal due to concerns about reduced competition. The companies plan to sell up to $1.25 billion worth of Office Depot's sales to secure approval. If the deal goes through, Staples and Office Depot will have a combined $34 billion in revenue and 4,400 stores.

site_title: Mexico rescues 129 workers 'abused' by South Korean firm
summary: Mexican authorities have rescued 129 workers, including six children, from a South Korean garment firm in Jalisco, who claimed they were physically and sexually abused. Four South Korean nationals have been handed over to prosecutors, who are investigating potential child abuse and sexual crimes. The workers reported unsanitary conditions, long working hours, and lack of fire safety equipment. Officials also found that workers lacked contracts, were not paid for overtime, and were not given health benefits. The incident has raised concerns about labor exploitation in the garment industry.

site_title: Hiring business drives LinkedIn revenue beat
summary: LinkedIn Corp reported a 44% jump in quarterly revenue, driven by its hiring business, which saw a 41% increase in revenue to $369.3 million. The company's net income fell to $3.1 million, but it forecast an adjusted profit of $2.95 per share for 2015, beating analyst estimates. Revenue rose to $643.4 million, with the hiring business accounting for 57% of the company's revenue. The company's shares were up 6% in extended trading.

site_title: BoE leaves interest rates at record low on deflation fears
summary: The Bank of England maintained interest rates at a record-low 0.50% amid fears of deflation and slowing growth. The decision was made to keep quantitative easing cash stimulus at £375 billion, in line with expectations. Economists expect interest rates to remain on hold until after Britain's general election in May, as a prolonged period of falling prices is still a concern. The Bank of England aims to keep 12-month consumer price inflation close to a government-set target of 2.0%.

site_title: CME sees US$10m savings per year from closing futures pits
summary: CME Group Inc will save US$10 million annually after closing nearly all its futures pits in New York and Chicago, a cost-cutting measure amid declining volumes and the rise of computerized systems. The move, expected to impact 1,400 workers, follows a years-long decline in pit futures volumes, which have plummeted 75% since 2008. Options trading will continue in the pits, but its long-term future is uncertain, with most market participants expressing doubt.

images.alt_text: CME Group Inc will save US$10 million per year after it shuts nearly all of its futures pits in New York and Chicago, a spokesman said on Thursday, as the world's biggest futures exchange pushes ahead with cost-cutting measures.

site_title: Great Eastern Q4 profit up 25% to S$207.8m
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a 25% increase in net profit to S$207.8 million for Q4, driven by higher mark-to-market gains and insurance business growth. Gross premiums rose 6% to S$2.3 billion. The company's full-year net profit jumped 30% to S$878.6 million. Great Eastern also increased its embedded value to S$10.4 billion and recommended a final dividend of 40 cents and a special dividend of five cents per share.

images.alt_text: Great Eastern Holdings posted a 25 per cent rise in net profit to S$207.8 million for the fourth quarter, thanks to higher mark-to-market gains and a growth in operating profit from the insurance business.

site_title: Europe: Stocks shrug off Greek debt clash
summary: Europe's stock markets ended the day near break-even despite concerns over Greece's debt clash. The ECB restricted Greek banks' access to government debt as collateral, adding pressure on Athens to renegotiate its massive debts. Greek stocks plummeted 9% before recovering, while Athens stocks closed down 3.4%. The euro rose to $1.1439, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 index slipped 0.05%. German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble indicated a debt reduction was out of question, but other measures could ease the financial burden.

site_title: Indonesian banks strong enough without merger
summary: Indonesian banks, including PT Bank Negara Indonesia (BNI), are strong enough to compete with overseas rivals without merging, according to Bank Negara's head Gatot Suwondo. The country's top lenders can utilize their geographical reach within Indonesia to retain an advantage, and employees at BNI would resist any merger with PT Bank Mandiri. Indonesia's financial regulator aims to consolidate its 119 banks into two through mergers or capital injections, but mergers are unlikely to happen this year.

site_title: Oil up over 4% on Libya raid, China easing; volatility seen
summary: Oil prices surged over 4% on Thursday, rebounding from a sharp rout in the previous session, driven by rising violence in Libya and an expected boost in oil demand from China's central bank easing. Benchmark Brent crude futures settled at $57.57 a barrel, while US crude futures rose to $50.48. Despite concerns over record-high US inventories and a glut, traders expect crude to continue its rollercoaster ride as it searches for a bottom.

site_title: Sony Pictures boss steps down after damaging hack
summary: Amy Pascal, co-chair of Sony Pictures Entertainment, is stepping down after a damaging hack attack on the studio, which was blamed on North Korea. The attack, centered on the film "The Interview," prompted threats and a cancelled theatrical release, but the film has since become Sony's highest-grossing online film. Pascal will launch a "major new production venture" at the studio, which will focus on movies, television, and theater, with Sony financing the venture. Pascal's departure comes after she apologized for racially insensitive emails leaked during the hack.

images.alt_text: Sony Pictures Entertainment co-chair Amy Pascal, whose embarrassing emails were leaked in a hack attack on the Hollywood studio blamed on North Korea, is stepping down, the company said Thursday.

site_title: Falling oil prices to pull India's budget out of deficit trap
summary: Falling oil prices are expected to help India's budget avoid a deficit, contrary to initial concerns. The upcoming budget for fiscal 2015/16 is seen as a test of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's economic reform efforts. Lower oil prices will not only meet budget targets but also provide extra funds for reforms. The budget, set to be unveiled on February 28, is a crucial moment for Modi's leadership.

site_title: Washington-based IIF flags danger of 'easing wars'
summary: The Washington-based Institute of International Finance (IIF) warns of a potential "contagion" in global financial markets due to the intensification of monetary "easing wars" among major central banks. This could lead to distortions in the financial system, heighten uncertainty and market volatility, and threaten global financial stability. The IIF cautions that sustained ultra-low and negative interest rates could pose a significant financial stability risk, while the launch of quantitative easing programs by central banks could force other countries to follow suit, exacerbating the situation.

site_title: Fine acting, direction lift low-stakes comedy
summary: Pangdemonium's "Circle Mirror Transformation" is a feel-good comedy directed by Tracie Pang, featuring great live acting and amiable jokes. Based on Annie Baker's 2009 Obie-winning script, the play follows an acting class where participants achieve personal emotional breakthroughs through exercises. While the acting and production designs are strong, the drama is ultimately tamped down due to unsatisfying stakes and a thin plot. Despite this, the cast, including Neo Swee Lin, Daniel Jenkins, and Nikki Muller, deliver impressive performances.

site_title: A gritty warehouse turns into party hub
summary: A converted warehouse space in Singapore's Henderson Industrial Estate has been transformed into a party hub called The Henderson Project, founded by actress-writer-producer Selena Tan and her husband John Pok. The space, which initially hosted small events, has grown in popularity, attracting a hipster crowd with its unique blend of art, music, and entertainment. The project, which has partnered with brands such as Heineken and Crumpler, hosts events like film screenings, live music performances, and DJ parties, and has become a sought-after space for artists and creatives.

site_title: Dec trade gap widens to biggest shortfall in 2 years
summary: The US trade deficit widened to its largest shortfall in two years in December, increasing 17.1% to $46.6 billion, driven by a surge in motor vehicle imports and decreased exports. This marks the biggest gap since November 2012.

site_title: European banks beef up for Aussie deals
summary: European banks are rebuilding their advisory and financing teams in Australia to capitalize on the country's A$90 billion worth of privatisations expected in the next three years. The Australian government plans to sell ports, energy generators, and electricity networks to pay down debt and fund new public works. European banks, such as Barclays, Royal Bank of Scotland, and Societe Generale, are hiring bankers to prepare for these deals, with combined bank fees estimated to exceed US$1 billion. This follows strong M&A deals involving Australian firms in 2024, with US firms also entering the market.

site_title: US pork looks to surpass beef as most-produced meat
summary: US pork production is expected to surpass beef as the most-produced meat in the country, according to the US Department of Agriculture. Hog herds have rebounded from a deadly virus in 2014, leading to a 4.6% increase in pork output in 2015. This is expected to reach a record 23.908 billion pounds, while beef production is projected to drop 1.7% to 23.901 billion pounds. As a result, pork prices are expected to decline significantly this year, with wholesale pork prices already down more than 40% from a record in July.

site_title: Twitter said to reach deal for tweets in Google search results
summary: Twitter has struck a deal with Google to make its tweets searchable in Google search results as soon as they're posted, thanks to access to Twitter's firehose. This deal, which will be implemented in the first half of this year, will give Google access to Twitter's data stream, allowing tweets to appear in search results without the need for manual crawling. The agreement is aimed at increasing Twitter's visibility and advertising revenue, as the company faces slowing user growth.

site_title: Ministries explain lapses on resource management
summary: The Public Accounts Committee has urged public-sector agencies in Singapore to be more diligent in managing public resources, citing lapses in the Auditor-General's Report. The committee expressed concern over weak resource management, particularly the under-utilisation of land, buildings, and assets, resulting in waste of public resources. Ministries such as Ministry of Defence and Ministry of National Development have provided explanations for the lapses, with some addressing issues of land usage and asset management.

images.alt_text: THE Public Accounts Committee has urged public-sector agencies to be more diligent in managing public resources.

site_title: Malaysia's trade surplus widens 16.6% in 2014
summary: Malaysia's trade surplus widened 16.6% in 2014, reaching 83.11 billion ringgit, driven by higher demand for manufactured products. The country's export growth rose 2.7% in December, while imports increased 5.4%. The surplus shrank to 9.2 billion ringgit in December. The growth was largely attributed to falling world prices for oil, gas, and commodity exports.

site_title: Manhattan condos go for a bargain of US$3m
summary: Manhattan developers are shifting focus from ultra-luxury condos to non-luxury units priced under $3 million, offering more affordable options to buyers. Former rental buildings are being converted into condos, with 3,845 units under development this year, more than double the number in 2014. Prices range from $765,000 for a one-bedroom apartment to $2.08 million for a three-bedroom unit. This shift is driven by demand from buyers priced out of high-end market, as well as landlords seeking to capitalize on expiring tax incentives and rising rents.

site_title: EC raises growth forecasts as oil prices dip
summary: The European Commission raised its euro-area growth forecasts to 1.3% in 2015 and 1.9% in 2016, citing cheaper energy and a decline in oil prices. Consumer prices are predicted to drop 0.1% this year and increase 1.3% in 2016. Unemployment is forecast to decrease to 11.2% this year and 10.6% in 2016, with joblessness in Greece and Spain still above 20%. The commission also cut its deficit forecasts to 2.2% this year and 1.9% in 2016.

site_title: ERA Realty sees auctions market as a new growth area
summary: Singapore's largest real estate agency, ERA Realty, plans to enter the auctions market this year, capitalizing on the growing demand for auctioned properties. The company expects more sales to be made, citing a narrowing gap between sellers' and buyers' expectations. ERA aims to establish a franchise in the Philippines, where properties are relatively affordable, and will expand its operations to five locations with over 65,000 sq ft of space.

site_title: Democrats should latch on to Warren's proposals on Wall St
summary: Senator Elizabeth Warren's proposals on Wall Street have resonated with Democrats, offering a plausible alternative to the party's internal disagreement on financial reform. Warren's ideas aim to confront the outsize influence and structure of America's largest banks, proposing to remove implicit government subsidies and promote market competition. Her message plays well across the political spectrum, and growing support for her ideas could strengthen market competition and prevent big banks from taking on excessive risk.

site_title: On track to another hit
summary: Singaporean graphic novelist Koh Hong Teng's book "Last Train from Tanjong Pagar" has received acclaim for its nostalgic look at the iconic Tanjong Pagar Railway Station, which closed in 2011. The novel combines historical fact and fiction, following the story of a young man who rode the train daily and the life story of the architect and historian who leads a walking tour of Singapore's railway history. The book balances informative dialogue with humorous illustrations, capturing the rich cultural history of Singapore while keeping readers engaged.

site_title: A journey worth going on
summary: Reese Witherspoon stars as Cheryl Strayed in the film adaptation of her memoir "Wild," directed by Jean-Marc Vallée. Strayed embarks on a 1,800 km solo trek along the Pacific Crest Trail after her life falls apart, including the collapse of her marriage, the death of her mother, and her struggles with addiction. Witherspoon delivers a powerful performance, and the film balances raw emotion with restraint, using non-chronological flashbacks to tell the story. The film has received critical acclaim, including a Best Actress Oscar nomination for Witherspoon.

site_title: Alibaba drones fly over Beijing as Amazon pleads for US tests
summary: Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba has tested its first drone delivery service, promising to deliver ginger tea to customers within an hour in select areas of Beijing, Shanghai, and Guangzhou. The service is limited to just three days and 450 deliveries, with strict controls on airspace due to military use. The trial comes after regulatory issues delayed Amazon's plans for US drone deliveries, with the company's founder Jeff Bezos citing "red tape" as a major obstacle. Alibaba's move aims to provide a "cool consumption experience" for consumers.

site_title: Uber pilots ride-sharing service in Japan
summary: Uber has launched a pilot ride-sharing service in Fukuoka, Japan, as part of its research into mobility and transportation. The "Everyone's Uber" service allows users to request a ride through the app, with drivers using their own vehicles. The pilot program, which is free for passengers, will run until data collection is complete. This move comes as Uber expands its operations globally, with over 200 cities in 54 countries. The service is the latest attempt by Uber to challenge traditional taxi operations and regulators.

site_title: China to rein in luxury car prices with parallel imports
summary: China has introduced a pilot scheme allowing unauthorised dealers to sell imported luxury cars, known as "parallel imports," in Shanghai, starting next week. The scheme aims to cut high-end car prices, which are significantly higher in China than elsewhere. Over 20 dealers have applied to join the scheme, which will offer imported luxury models at a 10-20% discount to those available through authorised channels. The move is part of China's broader anti-monopoly campaign to bring down prices and promote competition in the luxury car market.

site_title: First Sponsor's Q4 earnings more than double to S$19.3m
summary: First Sponsor Group, a China-focused property developer, reported a net profit of S$19.3 million in Q4 2014, more than doubling from S$9.2 million the previous year, driven by revenue from property sales and financing. The company's revenue surged to S$84.5 million, with the Millennium Waterfront project contributing S$77.3 million. First Sponsor is cautiously optimistic about the Chinese property market's recovery and is diversifying its business with a 51.5 million euro investment in a commercial building in Amsterdam.

site_title: FSB's 'loss absorbing' rule could swamp debt market
summary: The Financial Stability Board's proposed "loss absorbing" rule, which aims to tackle too-big-to-fail banks, may overwhelm the corporate bond market with new debt, driving up funding costs for companies. Industry groups call for a wider range of securities to comply with the rule, citing the $4 trillion market at risk.

site_title: Euro rallies on speculation of SNB intervention
summary: The euro surged against major currencies, including the Swiss franc and yen, on speculation that the Swiss National Bank was buying euros to weaken the franc. The euro rose 0.7% against the dollar and 1.06425 francs, its strongest level since January 15. The move came after the European Central Bank announced it would no longer accept Greek bonds in return for funding, leading to a decline in the euro.
