site_title: India considering separate duty structure for Goa iron ore exports: minister
summary: India's mines and steel minister, Narendra Singh Tomar, announced plans to consider a separate duty structure for iron ore exports from Goa, which has been struggling due to a two-year mining ban and 30% export tax. The state's iron ore is of low-grade and not suitable for Indian steelmakers. The proposed measure aims to stop the dumping of steel on the world market. Additionally, the government may raise import duties to address the issue. This move is expected to help stabilize the iron ore export industry in Goa.

site_title: Malaysia December exports grew 2.7% y/y, beat expectations
summary: Malaysia's export growth exceeded expectations, rising 2.7% in December from a year earlier, driven by non-commodity exports. The trade surplus shrank to 9.2 billion ringgit (US$2.58 billion). Imports rose 4.2% from a year ago. Despite weak external demand and negative oil prices, economists expect the second half of the year to improve.

site_title: Trading dries up in South Korea's new carbon market
summary: South Korea's new carbon market, the world's second-largest, has seen trading volumes dwindle after its launch in mid-January. Officials attribute the slow start to concerns over permit shortages and companies' difficulty predicting their emissions. The market, which aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 30% by 2020, has seen bids to buy permits but no offers to sell, driving up prices to 9,960 Korean won. Analysts expect trading to gradually pick up as participants become more familiar with the market.

site_title: Oil markets drop further after crashing on inventory concerns
summary: Oil markets dropped further after a four-day rally, as record high US inventories cut optimism about China's central bank steps. US crude lost 9% on Wednesday, and Brent crude fell 14 cents to $54.02 a barrel. US crude stocks rose to a record high of 413.06 million barrels, amid concerns about seasonal demand and production from existing wells. Negotiations over a new wage contract for US refinery workers continued, while a remote oilfield in Libya was stormed, raising doubts about Libya's oil exports.

site_title: Greece's borrowing rate soars after ECB move
summary: Greece's 10-year bond yields surged above 10% on Thursday, following the European Central Bank's decision to restrict Greek banks' access to a key cash source. The move, made in response to Greece's new hard-left government's vow to renegotiate its 240-billion-euro bailout, has cast uncertainty on the country's repayment plans. The ECB's announcement also rattled financial markets, sending the euro tumbling by over one percent against the dollar. Greece's Finance Minister Yannis Varoufakis is set to hold talks with German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble in Berlin.

images.alt_text: Greece's borrowing rate soared above the symbolic level of 10 per cent on Thursday, after the European Central Bank moved to restrict the country's banks' access to a key source of cash.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall 0.98% amid Greek debt fears
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.98% on February 5, 2015, amid concerns over Greece's debt negotiations and a stronger yen, which negatively impacted exporters. However, Sony's earnings outlook was upgraded, causing its stock to surge 12%. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 17,504.62, while the Topix index fell to 1,410.11.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index down 6.59 points to 3,410.98. Volume was 48.5 million shares worth S$126.0 million, with 74 gainers outnumbering 54 losers.

site_title: Malaysia 2014 trade surplus widens 16.6%, Dec exports grew 2.7% y-o-y
summary: Malaysia's export growth rose 2.7% in December, exceeding forecasts, while its monthly trade surplus shrank to 9.2 billion ringgit, a 16.6% increase from 2013. For the full year, the country posted a surplus of 83.11 billion ringgit, driven by higher demand for manufactured products. The trade ministry expects the surplus to increase by 2-3% in 2015 and export growth of the same magnitude. Despite weak external demand and declining oil prices, economists see potential for improvement in the second half of the year.

site_title: Indonesian economy grew 5.01% in 2014, slowest in 5 years: govt
summary: Indonesia's economy grew 5.01% in 2014, the slowest rate in 5 years, according to official statistics. The slowdown was due to declining commodity exports and foreign investment, influenced by China's weakening demand. Despite this, the election of reformist Joko Widodo has raised hopes for economic improvement in 2015. The country's exports remained subdued, and political uncertainty also played a role in slowing economic growth.

site_title: Hyundai Motor chairman, son to sell US$1b stake in Hyundai Glovis
summary: Hyundai Motor Co chairman Chung Mong-koo and his son Chung Eui-sun are restarting the sale of a $1 billion stake in Hyundai Glovis Co Ltd, offering a 13.4% share at a discounted price of 227,500-232,500 won per share. The sale was previously scrapped after failing to generate interest from local institutional investors last month. The new term sheet is a 1.9-4% discount from Thursday's closing price, indicating a revised strategy to attract buyers.

images.alt_text: Chung Mong-koo, chairman of Hyundai Motor Group and Chung Eui-sun, his son, are offering a combined 13.4 per cent stake in Hyundai Glovis at 227,500 won to 232,500 won per share.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices rise 13% in 2014 to record high
summary: Hong Kong home prices rose 13% in 2014 to a record high, with an overall private home price index reaching 277.6 points, a 9th consecutive monthly gain. Prices have increased nearly 35% since 2012, sparking concerns of a housing bubble. Analysts predict another 5-10% rise in home prices this year due to pent-up demand. The government has warned of anti-cyclical measures and necessary measures to curb the market, but developers remain optimistic.

site_title: BNP Paribas sees tax, compliance pressures piling up
summary: BNP Paribas, France's largest bank, expects rising taxes and new regulations to impact earnings by 500 million euros in 2016, affecting its return on equity target of at least 10%. The bank is also dealing with ultra-low interest rates and a weaker euro zone economic recovery. This presents a more pessimistic outlook than its 2014-2016 strategic plan, which previously targeted a return of at least 10%. The bank has increased cost cuts to cover growing compliance and control expenses.

site_title: Thai consumer confidence index slips in Jan as economy worries rise
summary: Thailand's consumer confidence index fell to 80.4 in January, down from 81.1 in December, due to rising economic worries despite lower gasoline prices. The index, which measures consumer spending intentions, was impacted by lower prices for commodities such as rubber and rice, which hurt demand. The military government's struggles to revive growth, weak exports, and high household debt also contributed to the decline. The Bank of Thailand predicts 2014 growth of 0.8%, but some analysts expect a potential rate cut due to falling consumer prices.

site_title: Daimler sees Q4 adjusted EBIT rise on Mercedes sales gains
summary: Daimler's Mercedes-Benz division reported a 10% increase in Q4 adjusted operating profit to 2.82 billion euros, driven by new model launches and rising demand in the US and China. The company's return on sales rose to 8.3% in Q4 and 8% on a full-year basis. Daimler expects significant growth in revenue, EBIT, and unit sales from ongoing business in the coming year, leading to a proposed dividend of 2.45 euros per share, the highest ever.

site_title: China in talks to sell high-speed trains to US: official
summary: China is in talks to sell high-speed trains to the US, with state-owned firms discussing a potential deal. This move aims to boost China's high-tech exports and expand its rail network globally. The proposal comes after China's leaders promoted its fast rail technologies in foreign meetings. The US has faced controversy over Chinese rail projects, including a scrapped contract in Mexico and a subway train deal in Boston. The outcome of the US-China rail talks remains uncertain, but could have significant implications for global trade and transportation.

site_title: Singapore's GIC buys 5% stake in TV ratings firm Nielsen
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has acquired a 5% stake in TV ratings firm Nielsen NV for an undisclosed amount. This investment marks GIC's latest move in taking stakes in businesses in emerging and developed markets. Nielsen's market value stands at US$16.7 billion. The move comes as GIC continues to expand its portfolio, ranking as the world's eighth-largest fund with $320 billion in assets.

site_title: ECB move on Greek funding hits euro in Asia
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) blocked Greek lenders from using government bonds as collateral, cutting off a needed line of credit. This move weakened the euro in Asia, with the currency falling to US$1.1304 in morning trade. Despite a slight increase, the euro remains below its US$1.1469 level seen before the announcement.

site_title: Hackers steal tens of millions of records from health insurer Anthem: WSJ
summary: Hackers stole tens of millions of records from health insurer Anthem, exposing the personal information of about 80 million customers and employees. The breach, discovered last week, likely involved names, birthdays, addresses, and Social Security numbers, but not medical information or financial details. Anthem is setting up an informational website and offering credit-monitoring services to affected individuals. The incident highlights the vulnerability of the US healthcare industry to cyber threats, with security experts warning of the persistent risks.

site_title: Broker's take: Ezion top pick in offshore and marine sector for Maybank Kim Eng
summary: Maybank Kim Eng analyst Yeak Chee Keong has named Ezion as his top pick in the offshore and marine sector, advising investors to avoid Sembcorp Marine and Keppel Corp due to capital expenditure cuts. The analyst expects the oil rout's impact to be felt in the upcoming earnings season, with companies' strategies, pricing, and order enquiries being key factors. This is as the uncertainty over oil prices' bottom remains, making it difficult for companies to accurately assess their prospects.

site_title: Singapore's dollar to fall to 5-year low on easing, survey shows
summary: Singapore's dollar is expected to fall to a 5-year low of S$1.39 by year-end, according to a Bloomberg News survey of 15 economists and strategists. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is likely to ease monetary policy, reducing the slope of its appreciation against a basket of currencies by a percentage point. Analysts forecast the Singapore dollar to slide about 3% versus the US dollar, with Royal Bank of Canada predicting a tumble to S$1.48 by Dec 31.

site_title: Ending an era, CME Group to shutter most futures pits
summary: CME Group, the world's largest futures market operator, will close most of its open-outcry futures pits by July 2, marking the end of a once-raucous tradition. The decision comes as open-outcry volume has dropped to 1% of total futures trading due to the rise of computerized trading. Options pits in Chicago and New York will remain open. Traders had long anticipated the closure, with one veteran trader stating, "We all knew it was going to end." The closure is a result of declining use of open-outcry trading.

images.alt_text: At CME's exchanges, including the Chicago Board of Trade, Chicago Mercantile Exchange, New York Mercantile Exchange and Comex, open-outcry volumes have been steadily declining since the first electronic trades were made on the company's Globex trading platform in 1992.

site_title: Japan's women wrestlers take on sumo's big boys
summary: Japan's women wrestlers, such as 19-year-old Sayaka Matsuo, are gaining popularity in the traditionally male-dominated sport of sumo. Matsuo, the daughter of a former professional sumo wrestler, has been training since age five and aims to win the women's Sumo World Championship. Despite the sport's religious and spiritual origins, which restrict women from competing in the top-level ring, the Japan Sumo Federation is exploring ways to legitimize sumo as an Olympic event and promote women's participation. With growing numbers of female wrestlers, such as Anna Fujita, who compete in the under 65kg weight category, the sport is slowly shifting towards greater equality.

images.alt_text: Nineteen-year-old Sayaka Matsuo lies on the tatami mat as a personal masseur works on her neck and shoulders to squeeze out the knots.

site_title: China: Shares jump over 2% after PBOC cuts bank reserve requirement
summary: China's stock markets surged over 2% at open on Thursday after the People's Bank of China (PBOC) cut banks' reserve requirement ratio for the first time in over two years to combat an economic slowdown and deflation. The CSI300 index rose 2.5% and the Shanghai Composite Index gained 2.4%. This move follows a 40% increase in Chinese stocks since November when the PBOC cut interest rates.

site_title: Gold extends gain as Greece debt, global easing fan haven demand
summary: Gold prices rose for a second day, climbing 0.4% to US$1,274.18 an ounce, as European policymakers tightened Greece's bailout terms and the People's Bank of China eased monetary policy to counter slower growth. The metal has gained 7.3% this year due to concerns over Greece's potential exit from the euro area and speculation about the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions. Analysts note that central banks' easing of policy may provide limited support to gold prices.

site_title: Top Indonesia banks strong enough without merger: bank head
summary: Indonesia's largest banks, including PT Bank Negara Indonesia, are deemed strong enough to compete with overseas rivals without a merger, according to the bank's president director Gatot Suwondo. The country's four state-owned lenders are being considered for consolidation, but Suwondo stated that top-tier banks like BNI are ready to face competition when the Asean economic community comes into effect in 2020. Employees at BNI would resist a merger with PT Bank Mandiri, and the government controls all four banks.

site_title: Obama finds bipartisan support for first 'Big Data' privacy plan
summary: President Barack Obama's administration is working with bipartisan sponsors to introduce a bill to protect data collected from students through educational apps, marking the first of his "Big Data" privacy plans to gain traction in Congress. The bill aims to ensure data collected from students is used only for educational and legitimate research purposes. Indiana Congressman Luke Messer and Democrat Jared Polis are expected to unveil the bill in the next couple of weeks, with support from over 100 companies, including Microsoft and Google. The move comes amid growing public concerns over privacy and cybersecurity.

images.alt_text: Mr Obama has pushed to do more to protect privacy in an age when consumers leave a trail of digital footprints through smart phones, personal devices and social media - information that can be collected, analyzed and sold.

site_title: South Korea finance minister says 3.8% 2015 GDP forecast achievable
summary: South Korea's Finance Minister Choi Kyung-hwan stated that the country's 2015 economic growth forecast of 3.8% is achievable, citing factors such as falling oil prices and expansionary policies. The economy is in a state of disinflation, not deflation, according to the minister.

images.alt_text: South Korea's finance minister said on Thursday the government's 2015 economic growth forecast of 3.8 per cent is achievable, citing a number of factors such as falling oil prices which could boost demand.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 1.49% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.49% in the opening exchanges on February 5, 2015, following China's central bank decision to cut the amount of cash lenders must keep in reserve. The Hang Seng Index increased by 368.50 points to 25,048.26. This move is aimed at kickstarting the mainland economy.

site_title: Oil prices rebound in Asian trade but gains capped
summary: Oil prices rebounded in Asia, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rising 42 cents to $48.87 and Brent crude gaining 71 cents to $54.87, despite concerns over Greece's financial situation. The euro's decline, triggered by the European Central Bank's decision to cut off Greek banks' access to government debt, further hurt demand. Analysts say the gains are unlikely to be sustained, as a sinking euro makes dollar-priced oil more expensive, denting demand. Crude prices have lost over half their value since June due to a supply glut and weak demand.

site_title: Netflix to enter Japan in fall of 2015
summary: Netflix plans to launch its movie and TV streaming service in Japan in the fall of 2015, with an office in Tokyo. The service will offer a range of Japanese content, including original series "Marco Polo" and "Sense8". Pricing, programs, and supported devices will be announced later. This move is part of Netflix's global expansion into 150 new markets within two years.

site_title: Twitter and Google strike deal to show tweets in search results: Bloomberg
summary: Twitter and Google have reached a deal to make tweets more searchable online. The deal allows tweets to be visible in Google search results as soon as they are posted, starting in the first half of 2015. This change will come automatically from Twitter, eliminating the need for Google to crawl the site for information. The terms of the deal were not disclosed.

site_title: HDB resale prices higher in January, first time in a year: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore rose 0.6% in January, the first increase in a year, driven by higher prices for four and five-room flats. The median transaction over x-value (TOX) improved to a negative S$1,000, indicating buyers are not overpaying. Despite fewer flats sold, prices still fell 5.7% compared to last year, with non-mature estates experiencing a 7.8% drop. Prices in mature estates held up better, falling 3% year-on-year.

site_title: South Korea rejects Uber proposal for driver registration system
summary: South Korea's transport ministry rejected Uber's proposal for a new driver registration system, citing rules requiring licensed drivers and vehicles for taxi services. The ministry also denied reports of negotiations, stating Uber's operations will continue to be taken action against. Uber had proposed the system to overcome a ban on connecting passengers to private cars in the country.

site_title: Australia retail volumes surge in Q4 as prices fall flat
summary: Australian retail sales surged in Q4, driven by a 1.5% jump in inflation-adjusted sales to a record A$69.2 billion. Despite a modest 0.2% increase in December sales, the fourth quarter's outsized gain in volumes was largely due to a lack of pricing pressure. Lower interest rates and falling petrol prices are expected to boost consumer spending, with households potentially saving A$750-761 per year on mortgage payments. The Reserve Bank of Australia's interest rate cut is seen as a necessary step to offset deepening economic drag.

site_title: India's war on inflation still not won: central bank gov Rajan
summary: Reserve Bank of India Governor Raghuram Rajan stated that India's war on inflation is not yet won, citing the need for credibility to control future price shocks. He emphasized the importance of double-digit growth and warned of the risks of a strong exchange rate. Rajan acknowledged that India is benefiting from "disinflationary conditions" from the global economy, but emphasized the need for careful management to avoid inflationary expectations. The RBI's latest policy review held interest rates steady, but Rajan's comments suggest ongoing concerns about inflation and economic growth.

site_title: Asia: China rate cut offsets Greek fears
summary: China cut the amount of funds banks must hold in reserve, offsetting concerns about Greece's plans to renegotiate its bailout, which had rattled Asian markets. Shanghai and Hong Kong rallied, with Shanghai surging 2.45% and Hong Kong adding 1.01%. The move was seen as a boost to the Chinese economy, which had grown at its slowest pace in 24 years in 2014. The euro fell, while the dollar strengthened against the yen.

site_title: Philippine central bank expects inflation to stay within target over policy horizon
summary: The Philippine central bank expects inflation to remain within its 2-4% target range for 2015-2018, citing a 2.4% rise in consumer prices in January, the slowest since August 2013. Governor Amando Tetangco said the bank will monitor international oil prices and financial market volatility to adjust its policy levers if necessary. The central bank is expected to keep key policy rates at 4.0% and the special deposit account rate at 2.5% when it meets for the first time this year on February 12.

site_title: Russia said to lead UN effort to curb Islamic State's cash flow
summary: Russia has drafted a UN Security Council resolution aimed at curbing Islamic State's cash flow, targeting its three main revenue sources: illegal oil exports, antiquities sales, and ransom from hostage-taking. The draft, circulated to the five permanent members, aims to increase pressure on governments to cut off these funds. Russia is taking the lead on the proposal due to concerns about radicals from its Chechnya region joining the extremist group in Syria and Iraq. The resolution expresses the international community's resolve to take more action against Islamic State, following recent executions of hostages.

site_title: Top China official in Hong Kong warns against confronting Beijing
summary: China's top official in Hong Kong warned democracy campaigners against pushing for independence and confronting Beijing, citing the need for stability. Pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong last year demanded open nominations for the 2017 chief executive election, but Beijing has agreed to a vote between pre-screened candidates. This warning comes as the city prepares for the 2017 election.

site_title: Australian PM 'very confident' he will not be toppled
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott expressed confidence that he will remain in office despite growing pressure from within his own party. Following a speech by former assistant treasurer Arthur Sinodinos, who questioned Abbott's leadership, the PM stated he was "very confident" of staying on. A leadership challenge is possible, but momentum appears to be waning, and no clear contender has emerged to replace Abbott.

site_title: Indonesia protests over 'demeaning' Malaysia ad
summary: Indonesia has formally protested Malaysia over a vacuum cleaner ad deemed "utterly insensitive" to Indonesian maids working in the country. The ad, which read "Fire your Indonesian maid now!", was removed after the Indonesian embassy sent a formal protest note. The incident is the latest in a series of strained relations between the two Southeast Asian neighbors, with Indonesia recalling domestic workers in 2009 due to reports of abuse. The Indonesian embassy urges Malaysia to ban the ad and considers further legal action against the company.

site_title: China joins global-easing wave with bank reserve ratio cut
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, cut the reserve ratio by 50 basis points to 19.5%, aiming to boost loan supply and counter a slowdown in the country's economy. This move joins a global trend of easing monetary policy, as tumbling commodity prices provide support for growth. The cut is part of efforts to stimulate the economy, which has been weakened by capital outflows and factory slowdowns.

site_title: Debt worldwide up US$57t since global financial crisis
summary: Global debt has grown by US$57 trillion since the 2008 global financial crisis, posing new risks to financial stability. Government debt has increased by US$25 trillion, with China's debt quadrupling in the last seven years. Household debt has also risen to record-high levels, particularly in Northern Europe and some Asian countries. To address these concerns, governments may need to explore innovative ways to reduce debt, such as increased productivity, asset sales, taxes, and efficient debt restructuring programs. The situation highlights the need for governments to engage in deleveraging to maintain financial stability.

site_title: UBS in new probe over aiding tax evasion: report
summary: Swiss bank UBS is facing a new US investigation over allegations of aiding tax evasion through the sale of bearer bonds, which can be transferred anonymously. The probe, launched by the Justice Department, seeks to determine if UBS employees helped clients evade taxes or engaged in securities fraud. This is the second time UBS has been fined for helping clients evade US taxes, with a previous fine of $780 million in 2009. Authorities are trying to determine if the bank covered up alleged conduct once it became known.

site_title: Takata whistle-blower willing to testify on deadly air bag flaws
summary: A former Takata Corp. engineer, Mark Lillie, has told a US congressional committee he warned of deadly consequences before the company chose a design for air bags that were later recalled due to lethal flaws. Lillie, who left the company in 1999, said he was dismissed after raising concerns about the use of ammonium nitrate, a chemical compound that can cause air bags to rupture and shoot metal fragments. Over 20 million cars have been recalled worldwide due to the design flaw, resulting in six deaths. Takata has formed an independent review panel to investigate manufacturing weaknesses.

site_title: Death toll from TransAsia plane crash in Taiwan rises to 31
summary: A TransAsia Airways plane crashed into a river in Taipei, Taiwan, shortly after taking off, killing 31 people and injuring 15. The plane, carrying 58 passengers and crew, clipped an overpass and crashed upside down. Three Chinese tourists among the survivors were among a group of 31 tourists from mainland China. The pilot and co-pilot were among those killed. The cause of the crash is still unknown.

site_title: Global Logistic Properties Q3 profit down 36.2%
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) reported a 36.2% decline in Q3 profit to US$112.4 million due to flat revenue and rising expenses. Revenue edged up 0.7% to US$179 million, but was offset by deferred rental revenue and a weaker Japanese yen. Despite the decline, CEO Ming Z Mei expressed confidence in the company's growth strategy, citing continued leasing momentum in China and new investors. The group aims to expand its fund management platform and create value through developments.

site_title: CAAS ties up with Aireon to enhance tracking capability (Amended)
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) has partnered with Aireon to enhance aircraft tracking capability within the Singapore Flight Information Region (FIR) by deploying a space-based Automatic Dependent Surveillance - Broadcast (ADS-B) service. This will improve surveillance in remote regions and areas over the oceans, allowing for reduced separation between aircraft and increased airspace capacity. CAAS Director-General Yap Ong Heng and Aireon's President and CEO Don Thomas signed a memorandum of agreement to develop policies, standards, and procedures for the service.

site_title: Buffett says tough for Fed to lift rates given strong dollar
summary: Warren Buffett expressed concerns that the Federal Reserve will struggle to raise interest rates this year due to the US dollar's strength. The dollar's value has increased by 5% in the last quarter, making it cheaper for Americans to buy imported goods and reducing inflation. Buffett stated that it would be "very tough" for the Fed to lift rates, citing the risks for investors who accept low yields. The US 30-year debt traded at a record low of 2.22% on January 30, making long-term Treasury yields record lows.

site_title: First Sponsor Q4 profit more than doubles; group in tie-up to buy Amsterdam property
summary: First Sponsor Limited reported a 9-fold increase in revenue to S$84.5 million in the fourth quarter, driven by property sales. Net profit more than doubled to S$19.3 million. The company is also investing in a 51.5 million euro (S$77.7 million) commercial property in Amsterdam, with a 33% stake, expected to be completed by March 16. This deal aims to diversify exposure to China and increase recurring income for its property holdings business segment.

site_title: ECB cancels soft treatment of Greek debt in warning to Athens
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) cancelled its acceptance of Greek bonds in return for funding, shifting the burden to Greece's central bank to finance its lenders. This decision, effective February 11, isolates Greece unless it strikes a new reform deal. The ECB move comes after Greece's new finance minister Yanis Varoufakis claimed the ECB would support member states, but the ECB governors rejected this appeal. The decision puts Greece's banks in a difficult position, with tens of billions of euros in emergency liquidity assistance now required from the Bank of Greece.

site_title: Sony shares jump almost 10% on improved earnings outlook
summary: Sony shares jumped almost 10% in early trade Thursday after revising its earnings outlook upward. The company now expects to lose 170 billion yen (S$1.9 billion) in its fiscal year to March, down by more than a quarter from an earlier estimate. This upward revision led to a significant increase in shares, with buying bids overwhelming sell offers, and Sony opened at 3,040.0 yen on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

site_title: Higher CPF contribution rates for older workers mooted
summary: The CPF Advisory Panel has proposed two points to boost workers' retirement savings, which would inevitably raise business costs. The first point suggests equalizing CPF contribution rates for older workers (aged 50-55) to the same levels as younger workers, with a two percentage point rise in contribution rates. The second point proposes raising the CPF contribution salary ceiling to keep pace with wage growth and enable more members to accumulate higher savings. The panel's recommendations would push up business costs, prompting business leaders to call for government assistance.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Global Logistic Properties, First Sponsor, Singpost, Sats
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) reported a 36.2% drop in third-quarter earnings, with revenue remaining flat and expenses rising. The logistics group recorded a net profit of US$112.4 million for the period ended Dec 31. Revenue edged up 0.7% to US$179 million, driven by the inclusion of Brazil portfolio revenue and completed development projects in China.

site_title: China's slowdown spells trouble for migrant workers' pensions
summary: China's slowing economy is exacerbating its pension crisis for 166 million migrant workers, who are largely underpaid and have limited access to retirement benefits. The issue is partly due to lax enforcement of pension contributions by local authorities and companies, which have been reluctant to pay due to economic pressure. Strikes have doubled to 1,378 in 2014, with workers demanding better pension arrangements. Experts call for reforms to address the unfair system and ensure migrant workers receive fair compensation for their decades of work.

site_title: SEC, Chinese units of accounting firms near settlement: WSJ
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and Chinese units of the Big Four accounting firms (PricewaterhouseCoopers, Deloitte, KPMG, and Ernst & Young) are close to settling a dispute over audits of US-listed Chinese firms. The settlement would require the Chinese units to pay fines totaling around $2 million and cooperate with the SEC in future audits. The six-month suspension of the firms from auditing US-listed companies is expected to be lifted, resolving a dispute that threatened to complicate audits and fundraising for Chinese companies and US multinationals.

images.alt_text: The dispute had threatened to complicate the audits and fundraising capabilities of many Chinese companies and US multinationals.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.51% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.51% lower on Thursday due to concerns over Greek debt problems. The Nikkei 225 index fell 89.53 points to 17,589.21. The euro remained weak after the European Central Bank's decision not to allow Greek banks to use government debt as collateral, affecting financial markets.

site_title: Universal to release Steve Jobs biopic in theatres in October
summary: Universal Pictures will release a Steve Jobs biopic in theaters on October 9, directed by Danny Boyle and starring Michael Fassbender as Jobs and Kate Winslet as Joanna Hoffman. The film, based on Walter Isaacson's biography, will cover three product launches, ending with the 1998 iMac unveiling. The film was acquired by Universal from Sony Pictures after a casting dispute between producers Scott Rudin and Amy Pascal, which was revealed in leaked e-mail exchanges in November.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened flat on Thursday, rising 0.77 points to 1803.79. The trading volume was 26.49 million lots worth RM13.15 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 68 to 58.

site_title: Indonesia set for weakest growth in 5 years, policy rates seen on hold
summary: Indonesia's economic growth is expected to be its weakest in five years, with a forecasted 4.95% growth in the fourth quarter and 5.07% for 2014, according to analysts. The central bank, Bank Indonesia, is likely to maintain a tight policy stance to hold down the current account deficit, despite a decline in fuel prices and easing inflation. The bank has warned of an uptick in capital goods imports and is expected to keep its policy bias hawkish, unlike other central banks that are cutting rates to prop up slowing growth.

site_title: Greece's growth-linked debt plan may face legal obstacle: lawyer
summary: Greece's proposed debt swap plan, which would exchange rescue loans for growth-indexed bonds, may face legal obstacles under European Union rules. Lawyer Yannis Manuelides warns that creditors, including euro zone member states and the EFSF, cannot accept losses on their loans, despite potentially losing less through the swaps. The plan's complexity and potential for Greece to not pay full interest payments could also lead to legal issues, violating the EU's no-bailout provision.

site_title: European banks beef up for Australia infrastructure sale bonanza
summary: European banks are rebuilding their advisory and financing teams to capitalize on Australia's A$90 billion worth of privatisations expected in the next three years. The Australian government plans to sell ports, energy generators, and electricity networks to pay down debt and fund new public works, generating combined bank fees of more than US$1 billion. Despite some risks, including a potential election result in Queensland that could block asset sales, European banks are positioning themselves for a lucrative opportunity, with Barclays, Royal Bank of Scotland, and Societe Generale hiring bankers to prepare for deals.

site_title: US: Wall St ends lower with oil prices, renewed Greece worries
summary: US stocks ended lower on Wednesday, snapping a two-day rally, due to a decline in energy shares and renewed concerns about the euro zone. The European Central Bank cancelled its acceptance of Greek bonds, prompting a liquidity crunch and a 10.4% drop in the Global X FTSE Greece 20 exchange-traded fund. Meanwhile, the Dow ended in positive territory, lifted by Walt Disney's quarterly profit that topped analyst expectations.

site_title: US plan would regulate Internet as public utility
summary: US telecom regulator Tom Wheeler plans to regulate the Internet as a public utility, proposing rules to prevent Internet providers from blocking or favoring certain services. The plan aims to reclassify Internet service providers as regulated entities under the 1934 Telecommunications Act, banning "paid prioritization" and "blocking and throttling of lawful content and services." Wheeler's proposal, expected to face opposition, aims to ensure the Internet remains "fast, fair and open" for consumers and innovators, while critics argue it would stifle investment and innovation.

site_title: S'pore can learn from Germany in skills training, says PM Lee
summary: Singapore can learn from Germany's vocational training model, said Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, describing it as "very unique". The German model involves apprenticeships with firms, where workers stay long-term and don't jump to higher-paying jobs immediately. Singapore aims to adopt this model through its SkillsFuture initiative, promoting skills mastery and employer engagement in training. The country hopes to learn from Germany's decades-long approach to vocational training, which has led to a skilled workforce.

site_title: Oil crashes after 4-day rally; US inventory renews glut worry
summary: US oil prices plummeted 9% on Wednesday, with US crude dropping below $48 a barrel, after the US reported record-high oil inventories, sparking concerns about a global oil glut. The four-day rally was cut short after a rebound in the dollar and a surge in US crude supplies. Analysts say the market may remain oversupplied through the first half of the year, and prices may continue to decline. The oil market is now expected to be driven by external factors rather than fundamental changes.

site_title: Maersk offshore oil industry service units to cut head office jobs
summary: A.P. Moller-Maersk's oil industry service companies, Maersk Drilling and Maersk Supply Services, are cutting head office jobs due to the slump in oil prices. Maersk Drilling will cut 90 positions (20% of its workforce) and Maersk Supply Services will cut 30 jobs (15% of its workforce). The cuts are part of a cost reduction and efficiency enhancement programme, with the companies citing challenging market conditions. The moves come as oil prices have fallen by over 50% since July last year.

images.alt_text: Moller-Maersk's oil industry service companies Maersk Drilling and Maersk Supply Services, are to cut staffing at their Danish head offices due to the slump in oil prices.

site_title: Petrobras management quits, race on to find replacements
summary: Brazil's Petrobras CEO Maria das Graças Foster and five other senior executives resigned amid a corruption scandal, with the company's board set to elect a new management team. The resignations came as a surprise to the Rousseff administration, which was hoping for more time to find replacements. Investors are hoping for a more market-friendly leadership team to restore investor confidence and boost production and profits. The scandal has diverted at least $3.7 billion from Petrobras coffers, and prosecutors plan to name politicians from Rousseff's party as alleged recipients of kickbacks.

site_title: Falling oil prices pull India's budget out of the fire
summary: India's budget is expected to hit its fiscal deficit targets and provide extra cash to support economic reform, thanks to falling oil prices. The government plans to raise diesel prices and cut taxes, generating nearly $18 billion in revenue. The budget will also support the "Make in India" drive with tax incentives for the manufacturing sector and address structural economic problems. With the European Central Bank's stimulus, investors are upbeat, and the benchmark BSE share index has risen over 5% this year.

images.alt_text: The government has pocketed nearly US$3.5 billion (S$4.7) from repeated hikes in tax on fuel while the central bank cut interest rates by 25 basis points last month, and has hinted at further rate cuts if inflation declines.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close mostly higher
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed mostly higher on February 4, 2015, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 index reaching a record high and Paris's CAC 40 rising 0.39%. London's FTSE 100 slipped 0.17% due to a drop in oil prices affecting energy stocks.

site_title: Europe's commercial property market hottest since 2007
summary: Europe's commercial property market saw a 13% rise in transactions in 2014, reaching 213.1 billion euros, the highest level since the financial crisis. Paris attracted significant investment, with France experiencing a 31% rise in investment volumes. London's investment volumes slipped 3% due to high prices, while second-tier British markets like Manchester and Leeds saw a 16% increase. Ireland and Spain's markets saw the largest gains, with investment volumes rising 89% and 134% respectively. Global investors, particularly those advised by Blackstone Group, dominated transactions.

site_title: Buffett tells Fox Business he wants a company in Europe
summary: Billionaire investor Warren Buffett expressed interest in buying a small business in Western Europe, as part of Berkshire Hathaway's expansion plans. He stated that the company would like to acquire more businesses abroad, despite the US Federal Reserve's potential difficulty in raising interest rates this year. Buffett also mentioned that he would support Democrat Hillary Clinton in the 2016 presidential election and that yields on US Treasuries remain low, making 30-year government bonds the "last asset" he would want to buy.

site_title: With parallel import scheme, China aims to rein in luxury car prices: sources
summary: China is launching a pilot scheme in Shanghai's free trade zone to allow unauthorized dealers to sell imported luxury cars, known as parallel imports, to reduce high-end car prices. The move is part of a series of measures aimed at bringing down prices that are significantly higher in China than elsewhere. The scheme is seen as a response to weakening sales growth, dealer tensions, and a recent price fixing probe affecting luxury car makers such as Audi, BMW, and Mercedes-Benz.

site_title: Remisiers write to Tharman to resolve issues plaguing market
summary: Over 1,000 Singapore stock traders and investors have written to Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, urging him to resolve industry issues and rebuild confidence in the local market. The letter, signed by investment specialist S Nallakaruppan, proposes separating regulatory and commercial roles at the Singapore Exchange, raising public portions of IPOs, and reviewing onerous rules for "high-risk" products. The market has seen a 26% decline in annual trading volume over the past five years, attributed to a loss of confidence among investors.

site_title: Obama's Pentagon nominee suggests support for arming Ukraine
summary: Ashton Carter, President Barack Obama's Pentagon nominee, suggests supporting defensive arms for Ukraine, but emphasizes the focus should remain on pressuring Russia economically and politically. Carter "very much inclines" towards providing arms, including lethal ones, but cautions against escalating the conflict. The US has not sent arms to Ukraine, but has provided non-lethal military equipment. Carter is expected to be swiftly confirmed by the Senate, with some lawmakers expressing support and others questioning his influence.

images.alt_text: President Barack Obama's pick to become defense secretary told Congress on Wednesday he was leaning in favor of providing arms to Ukraine but later cautioned that the focus must remain on pressuring Russia economically and politically.

site_title: Tony Abbott defiant as members of parliament call for his sacking
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott is fighting for his job after backbenchers publicly called for a Liberal Party vote on his leadership, citing fading poll numbers and policy backflips. The call comes after Abbott's decision to make Prince Philip a knight sparked outrage among his own MPs. Despite a show of support from Treasurer Joe Hockey, reports suggest up to 40 MPs could back a leadership change, with Deputy Liberal Leader Julie Bishop and Communications Minister Malcolm Turnbull also considering a challenge.

site_title: Jasmine raises 36.7b baht through Internet fund IPO
summary: Thailand's second-largest high-speed Internet provider, Jasmine International PCL, raised 36.7 billion baht (S$1.52 billion) through its initial public offering (IPO) of its Internet fund, primarily for expanding its high-speed broadband network. The IPO price was set at 10.00 baht per unit, within the initial indicative range of 10.00-10.50 baht.

site_title: Jordan king vows 'severe response' to IS after pilot killing
summary: Jordan's King Abdullah II vowed a "severe" response to the Islamic State (IS) group after a Jordanian fighter pilot, Maaz al-Kassasbeh, was burned alive in Syria. The king promised a severe response after IS released a video of the pilot's killing, prompting global revulsion. Jordan executed two IS militants, including a would-be suicide bomber, as promised if Kassasbeh were killed. The incident has strengthened Jordan's commitment to fighting IS, with the country joining a US-led coalition conducting airstrikes against the group in Syria and Iraq.

site_title: BP posts net loss of US$4.4b in Q4 2014
summary: BP reported a net loss of $4.4 billion in Q4 2014 due to write-offs of $5.5 billion on North Sea and Angola assets. The company attributed the losses to lower oil prices and revised reserve estimates. BP also reduced capital spending to $20 billion and plans to cut exploration spending and postpone marginal projects. Oil prices rose for a third straight day, with prices below $50 per barrel earlier in the year.

site_title: Economists now fill the role of oracles and shamans
summary: Economists have become the go-to experts for understanding the mysterious and unpredictable economic forces, known as "Macro." Their predictions and analysis of macroeconomic trends, such as inflation, unemployment, and asset class movements, have gained significant attention from the public. However, this has led to a misalignment of incentives, as economists are more focused on providing Macro Sages rather than conducting careful and useful research. As a result, economists' predictions are often based on politics rather than empirical evidence, leading to a bad reputation for the profession.

site_title: Yum's China sales fall less than expected, shares rise
summary: Yum Brands Inc reported same-restaurant sales in China fell 16% in the fourth quarter, less than the 19.4% decline expected by analysts. The decline is attributed to fallout from a food scandal involving a former supplier. Despite this, Yum's shares rose 2.1% to US$75.16 in extended trading, as the drop was less severe than anticipated. The company is working to recover from the scandal.

site_title: Mockingbird author Harper Lee to publish second novel
summary: Harper Lee, author of the classic novel "To Kill a Mockingbird," will publish her second novel, "Go Set a Watchman," on July 14, 2015, more than half a century after its initial writing in the 1950s. The novel features the same characters as "Mockingbird" and was rediscovered by Lee's friend and lawyer, Tonja Carter, in 2014. Lee, 88, was initially hesitant to publish the manuscript, but ultimately agreed, calling it a "remarkable literary event" and saying she was "humbled and amazed" by its rediscovery.

site_title: New York Times' profit falls as it makes strides in digital ads
summary: The New York Times Co reported a decline in annual operating profit to $92 million in 2014 due to investments in digital journalism and severance costs from job reductions. Revenue was flat, with growth in digital advertising offsetting declines in print business. Digital advertising revenue rose 19% in the last quarter and 12% for the year, while print advertising declined less than 1%. The company plans to invest in digital growth and reduce costs to defend profitability, with 910,000 paid digital subscribers and plans to exceed 1 million by the end of the year.

site_title: US auto sales stay in the fast lane in Jan, overtaking expectations
summary: US auto sales surged in January, surpassing expectations with a 14% year-over-year increase to 1.15 million vehicles sold, the highest rate since 2006. General Motors, Ford, Fiat Chrysler, Toyota, and Honda all reported double-digit gains. SUVs and trucks dominated sales, with sport utility vehicles up 36% and full-size trucks like the Silverado seeing a 25% increase. Analysts attribute the strong gains to low gas prices, an improving economy, and milder weather, with sales expected to continue into February and March.

site_title: China January services sector growth slowest in 6 months
summary: China's services sector experienced its slowest growth in six months in January, with a PMI score of 51.8, down from 53.4 in December. This slowdown is raising concerns about the country's economic slowdown in 2015. The services sector, which has helped cushion the broader impact of a cooling manufacturing sector, saw new business growth ease to a six-month low. Despite this, employment remained steady, and policymakers may consider stimulus measures to support growth. The slowdown is seen as a warning sign for China's economy, which faces headwinds in 2015.

site_title: The write way to welcome Chinese New Year
summary: OCBC Bank hosted a Chinese New Year luncheon in Singapore, welcoming over 200 clients with traditional lion dance performances, paper fans, and a "God of Fortune" mascot. The event was attended by bank executives, including chairman Ooi Sang Kuang and group CEO Samuel Tsien, who wrote auspicious greetings in Chinese calligraphy.

site_title: Euro slumps, bonds rally after ECB puts more pressure on Greece
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) canceled its acceptance of Greek bonds in exchange for funding, putting pressure on Greece to implement new reforms. The move led to a 1.3% drop in the euro and a 0.9% gain in the US dollar index. The ECB's action was seen as a response to Greece's abandonment of its aid-for-reform program, requiring the Greek central bank to provide emergency liquidity to its banks in the coming weeks. The unexpected move fueled market volatility and raised concerns about Greece's economic stability.

site_title: EDB appoints four economic envoys from Germany
summary: The Economic Development Board (EDB) of Singapore has appointed four German economic envoys to serve as its economic ambassadors for the next three years. The appointees, from renowned "Mittelstand" companies, have direct experience investing in Asia and will provide practical advice to Mittelstand companies on operating in the region. This move comes as Singapore and Germany celebrate 50 years of diplomatic and trade relations, with Germany's foreign direct investments in Singapore reaching 1 billion euros in 2013. The envoys will help promote Singapore as a suitable location for Mittelstand companies to operate.

site_title: China cuts bank reserve requirement to shore up growth
summary: China's central bank cut the reserve requirement ratio for banks by 50 basis points, effective from February 5, in an effort to shore up flagging growth. This is the first industry-wide cut in over 2.5 years, following a surprise interest rate cut in November. The move aims to inject more liquidity into the economy, which has been slowing down, with GDP growth at a 24-year low of 7.4% in 2014. Analysts expect the policy easing to have limited impact, with some predicting a possible Q1 GDP growth below 7%.

site_title: Different minimum sums and flexible withdrawals up ahead
summary: Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) is set to undergo significant changes, including higher payouts for those who contribute more and flexible withdrawals. The CPF Advisory Panel proposed introducing different retirement sums, ranging from a basic retirement sum of S$80,500 to an enhanced retirement sum of S$241,500. Members can now choose between three monthly payouts: S$650 to S$700, S$1,200 to S$1,300, and S$1,750 to S$1,900. Additionally, members can withdraw up to 20% of their Retirement Account savings at age 65, and the government will provide incentives to encourage members to leave their retirement savings in the CPF.

site_title: CNOOC to make deep cuts in capex, targets 15% production growth
summary: CNOOC Ltd, China's largest offshore energy producer, announced a 50% cut in capital spending for this year due to the oil market turmoil. The slump in crude prices has put a heavy burden on oil companies worldwide, with billions of dollars wiped from their stock market values. Despite this, CNOOC targets 15% production growth this year, aiming to mitigate the impact of the market downturn. The move is seen as a response to the turmoil in the oil market.

site_title: Malaysia residential property demand to fall further: report
summary: Malaysia's residential property demand is expected to drop further in 2015 due to cooling measures and weaker buyer sentiment, according to Moody's Investors Service. The implementation of a 6% goods and service tax in April and higher mortgage rates are anticipated to dampen sales. However, the five biggest listed property developers in Malaysia are likely to remain resilient in terms of revenue, despite the slowdown.

site_title: Bahrain looks for regional edge with central Syariah board
summary: Bahrain's central bank is drafting a legal document to establish a country-level Syariah board of scholars to oversee the kingdom's Islamic finance sector, a move seen as a step to boost investor confidence and compete with regional rivals. The board, which is set to be more comprehensive than the existing one, will help standardize products and speed up the approval process. This move is rare in the Gulf and could give Bahrain an edge over other financial centers in the region, with a major investment bank stating that it will make products more attractive to investors.

site_title: Euro drops amid Greek debt renegotiations
summary: The euro weakened against the dollar for the first time in three days amid concerns over Greece's debt renegotiations, outweighing improving economic data. The euro fell 0.2% to $1.1456, while the dollar dropped 0.1% to 117.47 yen. Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis met with European Central Bank president Mario Draghi and German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble in an effort to convince Greece's creditors to reduce its debt burden. The euro's decline was also influenced by a reluctance to cut interest rates by New Zealand's central bank governor Graeme Wheeler.

site_title: Gridlock Light expected in Washington?
summary: A budget deal is expected in Washington, with both Democrats and Republicans agreeing to work together to address fiscal issues. President Obama's $4 trillion budget proposal includes tax increases and spending cuts, but no grand bargain on entitlement programs. The proposal includes bipartisan cooperation on issues like military spending, corporate tax reform, and infrastructure funding. Republicans are expected to accept the proposal, which would allow them to claim support for tax cuts and defense spending, while Democrats would benefit from increased domestic spending and assistance for the poor. This compromise is seen as a step towards resolving the structural problems of the American economy, despite ideological differences between the parties.

site_title: What failed in 2008?
summary: The 2008 financial crisis was caused by unsustainable debt levels, deregulation, and wrongheaded policymaking, including the introduction of the euro and overly optimistic inflation targets. Despite warnings from economists, policymakers responded with ineffective measures, such as austerity and structural reform, which have led to a stagnant economy. The crisis has been characterized by a failure to learn from its lessons, with the main shortcomings being intellectual. Experts Martin Wolf and Barry Eichengreen propose solutions, including increasing debt and inflation targets, and implementing regulatory measures to lower debt levels, but these have yet to be implemented.

site_title: Sometimes, firms need to break up too
summary: Corporate breakups, also known as spin-offs, are becoming increasingly common as companies seek to ignite shareholder returns. Recent examples include HP Inc and Hewlett-Packard Enterprise, eBay and PayPal. However, these separations come with significant costs, typically ranging from 1-2% of revenue, and can be time-consuming, taking 12-18 months to complete. Additionally, they can be resource-intensive and distracting for the organization. The question remains whether these breakups are worth the costs and disruption.

site_title: Bloc of 16 units at 111 Emerald Hill sold for about S$75m via sale of shares
summary: A bloc of 16 units at the 40-unit condo project 111 Emerald Hill in Singapore sold for approximately S$75 million to S$76 million, valuing the units at a low S$1,700 psf. The sale, which was brokered by Savills, reflects a decline in luxury condo prices and a discount for the bulk transaction. The units include four penthouses with roof terrace areas, which would have diluted the psf price. The sale was made by a fund managed by LaSalle Investment Management to entities fully owned by Singapore citizens, who will now be free to lease or hold the units without restrictions.

site_title: Post-Gross, investors continue to pull out of Pimco
summary: Investors have pulled out $11.6 billion from Pimco's flagship fund in January, following Bill Gross' exit in September. This marks a notable reduction from December's $19.4 billion outflows. Monthly outflows have remained elevated since Gross' departure, indicating investor confidence in the firm's ability to manage the fund. The move is part of a broader trend of investors pulling out of Pimco following Gross' departure, as they reassess the firm's strategy and leadership.

site_title: With CSA, cyber security gets the attention it deserves
summary: The Singapore government has established the Cyber Security Agency (CSA) to oversee the country's cyber security, effective April 1. The agency will combine functions from various ministries and industry verticals, including the Infocomm Development Agency, Ministry of Home Affairs, and others. This move is in line with global leaders recognizing cyber security as an integral part of national security, with US President Barack Obama mentioning cyber threats alongside terrorism in his State of the Union address. The CSA will be led by Minister Yaacob Ibrahim, who will oversee the sector leads in reporting on cyber security.

site_title: Oil slips after 4-day rally on demand concerns, stock levels
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday, reversing a 4-day rally, amid concerns over global demand and high stock levels. Weaker-than-expected data from China's services sector and estimates of a 6 million-barrel increase in US crude stockpiles contributed to the decline. Despite some forecasts predicting lower oil prices will spur economic growth, oil prices remain volatile, with West Texas Intermediate falling to $51.90 a barrel and Brent at $56.16 a barrel.

site_title: PEC wins S$132m refinery deal in the Middle East
summary: MAINBOARD-listed PEC Ltd won a S$132 million contract to build large crude and fuel oil tanks for a refinery in the United Arab Emirates. The project, scheduled to be completed by April 2016, will require engineering, procurement, and construction works. The contract is expected to boost PEC's standing in the Middle East and enhance its earnings for the fiscal year ending June 2015.

site_title: GuocoLand gears up for Tanjong Pagar marketing
summary: GuocoLand is gearing up for the marketing of Tanjong Pagar Centre, a mixed-use development in Singapore, with a focus on food and beverage (F&B) for the retail component. The 100,000 sq ft of netlettable retail space will feature a range of F&B outlets, aiming to create a "national food haven." The development, which includes a 5-star hotel and 181 luxury residences, is expected to attract diverse office tenants, including tech and social media companies. GuocoLand's managing director, Cheng Hsing Yao, believes the project will benefit from Singapore's growing food culture and limited office supply.

site_title: Flexibility comes with risks
summary: Singapore's CPF Advisory Panel has proposed changes to the country's retirement system, emphasizing flexibility and individual choice. The new proposals allow those owning property with a CPF charge to withdraw savings above $80,500 at 55, while those without property can withdraw up to $161,000. However, critics warn that this could lead to a decrease in retirement adequacy, as many Singaporeans may withdraw their savings prematurely, potentially depleting the system. The panel's recommendations also include the option for individuals to invest more in the CPF system, but experts caution that this may not offset the risks of premature withdrawals.

site_title: 'Sharing economy' reshaping markets
summary: The sharing economy, led by platforms like Uber, is reshaping markets. Uber's valuation reached $40 billion, while Airbnb offers alternative income opportunities. Meanwhile, companies like Levi and Adidas are adapting to tariff threats by exploring new products and markets. Despite US tariffs, Levi sees revenue growth, and DBS downgrades Genting Singapore's stock due to tariff dampened outlook. Merck is nearing a $10 billion deal for a lung therapy firm, and IHH is considering expansion in Indonesia and Vietnam. These developments indicate the sharing economy's growing influence and companies' resilience in the face of global challenges.

site_title: Novartis Japan faces penalty over drug side effects
summary: Novartis Japan is facing a possible 15-day suspension order for failing to report over 3,000 cases of patient health problems potentially caused by adverse effects from its drugs. The company admitted the failure in December. This marks the latest penalty for Novartis in Japan, following a business improvement order in July and charges laid over falsified data. A decision is imminent, with the health ministry stating it will be announced soon.

site_title: Jordan hangs 2 Iraqi terrorists for the killing of pilot
summary: Jordan executed two Iraqi terrorists, including a female militant Sajida Al-Rishawi, for her role in a 2005 suicide bombing in Amman. The execution came in response to an ISIS video showing a captured Jordanian pilot being burned alive. Al-Rishawi had been sentenced to death for her involvement in the attack.

site_title: Lower costs help lift SATS Q3 profit by 25%
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based ground-handler and food solutions firm, reported a 25.2% year-over-year increase in its third-quarter net profit to S$53.7 million, driven by lower costs. Revenue declined 3.2% to S$450.7 million, with a 3.5% rise in gateway services revenue offsetting a 7.2% drop in food solutions revenue. Operating profit rose to S$51.1 million, with staff and raw material costs decreasing. Despite a decline in passengers and flights handled, cargo/mail processed increased 6.1%, and gross meals produced edged up 1%.

site_title: Banks, HK Land and Keppel lift STI
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 9.55 points to 3,417.57 on Wednesday, despite being off its intraday high. The gain was primarily driven by banks, Hongkong Land, and Keppel Corp, with UOB and the Singapore Exchange also contributing to the increase. Analysts note that investors are cautious due to potential asset quality issues and tightening liquidity conditions, but some remain optimistic about the sector's performance, with DBS being highlighted as a top pick.

site_title: COE prices lower, except for motorbikes
summary: In the latest round of vehicle certificate of entitlement (COE) bidding in Singapore, COE premiums mostly fell, except for motorcycles. Category A (cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp) COE ended at S$62,002, down from S$65,001. Category B (cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp) COE fell to S$70,890, and Category C (goods vehicles and buses) COE closed at S$52,101. However, motorcycle COE premiums rose to S$5,504 due to a drastic reduction in COE quotas.

site_title: UK regulator says new runways will require more compensation payouts
summary: The UK's Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) stated that expanding London's airports will require higher compensation payouts to communities affected by new runways due to increased noise levels. Without extra compensation, expansion plans may be scuppered. The CAA's chief executive, Andrew Haines, emphasized the need for comprehensive tackling of the issue, which has been a major obstacle to plans for a new runway since the 1970s. The government commission is set to make a recommendation on expanding at Heathrow or Gatwick this summer.

site_title: Shell, union still deadlocked over US refinery pay issue
summary: Royal Dutch Shell Plc and the United Steelworkers union remain deadlocked over a new wage contract for US refinery workers on strike for three days. The union seeks 6% annual pay increases, double the previous agreement, and wants work previously given to non-union contractors to be reassigned to USW members. Executives claim they cannot afford to lift wages due to a 50% drop in crude prices, while the union threatens further walkouts at 63 refineries and chemical plants if progress is not made.

site_title: Lankan president pledges national reconciliation
summary: Sri Lanka's new President Maithripala Sirisena has pledged national reconciliation six years after the island's ethnic war ended, vowing to work with the UN to end the country's pariah status. He promised to never again allow the "land to be traumatised by the shedding of blood of innocents." The new government's approach has been welcomed by the US and Commonwealth, with a focus on addressing foreign policy problems and improving human rights.

site_title: Offer for LCD Global turns unconditional
summary: Aspial Corp and Fragrance Group's cash offer for LCD Global Investments has become unconditional after JTrust Asia, the company's largest shareholder, agreed to sell its 29.5% stake. The offer, valued at 33 Singapore cents per share, now holds 59.6% of LCD Global's shares, surpassing the 50% threshold for voting rights. JTrust Asia cited instability in LCD management and favourable offer conditions as reasons for accepting the bid, which is expected to yield a gain of $11.46 million.

site_title: Israeli biotech firm surges on mystery firm's nameless analyst note
summary: Israeli biotech firm Pluristem Therapeutics Inc surged 39% in Nasdaq trading after a bullish report from Acceleron Equity Research, a California-based firm with an unknown analyst. The report, dated January 26, recommended buying Pluristem stock, which finished the week at US$3.72, valuing the company at US$261.3 million. Acceleron's credibility is questionable due to lack of information about its owners and managers. The firm's domain was registered by ME Garza, who operates a biotech news site and has previously owned Pluristem shares.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: OSIM International reported a slightly lower Q4 FY14 revenue and profit after tax and minority interests, largely within expectations. The company maintained a positive outlook on China, citing a resilient affluent consumer market and the launch of new products. SIA Engineering Company's revenue dropped 6.5% year-on-year, with associates and joint ventures plunging 33.2% due to reduced engine shop visits. The company's business model may experience periodic hiccups as engine reliability improves, leading to a lower target price of S$3.62 for SIA Engineering Company.

site_title: What the CPF recommendations mean
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) recently released CPF recommendations. The recommendations aim to enhance the retirement savings system, encouraging individuals to save more and invest wisely. Key changes include increasing the retirement savings contribution rate and introducing a Retirement Account, which can be created using Ordinary and Special Accounts savings. These changes aim to improve Singapore's retirement security and create a more sustainable future.

site_title: Business jet makers not keen on UN aircraft-tracking plan
summary: Business jet makers oppose a UN proposal to require plane makers to install tracking equipment on aircraft with 19 or fewer passenger seats, citing added costs and limited safety benefits. The International Business Aviation Council argues that the expense would be a "huge cost that would push up the cost of the airplane to the customer." The proposal comes after the disappearance of a Malaysian airliner last March, aiming to improve rescue efforts.

site_title: S'pore to retain manufacturing as pillar of economy: PM Lee
summary: Singapore will continue to prioritize manufacturing as a key pillar of its economy, said Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong during his visit to Germany. He expressed hope that German small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) would expand in Singapore, using it as a gateway to Asia. Lee emphasized the importance of consistency in policy, regulatory transparency, and protecting intellectual property for German businesses investing in Singapore. He assured them that the government would uphold the system that has worked well for them and continue to upgrade the economy.

images.alt_text: PM Lee addressing about 100 Singaporean and German business leaders and government officials at a state dinner in a 15th-century castle chapel in Dresden on Monday evening.

site_title: Singapore and China exploring 3rd govt-to-govt project in western China
summary: Singapore and China are exploring a third government-to-government project in western China, following successful collaborations in Suzhou Industrial Park and Tianjin Eco-City. Minister for Social and Family Development Chan Chun Sing recently returned from a visit to assess feasibility, with Singapore businesses to continue exploring collaborations with Chinese counterparts. The project aims to enhance connectivity within the region and connect it to other parts of China and the world, with a focus on commercial viability and alignment with China's developmental priorities.

site_title: Indonesia palm oil firms seen as takeover targets
summary: Indonesian palm oil firms with a market value under $1 billion are being targeted for takeovers as weaker demand and lower prices make smaller producers more willing to sell. A 2013 law limits companies to 100,000 hectares of oil palm plantations, but exemptions for listed companies owned by the public create opportunities for consolidation. With global demand for palm oil declining, smaller producers are more open to deals, and analysts predict potential acquisitions.

site_title: Sony cuts full-year loss forecast to US$1.4b
summary: Sony cuts its full-year loss forecast to $1.4 billion, citing a weak yen and improving smartphone sales. The company also announced another 1,100 job cuts in its mobile phone business, on top of a previously announced 1,000 redundancies. Despite a cyber attack on its film unit, Sony's third-quarter profit more than tripled to an estimated 89 billion yen. The company's restructuring efforts aim to drag itself out of the red, with plans to unload its laptop business and sell its Manhattan headquarters.

site_title: Proposed changes strike a balance, say observers
summary: Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) proposes higher payouts and flexible withdrawal options, striking a balance between financial stability and flexibility. Observers welcome the changes, but some question letting people withdraw up to 20% of retirement savings at age 65, as it may not be financially responsible, especially considering the high interest rates on savings.

site_title: The power and risks of high-tech fashion
summary: High-tech fashion has introduced new privacy implications as technology is embedded in clothing. Designs such as the Navigate Jacket, which provides haptic feedback for navigation, and the Mood Sweater, which detects a person's excitement levels, raise concerns about data collection and tracking. The exhibition "Cloud Couture" at Pratt Institute's Brooklyn Fashion and Design Accelerator explores the power and risks of advanced technology in clothing. Experts warn that the introduction of wearable technology could lead to a more intimate experience, with clothing monitoring vital signs and communicating with computers via Bluetooth, raising questions about privacy and consent.

site_title: BOJ governor sticks to his guns on 2% inflation target
summary: Bank of Japan (BOJ) Governor Haruhiko Kuroda reiterated the central bank's 2% annual inflation target, despite signs of controversy surrounding its policies. Kuroda defended himself in parliament, stating that the target would be met "around fiscal 2015," not within exactly two years. This comes amid concerns that the BOJ's policies could become entangled in national politics.

site_title: Chinese TV reboots Korean reality shows for celebrity thrills
summary: Chinese TV producers are rebooting Korean reality shows to capitalize on the "Korean Wave" phenomenon, as foreign content was previously barred from airing during prime time. Shows such as Hurry Up, Brother and Where Are We Going, Dad? have gained popularity, with an estimated 4.2% of Chinese homes tuning in. Producers attribute the success to cultural similarities and the appeal of Korean products playing on Confucian values. Remakes of US and European shows also draw viewers, with a Korean version of The Amazing Race and an American version of Grandpas Over Flowers in development.

site_title: Fidelity fund aims to invest only in assets that are collateralised
summary: Fidelity Investments plans to convert its $111.5 billion Fidelity Cash Reserves fund to invest at least 99.5% of assets in US government securities or repurchase agreements fully collateralized. This move follows US Securities and Exchange Commission changes to money market funds, including the abolition of the $1 share price and introduction of liquidity fees and redemption gates. The proposal is subject to shareholder approval on May 12 and is expected to occur in the fourth quarter. The changes aim to prevent runs and stabilize the money market.

site_title: Rigbuilders gain on crude rally
summary: Rigbuilders Keppel Corporation and Sembcorp Marine in Singapore have seen their shares rise due to the recent surge in crude prices. Brent crude has jumped 17.2% to $57.08, while West Texas Intermediate has risen 16.54% to $51.80. Analysts remain cautious about the sustained oil price rebound, citing a fundamental supply-demand mismatch in the oil markets.

site_title: Airfares may stay flat despite removal of fuel surcharges
summary: Airfares are unlikely to increase significantly despite the removal of fuel surcharges by airlines, according to a Maybank Kim Eng report. Base fares may be raised to protect margins, leading to flat or slightly lower airfares, with average fares potentially falling 1-2% year-on-year. Airlines plan to adjust yield management strategies, offering more tickets in the middle price range to offset the removal of fuel surcharges. This shift may result from increased competition on international routes and weak yields.

site_title: UK polls put political, economic stability on the line
summary: The UK general election on May 7 is expected to be closely contested, with polls indicating a neck-and-neck race between the Conservatives and Labour. A coalition with anti-business parties is likely, with Labour and the Scottish National Party (SNP) potentially forming an alliance. This could undermine economic stability and confidence in Britain. The Liberal Democrats, who have ensured stability in the current coalition, are expected to lose most of their seats. The UK Independence Party (UKIP) and its anti-immigration stance could also impact the election, with Conservative leaders trying to persuade UKIP voters to switch to the Tories.

site_title: BP hunkers down for prolonged oil slump
summary: BP is preparing for a prolonged oil slump by reducing its capital expenditure budget to $20 billion, a 20% decrease from previous guidance. The company has also written off billions of dollars in assets and plans to cut costs further. BP's CEO, Bob Dudley, is taking a more aggressive approach than peers Shell and Exxon, but faces lingering risks from the 2010 Macondo spill. The company aims to preserve its dividend and has a strong balance sheet, but investors remain uncertain about its ability to manage the downturn.

site_title: India urges Fed to accept a stronger greenback
summary: India's central bank chief Raghuram Rajan urged the US Federal Reserve to accept a stronger dollar as it considers raising interest rates for the first time since 2006. Rajan stated that the Fed will have to start normalizing interest rates, and when it does, it will have to accept a stronger dollar. This comes as the US economy outperforms its industrialized counterparts, leading to a stronger dollar that has damaged earnings at American companies.

site_title: US drugmakers' reports on side effects often incomplete: study
summary: A study by the Institute for Safe Medicine Practices found that US drugmakers often submit incomplete information about side effects to the FDA, with only about half of reports meeting basic standards. The study analyzed over 847,000 case reports and found that FDA-collected reports were more comprehensive, with 85% meeting standards. The lack of completeness makes it difficult to evaluate drug safety, particularly for high-profile drugs like hepatitis C treatment Solvadi. The FDA is working to improve the system, but the voluntary nature of reporting makes it challenging.

site_title: Samsung to expand range of smart appliances
summary: Samsung plans to launch a range of smart appliances, including refrigerators, air conditioners, and washing machines, as it seeks to expand its business in Internet-connected homes. The move comes as the market for smartphones becomes increasingly saturated, prompting the company to focus on IoT. By expanding its smart appliance range, Samsung aims to tap into the growing demand for connected home products and increase its presence in the market.

site_title: TUI's shake-up of airline ops likely to cost hundreds of jobs: sources
summary: TUI Group, the world's largest leisure and tourism company, is planning to shake up its airline operations, potentially leading to hundreds of job losses in Hanover, Germany. The company aims to save over 100 million euros by combining airline operations, including TUIfly, Jetairfly, and Thomson Airways, with Thomson Airways as the base in the UK. This move is expected to affect around 400-500 jobs out of 2,000 at TUIfly's Hanover base, sparking concerns of strikes or legal action from unions. A decision is expected by Easter.

site_title: Fed may not raise rates at all this year, says Lombard Odier official
