The rally in oil prices is seen as a positive factor for the ringgit, with markets taking cues from the US market and oil prices.

site_title: Delta Air Lines expands partnership with Starbucks
summary: Delta Air Lines is expanding its partnership with Starbucks, serving the coffee chain's brand coffee on all flights, replacing Seattle's Best Coffee. The move is part of the airline's efforts to enhance the travel experience, with free cups of Starbucks coffee available to all customers. This upgrade follows a trend of airlines investing in premium products and services, driven by reduced competition and lower fuel costs. Delta's partnership with Starbucks may inspire other airlines to follow suit, offering premium coffees in-flight.

site_title: Updated: CPF advisory panel pushes for more flexibility in withdrawals and monthly payouts
summary: The Central Provident Fund (CPF) Advisory Panel has proposed nine recommendations to increase flexibility in the CPF system. The suggestions include adjusting the Minimum Sum (MS) after 2015, increasing lump sum withdrawal at 65, and allowing members to defer their payout start age up to 70 years old. The panel also recommends increasing the Basic Retirement Sum (BRS) for those turning 55 from 2017 to 2020 by 3% for each successive cohort. The changes aim to provide more flexibility and options for CPF members, particularly those with low balances.

site_title: Uber cabbie denies raping Indian passenger
summary: A special court in New Delhi heard the trial of Uber taxi driver Shiv Kumar Yadav, 32, who was accused of raping a 25-year-old Indian passenger in December. Yadav denied the charges, claiming he tried to calm her after she started crying and stating that the alleged incidents were "false". His trial continues in a fast-track court.

site_title: China: Shares up slightly in morning trade
summary: Chinese shares rose slightly in morning trading on February 4, 2015, tracking overnight gains in US stocks. The Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.14%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.33%. These gains followed a period of market volatility, with the US and EU focusing on trade talks and tariff threats.

site_title: Japan wages show sign of pickup in welcome news for Abe
summary: Japan's wage earners experienced a 2.6% increase in special payments, including bonuses, and a 1.6% growth in total cash earnings in December, marking the 10th consecutive month of gains. Real wages adjusted for inflation fell 1.4% year-on-year, but the decline slowed from the prior month. The positive signs are seen as a welcome news for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's plans to boost wages and consumption, helping to reflate the economy. However, many companies remain cautious about increasing base salaries, with some expecting similar wage hikes to last year.

site_title: Uber proposes new registration system for South Korea drivers
summary: Uber Technologies Inc. has proposed a new registration system for its drivers in South Korea, aiming to overcome a ban on connecting passengers to private cars. The system would provide legal commercial licenses for registered drivers, subject to minimum experience training and background checks. This move is seen as an attempt to work with lawmakers to find a way for Uber's services to operate legally in South Korea. The proposal follows a ban on Uber's services in the country, which has been in place since 2015.

site_title: Sim Lian buys Perth office complex for A$72.8m
summary: Property developer Sim Lian has acquired an office complex in Perth, Australia for A$72.8 million. The complex, located in Victoria Park, features two office buildings and ground floor retail units, with a total lettable area of 12,813 square meters. The acquisition is funded through internal funds and bank borrowings, with no expected impact on Sim Lian's earnings or net tangible assets. The property is situated near the Perth CBD and offers direct access to public transportation.

site_title: Shell, USW resume talks amid biggest oil strike in 35 years
summary: Royal Dutch Shell and the United Steelworkers (USW) resumed talks on a three-year labor contract amid the biggest US oil strike in 35 years. The strike, which began on Sunday, affects 200 refineries, terminals, and chemical plants, accounting for 10% of US refinery capacity. The USW has rejected five offers made by Shell, seeking better healthcare benefits and measures to prevent worker fatigue. The strike threatens to disrupt up to 64% of US fuel output, with nine sites currently on strike.

images.alt_text: Royal Dutch Shell Plc and United Steelworkers leaders met on Tuesday to discuss a new three-year labour contract as US oil workers extended the biggest refinery strike since 1980 into a third day.

site_title: Asean must be bold in developing post-2015 vision: Lim Hng Kiang
summary: ASEAN Minister Lim Hng Kiang emphasized the need for the region to be bold and ahead of the curve in developing its post-2015 vision. This will enhance Asean's centrality in regional and global architectures. Singapore and the Philippines are working closely on regional initiatives such as RCEP and Apec.

site_title: Yahoo to spin off Small Business unit with Alibaba stake
summary: Yahoo to spin off its Small Business unit as part of a tax-free spinoff of its 15% stake in Alibaba Group Holding Ltd, valued at approximately $40 billion. The unit will be transferred to a new entity called SpinCo before the transaction is completed in Q4 2015. Yahoo Small Business will continue to operate and invest in its platform and services.

site_title: Dollar slides as euro joins rally in commodity currencies
summary: The US dollar slid 0.9% against a basket of currencies, its largest one-day fall in over a year, as investors cut long positions in the greenback. The euro surged to a 3-month high, while commodity currencies like oil, copper, and the Australian, Canadian, and British pounds also rose. The euro's gain was attributed to optimism over a potential new debt deal in Greece, but traders believe it may be more about positioning than a change in fundamentals.

site_title: Russia to spend US$7.9b from wealth fund on infrastructure projects: minister
summary: Russia's economy minister, Alexei Ulyukayev, announced plans to spend 525 billion roubles (approximately $10.63 billion) from the state's National Wealth Fund on infrastructure projects, including a liquefied natural gas production facility. This funding will not be used for the government's anti-crisis spending programme. The move aims to support the country's infrastructure development.

site_title: China retailers play poker in empty malls as shoppers go online
summary: China's retail industry is struggling as consumers increasingly turn to online shopping, with many brick-and-mortar stores shutting down or shifting to IT services. The rise of e-commerce giants like Alibaba and JD.com has boosted productivity and could create 46 million new jobs, but it also threatens traditional roles, with an estimated 31 million jobs at risk. The shift online could contribute up to 22% of China's productivity growth by 2025, translating to $3 trillion in annual GDP. As the economy adapts, some experts warn of a "credibility crisis" for e-commerce platforms and the potential for clashes between old and new economies.

site_title: Aspial-Fragrance bid for LCD Global turns unconditional
summary: Aspial-Fragrance's joint-venture firm AF Global has made an unconditional bid for LCD Global Investments, acquiring 59.6% of the company's shares with an offer of S$0.33 per share. The bid aims to wrest control from JTrust Asia, the firm's largest shareholder. The offer will remain open until March 12.

images.alt_text: Potential buyers at the launch of Australia 108, a freehold condo by Aspial Corp unit World Class Land touted to be Melbourne's tallest building.The bid by AF Global, a joint-venture firm of Aspial Corporation and Fragrance Group, for hospitality and property development player LCD Global Investments has turned unconditional.

site_title: China Jan HSBC services PMI at 6-mth low, more stimulus expected
summary: China's services sector grew at its slowest pace in six months in January, with the HSBC/Markit Services PMI at 51.8, down from 53.4 in December. This raised expectations for policymakers to unveil more stimulus measures to avert a sharper slowdown in the economy. The services sector has cushioned the broader impact of a cooling manufacturing sector, but its weakening performance could fan market concerns about China's economic slowdown in 2015.

site_title: Oil market rebounds on demand prospects
summary: World oil prices rose sharply on Tuesday, with European benchmark Brent North Sea crude gaining $1.40 to $56.15 a barrel, and US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rising $1.53 to $51.10 a barrel. The price rebound is attributed to hopes of a rebound in global energy demand, particularly in the first half of 2015. Analysts note, however, that the current price rebound may not be sustained due to the ongoing global supply glut.

site_title: IMF lowers Thai growth forecast to 3.5% for 2015
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) lowered its forecast for Thailand's economic growth to 3.5% in 2015, and 0.5% in 2014, due to concerns over political stability, weak export demand, and slow consumption. The military government's efforts to revive growth since seizing power in May have been unsuccessful, and the forecast is below the central bank's expectation of 4.0% growth this year. This marks a downward revision from the IMF's previous forecast of 1.0% growth in 2014 and 4.6% growth in 2015.

site_title: Stocks to watch: LCD Global, OSIM, SIA Engineering, Eu Yan Sang
summary: Several Singapore stocks made announcements on Tuesday and Wednesday that could impact trading on Wednesday. LCD Global Investments accepted a bid from AF Global to acquire the company for S$0.33 per share. OSIM reported weaker fourth-quarter results but a strong full-year performance. SIA Engineering Co reported a 23.5% drop in third-quarter net profit due to lower profits from associated companies. Eu Yan Sang's second-quarter net profit dropped 38% due to a slowdown in Chinese tourist spending.

site_title: New Singapore activist hedge fund seeks to shake up companies
summary: Roland Thng, CEO of Dektos Investment Corp, has established EVA Capital SP, a new hedge fund focused on influencing Singapore's locally listed companies. The fund aims to pressure small- and medium-sized construction and engineering companies to improve performance by buying stakes and pushing for special dividends or share buybacks. Thng's approach is seen as unconventional in Singapore's corporate landscape, where controlling shareholders often resist demands from activist investors. If successful, EVA Capital plans to raise its fund to US$30 million and invest in more industries.

site_title: Credit Suisse exits US retail market making business
summary: Credit Suisse Group is exiting the US retail market making business by the end of Q1 2015 due to failing to gain enough scale. This decision does not affect the bank's retail execution services operations, including its Crossfinder platform. Credit Suisse cited a need to create efficiencies for its franchise and clients, while also acknowledging its commitment to providing top-tier offerings. The move follows the bank's ongoing review of its investment banking business.

site_title: US auto sales jump in January
summary: Major US automakers reported significant gains in January sales, driven by an improving economy, low fuel prices, and favorable financing conditions. General Motors posted an 18% increase in US sales, while Ford Motor rose 15%. FCA US, Toyota Motors, and others also saw notable gains. The improving labor market, low fuel costs, and the success of new models, such as the Ford F-150 and Toyota Corolla, contributed to the surge in demand. Industry analysts praised the results, citing "unusually favorable" financing conditions and robust demand for trucks and crossovers.

site_title: Greece cheers market with debt restructuring plan
summary: Greece unveiled a debt restructuring plan, boosting stock markets with hopes for a deal with European Union partners. Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi expressed support for a deal, while Greek counterpart Alexis Tsipras called for more growth-oriented policies. The proposals will be discussed by EU leaders next week, with Renzi promising to steer clear of detail. The move aims to ease economic pressure and put social cohesion and growth before policies of poverty and insecurity.

site_title: New arrest in US Navy bribery scandal
summary: A former US Navy officer, Paul Simpkins, 60, was arrested and charged with conspiracy to commit bribery for allegedly steering Navy contracts to defense contractor Glenn Defence Marine Asia (GDMA) between 2006-2012. Simpkins accepted hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes, travel expenses, and prostitutes in exchange for the favors. Seven individuals, including GDMA's "Fat Leonard" Leonard Francis, have pleaded guilty to the scheme. US prosecutors seek Simpkins' transfer to southern California to face justice.

images.alt_text: A former top US Navy officer was arrested on Tuesday over a bribery scandal centered on a Singapore-based contracting firm, in which seven people have already pleaded guilty, officials said.

site_title: US: Wall St posts 2nd day of strong gains, led by energy
summary: US stocks rose 1% on Tuesday, led by energy shares as oil prices rallied. Higher-than-expected January car sales also boosted the advance. The S&P 500 gained 2.8% over two sessions, with merger activity contributing to the gains. The index has been trading in a range since mid-December.

site_title: Regulatory loophole, weak prices spur Indonesia palm oil takeovers
summary: Indonesia's top palm oil producers are exploiting a regulatory loophole to expand their oil palm acreage. A 2013 law limits companies to 100,000 hectares, but exempts listed companies majority owned by the public. Nine listed companies have a market value of less than $1 billion, making them takeover targets. Smaller producers are selling out due to weak demand and prices, creating opportunities for larger agri-conglomerates. Malaysian firm Sime Darby Bhd and Singapore-listed Wilmar International Ltd are seeking to expand in Indonesia and Africa, while others plan to invest in Brazil or Europe.

site_title: US factory orders down for 5th straight month in Dec
summary: US factory orders declined 3.4% in December for the fifth consecutive month, with demand falling across various industries. Despite this, business spending plans showed a smaller drop, supporting a rebound in the months ahead. Manufacturing is slowing due to weak global demand, falling crude oil prices, and shipment delays from the West Coast ports labor dispute. Factory activity and business investment are expected to continue slowing, with cautious optimism that domestic demand will limit the slowdown.

site_title: DBS to nudge more customers online with revamped website
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest retail bank, has launched a revamped Internet banking interface to encourage customers to complete simple transactions online, freeing up branches for investment sales. The new interface will screen users' frequent transactions to offer targeted advertising and relevant promotions. This move aims to comply with stricter rules on consumer data usage for marketing purposes, similar to Amazon's approach. The bank hopes to increase online transactions and create new revenue streams.

site_title: Apple bond sales fuel speculation US rates poised to rise
summary: Apple's $6.5 billion bond sale has fueled speculation that US interest rates are poised to rise. Following a record low in benchmark Treasury yields, experts believe the Federal Reserve may raise rates in the middle of this year. The sale comes after a 2.9% increase in Treasuries in January, driven by sliding oil prices and Greek uncertainty. While some predict a 62% chance of a rate hike by December, others caution that the overall interest-rate environment won't be high, and corporate yields may remain low.

site_title: Obama's budget could be a missed opportunity
summary: US President Barack Obama's new federal budget increases outlays by 6.4% annually over a decade, requiring tax revenue to grow at 7.2% annually to control borrowing. The budget includes proposals such as a tax on big banks and multinationals, but these are unlikely to pass due to Republican opposition. The budget also includes new expenditures of $1 trillion over a decade, making it a "missed opportunity" for deficit reduction, as the economy can handle lower spending. The White House's half-hearted deficit reduction plan may not be enough to address long-term demographic trends.

site_title: StanChart (S) completes 50m yuan loan transaction linked to Tianjin Eco-City
summary: Standard Chartered Bank has completed a 50 million yuan (S$10.8 million) cross-border loan to Tianjin Eco-City Keppel New Energy Development Co Ltd in Tianjin, China, marking the first foreign lender to do so. This transaction is part of China's efforts to promote the internationalization of the renminbi currency. The deal is expected to widen cross-border RMB transactions between China and Singapore, contributing to the growth of Singapore's offshore RMB market.

site_title: Uber's biggest rival? Its investor, Google
summary: Google, a significant investor in Uber, is reportedly preparing to launch its own ride-hailing service, potentially rivaling Uber's operations. Google's venture capital arm invested $258 million in Uber in 2013, with Google's chief legal officer, David Drummond, joining the Uber board. Uber's dependence on Google's mapping application, Google Maps, is a concern, as Google is developing its own driverless car technology. Uber's CEO, Travis Kalanick, has discussed the inevitability of autonomous taxis, but the company may struggle to compete with Google's resources and technological advancements.

site_title: European Central Bank wary of Greek bailout plan: Financial Times
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is unwilling to approve Greece's proposal to sell short-term Treasury bills worth 10 billion euros to tide over the debt-ridden country. The ECB "will play hardball" on raising a 15 billion euros ceiling, which is essential for the Greek bailout plan. Without financing, Greece will exit the program, potentially running out of cash within weeks, and may exit the euro zone, sparking concerns about the country's future in the currency.

site_title: Forces of opportunity and failure at play amid oil bust
summary: The US oil industry is facing a potential bust, with many companies struggling to pay off debts due to plummeting oil prices. Resolute Energy, a Colorado-based company, is among those in financial trouble, having borrowed hundreds of millions of dollars to invest in horizontal drilling. The company's stock has plummeted, and its credit line has been slashed, forcing it to take on a high-interest loan from a hedge fund. As the industry tightens its belt, Wall Street's bottom feeders are sniffing out distressed debt opportunities, with investors like the Carlyle Group and Blackstone Group raising billions to invest in energy assets.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close higher
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed higher on Tuesday, driven by rising world oil prices and easing tensions over Greece. London's FTSE 100 rose 1.32%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 climbed 0.58%, and Paris's CAC 40 rose 1.09%. The gains followed a relaxing of tensions over Greece, contributing to a positive market sentiment.

site_title: GT Land plans US$500m IPO
summary: GT Land Holdings, a commercial developer in southern China, plans to raise approximately US$500 million through an initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong. The company aims to complete the sale by the end of this year. The IPO comes amid government probes into dealings with local officials at other southern Chinese developers, which have led to project sales halts and investigations. Bank of America Corp and Macquarie Group are working on the IPO, with GT Land seeking funds after facing similar issues.

site_title: Euro jumps as possible Greek deal takes shape
summary: The euro surged 1.6% to $1.1512 as Greece dropped calls for radical debt restructuring and sought longer payment terms to give its government more budget resources. However, the European Central Bank objected to Athens' plan to issue $11.5 billion in short-term debt to cover financial gaps. The euro slipped back to $1.1479 after the objection. The possible deal on Greece's finances is seen as a positive development for the euro, but the objection from the ECB has raised concerns about the plan's viability.

site_title: Dalai Lama meeting irritates Beijing during upswing in US-China relations
summary: US President Barack Obama is set to meet the Dalai Lama at the National Prayer Breakfast on Thursday, despite potential anger from Beijing. The meeting comes amid a relatively positive upswing in US-China relations, marked by recent commercial agreements and a landmark climate change agreement. Despite some irritants, including China's growing military presence and nationalist Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's re-election in Japan, both Washington and Beijing appear to be committed to managing tensions and cooperating on issues like climate change. The short-term outlook for China-US relations is relatively positive, but significant downside risks remain.

site_title: BOJ in bind as oil slump makes for slippery price goal
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is struggling to achieve its 2% inflation target due to tumbling oil prices, which has led to a shift in its goalposts. Nearly two years into its stimulus experiment, the BOJ has qualified its inflation goals, making it more challenging to meet the target. The central bank has been adding complexity to its communication strategy, citing a broader range of price indicators, including those excluding energy costs. This move may be seen as an attempt to justify holding pat on monetary easing despite inflation grinding to a halt in the coming months.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan is caught in a bind, nearly two years into its stimulus experiment, as it further qualifies its inflation goals in response to tumbling oil prices, a move that could prove self-defeating by tempering price expectations.

site_title: Russia considers further easing of rules on risk to take heat off banks
summary: Russia's central bank is considering further relaxing regulations on banks to ease pressure from Western sanctions and an economic slowdown. The move aims to alleviate the burden on banks, particularly those calculating risks associated with high-interest consumer loans. This would temporarily relax rules affecting these loans, but the specifics and timeline for implementation have not been announced.

site_title: Dubai aims to be top airport by retail sales with help from China travellers
summary: Dubai International Airport is aiming to become the world's top hub for retail sales by 2015, driven by a surge in Chinese passengers. Spending at the airport is expected to reach $2.1 billion, up from $1.9 billion last year, with Chinese travelers contributing 13% of duty-free revenue in 2014. Dubai is vying with Incheon International Airport in South Korea, which had $2.56 billion in sales last year. The airport's retail revenue is expected to surpass $48 per passenger, with a focus on luxury goods such as perfume, gold, and electronics.

site_title: Having happy employees makes business sense
summary: Irish corporate law firm William Fry is implementing a nine-month program to help its partners identify what they enjoy and excel at, aiming to increase engagement and motivation. This follows increased competition for talented staff, technological changes, and the influx of Millennials into the workforce. The program, developed by Potentialife, focuses on the things partners are good at and emphasizes their impact, rather than eliminating weaknesses. Companies with highly engaged employees tend to outperform in stock returns and sales growth, with 20% of the workforce having a significant impact on outcomes.

site_title: NZ house price growth picks up for first time since Dec 2013
summary: New Zealand's house prices saw a 5.7% annual growth in January, the first increase since December 2013, driven by a shortage of properties for sale in the Auckland region. The value of new housing developments also rose due to higher demand. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has warned that the housing market is heating up, particularly in Auckland, and may see interest rate changes in the future. This growth contrasts with restrictions on low deposit lending and concerns about affordability for first-time buyers.

site_title: KL pushing UN to make it mandatory to report conflict zone air risk
summary: Malaysia is urging the United Nations to make reporting risks to airlines over conflict zones mandatory. The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has proposed a central website for public warnings, but data provision is not mandatory. The proposal comes after two commercial air disasters in Malaysia last year, including the shooting down of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 over Ukraine, killing 298 people. The US and Netherlands support the ICAO proposal, with the Netherlands calling for swift action to ensure flying is associated with freedom and safety.

site_title: Firms fret as Vietnam drops digit to meet rising mobile phone demand
summary: Vietnam is set to introduce a standardized phone-numbering plan on March 1, but businesses are concerned about the high costs associated with updating phone numbers on various materials. The government's decision could lead to significant expenses for companies, including taxi signs, business cards, and letterheads. Executives, such as Nguyen Kim Khanh of Taxi Group, are worried about the financial burden and potential long-term consequences of the change.

site_title: Alibaba's new partner to lend to US buyers of Chinese goods
summary: Alibaba has partnered with LendingClub Corp to offer financing to US businesses looking to buy from Chinese suppliers. The service will provide loans of up to $300,000 at rates of 0.5-2.4% and is expected to aid smaller businesses and merchants. This move aims to expand Alibaba's US footprint by connecting American sellers with affluent Chinese buyers, with plans to expand to other major markets. LendingClub will be the main source of US buyer financing on Alibaba.com, reducing credit costs for US buyers.

site_title: RBA cuts interest rates to record low in unexpected move
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) unexpectedly cut its benchmark interest rate to a record low of 2.25% in a surprise move on February 3, 2015. The move was attributed to weaker-than-expected growth and a higher-than-expected jobless rate. The decision was seen as a response to the global economic slowdown and the decline in commodity prices, particularly iron ore. The Australian dollar also fell to its lowest level in over 5 years, and stocks surged to an almost seven-year high.

images.alt_text: Mr Stevens said "a lower exchange rate is likely to be needed to achieve balanced growth in the economy".

site_title: Sharp feels heat from Chinese, Korean competition
summary: Sharp Corporation forecasts a group net loss of 30 billion yen for FY2014, marking its third annual loss in four years, due to increased competition from Chinese and Korean electronics giants. The company's sales are expected to fall 0.9% to 2.9 trillion yen. Sharp's struggles in TV operations and solar panels have been exacerbated by price competition and the depreciation of the yen. The company may drop its current business plan and implement additional job cuts as it seeks to create a new medium-term strategy.

site_title: China market still drawing bearish views
summary: China's stock market experienced a brief respite on Tuesday, but Bank of America strategist David Cui remains bearish, citing bad debt woes, profit-taking, and regulatory policies to control leverage. Cui predicts the market will decline in the next couple of months, as the government's efforts to control leverage will hinder a sharp market rally. He also warns that China's debt problems are looming, and the government's response to these issues will be crucial in determining the market's trajectory.

site_title: Greek finance minister ruffles a few feathers
summary: Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis has made a tumultuous start to his role, sparking market volatility with his critical stance towards the country's international creditors. Varoufakis has described the bailout deal as "fiscal waterboarding" and called for a European debt conference, which has been met with resistance from EU leaders. The Greek stock and bond markets have tanked, and Varoufakis's fiery rhetoric has raised concerns about his ability to negotiate a better deal. However, some of his supporters argue that his intellectual intensity and game theory expertise will serve him well in negotiations, and that his goal is to establish Syriza's anti-austerity credentials.

site_title: Another top China banker under investigation
summary: Bank of Beijing Co Ltd board director Lu Haijun is under investigation for serious disciplinary violations, the latest high-ranking banker to fall under scrutiny as China's anti-corruption drive expands to the finance sector. This comes after China Minsheng Banking Corp's president Mao Xiaofeng resigned following an investigation. Chinese President Xi Jinping has vowed to tackle corruption, warning it threatens the Communist Party's legitimacy. Investigations have targeted powerful figures, including former domestic security chief Zhou Yongkang and Ling Jihua, a former aide to Hu Jintao.

site_title: Facebook, Twitter lock horns in US Super Bowl battle of statistics
summary: Facebook and Twitter engaged in a social media battle to claim the title of most-popular platform for Super Bowl viewers, with Facebook boasting 65 million users discussing the game and 676,000 people per minute commenting on a key play, while Twitter reported 28.4 million game-related tweets. The competition highlights the growing importance of social media in big events and brand advertising, with companies like Pepsi and Snickers promoting their ads on both platforms.

site_title: More sells than buys in Singapore stocks
summary: In the Singapore stock market, global mutual funds sold stocks more than they bought in the three months to Jan 28, with S$1.09 billion in net sells compared to S$1.02 billion in buys. Industrials stocks excluding transportation were the sector of focus, with S$74 million in net sells versus S$11.7 million in buys. The top selling stock was Singapore Technologies Engineering, while Boustead Singapore was the top buying stock.

site_title: If trading bonds is tough, think about the pain when rates rise
summary: US Treasuries market faces challenges due to decreased depth, resulting in greater volatility. The market's ability to handle large trades without significant price movements has diminished, with JPMorgan estimating a 70% decline in the amount of 10-year notes available for trade in the past year. This decrease in liquidity has raised concerns about the potential for disruptions, particularly as the US Federal Reserve prepares to raise interest rates, which could elevate the US's cost to borrow.

site_title: Exxon slashes share buybacks to 14-year low
summary: Exxon Mobil reduced its share buybacks to a 14-year low of $1 billion for the current quarter, citing declining production and tumbling crude prices. The company's US refineries lost $1 million and cash flow tumbled 36% due to a 3.8% drop in oil and gas production. Despite this, Exxon's dividend payout remains intact at 9.5% increase. The company's net income fell to $6.57 billion, a 22 cents per share below analysts' estimates. Exxon joins other oil majors in scaling back measures to prop up share prices amid a global supply glut.

site_title: SGX off to strong start with surge in January trading value
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 17% increase in January trading value to S$25.3 billion, up 12% year-on-year. The surge was driven by a Keppel Corporation bid to take its property subsidiary private and the introduction of the 100-share board lot. This led to increased retail participation in Straits Times Index stocks.

site_title: RBI holds rates steady, boosts banks' liquidity
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) held interest rates steady at 7.75% on February 3, 2015, while boosting banks' liquidity to encourage them to lower lending rates. The RBI cut the statutory liquidity ratio by 50 basis points to 21.5% to prod banks to lend more. The central bank aims to persuade banks to pass on the benefits of the last rate cut, which was not fully passed on by banks. The RBI governor, Raghuram Rajan, expressed hope that banks will cut base lending rates, citing weak credit growth and the need for banks to become more competitive.

site_title: PBC mulling over policy options to deal with capital flows
summary: China's central bank is considering policy options to address volatile capital flows, including widening the yuan's trading band and guiding the exchange rate lower. The move aims to deter speculative gains and outflows, which have contributed to the country's biggest capital deficit since 1998. Experts suggest a gradual weakening of the fixing and widening the trading band could boost exports and make it more expensive for capital to leave. The decision comes as China's economic growth slows and the yuan reaches a record high against the euro.

site_title: FCC expected to propose regulating the Internet as a utility
summary: The FCC is expected to propose regulating the Internet as a utility, which would give the commission strong legal authority to ensure Net neutrality and prevent content blocking and pay-to-play fast lanes. Chairman Tom Wheeler is expected to advocate a light-touch approach, avoiding intrusive aspects of utility-style regulation. The proposal, expected to be submitted Thursday, is a response to President Barack Obama's call for the strongest possible Net neutrality rules, and will be voted on by the full commission on February 26.

site_title: Boost seen for S-Reits but not property developers
summary: Singapore's Budget 2015 is expected to bring mixed news for the country's property sector. Real estate investment trusts (Reits) are likely to see their tax incentives extended, with most likely renewals for tax exemptions and reduced withholding tax for foreign investors. In contrast, property developers are unlikely to see significant easing of cooling measures, with consultants expecting the status quo to continue unless developers can demonstrate significant price drops or propose alternative measures to boost sales activity.

site_title: Nielsen partners EDB to set up Asian innovation hub in Singapore
summary: Nielsen partners the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) to launch the Asia Innovation Centre in Singapore, investing S$14 million over five years. The centre, modeled after Nielsen's US-based Innovation Lab, will hire 30 employees and collaborate with universities, startups, and businesses to drive innovation and address evolving information needs in Asia. The partnership aims to leverage Singapore's startup ecosystem to find solutions for clients and create startups to address market needs. The centre will focus on providing insights into Asian consumer behavior and lifestyles.

site_title: Jack Ma beating China is hollow win for Alibaba
summary: Alibaba founder Jack Ma has successfully defied China's criticism over selling fake products on its e-commerce site, marking a rare victory for the private business. However, Ma's success is short-lived as China's economic slowdown poses significant risks to Alibaba's future. The company faces challenges from a declining manufacturing sector, a slowing economy, and unpredictable regulatory policies under President Xi Jinping's leadership, which could impact Alibaba's growth and profits. Ma's future success relies on navigating these risks and maintaining his company's position as a key driver of China's consumer-driven economy.

site_title: FSB's too-big-to-fail fix may hinder global growth
summary: The Financial Stability Board's proposed "too-big-to-fail" fix may hinder global economic growth, according to the Institute of International Finance and the Global Financial Markets Association. The FSB's plan requires banks to issue securities equivalent to 20% of their assets to ensure investors, not taxpayers, foot the bill for financial failure. Industry groups recommend limiting the requirement to 16% of risk-weighted assets to avoid raising bank funding costs and affecting real-economy financing. The FSB will conduct impact studies before finalizing the rule, which is set to be completed by the 2015 G20 nations summit.

site_title: New awards unveiled to recognise firms with responsible practices
summary: The Singapore Apex CSR Awards have been unveiled to recognize firms with responsible practices. Organized by the Singapore Compact for Corporate Social Responsibility, the awards aim to showcase the highest level of CSR excellence in Singapore. The awards will be co-presented by the Singapore Business Federation and The Business Times, with support from the Ministry of the Environment and Water Resources. Companies can submit entries in two categories: large companies with revenue over S$300 million and small and mid-sized companies. The closing date for submission is March 27, 2015.

site_title: Jack Ma defends Alibaba amid criticism about fake products
summary: Alibaba founder Jack Ma defended his company against criticism over fake products on its platform, stating he wants to be seen as transparent and not a hub for counterfeit goods. The State Administration for Industry & Commerce (SAIC) accused Alibaba of allowing "illegal operations" on its websites, but Ma said the company is listening to regulators and pushing for change. Alibaba has sent 400 people to jail for selling fake products, and Ma met with SAIC director Zhang Mao, potentially signaling a de-escalation of the dispute.

site_title: European shares rally as Greece drops calls for debt write-off
summary: European shares rose as Greece dropped calls for a debt write-off, with the eurozone government bond yields tumbling. The Greek government, led by Syriza, proposed swapping debt for new growth-linked bonds, sparing privately held bonds from losses. This move may shift attention to Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras's desire to increase spending and roll back austerity, potentially leading to further conflict with euro-area leaders.

site_title: US retail brokers plan to give clients more information about execution of trades
summary: US retail brokers plan to disclose more information about trade execution to combat claims of failing to get the best possible prices for customers. The move aims to ease concerns about conflicts of interest resulting from payments from market makers, which may encourage brokers to prioritize higher-paying market makers over lower-priced ones. The brokers, including TD Ameritrade, Charles Schwab, and Fidelity Investments, will provide detailed reports on average savings and order execution speeds, in an effort to reassure regulators and investors.

site_title: A$23,100 McDonald's 'special sauce' - for charity
summary: McDonald's is auctioning a 500ml bottle of their "Limited Edition Big Mac Special Sauce" on eBay for at least A$23,100, with proceeds going to charities helping sick children and their families. The auction is one of only 200 bottles available, and the sale is expected to benefit a good cause.

site_title: SIA Engineering's Q3 profit falls 23.5%
summary: SIA Engineering Co reported a 23.5% decline in net profit to S$46.3 million for Q3 2014, down from S$60.5 million in the same period a year earlier. Revenue fell to S$265.3 million, driven by lower airframe and component overhaul revenue. Operating profit was S$24.3 million, 3.6% lower, and shares closed at S$4.32. The company attributed the decline to decreased engine shop visits and contributions from joint-venture companies. Despite a lower expenditure of 6.8% year-on-year, the company warned that the operating environment remains challenging.

site_title: Heady days for tech sector 15 years after bubble burst
summary: The tech sector is experiencing a resurgence 15 years after the dotcom bubble burst, with record-breaking merger and acquisition deals worth $237.6 billion in 2014. The number of deals has increased, with 3,512 mergers and acquisitions, and startups like Uber and Snapchat have seen their values soar with new capital inflows. Analysts attribute the trend to the growing demand for mobile tech, security, and cloud computing, and the increased valuations of companies like Apple and Alibaba. However, some experts question whether the high valuations are justified, citing concerns about speculation and inflated valuations.

site_title: Sakae venturing into asset management
summary: Sakae Holdings, the owner of Sakae Sushi, has announced its entry into asset management with a S$250 million fund to invest in public and private opportunities. This marks a "natural progression" from its corporate advisory business, which counts Q&M Dental as its first client. Sakae aims to reinforce partnerships with stakeholders, benefit invested companies, and promote investors' goals. The company will recruit experienced individuals in financial regulations and investing to boost expertise.

site_title: No surprises as STI weakens 15 points
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 15.33 points on Tuesday to 3,408.02, reversing Monday's 32-point rise. The decline was attributed to short-covering and not 'real' demand, with the same stocks responsible for the Monday gain also contributing to the pullback. The index's performance remains closely tied to the US market, and dealers expect a continued correlation. Meanwhile, Keppel Corp's plan to privatize its property arm is expected to have a positive impact on the company's earnings, with Daiwa initiating a "hold" rating and a 12-month target price of S$8.55.

site_title: Famed Tokyo hotel to be torn down this summer
summary: The iconic Hotel Okura in Tokyo, a renowned landmark for its modernist design and rich history, will be demolished this summer. The main wing, home to the iconic lobby and meeting places, will be torn down to make way for a $1 billion, 3.5-year construction project, featuring two glass towers for a five-star and six-star hotel. The hotel has hosted numerous US presidents, celebrities, and has played a significant role in Japan's modernization, but its facilities are now outdated and non-compliant with modern earthquake regulations. Design enthusiasts have mounted campaigns to preserve the hotel's legacy.

site_title: Construction sector seeks manpower policy tweaks
summary: The construction sector in Singapore is seeking policy tweaks to help manage manpower costs amid a limited foreign workforce and productivity boost. The Singapore Contractors Association Ltd (SCAL) proposes allowing companies to use foreign worker levies for worker training and upgrading, as well as gratuities for long-service workers. SCAL also requests extending employment periods for skilled workers and returning unused man-year entitlements to employers. These changes aim to retain trained workers and save time and resources for companies.

site_title: Shimao reopens bond market for junk-rated companies
summary: Shimao Properties, the first Chinese property developer, launched a high-yield bond with a US$6 billion order book within hours. The seven-year bond's indicated yield of about 8.5% is 100 basis points higher than expected, suggesting significantly higher funding costs for the sector. This move comes after problems at Kaisa Group, which rocked the sector.

site_title: Asia to drive global gas demand in next 15 yrs: Gazprom
summary: Gazprom predicts that Asia will drive global gas demand, maintaining its share of 23-24% over the next 15 years. Meanwhile, oil and coal demand will decline, falling to 28% and 26% respectively by 2030. This shift is attributed to rising renewable and nuclear power generation, as well as improved energy efficiency. Gazprom expects Asia's gas demand to rise from 20% to 25% by 2030, driven by growth in liquefied natural gas (LNG) trade, with China being a key market.

site_title: Ezion's November perpetuals get tax exemption for dividends
summary: Ezion Holding's November perpetual securities have received tax exemption for dividends, following the QDS and QDS Plus schemes introduced to promote Singapore's debt market. The schemes require substantial arrangement by financial institutions in Singapore. This is the second time Ezion's perpetual bonds have received QDS status, following the September 2012 issue.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singtel's stock is expected to weaken due to the Monetary Authority of Singapore's policy band reduction. Despite this, the company's diversified exposure to overseas markets and strong dividend yield make it an attractive investment. UOB Kay Hian Research reduced their earnings forecast for FY15 and FY16 due to recent forex rate fluctuations. Micro-Mechanics saw a 20% year-on-year jump in H1 FY15 sales, driven by volume growth, and has a strong balance sheet and dividend payout history.

site_title: PM Lee, Merkel keen to get S'pore-EU FTA going
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and German Chancellor Angela Merkel expressed desire for the EU-Singapore free trade pact to be implemented as soon as possible, despite "outstanding issues" hindering its progress. The agreement, concluded in negotiations, aims to liberalize services, investment, and procurement markets, and remove tariff and non-tariff barriers to trade. However, the pact's implementation is uncertain due to the need for ratification by the European Parliament and majority of EU member states, as well as potential challenges from the European Commission's competence to negotiate FTAs.

site_title: Japan, US eye penalty system in TPP
summary: Japan and the US are nearing an agreement on a penalty system for the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) free trade agreement. If either country fails to implement automobile trade accords, they can raise tariffs on specific categories, such as cars and farm products. The US aims to abolish tariffs on Japanese cars, while Japan is seeking to raise tariffs on American farm products. The two countries will focus on the penalty system's specifics, including the length of time the penalties will be enforced. This agreement is crucial for the TPP agreement's effectiveness.

site_title: KL's current account surplus seen falling on LNG slump
summary: Malaysia's current account surplus is expected to narrow due to a potential 50% decline in liquefied natural gas prices by mid-year. This decline, according to Bank of America Merrill Lynch, would reduce the surplus by 2.5-3% of GDP, adding pressure to the nation's weakening economic outlook. The decline in LNG prices, combined with a weaker currency, has already led to a 11% drop in the Malaysian currency against the US dollar in the past six months. The nation's budget gap is forecast to be 3.2% of GDP, exceeding an earlier target of 3%.

site_title: Environment tougher but look at OSIM's full-year results: Ron Sim
summary: OSIM International reported a 7% increase in full-year revenue to S$691.1 million, with net profit rising 0.6% to S$102.2 million. The company's core massage chair market experienced a slight softening in the fourth quarter, while subsidiary TWG Tea continued to grow at a double-digit pace. Despite a 0.5% dip in fourth-quarter revenue, OSIM remains cash-rich and has increased operating cash flow. The company's CEO, Ron Sim, emphasized the importance of taking a full-year perspective and targets double-digit growth for 2015.

site_title: Modi to tap US$19b hoard in India's state companies
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is urging state-controlled companies to spend their US$19 billion cash reserves to boost the economy. The government has asked these companies to invest in major projects such as mines and power plants. Five state companies, including Coal India and Oil & Natural Gas Corp, are sitting on this large amount of cash, which could help increase economic growth. The government aims to increase capital expenditure and is exploring options such as domestic and overseas asset purchases and joint ventures.

site_title: Mobile devices more popular than computers among Singaporeans
summary: A recent Bain & Company study found that mobile devices have surpassed computers as the primary form of digital interaction for consumers in Singapore, with 30% of total interactions between consumers and banks occurring on mobile devices in 2014, compared to 25% on computers. However, lenders are not effectively using mobile banking as a sales tool, particularly for high-margin products, and more than half of customers in Singapore have bought new products from competing banks. This trend is expected to continue, with banks potentially losing customers and profits to digital startups and specialist firms.

site_title: Russia, Ukraine in indirect talks over key air corridor
summary: Russia and Ukraine are holding indirect talks to reopen a key international air corridor over the Black Sea, which could bring much-needed overflight fees and ease congestion on other crowded air routes. The talks, brokered at an ICAO safety meeting in Montreal, focus on adopting new safety standards for global plane tracking and cooperation on flying over conflict zones. The airspace, which was closed last April, could resume flights to the Middle East and Asia, with Ukraine seeking to regain revenue from international carriers.

site_title: Sotheby's to auction five Monets that could fetch a total of £70m
summary: Sotheby's is set to auction five Claude Monet paintings in London, with a combined estimate of up to £70 million, as the Impressionist art market experiences a renewed interest. The sale includes five paintings, including "Le Grand Canal" and "Les Peupliers a Giverny", with top estimates ranging from £20 million to £30 million. The market, which has seen a significant increase in sales in recent years, is driven by emerging collectors from emerging markets and Asian buyers, with Sotheby's estimating £738.5 million of art will be auctioned through next week.

site_title: The humble fish and chips gets makeover in London restaurants
summary: A modern makeover of the classic fish and chips dish is underway in London, with new restaurants serving sustainable, high-protein meals and unique twists such as beer batter and fine wines. Despite the enduring popularity of fast food, fish and chips remains a beloved British staple, with 10,500 shops across the country generating £1.2 billion in annual sales. Many top restaurants, including celebrity hangouts, are now serving fish and chips, often at high prices, and the dish has become an integral part of British culture, with even royalty enjoying it.

site_title: In brief
summary: Eu Yan Sang reported a 38% drop in Q2 net profit to S$1.98 million due to the impact of the Occupy Central movement and a slowdown in Chinese tourists in Hong Kong. JTrust Co accepted a voluntary offer to sell its LCD Global Investments shares, while Soilbuild Construction won a S$26 million HDB contract.

site_title: 2015 good year for returns: Fullerton
summary: Fullerton Fund Management expects 2015 to be a "good" year for returns, with Asia ex-Japan equities projected to deliver around 10% returns. Central banks' lack of clarity on the economic outlook is expected to lead to persistent volatility. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates gradually, while Asian central banks maintain easy monetary policies. Companies in Asia are expected to benefit from lower input costs and improved capital discipline, but valuations are considered fair, and stock-picking skills become more important drivers for returns.

site_title: Two French additions to Michelin's best
summary: Two French restaurants, "La Bouitte" in the French Alps and "Ledoyen" in Paris, have been awarded three Michelin stars in the 2015 edition. "La Bouitte" is run by father-and-son team Rene and Maxime Meilleur, while "Ledoyen" is headed by chef Yannick Alleno. This achievement marks the two restaurants' inclusion in the pantheon of top eateries, solidifying their reputation in the culinary world. The Michelin guide's 2015 edition highlights the exceptional quality of these two French establishments, showcasing their commitment to gastronomic excellence.

site_title: Renault hopes first compact SUV will be popular in China
summary: Renault unveiled its first compact SUV, a crossover vehicle, in Saint-Denis, France, aiming to cater to European and Chinese urban drivers and rival Nissan's Qashqai. The mid-size crossover, set to go on sale later this year, will allow Renault to expand its market share. Renault chief executive Carlos Ghosn described the new vehicle as a "masterpiece" that enriches the company's range.

site_title: SIA to roll out premium economy class from Aug 9
summary: Singapore Airlines will introduce its new premium economy class on August 9, 2015, on selected flights between Singapore and Sydney. The airline is investing US$80 million in the new product, which will feature wider seats, in-seat power, and additional meal choices. The premium economy cabin will have 36 seats on A380s, 28 on Boeing 777s, and 24 on A350s, with priority check-in and 35kg of baggage. Analysts say the introduction of premium economy will help the airline stay competitive in a tough operating environment.

site_title: Divergence to the fore - China and India on new paths
summary: China and India are taking divergent paths in terms of economic reform. China is relying on policy easing to stabilize growth, while India is experiencing the benefits of structural reforms. This divergence is expected to have significant implications for investors, with growth markets like China and South Korea, and unique growth stories like India, emerging as opportunities. However, interest rate sensitivity remains a concern, and investors should be cautious of potential short-term impacts. The introduction of a harmonized Goods & Services Tax in India's budget is also expected to boost economic growth.

site_title: Reit trading more volatile after MAS move on S$
summary: Singapore's central bank eased monetary policy, allowing the Singapore dollar to appreciate at a slower pace against a trade-weighted basket of currencies. This move led to a 40% increase in Reit trading volume and a 1.4% decline in Reit prices from Wednesday to Friday. Analysts attribute the decline to a weaker SGD, which is expected to lessen the appeal of SGD-denominated assets. Reit prices have since rallied, but remain below pre-announcement levels.

site_title: US oil refineries rely on automation amid largest strike since 1980
summary: A strike by the United Steelworkers union at nine US refineries, which accounts for 10% of US refining capacity, is unlikely to significantly impact fuel production. The refineries are highly automated, with computers controlling the flow and temperature of every tank and valve, allowing for minimal disruption. Non-union management and contract workers will be called in to maintain operations, and the union has rejected offers from companies including Exxon Mobil Corp and Chevron Corp. The strike may hurt refiners more than the last major strike in 1980, and oil prices have already fallen amid speculation about the strike's impact.

site_title: RBA's surprise move hits Australian, NZ dollars
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) unexpectedly cut its main interest rate by 25 basis points, weakening the Australian and New Zealand dollars. The Aussie fell 2% to a 6-year low of US$0.7635, while the kiwi dropped 1.5% to US$0.7185. Analysts expect the RBA to cut interest rates further due to concerns about growth, with some predicting a softer tone from New Zealand central bank chief Graeme Wheeler in a speech on Wednesday. The move has also led to a rise in the value of the yen against the dollar.

site_title: Abe faces delicate balancing act in modifying Japan's defence strategy
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's administration is re-examining its security strategy amid the hostage crisis, which ended with the beheading of journalist Kenji Goto by ISIS militants. The crisis highlights Japan's post-war "pacifist" Constitution, which restricts the country's ability to defend its interests and citizens. Abe's administration must balance Japan's desire to defend itself without setting off a path of further confrontation. The international community has condemned the act, and Japan must navigate this delicate situation to ensure its security without escalating tensions.

site_title: Swiss property risks still elevated amid loose central bank policy
summary: Swiss real estate risks remain elevated due to the central bank's loose policy, according to the UBS Swiss Real Estate Bubble Index. The index fell slightly to 1.28 points in the fourth quarter, but 17 regions are still considered particularly risky. The Swiss National Bank's expansive monetary policy has driven down mortgage costs, leading to strong residential property price increases. To mitigate a potential crisis, the government has required banks to build up capital reserves.

site_title: Piracy still a bane to shipping
summary: Pirate attacks on ships remain a significant concern in 2014, with 245 incidents worldwide, a 44% drop since 2011. Somali pirates were responsible for 11 attacks, all of which failed. However, attacks in South-east Asia increased, with 21 vessels hijacked, 13 fired upon, and 442 crew members taken hostage. Armed gangs also targeted small tankers in the region for cargo theft. The International Maritime Bureau (IMB) commended efforts by regional authorities to combat piracy, but warned that the threat has not been eliminated, and that violent hijackings could become more common if left unchecked.

site_title: Airline industry can't agree on aircraft tracking solution
summary: The airline industry remains divided over implementing an aircraft tracking solution, nearly a year after Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 vanished. Regulators, safety advocates, and airlines disagree on the best approach, despite the potential to locate crashed planes using existing technology. Industry stakeholders are still working to reach a consensus on the implementation and costs of such a system.

images.alt_text: Another reason to pause before imposing mandates on airlines is that new technology may soon make it easier to follow planes anywhere in the world.

site_title: Need to give more restructuring support to SMEs in 2015 (Amended)
summary: Singapore's small and medium enterprises (SMEs) continue to struggle with productivity and innovation due to a competitive business environment and rising costs. Despite economic restructuring efforts, SMEs are focusing on immediate needs rather than investing in long-term growth. The lack of productivity balance has led to ongoing struggles for many SMEs, which have not recovered from the restructuring pain.

site_title: Asia traders mull over storing gasoil, petrol on tankers
summary: Asia oil product traders are considering storing gasoil and petrol on tankers due to oversupply, weak demand, and low crude prices. This move may lead to higher prices for the fuels in two to three months. The decision is driven by cheap crude oil encouraging refineries to maximize throughput and new competition from Middle Eastern capacity in Europe and Africa.

site_title: Merkel urges EU parliaments to ratify Singapore trade deal
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel urged EU lawmakers to expedite ratification of the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA), which needs to be ratified by the European Parliament. The deal, concluded in October, includes investor protection clauses criticized by Germany for undermining labor, environment, and food standards. Merkel emphasized it's in Europe's interests to push through the ratification process quickly, as the EU is the largest contributor of foreign direct investment in Singapore, and the deal is seen as a stepping stone to similar agreements with other southeast Asian economies.

site_title: Tokyo-listed JTrust accepts offer for its LCD Global shares
summary: JTrust Co, a Tokyo-listed company, has accepted a voluntary conditional cash offer from AF Global to sell its 29.5% stake in LCD Global Investments. The decision was made due to concerns over LCD's management instability and the favourable offer conditions. The sale is expected to generate a gain of approximately 1 billion yen (S$11.5 million) for JTrust. As a result, LCD's shares closed 2.9% lower at S$0.34.

site_title: Poll forecasts slowest growth in 5 years for Indonesia
summary: Indonesia is expected to experience its slowest economic growth in five years in 2014, with a forecasted 5.07% expansion, down from 5.78% in 2013. Political uncertainties, declining commodity prices, and rising domestic fuel prices have contributed to the slowdown. Exports and imports contracted in 2014, and analysts predict conditions will improve this year with reforms under President Joko Widodo. However, concerns over the current account deficit and volatility in the rupiah remain.

site_title: Manufacturing in Singapore off to a weak start in 2015
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector started 2015 on a weak note, with the PMI signaling a second consecutive month of contraction in January. The index rose to 49.9 from 49.6 in December, still below the 50-point threshold. Shrinking new orders and inventory cited as primary factors, economists expect a tepid outlook in the coming months.

site_title: Continental says oil production, reserves spiked in 2014
summary: Continental Resources Inc, the second-largest North Dakota oil producer, reported a 28% increase in oil production and a 20% increase in total reserves to 1.35 billion barrels of oil equivalent in 2014. Despite declining crude oil prices, the company reached a daily production milestone of 200,000 barrels of oil equivalent in late December. CEO Harold Hamm attributed the growth to the company's expansion into Oklahoma's SCOOP shale formation, calling it "one of the best new plays in North America."

site_title: Insurers must use QE wisely to gird for correction: watchdog
summary: The European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA) warns that European insurers must use the time gained from the European Central Bank's quantitative easing (QE) program to prepare for an inevitable market correction. EIOPA's executive director, Carlos Montalvo, advises insurers to use the extra time wisely and assess risks in their investment portfolios. Insurers are under pressure to invest in infrastructure projects to generate stable income, but many small insurers lack the capability to properly assess risks. EIOPA aims to develop criteria for infrastructure investments by September.

site_title: Lew says economy enters self-sustaining phase as budget debated
summary: Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew stated the US economy has entered a self-sustaining growth phase, with projections of stronger growth than other advanced economies. President Barack Obama's $4 trillion fiscal proposal aims to raise taxes, invest in infrastructure, and housing, stabilizing but not eliminating the budget deficit. Lew urged Congress to build on this progress, warning against further sequestration cuts. The proposal includes $2.1 trillion in new revenue over 10 years, with a 19% minimum tax on foreign earnings and a new fee on large financial firms to discourage excessive borrowing.

site_title: JPMorgan to pay US$500m in mortgage settlement
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has agreed to pay US$500 million to settle class action litigation over the sale of defective mortgage securities by Bear Stearns in 2006-2007. The settlement resolves claims that Bear misled investors about underwriting guidelines and property appraisals. JPMorgan denied wrongdoing, but agreed to pay an additional US$5 million for administration costs. This settlement is separate from JPMorgan's 2013 US$13 billion settlement with regulators over mortgage securities sales.

site_title: GuocoLand raises S$170m through bond issuances
summary: GuocoLand Ltd raised S$170 million through two bond issuances, a 2.5-year bond at 3.60% and a 5-year bond at 4.20%. The dual-tranche offering received strong demand, with the final order book closing at S$750 million. This is GuocoLand's first dual-tranche transaction since 2013 and its second SGD bond issuance. The positive market reception indicates the SGD bond market remains favorable for established issuers with suitable terms and structures.

site_title: Rolls-Royce unveils service centre in Singapore
summary: Rolls-Royce has launched its first Customer Service Centre (CSC) in Singapore, providing regional support to customers in the Asia-Pacific region. The centre, located at the Rolls-Royce Seletar Campus, will serve over 20 airline customers and offer operational support, local expertise, and engineering decision-making capability. The centre is part of a network of five CSCs, covering Asia-Pacific, the Americas, Europe, Greater China, and the Middle East and Africa, with more than 50 staff trained by the end of 2015.

site_title: Trucks, SUVs drive US vehicle sales in January
summary: US vehicle sales in January exceeded expectations, driven by low gasoline prices and easy credit terms, with trucks and SUVs accounting for 69% of sales. General Motors, Ford, and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles reported strong sales, with Ford selling a record 54,370 F-series pickups and GM's full-size pickups increasing 22%. Toyota and Nissan also topped expectations, while Honda narrowly missed projections.

site_title: Sino Construction unit in renewable energy venture
summary: Sino Construction's wholly owned subsidiary, Magnum Energy, has entered a joint-venture agreement with Primeforth Special Situation Fund to establish Magnum Modular Power Generation, a company generating and selling electricity from renewable energy sources, starting with palm biofuel. The JV will be incorporated in Singapore with S$1 million of issued and paid-up shares, 70% owned by Magnum Energy and 30% by Primeforth. The agreement is expected to have minimal financial impact on Sino Construction.

site_title: US spirits sales rise in 2014 on strong growth in whiskey and bourbon
summary: US spirits sales rose 4% to $23.1 billion in 2014, driven by strong growth in brown liquors such as bourbon and whiskey. Bourbon and Tennessee whiskey volumes increased 7.4%, while Irish whiskey and single malt scotch rose 9.1% and 6.4% respectively. Vodka sales volumes rose 3.7%, but overall vodka is facing slower growth as newer generations prefer bourbon and whiskey. The Distilled Spirits Council also reported a slight increase in market share versus beer for the fifth straight year.

site_title: Obama administration urges Congress to focus on business tax reform
summary: The Obama administration urged Congress to focus on business tax reform, proposing a potential overhaul of the business tax code. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew suggested bipartisan cooperation, but Republican lawmakers, including committee chair Paul Ryan, expressed skepticism, arguing the proposal did not do enough to help small businesses. The proposal includes raising taxes on the wealthy and international companies to increase spending in areas like highways and education. A bipartisan deal on business tax reform appears unlikely given the Republican-controlled Congress.

site_title: Inclusion the way to tackle income inequality
summary: Income inequality is a pressing issue, but the traditional approach of redistribution may not be effective. Inclusive growth, which focuses on investing in skills and connecting people to inputs and networks, is a more promising solution. However, poor countries face challenges in connecting all places to all inputs, leading to unequal development. The problem of distributing income generated by complementary inputs also arises, with teams and value chains creating a surplus that can be captured by those with market power. To address this, policies should focus on owning or taxing inputs that capture the surplus, rather than relying solely on redistribution, which may fail to benefit either inclusion or growth.

site_title: Greek forced to surrender 500,000 euros at Cyprus customs
summary: Authorities in Cyprus have confiscated 500,000 euros (US$571,450) from a Greek businessman attempting to leave the island with the cash after Cypriot banks refused to accept it. The businessman claimed banks had refused to accept the cash due to lack of documentation, but it was found in his possession as he was leaving. The confiscation is part of an ongoing investigation.

site_title: Barcelona president named as suspect in US$107m Neymar deal
summary: Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu is named as a suspect in an investigation into tax evasion related to the $107 million signing of Brazilian soccer player Neymar. A Spanish judge ordered Bartomeu to attend a hearing and for the club and tax agency to hand over documents. Prosecutor Jose Perals alleges the club failed to withhold taxes on income paid to Neymar's parents, totaling $3.2 million. Barcelona denies any wrongdoing and claims it received tax advice throughout the process.

site_title: Thai PTT to sell 15% stake in oil refiner Bangchak to state fund
summary: Thai PTT, the country's largest energy firm, agreed to sell 15% of its stake in oil refiner Bangchak Petroleum to state investment fund Vayupak. The deal is worth at least 10 billion baht (US$306 million) and aims to reduce criticism of PTT's monopoly. PTT plans to sell the remaining 12.22% stake to interested investors, with potential buyers including oil retailers SUSCO PCL and PTG Energy PCL. The sale is part of PTT's strategy to diversify its interests and address concerns from political lobby groups.

site_title: US factory orders fall sharply, decline broad-based
summary: US factory orders fell 3.4% in December for the fifth straight month, a decline that's broad-based across industries. Demand for manufactured goods dropped, with a 1.7% decrease in November's revised orders. Economists had forecast a 2.2% drop. Business spending on equipment in the fourth quarter was the weakest since 2009, and the labor dispute at West Coast ports has hampered factory activity. Despite this, there's cautious optimism that firming domestic demand will limit the slowdown in manufacturing.

site_title: Billionaire Lundin bets on copper rebound with boost at top mine
summary: Billionaire Lundin's mining company, Lundin Mining Corp, is boosting drilling at its top copper mine, Candelaria, betting on a copper price rebound from six-year lows. CEO Paul Conibear expects copper to reach $3 a pound this year, driven by looming mine shortages. Lundin aims to maintain company-wide output rates over the next five years despite projected production drops. The company's family has a history of investing at market lows, and Lundin is also expanding its gold and oil operations, including a major acquisition in Ecuador.

site_title: High chance of further euro weakness from political developments
summary: The European Central Bank's asset purchase program, set to start next month, is facing uncertainty due to Greece's refusal to engage with the international "troika" of creditors. This refusal may lead to a shortage of prime government paper in the euro area, causing capital to flow into top-rated government bonds. German bond prices have risen, making the Bundesbank cautious about buying such paper. Greece's newly appointed finance minister, Yanis Varoufakis, is on a European tour to set out the Athens government's economic strategy, which includes a four-month cooling off period for debt restructuring. This approach is likely to pose challenges for the German government and the ECB, potentially leading to further euro weakness.

site_title: Eu Yan Sang Q2 net profit down 38%
summary: Eu Yan Sang reported a 38% drop in Q2 net profit to S$1.98 million, largely due to the impact of the Occupy Central movement and a slowdown in Chinese tourist spending in Hong Kong. Revenue decreased 8% to S$84.69 million, with higher distribution and selling expenses contributing to the earnings decline. Shares closed unchanged at S$0.76. The company attributed the results to a shorter period leading up to Chinese New Year in its core markets.

site_title: Gold slips as risk appetite boosts financial markets
summary: Gold prices fell 0.5% to $1,268.90 an ounce, following a rally in stock markets as risk appetite increased. The Greek government's proposal to swap foreign debt for growth-linked bonds reduced investor concerns, leading to a decline in gold prices. European shares rose 1% and US stock index futures climbed, with expectations of a deal on Greek debt. Gold prices rose 8% in January, but were kept in check by expectations of a US interest rate increase.

site_title: BP Chief: No hope of US$100 oil for a 'long time' as stocks build
summary: BP CEO Bob Dudley says there's no hope of reaching a $100 oil price for a long time due to a global glut of crude oil. This sentiment echoes the 1986 oil price slump, which didn't recover until Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990. Dudley predicts prices may stay below $60 for three years, contradicting predictions from Eni CEO Claudio Descalzi and Opec Secretary-General Abdalla El-Badri. The industry is responding to the glut by cutting spending, with BP pledging to cut $2 billion in planned spending.

site_title: Czech central bank won't move FX cap but keep it for longer: poll
summary: The Czech central bank (CNB) will maintain its exchange rate cap of 27 per euro, despite speculation it may be lowered due to deflationary pressures. A Reuters poll shows 12 out of 13 analysts believe the cap will not be raised before the policy exits in 2016. Deflationary pressures, combined with falling oil and food prices, are expected to keep the policy in place longer than initially planned. The bank's inflation forecast is expected to show prices falling in coming months and recovering more slowly than previously expected.

site_title: Twitter expands promoted tweet advertising to outside websites
summary: Twitter is expanding its promoted tweet advertising to outside websites, including Flipboard and Yahoo Japan, starting with a revenue-sharing model. This move aims to capitalize on tweets being seen 185 billion times on non-Twitter websites, as the company seeks to bolster its revenue prospects. Promoted Tweets will appear on these platforms, with Twitter sharing ad revenue with the sites. The expansion follows Twitter's efforts to distribute its ads more widely and follows CEO Dick Costolo's promise to monetize the platform's "rich canvas" of tweets.

site_title: EU capital market reforms won't unleash wave of new rules: Hill
summary: European Union financial services commissioner Jonathan Hill said the bloc's capital markets union plans won't lead to a wave of new rules, contradicting fears from banks and policymakers. The CMU aims to reduce reliance on banks for funding and boost jobs and growth. Hill's comments come as Brussels seeks to create a more integrated market, cutting banks' influence and increasing access to capital for companies and start-ups.

site_title: Italy's Renzi to resign as formality to new president, seen re-instated immediately
summary: Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi announced his resignation as a formality to new President Sergio Mattarella, who was sworn in earlier. Renzi is expected to be immediately re-instated due to the president's role in appointing prime ministers. This practice is common, allowing standing prime ministers to step down and be re-appointed by the new head of state.

site_title: SAP launches biggest software product overhaul in two decades
summary: SAP has launched its biggest software product overhaul in two decades, introducing S4 HANA, a unified database platform that promises to cut business data-crunching times to minutes. The new system combines an in-memory database with business analysis functions, allowing for real-time financial planning and analysis. The move aims to boost SAP's cloud-based Internet software sales and fend off rivals, with thousands of customers already using the system. Analysts predict exponential improvements in data-crunching times and a potential shift towards cloud-based software delivery.

site_title: EU policy-makers seek to make electric transport a 'priority'
summary: The European Commission is urging policymakers to prioritize electric vehicles in the EU's energy union strategy, citing their potential to reduce dependence on fossil fuels and decrease emissions from transport. The proposal, outlined in a discussion paper, aims to integrate electric vehicles into urban mobility policies and the electricity grid. Environmental groups and business interests, including major utilities, support the move, which could lead to increased investment in renewable energy sources and improved cross-border energy links.

site_title: Russian central bank considers further relaxation of banking sector regulation
summary: The Russian central bank is considering further relaxing banking sector regulation to alleviate pressure from Western sanctions and an economic slowdown. The bank is looking to temporarily relax rules on consumer loan risk calculations, which have led to increased costs for Russian banks. This move aims to ease the burden on banks and restore their access to Western markets.

site_title: Ferrari introduces a turbo engine in the new, efficient 488 GTB
summary: Ferrari unveiled the 2016 488 GTB, its first turbocharged production car since the 1970s. The 3.9-liter V8 supercar boasts 660 horsepower and 560 pounds-feet of torque, reaching 205mph and 0-60mph in 3 seconds. The new model is lighter, cleaner, and quicker than its predecessor, the 458 Italia, and sets a new record for efficiency in a street-legal Ferrari. The 488 GTB will debut at the Geneva Motor Show in March and go on sale in the US during the second half of 2015, priced to be announced.

site_title: Biggest FX trader in Scandinavia says Danish krone is overvalued
summary: SEB AB, Scandinavia's largest foreign-currency trader, has stated that the Danish krone is overvalued, contrary to Denmark's efforts to defend its peg to the euro. According to SEB's analysis, the Danish krone's fair value is closer to 8 against the euro, not the current peg of 7.46038. This contradicts Denmark's trade and current account surpluses, which normally support an undervalued currency. SEB's chief FX strategist, Johan Javeus, warns that Denmark's efforts to defend its peg may lead to a drop in the currency's value.

site_title: Obama to announce data collection modifications: NYT
